Ltd</SortTitle><SortDate>2009-07-01T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 48/2006, SUM 1498/2009</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" Ling (Rajah &amp; Tann LLP) for the respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Injunctions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Creditor applying to vary injunction on ground that Escrow Sum in excess of claim of debtor</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether court had power to vary injunction on ground of material change in circumstances</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2300\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Injunctions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2313\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Purposes for grant</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2318\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Restraint of proceedings</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Debtor obtained injunction restraining creditor from winding up debtor on ground that debtor had cross-claim</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Cross-claim secured by Escrow Sum held in Claims Escrow Account to meet claims of debtor under sales transaction</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Escrow Sum to be released only upon joint written instructions of parties</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">1\u00a0July\u00a02009</p>\n</td>\n<td width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">Judgment reserved.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\">Chan Sek Keong CJ (delivering the judgment of the court):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Introduction</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_1\"/>1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This application in Summons No\u00a01498 of 2009 is a sequel to the decision of this court in Civil Appeal No\u00a048 of 2006 (\u201cCA\u00a048\u201d) (see <em>Metalform Asia Pte Ltd v Holland Leedon Pte Ltd</em> <nobr>[2007] 2 SLR 268</nobr> (\u201cthe Judgment\u201d)) to grant an injunction to Metalform Asia Pte Ltd (\u201cMA\u201d), restraining Holland Leedon Pte Ltd (\u201cHL\u201d) from commencing winding-up proceedings against MA for an unpaid and undisputed debt on the ground that MA had a genuine cross-claim against HL which could equal or exceed the undisputed debt.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_2\"/>2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The present application by HL seeks the following relief:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">That the injunction granted by [this court] in [CA\u00a048] be varied such that its continuation shall be conditional upon [MA] agreeing to the release of the sum of US$5,254,877.97 (as at 25\u00a0March 2009) to [HL] from the Claims Escrow Account [<em>ie</em>, the account into which a sum of S$25m was deposited as security] held by Allen &amp; Gledhill LL[P] pursuant to a Claims Escrow Letter dated 13\u00a0June 2004.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">As the injunction granted by this court was to restrain HL from presenting a winding-up petition against MA, it is evident from the relief sought in the application that HL is not really seeking to vary the injunction as such, but the basis on which, or the factors that led, the court to grant the injunction.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Background facts</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_3\"/>3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The background facts to the present application are fully set out in the Judgment. In summary, the parties had entered into a sale and purchase agreement dated 13\u00a0June 2004 (which was later amended) (\u201cthe SPA\u201d), pursuant to which MA purchased the business and assets of HL for the sum of about US$267m. Of that sum, a US-dollar equivalent of S$25m (\u201cthe Escrow Sum\u201d) was paid pursuant to the terms of the SPA to Allen &amp; Gledhill LLP (\u201cthe Escrow Agent\u201d) to hold as security to meet any claims by MA for breach of warranties by HL. Any such claim had to be made by 30\u00a0September 2005, failing which the Escrow Sum would be released to HL.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_4\"/>4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A letter from MA and HL dated 13\u00a0June 2004 (\u201cthe Escrow Letter\u201d) and addressed to the Escrow Agent sets out the terms on which the Escrow Sum would be held and released. Paragraph\u00a02.1.5 of the Escrow Letter provides as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[I]f [HL] admits all or any part of the Amount Claimed or there is a determination of the amount payable in respect of the Relevant Claim by a final arbitral award made pursuant to clause\u00a021 of the [SPA], the Escrow Agent shall pay to [MA] the amount so admitted or determined (in the latter case less any money previously paid under paragraph\u00a02.1.4 in respect of the Relevant Claim) out of the amount standing to the credit of the Claims Escrow Account in accordance with the joint written instructions of [MA] and [HL] pursuant to paragraph\u00a02.3.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_5\"/>5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0On 28\u00a0September 2005, MA made a warranty claim against HL which was quantified at S$34,472,740. In December 2005, MA commenced arbitration proceedings against HL (\u201cthe Arbitration\u201d). Based on its current pleadings in the Arbitration, MA is claiming a sum of at least S$30,993,960.18 plus interest and costs.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_6\"/>6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Prior to this date, HL had served a statutory demand on MA under s\u00a0254(2)(<em>a</em>) of the Companies Act (Cap\u00a050, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed) requiring MA to pay an undisputed debt of US$11,100,206.60 and S$112,667.17 (\u201cthe Undisputed Debt\u201d) in respect of steel supplied by HL to MA between July 2004 and June 2005. In response, MA applied for an injunction in Originating Summons No\u00a01996 of 2005 to restrain HL from commencing winding-up proceedings against MA on the basis that MA had a genuine cross-claim against HL for damages in excess of the Undisputed Debt for breach of warranties under the SPA, and that the commencement of the winding-up proceedings would cause irreparable damage to MA which had an ongoing business. The High Court dismissed MA\u2019s application. MA appealed to this court which allowed the appeal and granted the injunction. This court found, <em>inter alia</em>, that MA had a genuine cross-claim against HL which might or might not be less than S$34m and that the security of S$25m for the cross-claim did not reduce the amount of the cross-claim and could not be treated as payment of the cross-claim. Accordingly, until the cross-claim was decided in the Arbitration, it was not possible to conclude that MA\u2019s cross-claim was not equal to or in excess of the Undisputed Debt. Apart from the Undisputed Debt, there was also no evidence then that MA was insolvent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">HL\u2019s reasons for this application</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_7\"/>7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0HL\u2019s application is based on a material change in circumstances concerning, <em>inter alia</em>, the amount claimed by MA in the Arbitration and its financial condition. HL has made the following points in support of this application:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_7-p2_a\"/>(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Even if MA were to succeed in the Arbitration with respect to its cross-claim currently assessed at S$30,993,960.18, there would be at least US$5,254,877.97 (\u201cthe Balance Sum\u201d) left of the Escrow Sum, without taking into account the accrued interest to the Escrow Sum, after the Undisputed Debt has been set off against the cross-claim. (This is not disputed by MA.)</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_7-p2_b\"/>(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0MA is now insolvent as its total liabilities exceed its total assets by US$236,527,949 as at 30\u00a0June 2006, and by US$241,365.691 as at 30\u00a0June 2007, and MA has been unable to pay all moneys owing to and demanded by its bankers since October 2006. (Again, MA has not disputed this statement, except to say that the bank creditors have not taken any step to wind it up.)</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_7-p2_c\"/>(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0MA has agreed that it would set off any recovery for its warranty claim against the Undisputed Debt first, which would thereby leave the Balance Sum in the escrow account held by the Escrow Agent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_7-p2_d\"/>(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0At the hearing before the High Court and the Court of Appeal on MA\u2019s application for the injunction, MA had offered to agree to the release of the sum of S$10m from the Escrow Sum to notionally equalise the cross-claim with the Undisputed Debt. There is no reason why, with the change in circumstances, MA should not agree, or be ordered by this court to agree, to the release of the Balance Sum to HL.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Essentially, HL\u2019s reason for the present application is that it is wholly unjust and inequitable that HL be deprived of its right to immediate payment of the Balance Sum, and that this court should therefore grant its application. It bears noting that the Escrow Sum belongs to HL as it was part of the sale consideration under the SPA, although it is currently held by the Escrow Agent to meet MA\u2019s warranty claim which is the subject of the Arbitration.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_8\"/>8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0HL has argued that the court has inherent jurisdiction to set aside an injunction, whether perpetual or interlocutory, should it become appropriate to do so, citing I\u00a0C\u00a0F\u00a0Spry, <em>The Principles of Equitable Remedies: Specific Performance, Injunctions, Rectification and Equitable Damages</em> (Lawbook Co, 7th\u00a0Ed, 2007) at p\u00a0382. HL contends that the present case is an appropriate one for this court to vary the injunction it has granted.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">MA\u2019s objections</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_9\"/>9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0MA\u2019s position is that this court may not, and in any event should not, grant HL\u2019s application for the following reasons:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_9-p2_a\"/>(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The injunction granted by this court is the result of a final judgment, and this court is <em>functus officio</em> in the matter, according to <em>Singapore Court Practice 2006</em> (Jeffrey Pinsler gen ed) (LexisNexis, 2006) at para\u00a042/1/9, and also <em>Godfrey Gerald QC v UBS AG</em> <nobr>[2004] 4 SLR 411</nobr>. Counsel for MA accepts the principle that a court has power to clarify or to make consequential or incidental orders in relation to a final judgment, but submits that HL\u2019s application is not such a case. MA also contends that there is in fact no change in circumstances as alleged by HL, but even if there were, it would not be a ground to vary the final judgment. Furthermore, MA contends that there is no change in the circumstances that have led this court to grant the injunction against HL.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_9-p2_b\"/>(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Even if this court has the power to vary the judgment, HL is estopped from seeking a variation as the release of the Balance Sum was an issue which could have, and so ought to have, been raised at the hearing of CA\u00a048 (see <em>Singapore Court Practice 2006</em> at para\u00a018/19/14, pp\u00a0466\u2013467 and the authorities cited therein). The issue of the release of the Escrow Sum was raised by the parties and considered by this court in the context of HL\u2019s argument that the Escrow Sum of S$25m had reduced MA\u2019s claim of about S$34m to about S$9m, thereby causing MA\u2019s cross-claim against HL to be reduced to less than the Undisputed Debt. In view of this argument, MA was prepared to agree to the release of the sum of S$9m (or S$10m as computed by this court) in order to equalise the cross-claim and the Undisputed Debt (with the consequence that HL would not be able to justify commencing winding-up proceedings against MA). HL rejected this offer. However, this court went on to hold that as the Escrow Sum was held as security, it could not constitute payment, and therefore there could be no reduction in the amount of the warranty claim in fact and in law.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_9-p2_c\"/>(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Whether or not HL is entitled to the release of the Escrow Sum or any part thereof before the final determination of MA\u2019s warranty claim is a question which properly ought to be referred to arbitration in accordance with the terms of cl\u00a021 of the SPA and the terms of the Escrow Letter. In any event, this court ought not to interfere with a matter which has been referred to arbitration, following <em>NCC International AB v Alliance Concrete Singapore Pte Ltd</em> <nobr>[2008] 2 SLR 565</nobr>, which held that the court\u2019s jurisdiction in matters that have been referred to arbitration was limited, and that it would not intervene in any matter which had been referred to arbitration unless the arbitral tribunal had no jurisdiction to grant the relief in the matter at hand.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_9-p2_d\"/>(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Balance Sum does not accurately represent the sum that would remain of the Escrow Sum if MA were to succeed in its entire warranty claim as MA is also claiming unliquidated damages and interest thereon, and until the claims are finally determined in the Arbitration, it would not be known how much would be left of the Escrow Sum.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Our decision</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_10\"/>10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We do not propose to examine in detail any of the grounds or reasons which HL has given to justify this application or any of the arguments advanced by MA by way of rebuttal, as HL\u2019s application is misconceived. In our view, it is clear from para\u00a02.1.5 of the Escrow Letter (see <a href=\"#p1_4\">[4]</a> above) that, unless it has been jointly instructed in writing by MA and HL, the Escrow Agent has no obligation to release the Escrow Sum or any part thereof. This is simply a matter of contract between the parties and the Escrow Agent and the court has no power to order the Escrow Agent to release the Escrow Sum or any part thereof to either HL or MA unless the Escrow Agent is in breach of its obligations as an escrow agent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_11\"/>11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0HL has contended that the injunction should be varied as MA has agreed to set off any recovery for its warranty claim against the Undisputed Debt first, which would thereby leave the Balance Sum in the escrow account held by the Escrow Agent. However, HL has not argued that MA\u2019s agreement in this respect amounted to a variation of the terms of the escrow arrangement under the SPA that obliges MA, as a matter of contract, to agree to the release of the Balance Sum from the Escrow Sum. Even if that were the case, this court would not have the jurisdiction to hear such a claim. HL would have to commence separate proceedings against MA to enforce its contractual rights.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_12\"/>12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0HL is ostensibly asking this court to vary the injunction to make it conditional upon MA agreeing to the release of the Balance Sum to HL. However, in truth, it is not so much an application to vary an injunction but an attempt to entreat the court\u2019s assistance to order MA to agree to the release of the Balance Sum against the latter\u2019s wishes. The injunction granted by this court was to restrain HL from commencing winding-up proceedings against MA. The court has the power to dissolve or revoke this injunction where there is a material change of circumstances affecting its continuance, for example, where HL can produce evidence to show that MA is insolvent, which entitles HL to file an application to wind up MA. HL has not done so, although its counsel has stated that it is something that HL will seriously consider. But whether HL is entitled to have the existing injunction revoked is an issue which we need not consider as it is not before us.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_13\"/>13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It may well be that, looking at the matter in the round, it may not seem fair or equitable to HL, as it claims, for it to be kept out of its money in the present situation where it is certain, or at least highly probable, that HL would be entitled to payment out of the Balance Sum when MA\u2019s warranty claim is finally determined in the Arbitration. However, in our view, that is not a relevant consideration because it is a natural outcome of HL\u2019s bargain with MA. HL has no equitable basis upon which it can complain. Indeed, it can even be said that the predicament that HL is now in is of its own making. In the previous proceedings, MA had offered to agree to the release of S$10m from the Escrow Sum to HL, but HL rejected it because it was of the view that it had good grounds to wind up MA. Unfortunately for HL, this court did not agree, and now HL is placed as a supplicant <em>vis-\u00e0-vis</em> MA for the release of the Balance Sum.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_14\"/>14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0MA has argued that this court has no power to vary the injunction as it is a final order and not an interlocutory order, as contended by HL. It is not necessary for us to decide on this issue for the disposition of this application. In our view, the injunction is in substance a final and not an interlocutory injunction in the sense that it was the only relief that was sought in the proceedings, and was not a relief granted as part of ongoing proceedings. It is, however, a provisional order in that, if the basis of the injunction disappears or can no longer support it, such as if the arbitrator made an award on MA\u2019s cross-claim that is less than the Undisputed Debt to HL, there would be nothing to prevent HL from issuing another statutory notice to MA to pay the amount outstanding, failing which it would be entitled to take proceedings to wind up MA.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_15\"/>15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0MA has also contended that HL is estopped from raising this issue since the issue was argued by the parties and considered by the court in the previous proceedings. In our view, issue estoppel does not apply because there was no issue before the court in the previous proceedings which required the court\u2019s decision. MA\u2019s offer to agree to the release of S$10m from the Escrow Sum was within its contractual right and the rejection of the offer was also within the contractual right of HL. Nevertheless, HL has not been able to point out to us any principle of law that the court has the power to vary the existing injunction by imposing a condition on MA such as to interfere with its bargain with HL as to how and when the Escrow Sum should be paid. In fact, HL recognises the court\u2019s lack of judicial power to vary the injunction, as HL is not applying to have the injunction varied, but is persuading the court to order MA to agree to the release of the Balance Sum to HL as a condition for continuing the injunction.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_16\"/>16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The issue can be considered from another perspective. The application is to vary a final injunction to a conditional injunction (<em>ie</em>, conditional upon MA agreeing to the release of the Balance Sum to HL). Suppose MA does not perform the condition, what follows then? Presumably, the injunction would not continue, <em>ie</em>, it would be discharged. But, if it had that effect, it would be contrary to the purpose of the existing injunction, which is to restrain HL from winding up MA because HL has not been able to prove that MA is unable to pay its debt to HL.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_17\"/>17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We therefore agree with the general submission of counsel for MA that the circumstances in which this court granted the injunction have not changed. The Escrow Sum is still held as security for the cross-claim which has yet to be determined in the Arbitration. The Escrow Agent cannot release any part of the Escrow Sum to HL without the joint written instructions of HL and MA. This court could not interfere in the previous proceedings, and cannot interfere now, with the escrow arrangements between the parties. Although HL may consider it unjust that MA is now grossly over-secured with respect to its cross-claim, that, however, is a contingency inherent in any arrangement where security is given for an unliquidated claim which itself is also based on a contingency. The fact is that HL agreed to provide the Escrow Sum and it cannot now complain that it has provided too much.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Conclusion</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_18\"/>18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the above reasons, we dismiss HL\u2019s application with costs and the usual consequential orders.</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta    <CaseTitle>Ching Mun Fong (executrix of the estate of Tan Geok Tee, deceased) v Liu Cho Chit (No 2)</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Ching Mun Fong (executrix of the estate of Tan Geok Tee, deceased) v Liu can and should be imposed</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>dismissed Fook Gees claim for the repayment of the alleged loan. However, the she gave judgment\n\nfor Madam Lim against Lee Tat, for the balance of the purchase price.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The matter was taken to the Court of Appeal, which delivered its judgment on 6\n\nFebruary 1998. The Court of Appeal dismissed Fook Gees appeal. However, the appeal by Lee Tat was\n\nallowed, on the ground that Madam Lim never had any interest in the joint venture site, and\n\nconsequently had no interest in the Property which she could sell.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">On 4 June 1998, Madam Ching, as executrix of Mr Tans estate, commenced the\n\npresent proceedings against Mr Liu seeking to recover the sum of $1,368,420.71 (being the equivalent\n\nof US$642,451.04 at the agreed rate of exchange at the time of payment to Mr Liu) as money had and\n\nreceived, on the ground that the US$642,451.04 was paid to Mr Liu under a mistaken assumption that\n\nMadam Lim had an interest in the Property. After further litigation, Madam Ching managed to amend\n\nher statement of claim to include a claim for a remedial constructive trust.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The trial judge dismissed Madam Chings claims on two grounds. Firstly, it was\n\nheld that the true contracting parties in the sale of Madam Lims alleged interest to Lee Tat was\n\nMadam Lim (as the purported vendor) and Lee Tat (as the purported purchaser). As such, any action\n\nfor money paid under a mistake ought to have been brought by Lee Tat against Madam Lim. Mr Tans\n\nestate was not the proper plaintiff, and Mr Liu was not the proper defendant. Secondly, the trial\n\njudge held that in any case, the claim was time barred, and no remedial constructive trust arose.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Madam Ching thus brought the present appeal. On the question of the proper\n\nparties to the action, Madam Ching argued that the true contracting party to the joint venture was\n\nMr Liu, and that Madam Ching was purportedly conveyed the joint venture site as Mr Lius nominee.\n\nAs such, any interest in the joint venture site (and consequently in the Property) was supposed to\n\nhave been vested in Mr Liu. Conversely, when Lee Tat contracted to purchase the interest in the\n\nProperty from Mr Liu, it did so as Mr Tans nominee. Madam Ching thus contended that the true\n\ncontracting parties in the purported sale of Madam Lims interest in the Property to Lee Tat were\n\nactually Mr Liu and Mr Tan, so that the parties were properly constituted for the present action.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">With regards to the issue of time bar, Madam Ching contended that the mistaken\n\nassumption that Madam Lim had an interest in the Property was discovered only on 6 February 1998,\n\nwhen the Court of Appeal pronounced its judgment. Madam Ching therefore claimed that the limitation\n\nperiod began to run only as of that date, so her claim was not time-barred. Alternatively, Madam\n\nChing argued that when the Court of Appeal pronounced its judgment on 6 February 1998, Mr Liu could\n\nno longer retain the monies without his conscience being affected. She thus contended that the\n\nmonies became impressed with a remedial constructive trust as of 6 February 1998.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Held</p></b>, dismissing the appeal:\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) The true contracting parties were Mr Tan and Mr Liu and nobody else. (\n\n  22-25). Madam Ching as the executrix of the estate of Mr Tan, was thus entitled to bring this\n\n  action against Mr Liu for the recovery of the sum paid to him. The proper parties were before the\n\n  court ( 26).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) The trial judge was correct in holding that the six year limitation period\n\n  found in s 6(1)(a) of the Limitation Act applied to Madam Chings claim ( 27). However, if the\n\n  monies sought to be recovered were paid under a mistake, then by virtue of s 29(1)(c) of the\n\n  Limitation Act, the limitation period would begin to run only as of the time when the mistake\n\n  could have been discovered ( 28).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) The contention that the mistake underlying the payment could not have been\n\n  discovered until the Court of Appeal delivered its decision on 6 February 1998 was rejected (\n\n  29). In the 1984 action brought by Madam Lim, Mr Tan asserted in his affidavit, filed on 1\n\n  February 1989, that Madam Lim had no interest in the Property. Thus, as of 1 February 1989, if not\n\n  earlier, he had already discovered the mistake. Even if the limitation period was postponed by\n\n  virtue of s 29(1)(c) of the Limitation Act, the time bar would have set in by 1\u00a0February\n\n  1995, at the latest ( 30). Section\u00a029(1)(c) of the Limitation Act states quite clearly that\n\n  time begins to run once the plaintiff could with reasonable diligence have discovered the\n\n  mistake. As far as s 29(1)(c) is concerned, it is the plaintiffs means of ascertaining the\n\n  mistake, and not what the court eventually decides, that is relevant in determining when the\n\n  limitation period begins to run ( 32).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(4) A remedial constructive trust arises where the court imposes a constructive\n\n  trust de novo on assets which are not subject to any pre-existing trust as a means of granting\n\n  equitable relief in a case where it considers just that restitution should be made ( 34). In\n\n  order for a remedial constructive trust to arise, the payees conscience must have been\n\n  affected, while the monies in question still remain with him. If the payee learns of the mistake\n\n  only after the monies have got mixed with other funds or dissipated, no constructive trust in\n\n  respect of these monies can arise. This is because there would no longer be an identifiable fund\n\n  for the trust to bite ( 36).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(5) On the facts of this case, there was no ground for imposing a remedial\n\n  constructive trust on Mr Liu in respect of the US$642,451.04 paid to him. The relationship between\n\n  Mr Liu and Mr Tan was only that of a vendor and purchaser and was wholly commercial. There was no\n\n  dishonest conduct on the part of Mr Liu. The sum was paid to Mr Liu in April 1981 with the intent\n\n  that he was free to deal with it as his money. It was never intended by either Mr Tan or Mr Liu\n\n  that it should be kept, and it had never been kept, distinct as an identifiable fund. On the basis\n\n  of Mr Khoos contention that Mr Liu discovered the mistake only in February 1998 or thereabouts,\n\n  there was a span of some 17 years and the sum paid to Mr Liu must have, in the meanwhile, been\n\n  spent or mixed with other funds of Mr Liu. There was no sum or fund on which a remedy of\n\n  constructive trust could be imposed by the court. The sum paid to Mr Liu was certainly not trust\n\n  property. There was, of course, an obligation on the part of Mr Liu to return the monies to Mr\n\n  Tan, but that was only a personal obligation ( 37).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Case(s) referred to</p>\n\n</b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Kleinwort, Sons &amp; Co v Dunlop Rubber Co </p></i>(1907) 97 LT 263 (refd)\n\n<i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Metal Und Rohstoff A G v Donaldson Lufkin &amp; Jenerette Inc and Anor</p></i> [1990] 1 QB 391 (refd)\n\n<i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Westdeutsche Landesbank Gironzentrale v Islington London Borough County Council</p></i>\n\n[1996] AC 669 (refd)\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Legislation referred to</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed), ss 6(1)(a), 22(1), 29(1)(c)</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font face=\"Times New Roman\" color=\"#3322AA\" size=\"4\"><strong>JUDGMENT:</strong></font></p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><strong><font face=\"Times New Roman\" size=\"3\" color=\"#804040\">Grounds of Judgment</font></strong></p>\n\n<font face=\"Times New Roman\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\">1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against the decision of Woo Bih Li JC, in\n\nwhich he dismissed the claim of the appellant, Madam Ching Mun Fong (Madam Ching) suing as the\n\nexecutrix of the estate of Tan Geok Tee deceased (Mr Tan), against the respondent, Mr Liu Cho\n\nChit (Mr Liu) for the sum of $1,386,420.71 (being the equivalent of US$642,451.01 at the rate\n\nof exchange of S$2.13 to US$1) as money had and received. We dismissed the appeal and now give our\n\nreasons.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Background facts</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The material facts that led to this appeal stretch back to\n\nsome 27 years. The convenient starting point was 18\u00a0July 1972, when a company called Peng Ann\n\nRealty Pte Ltd (Peng Ann) purchased a large parcel of land situate at Kampong Chai Chee,\n\ncomprising lots 21-26, 4-4, 4-7, 112, 122, 123 and 221 of Mukim 28 having an area of 186.7 acres. At\n\nthat time, there were three shareholders of the company, and Mr Liu was one of them. He was also the\n\nmanaging director of the company. Two days after the sale and purchase agreement was made, there\n\nappeared in the government gazette a notification of compulsory acquisition by the government of two\n\nof the lots, namely, Lots 4-4 and 221. Being apprehensive of further compulsory acquisitions by the\n\ngovernment, Mr Liu and his co-directors decided to sell the remaining lots of land. In December\n\n1972, Mr Liu was introduced to Mr Tan, who was interested in purchasing the remaining lots.\n\nNegotiations took place between the two of them and eventually they reached an agreement. The\n\nagreement was signed on 23 January 1973, and it was made between Peng Ann and one of Mr Tans\n\nfamily companies, Lee Kai Investments Pte Ltd (Lee Kai) (then known as Collin Investment Pte\n\nLtd). Under the agreement, Peng Ann agreed to sell to Lee Kai three of the lots, namely, lots 21-26,\n\n4-7 and 123, having a total area of 178 acres, at the price of $2,050,000.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the meanwhile, Mr Tan and Mr Liu had orally agreed to\n\nenter into a joint venture to develop a small parcel of land containing an area of 5 acres, which\n\nwas within lot 21-26 and zoned residential (the joint venture site). The terms of this joint\n\nventure were subsequently reduced into four written agreements (collectively called the joint\n\nventure agreements). The agreement most material to the present appeal was the sub-sale agreement\n\nof the joint venture site expressed to be made between on the one hand Lee Kai, and on the other Mr\n\nLius wife, Madam Lim Siam Soi (Madam Lim), and Mr Tans daughter, Collin Tan (Collin).\n\nUnder this sub-sale agreement, Lee Kai agreed to sell the joint venture site to Madam Lim and Collin\n\nat the price of $50,000. The agreement was signed by Mr Tan on behalf of Lee Kai and Collin\n\nrespectively and by Mr Liu on behalf of Madam Lim. The other material joint venture agreements were\n\n(i) a pre-incorporation agreement, whereby Collin and Madam Lim agreed to incorporate a joint\n\nventure company, and (ii) a further sub-sale agreement, whereby Collin and Madam Lim agreed to\n\ntransfer to the joint venture company the joint venture site in exchange for shares to be issued by\n\nthat company to them respectively. These other agreements were also signed by Mr Tan on behalf of\n\nCollin and by Mr Liu on behalf of Madam Lim. However, neither Collin nor Madam Lim was aware of the\n\nagreements signed on their behalf or even of the joint venture itself.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The sale of the three lots, 21-26, 4-7 and 123, by Peng Ann\n\nto Lee Kai was completed on 14 March 1973, and the lots were conveyed, on the direction of Mr Tan\n\npresumably on behalf of Lee Kai, to another company of Mr Tan, called Lee Tat Development Pte Ltd (Lee\n\nTat) (then known as Collin Development Pte Ltd).</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 23 July 1976, these three lots, except a portion\n\ncontaining an area of 4.2 acres on Lot 21-26, were compulsorily acquired by the government. The\n\nunacquired land comprised: (i) a portion of 3.7 acres of the joint venture site, and (ii) another\n\nportion of about 21,808 sq ft of land, which was immediately adjoining the joint venture site and\n\nzoned rural and was also part of Lot 21-26. The entire area of the unacquired land was subsequently\n\nresurveyed and was described as resurvey Lot 1606 (the Property).</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As it transpired, the joint venture entered into between Mr\n\nTan and Mr Liu was not implemented. In particular, neither Mr Tan nor Mr Liu took any step to\n\nimplement or carry out the terms of any of the joint venture agreements. Nor did their respective\n\nnominees, Madam Lim and Collin. Among other things, the proposed joint venture company was never\n\nincorporated. In the result, the Property remained vested in Lee Tat and was never conveyed to Madam\n\nLim and Collin or the proposed joint venture company. To all intents and purposes, the joint venture\n\nwas abandoned.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was only in 1980 that Mr Tans and Mr Lius interests\n\nin developing the Property revived. In that year they appointed a firm of architects to draw up\n\nplans for the development of a housing project on the Property and planning approval was sought.\n\nHowever, the negotiations between Mr Tan and Mr Liu to develop the property did not lead to\n\nfruition, as they could not agree on the proposed development; each had in mind a different type of\n\ndevelopment.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 All this while, Mr Liu claimed that he or his wife, Madam\n\nLim, had an interest in the Property and he offered to sell this interest to Mr Tan. According to Mr\n\nLiu, he negotiated with Mr Tan on the price and Mr Tan agreed to purchase his or his wifes\n\ninterest in the Property at the price of $3.8 m net of tax and agreed to pay a sum of $2 m by\n\nApril 1981 and the balance two months later. On 23 April 1981, the parties met in Hong Kong, and Mr\n\nTan handed to Mr Liu two cashiers orders for the total sum of US$642,451.04 (being the equivalent\n\nof $1,368,420.70 at the exchange rate of S$2.13 to US$1). Mr Liu claimed that thereafter he asked Mr\n\nTan for payment of the balance of the purchase price, but no payment was made by the latter.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 About two years later, on 25 August 1983, a Hong Kong\n\ncompany owned by Mr Tan and his wife, Madam Ching, called Fook Gee Finance Ltd (Fook Gee),\n\ncommenced an action in Suit No 4141 of 1983 (the 1983 action) against Mr Liu, claiming the sum\n\nof US$642,451.04 as a loan which, it was alleged, had been advanced to Mr Liu and seeking the\n\nrepayment of that amount. Mr Liu resisted the claim. His defence was that there was no loan made to\n\nhim by Fook Gee, and that the amount was part payment of the purchase price made by Mr Tan for Madam\n\nLims interest in the Property which Mr Tan had agreed to purchase at the price of $3.8 m net\n\nof tax.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 About a year after Fook Gee had commenced the action, Madam\n\nLim commenced an action in Suit No. 4149 of 1984 (the 1984 action) against Lee Tat, Mr Tan and\n\nLee Kai, claiming, inter alia, the balance of the purchase price. She subsequently joined Collin as\n\nthe fourth defendant. The defence put forward on behalf of the defendants was essentially that Madam\n\nLim never had any interest in the Property. Mr Tan died before the action came on for trial and\n\nMadam Ching was appointed to represent his estate.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both the actions, were tried together before Lai Siu Chiu\n\nJ, as the events and the evidence were inextricably linked. The judge found that there was no\n\nevidence that the sum of US$642,451.04 was a loan by Fook Gee to Mr Liu, and that the sum came from\n\nthe funds of a Liberian import and export company called Komala Deccoff &amp; Co SA, which was owned\n\nby Mr Tan and another person. She therefore dismissed Fook Gees claim in the 1983 action. Turning\n\nto the claim of Madam Lim in the 1984 action, the judge found that Madam Lim did have an interest in\n\nthe Property, that Mr Tan had agreed to buy that interest at the price of $3.8 m, and that the sum\n\nof US$642,451.04 paid to Mr Liu was a part payment of the purchase price. She therefore entered\n\njudgment in her favour but only against Lee Tat for the balance sum, being the difference between\n\nthe purchase price of $3.8 m and the sum of $1,368,420.70 (being the equivalent of US$642,451.04 at\n\nthe exchange rate of S$2.13 to US$1) that had already been paid.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Against her decision, Lee Tat, Madam Ching representing the\n\nestate of Mr Tan and Lee Kai as well as Fook Gee appealed to this Court by two separate appeals.\n\nBoth the appeals were heard together. This Court dismissed Fook Gees appeal and affirmed the\n\ndecision below in the 1983 action. However, this Court allowed the appeal by Lee Tat, Madam Ching\n\nrepresenting the estate of Mr Tan and Lee Kai, and set aside the judgement in the 1984 action. The\n\nCourt held that Madam Lim had not established that she had any interest in the Property and thus\n\ndismissed her claim in the 1984 action: see <i>Fook Gee Finance Co Ltd v Liu Cho Chit and another\n\naction </i><a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=45552&amp;freetext=\">[1998] 2 SLR 121</a>.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As a sequel to the decision of this Court, Madam Ching, as\n\nthe executrix of Mr Tans estate, on 4 June 1998, commenced the present proceedings in Suit No 862\n\nof 1998 against Mr Liu seeking to recover the sum of $1,368,420.71 (being the equivalent of\n\nUS$642,451.04 at the agreed rate of exchange at the time of payment to Mr Liu) as money had and\n\nreceived, on the ground that the US$642,451.04 was paid to Mr Liu under a mistaken assumption that\n\nMadam Lim had an interest in the Property, and/or that the consideration for the sum of\n\nUS$642,451.04 had totally failed.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After the close of pleadings, Mr Liu applied to strike out\n\nthe statement of claim on the ground that it was frivolous, vexatious or otherwise an abuse of\n\nprocess, or alternatively on the ground that the claim was time barred. Upon being served with the\n\napplication to strike out, Madam Ching applied to have the statement of claim amended by the\n\naddition of an alternative claim for a constructive trust. Both the applications were heard before\n\nthe assistant registrar, who dismissed Madam Chings application to amend the statement of claim\n\nand allowed Mr Lius application to strike out the statement of claim. The assistant registrar\n\nheld that the claim was time barred under s 6 of the Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 ed), and that the\n\nfacts did not give rise to any constructive trust. Against the decision of the assistant registrar,\n\nMadam Ching appealed to a Judge in Chambers and the appeal was dismissed.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On further appeal, this Court allowed both the appeals, i.e<i>.</i>\n\nthe appeal against the striking out of the statement of claim and the appeal against the refusal to\n\nallow the amendment: see <i>Ching Mun Fong (executrix of the estate of Tan Geok Tee deceased) v Liu\n\nCho Chit &amp; another</i> <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=50779&amp;freetext=\">[2000] 1 SLR 517</a>. Hence, the action proceeded to trial. The trial judge\n\nat the conclusion of the hearing dismissed Madam Chings claim. Against that decision this appeal\n\nwas brought.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The appeal</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The issues canvassed before us were the same as those\n\nraised and decided below, namely:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) whether the proper parties were before the court;</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) whether Madam Chings claim for the sum of $1,368,420.71 was time barred\n\n  by the Limitation Act; and</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) whether a remedial constructive trust arose on the facts of this case.</p>\n\n  <b><i>\n\n  </i></b></blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The proper parties</p>\n\n  \n\n<p align=\"justify\">17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 One of the defences raised by Mr Liu in the pleadings was\n\nthat the proper parties were not before the court. First, Madam Ching as the executrix of the estate\n\nof Mr Tan was not the proper plaintiff. The reason for this was that it was established in the 1983\n\naction that the monies paid to Mr Liu came from a company, Komala Decoff SA, and therefore the\n\nmonies belonged to that company and accordingly that company should be the plaintiff. Secondly, Mr\n\nLiu was not the proper defendant. Here, the reason was that in the 1984 action, the judge found that\n\nMadam Lim had entered into an agreement, through Mr Liu, to sell her interest in the Property and\n\nthat Mr Liu was only the agent for Madam Lim, and therefore the proper defendant should be Madam Lim\n\nand not Mr Liu.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On this issue, the judge held that the correct plaintiff\n\nshould be Lee Tat and that the correct defendant should be Madam Lim. The basis for this conclusion\n\nwas that the parties to the underlying agreement for the sale of Madam Lims alleged interest were\n\nMadam Lim and Lee Tat. The judge approached the issue thus:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">34 As regards the question as to who the correct plaintiff should be, I am of\n\n  the view that the material point is not where the monies came from or who paid the monies or who\n\n  the monies belonged to. The material point is who the contracting parties were. This would also be\n\n  the correct approach on the question as to who the correct defendant should be.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">35 For example, if X enters into a contract with Y to buy Ys interest in a\n\n  property and monies are paid pursuant to that contract to purchase Ys interest, it is\n\n  irrelevant as between X and Y whether the money came from Xs parents or a family company or a\n\n  financial institution. It is also irrelevant whether Y received the monies personally or not. X is\n\n  the correct person to sue and Y is the correct person to be sued if there is a total failure of\n\n  consideration on Ys part or if the payment was made pursuant to a mistake.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The judge then turned to what was found in the 1983 and 1984 actions by the High\n\nCourt, and said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">36 As I have mentioned, in the 1983 and 1984 actions, the trial judge had\n\n  found:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) that the monies were paid as part payment of Mdm Lims interest in the\n\n    Property pursuant to an agreement in April 1981 which Mdm Lim had entered, through Liu, to sell\n\n    her interest to Lee Tat, and</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) that Mdm Lim had acquired an interest in the Property and therefore there\n\n    was something for her to sell. Accordingly the trial judge had ordered Lee Tat, and only Lee\n\n    Tat, to pay the balance of the purchase price to Mdm Lim.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">37 When the Court of Appeal reversed the trial judges decision, it was only\n\n  on the basis that Mdm Lim had not established that she had, or had acquired, an interest in the\n\n  Property.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">38 The Court of Appeal did not disturb the other findings of the trial judge in\n\n  the 1983 and 1984 actions, i.e. that the purchaser was Lee Tat and the vendor was Mdm Lim.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">39 Accordingly, as regards the causes of action based on mistake of fact and\n\n  total failure of consideration, and monies had and received, I am of the view that in the light of\n\n  the findings of the trial judge in the 1983 and 1984 actions, the claims before me should have\n\n  been made by Lee Tat against Mdm Lim and not by Mdm Ching, as executrix of Tans estate, against\n\n  Liu.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">40 As for the cause of action based on a remedial constructive trust, I am of\n\n  the view that even though Liu had received the monies, the findings of the trial judge in the 1983\n\n  and the 1984 actions would also mean that Liu had received the monies on behalf of Mdm Lim.\n\n  Whether he had parted with the monies to Mdm Lim is a matter between them. It would then follow\n\n  that it is Mdm Lim, not Liu, who is to account as trustee for the monies even if I should find\n\n  that the Plaintiff has established a remedial constructive trust.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, Mr Michael Khoo, counsel for Madam Ching, argued\n\nthat the approach of the judge ignored the fact that the true contracting parties were Mr Tan and Mr\n\nLiu, which was accepted by Mr Liu in his evidence. On a true analysis of the facts, so far as Mr Liu\n\nwas concerned, Madam Lim was his nominee, and the interest in the Property which he thought had been\n\nacquired was his but held by Madam Lim as his nominee. In the negotiation with Mr Tan, Mr Liu acted\n\nin his personal capacity as the beneficial owner. As for Mr Tan, he also negotiated with Mr Liu as\n\nthe true owner of the Property and not as the agent for Lee Tat. The negotiations were conducted\n\nonly between Mr Tan and Mr Liu and the agreement was reached between them as the contracting\n\nparties, and the moneys were handed by Mr Tan to Mr Liu. Mr Khoo thus contended that the money\n\nshould be recovered from Mr Liu, not Madam Lim, and the action was properly brought by Madam Ching,\n\nas the executrix of the estate of Mr Tan, against Mr Liu.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the other hand, Mr C R Rajah, counsel for Mr Liu, argued\n\nthat the claim brought by Madam Ching against Mr Liu was for the return of some $1.3 m paid by\n\nmistake as part of the purchase price under a contract for the purchase of an interest in the\n\nProperty, which the vendor did not have. The contract was made between Mr Liu on behalf of his wife,\n\nas the vendor and Mr Tan on behalf of Lee Tat as the purchaser. If this sum had to be returned, it\n\nwould be by the vendor, Madam Lim, to the purchaser, Lee Tat. On this point, Mr Rajah relied on what\n\ntranspired in the 1983 and 1984 actions and what the High Court found in those actions. He thus\n\nmaintained that the proper plaintiff should be Lee Tat and the proper defendant Madam Lim.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We were unable to agree with Mr Rajah. It should be borne\n\nin mind that, in the 1984 action, before the High Court and on appeal before this Court, the\n\nquestion as to the proper parties for the recovery of the sum of $1,368,420.71 (being the equivalent\n\nof US$642,451.01) was not in issue. The main issue there was whether Madam Lim had an interest in\n\nthe Property. The High Court held that she had, but on appeal this Court found that she had not\n\nestablished that she had such interest. As Mr Khoo rightly pointed out, both the High Court and this\n\nCourt, at times in the course of the respective judgments, dealt with the alleged interest in the\n\nProperty as interchangeably that of Mr Liu and Madam Lim. Certainly this Court did not make any\n\nclear distinction between the two.</p>\n\n</font>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <font face=\"Times New Roman\">On the facts, there was no\n\ndoubt that both in the joint venture agreements made in January 1973 and in the sale of the alleged\n\ninterest in the Property in April 1981, the true contracting parties were Mr Tan and Mr Liu and\n\nnobody else. In respect of the joint venture, Mr Tan and Mr Liu were the ones who negotiated with\n\neach other and reached an agreement, which was then reduced into four separate agreements. So far as\n\nMr Liu was concerned, his wife, Madam Lim, was merely his nominee. In entering into the joint\n\nventure with Mr Tan in 1973, he made use of his wife as a nominal party to the joint venture\n\nagreements and signed the agreements on her behalf. She did not even know of the joint venture or of\n\nany of the agreements which were made in her name. The same applies to Mr Tan with regard to using\n\nhis daughter, Collin, and his family company, Lee Kai, in entering into the joint venture\n\nagreements. Mr Tan signed the agreements on behalf of Collin and Lee Kai respectively. Like Madam\n\nLim, Collin did not even know of the joint venture or any of the joint venture agreements. In truth\n\nand in fact, Mr Liu and Mr Tan were the contracting parties. As Mr Khoo submitted, and we agreed,\n\nnone of the nominal parties to the joint venture agreements had any independent thought or action as\n\nregards any of the agreements. Further, the subsequent dealings in relation to the proposed\n\ndevelopment on the joint venture site were between Mr Tan and Mr Liu only.</font></p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequently, in April 1981, when Mr Liu and Mr Tan\n\nnegotiated on the sale and purchase of what was then believed to be Madam Lims or Mr Lius\n\ninterest in the Property, only Mr Liu and Mr Tan were the parties involved in such negotiations. So\n\nfar as Mr Liu was concerned, his wife was the nominee and the interest acquired was his, and in the\n\nnegotiations he was acting in his personal capacity as the beneficial owner of that interest. The\n\nevidence of Mr Liu was that he negotiated with Mr Tan on the sale of that interest, and they reached\n\nan agreement, whereby Mr Tan agreed to purchase that interest at the price of $3.8 m, and in part\n\npayment of the purchase price, Mr Tan handed to him the two cashiers orders for the total amount\n\nof US$642,451.04. It was Mr Tan who made the payment. Where he got the funds from was immaterial.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Even if it can be said, as it was so argued on behalf of Mr\n\nLiu, that Madam Lim was the contracting party and that the sum of US$642,451.01 was a purported part\n\npayment, through Mr Liu, to Madam Lim of what was then believed to be her interest in the Property,\n\nand thus the payment was made to Mr Liu as the agent for Madam Lim, an action could still be\n\nbrought, as was brought here, to recover that sum from him. He was the sole recipient and\n\nbeneficiary of this sum, and the irrefutable evidence was that no part of that sum was ever paid to\n\nMadam Lim. He had kept this sum and treated it as his. He could properly be sued, as he was here,\n\nfor repayment of the money that was paid to him. There is authority for the proposition that, where\n\na payer makes a payment to an agent of the payee under a mistake of fact, the payer can recover the\n\npayment from the agent, if the agent has not paid it over to the principal: <i>Kleinwort, Sons &amp;\n\nCo v Dunlop Rubber Co </i>(1907) 97 LT 263, at 264 and 265. See also Goff and Jones, <i>The Law of\n\nRestitution </i>(5<sup>th</sup> edn) (1998) at pp 186 and 833.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to Mr Tan, it was not in evidence that Mr Tan on\n\nbehalf of Lee Tat entered into the sale and purchase agreement with Mr Liu; there was only an\n\ninference that he probably did so, because the Property was then vested in Lee Tat. The undisputed\n\nevidence was that it was Mr Tan who negotiated with Mr Liu for the purchase of the alleged interest\n\nof Madam Lim or Mr Liu in the Property, that it was Mr Tan who agreed with Mr Liu on the price for\n\nthe alleged interest, and that it was Mr Tan who paid the monies to Mr Liu. The monies were clearly\n\nhis, and there was no evidence that the monies were Lee Tats. In any case, Lee Tat was his\n\nnominee and his company, and to all intents and purposes the Property was his. There was nothing to\n\nprevent him, on his own account, from purchasing what he believed was Madam Lims or Mr Lius\n\ninterest in the Property and made the part payment. Even if, acting as an agent of Lee Tat, he made\n\nthe payment to Mr Liu, he did so in the mistaken belief that Madam Lim or Mr Liu had an interest in\n\nthe Property, which in fact neither of them had. In such circumstances, that mistake was entirely\n\nhis and not his principals; nor could it be attributed to his principal, and he can recover the\n\nmonies from the payee: see Goff and Jones, <i>The Law of Restitution</i> (5<sup>th</sup> edn) (1998)\n\nat pp 183  184.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">26.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our judgment, Madam Ching as the executrix of the estate\n\nof Mr Tan, was entitled to bring this action against Mr Liu for the recovery of the sum paid to him.\n\nThe proper parties were before the court. On this point, with respect, we were unable to agree with\n\nthe judge below.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Periods of limitation</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">27.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect to Madam Chings claim for money had and\n\nreceived for a total failure of consideration, the judge held that the cause of action was founded\n\non contract, and s 6(1)(a) of the Limitation Act (Cap 163) applied. As the money was paid to Mr Liu\n\non or about 23 April 1981, the claim for the recovery of this sum had been barred by 22 April 1987.\n\nHe said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">72 I am of the view that such causes of action are founded on a contract for\n\n  the purpose of s 6(1)(a) of the Limitation Act (Cap 163) which states:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">6 - (1) Subject to this Act, the following actions shall not be brought after\n\n    the expiration of 6 years from the date on which the cause of action accrued:</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) actions founded on a contract or on tort; </p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">73 The monies which are the subject of this action were paid pursuant to the\n\n  oral contract to purchase Mdm Lims interest. The claim for monies had and received are also\n\n  founded on the oral contract in that it was not as though the monies were received on a basis\n\n  apart from the oral contract. In addition, the words founded on a contract are wide enough\n\n  to cover claims for the recovery of monies paid pursuant to a contract where the underlying\n\n  subject matter of the agreement did not exist or did not materialise.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\"/>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">76 Accordingly these causes of action would be time-barred long before the\n\n  commencement of the present action on 4 June 1998.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The judges reasoning on this point was, with respect, correct. We agree with\n\nhim entirely.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">28.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the claim for recovery of the monies on the\n\nground that the payment was made under a mistake. If the monies were paid under a mistake, then the\n\nlimitation period for Madam Lims action would have been postponed under s\u00a029(1)(c) of the\n\nLimitation Act. The provision states:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">29(1) Where, in the case of any action for which a period of limitation is\n\n  prescribed by this Act </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\"/>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(c) the action is for relief from the consequences of a mistake, the period of\n\n  limitation shall not begin to run until the plaintiff has discovered the fraud or the mistake, as\n\n  the case may be, or could with reasonable diligence have discovered it.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">29.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was Mr Khoos contention that payment of the\n\nUS$642,451.04 was made under a mistake of law, and that this mistake could not have been discovered\n\nuntil this Court delivered its decision on 6 February 1998. He thus argued that the present\n\nproceedings, which were commenced in 1998, were not time barred. This argument was rejected by the\n\njudge below. We too rejected it.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">30.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was ample evidence before the court that Mr Tan\n\ndiscovered the mistake long before the judgment of this Court was delivered. The judge laid out the\n\nevidence as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">93 By a letter dated 4 May 1983, M/s Drew &amp; Napier, acting for Fook Gee,\n\n  demanded the return of the monies paid and interest from Liu on the basis that Fook Gee had lent\n\n  the monies to Liu.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">94 By a letter dated 11 May 1983, M/s Allen Yau, acting for Liu, replied. They\n\n  said that Liu had received on behalf of Mdm Lim the monies from Lee Tat. They also said that the\n\n  monies represented part payment of a purchase price for Mdm Lims interest in the Property.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">95 By a letter dated 27 July 1983, M/s Drew &amp; Napier asserted that Mdm Lim\n\n  never had any direct interest in the land.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">96 M/s Drew &amp; Napier must have been taking instructions from Tan as Tan was\n\n  controlling Fook Gee and Lee Tat.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">97 Lee Tats and Tans position was reiterated in paragraph 12 of the\n\n  Amended Defence (of the first three defendants), filed on 7 October 1987, in the 1984 action,\n\n  which states:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">12. Paragraphs 5 and 6 of the Statement of Claim are denied. Further the\n\n    Statement of Claim discloses no share which the Plaintiff owned at the said date which she could\n\n    agree to sell. The Defendants reserve the right to plead further hereto when the case is\n\n    properly particularised.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Apart from the pleadings filed in that action, Mr Tan himself asserted in his\n\naffidavit filed on 1 February 1989 that Madam Lim had no interest in the Property. Thus, as of that\n\ndate, if not earlier, he had already discovered the mistake. That was the most damning piece of\n\nevidence against the claim that the mistake was not discovered until the decision of this Court. The\n\njudge referred to Mr Tans affidavit and said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">99 Furthermore, paragraph 20(iii) of Tans affidavit affirmed on 1 February\n\n  1989 for the 1984 action stated:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(20) In June 1984, 11 years after the alleged Second Agreement was\n\n    purportedly entered into, the Plaintiff commenced this action to claim the following relief:-</p>\n\n    <blockquote>\n\n      <p align=\"justify\">(iii) as against the 1st Defendants and/or myself, she claims specific\n\n      performance of a purported oral agreement made sometime in April 1981, under which the 1st\n\n      Defendants and/or myself allegedly agreed to buy her share in Lot 1606 of Mukim 28 for $3.8\n\n      million (hereinafter called \"the alleged oral Third Agreement\").</p>\n\n    </blockquote>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">100 Paragraphs 25(a) and 27 to 29 of the same affidavit stated:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(25) The Plaintiffs claim that the 1st Defendants are holding Lot 1606 of\n\n    Mukim 28 on trust for her and Collin Tan is also misconceived and cannot be sustained for the\n\n    following reasons:-</p>\n\n    <blockquote>\n\n      <p align=\"justify\">(a) At all material times, the Plaintiff had <i>no proprietory interest in\n\n      the property</i>;</p>\n\n      <p align=\"justify\">(b) </p>\n\n      <p align=\"justify\">(c) </p>\n\n    </blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(26) </p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(27) Further, for any or all of the above reasons, the Plaintiff had <i>no\n\n    interest in the property</i> and, consequently, nothing for which she could allegedly sell to\n\n    the 1st Defendants or myself.</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(28) Besides, the 1st Defendants were at all material times the de facto and\n\n    de jure owner of the property (including Lot 1606 of Mukim 28). Even if the alleged oral Third\n\n    Agreement existed, which is denied, there was no consideration to support it.</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(29)  At the time of the alleged oral Third Agreement, she had no right\n\n    whatsoever in the property. For this reason, the alleged oral Third Agreement is invalid for\n\n    want of consideration. [Emphasis is added]</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">In view of what had transpired, it was impossible to argue on behalf of Madam\n\nChing that Mr Tan could not have known about Madam Lims want of interest until this Courts\n\ndecision. At the latest, Mr Tan knew about it by 1 February 1989, when he affirmed the affidavit.\n\nEven if the limitation period was postponed by virtue of s 29(1)(c) of the Limitation Act, the time\n\nbar would have set in by 1 February 1995, at the latest.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">31.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The following argument was, nevertheless, raised by Mr Khoo\n\non behalf of Madam Ching in the Appellants Case:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">86. It was held by the Lords in <i>Kleinwort Benson v Lincoln County Council</i>\n\n  that the date when the local authority interest swap rate transactions proved to be void was when\n\n  the House of Lords made its decision in <i>Hazell v Hammersmith and Fulham London Borough Council</i>.\n\n  It is submitted that it is implicit if not express in that judgment that the cause of action to\n\n  recover a payment made under a mistake of law only accrues when the court determines that there is\n\n  a mistake of law.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">..</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">89. Therefore it was not until the Court of Appeal judgment of 6<sup>th</sup>\n\n  February 1998 that it was established that there had been a mistake in 1981 when the moneys were\n\n  paid over to the respondent. The mistake was therefore not \"discovered\" until the Court\n\n  of Appeal held that Mdm Lim/the respondents assumed interest was not an interest at all.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">32.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We were unable to accept this argument. The provision in\n\nquestion is s\u00a029(1)(c) of the Limitation Act, which states quite clearly that time begins to\n\nrun once the plaintiff could with reasonable diligence have discovered the mistake. As far as\n\ns 29(1)(c) is concerned, it is the plaintiffs means of ascertaining the mistake, and not what the\n\ncourt eventually decides, that is relevant in determining when the limitation period begins to run.\n\nWhile the fact that Madam Lim (or Mr Liu) had no interest in the Property was determined only after\n\nthis Courts decision on 6 February 1998, Mr Tan obviously knew about the true state of affairs\n\nlong before that date. In fact, he had already discovered the mistake by the time he affirmed his\n\naffidavit on 1 February 1989. In these circumstances, it was impossible to maintain that Mr Tan <i>could\n\nnot with reasonable diligence</i> have discovered that Madam Lim (or Mr Liu) had no interest in the\n\nProperty until only after the decision of this Court.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Remedial constructive trust</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">33.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr Khoo finally argued that the court should impose a\n\nconstructive trust on the sum of US$642,451.01 paid to Mr Liu. His argument was along the following\n\nline. The money was paid to Mr Liu under a mistake, and although the mere receipt of the money in\n\nignorance of the mistake did not give rise to a trust in favour of Mr Tan at that time, the\n\nretention of the money by Mr Liu after he discovered the mistake, i.e. after this Court had\n\ndelivered its decision, gave rise to a constructive trust, because thenceforward his conscience was\n\naffected by the fact that the monies received by him had been paid for no consideration or under a\n\nmistake. It was the continued retention of such monies by Mr Liu that gave rise to this remedial\n\nconstructive trust, which the court should now impose, requiring Mr Liu to return the money to Mr\n\nTan. Mr Khoo then invoked s 22(1) of the Limitation Act, which provides:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">No period of limitation prescribed by this Act shall apply to an action by a\n\n  beneficiary under a trust, being an action </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">. . . . .</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(b) to recover from the trustee trust property or the proceeds thereof in the\n\n  possession of the trustee, or previously received by the trustee and converted to his use.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">34.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A remedial constructive trust arises where the court\n\nimposes a constructive trust de novo on assets which are not subject to any pre-existing trust as a\n\nmeans of granting equitable relief in a case where it considers just that restitution should be made\n\n(per Slade LJ in <i>Metal Und Rohstoff A G v Donaldson Lufkin &amp; Jenerette Inc and Anor</i>\n\n[1990] 1 QB 391, 478. Slade LJ, however, said (at p 479) that the extent to which a constructive can\n\nproperly be treated as a remedy is far from clearly defined in the authorities, and said at the end\n\nof p 479:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">While we have had the benefit of very full argument on almost all other aspects\n\n  of the law involved in this case, we have neither heard nor invited comprehensive argument as to\n\n  the circumstances in which the court will be prepared to impose a constructive trust de novo as a\n\n  foundation for the grant of equitable remedy by way of account or otherwise. Nevertheless, we are\n\n  satisfied that there is a good arguable case that such circumstances may arise and, for want of a\n\n  better description, will refer to a constructive trust of this nature as a \"remedial\n\n  constructive\" trust.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">35.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr Khoo relied on certain dicta of Lord Browne-Wilkinson in\n\n<i>Westdeutsche Landesbank Gironzentrale v Islington London Borough County Council</i> [1996] AC\n\n669. In that case, a bank in June 1987 entered into a swap contract with a local authority,\n\nand pursuant to that contract paid certain sums to the local authority. As a result of the decision\n\nof the House of Lords in <i>Hazell v Hammersmith and Fullam London Borough Council</i> [1992] 2 AC\n\n1, such a contract was ultra vires the authorities and therefore void. The bank therefore sought the\n\nrecovery of the sums from the local authority it had paid together with compound interest and\n\nsucceeded before the trial judge and the Court of Appeal. The local authority appealed to the House\n\nof Lords and one of the questions for consideration was whether the bank could get compound interest\n\non the sums recovered from the authority. As the general rule was that, in the absence of fraud,\n\nequity would not award compound interest except against trustees or other persons in a fiduciary\n\nposition in respect of profits improperly made, the bank sought to argue that the sums received by\n\nthe authority were held on trust for the bank. This argument was rejected and it was held, inter\n\nalia, that a recipient of monies under a contract subsequently declared void or as being ultra vires\n\ndoes not hold those monies on a resulting trust and that equity would not award the bank compound\n\ninterest in aid of their common law claim of restitution. In the course of his speech, Lord\n\nBrowne-Wilkinson discussed the possibility of a remedial constructive trust being available and\n\ndistinguished the remedial constructive trust from the normal institutional constructive trust as\n\nfollows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Under an institutional constructive trust, the trust arises by operation of law\n\n  as from the date of the circumstances which give rise to it: the function of the court is merely\n\n  to declare that such trust has arisen in the past. The consequences that flow from such trust have\n\n  arisen (including the possibly unfair consequences to third parties who in the interim have\n\n  received the trust property) are also determined by rules of law, not under a discretion. A\n\n  remedial constructive trust, as I understand it, is different. It is a judicial remedy giving rise\n\n  to an enforceable equitable obligation: the extent to which it operates retrospectively to the\n\n  prejudice of third parties lies in the discretion of the court.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">And later at p 716 his Lordship said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Although the resulting trust is an unsuitable basis for developing proprietary\n\n  restitutionary remedies, the remedial constructive trust, if introduced into English law, may\n\n  provide a more satisfactory road forward. The court by way of remedy might impose a constructive\n\n  trust on a defendant who knowingly retains property of which the plaintiff has been unjustly\n\n  deprived. Since the remedy can be tailored to the circumstances of the particular case, innocent\n\n  third parties would not be prejudiced and restitutionary defences, such as change of position, are\n\n  capable of being given effect. However, whether English law should follow the United States and\n\n  Canada by adopting the remedial constructive trust will have to be decided in some future case\n\n  when the point is directly in issue.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">36.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reverting to the case at hand, the judge below held that\n\neven if remedial constructive trust applies in Singapore, no remedial constructive trust arose in\n\nthis case. He said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">141  I am satisfied that on the particular facts before me, the Plaintiff\n\n  has failed to establish such a trust.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">142 The Plaintiffs case was that the payment was made pursuant to a contract\n\n  of sale of Mdm Lims interest. The Court of Appeal has found that Mdm Lim did not have such an\n\n  interest.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">143 The Plaintiff is in no better position than the depositors in <i>Sinclair v\n\n  Brougham</i> where the monies were paid pursuant to a void contract.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">144 As in that case, when the monies were paid to purchase Mdm Lims\n\n  interest, it was intended that she should be free to deal with the monies and she was entitled to\n\n  mix the monies with other monies of hers or anyone else for that matter. Whether it was in fact\n\n  mixed is irrelevant.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">145 The Plaintiffs cause of action is one based on a total failure of\n\n  consideration and not trust. Mdm Lim has been unjustly enriched and was accountable for the monies\n\n  received but the relationship was exclusively commercial and the monies were and are not trust\n\n  property.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">We agree with these observations of the judge. A remedial constructive trust is a\n\nrestitutionary remedy which the court, in appropriate circumstances, gives by way of equitable\n\nrelief. In order for a remedial constructive trust to arise, the payees conscience must have been\n\naffected, while the monies in question still remain with him. If, as was the situation in the <i>Westdeutsche</i>\n\ncase, the payee learns of the mistake only after the monies have got mixed with other funds or\n\ndissipated, no constructive trust in respect of these monies can arise. This is because there would\n\nno longer be an identifiable fund for the trust to bite. It is significant to note that the\n\nplaintiff bank in the <i>Westdeutsche</i> case expressly disavowed any intention of pursing a claim\n\nin constructive trust. The reason for their not having done so was stated by Lord Browne-Wilkinson\n\nat p 707:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">This is not a case where the bank had any equitable interest which pre-dated\n\n  receipt by the local authority of the upfront payment. Therefore, in order to show that the local\n\n  authority became a trustee, the bank must demonstrate circumstances which raised a trust for the\n\n  first time either at the date on which the local authority received the money or at the date on\n\n  which payment into the mixed account was made. <i>Counsel for the bank specifically disavowed any\n\n  claim based on a constructive trust. This was plainly right because the local authority had no\n\n  relevant knowledge sufficient to raise a constructive trust at any time before the moneys, upon\n\n  the bank account going into overdraft, became untraceable. Once there ceased to be an identifiable\n\n  trust fund, the local authority could not become a trustee</i>: <i>In re Goldcorp Exchange Ltd.</i>\n\n  [1995] 1 A.C. 74. Therefore, as the argument for the bank recognised, the only possible trust\n\n  which could be established was a resulting trust arising from the circumstances in which the local\n\n  authority received the upfront payment. [Emphasis is added]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">37.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the facts of this case, we found that there was\n\nno ground for imposing a remedial constructive trust on Mr Liu in respect of the sum US$642,451.01\n\npaid to him. The relationship between Mr Liu and Mr Tan was only that of a vendor and purchaser and\n\nwas wholly commercial. There was no dishonest conduct on the part of Mr Liu The sum was paid to Mr\n\nLiu in April 1981 with the intent that he was free to deal with it as his money. It was never\n\nintended by either Mr Tan or Mr Liu that it should be kept, and it had never been kept, distinct as\n\nan identifiable fund. On the basis of Mr Khoos contention that Mr Liu discovered the mistake only\n\nin February 1998 or thereabouts, there was a span of some 17 years and the sum paid to Mr Liu must\n\nhave, in the meanwhile, been spent or mixed with other funds of Mr Liu. There was no sum or fund on\n\nwhich a remedy of constructive trust could be imposed by the court. The sum paid to Mr Liu was\n\ncertainly not trust property. There was, of course, an obligation on the part of Mr Liu to return\n\nthe monies to Mr Tan, but that was only a personal obligation. In our judgment, no remedial\n\nconstructive trust could and should be imposed on the facts of this case.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Conclusion</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">38.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, Madam Chings appeal failed, and we\n\ndismissed it.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<div align=\"left\">\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"2\"
