in respondents' product</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"10\">Whether claim ought to be given wholly purposive construction</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Words and Phrases</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">'Making or importing a product for disposal'</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">s 77(4) Patents Act (Cap 221, 1995 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p align=\"justify\">\n      <font face=\"Times New Roman\" color=\"#3322AA\" size=\"4\">\n        <strong>JUDGMENT:</strong>\n      </font>\n    </p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><strong><font face=\"Times New Roman\" size=\"3\" color=\"#804040\"><i>Cur Vult Adv</i></font></strong></p>\n\n<font face=\"Times New Roman\"><b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The facts</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal concerns a Singapore Patent No. 52288 for a\n\ndevice described as a mail box assembly with lockable delivery flaps. The patent was first\n\nregistered in the United Kingdom as No GB 2 289 500. It was subsequently registered in Singapore and\n\nthe certificate of registration was issued on 16 November 1998. The mailbox assembly was designed by\n\nthe second appellant, Tan Mui Teck (Mr Tan). He is therefore the proprietor of the patent, and\n\nthe first appellant, Bean Innovations Pte Ltd (Bean Innovations), in which Mr Tan is the\n\nmanaging director, is the exclusive licensee of the patent in Singapore. The mailbox assembly as\n\ndesigned by Mr Tan has a device of central locking system for individual mailboxes, which serves to\n\nprevent junk mails from being delivered into the individual mailboxes. For convenience, we shall\n\nrefer to Mr Tans patent as the appellants patent, and the device or invention designed by him\n\nas the appellants device or invention.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants device or invention has the following main\n\nfeatures. Each of the mail box in the assembly has a delivery flap, called the postmans trap\n\ndoor, through which the mails are delivered, and a collection door for collecting the mails. The\n\ntop edge of each postmans trap door is pivotally connected to a bar and the lower outer edge\n\nabuts against a portion of a stopper, called the trap door stopper. This assembly of mailboxes\n\nhas a device of a central locking system for individual mailboxes, and the device operates in this\n\nway. In the interior of the mailboxes, there is a matrix of orthogonal bars comprising: (i) a\n\nuniversal biasing bar at the top running along the width of the assembly; (ii) a pair of vertical\n\nsupporting bars, one on each side, connected to both ends of the biasing bar at the top; and (iii) a\n\nplurality of horizontal bars, called the anti-junk mail bars, which are positioned behind the\n\npostmans trap doors extending between the two vertical support bars and connected to them. Thus,\n\nall the bars within this matrix are connected. This matrix of bars is movable vertically. When the\n\nmatrix is lowered, the horizontal anti-junk mail bars block the postmans trap doors, thus\n\npreventing them from being opened, and when the matrix is raised the anti-junk mail bars in turn are\n\nraised, thus allowing the postmans trap doors to be opened and mails to be delivered into the\n\nmailboxes. This movement of the matrix is operated by a master lock located at the upper front panel\n\nof the mailbox assembly but just below the biasing bar so that when the lock is turned or unlocked,\n\nit raises the matrix of bars within the mailbox assembly, and when it is locked, it lowers the\n\nmatrix. Such device serves to prevent junk mails from being delivered into the individual mailboxes.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondents, Flexon Pte Ltd (Flexon), were\n\nincorporated in 1975, and have since been involved in the manufacture of fabricated metal products.\n\nThey have designed a mail box assembly, which also has a device of central locking system for\n\nindividual mailboxes, and they call it Master Door Letter Box with Aperture Central Locking.\n\nWe shall refer to this invention of Flexon as the Flexon device or invention.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Flexon invention has the following main features. It is\n\nan assembly of mailboxes and each mailbox has a delivery flap through which the mails are delivered,\n\nand a collection door immediately below the flap. The lower edge of the flap abuts against the upper\n\nedge of the collection door, which acts as a stopper for the flap. The mailbox central locking\n\nsystem operates in this way. In the interior of the mailboxes are the stopper screws at one side\n\nwhich are located immediately behind the flaps but do not extend across the flaps. They are screwed\n\nonto a vertical bar at the side The vertical side bar is connected to a lever at the top and this\n\nlever raises and lowers the side bar vertically. When the side bar is lowered, the stopper screws\n\nare in turn lowered and block the flaps, thus preventing them from being opened. When the side bar\n\nis raised, the stopper screws in turn are raised, thus allowing the flaps to be opened. The movement\n\nof the side bar vertically is operated by a master lock located at the upper front panel but slotted\n\ninto the lever inside. When the lock is in a locked position, it lowers the vertical bar which in\n\nturn lowers the stopper screws to a position just behind the flap thus preventing the flaps from\n\nbeing opened. When the master lock is turned and unlocked, the lever raises the side bar, which in\n\nturn raises the stopper screws, thus allowing the flaps to be opened and mails to be delivered. This\n\ndevice is also designed to prevent junk mails from being delivered into the mailboxes.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Admittedly, there is a demand for mailbox assemblies with a\n\ncentral locking system for individual mailboxes. Such mailboxes have postmans doors which are\n\nclosed and can be opened manually by using a central locking key when the mail is delivered. After\n\ndelivery, the mailboxes are centrally locked by a device which keep the postmans doors closed,\n\nthus preventing junk mails from being inserted into the postmans slots in the mailboxes.\n\nSuch mailboxes are now commonly seen in condominiums and Housing Development Board (HDB)\n\nhousing estates. The market for such a product appears to be huge.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In September 1999 or thereabouts, Mr Tan discovered that\n\nFlexon had supplied and installed their mailboxes with lockable delivery flaps in a couple of HDB\n\nhousing estates. Following such discovery, on 28 September 1999, Bean Innovations, through their\n\nsolicitors, sent a letter to Flexon, claiming that they were the exclusive licensees of the\n\nSingapore patent and that Flexon had infringed their patent, and demanding, inter alia, that Flexon\n\nimmediately cease to manufacture and supply such mailboxes which infringed their patent, and\n\nthreatening to take legal action against Flexon, should their demands be not complied with.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In response, Flexon through their solicitors on 15 October\n\n1999 wrote to the solicitors for Bean Innovations, denying any infringement and demanding that the\n\nlatter retract and withdraw their allegations. There was a further exchange of correspondence\n\nbetween the two firms of solicitors. Following legal advice, Flexon instituted legal proceedings\n\nagainst Bean Innovations and Mr Tan (jointly referred to as the appellants) under s 77 of the\n\nPatents Act, seeking a declaration to the effect that the appellants threats of proceedings for\n\ninfringement were unjustifiable, an injunction against further threats, and damages. In their\n\nstatement of claim Flexon admitted to having made prototypes of, manufactured, supplied and sold\n\nmailboxes with lockable delivery flaps to a certain construction company and certain HDB housing\n\nestates, but they denied that their mailboxes infringed the patent. In the alternative, they pleaded\n\nthat they were not aware of the existence of the patent and had no reasonable grounds for supposing\n\nits existence, and invoked the defence under s 69(1) Patents Act. The appellants in their defence\n\ndisputed the validity of Flexons claim and pleaded that Flexon were not entitled to bring\n\nproceedings against the appellants on the ground that the alleged threats, if any, fell within the\n\nscope of s\u00a077(4) of the Patents Act. The appellants counter-claimed against Flexon damages for\n\ninfringement of the patent and an injunction.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The case was tried before Rubin J, and at the conclusion he\n\nheld that the threats made by the appellants were actionable under s 77(1) and (2) of the Patents\n\nAct, and that Flexon were the aggrieved party and were entitled to bring the action. He further held\n\nthat there was no infringement by Flexon of the patent, and in consequence he allowed the Flexons\n\nclaim and dismissed the appellants counterclaim. Against his decision, the appellants now appeal.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The appeal</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn to the first issue relating to the threats made by\n\nthe appellants through their solicitors. The relevant provision, which gives Flexon the right to\n\nbring this action, is s 77 of the Patents Act which, so far as material, provides as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) Where a person (whether or not the proprietor of, or entitled to any right\n\n  in a patent) by circulars, advertisements or otherwise threatens another person with proceedings\n\n  for any infringement of a patent, a person aggrieved by the threats (whether or not he is the\n\n  person to whom the threats are made) may, subject to subsection (4), bring proceedings in the\n\n  court against the person making the threats, claiming any relief mentioned in subsection (3).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) In any such proceedings, the respondent shall, if he proves that the\n\n  threats were so made and satisfies the court that he is a person aggrieved by them, be entitled to\n\n  the relief claimed unless:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) the appellant proves that the acts in respect of which proceedings were\n\n    threatened constitute or, if done, would constitute an infringement of a patent; and</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) the patent alleged to be infringed is not shown by the respondent to be\n\n    invalid in a relevant respect.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) The said relief is:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) a declaration to the effect that the threats are unjustifiable;</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) an injunction against the continuance of the threats; and</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(c) damages in respect of any loss which the respondent has sustained by the\n\n    threats.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(4) Proceedings may not be brought under this section for a threat to bring\n\n  proceedings for an infringement alleged to consist of making or importing a product for disposal\n\n  or of using a process.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It does not appear to us that there is any dispute that the\n\nappellants, or at least Bean Innovations, by their solicitors letters to Flexon threatened Flexon\n\nwith legal proceedings, and that these letters were a threat falling within s 77(1) of the Patents\n\nAct. During the course of proceedings, counsel for the appellants conceded that the threats of\n\ninfringement proceedings were made out. It is therefore unnecessary to dwell further on this issue.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What the appellants now contend is that the threats fell\n\nwithin the scope of s\u00a077(4) Patents Act on the ground that Flexon were, in fact, the makers of\n\nthe mailboxes, and the threats concerned the infringing acts of making for disposal of such\n\nproducts, and hence no action can be brought against the appellants under s\u00a077(1) Patents Act.\n\nWe are unable to accept this contention. Section 77(4) of the Patents Act only exempts threats\n\nrelating to making or importing a product for disposal, or to using a process, but does not apply to\n\nother acts of infringement, such as supplying, delivering, installing, selling and/or offering to\n\nsell a product, or otherwise disposing of it. The threats made by or on behalf of the appellants\n\nwere much more extensive. They were not confined only to the infringing acts described in s 77(4).\n\nThe alleged infringing acts referred to in the appellants threats were the following: making\n\nprototypes of, manufacturing, supplying, delivering, installing, selling and/or offering to sell\n\nmailboxes, which infringed the appellants patent. In our judgment, the defence afforded by s\n\n77(4) Patents Act cannot possibly apply to the threats made by or on behalf of the appellants.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Cavity Trays Ltd v RMC Panel Products </i>[1996] RPC\n\n361, the threat was in respect of acts of promotion, marketing and sale of the alleged infringing\n\narticle. The Court of Appeal held that the purpose of s 70(4) of the Patents Act of the United\n\nKingdom (to which our s 77(4) is similar) was to enable a person to warn off primary infringers\n\nwithout fear of being sued for threats. It prevents proceedings from being brought for threats\n\nalleged to consist of certain acts, namely, making or importing a product for disposal or using a\n\nprocess. Other threats of proceedings against manufacturers or importers, for example, threats of\n\nproceedings alleging disposal or use, do not fall within the subsection. The subsection defines the\n\nacts of alleged infringement that were excluded and not the types of persons who could be\n\nthreatened. It was therefore held that the threats relating to promotion, marketing and sale were\n\nnot excluded by s 70(4) of the Patents Act 1977.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Cavity Trays Ltd </i>was applied in <i>Brian v Ingledew </i>[1997] FSR 511. Jacob J said at 525:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">section 70(4) excluded from the generality of the prohibition of section 70(1),\n\n  threats in relation to certain types of infringement Although section 70(4) allowed a patentee\n\n  to issue threats in respect of use of a process, <i><font face=\"Times New Roman\">it did not permit\n\n  threats to be made in respect of offering a process for use which was a separately identified\n\n  category of infringement prescribed by the Patents Act. Thus, if the threat went beyond\n\n  threatening anyone for the use of the patented process, it was actionable.</font></i></p>\n\n  \n\n  <p align=\"justify\">[Emphasis is added]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants further contend that s 77(4) of the Patents\n\nAct refers to making or importing a product for disposal and that, acts of supplying,\n\ndelivering, installing, selling and/or offer to sell are <i>ejusdem generis </i>and are logical\n\nadjuncts to the meaning of the word disposal. Such a contention is manifestly unsustainable.\n\nThe alleged infringing acts of Flexon cannot be construed as an adjunct to or <i>ejusdem generis </i>to\n\nmaking or importing for disposal. In any case, what the provision refers to is the making\n\n a product for disposal and not the making or disposal of a product. It is the act of\n\nmaking and not the act of disposal that is exempted by the subsection. Threats relating\n\nto the acts of sale and supply are not exempted.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our judgment, the defence under s 77(4) of the Patents\n\nAct is not available to the appellants. The threats contained in the letters were actionable under s\n\n77 Patents Act. It follows therefore that as a threat or threats had been made to Flexon and Flexon\n\nwere the aggrieved party, they were entitled to claim reliefs under s\u00a077(3) of the Patents Act,\n\nunless the appellants prove that the acts in respect of which the proceedings were threatened\n\nconstitute or, if done, would constitute an infringement of their patent. Hence, the issue now for\n\nconsideration is whether Flexon have infringed the appellants patent.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Infringement of patent</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On this issue it is necessary to turn to the claims made in\n\nthe specifications of the patent. By these claims, the inventor sets out the essential features of\n\nhis invention for which the patent is granted, and these claims are intended to inform persons\n\nskilled in the art, namely, persons with practical knowledge and experience of the kind of work,\n\nin which the invention is intended to be used. The setting out of the claims in the description or\n\nspecification of the patent is a statutory requirement. Under s 25 of the Patents Act, an applicant\n\nfor a patent is required to set out in the application, inter alia, a claim or claims which are to\n\ndefine the matter, for which protection is sought, in clear and concise terms supported by a\n\ndescription of his invention. In <i>Rodi &amp; Wienenberger A G v Henry Showell Ltd</i> [1969] RPC\n\n367 at p\u00a0380, Lord Morris of Both-y-Gest said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">It is a statutory requirement that every complete specification of a patent\n\n  must end with a claim or claims defining the scope of the invention claimed: the specification\n\n  must particularly describe the invention and the method by which it is to be performed and must\n\n  disclose the best method of performing the invention which is known to the applicant and for which\n\n  he is entitled to claim protection.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Thus, the claims as stated in the specification of the patent are the principal\n\ndeterminant of the scope of the monopoly for which protection is provided. In <i>Electric and\n\nMusical Industries Ltd v Lissen Ltd </i>(1939) 56 RPC 23 at 39, Lord Russell of Killowen said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <i>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The function of the claims is to define clearly and with precision the monopoly\n\n  claimed, so that others may know the exact boundaries of the area within which they will be\n\n  trespassers. Their primary object is to limit and not to extend the monopoly. What is not claimed\n\n  is disclaimed</p></i> It is not permissible, in my opinion, by reference to some language used in\n\n  the earlier part of the specification, to change a claim which by its own language is a claim for\n\n  one subject-matter into a claim for another and a different subject-matter, which is what you do\n\n  when you alter the boundaries of the forbidden territory. A patentee who describes an invention in\n\n  the body of a specification obtains no monopoly unless it is claimed in the claims. As Lord Cairns\n\n  said, there is no such thing as infringement of the equity of a patent <i><font face=\"Times New Roman\">I know of no canon or principle which will justify one in departing from\n\n  the unambiguous and grammatical meaning of a claim and narrowing or extending its scope by reading\n\n  into it words which are not in it; or will justify one in using stray phrases in the body of the\n\n  specification for the purpose of narrowing or widening the boundaries of the monopoly fixed by the\n\n  plain words of a claim.</font>\n\n  </i>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">[Emphasis added]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">and at p 41 said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">A claim is a portion of the specification which fulfils a separate and distinct\n\n  function. It and it alone defines the monopoly; and the patentee is under a statutory obligation\n\n  to state in the claims clearly and distinctly what is the invention which he desires to protect.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, only Claim 1 of the claims in the specification\n\nof the appellants patent is in issue. This claim is stated as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <u>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Claim 1</p>\n\n  </u>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">In a multiple slot mailbox having a plurality of individual mailboxes, said\n\n  individual mailboxes each having at least one postmans trap door on at least one open panel,\n\n  said individual mailboxes each further having at least one users trap door on at least one open\n\n  panel, an apparatus for preventing the unauthorized access of the postmans trap doors, said\n\n  apparatus comprising:</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">a trap door stopper along the lower edge of each said postmans trap doors\n\n  for minimising the gap between the trap door stopper and the lower edge of the said postmans\n\n  trap door, said trap door stopper further having a stopper portion for wedging the lower and outer\n\n  edge of said trap door;</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">a matrix of orthogonal bars being placed in the interior of said mailbox and\n\n  directly behind the postmans trap door for wedging the lower and inner edge of said postmans\n\n  trap door against the inner surface of said stopper portion when said matrix of orthogonal bars is\n\n  lowered, said matrix of orthogonal bars having as its top member at least one universal biasing\n\n  bar running along the width of said multiple slot mailbox, said matrix of orthogonal bars further\n\n  having as its horizontal members a plurality of parallel anti-junks mail bars, said matrix of\n\n  orthogonal bars further having at its vertical members of plurality of parallel bars, said\n\n  vertical bars having its upper end coupled to said universal biasing bar; and</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">at least one master lock being disposed on the upper front panel and below said\n\n  universal biasing bar for raising and lowering said matrix of orthogonal bars.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">whereby the postmans trap doors can be released or closed simultaneously.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The question that arises now is whether this claim has been\n\ninfringed by Flexon. This is essentially a question of construction of the Claim, comparing the\n\nfeatures of such Claim with those of the Flexon invention. In construing the Claim, the words and\n\nterms thereof must be given their reasonable and sensible meaning. In <i>Rodi Weinenebeger v Henry\n\nShowell</i> (supra), Lord Morris said at p 380:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">In the process of construing the claim (a process which must be independent of\n\n  any consideration of an alleged infringement) words must be given their reasonable and sensible\n\n  meaning as words in a document to be read by those versed in the subject and skilled in the prior\n\n  art. But if monopoly is to result it will only be for that which has been claimed. Protection will\n\n  not extend to that which might have been claimed but which, when definition was requisite, was not\n\n  claimed.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Similar pronouncements were made by Lord Upjohn in his speech in that case at\n\np\u00a0391:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">[T]he question is whether the relevant claim has been infringed. This is purely\n\n  a question of construction of the claim read as a matter of ordinary language, in the light of the\n\n  complete specification taken as a whole; but the claim must be construed as a document without\n\n  having in mind the alleged infringement. What is not claimed is disclaimed. The claim must be read\n\n  through the eyes of the notional addressee, the man who is going to carry out the invention\n\n  described.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the other hand, one must not adhere too strictly to the\n\nliteral wordings of the claim. A purposive construction is to be adopted. In the leading case of <i>Catnic\n\nComponents Ltd and Anor v Hill Smith Ltd </i>[1982] RPC 183, 242  243, Lord Diplock, who\n\ndelivered the main speech of the House with which all the other Law Lords concurred, said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">My Lords, a patent specification is a unilateral statement by the patentee, in\n\n  words of his own choosing, addressed to those likely to have a practical interest in the subject\n\n  matter of his invention (i.e. \"skilled in the art\"), by which he informs them what he\n\n  claims to be the essential features of the new product or process for which the letters patent\n\n  grant him a monopoly. It is those novel features only that he claims to be essential that\n\n  constitute the so-called \"pith and marrow\" of the claim. A patent specification should\n\n  be given a purposive construction rather than a purely literal one derived from applying to it the\n\n  kind of meticulous verbal analysis in which lawyers are too often tempted by their training to\n\n  indulge. The question in each case is: whether persons with practical knowledge and experience of\n\n  the kind of work in which the invention was intended to be used, would understand that strict\n\n  compliance with a particular descriptive word or phrase appearing in a claim was intended by the\n\n  patentee to be an essential requirement of the invention so that <i>any</i> variant would fall\n\n  outside the monopoly claimed, even though it could have no material effect upon the way the\n\n  intervention worked.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">In that case, the plaintiffs were the registered proprietor of a patent for\n\ngalvanised steel lintels for use in the construction industry. Such lintels were used as support\n\nspanning the spaces above the window and door openings in cavity walls built of bricks and had at or\n\nnear the rear vertical support members. The defendants manufactured lintels which were similar to\n\nthose manufactured by the plaintiffs but with the rear support members inclined at six to eight\n\ndegrees. The plaintiffs claimed, inter alia, that the defendants had infringed their patent. At\n\nfirst instance, the trial judge found that defendants had infringed the patent, but the Court of\n\nAppeal reversed this finding. The plaintiffs therefore appealed to the House of Lords, which allowed\n\nthe appeal and held that the defendants had infringed the patent. In dealing with the essential\n\nfeatures of the claim, Lord Diplock said at p 244:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Put in a nutshell the question to be answered is: Would the specification make\n\n  it obvious to a builder familiar with ordinary building operations that the description of a\n\n  lintel in the form of a weight-bearing box girder of which the back plate was referred to as\n\n  \"extending vertically\" from one of the two horizontal plates to join the other, could <i>not</i>\n\n  have been intended to exclude lintels in which the back plate although not positioned at precisely\n\n  90 to both horizontal plates was close enough to 90 to make no material difference to the way\n\n  the lintel worked when used in building operations? No plausible reason has been advanced why any\n\n  rational patentee should want to place so narrow a limitation on his invention. On the contrary,\n\n  to do so would render his monopoly for practical purposes worthless, since any imitator could\n\n  avoid it and take all the benefit of the invention by the simple expedient of positioning the back\n\n  plate a degree or two from the exact vertical.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Essential features</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is necessary to identify the features of the invention\n\nthat are claimed in Claim 1. On the issue of infringement, the claims are the principal determinant,\n\nbut the description and other parts of the specification may assist in the construction of the\n\nclaims.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the main features of Claim 1 are the\n\nfollowing:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) A multiple slot mailbox having a plurality of individual mailboxes, each\n\n  having one postmans trap door on an open panel and one users trap door, i.e. the collection\n\n  door, also on an open panel.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(ii) A trap door stopper is made along the lower edge of each of the postmans\n\n  trap doors for minimising the gap between the trap door stopper and the lower edge of the postmans\n\n  trap door. This trap door stopper has a stopper portion for wedging the lower and outer edge of\n\n  trap door.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(iii) A matrix of orthogonal bars in the interior of mailbox and directly\n\n  behind the postmans trap door for wedging the lower and inner edge of the postmans\n\n  trap door against the inner surface of the stopper portion, when the matrix of orthogonal bars is\n\n  lowered. This matrix of orthogonal bars has (i) as its top member, one universal biasing bar\n\n  spanning the width of the multiple slot mailbox, (ii) as its horizontal members, a plurality of\n\n  parallel anti-junk mail bars, and (iii) as its vertical members, a plurality of parallel bars,\n\n  these vertical bars at the upper end being coupled to the universal biasing bar.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(iv) There is one master lock on the upper front panel and below the universal\n\n  biasing bar, which is used for raising and lowering the matrix of orthogonal bars, whereby all the\n\n  postmans trap doors in the mailboxes can be released and closed simultaneously.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Of all these features, the most essential one is undoubtedly the presence of the\n\nmatrix of orthogonal bars described in item (iii) above. This matrix of orthogonal bars are used to\n\nrelease and close the postmans trap doors. As and when mail is delivered the master lock is\n\nunlocked, and this matrix of orthogonal bars is lifted with the result that the anti-junk mail bars\n\nare in turn lifted, thereby releasing the postmans trap doors. When the master lock is locked,\n\nthe matrix of orthogonal bars is moved down with the result that the anti-junk bars are moved down\n\nblocking the postmans trap doors from being opened, thereby preventing junk mails from being\n\ninserted through the postmans trap doors into the mailboxes.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Differences between the devices</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are clearly differences between the two inventions,\n\nand the principal differences are the following:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) The Flexon invention does not have a matrix of the orthogonal bars. Nor\n\n  does it use a horizontal locking bar to lock the postmans trap doors. It uses stopper screws,\n\n  which are screwed to a vertical bar at one side and do not extend across the entire width of the\n\n  postmans trap doors. This side bar is raised or lowered by a lever at the top. Compared to\n\n  this, the appellants device (as stated in Claim 1) has a matrix of orthogonal bars (described\n\n  above). This whole matrix of orthogonal bars is raised or lowered by the universal biasing bar\n\n  at the top, as the central locking system is locked or unlocked, as the case may be.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) The master lock in the appellants device (as stated in Claim 1) sits\n\n  below the universal biasing bar which, when lifted, moves the entire matrix of orthogonal\n\n  bars upwards or downwards, whereas the master lock in the Flexon device is slotted into a\n\n  horizontal bar-lever at the top and this bar-lever moves the grid upwards and downwards.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) The bar-lever at the top in the Flexon device moves the vertical side bars\n\n  up and down with each 90 degree turn of the key. This feature, however, is absent in the\n\n  appellants device.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">In our opinion, Flexons assembly of mailboxes does not infringe Claim 1 of the\n\nappellants patent.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr Wong Siew Hong, counsel for the appellants, submits that\n\nthe two devices perform the same or similar function, namely, that of preventing junk mails from\n\nbeing delivered into the mailboxes. In this regard, the appellants invention employs a master\n\nlocking mechanism to move up and down a grid, which is located just behind the mailbox doors with\n\nthe horizontal members of the grid, described as anti-junk mail bars, blocking the opening of\n\nthe postmans trap doors, when the devices are in a locked position, thereby preventing the\n\ninsertion of junk mails into the mailboxes. The Flexon device works in exactly the same manner. It\n\nemploys a master locking mechanism to move up and down a grid also mounted behind the mailbox doors\n\nbut with stopper screws, screwed onto the vertical bars at the side to form the horizontal members\n\nof the grid. These stopper screws prevent the inward swing of the postmans trap doors when the\n\ndevices are in a locked position, thereby preventing the insertion of junk mails into the\n\nmailboxes. These stopper screws in the Flexon device therefore perform the same function as the\n\nhorizontal bars, the anti-junk mail bars, in the appellants device.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel therefore relies on the similarity of function of\n\nthe two devices. Both, of course, were designed to prevent the insertion of junk mails into the\n\nmailboxes. The appellants invention uses the matrix of orthogonal bars to lock and unlock the\n\npostmans trap door, whereas the Flexon invention uses the stopper screws for the purpose. Both\n\nperform the same function. Relying on this, counsel argues that, although Claim 1 claims the\n\nessential features which are not found in the Flexon device, the absence of such features in the\n\nlatter is immaterial. The Flexon device is functionally the equivalent of the appellants device.\n\nAdopting a purposive construction, counsel submits that the Flexon device comes within the claims of\n\nClaim 1. We reject the approach.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In coming to this conclusion we find helpful the following\n\npassage of the speech of Lord Upjohn in <i>Rodi &amp; Wienenberger v Henry Showell Ltd</i> (supra)\n\nat p\u00a0391:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">[T]he essential integers having been ascertained, the infringing article must\n\n  be considered. To constitute infringement the article must take each and every one of the\n\n  essential integers of the claim. Non-essential integers may be omitted or replaced by mechanical\n\n  equivalents; there will still be infringement. I believe that this states the whole substance of\n\n  the \"pith and marrow\" theory of infringement. Furthermore, where the invention, as in\n\n  this case, resides in a new combination of known integers but also merely in a new arrangement and\n\n  interaction of ordinary working parts it is not sufficient to shew that the same result is\n\n  reached; the working parts must act on one another in the way claimed in the claim of this patent.\n\n  This is well illustrated by <i>Birmingham Sound Reproducers Ltd v Collaro Ltd</i> [1956] RPC 232\n\n  where Lord Evershed, MR delivering the judgment of the court said at page 245:</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"Thus the essence of the invention resides wholly in the selection and\n\n  arrangement of the parts and the manner in which they interact when arranged in accordance with\n\n  the invention. It is therefore essential to the invention that it should consist of the particular\n\n  parts described in the claim arranged and acting upon each other in the way described in the\n\n  claim.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The question therefore appears to be whether the allegedly infringing apparatus\n\n  consists of substantially the same parts acting upon each other in substantially the same way as\n\n  the apparatus claimed as constituting the invention. It is not enough to find that the parts\n\n  comprised in the respondents apparatus individually or collectively perform substantially\n\n  similar functions to those performed individually or collectively by the parts comprised in the\n\n  apparatus claimed as the appellants invention, or that the respondents apparatus produces\n\n  the same result as the appellants apparatus. It must be shown that the respondents selection\n\n  and arrangement of parts is substantially the same as the appellants selection and arrangements\n\n  of parts, for it is in such selection and arrangement that the appellants invention\n\n  resides.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">26.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The essence of the approach as urged by counsel is to\n\nconstrue the claim wholly functionally. Clearly, this approach is wrong. To construe the claims in\n\nthe manner as urged by counsel would be tantamount to disregarding what is stated in the claims. The\n\nclear and unambiguous words employed in Claim 1 must be given their natural and ordinary meaning.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">27.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should add that the well-known principle that patent\n\nclaims are to be given a purposive construction does not mean that the court in construing a claim\n\nis entitled to disregard the clear and unambiguous words used to describe the essential features of\n\na claim. In <i>Societe Technique de Pulverisation STEP v Emson Europe Ltd </i>[1993] RPC 513 at 522,\n\nHoffmann LJ said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The well-known principle that patent claims are given a purposive construction <i>does\n\n  not mean</i> that an integer can be treated as struck out if it does not appear to make any\n\n  difference to the inventive concept. It may have some other purpose buried in the prior art and\n\n  even if this is not discernible, the patentee may have had some reason of his own for introducing\n\n  it .</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Laddie J in <i>Brugger v Medic-Aid Ltd </i>[1996] RPC 635 at 649, having referred\n\nto the preceding case quoted above, said:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The warning in <i>STEP v Emson</i> cited above has particular relevance here.\n\n  If a patentee has chosen to define the characterising part of his claim in narrow terms it is not\n\n  for the court to rewrite it in broader language simply because it thinks a wider form of wording\n\n  would have been easy to formulate.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Even adopting a purposive construction, one cannot write words into a claim that\n\nare not there or give a meaning to a term of a claim that is contrary to its language. A caution\n\nagainst blurring the purposive construction approach and the re-writing of a claim was given by\n\nGraham J in <i>Rotocrop International Ltd v Genbourne Ltd </i>[1982] FSR 241 at 255:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The question of equivalence and pith and marrow of course only arises in\n\n  doubtful cases. The authorities establish that if it is clear from the description and claims as a\n\n  whole that a particular feature is claimed as and must be regarded as essential to the invention,\n\n  then that is an end of the matter. Either the defendant has taken it or he has not and accordingly\n\n  he has infringed or not as the case may be.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Conclusion</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">28.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To succeed on the infringement of their patent, the\n\nappellants must show that all the essential integers of Claim 1 are present in the respondents\n\ninvention: <i>Rodi &amp; Weinberger AG v Showall (Henry) Ltd </i>[1969] RPC 367 at 391. This they\n\nhave failed to do. Accordingly, their claim failed and the appeal is dismissed with costs. The\n\ndeposit as security for costs, with interest, if any, is to be paid to Flexon or their solicitors to\n\naccount of costs.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<div align=\"left\">\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"2\" width=\"100%\">\n\n      <tr>\n\n        <td </blockquote>\n\n</div>\n\n</font>\n\n\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n
