Paragraph\u00a014-25 states that, \u2018Mere unpermitted possession \u2026 is not a conversion \u2026 But there will be conversion if there is some detention consciously adverse to the rights of the owner, such as assertion of a lien that does not exist\u2019. Naturally, the possession or retention must be wrongful before there can be conversion.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The elements of the tort of deceit were summarised by the Singapore Court of Appeal decision of <i>Kea Holdings Pte Ltd v Gan Boon Hock</i> <nobr>[2000] 3 SLR 129</nobr>, as follows (at [37]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The tort of deceit consists of the wilful making of a false statement with the intent that the plaintiff shall act in reliance upon it and with the result that he does so act and suffers damage in consequence. This damage must be proved by the plaintiff; <i>Diamond v Bank of London and Montreal</i> <nobr>[1979] QB 333.</nobr></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With regard to the equitable duty of confidentiality owed by the respondent to his former employers, the general propositions of law were set out in the House of Lords decision of <i>Prince Jefri Bolkiah v KPMG</i> <nobr>[1999] 2 AC 222</nobr>, as follows (at 235):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whether founded on contract or equity, the duty to preserve confidentiality is unqualified. It is a duty to keep the information confidential, not merely to take all reasonable steps to do so. Moreover, it is not merely a duty not to communicate the information to a third party. It is a duty not to misuse it, that is to say, without the consent of the former client to make any use of it or to cause any use to be made of it by others otherwise than for his benefit.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having set out the relevant elements of each cause of action, we are of the view that each cause of action is at least to some degree dependent upon a determination of the respondent\u2019s precise actions and the events that occurred between the respondent and STB. These factual issues are likely to be in contention between the appellants and the respondent, and it is likely that there will be a considerable reliance on witness testimony so as to establish the version of events posited by each party. It follows from this that the location of the witnesses from STB, who are in Singapore, is a significant factor in favour of Singapore being the more appropriate forum. In particular, the action in deceit and breach of confidentiality would require evidence from the parties that the respondent allegedly made the false statements to. This would include Mr\u00a0Koh and one Mrs\u00a0Pamelia Lee (\u201cMrs\u00a0Lee\u201d), a senior director of STB, both of whom are based in Singapore. Given the likelihood of the appellants\u2019 claims raising a significant number of disputed factual issues, the location of witnesses should be attributed significant weight when assessing the appropriateness of Singapore as a forum for the dispute. It is trite law that a court, when engaging in the enquiry under Stage One, can and should attribute <i>differing</i> weight to each connecting factor depending on the nature of the particular dispute. This was recognised in the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Andre Ravindran S\u00a0Arul v Tunku Ibrahim Ismail bin Sultan Iskandar Al-Haj</i> <nobr>[2001] SGHC 209</nobr>, where Choo Han Teck\u00a0JC (as he then was) held (at [8]) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The determination of the appropriate forum is not an exercise carried out merely by adding the sum total of all the relevant connecting factors. The court has to apportion a value to each factor and consider its place in the overall picture.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The importance of the witnesses from STB was, in fact, implicitly acknowledged by the Judge, who noted (at [28] of the GD) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As regards the plaintiffs\u2019 allegation of breach of equitable and fiduciary duties and deceit, the plaintiffs asserted, <i>inter alia</i>, that [the respondent] had withheld information from his principal and had also disclosed price-sensitive information to the Singapore Tourism Board (\u201cSTB\u201d), which was the eventual buyer of the Tang cargo.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Ultimately, however, the Judge found that the location of the witnesses was not an important factor. The Judge stated (at [57] of the GD):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As regards the point that witnesses like Mr\u00a0Koh and Mrs\u00a0Lee are not compellable to attend in Germany or would also have to fly to Germany, I noted that the German court had already sought the attendance of Mr\u00a0Koh with regard to [the respondent\u2019s] claims. If he chooses not to fly there, it does not mean all is lost for the plaintiffs because there should be avenues for his evidence to be taken in Singapore. Mr\u00a0Bull did not suggest that such avenues are absent and I reiterate that Rickshaw itself had envisaged that allegations of [the respondent\u2019s] misconduct be heard by a German court, although this was in the context of their defence to [the respondent\u2019s] claims.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we disagree with the Judge, as we find that the location of the witnesses is an important factor to be considered, and the fact that key witnesses are located in Singapore is a factor that points towards Singapore being the most natural forum to hear the substantive disputes. The assessment of the respective witnesses\u2019 credibility is also crucial \u2013 especially in so far as the claim for fraudulent misrepresentation or deceit is concerned. Indeed, in so far as the claims for breach of fiduciary duty and breach of confidence are concerned, the principal witnesses (as we have already noted at [23] above) are located in Singapore. It is significant, in our view, that they are <i>clearly</i></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">compellable to testify in the Singapore proceedings, whereas this is not the case in so far as the German proceedings are concerned.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The location and compellability of the relevant witnesses were also key issues in dispute in the affidavit of Narayan, a director of the first appellant, that was admitted as fresh evidence, and in the respondent\u2019s skeletal submissions in reply to the fresh evidence adduced. Annexed to Narayan\u2019s affidavit were the submissions of the respondent\u2019s German counsel to the German court (\u201cthe German submissions\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 According to the appellants, the German submissions revealed that the respondent had taken the position before the German court that the court should hear key witnesses such as Mr\u00a0Koh, Mrs\u00a0Lee and one Ms\u00a0Tania Wolff in person. This would give these witnesses the opportunity to prove their credibility. The appellants used this contradiction to cast doubts on the respondent\u2019s credibility and, more importantly, to show that even the respondent had acknowledged the importance of the physical presence of the key witnesses in court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In reply, the respondent pointed out, firstly, that the first appellant had requested that the German court dismiss the respondent\u2019s claim based on the briefs filed and the evidence that was already before the German court. The first appellant was therefore acknowledging that it was unnecessary for the witnesses to give evidence for the disposal of the proceedings. Secondly, under the German Code of Procedure, evidence could be taken from witnesses residing abroad either by way of written statements or before a German consul. Thirdly, there was no suggestion that any of the first appellant\u2019s witnesses were unco-operative or unwilling to travel to Germany. Fourthly, documentary evidence from the witnesses residing in Singapore could easily be produced in Germany.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the fresh evidence and attendant reply submissions did not significantly add to the evidence that was already before this court. However, it did reveal that the German court was of the similar view that the assessment of the credibility of the witnesses was important, and that their physical presence in the court hearing the matter was therefore desirable. We do not make too much of the fact that the first appellant had tried to dispose of the respondent\u2019s claim in Germany based on the evidence that was <i>already</i> before the German court. This could have been the result of a legal strategy that was taken precisely because the first appellant\u2019s German counsel realised that there could be difficulty in compelling the key witnesses to attend court proceedings in Germany. In any event, this evidence confirmed our view that the location and the compellability of the witnesses were important to the effective adjudication of the substantive actions between the appellants and the respondent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning next to the jurisdictional connections of the parties involved, we note that the first appellant was incorporated in the Cayman Islands. The first appellant has two directors \u2013 Narayan and one Tilman Walterfang (\u201cWalterfang\u201d), a German national who is resident in New Zealand. The first appellant uses its related Singapore registered company, Seabed Explorations Pte Ltd, as a vehicle for its Singapore operations. The second appellant is a German partnership. Walterfang is one of the partners. The other partner, Draeger, is a German national who resides in Germany. However, the second appellant has transferred all of its assets to the first appellant and is only joined as a party to ensure that all the parties are before the court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent is a German citizen who currently resides in Germany. He is a permanent resident of Singapore and he was resident in Singapore at the time the alleged tortious acts and equitable breaches took place. The respondent has a bank account with the Development Bank of Singapore. Further, it is significant that the second appellant had initially hired the respondent as its agent because the respondent had represented that he had connections in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In addition, the German submissions, which were adduced as fresh evidence before this court, stated (at p\u00a08) as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[The respondent] was born in Japan and grew up in Japan and Singapore. To date he has spent a total of [approximately] 22 years of his life in Singapore where he is still resident today. ...</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[The respondent\u2019s] family had good business relations in Eastern and South-East Asia, particularly in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the respondent\u2019s reply skeletal submissions on further evidence, he only sought to clarify that he is now residing in Germany. The rest of the statement quoted above remains undisputed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In April 2003, the first appellant hired a Singapore-registered company, Davka Pte Ltd (\u201cDavka\u201d), to assist in the respondent\u2019s negotiations with STB. Davka was hired at the respondent\u2019s request. Although Davka is not a party to the proceedings, the fact that it is located and operates in Singapore further cements the notion that the respondent had contacts in, and ties to, Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Hence, having considered the circumstances of the case, we are of the view that the above connecting factors point towards Singapore as the appropriate forum to hear the substantive actions.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Whether the natural and most appropriate forum is that in which the tort occurred</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the trial below, the appellants relied on the case of <i>Cordoba Shipping Co Ltd v National State Bank, Elizabeth, New Jersey (The Albaforth)</i> [1984] 2\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 91 (\u201c<i>Albaforth</i>\u201d), which states that the place where a tort occurred is <i>prima facie</i> the natural forum for determining the claim. According to the appellants, the <i>Albaforth</i> principle illustrates the application of the more general <i>Spiliada</i> principles to a particular fact situation (here, where a tort has occurred within the jurisdiction). This principle was accepted by the House of Lords in <i>Berezovsky v Michaels</i> <nobr>[2000] 1 WLR 1004</nobr> (\u201c<i>Berezovsky</i>\u201d) as well as by the English High Court in <i>Caltex Singapore Pte Ltd v BP Shipping Ltd</i> [1996] 1\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 286 and <i>The Xin Yang and An Kang Jiang</i> [1996] 2\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 217 (\u201c<i>The Xin Yang</i>\u201d), and has been applied locally by the Singapore High Court in the case of <i>Evergreen International SA v Volkswagen Group Singapore Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2004] 2 SLR 457.</nobr> The appellants contended that all the elements of the respondent\u2019s alleged tortious acts occurred in Singapore, and therefore that the <i>Albaforth</i> principle should be given its full weight. Following from this, the appellants submitted that since the tort claims should be heard in Singapore, it made sense that the claims in equity should be heard in Singapore as well, so that the claims could be heard together.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent dealt with these arguments by submitting that the strength of the <i>Albaforth</i> principle depends on the facts of every case: <i>The Forum Craftsman</i> [1985] 1\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 291. The strength of the presumption in every case turns upon the likely issues in dispute: <i>The Xin Yang</i>. This is consistent with the approach in <i>Spiliada</i> of determining the best forum to decide the case in the interests of the parties and to achieve the ends of justice. In the present case, an analysis of the alleged causes of action would not be either simple or clear. At the hearing before us, the appellants made the cogent rebuttal that <i>The Forum Craftsman</i> was distinguishable as Ackner\u00a0LJ had made it clear that the <i>Albaforth</i> principle did not apply to torts that were committed on moving vehicles such as ships and aeroplanes, which was not the case here.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, a close reading of <i>Albaforth</i> and <i>Berezovksy</i> does indeed support the appellants\u2019 contention that, as a general rule, the place where a tort occurred is <i>prima facie</i> the natural forum for determining the claim. Lord Steyn\u2019s judgment in <i>Berezovsky</i> sought to accommodate the <i>Albaforth</i> principle within the traditional <i>Spiliada</i> formulation. His Lordship opined that while Lord\u00a0Goff of Chieveley\u2019s analysis in <i>Spiliada</i> sought to explore and explain the legal principles and provide guidance, it did not examine exhaustively the classes of cases that could arise in practice. The principle contained in <i>Albaforth</i>, on the other hand, was concerned with \u201cpractical problems at a much lower level of generality\u201d (<i>Berezovsky</i> at 1014). His Lordship also suggested that there was a very fine distinction between a <i>prima facie</i> position, <i>ie</i>,</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">considering the place where the tort occurred as the <i>prima facie</i> natural forum, and treating the same factor as a weighty circumstance pointing towards a particular forum.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>Albaforth</i> principle was also confirmed in <i>The Xin Yang</i>, where Clarke\u00a0J emphasised that the place where the tort occurred is of some significance as a pointer towards the natural forum, even if the parties have limited connection with that jurisdiction. Importantly, however, Clarke\u00a0J\u2019s approach suggests that the result reached by applying the <i>Albaforth</i> principle is only one of the factors to be considered in the <i>Spiliada</i> balancing exercise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our opinion, the principle articulated in <i>Albaforth</i> is logical and sound, and should be applied in Singapore. As Robert Goff\u00a0LJ (as he then was) stated in <i>Albaforth</i></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">(at 96):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[W]here it is held that a Court has jurisdiction on the basis that an alleged tort has been committed within the jurisdiction of the Court, the test which has been satisfied in order to reach that conclusion is one founded on the basis that the Court, so having jurisdiction, is the most appropriate Court to try the claim, where it is manifestly just and reasonable that the defendant should answer for his wrongdoing. This being so, it must usually be difficult in any particular case to resist the conclusion that a Court which has jurisdiction on that basis must also be the natural forum for the trial of the action. If the substance of an alleged tort is committed within a certain jurisdiction, it is not easy to imagine what other facts could displace the conclusion that the Courts of that jurisdiction are the natural forum.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we must emphasise that the result that is arrived at through the application of the <i>Albaforth</i> principle is only the <i>prima facie</i> position and/or a weighty factor pointing in favour of that jurisdiction. Applying this to the present case, the fact that the respondent\u2019s alleged torts were committed in Singapore does point towards Singapore as being the natural forum to hear the dispute, but this is only one of the factors to be taken into account in the overall analysis, albeit a significant one.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We do note, however, that the respondent did suggest that, in so far at least as the tort of fraudulent misrepresentation or deceit was concerned, this may not have in fact been committed (if at all) in Singapore. However, as we point out below (at [72]), such an argument was, with respect, unclear \u2013 especially in terms of specific detail. We deal, in fact, with this particular argument in the context of the issue of choice of law below (at [72]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Choice of law</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Introduction</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Choice of law issues are relevant even to a question of jurisdiction. The relevance of choice of law considerations in a <i>jurisdictional</i> enquiry regarding the \u201cnatural forum\u201d lies in the general proposition that where a dispute is governed by a foreign <i>lex causae</i>, the forum would be less adept in applying this law than the courts of the jurisdiction from which the <i>lex causae</i> originates. While it is true that the courts of a country (for example, Singapore courts) can apply the laws of another country (for example, German law) to a dispute, there will clearly be savings in time and resources if a court applies the law of its own jurisdiction to the substantive dispute. Hence, choice of law considerations can be a significant factor in determining the appropriate forum to hear a dispute.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Choice of law questions raise a related issue regarding a party\u2019s evidential burden to plead foreign law. In <i>Goh Chok Tong v Tang Liang Hong</i> <nobr>[1997] 2 SLR 641</nobr>, Lai Kew Chai\u00a0J pointed pertinently to <i>the need for foreign law to be pleaded</i>, and held that if foreign law was not in fact pleaded, it would be presumed to be the same as the relevant position under Singapore law (see generally at [77]\u2013[84], and especially at [79]): see also <i>Ertel Bieber and Company</i> <i>v Rio Tinto Company, Limited</i> <nobr>[1918] AC 260</nobr> at 294\u2013295. Where this evidentiary presumption can be invoked, the applicability of a foreign <i>lex causae</i> under choice of law rules may therefore be reduced in significance since the forum is unlikely to have difficulty applying a foreign law which is (assumed to be) identical to the <i>lex fori</i>. In this regard, however, a number of cases suggest that a court may, despite a party\u2019s failure to adduce proof of foreign law, have regard to the fact that the principles in the foreign jurisdiction concerned will, in all likelihood, differ from the <i>lex fori</i> in some respects (see, for example, the Singapore High Court decision of <i>PT\u00a0Jaya Putra Kundur Indah v Guthrie Overseas Investments Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1996] SGHC 285</nobr> at [44] (\u201c<i>PT Jaya</i>\u201d)). Hence, in the present case, the mere factum of a foreign <i>lex causae</i>, <i>ie</i>, German law, may be accorded due weight <i>despite</i> the respondent\u2019s failure to adduce evidence regarding the content of this law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present proceedings, the appellants\u2019 arguments relating to choice of law can be briefly summarised as such: The choice of law provision in the Employment Agreement was not exclusive and pertained only to questions arising from the employment contract. Hence, the Judge should have applied common law choice of law principles. These principles would have led to the conclusion that Singapore law should be applied. The existence of the Employment Agreement did not detract from the applicability of these general principles. Before us, the respondent did not dispute that the choice of law clause is non-exclusive. Instead, he focused his arguments on the choice of law rules that should apply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The relevance (if any) of the Employment Agreement</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A crucial consideration that weighed with the Judge was what he perceived to be the appellants\u2019 attempt to avoid the governing law provision in the Employment Agreement (\u201cthe governing law provision\u201d). As he put it (at [42] of the GD):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 I did not think it was sufficient for Mr\u00a0Bull to rely on the principle that it was for the plaintiffs to choose whether to sue in contract or tort. The real issue was whether the plaintiffs can avoid the governing law provision in the 30\u00a0June 2003 agreement by couching their causes of action outside of contract even though the duties allegedly owed by [the respondent] arose from his contractual appointment and the alleged breaches arose in the course of his performance of his contractual obligations.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This concern was reiterated by the Judge a little later on in the judgment (see the GD at [45]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, however, absent bad faith on the part of the appellants, we see no reason why they should be denied the freedom of choice to frame their causes of action in the way they have. This has in fact been made clear in the case law. It is, for example, established law that the mere presence of a contractual relationship does not in itself preclude the existence of an <i>independent</i> duty of care in tort: see the leading House of Lords decision of <i>Henderson v Merrett Syndicates Ltd</i> <nobr>[1995] 2 AC 145</nobr> as well as the decision of this court in <i>The Jian He</i> <nobr>[2000] 1 SLR 8</nobr> at [26]. Liability can exist concurrently in tort and contract, and provided that the latter does not expressly limit or exclude the former, a plaintiff is free to choose whichever is more advantageous to him: see <i>Midland Bank Trust Co Ltd v Hett, Stubbs &amp; Kemp</i> <nobr>[1979] Ch 384.</nobr></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are of the view that the appellants had the right to avail themselves of the cause of action that was most advantageous to them, <i>inter alia</i>, in the light of choice of law considerations. Given the way they were framed, their claims must be treated as claims in tort, and the fact that the respondent\u2019s actions arose from his contract becomes irrelevant for the purposes of characterising the issues involved. It is certainly the case that the respondent\u2019s actions were carried out in the course of his employment and in the course of performing his contractual obligations. Indeed, his actions probably also constituted breaches of implied terms of the employment contract. However, even while this is true, his actions incurred <i>tortious</i> liability that existed independently of, and concurrently with, his <i>contractual</i> obligations and breaches thereof. In other words, although the allegedly tortious acts were committed in the course of the respondent\u2019s employment <i>in fact</i>, the acts had a separate <i>legal</i> existence from his contractual obligations and breaches thereof. In this regard, we also note the following observations by Robert Goff\u00a0LJ (as he then was) (and with whom both Oliver and Waller\u00a0LJJ agreed) in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Coupland v Arabian Gulf Oil Co</i> <nobr>[1983] 1 WLR 1136</nobr> at 1153 (significantly, Goff\u00a0LJ was also to deliver the leading judgment (as Lord\u00a0Goff of Chieveley) in <i>Henderson v Merrett Syndicates Ltd</i>:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The plaintiff can advance his claim, as he wishes, either in contract or in tort; and no doubt he will, acting on advice, advance the claim on the basis which is most advantageous to him. It appears that he is likely to proceed primarily on the basis of his claim in tort [as opposed to contract], for reasons which I suspect are connected with the assessment of damages.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, this is not to state that the governing law provision is necessarily irrelevant since the appellants\u2019 <i>other</i> claims may, for choice of law purposes, nevertheless be characterised as issues arising in the realm of contract. As we shall see, where the appellants\u2019 cause of action in <i>equity</i> is concerned, the issue arises as to whether or not, <i>assuming</i> that equity does not constitute (in and of itself) an <i>independent</i> category with its own choice of law rules, the choice of law rules relating to <i>contract</i> should be invoked instead for, <i>ex hypothesi</i>, one would not be able to characterise the respective causes of action by reference to equity. In <i>such</i> a situation, the Employment Agreement in general and the governing law provision in particular would be relevant since, unlike their claims against the respondent in tort, the appellants\u2019 claims against the respondent in equity ought to be <i>characterised differently</i>. But this is a quite different situation compared to the bare proposition that litigants such as the appellants are <i>ipso facto</i> prevented from framing their respective causes of action the way they did (here, in tort) merely because by doing so, they would be avoiding the governing law provision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We pause here to note, parenthetically, that, in so far as the <i>German proceedings</i> are concerned, even taking the respondent\u2019s case at its highest, the <i>German</i> court would <i>necessarily</i> have to take into account <i>the allegations of misconduct against the respondent \u2013 which allegations constitute the very pith and marrow of the Singapore proceedings</i> mounted by the appellants against the respondent, and which are in fact the focus of the present proceedings. In other words, the <i>fundamental legal and factual substratum</i> of the appellants\u2019defence in the <i>German</i> proceedings comprises the allegations of misconduct against the respondent. If these allegations are proved, then the appellants would be exonerated in so far as the German proceedings are concerned (bearing in mind that the alleged wrongful termination of the Employment Agreement constitutes the main thrust of the German proceedings, one of the remaining two claims having been largely satisfied, with the final claim being (in effect) a request for information). The contrary result would of course obtain if the allegations are not in fact proved. That this ought \u2013 and, indeed, would \u2013 be the situation is acknowledged by counsel for the respondent, Mr\u00a0Leung Wing Wah, himself (see the GD at [33] and [34]). So it seems to us, without even speculating what the German court might do (which is impermissible in any event), that our decision on the relevant choice of law principles that would govern the respective claims of the appellants in the Singapore proceedings would be of at least <i>some</i> relevance to the German court \u2013 based on principles of comity, if nothing else. <i>More importantly</i>, it seems to us clear that the German court would also take into account the findings of <i>fact</i> of the Singapore court, particularly since the factual context \u2013 at least, as we shall see, in so far as the action in conversion is concerned \u2013 took place in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to the issues at hand, we turn now to consider what the relevant principles of choice of law are with respect to the various claims brought by the appellants against the respondent in the present (Singapore) proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The claims in tort</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">GENERAL PRINCIPLES</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, first, to the claims in <i>tort</i>, there are in fact two separate causes of action pleaded. One is in <i>conversion</i>, the other for <i>fraudulent misrepresentation or deceit</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On a <i>general</i> level, however, the principles which obtain with regard to the issue of the choice of law in tort in the Singapore context are clear. These are embodied in the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d. Put simply, this rule states that in order for a tort to be actionable in Singapore, the alleged wrong must be actionable not only under the law of the forum (the <i>lex fori</i>) but also under the law of the place where the wrong was in fact committed (the <i>lex loci delicti</i>). In other words, both these limbs must be satisfied.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As Prof\u00a0Adrian Briggs pointed out helpfully, the original rule centred on the former limb only (<i>viz</i>, relating to the <i>lex fori</i>) as \u201c[n]o doubt the historical reason for such a view was the closeness between torts and criminal wrongs, in that both involved breaches of duties not voluntarily undertaken, and in such cases the forum\u2019s own standards of justice should prevail\u201d (see Adrian Briggs, \u201cTort in the Conflict of Laws\u201d (1989) 105\u00a0LQR 359 at 359). This view was, as the learned author points out (<i>ibid</i>), later modified by the House of Lords in <i>Boys v Chaplin</i> <nobr>[1971] AC 356</nobr> to include the second limb (<i>viz</i>, relating to the <i>lex loci delicti</i>). Such an approach, modifying the bias towards parochialism in general and the <i>lex fori</i> in particular, was adopted more than three decades ago. Such an underlying spirit is, of course, even more needful today.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The oft-cited starting point is the English decision of <i>Phillips v Eyre</i> (1870) LR\u00a06 QB 1, where Willes\u00a0J observed thus (at 28\u201329):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As a general rule, in order to found a suit in England for a wrong alleged to have been committed abroad, two conditions must be fulfilled. First, the wrong must be of such a character that it would have been actionable if committed in England; \u2026 Secondly, the act must not have been justifiable by the law of the place where it was done.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The \u201cmodern\u201d starting point, however, is the House of Lords decision in <i>Boys v Chaplin</i> ([54] <i>supra</i>). Although it confirmed the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d, a close perusal of the various judgments delivered is, with respect, apt to lead to at least a modicum of uncertainty. An excellent summary of the various judgments (and accompanying differences) can be found in Yeo Tiong Min, \u201cTort Choice of Law Beyond the <i>Red Sea</i>: Whither the <i>Lex Fori</i>?\u201d (1997) 1\u00a0Sing\u00a0J\u00a0Int\u2019l &amp; Comp\u00a0L\u00a091 at 92\u201393. The various complications need not detain us, as there is a subsequent Hong Kong Privy Council decision which helped to clarify the position, particularly with regard to the ambit of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d: see <i>Red Sea Insurance Co Ltd v Bouygues SA</i> <nobr>[1995] 1 AC 190</nobr> (\u201cthe <i>Red Sea</i> case\u201d). The <i>Red Sea</i> case has been held by this court to be the law in Singapore: see <i>Parno v SC Marine Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1999] 4 SLR 579</nobr> at [36], citing and applying the Singapore High Court decision in <i>Goh Chok Tong v Tang Liang Hong</i> ([43] <i>supra</i>). What the <i>Red Sea</i> case now establishes is that the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d applies, but subject to the exception (first laid down by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Boys v Chaplin</i> (at 391)) that, under certain circumstances, the tort might nevertheless be actionable in Singapore even though one of the limbs (mentioned at [53] above) is not satisfied. Indeed, in <i>Boys v Chaplin</i> itself, the second limb (relating to actionability under the <i>lex loci delicti</i>) was not satisfied. What the <i>Red Sea</i> case effected was a symmetry which also recognised the operation of the exception even when the second limb (relating to actionability under the <i>lex fori</i>) had not been satisfied (Prof\u00a0Adrian Briggs aptly terms the resultant rule as \u201cone of double actionability subject to double flexibility\u201d: see Adrian Briggs, \u201c<i>The Halley</i>: Holed, but Still Afloat?\u201d (1995) 111\u00a0LQR 18 at 21). Such an approach is, of course, consistent with the tenets of globalisation and internationalisation that now accompany the central idea of comity (together with the corresponding need to eschew parochialism). Indeed, the decision in the <i>Red Sea</i> case paves the way for the <i>lex causae</i> of a tort to be the law of a <i>third</i> jurisdiction (other than the <i>lex fori</i> or the <i>lex loci delicti</i>), which has the most significant relationship with the occurrence and with the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The central difficulty with such an exception, however, is that an overly liberal application of it might lead, in effect, to an emasculation or even <i>de facto</i> abolition of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d and may, in the worst case scenario, result in a \u201cproper law of the tort\u201d approach instead (<i>cf</i> also Briggs ([56] <i>supra</i> at 20)). This is the perennial danger when exceptions are made to existing rules. Yet, such exceptions are both inevitable and (more importantly) necessary, lest an ossified set of rules result, which will invariably lead to injustice and unfairness. For example, if the parties and other connecting factors have nothing to do with the place where the tort was actually committed (<i>ie</i>, that that place merely happened to be fortuitous), then it would appear both just and fair to hold that the fact that the second limb of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d (that the wrong also be actionable under the <i>lex loci delicti</i>) is not satisfied should not prejudice the plaintiff\u2019s claim. Indeed, what is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander. Hence, by the same token, if the same scenario obtains, but in relation to the <i>lex fori</i> instead, then it would also appear both just and fair to hold that the fact that the first limb of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d (that the wrong also be actionable under the <i>lex fori</i>) is not satisfied should (equally) not prejudice the plaintiff\u2019s claim. Indeed, where the parties and other connecting factors have nothing to do with either the place where the action is brought (here, Singapore) and the place where the wrong was committed, a <i>third</i> possible law might govern the action concerned (as alluded to at the end of the preceding paragraph). The overriding consideration is that a just result be achieved.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nevertheless, in order that the exception might not \u201coverwhelm\u201d the rule (here, the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d), it is imperative that the exception be strictly applied. It is perhaps less than useful to state that this will depend on the precise facts of the case at hand, but there does not, in our view, appear to be any better way of stating the parameters of the exception. As one learned commentator aptly put it, \u201c[t]he scope of the exception to the \u2018general rule\u2019 to which their Lordships have had resort in the <i>Red Sea</i> \u2026 case <i>cannot be defined with pedantic precision</i>\u201d [emphasis added] (see P\u00a0B\u00a0Carter, \u201cChoice of Law in Tort: The Role of the <i>Lex Fori</i>\u201d <nobr>[1995] CLJ 38</nobr> at 39). The important point is, rather, one of <i>attitude</i>. In other words, the Singapore courts must not be quick to apply the exception unless the <i>lex fori</i> and/or the <i>lex loci delicti</i> are purely fortuitous and the application of either or both limbs of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d would result in injustice and unfairness. The Singapore courts \u2013 indeed, any court in any jurisdiction \u2013 would, in our view, be well-equipped to analyse any given fact situation based on these criteria.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The more difficult question that arises, however, is whether or not a <i>local tort</i> (<i>ie</i>, a tort committed (here) in <i>Singapore</i>) would be subject to this exception. Indeed, at a threshold level, it might be asked whether a local tort ought to be subject to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d in the first place. In this last-mentioned regard, it might be argued that this is a moot point since, even if the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d applies, there would <i>not</i> be a <i>practical</i> difference since both the <i>lex fori</i> and the <i>lex loci delicti</i> would be the <i>same</i> (<i>ie</i>, <i>Singapore</i> law). This being the case, the rule would be satisfied in any event (reference may also be made, in this regard, to the English decisions in <i>Szalatnay-Stacho v Fink</i> <nobr>[1947] KB 1</nobr> and <i>Metall und Rohstoff AG v Donaldson Lufkin &amp; Jenrette Inc</i> <nobr>[1990] 1 QB 391</nobr> (\u201c<i>Metall und Rohstoff</i>\u201d)). The more pertinent question, perhaps, is whether or not the <i>exception</i> to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d (most fully articulated, as we have seen, in the <i>Red Sea</i> case) applies even in the context of a <i>local tort</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The point appears to have been left open in a leading work, although it appears, in the final analysis, to <i>lean</i> <i>against</i> the application of the exception in the context of a local tort (see Sir\u00a0Peter North &amp; J\u00a0J\u00a0Fawcett, <i>Cheshire and North\u2019s Private International Law</i> (Butterworths, 13th\u00a0Ed, 1999) at pp\u00a0613\u2013614). The learned authors do in fact consider the <i>Red Sea</i> case, but point out (see <i>ibid</i>):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the Privy Council in the <i>Red Sea</i> case there is no mention at all of the position in relation to torts committed in England. This case was concerned, in effect, with the displacement of English law by that of the foreign law of the place where the tort was committed and not with the displacement of the English law of the place where the tort was committed by a foreign law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, it is then admitted that (see p\u00a0614):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Arguably, though</span></i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">, the decision [in the <i>Red Sea</i> case] <i>raises a question mark</i> over the position in respect of torts committed in England in that it accepts for the first time that a flexible exception may lead to the displacement of English law by a foreign law. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nevertheless, the learned authors conclude thus (see <i>ibid</i>):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Nonetheless, it must remain doubtful</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">whether an exception would ever be held to operate in the situation where a tort is committed in England. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The views expressed in the preceding paragraph notwithstanding, the need to ensure that the requirements of comity are observed and the corresponding need to avoid unwarranted parochialism would appear to suggest that the exception ought to apply, even in the context of local torts. In this regard, we note that one learned scholar (see Yeo ([56] <i>supra</i>) at 110\u2013111) has expressed the view that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Before [the] <i>Red Sea</i> [case] \u2026 given the paramountcy of the <i>lex fori</i> \u2026 the <i>lex fori</i> rule for local torts made some sense. Since the <i>lex fori</i> coincided with the <i>lex loci delicti</i>, and it was not yet possible to have an exception to the application of the <i>lex fori</i>, it was only sensible to short-circuit the process in favour of a simple <i>lex fori</i> rule. \u2026 However, the only justification for reserving such inhibitions to torts committed within the jurisdiction can be forum preference, and any dimunition of the present role of the <i>lex fori</i> may shed some needed light in this area. Once the inhibitions are openly confronted, the dichotomy of treatment between local and foreign torts will prove difficult to justify.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In other words, it might, in certain exceptional circumstances, be possible for a law <i>other than Singapore law</i> to apply, even in the case of a local tort. Although the <i>Red Sea</i> case did not <i>in fact</i> relate to a situation involving a local tort, the <i>general principles</i> contained therein would, in our view, apply equally in the context of local torts. In particular, the rationale underlying the exception in so far as <i>foreign</i> torts are concerned (brief illustrations of which have been given at [55] above) would, in our view, apply <i>equally</i> (as a matter of both principle and logic) to <i>local</i> torts as well. We have in mind, in particular, the situation where the fact that the tort has been committed in Singapore is a <i>wholly fortuitous</i> <i>happenstance</i> that has nothing whatsoever to do with every other aspect of the case concerned. In such a situation, it would seem to us to be neither just nor fair to insist that the exception should be excluded and that Singapore law should apply. In this regard, we do not see any distinction in either logic or principle between the situation concerning a foreign tort and that concerning a local tort.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is true that there is authority which suggests that where a <i>local</i> tort is concerned, the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d does not apply and that the <i>lex fori</i> would, presumably, apply instead (see, for example, <i>Metall und Rohstoff</i> ([59] <i>supra</i>), especially at 445\u2013447 as well as the Supreme Court of Canada decision of <i>Interprovincial Co-operatives Ltd v The Queen in Right of Manitoba</i> (1975) 53\u00a0DLR (3d) 321 at 339\u2013340). As just mentioned, however, such an approach militates not only against both principle and logic but also against considerations of comity as well. Most importantly, however, and as already argued above, such an approach could, on occasion, lead to actual injustice \u2013 especially where (as already mentioned) the fact that the tort was committed in Singapore was <i>purely fortuitous</i>. Indeed, a blanket and blatant predilection for the <i>lex fori</i> is no longer sustainable \u2013 especially during present times. It also bears repeating that in the <i>ordinary</i> course of events, application of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d to <i>local</i> torts will not in fact result in any difference from both practical as well as conceptual points of view (see also [59] above). In any event, even if the focus is on the <i>lex fori</i>, an <i>exception</i> ought, as already argued above, to be made for situations where the fact that the tort was committed in Singapore was purely fortuitous. If so, then there would be very little difference (if any) in substance between that particular approach and the application of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Our only concern was whether or not an <i>even stricter</i> approach ought to be taken in applying the exception to <i>local</i> torts compared to <i>foreign</i> torts. On further reflection, we do not see why this ought to be the case. This follows from the general reasoning canvassed in the last part of the preceding paragraph. Indeed, to apply the exception in a stricter fashion to local torts (as opposed to foreign torts) would in fact undermine the general need for comity which is an integral part of the jurisprudence relating to the conflict of laws. But we need to underscore one point: The exception to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d is precisely that and must be applied only when the factual matrix as well as the justice and fairness of the case warrant it. A liberal approach must be eschewed, lest the structure and integrity of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d be undermined or (worse still) destroyed. Whatever the relative merits (or otherwise) of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d, it is still the law in Singapore. Indeed, a wise and judicious application of the exception in appropriate cases will ensure that the retention of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d does not place the Singapore courts in a less advantageous position compared to other jurisdictions, such as the United Kingdom where the law has been reformed. The following wise counsel by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Boys v Chaplin</i> ([54] <i>supra</i> at 391) bears repeating:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It [the exception] will not be invoked in every case or even, probably, in many cases. The general rule must apply unless clear and satisfying grounds are shown why it should be departed from and what solution, derived from what other rule, should be preferred. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The above observations were, not surprisingly, reiterated in the <i>Red Sea</i> case ([56] <i>supra</i> at 206). In any event, any abolition or reform of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d is, if at all, a subject for <i>legislative</i> reform. Reference may be made, in this particular regard, to the Report of the Law Reform Committee of the Singapore Academy of Law entitled <i>Reform of the Choice of Law Rule Relating to Torts</i> (31\u00a0March 2003) where, with the exception of claims in defamation, it was recommended that the requirement for actionability by the law of the forum (<i>viz</i>, the <i>lex fori</i>) be abrogated and that the choice of law rule be the law where the act was done (<i>viz</i>, the <i>lex loci delicti</i>) <i>and</i> that <i>a flexible exception</i> to the choice of law rule may be invoked in exceptional circumstances, allowing the court to apply the law of a country that is significantly connected with the tort (a preference for this approach was also expressed by Woo Bih Li\u00a0J in the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Ang Ming Chuang v Singapore Airlines Ltd</i> <nobr>[2005] 1 SLR 409</nobr> at [50]). We would only pause to observe that, in <i>practical</i> terms, the flexibility accorded by the wise and judicious use of the <i>flexible exception</i> to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d ensures that the court concerned would, nevertheless, be able to achieve a just and fair result in the meantime even if the law is not reformed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would be appropriate to turn now to the application of the principles considered in this part of the judgment to the respective heads of claim the appellants have raised in the tortious context.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">THE\u00a0CLAIM\u00a0IN CONVERSION</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, first, to the appellants\u2019 claim in conversion, there is no doubt that the <i>lex fori</i> is Singapore law. It seems to us also clear that, having regard to the facts of the present case in general and the location of the 25 pieces of the Tang Cargo alleged to have been converted by the respondent in particular, that the <i>lex loci delicti</i> is also Singapore law. To all intents and purposes, therefore, the <i>lex causae</i> for the claim in conversion would appear to <i>prima facie</i> be Singapore law exclusively.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">69\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, Mr\u00a0Leung argued that the respondent would be relying on a <i>defence</i> that had its source in the Employment Agreement, which is governed by German law (<i>cf</i> also <i>Coupland v Arabian Gulf Oil Co</i> ([48] <i>supra</i>) at 1153). This alleged defence is, however, both vague and unclear. No specific term of the Employment Agreement was referred to. The argument against Singapore being the natural forum by reason of the need to apply a foreign <i>lex causae</i> would therefore appear to be of negligible significance.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">70\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are also of the view that the exception to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d does not apply in the context of the present claim. Indeed, as we have already observed, most of the relevant connecting factors relate to Singapore (as opposed to Germany).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">THE CLAIM FOR FRAUDULENT MISREPRESENTATION OR DECEIT</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">71</span><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Turning, next, to the appellants\u2019 claim based on the tort of fraudulent misrepresentation or deceit, it is first of all clear that the <i>lex fori</i> for this claim would be Singapore law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">72\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, Mr\u00a0Leung argued that (contrary to counsel for the appellants, Mr\u00a0Cavinder Bull\u2019s, assertion) the <i>lex loci delicti</i> was not Singapore law as the alleged misrepresentations were actionable where they had been received and that they had been received in either Germany or New Zealand, and not in Singapore (<i>cf</i> the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Diamond v Bank of London and Montreal Ltd</i> <nobr>[1979] QB 333</nobr> at 345\u2013346). However, the fact of the matter was that it was not clear, on the pleadings, <i>where</i> the alleged misrepresentations were in fact received. This is not surprising in view of the fact that only the appellants\u2019 statement of claim is available. The respondent had, not surprisingly, applied for a stay without filing a defence. On this fact alone, we are inclined to the view that the respondent\u2019s argument in this regard, whilst ingenious, is rather speculative. Further, as with the claim in conversion, the respondent has not adduced any evidence as to why the exception to the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d should apply in the context of the present proceedings. Hence, both limbs of the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d apply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">CONCLUSION</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">73</span><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">It is clear, from the analysis above, that the governing law for both the appellants\u2019 claims (in conversion and for fraudulent misrepresentation or deceit) is Singapore law. Indeed, the \u201cdouble actionability rule\u201d has been satisfied in respect of both claims and the exception to that rule does not apply on the facts of the present proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The claims in equity</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">74\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, next, to the claims in <i>equity</i>, these, too, comprise two separate causes of action. One is for <i>breach of confidence</i>, the other for <i>breach of fiduciary duties</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">75<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We note, at the outset, that the principles relating to choice of law with regard to claims in equity are not entirely clear. We are therefore especially grateful to have the benefit of the views of the leading expert in the field in Singapore (and, indeed, the Commonwealth) as embodied in a very scholarly volume which, if we may say so, has justly received widespread praise: see T\u00a0M\u00a0Yeo, <i>Choice of Law for Equitable Doctrines</i> (Oxford University Press, 2004) (\u201c<i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Yeo</i>\u201d). Indeed, this is the seminal work in the field in the Commonwealth and is based on the author\u2019s doctoral thesis completed at Oxford University (a summary of his main theses can be found in Tiong Min Yeo, \u201cChoice of Law for Equity\u201d in ch\u00a07 of <i>Equity in Commercial Law</i> <span style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: italic\">(</span>Simone Degeling &amp; James Edelman eds) (Law Book Co, 2005)). There is in fact little by way of direct authority in this particular area of the law and the learned author does rely much on first principles. His views are therefore especially valuable in the circumstances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It used to be thought that the <i>lex causae</i> for claims in equity would generally be the <i>lex fori</i> (in these proceedings, Singapore law). The central insight of Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s book (referred to in the preceding paragraph) is the suggestion of a more nuanced approach. Put simply, there would not, <i>ipso facto</i>, be an automatic and blanket application of the <i>lex fori</i> in any and every situation of this nature. Instead, the nature and origins of the equitable obligations concerned would need to be closely examined in the context of their respective factual matrices. In our view, such an approach is undoubtedly sound. The adoption of the <i>lex fori</i> as the <i>lex causae</i> for <i>all</i> issues arising in equity would fail to recognise the disparate doctrines and causes of action arising in equity. Such an approach would be no different from a suggestion that all common law claims, whether arising in contract, tort, or otherwise, should be governed by the <i>lex fori</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With these preliminary \u2013 and perhaps slightly oversimplified \u2013 remarks which do not do justice to the work just considered, we turn now to consider the specific issues presently before us. Indeed, as it turns out, both equitable causes of action framed by the appellant in the Singapore proceedings (<i>viz</i>, the alleged breach of fiduciary duties as well as breach of confidence) raise common issues.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first common issue stems from the fact that both causes of action could each arise from a variety of possible bases (see <i>Yeo</i> ([75] <i>supra</i>)). For example, a breach of fiduciary duty could arise from a contract or, alternatively, could arise from a voluntary undertaking that is not, strictly speaking, contractual in nature. Indeed, the nature and sources of fiduciary duties are so varied that no single set of principles governs this area of law (see generally, for example, L\u00a0S\u00a0Sealy, \u201cFiduciary Relationships\u201d <nobr>[1962] CLJ 69</nobr> and, by the same author, \u201cSome Principles of Fiduciary Obligation\u201d <nobr>[1963] CLJ 119</nobr> and \u201cFiduciary Obligations, Forty Years On\u201d (1995) 9\u00a0JCL 37; as well as the oft-cited Australian High Court decision of <i>Hospital Products Limited v United States Surgical Corporation</i> (1984) 156\u00a0CLR 41 (\u201c<i>Hospital Products</i>\u201d), especially at 68\u201369 and 141\u2013142). The actual legal position would depend very much on the particular factual context. This is perhaps why Prof\u00a0Yeo observes that \u201cthere is general agreement that the existence and content of fiduciary duties are situation-specific\u201d (see <i>Yeo</i> at para\u00a07.26). To exacerbate matters, there are legal systems that do not recognise the concept of fiduciary duty (at least not specifically in the context of civil law systems, as to which, see <i>Yeo</i> at para\u00a07.34). And even within jurisdictions that do recognise such a concept, there also arise differences of views from the perspective of content (see <i>Yeo</i> at para\u00a07.24).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In a similar vein, the learned author also observes that \u201c[t]he theoretical basis of the claim [for breach of confidence] is unclear\u201d and \u201chas been argued variously to be based on contract, tort, breach of fiduciary duty, restitution, trusts, or property\u201d (see <i>Yeo</i> at para\u00a07.73). This is within the common law context. The situation in the civil law context is described by the learned author as being \u201cserved by the law of contract and wrongs, and sometimes the criminal law\u201d (see <i>ibid</i>; see also <i>id</i> at para\u00a07.74). There are also further possible complications introduced as a result of the difficulties inherent within the process of <i>characterisation</i> of the specific issue or issues that arise from the facts at hand (see, albeit not in the context of equity, the oft-cited English High Court decision of <i>Macmillan Inc v Bishopsgate Investment Trust Plc (No\u00a03)</i> <nobr>[1995] 1 WLR 978</nobr>; affirmed on different grounds by the English Court of Appeal in <i>Macmillan Inc v Bishopsgate Investment Trust Plc (No\u00a03)</i> <nobr>[1996] 1 WLR 387</nobr>, analysed incisively in <i>Yeo</i> at paras\u00a03.12\u20133.20 and Adrian Briggs in \u201cDecisions of British Courts During 1996 Involving Questions of Public or Private International Law\u201d (1996) 67\u00a0BYIL 537 at 605\u2013606).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">80<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The possible \u2013 and different \u2013 bases as well as sources for both a breach of fiduciary duty and a breach of confidence (both within the common law and civil law jurisdictions alike) themselves suggest that Prof\u00a0Yeo is correct in arguing that a blanket rule to the effect that the <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">lex fori</i> would always apply is inappropriate (<i>cf</i> the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Sumitomo Bank Ltd v Kartika Ratna Thahir</i> <nobr>[1993] 1 SLR 735</nobr> at 787\u2013791, [140]\u2013[172]; affirmed in <i>Kartika Ratna Thahir v PT\u00a0Pertambangan Minyak dan Gas Bumi Negara (Pertamina)</i> <nobr>[1994] 3 SLR 257</nobr>, especially at 272, [37] as well as the Malaysian High Court decision of <i>Bank Bumiputra Malaysia Bhd v Lorrain Esme Osman</i> <nobr>[1987] 1 MLJ 502</nobr> at 506 and the Australian Federal Court decision of <i>Paramasivam v Flynn</i> (1998) 160\u00a0ALR 203, especially at 215\u2013217 (which embodies a slight variation in approach); but <i>cf</i>, in turn, the perceptive analysis of Prof\u00a0Yeo (see <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Yeo</i> ([75] <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">supra</i>) at paras\u00a07.68\u20137.70 and 7.65, and, by the same author, \u201cChoice of Law for Fiduciary Duties\u201d (1999) 115\u00a0LQR 571, respectively). A blanket rule is also undesirable inasmuch as it tends to undermine considerations of comity that are an integral part of the theory as well as practice of the conflict of laws nowadays. However, that having been said, it is equally important that one does not slide towards the other extreme either \u2013 where the choice of law is not governed by any rules or principles but is premised on what is, in effect, mere arbitrary choice. To do so would undermine the very precept underlying the conflict of laws, which is premised on the formulation of choice of law rules which distil the critical connecting factor in a given area of substantive law. Underlying Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s central thesis in his work is the premise that the concept of equity is <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">not</i> a separate and distinct category in itself (see, for example, <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Yeo</i> at paras\u00a02.14\u20132.15 and 3.22). Hence, it is important to ascertain the foundational sources from which equitable rights and remedies arise \u2013 which would include, <i>inter alia</i>, established categories such as contract and tort. Indeed, it has been held that contractual terms may even authorise what would otherwise constitute a breach of fiduciary duty (see, for example, the Supreme Court of Canada decision of <i>Molchan v Omega Oil &amp; Gas Ltd</i> (1988) 47\u00a0DLR (4th) 481, especially at 492 and <i>Hospital Products</i> ([78] <i>supra</i>) at 102), although the converse does not follow (see, for example, the United States Court of Appeals (Fifth Circuit) decision of <i>The Deauville Corporation v Federated Department Stores, Inc</i> 756 F\u00a02d 1183 (1985) at 1194 as well as <i>Hospital Products Limited</i> at 97; and applied in the Bermudan Privy Council decision of <i>Horace Brenton Kelly v Margot Cooper</i> <nobr>[1993] AC 205</nobr> at 215)). However, there can be no fixed rules as such. For example, the view to the effect that equitable wrongs could be subsumed under tort instead has been criticised (convincingly, in our view) by a learned author, not least because of the very nature (including the variety and complexity) of the choice of law rules for tort across Commonwealth jurisdictions (see Laurette Barnard, \u201cChoice of Law in Equitable Wrongs: A Comparative Analysis\u201d <nobr>[1992] CLJ 474</nobr>, especially at 500\u2013503).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s thesis, whilst his premise (<i>viz</i>, to ascertain the foundational sources from which equitable rights and remedies arise) is not unpersuasive (particularly if we have regard to the discussion above), we would <i>not</i> go so far as to endorse the proposition that equitable concepts and doctrines are <i>always</i> dependent on other established categories (because, as the modern law of restitution illustrates, the law itself never ceases to develop). We would, however, accept the more <i>limited</i> proposition to the effect that where equitable duties (here, in relation to both breach of fiduciary duty and breach of confidence) arise from a factual matrix where the legal foundation is premised on an independent established category such as contract or tort, the appropriate principle in so far as the choice of law is concerned ought to be centred on the established category concerned. We would also leave open the possibility that future legal developments might result in equitable obligations constituting a separate established category in so far as choice of law is concerned (and <i>cf</i>, in this regard, Robert Stevens, \u201cChoice of Law for Equity: Is it Possible?\u201d in ch\u00a08 of <i>Equity in Commercial Law</i> ([75] <i>supra</i>)).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With that more limited and modest proposition in mind, we turn now to consider the alleged breaches in the instant proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear, in our view, that the content of the claims centring around the allegations of breach of fiduciary duty as well as breach of confidence <i>arise from the Employment Agreement itself</i> \u2013 or, more specifically, from the relationship established therein. It is true that there is a persuasive argument (at least from the perspective of Singapore law) to the effect that these duties are really to be <i>implied</i> (in law) from the relationship between the contracting parties themselves. It is established law that it is an implied term of an employment contract that an employee owes his or her employer a duty of good faith and fidelity (see the oft-cited English decisions of <i>Robb v Green</i> <nobr>[1895] 2 QB 315</nobr> and <i>Hivac Limited v Park Royal Scientific Instruments Limited</i> <nobr>[1946] Ch 169</nobr>). However, it is equally true that, in the context of the <i>conflict of laws</i>, one ought not to view the situation through the lenses of domestic (here, contract) law since (as is the case here) the governing law of the contract is in fact German law. If so, it would appear that the alleged breach of fiduciary duty as well as the alleged breach of confidence, having (on <i>these facts</i>) their <i>root source</i> in <i>the Employment Agreement</i>, the governing choice of law rules ought to be based on those governing this particular <i>contract</i> (in this instance, <i>German law</i>; see also generally <i>Yeo</i> ([75] <i>supra</i>) at paras\u00a07.30\u20137.31, 7.39\u20137.45, 7.49, 7.75, 7.77 and 7.82 (interestingly and parenthetically, though, Prof\u00a0Yeo is of the view that, \u201c[o]utside the relationship context, breach of confidence should be characterized as a tort for choice of law purposes\u201d: see <i>id</i> at para\u00a08.77)).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we would pause to observe that whilst the appellants\u2019 actions for both breach of fiduciary duty as well as for breach of confidence are to be governed by the choice of law principles relating to <i>contract</i> (in this instance, <i>German law</i>), the more pertinent inquiry is, in the context of <i>these</i> particular proceedings, a <i>factual</i> one in general and what transpired with regard to the respondent\u2019s dealings with the STB in particular (see also <i>Oriental Insurance</i> ([17] <i>supra</i>) at [40]). In this regard, we are thrown back, as it were, to the testimony not only of the respondent but (and more importantly) of Mr\u00a0Koh and Mrs\u00a0Lee as well. Looked at in this light, the focus (as we have already seen at [25] above) is on <i>Singapore.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Conclusion</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, given the fact that <i>Singapore</i> law ought to be the governing law with regard to the appellants\u2019 claims in tort and that <i>German</i> law ought to be the governing law with regard to the appellants\u2019 claims in equity, we are of the view that choice of law considerations are, on the whole and at best, a <i>neutral</i> factor in the <i>Spiliada</i> balancing exercise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The effect of concurrent proceedings in Germany</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">86\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was, on the facts of the present proceedings, clearly no <i>lis alibi pendens</i> involved. The more pertinent issue relates to the legal effect (if any) of there being concurrent proceedings in Germany.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">87\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It should first be noted that, in principle, it does not matter whether the action was <i>first</i> commenced in Singapore or abroad. In the English High Court decision of <i>The Coral Isis</i> [1986] 1\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 413, Sheen\u00a0J stated (at 417):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In a case, such as this one, in which there is more than one appropriate forum, but no natural forum I do not regard a mere accident of time in the commencement of a suit as necessarily decisive of the question: in which Court should this action proceed?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Taking into account which action started first would encourage parties to start actions in their forums as quickly as possible, whether the claim has a good chance of success or not. Such a practice clearly should not be encouraged. Further, even though the action was first commenced in Germany, Germany may not be the most appropriate forum for the substantive hearing.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also note that the German proceedings have not reached an advanced stage. Although the hearing has begun, the parties have only attended court on three occasions and only one witness has been heard. There has been consent judgment for part of the claim, pursuant to which the first appellant has paid \u20ac69,970. However, this judgment was for claims made by the respondent that were not disputed by the appellants as the respondent had furnished supporting documents to substantiate his claim. The bulk of the respondent\u2019s claims, including his claim for commission as well as for the balance of his salary and expenses, have not been fully heard. The partial judgment states that the German judge has also deferred an order as to costs until his final decision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, although the German proceedings are not at an advanced stage, there is nevertheless an overlap of both facts as well as issues between the German proceedings on the one hand and the Singapore proceedings on the other \u2013 particularly in so far as the issue of the respondent\u2019s alleged misconduct is concerned. In the circumstances, there is a risk of conflicting judgments, at least in so far as some issues are concerned. However, whilst this is a factor that must be taken into account, it is not decisive (bearing in mind that the concurrent proceedings in Singapore and Germany were respectively commenced by the appellants <i>and</i> the respondent, as opposed to a <i>lis alibi pendens</i>: see <i>PT\u00a0Jaya</i> ([43] <i>supra</i>) at [56]). The danger of conflicting judgments must be weighed against the other factors in the <i>Spiliada</i> enquiry and we have seen that, hitherto, the various factors point towards Singapore as being the most appropriate forum to hear the case. The relevant factors, when considered in their totality, strongly militate against any suggestion that the German courts would be \u201cclearly more appropriate\u201d than the Singapore courts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Stage Two</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Does justice require that a stay be refused?</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the light of our conclusion with regard to Stage One, it is, strictly speaking, unnecessary for us to consider Stage Two as such. We do so, however, for the sake of completeness. In this regard, Mr\u00a0Bull argued that granting the respondent a stay of the <i>Singapore</i> proceedings would result in the appellants\u2019 loss of a legitimate juridical advantage which would (in turn) result in injustice to them. He argued that this was due to the non-compellability of key witnesses (in particular, Mr\u00a0Koh and Mrs\u00a0Lee) if the proceedings were held in Germany instead.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">92\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This particular argument was attractive at first blush, not least because, as we have noted above (at [90]), the main focus of the German proceedings would be on the allegations of misconduct on the part of the respondent in general and what transpired between the appellants and STB in particular. In this last-mentioned regard, the testimony of Mr\u00a0Koh and Mrs\u00a0Lee would be particularly significant. However, we are of the view that the appellants did not, in the final analysis, establish to our satisfaction that such a juridical advantage would in fact be lost simply because there was no clear evidence that the key witnesses would in fact be non-compellable pursuant to German law. What <i>was</i> clear was that these witnesses <i>would</i> be compellable under <i>Singapore</i> law. However, this would relate more to the question of connecting factors under Stage One \u2013 which we have found in favour of the appellants not only in so far as this factor is concerned but with regard to the issue of connecting factors generally. On a more general level, because the respective burdens of proof with regard to Stage One and Stage Two are different, the court should be alert to situations of overlap between these two stages (<i>cf</i> Briggs ([79] <i>supra</i>) at 587\u2013589).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">93</span><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span></b> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Taking all the relevant factors into account, we are of the view that the appellants\u2019 action in the Singapore courts against the respondent ought <i>not</i> to be stayed. The connecting factors clearly point to Singapore as being the appropriate forum for the hearing of the substantive issues concerned. It is also clear that Singapore is the most natural and appropriate forum to hear the claims in tort. The issue of choice of law appears, as we have noted, to be neutral and, although there is a risk of conflicting decisions by the Singapore and German courts, this factor does not weigh decisively in the respondent\u2019s favour, having regard to the other factors.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">94\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the circumstances, therefore, we allow the appeal with costs, with the usual consequential orders to follow.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text/html;
