charset=UTF8\"/>\n    <meta name=\"filePath\" content=\"\\BLOBS\\7\\A\\URJ_[2000]_SGCA_3_v1.0.html\"/>\n  <style/></head>\n  <CaseReport>\n  <Metadata seqid=\"4056\" id=\"4056-M\" uniqueid=\"eacc9443-3ec9-421b-bd35-9b28bdf73212\">\n    <Category xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Content.xml#r1c1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Judgments</Category>\n    <Group>Cases</Group>\n    <PublishedInfo>\n      <Uri>/Judgment/4056-M.xml</Uri>\n      <PublishedDate>2003-09-19T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</PublishedDate>\n    </PublishedInfo>\n    <IndexCourt>Court of Appeal</IndexCourt>\n    <DecisionDate>2000-01-12T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</DecisionDate>\n    <IndexYear>2000</IndexYear>\n    <NeutralCitation>\n      <Year>2000</Year>\n      <Court>SGCA</Court>\n      <No>3</No>\n      <NCit>[2000] SGCA 3</NCit>\n    </NeutralCitation>\n    <Citation>\n      <Year>2000</Year>\n      <Series>SGCA</Series>\n      <PageNo>3</PageNo>\n      <Cit>[2000] SGCA 3</Cit>\n    </Citation>\n    <CaseTitle>Hunter Manufacturing Pte Ltd and Another v Soundtex Switchgear &amp; Engineering Pte Ltd (No 2)</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Hunter Manufacturing Pte Ltd and Another v Soundtex Switchgear &amp; Engineering Pte Ltd (No 2)</SortTitle><SortDate>2000-01-12T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 80/1999</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#3\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appellant</Role>\n        <Name>Hunter Manufacturing Pte Ltd</Name>\n        <Name>Another</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#6\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Respondent</Role>\n        <Name>Soundtex Switchgear &amp; Engineering Pte Ltd</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#7\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <AdditionalCaseDetails>\n      <SequelCase>(No 2)</SequelCase>\n    </AdditionalCaseDetails>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#539\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">L P Thean JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#627\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Yong Pung How CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Jimmy Yim SC and Kelvin Tan (instructed) with Patrick Yap (KL Tan &amp; Assocs) for the appellants in CA 80/99 and the respondents in CA 82/99</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Tan Tee Jim SC and Corrine Tan (Allen &amp; Gledhill) for the appellants in CA 82/99 and the respondents in CA 80/99</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#796\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Costs</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#797\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Principles</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Costs of abandoned claim</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Costs of dismissed claim</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Costs of successful appeal</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1772\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Designs</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1783\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Remedies</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Infringement of registered design</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Order for delivery up</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether injunction sufficient</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>(delivering the judgment of the court): In our judgment handed down on 23 December 1999 we allowed the claim of Hunter against Soundtex and granted an injunction in terms of prayer (a)(i) of the statement of claim. We invited counsel to address us on any other reliefs to which Hunter are entitled and on the question of costs here and below. We have since received and considered the submissions of counsel.<br/><br/>The court below held that the defence of innocent infringement was available to Soundtex, and that even if there was infringement of the registered design no damages would be awarded in respect of any infringement up to 12 June 1997 (ie the day on which Soundtex were notified by the solicitors for Hunter that Hunter are the proprietors of the design). We agree entirely. In any event, there was no appeal against this determination. Accordingly, there will be an inquiry as to damages only for infringement of the registered design committed by Soundtex after this date. We so order.<br/><br/>Counsel for Hunter also seeks an order for delivery up on oath and for destruction of all products, goods, documents and other articles and materials, the continued retention, use of or dealing with by Soundtex would offend the injunction. In reply, counsel for Soundtex submits that this relief is not necessary, as the injunction granted is sufficient. We agree. The court has a discretion whether or not to grant such relief and, should it decide to grant it, to limit the extent of such a relief. Such relief is granted not to punish the infringer but to give the necessary protection to the plaintiffs: per Russell J in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Mengenthaler Linotype Co v Intertype Co Ltd</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1926] 43 RPC 381</font>, 382. There is an injunction against Soundtex which they must obey and observe. In so far as they still hold or have any Soundtex boxes in their possession, custody or control, by reason of the injunction they cannot deal with them in any way. It should be borne in mind that the infringement here relates only to the design of the boxes, and in our view, to  order the delivery up and the destruction of all these boxes would be giving to Hunter a remedy far beyond what is necessary for their protection. In complying with the injunction, Soundtex should be allowed, if they so wish, to make changes to the boxes in such a way as not to infringe the registered design of Hunter. Alternatively, Soundtex may break up the boxes and use the materials or parts thereof for other purposes.<br/><br/><strong><i> Costs </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>We now come to the question of costs. First, the costs below. We set aside the order as to costs made at the conclusion of the trial. The plaintiffs abandoned their claim of passing off four months before the commencement of the trial, and they should bear the costs occasioned by this claim. We so order. Next, ABB`s claim was dismissed, and the question is whether in this case there should be an order against them for payment of any costs as a result of such dismissal. We think not. The dismissal of ABB`s claim was consequent on the finding that Hunter are the proprietors of the design. There was no separate issue raised as a result of ABB being joined as the co-plaintiff of Hunter, and their joinder did not result in any additional costs to Soundtex in pursuing their defence or counterclaim against Hunter. In the circumstances, we make no order as to costs against ABB. Subject to the order as to costs occasioned by the abandonment of the claim of passing off, we order Soundtex to pay Hunter the costs of the claim and counterclaim.<br/><br/>Next, we turn to the costs of the appeals. Although Hunter and ABB are the appellants in CA 80/99 and the respondents in CA 82/99, the real contest was between Hunter and Soundtex, and none of the orders we have made concerned ABB. We do not think it is appropriate to make an order as to costs in favour of ABB. We order Soundtex to pay Hunter the costs of the appeals. The deposit in court as security for costs in CA 80/99 is to be refunded to the appellants or their solicitors, and the deposit as security for costs in CA 82/99 be paid to Hunter or their solicitors to account of costs.<br/><br/><font color=\"#800040\" size=\"+1\"><strong><a name=\"Outcome\">Outcome:</a></strong></font></p>\n    <p>Order accordingly.<br/><br/></p>\n <CaseTitle>AP Moller-Maersk A/S (trading as Maersk Sealand) and Another v Special Entertainment Events, Inc and Others</CaseTitle><SortTitle>AP Moller-Maersk A/S (trading as Maersk Sealand) and Another v Special Entertainment Events, Inc and Others</SortTitle><SortDate>2005-01-26T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 105/2004</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#3\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appellant</Role>\n        <Name>AP Moller-Maersk A/S (trading as Maersk Sealand)</Name>\n <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#254\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Lai Kew Chai J</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Govintharasah s/o Ramanathan and Stephanie Wong (Gurbani and Co) for the appellants</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Kenny Yap and Leona Wong (Allen and Gledhill) for the first and second respondents</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Michael Lai and Wendy Tan (Haq and Selvam) for the third and sixth respondents</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Jainil Bhandari (Rajah and Tann) for the fourth and fifth respondents</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#819\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Interpleader</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#820\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Conflicting claims to cargo stored in PSA godown where storage charges accumulating</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Shipowner seeking determination of conflicting claims and claiming payment of freight and other charges from party entitled to cargo</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Interim order made requiring shipowner to release cargo upon security for freight and other charges being furnished</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Shipowner being in effect required to pay storage charges upfront</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">Shipowner appealing against interim order</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"9\">Whether order rightly made</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0January 2005</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\" style=\"MARGIN: 10pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Introduction</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Two vessels, <i>Soroe Maersk</i> and <i>Sine Maersk</i>, owned and operated by the appellants, carried 117 containers of articles relating to the \u201cStar Trek\u201d themed exhibition (\u201cthe cargo\u201d or \u201cthe goods\u201d as may be appropriate) from the United Kingdom and Holland to Singapore. Upon the arrival of the cargo in Singapore, the appellants were not able to deliver the cargo because of apparent disputes among the respondents as to who was entitled to it. The cargo was thus stranded at the godown of the Port of Singapore Authority (\u201cPSA\u201d) from April 2004 with substantial storage charges accumulating.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellants took out an interpleader summons to determine which of the respondents should be entitled to take delivery of the goods. The appellants also prayed for an order requiring the party, which was eventually adjudged to be entitled to the goods, to pay for the freight, demurrage, storage and other charges.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The summons came before Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J on 11\u00a0October 2004, who, having noted that substantial storage charges were mounting, made an interim order that pending the adjudication as to which of the respondents should be entitled to the cargo, the appellants pay up all outstanding storage charges due to the PSA. She also ordered that upon the sixth respondent, or any of the other respondents, furnishing security to the appellants covering freight, demurrage (in respect of 19 containers owned by the appellants) and PSA storage charges, the appellants were to release the cargo to the sixth respondent (or whoever provided the security) and the cargo was to be warehoused at 24\u00a0Jurong Port Road, Singapore 619097, to await the court\u2019s determination of the respondents\u2019 opposing claims to the cargo. A condition was imposed that if, by 20\u00a0October 2004 (extended to 9\u00a0November 2004 at the hearing of further arguments on 26\u00a0October 2004), none of the respondents had come forward to furnish the security, the appellants could dispose of the cargo and the proceeds were to be deposited into court. For the purposes of the hearing of the substantive interpleader summons, Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J ordered that the fourth and fifth respondents would be the plaintiffs and the others, the defendants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The first and second respondents were the owners of the goods. The third respondent was the agent of the sixth respondent who had, pursuant to an agreement entered into with the first and second respondents in December 2003, agreed to purchase the goods at a price of US$2.5m. The goods were then in Europe. Under the purchase agreement, the sixth respondent was to arrange for the transportation of the goods to Singapore. The third respondent appointed the fifth respondent to make the necessary arrangements to transport the goods from Europe. As the fifth respondent was located in Singapore, it, in turn, appointed the fourth respondent to handle the physical shipment of the goods from Europe to Singapore. In the bills of lading (\u201cB/L\u201d), the fourth respondent was named the shipper, and the fifth respondent, the consignee of the cargo.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellants objected to the order requiring them to pay the outstanding storage charges upfront to PSA in return for a security furnished by any of the respondents. They felt that the respondents should resolve the question of the storage charges directly with PSA and that the appellants should not be made a financier to the respondents. They said it was too onerous and inequitable a burden to require them to pay the PSA charges upfront, which was, in fact, the responsibility of the respondents. This was the main contention that came before Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J at the hearing of further arguments. However, the judge was not persuaded to change her mind.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It was against this aspect of the order that the appellants filed the present appeal. In the meantime, pursuant to further interlocutory applications, the order made by Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J was stayed pending the hearing of this appeal on an expedited basis. The appeal was heard on 25\u00a0November 2004 and was dismissed. The court also gave certain consequential orders. We now give our reasons for the dismissal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appellants\u2019 contention</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It is settled law that a carrier has a lien over a cargo in respect of freight and reasonably necessary storage charges. The appellants argued that the respondents, as the persons entitled to the cargo, should pay the storage charges directly (or through the appellants) to the PSA to obtain delivery of the cargo. The appellants averred that they should not be made to pay the storage charges on the respondents\u2019 behalf as they did not owe any duty to the respondents to make such a payment. The appellants claimed that they had completed their contractual obligations by discharging the cargo into the PSA godown, as is the standard procedure at the Singapore port. They contended that it was the respondents\u2019 dispute amongst themselves that had placed the appellants in a bind. The appellants accepted that until the cargo was delivered to the person lawfully entitled to it, they were under a duty only to take reasonable care of the cargo. Except for this, they argued that they owed no further obligations to the consignee or any other person who had an interest in the cargo. In this regard, the appellants relied upon <i>Booth Steamship Company, Limited v Cargo Fleet Iron Company, Limited</i> <nobr>[1916] 2 KB 570</nobr> to submit that, as each respondent had requested the appellants not to deliver the cargo to the other respondents, the respondents could only take delivery upon payment of storage charges to the PSA.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellants also argued that the order of 26\u00a0October 2004 was tantamount to the reallocation of rights and obligations of the parties in a manner inconsistent, not only with the law, but with the commercial realities of the matter, as such a reallocation of rights and obligations was not and could not have been within the contemplation of the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Our decision</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It is not in dispute that a shipowner has a lien over a cargo for freight due in respect of the carriage of that cargo and all charges necessarily and properly incurred by him in discharging and warehousing the same: see <i>Harley v Gardner</i> (1932) 43\u00a0Ll L Rep 104.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In an ordinary case, upon the cargo being discharged into a PSA godown, the consignee would collect the goods after paying freight and the PSA storage charges, if any. However, in this case, there was a dispute among the respondents as to who should be entitled to the cargo. As far as the appellants were concerned, they only wanted to recover the freight charges and demurrage which were due to them. They had no interest in the cargo. However, it seemed to us that the appellants were also concerned about the escalating storage charges at the PSA which were billed by the PSA to them. If eventually no party should come forward to pay the storage charges and freight and take the cargo away, the appellants would have to pay the PSA. Whether in that event the appellants would have recourse against any other party is a separate matter altogether.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It is clear that the party, among the respondents, who is ultimately adjudged to be entitled to the cargo, will be required to pay the freight and all charges (including storage), which were reasonably incurred in relation to the cargo, before the cargo can be released to him. Not only is that the position under the common law, it was expressly so provided in the contract of carriage. Clause\u00a017 of the B/L provided:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Carrier shall have a lien on the Goods and any documents relating thereto for all sums payable to the Carrier under this contract and for general average contributions to whomsoever due. The Carrier shall also have a lien against the Merchant on the Goods and any document relating thereto for all sums due from him to the Carrier under any other contract. The Carrier may exercise his lien at any time and any place in his sole discretion, whether the contractual Carriage is completed or not. In any event any lien shall extend to cover the cost of recovering any sums due and for that purpose the Carrier shall have the right to sell the Goods by public auction or private treaty, without notice to the Merchant. The Carrier\u2019s lien shall survive delivery of the Goods.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Clause\u00a022.2 of the B/L provided that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Merchant shall take delivery of the Goods within the time provided for in the Carrier\u2019s applicable Tariff. If the Merchant fails to do so, the Carrier may without notice unpack the Goods if packed in containers and/or store the Goods ashore, afloat, in the open or under cover at the sole risk of the Merchant. Such storage shall constitute due delivery hereunder and thereupon all liability shall cease and the costs of such storage shall forthwith upon demand be paid by the Merchant to the Carrier.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We should mention that the appellants had also referred to Part\u00a0VII of the Merchant Shipping Act (Cap\u00a0179, 1996\u00a0Rev Ed) which sets out a framework within which a shipowner, who has a lien over cargo for unpaid freight or other charges, may land the cargo and obtain payment of the same. However, while there is controversy as to whether the present case falls within Part\u00a0VII of the Act, we need not have to go into this question at this juncture.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We appreciate that the appellants instituted these proceedings primarily to have the court resolve the conflicting claims of the respondents to the cargo. However, it is vital to bear in mind that the order made by Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J was clearly interim in nature, with the object of saving storage costs pending the resolution of the respondents\u2019 opposing claims. It would benefit neither the appellants, nor the person ultimately adjudicated to be entitled to the cargo, to let the cargo remain any longer in the PSA godown in view of the high storage rate. The order would have the effect of halting the bleeding because the value of the cargo would diminish significantly for every day that it remained at the PSA godown. As we have alluded to earlier, if the sale proceeds were insufficient to meet the PSA charges, the PSA would have to look to the appellants for the shortfall.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It is understandable why the PSA\u2019s prescribed storage rates are high. The high storage rates are to discourage shipowners or consignees from leaving cargo at PSA premises for an inordinately long period because the space is required for the free flow of cargo traffic through the port.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The real question is: was the judge wrong to have made the order? In <i>BP Benzin und Petroleum AG v European-American Banking Corporation</i> [1978] 1\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 364, Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR, in pronouncing on the court\u2019s jurisdiction in an interpleader proceeding, said at 366:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It seems to me under the inherent jurisdiction of the Court, when an interpleader is taken out, the Court can make such order as it thinks just in the matter even though it does interfere with the rights of the parties if that is the just solution of the case. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 I think the jurisdiction of the Court, whether put under the rules or under the inherent jurisdiction, is ample for the Court to do what is right and just.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It was also not in dispute that the appellants had acted reasonably in discharging the cargo into the PSA godown. That has been the standard practice at the Singapore port. There is a 72-hour grace period where no storage charge will be levied, so as to enable consignees to collect their goods.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Unfortunately, in this case the respondents could not agree among themselves as to who should take delivery of the cargo. From the dates the two vessels arrived in Singapore, <i>ie</i>, on 14 and 21\u00a0April 2004 respectively, up to the date the appellants made the interpleader application, the appellants had informed the consignee, the fifth respondents, of the accruing PSA storage charges. On the other hand, the appellants had also received notices from each of the respondents specifically instructing the appellants not to release the cargo to any of the other respondents. Notwithstanding this impasse, the third and sixth respondents contended that the appellants should have moved the cargo to a private commercial warehouse where the charges would be much lower. This will be a question which will have to be addressed at the substantive hearing.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We do not think that by making the order, Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J had in any way affixed the appellants with the ultimate liability to bear the PSA storage charges.<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes\">\u00a0</span> Neither had the judge by the order imposed a new obligation on the appellants. PSA had billed the appellants for the storage charges. The judge had not made an order that permanently affected the rights of the parties. She had merely, having regard to the circumstances of the case before her, thought it just and expedient that the appellants should first pay the storage charges. The positions of the respondents were not all the same. The first and second respondents alleged that under the sale and purchase agreement, title to the goods would only pass to the sixth respondent upon full payment and full payment had yet to be made. Neither were the first and second respondents shippers nor consignees of the cargo. Barring any reason otherwise, as a rule, the party who succeeds in showing that he is entitled to the delivery of the cargo, would have to pay the freight, the storage charges and all other costs and expenses reasonably incurred by the shipowner in relation to the cargo. Thus, to secure the interest of the appellants, the judge also expressly ordered that the respondent who wished to have the cargo delivered to him should furnish to the appellants the required security to cover both the freight and the storage charges paid by the appellants to the PSA.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> A case where the facts are quite close to the present is <i>Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd v Procter &amp; Gamble (Philippines) Inc</i> [1997] 2\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 341 (\u201c<i>Hanjin Shipping</i>\u201d). There, the shipowner interpleaded in relation to the claims of the sellers of the goods, the buyers of the goods and the shipping agents. Faced with conflicting claims, the shipowner transferred the goods into bonded storage. The shipowner asked that the expenses which he had incurred be paid before he was required to release the goods. Longmore\u00a0J agreed with the averment. However, in <i>Hanjin Shipping</i>, at the time the matter came before Longmore\u00a0J, only the second and fourth defendants, who were acting in concert, came to stake their claims. There were no opposing claims to be adjudicated by the court. Thus, the cargo was released to them. In the circumstances in that case, there was no reason whatsoever for requiring the shipowner to pay up the storage charges first. Quite correctly, the two defendants were ordered to pay for the freight, storage and other charges before being allowed to collect the cargo.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> However, in our present case, not only is the substantive interpleader issue yet to be determined, two of the respondents have also challenged the appellants\u2019 actions in allowing the cargo to remain in the PSA godown, thus incurring such high storage charges. These are issues that require further scrutiny. We recognise that the difficulties that arose in this case were not of the appellants\u2019 doing. Nevertheless, the effect of the order of Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J was no more than to replace the form of the security for the appellants\u2019 claim, <i>ie</i>, instead of the cargo, a banker\u2019s guarantee for the requisite amount was to be furnished. In all the circumstances, it was an eminently reasonable order. As Prof Jeffrey Pinsler noted in his work, <i>Singapore Court Practice 2003</i> (LexisNexis, 2003) at 426, \u201cThe court\u2019s discretion is limited only by considerations of justice.\u201d We cannot accept the appellants\u2019 assertion that the order of the judge set a dangerous precedent. What would be a reasonable interim arrangement must depend on the circumstances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> There was only one minor adjustment which we made to the order of Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J. In determining the amount of the security, we thought the finance cost to the appellants for paying the PSA storage charges should be included. This, we fixed at 6% per annum over a period of 18 months from the date of the hearing of this appeal. That period should be sufficient to cover the time required for the trial and any appeal therefrom. This variation should adequately compensate for any loss which the appellant will suffer on account of their having to pay the PSA storage charges upfront.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Appeal dismissed with slight variation to order below.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", Tean and Probin Dass (Rajah and Tann) for appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Kenneth Lie and Chow Sy Hann (Joseph Tan Jude Benny) for respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#792\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#793\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Leave</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Judge in chambers allowing extension of time to file Statement of  Claim and allowing Statement of Claim filed out of time to stand</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether appellant required to obtain leave of court to appeal to Court of Appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Section 34(2)(d) Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322, 1999 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0April 2004</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Two motions were before this court in relation to Civil Appeal No\u00a0134 of 2003. The first was by the respondent cargo owners seeking to strike out the appeal on the ground that the appellant shipowners had failed to obtain leave of court, as required under s\u00a034(2)(d) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cSCJA\u201d), before filing the notice of appeal against the decision of Belinda Ang Saw Ean\u00a0J (reported at <nobr>[2003] 4 SLR 575</nobr>). The arguments before us centred on the true nature of the orders made by Ang\u00a0J against which the appellants sought to appeal. The second motion was an application by the appellants seeking the leave of this court, in the event that we should hold, pursuant to the first motion, that leave of the judge was required before an appeal could be filed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the conclusion of the hearing of the first motion, we ruled that the notice of appeal had been properly filed as no leave of the judge was required. This rendered the second motion redundant and the appellants duly withdrew it. We now give our reasons for the ruling.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 24\u00a0December 2000 the vessel <i>Melati</i> suffered a casualty in the course of its voyage from Buatan, Indonesia, to Huangpu and Shanghai, China. On 5\u00a0March 2002, the cargo owners, who suffered losses as a result of the casualty, took out a writ <i>in rem</i> against the shipowners. The <i>in rem</i> writ was served on 12\u00a0March 2002. Appearance was duly entered on 20\u00a0March 2002. Thereafter, the cargo owners took no further steps until 18\u00a0March 2003 when they filed and served a statement of claim out of time on the shipowners\u2019 solicitors.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under O\u00a018 r\u00a01 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cROC\u201d), the statement of claim to a writ must be served on the defendant within 14 days of the defendant entering appearance unless the court allows otherwise. Under O\u00a021 r\u00a02(6) of the ROC, if no party has, within a period of one year, taken any step or proceeding in the action, the action is deemed to have been discontinued.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the basis of these two rules, the shipowners objected to the service of the statement of claim effected on them on 18\u00a0March 2003, as not only was the statement of claim filed and served out of time, the action was also deemed discontinued under O\u00a021 r\u00a02(6). Subsequently, exchanges took place between the solicitors of the parties as to whether the filing and service of the summons in chambers was proper and whether the action had been automatically discontinued. As no agreement could be reached, the cargo owners made an application by summons in chambers for the following reliefs:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The time for filing of the statement of claim in the action be extended;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A declaration that the statement of claim filed and served on the defendants on 18 March 2003 was regular and made in accordance with the Rules of Court;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further and alternatively, the plaintiffs be at liberty to reinstate the action herein.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 24\u00a0April 2003, the assistant registrar dismissed the cargo owners\u2019 application and also ordered that the statement of claim filed on 18\u00a0March 2003 be \u201cstruck out\u201d. He felt that such a long extension of time to enable the statement of claim to be filed and served would \u201cquite fatally disrupt case management\u201d. He also refused to reinstate the action as the cargo owners did not prosecute it with due despatch.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The cargo owners appealed to the judge in chambers who, on 21\u00a0October 2003, allowed the appeal. She extended the time for the filing of the statement of claim and retrospectively validated the service of the statement of claim effected on 18\u00a0March 2003. She ordered that time ran from the date of her order for the shipowners to file their defence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 27\u00a0October 2003, as required under s\u00a034(1)(c) of the SCJA, the shipowners requested for a certification from the judge that she would require no further arguments on the matter. The judge duly so certified on 4\u00a0November 2003. On 20\u00a0November 2003, a notice of appeal was filed by the shipowners.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thereafter the parties proceeded in the normal way to discuss about the necessary documents to be included in the Record of Appeal. On 9\u00a0February 2004, the shipowners filed and served on the cargo owners the Appellant\u2019s Case, the Record of Appeal, the Core Bundle and the Bundle of Authorities. It was only eight days later, on 17\u00a0February 2004, that the cargo owners wrote to the shipowners alleging for the first time that as the latter had failed to obtain leave of court before filing their notice of appeal, there was, in fact, no appeal. The cargo owners contended that the failure to obtain such leave was fatal to the appeal. They said that without leave, there could be no appeal. Thus the notice of appeal should properly be withdrawn. This was the backdrop to the two motions before us.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Nature of the orders</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The fundamental question, which would be determinative of the first motion, related to the true nature of the orders made by the judge. Did they amount to an order \u201crefusing to strike out an action or a pleading or a part of a pleading\u201d within the meaning of s\u00a034(2)(d) of the SCJA?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To answer that question, it would be expedient to bear in mind the reliefs sought by the cargo owners in their summons in chambers: see [5] above. Quite clearly, they wanted an extension of time to file and serve their statement of claim out of time. Further, and in the alternative, if due to inaction on their part for such a long period the case should fall within the ambit of O\u00a021 r\u00a02(6), they beseeched this court, in exercise of its discretionary power under O\u00a021 r\u00a02(8), to reinstate the action.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 When the application came before the assistant registrar, no arguments pertaining to the merits of the claim were made. The arguments centred squarely on the two main points, namely, whether the court should exercise its discretion to extend time to enable the cargo owners to file and serve the statement of claim out of time and whether, if automatic discontinuance had set in, to reinstate the action. It is true that the assistant registrar, in refusing the reliefs prayed for, also ordered that the statement of claim already filed be struck out. But it was clear that by so ordering, the assistant registrar did not mean to suggest that the statement of claim was struck out as having no merits or being an abuse of process. He meant to say that the statement of claim should not have been filed and it should not, therefore, remain on the record, or, in his words, he saw no point in leaving the statement of claim \u201cfloating around\u201d. Instead of saying that it was struck out, he could very well have said that the statement of claim be removed from the record.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thus, when the matter came on appeal to the judge in chambers, who, in such circumstances, exercised a confirmatory jurisdiction (see <i>Herbs and Spices Trading Post Pte Ltd v Deo Silver (Pte) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1990] SLR 1234</nobr> and <i>Lassiter Ann Masters v To Keng Lam</i> <nobr>[2004] SGCA 10</nobr>), she reheard the arguments of the parties in relation to the application made in the summons in chambers. Like the assistant registrar, she did not hear any arguments on the merits of the claim. But, unlike the assistant registrar, the judge came to the conclusion that although the statement of claim was filed and served out of time on 18\u00a0March 2003, this failure constituted only an irregularity. In any event, this filing and serving of the statement of claim was a step taken in the action and in view of this, O\u00a021 r\u00a02(6) had not been activated as 20\u00a0March 2002 to 18\u00a0March 2003 was just short of one year. The judge then proceeded to consider the reasons advanced by the cargo owners as to why the statement of claim was not filed within the prescribed time. This was what she said in relation to the explanation offered (at [12] and [13]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Robinson explained that it was not unusual for parties to agree to solve the salvage claim before the main cargo claim. A protective writ was issued since the defendants [the shipowners] refused their request to extend suit time. The salvage claim took some time to resolve. The salvors had problems getting up their claim. \u2026. Eventually, the arbitration in London involving the bills of lading in this action was settled amongst the defendants as shipowners, salvors and the plaintiffs as cargo interests on 17 February 2003. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The delay was the result of a decision to await the outcome of the salvors\u2019 arbitration, as the plaintiffs had wanted to quantify the indemnity sought by them in the present action. The decision to wait may not have been justified as the cargo claim in Singapore could still proceed without quantification of the claim for salvage indemnity. Right or wrong, that was the course adopted and the decision could not in the circumstances be viewed as a manifest intention not to advance the cargo claim or that the plaintiffs were sleeping on the case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As the judge did not think that to regularise the statement of claim filed by extending time would cause any real prejudice to the shipowners, she accordingly granted the extension asked for. She felt that not to grant an extension of time here would be \u201ca drastic and disproportionate response in the circumstances of the particular breach and would give the [shipowners] an unjustified tactical advantage and windfall\u201d (at [18]). She also ordered that the statement of claim was to \u201cstand as served on 18\u00a0March 2003\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In other words, what the judge below decided was that she would exercise her discretion in granting an extension of time for the cargo owners to file their statement of claim out of time, and, by virtue of this extension, the irregularity in the filing and serving of the statement of claim was put right.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, the way in which the cargo owners perceived the orders of the judge was this. They said that the judge, by granting the extension of time to regularise the filing and service of the pleading, was in effect refusing to strike out the statement of claim. Therefore, the judge having refused to so strike out the statement of claim, had made a decision falling squarely within s\u00a034(2)(d) of the SCJA. It was not necessary that there must be a formal application to specifically strike out the statement of claim. The whole object of s\u00a034(2), which had other limbs too, of requiring leave of court, was to sieve out non-serious and unmeritorious appeals.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was not in dispute that if leave was required and not obtained, then the notice of appeal would not be valid. This court had previously in <i>Rank Xerox (Singapore) Pte Ltd v Ultra Marketing Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1992] 1 SLR 73</nobr> at 76, [10] ruled that a failure to obtain leave is a matter that goes to jurisdiction and is not something that can be waived by the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Was there really a decision not to strike out?</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Could it be said that the judge, in exercising her discretion to extend time to enable the cargo owners to file their statement of claim out of time and to allow the statement of claim already filed on 18\u00a0March 2003 to stand, had refused to strike out a statement of claim? The cargo owners urged this court to view the matter bearing in mind the orders made by the assistant registrar. In our opinion, this would be wrong. The orders made by the assistant registrar should have no bearing at all since they had been set aside by the judge in the exercise of her confirmatory jurisdiction. What was the nature or effect of the orders made by the judge should be apparent from the orders themselves. But, if the orders were at all unclear, reference should then be made to the prayers in the application concerned.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 When so viewed, the nature of the orders made by the judge was quite clear. First, the judge extended the time within which the statement of claim should be filed by the cargo owners. Second, and in consequence of the first order, the judge allowed the statement of claim already filed on 18\u00a0March 2003 to remain. Of course, the judge could have declared that the statement of claim filed and served on 18\u00a0March 2003 was of no effect and directed that a fresh statement of claim be filed and served forthwith or within a reasonable time thereafter. If the judge had taken this course, there could be no argument whatsoever that it would not be a case of the judge refusing to strike out a statement of claim. Instead, being practical, the judge treated the earlier statement of claim as having been properly filed and served. We could not see why the adoption of this sensible approach should change the nature of the orders.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Therefore, we do not see how it could truly be asserted that the judge refused to strike out the statement of claim.\u00a0 It is true that s\u00a034(2)(d) of the SCJA does not elaborate on what would constitute or amount to a refusal to strike out a statement of claim. But this is addressed in O\u00a018 r\u00a019(1) of the ROC which provides that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Court may at any stage of the proceedings order to be struck out or amended any pleading or the endorsement of any writ in the action, or anything in any pleading or in the endorsement, on the ground that \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it discloses no reasonable cause of action or defence, as the case may be;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it is scandalous, frivolous or vexatious;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it may prejudice, embarrass or delay the fair trial of the action; or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it is otherwise an abuse of the process of the Court,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">and may order the action to be stayed or dismissed or judgment to be entered accordingly, as the case may be.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 From this rule, it would be seen that the process of striking out is meant to be a simple and quick way of enabling a defendant to have a wholly unmeritorious claim be disposed of instead of having to waste time through a trial. Such a summary relief could be based on any of the grounds listed.\u00a0 It is trite law that the court will only make such an order in very clear cases because it would effectively deny the plaintiff or claimant his day in court. And if the judge should refuse the relief, it makes absolute sense that there should be no automatic right of appeal, as otherwise, a process which is intended to be short and simple will turn out to be long-drawn. Instead of a case coming up to the Court of Appeal once after trial, it could come up twice, rendering negative the very purpose of a quick solution. This is really the policy behind s\u00a034(2)(d) of the SCJA and O\u00a018 r\u00a019 of the ROC.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present case, Ang\u00a0J was not dealing with any arguments that the statement of claim should be struck out because it disclosed no reasonable cause of action or that it amounted to an abuse of process or the like.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, we held that the orders of Ang\u00a0J were not orders refusing to strike out a statement of claim. They were really interlocutory orders which would come under s\u00a034(1)(c) of the SCJA where an appeal could only be brought if the judge certifies, on an application made within seven days, that he or she requires no further arguments. In the present case, this condition was complied with by the shipowners. Accordingly, the appeal was properly brought.</span></p>\n\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of `MARA`</SortTitle><SortDate>2000-09-01T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 207/1999</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\"
