of damages</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"284\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0September 2004</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><em>Judgment reserved.</em></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Tan Lee Meng\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal relates to an arbitrator\u2019s ruling that the appellant, Salcon Limited (\u201cSalcon\u201d), a construction company, was liable to the respondent, United Cement Pte Ltd (\u201cUCL\u201d), for certain heads of consequential losses resulting from the former\u2019s negligence and breach of contract regarding the construction of a cement silo.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The facts in this case, shorn of details, are as follows. UCL, a Singapore company in the cement business, wanted to build a reinforced concrete silo (\u201cthe silo\u201d) at Pulau Damar Laut to store cement that was to be packed for sale. On 18\u00a0August 1993, UCL appointed Cheang Jen Boon (\u201cCheang\u201d), a professional engineer, to design the silo, which comprised seven cells within two concentric cylindrical walls, with the central cell (\u201cCell\u00a01\u201d) surrounded by six smaller cells (\u201cCells\u00a02 to 7\u201d) of varying sizes. Cheang\u2019s task was also to supervise the construction of the silo.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 16\u00a0November 1994, UCL appointed Salcon as the main contractor for the construction of the silo for a sum of $7,796,123.22. By December 1995, the construction work was substantially completed and by March 1996, the silo was fully operational.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The silo was neither well designed nor well constructed. By March 1997, a number of defects appeared. After these defects were rectified, Cheang issued the Certificate of Completion of Work and the Defects Liability Certificate on 26\u00a0June 1997. However, UCL continued to face problems with the silo. Between November 1997 and February 1998, chunks of concrete and rebars were flushed through the discharge valves of Cell\u00a04, which had to be emptied for repairs. Cracks and spalling along the inner wall of the silo were also discovered.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 3\u00a0February 1999, a site inspection was carried out by officers from the Building Control Division in the presence of all the parties. After this inspection, Cheang advised in his evaluation report of 13\u00a0February 1999 that the silo should not be operated beyond 70% of its capacity. This meant that each of the cells was not to be loaded beyond 70% of its capacity. By then, UCL had appointed Mr\u00a0Tan Ee Ping of M/s Tan Ee Ping &amp; Partners (\u201cTEPP\u201d) as its consultant. In two reports dated 4\u00a0May 1999 and 17\u00a0May 1999, TEPP recommended that the silo be shut down for repairs to be carried out. The silo ceased operating by 7\u00a0June 1999.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although TEPP knew that Cheang had advised that the silo should not be operated beyond 70% of its capacity, orders were given for Cell\u00a04 to be loaded to full capacity on 24\u00a0June 1999 so that stresses could be monitored by strain gauges. Some 6,000 tons of cement were poured into Cell\u00a04. This resulted in Cell\u00a04 being filled up to 97% of its storage capacity. On the following day, while cement was being discharged from Cell\u00a04 between 3.30pm and 4.00pm, a large vertical crack appeared around Cells\u00a03 and 4, after which the whole silo collapsed. As a result, rectification work was no longer possible as the silo had to be demolished and entirely reconstructed. Reconstruction work has since been completed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 UCL instituted proceedings in the High Court against Cheong and Salcon for negligence and/or breach of contract. UCL asserted that the silo was wholly defective, unfit for its purpose and/or unsafe. By an order made on 2\u00a0March 2000 pursuant to s\u00a022 of the Arbitration Act (Cap\u00a010, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed), the dispute was referred to a panel of three arbitrators. The arbitrators were Mr\u00a0C\u00a0R Rajah SC, Mr\u00a0Teh Hee Seang and Mr\u00a0Tan Chee Meng.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The arbitration proceedings</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Cheang and Salcon did not seriously dispute UCL\u2019s right to damages for defective design and workmanship. However, they submitted that TEPP\u2019s negligent advice to load Cell\u00a04 to full capacity on 24\u00a0June 1999 was a <i>novus actus interveniens</i> that broke the chain of causation and that, as such, the damages payable by them should be based on the cost of rectifying the defects resulting from the design and construction of the silo before it collapsed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In their Interim Award I, the arbitrators found as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Cheang was negligent and had breached his design and supervision contract with UCL.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Salcon was negligent and in breach of its construction contract with UCL.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 TEPP\u2019s advice to UCL to load Cell\u00a04 on 24\u00a0June 1999 to full capacity was a <i>novus actus interneniens</i> which broke the chain of causation.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 UCL was not guilty of contributory negligence or of a failure to mitigate its losses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both Cheang and Salcon were liable to UCL for \u201cdamages arising from their negligence and breach of contract for the design and construction deficiencies in the silo prior to 24\u00a0June 1999\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The liability of Cheang and Salcon was apportioned at 30% and 70% respectively.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In para\u00a0243 of their Interim Award\u00a0I, the arbitrators directed as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[Cheang] and [Salcon] are jointly and severally liable to [UCL] in damages for the cost of rectification of all design and construction defects in the silo in its state prior to the loading of Cell\u00a04 on 24\u00a0June 1999 and consequential loss arising therefrom, in the proportion of 30% and 70% respectively, such damages and loss to be assessed at a separate hearing, if not agreed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Salcon and UCL appealed against the findings of the tribunal. After both appeals were dismissed by this court, the assessment of damages was, for the purpose of saving costs, fixed before a single arbitrator, Mr\u00a0Tan Chee Meng.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Assessment of damages</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 That UCL is entitled to claim damages for the actual expenses incurred on or before 24\u00a0June 1999 (\u201cClaim\u00a0A\u201d) to rectify defects as well as the cost of rectification works for the remaining defects in the silo in its state prior to 24\u00a0June 1999 (\u201cClaim\u00a0B\u201d) was not in doubt and these two claims need not be further considered. The present appeal arose because UCL also claimed for other losses that would have arisen during the notional period of repair after the silo\u2019s collapse. The term \u201cnotional\u201d is used because the contemplated rectification works necessitated by Cheang\u2019s defective design and Salcon\u2019s defective construction work could no longer be carried out after the collapse of the silo. As a question arose as to whether UCL was entitled in law to claim for losses during the notional repair period because the tribunal had found that the silo collapsed as a result of TEPP\u2019s <i>novus actus interveniens</i>, the parties jointly framed the following preliminary questions of law on 3\u00a0November 2003 for the arbitrator\u2019s decision:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><u>Preliminary Question 1</u></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In addition to [Claims\u00a0A and B] \u2026, whether the Plaintiffs are entitled to recover damages for:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(C)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 consequential loss incurred during the rectification period \u2026 [\u201cClaim\u00a0C\u201d] and/or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(D)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 consequential loss due to the loss of capacity of the silo so rectified \u2026 [\u201cClaim\u00a0D\u201d].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><u>Preliminary Question 2</u></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In addition to [Claim\u00a0A] \u2026 and as an alternative to claim\u00a0(B), whether the Plaintiffs are entitled to recover damages for:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(E)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 consequential loss measured by discounted cash flow of the defective silo as compared to a sound silo (see Item No 23 of the 2<sup>nd</sup> Statement of Claim) [\u201cClaim\u00a0E\u201d]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><u>Preliminary Question 3</u></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In addition to [Claims\u00a0A and B] above, whether the Plaintiffs are entitled to recover damages for:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(F)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 consequential loss measured by the depreciated replacement cost to reinstate the silo (see Item No\u00a024 of the 2<sup>nd</sup> Statement of Claim) [\u201cClaim\u00a0F\u201d]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arbitrator made the following findings in his Interim Award II:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">i.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Preliminary Question 1 - CLAIM C:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">UCL is entitled to claim for consequential losses during the notional period of repairs;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">ii.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Preliminary Question 1 - CLAIM D:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">UCL is not entitled to claim for consequential losses due to the loss of capacity of the silo so rectified.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">iii.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Preliminary Question 2 - CLAIM E:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">UCL is entitled to be compensated for the diminution in value of the silo measured by the \u201cDiscounted Cash Flow\u201d method.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">iv.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Preliminary Question 3 - CLAIM F:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">UCL is entitled to be compensated for the diminution in value of the silo measured by the \u201cDepreciated Replacement\u201d Cost method.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Salcon appealed against the arbitrator\u2019s findings in relation to Claims\u00a0C, E and F.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The main issue in this appeal by Salcon against the arbitrator\u2019s findings in relation to Claims\u00a0C, E and F concerns the effect of TEPP\u2019s negligent advice on 24\u00a0June 1999 to load Cell\u00a04 to full capacity, which was regarded by the arbitrators as a <i>novus actus interveniens</i> that broke the chain of causation. Salcon contended that as the <i>novus actus interveniens</i> caused the silo to collapse, it is not liable to UCL for any consequential loss during the period of notional repairs to the silo (Claim\u00a0C) or any hypothetical diminution in the value of the silo measured by the two methods of assessment of loss referred to in Claims E and F. In coming to his decision in favour of UCL\u2019s Claims\u00a0C, E and F, the arbitrator relied on two English authorities, <i>The Haversham Grange</i> <nobr>[1905] P 307</nobr> and <i>Baker v Willoughby</i> <nobr>[1970] AC 467</nobr>. If both cases are examined, it will be found that they do not lend any support to UCL\u2019s case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first case, <i>The Haversham Grange,</i> must be viewed in the context of a number of other shipping cases. To begin with, in <i>The Glenfinlas</i> <nobr>[1918] P 363</nobr>, the plaintiff\u2019s vessel was involved in a collision as a result of the negligence of the defendant\u2019s vessel. Before permanent repairs could be effected, the plaintiff\u2019s vessel sank after hitting a mine. Apart from the repair costs, the plaintiff also made a claim for consequential losses, namely damages for detention that would have resulted had the vessel been repaired. The registrar, who dismissed the claim for damages for detention during the notional period of repair, said that this purely consequential loss stood on a different footing from the cost of repairs to the plaintiff\u2019s chattel. In his view, the principle to be applied was <i>restitutio in integrum</i>, and the question of awarding damages for loss of time when there was no such loss did not arise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The reasoning in <i>The Glenfinlas</i> was approved by the English Court of Appeal in <i>The York</i> <nobr>[1929] P 178</nobr>. In the latter case, the plaintiff\u2019s vessel, which was damaged in a collision by the defendant\u2019s vessel, was able to continue trading without being repaired as the damage did not render her unseaworthy. Before the repairs were effected, the plaintiff decided to sell the vessel. As such, when the vessel reached Antwerp, her engines, boilers and tanks were opened for the buyer\u2019s inspection. While the vessel was idle and awaiting inspection, the plaintiff took the opportunity to repair the collision damage. The plaintiff\u2019s claim for damages for the detention of the vessel during the period of repair was rejected. Scrutton\u00a0LJ explained at 184:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In this case there was no work which she would otherwise have done during the time, for the reason that by her contract of sale she had incapacitated herself from doing any work at the time; and that being so, it appears to me that the shipowner fails to prove that the wrong of laying the ship idle was the result of the collision. His ship was idle because of the contract of sale and purchase, and the work which had to be done under it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The facts in the above-mentioned shipping cases are very different from those in <i>The Haversham Grange.</i> In that case, the plaintiff\u2019s vessel was damaged during a collision with another vessel and was further damaged within a day in a subsequent collision with the defendant\u2019s vessel. Both the collisions rendered the plaintiff\u2019s vessel unseaworthy, which meant that she had to be repaired immediately. The repairs for the damage caused in both collisions were effected simultaneously and the damage caused by the defendant\u2019s vessel was repaired within the time required for repairing the damage caused in the first collision. The plaintiff agreed to share the responsibility for the first collision with the owners of the other ship involved in that collision. After paying half the costs of the dock dues and demurrage, the plaintiff claimed these amounts from the defendant. The English Court of Appeal accepted that the defendant had to share the cost of dock dues, which were part of the cost of repairs. However, in the case of consequential losses during the period of repair, namely demurrage, it was held that the first tortfeasor, and not the defendant, was liable for it. Collins\u00a0MR explained that as it turned out, the plaintiff\u2019s vessel was detained the whole time in dock by the repairs which had to be executed in consequence of the damage done by the first tortfeasor\u2019s vessel and although the repairs occasioned by the defendant\u2019s vessel were effected simultaneously, the plaintiff\u2019s ship was not detained an hour longer by reason of that fact. In view of this, the defendant was not liable for demurrage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The decision in <i>The Haversham Grange</i> cannot be applied to the present case. To begin with, in <i>The Haversham Grange,</i> the damage to the plaintiff\u2019s ship was actually repaired and the consequential loss, namely demurrage, was actually incurred by the plaintiff. However, in the present case, repairs to the cement silo could no longer be carried out because it collapsed as a result of a <i>novus actus interveniens</i>. If the shipping cases are of any assistance, the collapse of the silo may be compared to the sinking of a ship and the principle enunciated in <i>The Glenfinlas</i> would be more relevant when considering UCL\u2019s claim for consequential losses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to <i>Baker v Willoughby</i> <nobr>[1970] AC 467</nobr> (\u201c<i>Baker</i>\u201d), a personal injury case that was criticised but not overruled by the House of Lords in <i>Jobling v Associated Dairies Ltd</i> <nobr>[1982] AC 794</nobr> (\u201c<i>Jobling</i>\u201d). In <i>Baker</i>, the defendant motorist negligently injured the plaintiff\u2019s left leg. Subsequently, the plaintiff\u2019s left leg was hit by a bullet during an armed robbery at his work place. As a result of the second injury, the plaintiff\u2019s leg had to be amputated. The House of Lords held that the defendant motorist remained liable for the plaintiff\u2019s pain and suffering after the shooting that led to the amputation. Their Lordships took pains to stress that if this was not the case, the plaintiff would be prejudiced as the armed robbers, who found him in an injured state, were only liable for any additional damage that resulted from the shooting itself.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Baker</i> must now be viewed in the light of the subsequent decision of the House of Lords in <i>Jobling.</i> In <i>Jobling</i>, the plaintiff was injured at his workplace as a result of his defendant employer\u2019s negligence. After the injury and before the trial, it was discovered that the plaintiff\u2019s own medical problems with his back would have curtailed his working life in any event. The House of Lords held that the defendant was only liable for the pain, suffering and loss of earnings suffered by the plaintiff up to the time the plaintiff\u2019s own illness effectively overtook the effects of the injury at the workplace. The plaintiff\u2019s illness was regarded as part of the vicissitudes of life which ought to be taken into account to reduce the damages awarded to the plaintiff. In coming to this conclusion, the House of Lords cast doubt on its previous decision in <i>Baker.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Often enough, attempts have been made to reconcile <i>Baker</i> with <i>Jobling</i> on the basis that the supervening factor in the former case was a tort whereas the supervening event in the latter case arose from natural causes. This is far from satisfactory for as Prof\u00a0John Fleming rightly pointed out, the risk in <i>Baker</i> of being shot was at least as random as the chance of disease in <i>Jobling</i> and a claim against criminals is as forlorn as blaming fate for the disease: see \u201cProbabilistic Causation in Tort Law\u201d (1989) 68\u00a0Can Bar Rev 661 at 672.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We were invited to rule on whether <i>Baker</i> is applicable in Singapore in personal injury cases and if so, whether the effect of that decision may be extended to commercial disputes such as the present, as the arbitrator had done. In our view, whether <i>Baker</i> is applicable in Singapore in personal injury cases is a question that ought to be considered on another occasion when that question directly arises. What is clear for present purposes is that whether or not <i>Baker</i> is applicable in personal injury cases, its effect should not be extended to commercial disputes such as the one presently being discussed. After all, in <i>Jobling</i>, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce took pains to stress at 804 that the rationalisation of the decision in <i>Baker</i>, as to which he at least had doubts, \u201cneed and should not be applied to other cases\u201d, while Lord\u00a0Keith of Kinkel made it clear at 814 that the weakened <i>ratio decidendi</i> of <i>Baker</i> \u201cmust lead to the conclusion that in its full breadth it is not acceptable\u201d. It should also be noted that Lord Edmund-Davies said at 808\u2013809 that he could \u201cformulate no convincing juristic or logical principles supportive of the decision\u201d in <i>Baker</i> while Lord\u00a0Bridge of Harwich took the view at 821 that the <i>ratio decidendi</i> of <i>Baker</i> could not be sustained. Finally, Lord\u00a0Russell of Killowen declared at 811 that the reliance in <i>Baker</i> by Lord\u00a0Reid on a workman\u2019s compensation case for his conclusion was unsound and that the reasons given in <i>Baker</i> did not persuade him to take a further step to allow the workman in <i>Jobling</i> to claim with respect to the period when his own back problems made it impossible for him to work. In view of the aforesaid, the arbitrator erred when he relied on <i>Baker</i> in the context of a commercial dispute.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are of the view that the issue in the present appeal should be considered in the context of the legal effect of a <i>novus actus interveniens.</i> The relevant question in this case is whether the losses in respect of which UCL has made claims were caused by Salcon or by the <i>novus actus interveniens</i>, namely TEPP\u2019s order to load Cell\u00a04 to full capacity on 24\u00a0June 1999. That causation must be established before the question of quantification of damages arises is obvious. In <i>Carslogie Steamship Co Ld v Royal Norwegian Government</i> <nobr>[1952] AC 292</nobr> at 300<i>,</i> Viscount Jowitt explained:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[A]t the outset I think it is well to bear in mind the elementary principle that it is for the plaintiff in an action of damages to prove his case to the satisfaction of the court. He has to show affirmatively that damages under any particular head have resulted from the wrongful act of the defendant, before he can recover those damages.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the facts in the present case may be compared to those in <i>Beoco Ltd v Alfa Laval Co Ltd</i> [1994] 4\u00a0All ER 464 (\u201c<i>Beoco</i>\u201d), a decision of the English Court of Appeal. In that case, the first defendant installed a heat exchanger at the plaintiff\u2019s factory, which produced refined edible oils. Some 20 months after the installation, a leak, which resulted from a crack in the outer surface of the casing, was discovered in the heat exchanger. The plaintiff employed the second defendant to repair the crack. The repair work was not altogether successful and the heat exchanger failed a pressure test conducted by the plaintiff\u2019s engineers. Notwithstanding this, the plaintiff\u2019s engineers decided to put the whole system back into operation again before a proper inspection of the heat exchanger, which would have shown that it was still defective and that the crack was now even more extensive. It was the plaintiff\u2019s responsibility to arrange for such an inspection. Two months later, the defective heat exchanger exploded, causing damage to the plaintiff\u2019s plant and loss of production.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court of Appeal held that the plaintiff was responsible for the explosion which resulted from its decision to put an inadequately repaired heat exchanger into service. It further held that while the first defendant was liable for the cost of replacing the defective casing of the heat exchanger as well as the loss of production while it was actually being repaired, it was not liable for hypothetical damages for lost production for the additional period required to repair the defective heat exchanger if it had not exploded after having been put back in service. The reason for this was that such further repair work was not carried out and had been subsumed within the more extensive repairs required because of the explosion caused by the plaintiff\u2019s own negligence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reference may also be made to the decision of the House of Lords in <i>Carslogie Steamship Co Ld v Royal Norwegian Government</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>) (\u201c<i>Carslogie</i>\u201d). In that case, the defendant was responsible for a collision with the plaintiff\u2019s vessel. As permanent repairs were not immediately required, the vessel sailed again after some temporary repairs were effected. During the voyage, heavy weather damaged the vessel to such an extent as to render her unseaworthy. As a result, she had to be in dry dock in New York for repairs. Both the collision damage and the heavy weather damage were repaired concurrently. As 30 days were required for repairing the damage caused by heavy weather and only ten were required to repair the damage caused during the collision, it followed that the defendant did not cause the vessel to be detained any longer than was necessary to repair the damage caused by the heavy weather during the voyage. It was thus held by the House of Lords that the defendant was not liable for the ten days of detention that were allocated for repairs for the collision because these ten days were subsumed within the much lengthier period of time needed to repair the damage caused by heavy weather.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The situation in the present case is similar to that in <i>Beoco</i> and <i>Carslogie</i>. Before Salcon could complete the required repairs to the silo, there was an overloading of Cell\u00a04 on TEPP\u2019s orders. This <i>novus actus interveniens</i> necessitated the complete reconstruction of the silo itself. As legal effect must be given to a <i>novus actus inteveniens</i>, UCL\u2019s Claim\u00a0C, which concerns consequential losses during the period of notional repairs to the silo, did not rest on solid ground and should have been dismissed. The <i>amicus curiae</i>, Prof\u00a0Andrew Phang, rightly explained the position in para\u00a086 of his submissions as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[S]uch reconstruction necessarily encompasses and incorporates whatever repairs which were hitherto required, but which cannot now be effected and which have now, in fact, been subsumed within the much larger enterprise of reconstruction. And the cause of the need for such reconstruction was \u2026 the <i>novus actus interveniens</i> for which [TEPP] was responsible. In other words, the chain of causation insofar as the repairs (and resultant consequential loss flowing [therefrom]) are concerned had been broken by the <i>novus actus interveniens</i>. Hence, the appellant was \u2013 and is \u2013 no longer liable for the consequential loss flowing from the notional repairs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Claim\u00a0F will next be considered. UCL attempted through Claim\u00a0F to recover the diminution in the value of the cement silo, as measured by the depreciated replacement cost method. It is true that while the general measure of loss in situations such as the present is the cost of repairing the damaged chattel, there may be occasions where a diminution in market value may merit some compensation in addition to the cost of repairs. In <i>Payton v Brooks</i> <nobr>[1974] RTR 169</nobr> at 176, Roskill\u00a0LJ explained:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[W]here the evidence justifies a finding that there has been, on top of the cost of repairs, some diminution in market value \u2013 or, to put the point another way, justifies the conclusion that the loss to the plaintiff has not been fully compensated by the receipt of the cost of complete and adequate repairs, because of a resultant diminution in market value \u2013 I can see no reason why the plaintiff should be deprived of recovery under that head of damage also.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The facts in the present case do not warrant an award of damages for diminution in value for the simple reason that what UCL eventually had was not a repaired silo with a lower value due to defects but a totally new silo that had to be built because of the <i>novus actus interveniens.</i> UCL cannot be allowed to claim damages for the loss of value of a hypothetically repaired silo as that would result in compensating it for a loss that it has not suffered and will not suffer. Salcon thus succeeds in its appeal against the arbitrator\u2019s finding in relation to Claim\u00a0F.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for Claim\u00a0E, which concerns damages for the diminution in the value of the silo measured by the discounted cash flow method, we agree with Prof\u00a0Phang that in the circumstances of this case, \u201cthere is no legal impediment to allowing [this claim] to succeed in place of [Claim\u00a0B], provided that [UCL] is not put in a better position [than] it would have been had it recovered under [Claim\u00a0B] instead\u201d. However, as Salcon has already accepted liability for Claim\u00a0B and UCL cannot be put in a better position under Claim\u00a0E than under Claim\u00a0B, it would be an exercise in futility for the parties to continue to spend time arguing whether the discounted cash flow method adopted by UCL\u2019s accounting expert is a reasonable alternative as well as an accurate measure of the loss resulting from Salcon\u2019s negligence. That being the case, the arbitrator\u2019s finding that UCL may proceed with Claim\u00a0E has no practical significance and the parties ought to take no further steps with respect to this matter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Costs</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Salcon is entitled to the costs of the appeal.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of    <CaseTitle>Collector of Land Revenue v Heng Long Investment Pte Ltd</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Collector of Land Revenue v Heng Long Investment Pte Ltd</SortTitle><SortDate>2001-06-22T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 159/2000</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#627\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Yong Pung How CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Eric Chin and Leonard Goh (Attorney-General's Chambers) for the appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Alan Wong and Peter Wong (William Lai &amp; Alan Wong) for the respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2462\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Land</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2472\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Compulsory acquisitions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2473\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Compensation payable</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Appeal against Collector's award</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Award by Appeals Board</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Claim for stamp duty in addition to market value of land</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether separate award to be made for each head of claim</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">Whether \"amounted awarded\" refers to composite award</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"9\">s 35(1) Land Acquisition Act (Cap 152)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3140\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Construction of statute</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Interpretation of \"amount awarded\"</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">s 35(1) Land Acquisition Act (Cap 152)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p align=\"justify\">\n      <font face=\"Times New Roman\" size=\"4\" color=\"#3322AA\">\n        <strong>JUDGMENT:</strong>\n      </font>\n    </p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><strong><font face=\"Times New Roman\" size=\"3\" color=\"#804040\">Grounds\n\nof Judgment</font></strong></p>\n\n<font face=\"Times New Roman\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\">1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal by the Collector of Land\n\nRevenue against the decision of the Appeals Board. It raised an issue concerning the\n\ninterpretation of s 35(1) of the Land Acquisition Act (Cap 152, 1985 ed) (\u2018the\n\nAct\u2019). We allowed the appeal and now give our reasons.</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Background</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent, Heng Long Investment Pte Ltd\n\n(\u2018Heng Long\u2019) owned three plots of adjoining land, namely, Lots 119-4, 119-5 and\n\n121-17, with frontages to Kovan Road and Upper Serangoon Road. The total land area of\n\nthese plots was 3,898.1 square metres.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 By declaration No. 2134 made on 24 June 1996,\n\nwhich was published in the Government Gazette No. 32 on 28 June 1996, notice was given\n\npursuant to s 5 of the Act for the acquisition of all the three plots of land for a public\n\npurpose, namely for the Northeast MRT line and for comprehensive development.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pursuant to s 10 of the Act, an inquiry was held\n\non 2 August 1996 before the Collector of Land Revenue (\u2018the Collector\u2019), and\n\nHeng Long submitted a claim of $26,000,000 as compensation for the acquisition. This claim\n\nwas partly supported by a report by JLW Property Consultants Pte Ltd which valued the\n\nacquired land at $20,000,000 as at 1 January 1995. On 28 October 1996, the Collector\n\nawarded Heng Long an amount of $16,760,000 (for the land and buildings with vacant\n\npossession) as the market value of the acquired land at the relevant date.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Heng Long appealed to the Appeals Board against\n\nthe Collector\u2019s award, claiming the sum of $20,000,000 as the market value of the\n\nacquired land. In addition, at the hearing before the Appeals Board, Heng Long also\n\nclaimed under s\u00a033(1)(e) of the Act a sum of $220,200 for stamp duty as an expense\n\nthey had incurred as a result of the compulsory acquisition. This claim for stamp duty was\n\nmade for the first time before the Appeals Board; it was not made at the inquiry before\n\nthe Collector.</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The decision of the Appeals Board</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Appeals Board rejected altogether the\n\nvaluation put forward by Heng Long\u2019s valuer and determined that the market value of\n\nthe acquired land was $15,647,610, which was lower than the Collector\u2019s award of\n\n$16,760,000. As for the claim for the stamp duty in the sum of $220,000, the Collector\n\nconceded that Heng Long was entitled to the claim. He therefore submitted before the\n\nAppeals Board that the total amount to which Heng Long was entitled was only $15,867,610,\n\ncomprising the market value of $15,647,610 of the acquired land as determined by the\n\nAppeals Board and the stamp duty of $220,000. However, by reason of s 35(1) of the Act,\n\nthe Appeals Board has no power to award as compensation a sum less than the amount awarded\n\nby the Collector, and accordingly the Appeals Board should award the sum of $16,760,000\n\n(which was the amount awarded by the Collector), the stamp duty of $220,000 being included\n\nin the award.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Appeals Board did not agree with the\n\nCollector\u2019s submission. The Appeals Board took the view that the market value of the\n\nland represented a head of the claim under s 33(1) of the Act. Although the amount awarded\n\nby the Collector for the market value of the acquired land was more than that determined\n\nby the Appeals Board, by reason of s 35(1) of the Act, the Appeals Board did not have the\n\npower to award a sum less than the amount awarded by the Collector for that particular\n\nhead of claim. As for the stamp duty of $220,000 claimed by Heng Long, it came under a\n\ndifferent head of claim, wholly different from that relating to market value. It was not\n\nincluded in the award made by the Collector. Therefore, to the amount of $16,760,000\n\nawarded by the Collector, there still had to be added the sum of $220,000, which formed a\n\nseparate head of claim, to make the total award. The Commissioner of the Appeals Board\n\nsaid:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">[W]hen this matter was heard by the Collector, she was dealing with\n\n  market value of the land \u2013 that is made abundantly clear in her grounds of award\n\n  which I summarized a moment ago. She determined the market value of the land and buildings\n\n  with vacant possession and gave an award of $16,760,000. No claim had been put forward to\n\n  her under Section 33(1)(e) as has been put forward before us. We understand and appreciate\n\n  what Mr Chin has said that at the end of the day there has to be one composite figure for\n\n  compensation. However in that one composite figure, there would be various matters,\n\n  various headings, as I have enumerated, and in this case, the appellant made a claim for\n\n  stamp duty expenses which the respondent concede the appellants are entitled to. So far as\n\n  market value is concerned, we have ruled after hearing the evidence, having heard all the\n\n  evidence, that the correct market value must be as put forward for the respondents, the\n\n  sum of $15,647,610, which is less than the market value as given by the Collector at\n\n  $16,760,000. Mr Chin for the respondent submits that in making the award, the sum of\n\n  $220,200, being stamp duties, which the respondent concedes the appellants are entitled\n\n  to, is absorbed into the Collector\u2019s award of $16,760,000. With respect, we cannot\n\n  agree with that. As I have sought to demonstrate, that relates purely to the market value\n\n  of the land. This other sum of $220,200 is another matter \u2013 wholly different from\n\n  that relating to market value. Because we do not have the power to reduce the award that\n\n  has already been made by the Collector which is more than the market value as we\n\n  determined it to be, there still has to be added the sum of $220,200 which forms a\n\n  separate head of claim to make the total award. In those circumstances, the award of this\n\n  Board will have to be what the Collector gave plus the sum of $220,200, making a total\n\n  award of --- what\u2019s the amount? $16,980,200. Am I right?</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, the Appeals Board awarded Heng Long\n\nthe sum of $16,980,000, comprising: (i) $16,760,000 as the market value of the land, and\n\n(ii) $220,000 as the stamp duty paid. The Collector appealed against this award.</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Preliminary issue</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under s 29(2) of the Act, an appeal from the\n\ndecision of the Appeals Board can only be brought to this Court on a question of law.\n\nBefore us, a preliminary issue was raised as to whether the issue raised under appeal was\n\none of law. Mr Eric Chin, counsel for the Collector, conceded that Heng Long was indeed\n\nentitled to claim as part of the compensation the amount of stamp duty it had paid.\n\nHowever, he submitted that whether the amount of stamp duty claimed ought to be included\n\nas part of the amount awarded turned on the interpretation of s 35(1) of the Act.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the other hand, Mr Alan Wong, counsel for Heng\n\nLong, contended that there was no question of law to be decided in this appeal and\n\ntherefore the appeal fell foul of s 29(2) of the Act and should necessarily be dismissed.\n\nMr Wong argued that the only issue in this appeal was whether the Appeals Board could add\n\nthe $220,000, representing stamp duty paid by Heng Long, to the amount awarded by the\n\nCollector and that this was a question of fact.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We agreed with Mr Chin that the issue in this\n\nappeal was one of statutory interpretation. It is settled law that questions as to the\n\ncorrect interpretation of statutory provisions are indeed questions of law. In our\n\njudgment, the Collector was entitled to bring this appeal under s 29(2) of the Act.</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The substantive points in this appeal</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The issue raised turned on the true construction\n\nof s 35(1) of the Act which provides as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">35. --(1) Where the applicant has made a claim to compensation pursuant\n\n  to any notice under section 8, the amount awarded to him shall not exceed the amount so\n\n  claimed or be less than the amount awarded by the Collector under section 10.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The crucial issue revolved around how the phrase \u2018the amount\n\nawarded\u2019 in s 35(1) was to be interpreted \u2013 should it be construed to mean the\n\ntotal compensation awarded or should it relate to each of the six items or matters\n\nreferred to in s 33(1) of the Act?</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr Chin submitted that under the Act, the\n\nCollector was obliged to make one composite award after considering, in so far as\n\nrelevant, each of the six matters falling within s 33(1) of the Act. The Collector was not\n\nobliged to give a breakdown of the amounts attributed to each of the six matters listed.\n\nThat being the case, Mr Chin argued that on the true construction of s 35(1) \u2018the\n\namount awarded\u2019 means the composite award and not any specific sum for each of the\n\nmatters listed in s 33(1).</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Therefore, Mr Chin\u2019s contention was that the\n\nAppeals Board was mistaken in taking the view that it had to apply s 35(1) to each of the\n\nsix matters set out in s\u00a033(1) as the \u2018heads of claim\u2019, as opposed to\n\napplying it to the composite award made. The \u2018amount awarded\u2019 under s 35(1) does\n\nnot mean the individual amount that may be attributed to each \u2018head of claim\u2019\n\nthat makes up the award but <i>the total composite award</i> made under s 10 of the Act.\n\nHis position was that under s 35(1), the Appeals Board was free to reduce or increase the\n\namounts attributed to the heads of claim under s 33(1), but the total composite amount\n\nawarded should not exceed the amount claimed or be less than the amount awarded by the\n\nCollector.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Adopting this interpretation, Mr Chin argued\n\nthat, as the Appeals Board found that the market value of the acquired land was\n\n$15,647,610, which was an item referred to in s 33(1)(a) and that an expense in the sum of\n\n$220,000 was incurred as a result of the compulsory acquisition, which was an item falling\n\nwithin s 33(1)(e), the total composite figure for the award was therefore $15,867,610.\n\nHowever, by reason of s\u00a035(1) of the Act, the Appeals Board could not award an amount\n\nless than the amount awarded by the Collector. As a result, the Appeals Board should have\n\nordered the Collector\u2019s award of $16,760,000 to stand. Instead, the Appeals Board\n\ntook the view that, as it could not reduce the Collector\u2019s award of $16,760,000 as\n\nthe market value, it added to this amount a further sum of $220,000 for the stamp duty\n\nincurred, thus making a total award of $16,980,000.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Our decision</p></b>\n\n</i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><i>16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn first to s 33(1) of the Act, which so\n\nfar as material provides:</i></p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">33.\u2014(1) In determining the amount of compensation to be awarded\n\n  for land acquired under this Act, the Board shall, subject to subsections (2), (3) and\n\n  (4), take into consideration the following matters and no others:</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) the market value \u2014</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">\u2026..</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) any increase in the value of any other land of the person\n\n    interested likely to accrue from the use to which the land acquired will be put;</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(c) the damage, if any, sustained by the person interested at the time\n\n    of the Collector\u2019s taking possession of the land by reason of severing that land from\n\n    his other land;</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(d) the damage, if any, sustained by the person interested at the time\n\n    of the Collector\u2019s taking possession of the land by reason of the acquisition\n\n    injuriously affecting his other property, whether movable or immovable, in any other\n\n    manner;</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(e) if, in consequence of the acquisition, he is compelled to change\n\n    his residence or place of business, the reasonable expenses, if any, incidental to that\n\n    change; and</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(f) if, in consequence of the acquisition, any reissue of title is\n\n    necessary, the fees or costs relating to survey, issue and registration of title, stamp\n\n    duty and such other costs or fees which may reasonably be incurred.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Clearly in determining the amount of compensation to be awarded, the\n\nAppeals Board is required by s 33(1) to take into consideration such of these matters\n\nenumerated in sub-s (1) as are relevant. Having considered such of the matters as are\n\nrelevant, the Appeals Board then proceeds to make an award of compensation. The amount the\n\nAppeals Board makes is one composite award. There is nothing in the Act which requires the\n\nBoard to make, or entitles the Board to make, a separate award for each of the matters (so\n\nfar as they are relevant) listed in s 33(1).</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having determined the amount of the award, the\n\nBoard then applies s 35(1) which is as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">35. --(1) Where the applicant has made a claim to compensation pursuant\n\n  to any notice under section 8, <i>the amount awarded </i>to him shall not exceed the\n\n  amount so claimed or be less than <i>the amount awarded by the Collector</i> under section\n\n  10. [Emphasis is ours]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">It is clear to us that the words \u2018amount awarded to him\u2019 in\n\nthe context of the subsection clearly means the amount awarded by the Appeals Board. Now,\n\nin this case, the amount awarded by the Appeals Board comprises two sums: (i) the sum of\n\n$15,647,610 as the market value of the land acquired, a matter falling within\n\ns\u00a033(1)(a), and (ii) the sum of $220,000 as the stamp duty incurred as a consequence\n\nof the compulsory acquisition, a matter falling within s 33(1)(e). The total of these two\n\ncomponents came to $15,867,610, and this total sum represented <i>the amount awarded </i>to\n\nHeng Long as compensation. Now, the amount awarded by the Collector under s 10 of the Act\n\nwas $16,760,00. As the amount awarded by the Appeals Board was less than <i>the amount\n\nawarded by the Collector</i>, s 35(1) of the Act applied and the Appeals Board was obliged\n\nunder that section to award an amount not less than the amount awarded by the Collector.\n\nIn other words, the Appeals Board was obliged to award the amount of $16,760,000 to Heng\n\nLong. For the purpose of s 35(1) the total composite amount awarded has to be looked at\n\nand not the various sums or components that make up the total. In our judgment, the\n\nAppeals Board was not entitled to treat, as the amount awarded, the amount of $16,760,000\n\nbeing the market value of the acquired land and then add to it the amount of $220,000 as\n\nthe stamp duty incurred, thereby awarding in total a sum of $16,980,000.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this regard, we found the Indian authorities\n\ncited by Mr Chin to be highly persuasive and pertinent. The provisions of the Act,\n\nincluding s 35(1), are almost identical to the Indian equivalent, specifically the Indian\n\nLand Acquisition Act 1894 (\u2018the Indian Act\u2019). Section 35(1) of our Act is\n\nsubstantially the same as s 25 of the Indian Act. The interpretation of s 25 of the Indian\n\nAct has been dealt with in numerous Indian cases.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Firstly, in the case of <i>Bai Jadav and others v\n\nCollector of Broach</i> AIR 1926 Bombay 372, Macleod CJ said at p 372:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">We do not think then, that the Judge was in error in infringing the\n\n  rule under which the Court is not entitled to award as compensation to a claimant under\n\n  the Land Acquisition Act an amount less than the amount offered by the Collector. The\n\n  compensation\u2026..is to be determined after certain matters have been taken into\n\n  consideration by the Court and <b>the total compensation has to be looked to and not the\n\n  various items which make up that total</b>. [Emphasis is ours]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Some seven years later, the case of <i>Secretary\n\nof State v F.E. Dinshaw </i>AIR 1933 Sind 21 went before the courts. Rupchand AJC said at\n\np 24:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\u2026..it would appear that s 25 was <b>intended to refer to the whole\n\n  claim made by the claimant and the whole amount of compensation awarded to him</b>\u2026..,\n\n  and to empower the Judge to alter the award of the Land Acquisition Officer under any one\n\n  or more of the sub-heads by either decreasing and increasing the amount awarded, provided\n\n  he did not award less than the total amount awarded by that officer or more than the total\n\n  amount claimed before that officer by the claimant. [Emphasis is ours]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Rupchand AJC also referred to the case of <i>Gangadhara\n\nShastri v Deputy Collector of Madras</i> (1912) 14 IC 270, where the same principles\n\napplied \u2013 that the whole case and not merely the particular objection should be\n\nreferred to; therefore it is open to the judge to award a sum less than that awarded by\n\nthe Land Acquisition Officer in respect of some of the sub-items, provided of course that\n\nthe total amount which he awards to the claimant on all items is not less than that\n\noriginally awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The next relevant case was <i>Secretary of State\n\nv Malik Amir Mohammad Khan</i> AIR 1935 Lahore 653. A very pertinent passage from the\n\njudgment of Din Mohammad J at p 655 reads as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">It is no doubt true that the award made by the Collector cannot be\n\n  reduced, but <b>this restriction is confined to the award on the whole and not to its\n\n  component parts</b>. There is nothing in s 25(1) which precludes the District Judge from\n\n  introducing variations in different items that make up the award so long as the total\n\n  amount is not reduced. We cannot import into the plain language of section 25(1)\n\n  restrictions which do not exist there and <b>the only reasonable construction that can be\n\n  placed on the language employed therein is that it is only the total compensation made by\n\n  the Collector that cannot be reduced</b>. [Emphasis is ours]</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally the court in the case of <i>Sardar Sujan\n\nSingh and others v Secretary of State </i>AIR 1936 Peshawar 217 confirmed that the\n\nDistrict Judge had the power and was entitled to add some item while reducing another from\n\nthe Collector\u2019s award with the result that the total award was <b><i>increased</i></b>.\n\nThe only limitation to the court\u2019s power was that it could not <i><b>decrease</b> </i>the\n\nCollector\u2019s total award.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<b><i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Conclusion</p>\n\n</i></b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our judgment, the expression the \u2018amount\n\nawarded\u2019 refers to a composite award made by the Appeals Board and the Collector\n\nrespectively and not to each separate head of claim under s 33(1). The Act clearly\n\nenvisages the award of a composite figure, as opposed to an individual award for each head\n\nof claim.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our judgment, the Appeals Board, having\n\ndetermined that the market value of the acquired land was $15,647,610, should have added\n\nto it the sum of $220,000, representing the stamp duty, thus making one composite award of\n\n$15,867,610. As this amount was less than the Collector\u2019s award of $16,760,000, the\n\nAppeals Board, as required under s 35(1) of the Act, should have awarded to Heng Long the\n\nsum of $16,760,000. We accordingly allowed the appeal, and made an award of $16,760,000 to\n\nHeng Long.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Sgd:</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Yong Pung How<br/>\n\nChief Justice</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Sgd:</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">L P Thean<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Sgd:</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Chao Hick Tin<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0</p>\n\n</font>\n\n\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"Judg-quote-list0\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8 August 2007</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chan Sek Keong\u00a0CJ (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Introduction</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against the decision of the trial judge, who dismissed the claim of Spandeck Engineering (S) Pte Ltd (\u201cthe appellant\u201d) in the tort of negligence against the Defence Science &amp; Technology Agency (\u201cthe respondent\u201d). Her judgment is reported in <i>Spandeck Engineering (S) Pte Ltd v Defence Science &amp; Technology Agency</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 720</nobr> (\u201cthe Judgment\u201d). At the end of the hearing, we unanimously dismissed the appeal. We now give our reasons.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Apart from the substantive rights and liabilities of the parties, which must surely form the primary focus of any judicial decision, this case was also about an intensely practical problem in the law of negligence: How does one ascertain whether a duty of care exists in law between one person and another where there is no pre-existing contractual or legal relationship between them? The common law is rudderless and surprisingly fraught with difficulties and uncertainties in relation to this deceptively simple and yet important question. The courts in Singapore are no less spared from this problem which we will now address. We turn first to the facts of the present case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Background facts</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Award of the contract for the project</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s claim stemmed from a dispute relating to the building project known as \u201cThe Proposed Redevelopment of Medical Camp in Nee Soon Camp Lot 212 PT MK 13 at Transit Road \u2013 Project LE(D) 1068 C08 MINDEF/DSTA\u201d (\u201cthe Project\u201d). As its name suggests, the Project was to redevelop a medical facility at Nee Soon Army Camp for the Ministry of Defence (\u201cMindef\u201d). The Government of Singapore (\u201cthe Employer\u201d) put the Project out for tender to which the appellant submitted a \u201cbase tender\u201d and an \u201calternative tender\u201d. In relation to this \u201calternative tender\u201d, which was submitted on 15\u00a0March 1999,</span><a id=\"_ftnref1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\" name=\"_ftnref1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 1]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">the appellant offered an alternative pre-cast/structural design. This alternative design consisted of a change in the original cast-in-situ design to the pre-cast structure design which would result in cost savings of about $200,000 and a shortening of the construction time by two months.</span><a id=\"_ftnref2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\" name=\"_ftnref2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 2]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Employer accepted the alternative design and awarded the appellant a contract dated 24\u00a0June 1999 (\u201cthe Contract\u201d) at a lump sum price of $31.78m to execute and complete the Project. The agreed commencement date of the Contract was 15\u00a0June 1999 and the completion date was 14\u00a0January 2001.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Salient terms of the Contract</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Contract incorporated the terms of the Public Sector Standard Conditions of Contract (\u201cPSSCOC\u201d), by which an appointed superintending officer (\u201cSO\u201d) was responsible for the administration and supervision of the Project, including certifying interim payments in respect of the appellant\u2019s work for the Project. In particular, the Contract provided in cl\u00a02.8(1) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Superintending Officer, the Superintending Officer\u2019s Representative or any assistant appointed \u2026 shall at no time be under any obligation or duty to the Contractor [<i>ie</i>, the appellant] either on behalf of the Employer or his own account to exercise or not to exercise any of his powers under the Contract, nor shall any failure to do so on his own part in any way prejudice the rights of the Employer against the Contractor or render the Employer liable to the Contractor.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the settlement of disputes relating to the Project, cl\u00a034 was the governing clause. Its provisions, in so far as they are material, are set out below:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">34.1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reference to the Superintending Officer</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If a dispute or difference of whatsoever kind shall arise between the Employer or the Superintending Officer or the Superintending Officer\u2019s Representative and the Contractor in connection with or arising out of the Contract or the execution of the Works \u2026 including any dispute or difference as to any \u2026 certificate or valuation of the Superintending Officer or the Superintending Officer\u2019s Representative, it shall in the first place be referred by either party in writing to the Superintending Officer for his decision. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">34.2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reference to Arbitration</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If either the Employer or Contractor is dissatisfied with the decision of the Superintending Officer made pursuant to Clause\u00a034.1 hereof, \u2026 then the Employer or the Contractor may \u2026 give notice to the other party with a copy for information to the Superintending Officer of his intention to refer the decision or the dispute or difference that had not been decided to an arbitrator. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">However, the amount of damages for which the Employer might be liable to the appellant was qualified by cl\u00a032.8 of the Contract, which provided as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32.8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Delay in Certification</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Under no circumstances shall the Employer be liable to pay to the Contractor [<i>ie</i>, the appellant] any damages, whether by way of interest or otherwise, for <i>any failure or delay by the Superintending Officer in certifying any payment due or payable</i> to the Contractor.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Appointment of the SO and consultants</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 7\u00a0July 1999, Mindef advised the appellant by letter that Quek Kheng Song (\u201cQKS\u201d) and Huang Siong Hui were appointed the SO and SO\u2019s representative respectively, with Peh Chew Seng as the alternate SO\u2019s representative in the absence of the SO\u2019s representative. At that time, QKS was employed by the Employer as an officer in the Land &amp; Estate Organisation in Mindef. In addition, various individuals and entities were also appointed as consultants to provide professional services for the Project (\u201cthe Consultants\u201d). Among the Consultants appointed was KPK Quantity Surveyors (1995) Pte Ltd (\u201cKPK\u201d), which was appointed the quantity surveyor for the Project. In addition, RDC Architects Pte Ltd (\u201cRDC\u201d) was appointed the architect for the Project.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequent to that, the respondent was constituted under the Defence Science and Technology Agency Act (Cap\u00a075A, 2001\u00a0Rev Ed) in March 2000 and it was around that time that the respondent assumed the role of the SO. QKS was no longer the SO for the Project by this time but continued to represent the respondent at the Project after his employment was transferred from the Employer to the respondent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Summary of tender and cost breakdown</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The tender documents for the Project required the appellant to submit a summary of tender (\u201cSOT\u201d) as well as a cost breakdown (\u201cCBD\u201d). The SOT and CBD were documents prepared by KPK listing out all the items of work required for the Project being tendered. It required the contractors who were tendering for the Project to price this itemised list as a cost breakdown of the lump sum contract tender price, in the form of the CBD. The SOT was a summary of the detailed cost itemisation set out in the CBD.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Original SOT and CBD</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As alluded to earlier (at [3] above), as part of its bid, the appellant had offered an alternative tender in addition to the base tender. The SOT and CBD which the appellant had submitted with its tenders were based on the base tender and did not reflect the breakdown under the alternative tender. This meant that the original SOT and CBD did not accurately reflect the scope and actual value of the works to be carried out by the appellant under the alternative tender.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>SOT and CBD incorporated into the Contract</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As such, on the basis of the Employer accepting the appellant\u2019s alternative tender, KPK requested the appellant to submit a revised SOT and CBD to reflect the change of the design. Pursuant to this request, the appellant submitted a revised SOT and CBD dated 24\u00a0May 1999,</span><a id=\"_ftnref3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn3\" name=\"_ftnref3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 3]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">which it alleged was incorporated into the Contract <i>without</i> any further revision. On the other hand, the respondent contended that there <i>were</i> further revisions to the SOT and CBD dated 24\u00a0May 1999 and that the final SOT and CBD were finalised by KPK with the appellant and incorporated into the Contract in or about October 1999.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the Judgment at [9], the trial judge resolved this issue in favour of the respondent, where she said:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">After the Employer had accepted the plaintiff\u2019s alternative proposal, KPK requested the plaintiff to submit a revised SOT to reflect the change in design. The plaintiff submitted the first revision to KPK on 24\u00a0May 1999. <i>After further revisions by the plaintiff, the revised SOT and cost breakdown (\u201cCBD\u201d) for the contract price were finalised by KPK with the plaintiff and incorporated into the Contract documents in October 1999</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">We agreed with the trial judge\u2019s finding. It was clear to us that the SOT bound into the Contract documents</span><a id=\"_ftnref4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn4\" name=\"_ftnref4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 4]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">was not the same as the appellant\u2019s revised SOT dated 24\u00a0May 1999. That the SOT bound into the Contract was not a version <i>prior</i> to the SOT dated 24\u00a0May 1999 was supported by the fact that the total cost and contract period were based on the alternative tender. Given that the revised SOT dated 24\u00a0May 1999 was the <i>first</i> SOT based on the alternative tender, it must follow that any <i>other</i> SOT based on the alternative tender must have come <i>after</i> the SOT dated 24\u00a0May 1999. Accordingly, contrary to the appellant\u2019s contention, the SOT dated 24\u00a0May 1999 was indeed revised before it was incorporated into the Contract. This will henceforth be referred to as \u201cthe Contract SOT\u201d while the CBD incorporated into the Contract will be known as \u201cthe Contract CBD\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Exercise to revise the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant contended that, in the course of submitting its progress claims, it discovered that numerous items related to the alternative tender were omitted from the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD and this in turn allegedly led to the under-certification of the progress payments to the appellant. This had occurred even though the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD were bound into the Contract documents after revisions by the appellant itself. These alleged deficiencies in the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD were highlighted by the appellant by a letter dated 29\u00a0September 2000, in which it also submitted a revised SOT and CBD to KPK and requested KPK to review and approve them for use in the future assessment of the appellant\u2019s progress claims.</span><a id=\"_ftnref5\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn5\" name=\"_ftnref5\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 5]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The request was initially rejected by the Consultants by their letter of 11\u00a0October 2000,</span><a id=\"_ftnref6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn6\" name=\"_ftnref6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 6]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">who regarded it as a departure from the terms of the Contract. However, by this time, the respondent and the Consultants had received many unsolicited letters from sub-contractors and suppliers of the appellant complaining that they had been underpaid by the appellant. They also requested the Employer to arrange for direct payment to be made to them for work done.</span><a id=\"_ftnref7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn7\" name=\"_ftnref7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 7]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Eventually, in view of these developments, a meeting was held on 16\u00a0November 2000 between the representatives of the appellant and respondent. At this meeting, the appellant\u2019s managing director, Dr\u00a0Chi Chao-Ton Tony (\u201cDr\u00a0Chi\u201d), repeated the request for the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD to be revised so as to alleviate the appellant\u2019s cash-flow problems.</span><a id=\"_ftnref8\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn8\" name=\"_ftnref8\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 8]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent, on behalf of the Employer, expressed its willingness to consider the appellant\u2019s request to adjust the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD subject to the following conditions:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 KPK would evaluate the new SOT and CBD proposed by the appellant to try to ensure that adequate money was allocated for the uncompleted works; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the appellant was to submit a performance bond, equivalent to the amount of money proposed to be reallocated from the uncompleted works, to safeguard the Employer\u2019s interest.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">At the meeting, the appellant agreed to the conditions stated above and KPK was tasked to evaluate the appellant\u2019s proposed revision of the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD and to subsequently submit its recommendations to the respondent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 KPK completed its assessment on or about 22\u00a0January 2001 and a copy of the proposed revised SOT and CBD (\u201cKPK-revised SOT and CBD\u201d) was sent by KPK to the appellant by a letter dated 1\u00a0February 2001. By way of a letter dated 20\u00a0February 2001,</span><a id=\"_ftnref9\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn9\" name=\"_ftnref9\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 9]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">the appellant agreed to adopt the KPK-revised SOT and CBD. Subsequently, by way of a letter dated 6\u00a0April 2001,</span><a id=\"_ftnref10\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn10\" name=\"_ftnref10\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 10]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">RDC reminded the appellant of the discussion that had taken place at the meeting in November 2000 and requested it to propose the amount of bond money for the Employer\u2019s consideration.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Abandonment of exercise to revise the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Later, at a meeting held on 10\u00a0April 2001 between the representatives of the appellant and the respondent, RDC said that if the KPK-revised SOT and CBD were implemented, an extra amount of $200,000 would have to be paid upfront to the appellant in the forthcoming progress payment. This represented a risk to the Employer and that was why a performance bond was necessary before the KPK-revised SOT and CBD could be implemented. As recorded in the minutes of the meeting,</span><a id=\"_ftnref11\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn11\" name=\"_ftnref11\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 11]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Dr\u00a0Chi then informed the respondent and its representatives that the appellant had decided not to proceed with the implementation of the KPK-revised SOT and CBD because there was \u201cinsufficient incentive\u201d to do so. As such, and at the appellant\u2019s request, the exercise to revise the Contract SOT and the Contract CBD was abandoned.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Novation of the Contract</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 During a meeting on 24\u00a0May 2001 and by way of a letter dated 25\u00a0May 2001, the appellant informed the respondent that it was considering the possibility of novating the Contract to another contractor. The Contract was eventually novated to Neo Corporation Pte Ltd (\u201cNeoCorp\u201d). The novation agreement between the appellant, the Employer and NeoCorp was signed on 16\u00a0July 2001.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the time of the novation, the appellant had only completed about half of the Contract work. In the ordinary course of events, the appellant would have been paid the full lump sum at the end of the Project and would also have been entitled to submit to the Consultants for certification any claim for works not certified. If disputes arose, the appellant was entitled to submit these disputes for resolution in accordance with the arbitration clause (<i>ie</i>, cl\u00a034 of the Contract). However, the appellant lost this right when it novated the Contract to NeoCorp in July 2001.
