This was the reason why the appellant had decided to pursue a claim against the respondent in tort to recover its alleged losses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Appellant\u2019s claim and trial judge\u2019s findings</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant claimed against the respondent for negligence on the basis that the respondent owed it a duty of care to apply professional skill and judgment in certifying, in a fair and unbiased manner, payment for work carried out by the appellant to avoid causing it any loss due to undervaluation and under-certification of works. The appellant claimed that the respondent breached this duty by negligently undervaluing and under-certifying the appellant\u2019s works, leading to the following losses:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $2,234,704.24, being the difference between the amount claimed by the appellant for works done on site, and the certified amount in progress payment No\u00a023;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $290,102.25, being underpayment of variation orders;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $629,994.59, being loss of profit from the balance of works;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $124,827.02,</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">being loss of management fees from mechanical and electrical variation orders; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $530,324.08,</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">being loss of interest.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event, the trial judge dismissed the appellant\u2019s claim. The trial judge found that the respondent did not owe a duty of care to the appellant to avoid causing the latter to suffer pure economic loss through its (the respondent\u2019s) negligent conduct: the Judgment at [92]. Notwithstanding this finding, the trial judge went on to consider the other \u201cmain issues that arose from the evidence adduced at the trial\u201d and held that <i>even if</i> a duty of care had been owed, the evidence was \u201cagainst the [appellant]\u201d and \u201cclearly disproved the breach of any such duty by the [respondent] to the [appellant]\u201d: the Judgment at [92], [93] and [190].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Issues on appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is trite law that, in order to succeed in a claim under the tort of negligence, a claimant has to establish that (a) the defendant owes the claimant a duty of care; (b) the defendant has breached that duty of care by acting (or omitting to act) below the standard of care required of it; (c) the defendant\u2019s breach has caused the claimant damage; (d) the claimant\u2019s losses arising from the defendant\u2019s breach are not too remote; and (e) such losses can be adequately proved and quantified: see, for example, <i>Clerk &amp; Lindsell on Torts</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 19th Ed, 2006) at para\u00a08-04.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, the first issue which we had to consider was whether there was a duty of care owed by the respondent to the appellant in the manner we have outlined earlier. As we found against the appellant on this threshold issue, we did not have to consider the other issues of breach, causation and remoteness.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Trial judge\u2019s decision in relation to the duty of care</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In considering the duty of care issue, the trial judge applied both the two-stage test in <i>Anns v Merton London Borough Council</i> [1978] AC\u00a0728 (\u201c<i>Anns</i>\u201d) and the three-part test in <i>Caparo Industries Plc v Dickman</i> [1990] 2\u00a0AC\u00a0605 (\u201c<i>Caparo</i>\u201d) and reached the same result that there was no duty of care, an implicit judicial recognition of the state of confusion which belabours the local law in respect to the <i>applicable</i> test to be used to determine the existence of a duty of care for cases involving claims for pure economic loss (\u201ccases of pure economic loss\u201d) or, indeed, cases involving claims of personal injuries and physical damage (collectively \u201ccases of physical damage\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In coming to her decision, the trial judge placed considerable emphasis on the following factors: (a)\u00a0there was no assumption of direct responsibility by the respondent to the appellant for the economic loss claimed; (b)\u00a0there was no direct contractual relationship between the appellant as the main contractor and the respondent as the SO; (c)\u00a0the appellant had recourse under the Contract to claim additional payments for variation works from the Employer; and (d)\u00a0the property in question was an army camp, not a residential development: see the Judgment at [54].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before we deal with the substantive arguments in relation to the duty of care, it is first necessary for us to determine the <i>applicable test</i> for ascertaining the existence of a duty of care.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Applicable test for duty of care</span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The parties\u2019 arguments</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, the appellant submitted that the proper test to ascertain the existence of a duty of care for cases of pure economic loss should be a combination of the common elements from both the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> and the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i>, citing the views contained in Andrew Phang, Saw Cheng Lim &amp; Gary Chan, \u201cOf Precedent, Theory and Practice \u2013 The Case for a Return to <i>Anns</i>\u201d [2006] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a01. Adopting this approach, the appellant submitted that the following issues arose for our consideration in relation to the existence of a duty of care in this case: (a)\u00a0whether, in the circumstances of this case, there existed a relationship of sufficient proximity so as to give rise to a duty of care on the part of the respondent in respect of a pure economic loss; and (b)\u00a0if so, whether there was any policy consideration that should nonetheless limit or negate the duty established under the first stage. However, the appellant also submitted that before these two issues could even be considered, the court should determine a preliminary issue first, <i>viz</i>, whether the damage suffered by the appellant was foreseeable by the respondent. We shall come back to this submission after we have addressed the current tests in the developed common law jurisdictions on the duty of care.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The current state of the law in Singapore on liability in negligence for pure economic loss, and indeed for physical damage, is not entirely satisfactory. Liability for pure economic loss (which is the subject matter of the appeal before us) is an issue of great complexity and one that imposes on the courts a great responsibility as this is an area of law where the determination of liability has been and will continue to be, unless the Legislature intervenes, the exclusive domain of the Judiciary. Judicial adjudication of claims for pure economic loss calls for caution and judiciousness in not extending the limits of liability for negligent acts to avoid any unforeseen economic cost to the public in the court\u2019s desire to do justice to the claimant in the particular case. It is <i>par excellence</i> a policy decision for the court to make. To begin with, although the English courts have thought fit not to allow recovery of pure economic loss, the Singapore courts have taken a different path and have allowed recovery of such losses in a few decisions. Whether these decisions have laid down a general principle, that pure economic loss can be recovered in all cases of negligence, is a matter we wish to re-examine because of its implications for the redistribution of wealth in the economy. Furthermore, it is important that we revisit this issue as the Singapore courts have also applied a different test to determine the existence of a duty of care when the type of damages claimed is pure economic loss, and when it is for loss associated with physical damage, even though the foundation of the two different tests is derived from a common source, <i>viz</i>, the well-known English decisions in <i>Anns</i> and <i>Caparo.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Preliminary observations</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A few preliminary observations are apposite at this juncture. The common law is built on interconnected layers of principles, universal and particular, each dependent on and interacting with the other, held together by the overarching goal of fairness and justice. To understand this is to comprehend the common law\u2019s eternal search for rational and universal principles in the law. Thus, in the area of negligence, the principles relating to the imposition of a duty of care must be rational and coherent and be reliably and consistently determined. With the universal in the form of general principles, the law will be a coherent body of rules, and not consist of singular instances of judicial decisions unrelated to each other. However, to have the universal without the particular is to lose sight of the need for practical solutions for the myriad of disputes that come before the courts. These general principles provide the focus to which the particular (<i>viz</i>, the facts of decided cases <i>and</i> the present case) must then be analysed so that the courts may, within this aggregation of the universal and the particular, reach a result that is fair and just. As Cooke\u00a0P put it in <i>South Pacific Manufacturing Co Ltd v New Zealand Security Consultants &amp; Investigations Ltd</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 NZLR 282</nobr> at 294:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A broad two-stage approach or <i>any other approach is only a framework, a more or less methodical way of tackling a problem.</i> However it is formulated should not matter in the end. Ultimately the exercise can only be a balancing one and the important object is that all relevant factors be weighed. There is no escape from the truth that, whatever formula be used, the outcome in a grey area case has to be determined by judicial judgment. <i>Formulae can help</i> <i>to organise thinking but they cannot provide answers</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Ultimately, the resolution of a claim in negligence should be based on general principles that have universal application to every factual situation which gives rise to a legal dispute either on liability or damages.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the tort of negligence, careless conduct cannot, by itself, be used as a basis for tortious liability. It is only carelessness within the context of <i>breach of a duty to take care</i> <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> another person that there is liability in negligence, and hence the necessity to determine the circumstances in which the duty of care arises. In other words, even if duty sets the boundaries of liability (as Prof\u00a0Tan Keng Feng put it in \u201cThe Three-Part Test: Yet Another Test of Duty in Negligence\u201d (1989) 31\u00a0Mal\u00a0L\u00a0Rev 223 at 225), it also sets the limits on duty where liability is seen to be indeterminate. The two concepts of duty and liability are of course related but at the same time each affects the operation of the other. The difficulty is in balancing the goal of a fair and just result for the parties and the imposition of indeterminate liability on an indeterminate class of tortfeasors. That is the primary responsibility of the courts in developing the tort of negligence. How to do so without compromising on the usefulness of the tort of negligence as a tool for the redistribution of economic wealth fairly between tortfeasors and their victims is essentially the crucial issue for the courts. Unlike contract, where the rights and liabilities of the parties are primarily agreed or fixed between themselves, tortious liability occurs <i>independently</i> of the parties\u2019 intentions and is hence liable to manifest itself in, potentially, an infinite number of situations, given that carelessness is a human frailty. This was what Cardozo\u00a0CJ was afraid of in <i>Ultramares Corp v Touche, Niven &amp; Co</i> 255 NY\u00a0170 (1931) at 179, <i>ie</i>, the imposition of \u201cliability in an indeterminate amount for an indeterminate time to an indeterminate class\u201d. Lord Buckmaster also alluded to this concern when he said in <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> [1932] AC\u00a0562 at 577, \u201cIf one step, why not fifty?\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The answer to this lies in legal control mechanisms for which the courts are primarily responsible. Lord Atkin, who may be regarded as the founder of the modern law of negligence, referred to this heavy responsibility in <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> (at 583\u2013584):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[I]n the branch of the law which deals with civil wrongs, dependent in England at any rate entirely upon the application by judges of general principles also formulated by judges, it is of particular importance to guard against the danger of <i>stating propositions of law in wider terms than is necessary</i>, lest essential factors be omitted in the wider survey and the inherent adaptability of English law be unduly restricted. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Indeed, the various tests which have been applied by the courts following <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> are but a manifestation of one or more of the legal control mechanisms formulated by the courts within the general principles. It is essential, at the outset, to note that although there are now many such mechanisms, they all serve the <i>singular purpose</i> of limiting liability, albeit in different ways. To put it another way, these legal control mechanisms ultimately seek to limit liability by resorting to the use of different conceptual tests, such as reasonable foreseeability, proximity or public policy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The different tests in England</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The neighbour principle and its development</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although there were some cases prior to 1932 which purported to articulate some kind of general principle to determine the existence of a duty of care (see, for example, <i>Heaven v Pender</i> (1883) 11\u00a0QBD 503 at 509, <i>per</i> Brett\u00a0MR), the search for a universal basis for duty is generally regarded to have begun with the House of Lords decision of <i>Donoghue v Stevenson.</i> In that case, Lord Atkin famously said (at 580):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The rule that you are to love your neighbour becomes in law, you must not injure your neighbour; and the lawyer\u2019s question, Who is my neighbour? receives a restricted reply. You must take reasonable care to avoid acts or omissions which you can reasonably foresee would be likely to injure your neighbour. Who, then, in law, is my neighbour? The answer seems to be \u2013 persons who are so closely and directly affected by my act that I ought reasonably to have them in contemplation as being so affected when I am directing my mind to the acts or omissions which are called in question.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">This statement was then generally understood to mean that liability was founded on the test of pure foreseeability alone: see <i>Hay or Bourhill v Young</i> [1943] AC\u00a092 at 107, where Lord\u00a0Wright accepted Lord\u00a0Atkin\u2019s statement as establishing the \u201cgeneral concept of reasonable foresight as the criterion of negligence\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, it soon became apparent that a test based on foreseeability alone could be too wide and too pliable as a basis of liability in some situations. In order to limit or exclude what was deemed as unwarranted recovery, the courts frequently resorted to deciding artificially that certain claimants were \u201cunforeseeable\u201d: see Prof\u00a0Tan ([29] <i>supra</i>) at 225. This led Lord\u00a0Denning to consider foreseeability and the existence of a duty as simply a question of public policy. In <i>Spartan Steel &amp; Alloys Ltd v Martin &amp; Co (Contractors) Ltd</i> [1973] QB\u00a027, Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR said (at 36):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whenever the courts draw a line to make out the bounds of duty, they do it as <i>matter of policy</i> so as to limit the responsibility of the defendant. [emphasis added].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Similarly, in <i>Dorset Yacht Co Ltd v Home Office</i> [1969] 2\u00a0QB\u00a0412, Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR said (at 426):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[Duty] is, I think, at bottom a matter of public policy which we, as judges, must resolve. This talk of \u201cduty\u201d or \u201cno duty\u201d is simply a way of limiting the range of liability for negligence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The two-stage test in</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Anns</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The pendulum which swung between foreseeability and policy as the determinant of duty showed signs of resting in <i>Arenson v Casson Beckman Rutley &amp; Co</i> [1977] AC\u00a0405, in which Lord\u00a0Simon of Glaisdale appeared to endorse the idea that where Lord Atkin\u2019s neighbour principle was seen as fixing the defendant with responsibility for the claimant\u2019s damage, liability should follow, save where there was some good reason why it should not, and identified \u201cpublic policy\u201d as the qualifying factor (at 419). That pendulum finally became stationary in favour of an approach which meshed foreseeability with public policy in <i>Anns</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), where Lord\u00a0Wilberforce influentially said (at 751\u2013752):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[I]n order to establish that a duty of care arises in a particular situation, <i>it is not necessary to bring the facts of that situation within those of previous situations in which a duty of care has been held to exist</i>. Rather the question has to be approached in two stages. First one has to ask whether, as between the alleged wrongdoer and the person who has suffered damage there is a sufficient relationship of proximity or neighbourhood such that, in the reasonable contemplation of the former, carelessness on his part may be likely to cause damage to the latter \u2013 in which case a prima facie duty of care arises. Secondly, if the first question is answered affirmatively, it is necessary to consider whether there are any considerations which ought to negative, or to reduce or limit the scope of the duty or the class of persons to whom it is owed or the damages to which breach of it may give rise \u2026 [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</i> It is well known that there is some controversy regarding the meaning of the first stage of the test: Did it relate only to the <i>factual</i> issue of reasonable foreseeability <i>or</i> did it introduce the <i>legal</i> conception of proximity (see further Phang, Saw &amp; Chan ([26] <i>supra</i>) at 40\u201341)? We will revisit this problem later (see [74] below). For the moment, it suffices to note that this pronouncement in <i>Anns</i> is not only significant for the elucidation of a two-stage test to determine duty, it also introduced the concept of a truly \u201cuniversal\u201d test in that it could be applied without reference to previous decisions where the duty might or might not have been seen to have existed. This attracted considerable criticisms from many other judges who thought that the much sought-after universal basis for duty is unattainable and even undesirable, and that an incremental approach based on previous decisions on a case by case basis was less subjective and therefore preferable.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, these criticisms have arisen because of the perceived divorce of the particular from the universal (see [28] above). Whether or not Lord Wilberforce intended for his test to apply in a vacuum, distanced from all considerations of prior decisions, is not exactly clear, since the essence of the common law (which Lord Wilberforce must have known) is by its very nature incremental. A fair reading of the sentence (see [33] above) beginning with \u201cin order to establish \u2026 it is not necessary to bring the facts within those of previous situations\u201d does not preclude an incremental approach as the expression \u201cthe facts\u201d does necessarily connote <i>all</i> the facts, and is capable of implying that it is only necessary to bring <i>only some of the facts</i>. However, as the formula was perceived as such, it led to the concern of a potentially uncontrollable expansion of liability.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The two-stage test in</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Anns <em>doubted and overruled</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> This concern led to a check of the advance of the two-stage test in <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Anns</i> as doctrine. In <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Governors of the Peabody Donation Fund v Sir Lindsay Parkinson &amp; Co Ltd</i> [1985] AC\u00a0210, after quoting Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s test, Lord\u00a0Keith of Kinkel made the criticism (at 240) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">There has been a tendency in some recent cases to treat these passages as being themselves of a definitive character. This is a temptation which should be resisted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Similarly, the Australian High Court gave reasons in <i>Sutherland Shire Council v Heyman</i> (1985) 60\u00a0ALR\u00a01 (\u201c<i>Sutherland</i>\u201d) for declining to follow the direction in which <i>Anns</i> appeared to be taking the law in England. Brennan\u00a0J stated (at 43\u201344) that it was preferable that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]he law should develop novel categories of negligence incrementally and by analogy with established categories, rather than by a massive extension of a prima facie duty of care restrained only by indefinable \u201cconsiderations which ought to negative, or to reduce or limit the scope of the duty or the class of person to whom it is owed\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Following this, Lord\u00a0Brandon of Oakbrook remarked in <i>Leigh and Sillavan Ltd v Aliakmon Shipping Co Ltd</i> [1986] AC\u00a0785 at 815 that the propositions laid down by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Anns</i> \u201c[do] not provide, and cannot \u2026 have been intended by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce to provide, a universally applicable test of the existence and scope of a duty of care in the law of negligence\u201d. The Privy Council in <i>Yuen Kun Yeu v Attorney-General of Hong Kong</i> [1988] AC\u00a0175 (\u201c<i>Yuen Kun Yeu</i>\u201d) further expressed the opinion that whether or not a duty of care in negligence existed would depend primarily upon foreseeability of damage, together with the existence of a close and direct relationship or proximity between the parties, and that, occasionally, it would be necessary to go on to consider whether public policy required that liability should not attach. Lord\u00a0Keith of Kinkel observed in <i>Yuen Kun Yeu</i> (at 191) that the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> \u201chas been elevated to a degree of importance greater than it merits, and greater perhaps than its author intended\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> was finally overruled by the House of Lords in <i>Murphy v Brentwood District Council</i> [1991] 1\u00a0AC\u00a0398 (\u201c<i>Murphy</i>\u201d). In unanimously holding that the defendant council owed no duty of care to the claimant (a subsequent home owner) in respect of pure economic loss, Lord\u00a0Keith of Kinkel observed thus (at 471):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In my opinion it is clear that <i>Anns</i> did not proceed upon any basis of established principle, but introduced a new species of liability governed by a principle indeterminate in character but having the potentiality of covering a wide range of situations, involving chattels as well as real property, in which it had never hitherto been thought that the law of negligence had any proper place.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">He continued (at 471\u2013472):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In my opinion there can be no doubt that <i>Anns</i> has for long been widely regarded as an unsatisfactory decision. In relation to the scope of the duty owed by a local authority it proceeded upon what must, with due respect to its source, be regarded as a somewhat superficial examination of principle and there has been extreme difficulty, highlighted most recently by the speeches in [<i>D\u00a0&amp;\u00a0F Estates Ltd v Church Commissioners for England</i> [1989] AC\u00a0177], in ascertaining upon exactly what basis of principle it did proceed. I think it must now be recognised that it did not proceed on any basis of principle at all, but constituted a remarkable example of judicial legislation. It has engendered a vast spate of litigation, and each of the cases in the field which have reached this House has been distinguished. Others have been distinguished in the Court of Appeal. The result has been to keep the effect of the decision within reasonable bounds, but that has been achieved only by applying strictly the words of Lord Wilberforce and by refusing to accept the logical implications of the decision itself. These logical implications show that the case properly considered has potentiality for collision with long-established principles regarding liability in the tort of negligence for economic loss. There can be no doubt that to depart from the decision would re-establish a degree of certainty in this field of law which it has done a remarkable amount to upset.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The three-part test in</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Caparo</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With the fall of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>, another approach to determine the existence of a duty of care emerged. In <i>Smith v Eric S\u00a0Bush</i> [1990] 1\u00a0AC 831, Lord\u00a0Griffiths, in dealing with the question of when the law deems a person who has given advice to have assumed responsibility to the recipient who has acted on it and suffered damage, replied (at 865):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I would answer \u2013 only if it is foreseeable that if the advice is negligent the recipient is likely to suffer damage, that there is a sufficiently proximate relationship between the parties and that it is just and reasonable to impose the liability.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">This trend towards a three-part test was summarised by Lord\u00a0Bridge of Harwich in <i>Caparo</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) thus (at 617\u2013618):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">What emerges is that, in addition to the foreseeability of damage, necessary ingredients in any situation giving rise to a duty of care are that there should exist between the party owing the duty and the party to whom it is owed a relationship characterised by the law as one of \u201cproximity\u201d or \u201cneighbourhood\u201d and that the situation should be one in which the court considers it fair, just and reasonable that the law should impose a duty of a given scope upon the one party for the benefit of the other.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> is, by no means, unambiguous in its application; indeed, the very judges who had formulated it expressed their belief that it was unlikely to be a workable test. Lord\u00a0Bridge himself cautioned (at 618) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]he concepts of proximity and fairness embodied in these additional ingredients are not susceptible of any such precise definition as would be necessary to give them utility as practical tests, but amount in effect to little more than convenient labels to attach to the features of different specific situations which, on a detailed examination of all the circumstances, the law recognises pragmatically as giving rise to a duty of care of a given scope.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Similarly, Lord\u00a0Roskill gave a warning (at 628) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Phrases such as \u201cforeseeability,\u201d \u201cproximity,\u201d \u201cneighbourhood,\u201d \u201djust and reasonable,\u201d \u201cfairness,\u201d \u2026 will be found used from time to time in the different cases. But \u2026 such phrases are not precise definitions. At best they are but labels or phrases descriptive of the very different factual situations which can exist in particular cases and which must be carefully examined in each case before it can be pragmatically determined whether a duty of care exists and, if so, what is the scope and extent of that duty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In other words, some overlapping or merging of the three criteria will occur according to the particular circumstances: see also Steyn\u00a0LJ\u2019s comments in <i>Elguzouli-Daf v Commission of Police of the Metropolis</i> [1995] QB\u00a0335 at 349. In a similar vein, in <i>Marc Rich &amp; Co AG v Bishop Rock Marine Co Ltd</i> [1994] 1\u00a0WLR\u00a01071, Balcombe\u00a0LJ said (at 1088) that he doubted whether the words \u201cfair, just and reasonable\u201d imposed a test additional to that of \u201cproximity\u201d. He went on to state that \u201cthese are criteria to be adopted in considering whether the necessary degree of proximity exists\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The incremental approach</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41 \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Additionally, it ought to be noted that the House of Lords in <i>Caparo</i> also endorsed the <i>incremental</i> approach advocated by Brennan\u00a0J in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Sutherland</i> ([36] <i>supra</i>). Lord\u00a0Bridge observed (at 618) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whilst recognising, of course, the importance of the underlying general principles common to the whole field of negligence, I think the law has now moved in the direction of attaching greater significance to the more traditional categorisation of distinct and recognisable situations as guides to the existence, the scope and the limits of the varied duties of care which the law imposes.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although the English courts have accepted incrementalism as a useful guide, Prof\u00a0Keith Stanton has noted in \u201cIncremental Approaches to the Duty of Care\u201d (in <i>Torts in the Nineties</i> (Nicholas\u00a0J\u00a0Mullany ed) (LBC Information Services, 1997) at p\u00a044), that no consistent pattern emerges to indicate what the courts understand by this term. Prof\u00a0Stanton is of the view (at p\u00a039) that, at a general level, \u201cincrementalism may be regarded as restoring a traditional method of adjudication to the tort of negligence\u201d in that it remains intertwined with a formula-based approach, and that the general principle should henceforth be applied in a more cautious manner. On the other hand, at a more detailed level, incrementalism can be taken to mean the development of \u201cpockets of duty of care\u201d, modified and developed by the slow incremental accretion of case law, in lieu of a general principle which provides the basis of analysis. Indeed, the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> stands in apparent distinction from the incremental approach which was, somewhat curiously, advocated in the same case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If incrementalism is intended to return the development of liability in negligence to the basis that discrete sets of rules should govern different factual scenarios, the central problem, as Prof\u00a0Stanton noted at p\u00a048, is that it requires a return to an approach which has been systematically destroyed since <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i>, as generations of lawyers have since been trained to believe that the tort of negligence is based on a common general principle. In this respect, we agree with Lord\u00a0Bingham of Cornhill in <i>Customs and Excise Commissioners v Barclays Bank plc</i> [2007] 1\u00a0AC 181 (\u201c<i>Customs and Excise Commissioners</i>\u201d), where he observed (at [7]) that the \u201cincremental test is of little value as a test in itself, and is only helpful when used in combination with a test or principle which identifies the legally significant features of a situation\u201d. In our view, incrementalism is not a distinct and alternative method which results in a plethora of discrete sets of rules (as opposed to a set of general (and universal) principles). Instead, it is an analogical process to <i>apply</i> specific facts to the general principle. According to this approach, a court should, when applying the specific step of the general principle, utilise the incremental methodology to decide first whether that specific step (or criterion) can be satisfied <i>with reference to decided cases</i>. This will provide an essential check to any unwarranted expansion of liability for negligent acts. However, as we will further observe (at [72] below), where there are no decided cases, recourse to general principles is not only valid but also desirable. Such an approach, an interaction of the universal with the particular (see [28] above), would, in our view, aid in the development of a rational and purposive concept of negligence which can achieve fairness and justice in each case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Other tests</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The cases referred to above may be regarded as the main current in the search for a test for the existence of a duty of care in novel situations. But there have been other side-currents, particularly in relation to liability for psychiatric harm and negligent misstatements causing pure economic loss. A line of authority from <i>Hedley Byrne &amp; Co Ltd v Heller &amp; Partners Ltd</i> [1964] AC\u00a0465 (\u201c<i>Hedley Byrne</i>\u201d) has grounded liability for the latter on an <i>assumption of responsibility</i> towards the recipient of the statement in question and <i>reliance</i> by him on its accuracy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for acts or omissions causing pure economic loss, English law currently prevents recovery for such claims. In <i>Murphy</i> ([38] <i>supra</i>), the House of Lords adopted what is known as the \u201cexclusionary rule\u201d in relation to cases involving pure economic loss flowing from careless acts or omissions. Lord\u00a0Oliver of Aylmerton said (at 487) that if the infliction of loss by the defendant on the claimant was to be categorised as wrongful, it was necessary to find some factor beyond the mere occurrence of the loss and the fact that its occurrence could be foreseen. What was necessary was evidently a relationship of proximity so close that it was \u201cakin to contract\u201d (<i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Bridge of Harwich in <i>Murphy</i> at 481) to introduce the element of reliance such that the scope of the duty of care owed by the defendant to the claimant was wide enough to embrace pure economic loss. Lord\u00a0Oliver further noted that the <i>categorisation</i> of damage as economic served at least the useful purpose of indicating that something more was required. However, it has long been recognised that the effect of <i>Murphy</i> is simply that English law will deny the existence of a duty of care to any individual suffering pure economic loss caused by careless acts or omissions where there is neither personal injury nor property damage: see <i>Charlesworth &amp; Percy on Negligence</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 11th Ed, 2006) at para\u00a02-134. The reason for this appears to be a fear of indeterminate liability owing to the fluid nature of pure economic losses which are not strictly restricted by the physical interaction of the parties involved (see further [66] below).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Current position in England</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The search for clarity and certainty in a single formula has proved to be elusive even some 60 years after the first articulation of the \u201cneighbour\u201d principle in <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i>. Lord\u00a0Oliver of Aylmerton lamented in <i>Caparo</i> ([23] <i>supra</i> at 633) thus:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 I think that it has to be recognised that to search for any single formula which will serve as a general test of liability is to pursue a will-o\u2019-the wisp. The fact is that once one discards, as it is now clear that one must, the concept of foreseeability of harm as the single exclusive test \u2013 even a prima facie test \u2013 of the existence of the duty of care, the attempt to state some general principle which will determine liability in an infinite variety of circumstances serves not to clarify the law but merely to bedevil its development in a way which corresponds with practicality and common sense.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Customs and Excise Commissioners v Barclays Bank plc</i> [2005] 1\u00a0WLR 2082, Longmore\u00a0LJ identified (at [23]) <i>three</i> separate and independent tests in England to find a duty of care:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The modern law of negligence derives primarily from four decisions of the House of Lords:</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Caparo Industries plc v Dickman</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">[1990] 2\u00a0AC 605;</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Henderson v Merrett Syndicates Ltd</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">[1995] 2\u00a0AC 145;</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">White v Jones</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">[1995] 2\u00a0AC 207 and</span><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Phelps v Hillingdon London Borough Council</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">[2001] 2\u00a0AC 619.</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Caparo</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">laid down the threefold test of foreseeability, proximity and fairness and emphasised the desirability of incremental development: see in particular Lord\u00a0Bridge of Harwich, at pp\u00a0617\u2013618.</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Henderson</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">and</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">White</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">both emphasised the concept of assumption of responsibility in cases where the negligent performance of services had caused economic loss. In the light of these authorities this court has held (see</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Bank of Credit and Commerce International (Overseas) Ltd v Price Waterhouse</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\"><nobr>[1998] BCC 617</nobr>) that an appropriate course for ascertaining whether there is a duty of care, at least in an economic loss case, is to look at any new set of facts by using each of the three approaches in turn,</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">viz</span></i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">, the threefold test, the voluntary assumption of responsibility test and the incremental test \u2013 \u201cif the facts are properly analysed and the policy considerations are correctly evaluated the several approaches will yield the same result\u201d: per Sir\u00a0Brian Neill, at p\u00a0634.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judicial response of Longmore\u00a0LJ that has led to the establishment of no less than <i>three</i> separate tests for duty, in our view, puts paid to the search for a <i>general</i> principle applicable to all situations where tortious liability may arise. Damage arising from different situations (<i>viz</i>, pure economic loss or physical damage) is seen to require the application of different tests, and even within the rubric of physical damage, there is some confusion as regards which of the three tests is applicable to determine a duty of care.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On appeal in <i>Customs and Excise Commissioners</i> ([43] <i>supra</i>), the House of Lords did not express a definitive view on whether or not the three \u201ctests\u201d mentioned by Longmore\u00a0LJ were substantive tests in their own right and were all to be applied in any given case. Indeed, the general position adopted by the House itself is, with respect, none too clear (see also Steven Gee, \u201cThe Remedies Carried by a Freezing Injunction\u201d (2006) 122 LQR\u00a0535, especially at 536). Thus, as Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0J (as he then was) observed in <i>Sunny Metal &amp; Engineering Pte Ltd v Ng Khim Ming Eric</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 853</nobr> (\u201c<i>Sunny Metal</i>\u201d) at [79], the position in England, even at the present, continues to be in a \u201cstate of flux and confusion\u201d. This situation does not make it easier for the Singapore courts, but it does present them with an opportunity to revisit the subject and to try to fashion a general test that is principled and logical and capable of practical application to all cases where damage is caused by a negligent act. In this connection, it should be borne in mind that all such problems that come before the courts are evaluated and assessed on a retrospective and not a prospective basis; the damage has arisen and the only question is whether there is liability for it. This condition should, in most situations, give the courts an advantage in being able to see whether, on the facts of the case, the application of the test is likely to lead to an unmanageable expansion of liability for negligent acts or omissions that may be detrimental to the national welfare.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The different tests in Singapore</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to examine the current position in Singapore. The decisions have, as with the case in England, applied different tests to different types of damages claimed. For convenience, we will deal first with cases of pure economic loss and then cases of physical damage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>\u201cTwo-stage process\u201d for cases of pure economic loss</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we have stated earlier, the courts in Singapore have in certain cases declined to apply the \u201cexclusionary rule\u201d adopted by the House of Lords in <i>Murphy</i> ([38] <i>supra</i>) and have held that pure economic loss is recoverable in tort: see <i>RSP Architects Planners &amp; Engineers v Ocean Front Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1996] 1 SLR 113</nobr> (\u201c<i>Ocean Front</i>\u201d) which concerned the faulty construction of common property in a condominium. The rationale for this departure from the English position was explained in the subsequent case of <i>RSP Architects Planners &amp; Engineers v MCST Plan No\u00a01075</i> <nobr>[1999] 2 SLR 449</nobr> (\u201c<i>Eastern Lagoon</i>\u201d), where this court stated (at [43]) that there were cogent policy reasons to allow for claims of pure economic loss in relation to immovable property since land was scarce in Singapore and the financial outlay in such properties represented a significant investment in a person\u2019s lifetime.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Ocean Front</i>, the management corporation (\u201cMC\u201d) of Bayshore Park Condominium took out a writ against the developer of that condominium for damages arising out of the faulty construction of common property. This court applied the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) and relied on <i>Junior Books Ltd v Veitchi Co Ltd</i> [1983] 1\u00a0AC 520 (\u201c<i>Junior Books</i>\u201d) and found the developer liable in negligence for economic loss caused to the MC with whom the developer had no contractual relationship. The approach which this court took was that it first considered whether there was (on the facts of the case) sufficient proximity between the parties, which would give rise to a duty of care. L\u00a0P\u00a0Thean\u00a0JA, who delivered the judgment of the court, observed (at 139, [69]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">But the approach of the court has been to examine a particular circumstance to determine whether there exists that degree of proximity\u00a0between the plaintiff and the defendant as would give rise to a duty of care by the latter to the former with respect to the damage sustained by the former. <i>Such proximity is the \u2018determinant\u2019 of the duty of care and also the scope of such duty</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This court found that there was a duty of care from the combination of several factors evidencing proximity:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the developer developed the condominium (which included the common property as part of it) and undertook that the condominium would be constructed in a good and workmanlike manner;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 after completion of the condominium, the developer remained the legal owner of the common property and was responsible for its maintenance and upkeep;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the developer incorporated the MC to hold and to maintain the common property; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the developer was obviously aware that if the common property was defective as a result of defective workmanship, any damage to it would have to be made good by the MC.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The relationship between the developer and the MC was as close as could be short of actual privity of contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having found that there was proximity on these bases, this court then proceeded \u201cto consider whether there is any policy consideration in negativing such [a] duty of care\u201d (at 142, [75]). It found no policy reason negativing the duty of care primarily because the ambit of liability was determinate. Indeed, in our view, for the very reasons given by the court in deciding that there was proximity in that case, the policy considerations would be in favour of imposing liability on the developer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Ocean Front</i> was followed by <i>Eastern Lagoon</i> ([51] <i>supra</i>), in which this court revisited its holdings in <i>Ocean Front</i>. This court expressly rejected the \u201ctwo-stage test\u201d in <i>Anns</i> but adopted what was <i>substantively</i> a similar test. L\u00a0P\u00a0Thean\u00a0JA, who delivered the judgment of the court, observed thus (at [18]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It seems to us that what is objectionable in that passage [containing Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s test in <i>Anns</i>] is firstly his Lordship\u2019s sweeping proposition of a single general rule or principle which can be applied in every situation to determine whether a duty of care arises and secondly the fact that the test propounded by his Lordship in the first stage was based on foreseeability of damage alone.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">And later, at [29]\u2013[30]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It is abundantly clear that in <i>Ocean Front</i> this court did not follow the broad proposition laid down by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Anns</i>. True, the court reached its conclusion by a two-stage process. In principle, there is no objection to such approach. It depends on what is involved and considered in each stage. The court certainly did not apply the first test in <i>Anns</i>. The court\u2019s finding that there was sufficient degree of proximity giving rise to a duty on the part of the developers to avoid the loss sustained by the management corporation was not premised on foreseeability of damage alone, but on the consideration of other relevant facts. Nor did the court accept Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s proposition that in any given situation a single general rule or principle can be applied to determine whether a duty of care arises.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It does not follow from the mere fact that the court in the course of their determination examined the facts by the two-stage process that the court in effect followed <i>Anns</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As to what this \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d entailed, Thean\u00a0JA continued at [31]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Stripped of the verbiage, the crux of such approach [<i>ie</i>, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d] is no more than this: the court first examines and considers the facts and factors to determine whether there is sufficient degree of proximity in the relationship between the party who has sustained the loss and the party who is said to have caused the loss which would give rise to a duty of care on the part of the latter to avoid the kind of loss sustained by the former. \u2026 Next, having found such degree of proximity, the court next considers whether there is any material factor or policy which precludes such duty from arising.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 That the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d was only applicable to cases of pure economic loss was confirmed in <i>The Sunrise Crane</i> <nobr>[2004] 4 SLR 715</nobr>. In that case, the majority (at [31]\u2013[37]) referred to <i>Man B&amp;W Diesel S\u00a0E\u00a0Asia Pte Ltd v</i> <i>PT\u00a0Bumi International Tankers</i> <nobr>[2004] 2 SLR 300</nobr> (\u201c<i>Man B&amp;W Diesel</i>\u201d) and <i>Ocean Front</i> and held that the approach used in those cases (<i>ie</i>, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d) was <i>limited</i> <i>to pure economic loss situations</i> and thus was not applicable to <i>The Sunrise Crane</i>, which concerned physical damage. The majority therefore applied the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) to the case at hand. However, the dissenting judge in <i>The Sunrise Crane</i> took the view that a <i>uniform</i> approach should be applied to all cases of negligence, with the salient features of each case being determinative of the existence and scope of duty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The result of the majority\u2019s pronouncement in <i>The Sunrise Crane</i>, as Dr\u00a0Kumaralingam Amirthalingam notes in \u201c<i>The Sunrise Crane</i> \u2013 Shedding New Light or Casting Old Shadows on Duty of Care?\u201d [2004] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a0551 at 555, is that in Singapore, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d in <i>Ocean Front</i> is to be applied in cases of pure economic loss, while the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> is to be applied in all other situations (<i>ie</i>, cases of physical damage).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequently, in <i>United Project Consultants Pte Ltd v Leong Kwok Onn</i> <nobr>[2005] 4 SLR 214</nobr> (\u201c<i>United Project Consultants</i>\u201d) at [27], this court held that, in determining whether to impose a duty of care in cases of pure economic loss (which was the case in <i>United Project Consultants</i>), the courts have \u201cconsistently adopted a more <i>restrictive</i> approach\u201d [emphasis added] and applied the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d in <i>Ocean Front</i>. After endorsing Thean\u00a0JA\u2019s statement of the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d in <i>Eastern Lagoon</i> (see [56] above), this court went on to state (at [35]) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In essence, before liability may be imposed upon a defendant for pure economic loss, a court must be satisfied that all the circumstances of the case give rise to a relationship whereby the defendant owes a duty to the plaintiff to avoid the particular loss suffered by the plaintiff. In doing so, the court must likewise be satisfied that there are no policy reasons why such a duty ought not to be imposed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">However, it then expressly went on to clarify (at [36]) that the \u201crestatement of the principle in [<i>Eastern Lagoon</i>] <i>should not be construed as reverting to the two-stage test in</i> Anns\u201d [emphasis added].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At first glance, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d is substantively similar to the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>; indeed, it even involves the same elements as stated by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Anns</i>: see also <i>Man B&amp;W Diesel</i> at [29]. On another view, however, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d is a \u201chybrid or composite test\u201d in that it is not wholly \u201cuniversal\u201d in nature, since the court in <i>Ocean Front</i> pointed out that the facts of that case were similar to <i>Junior Books</i> ([52] <i>supra</i>) and <i>Bryan v Maloney</i> (1995) 69\u00a0ALJR 375, ostensibly using both these cases as precedents from which to advance the imposition of a duty of care in that case, a process not dissimilar to the incremental approach alluded to in <i>Caparo</i>: see Debbie Ong Siew Ling, \u201cThe Test of Duty for Defects in Property Causing Pure Economic Loss\u201d [1999] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a0667 at 670\u2013671.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, if one were to construe Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s words in <i>Anns</i> <i>literally</i> (see [33] above), such that there was no longer a need to draw analogies with decided cases, it would be true that the \u201ctwo-step process\u201d does constitute a \u201chybrid or composite\u201d test. However, as we stated earlier (see [43] above), the common law methodology is essentially incremental in nature, drawing its conclusions from <i>precedents</i>, and this necessarily presupposes that <i>even within the confines of a general principle</i>, there remains the scope for the application of an analogising or incremental approach, and the two must not be viewed as being mutually exclusive. As such, it may be better to view this court\u2019s characterisation in that case of the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d as being wholly unrelated to Lord Wilberforce\u2019s two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> and as a reflection of the reluctance of the local courts at that time to follow an English authority which had been discredited. It would therefore have been better had this court in <i>Eastern Lagoon</i> simply acknowledged that it was, in substance and effect, applying the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Three-part test for cases of physical damage</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to the decisions applying the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i>. As we mentioned earlier, for cases <i>not</i> involving pure economic loss, it is the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> which has also been endorsed in the Singapore context: see, for example, <i>Ikumene Singapore Pte Ltd v Leong Chee Leng</i> <nobr>[1993] 3 SLR 24</nobr> (\u201c<i>Ikumene</i>\u201d); <i>Standard Chartered Bank v Coopers &amp; Lybrand</i> <nobr>[1993] 3 SLR 712</nobr>; <i>Pang Koi Fa v Lim Djoe Phing</i> <nobr>[1993] 3 SLR 317</nobr>; <i>Mohd bin Sapri v Soil-Build (Pte) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1996] 2 SLR 505</nobr>; <i>D v Kong Sim Guan</i> <nobr>[2003] 3 SLR 146</nobr>; <i>TV Media Pte Ltd v De Cruz Andrea Heidi</i> <nobr>[2004] 3 SLR 543</nobr> (\u201c<i>TV Media Pte Ltd</i>\u201d); and <i>The Sunrise Crane</i> ([57] <i>supra</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear that the courts take the view that the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> involves an incremental approach. In <i>Ikumene</i>, this court reiterated (at 29, [18]) what Brennan\u00a0J said in the Australian High Court in <i>Sutherland</i> ([36] <i>supra</i>) at 43\u201344 (see [36] above). However, for reasons we have mentioned earlier, our courts have not made clear the relationship between the three-part test in <i>Caparo</i> and the incremental approach. We repeat our view that the application of a general principle does not exclude an incremental approach; the latter is a method by which the general principle is to be applied. The universal and the particular interact to produce a result that is fair and just.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Overview of the problems</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The search for the applicable test is not restricted to preferring one test over the other; a related question is whether there should be different tests to determine the existence of a duty of care for cases of pure economic loss and cases of physical damage. Why should there be two different tests, and what difference does it make, since the final result the courts wish to achieve is the same, <i>viz</i>, that which is fair and just between the parties without imposing an unacceptable economic cost to the public. We now consider whether a different or modified approach should apply to determine the existence of a duty of care in cases of pure economic loss.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">different approach to determine duty of care in cases of pure economic loss?</span></em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Rationale for different approach</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As stated earlier (see [45] above), pure economic loss arising from acts or omissions is not recoverable in England, although losses arising from negligent misstatements are recoverable, provided that there exists a special relationship between the parties concerned. In Singapore, while pure economic loss is recoverable, the courts have advocated a more restricted approach in its recovery, to the extent of purporting to apply a different test (<i>ie</i>, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d in <i>Ocean Front</i>) to supposedly reflect this different treatment of such losses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A possible explanation for the courts\u2019 adoption of a more restrictive approach could be the express reference made by this court in <i>The Sunrise Crane</i> to a passage from <i>Clerk and Lindsell on Torts</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 18th\u00a0Ed, 2000) which sets out a rationale for the difference between pure economic loss and losses associated with physical damage. This passage is as follows (at para\u00a07-85):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Three features distinguish economic loss claims from most physical damage claims. First, whilst the links between negligence and physical damage depend largely on the laws of nature and necessarily limit the type of relationship giving rise to a claim, those between negligence and pure economic loss are primarily human in creation and can form a complex web through which economic losses can ripple out from the one negligent act. Secondly, because the economic relationships are frequently created rather than imposed, the participants in the web have a greater opportunity to use contracts to determine the level of risk to be taken and the degree of protection from loss required. \u2026 Thirdly, as Hobhouse\u00a0L.J. has observed, \u201cin a competitive economic society the conduct of one person is always liable to have economic consequences for another and, in principle, economic activity does not have to have regard to the interests of others and is justifiable by the actor having regard to his own interests alone\u201d. Furthermore, as McHugh\u00a0J. has noted, \u201cpure economic losses frequently result in mere transfers of wealth. The plaintiff\u2019s loss is the defendant\u2019s or a third party\u2019s gain\u201d, whereas \u201charm to a person or property ordinarily involves a new loss to social wealth.\u201d These features have led the courts to take a more restrictive approach to the imposition of a duty of care in relation to economic loss than in relation to physical damage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Is a different approach justified?</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the reasons traditionally given as justification for a different approach, Robby Bernstein points out in <i>Economic Loss</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 2nd Ed, 1998) (at p\u00a021) that it is important to note that it is not anything inherent in the <i>type of the damage</i> itself that necessitates a different approach:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Rather, it is the <i>circumstances</i> in which the economic loss has arisen which sound an alarm that something more is required to warrant the imposition of a duty of care on the defendant for the plaintiff\u2019s loss than the mere fact that it was reasonably foreseeable that the defendant\u2019s negligent act or omission would cause that loss to the plaintiff. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the case of <i>Leigh and Sillivan Ltd v Aliakmon Shipping Co Ltd</i> [1985] QB\u00a0350, Oliver\u00a0LJ (as he then was) recognised this point when he said (at 375):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The premise appears to be that the reason why, in the older authorities, the plaintiff failed to recover damages was that the damage which he suffered was \u201ceconomic\u201d \u2026 Speaking for myself, <i>I have not felt able to accept that premise</i>, for as I read those cases it was <i>not</i> the \u201ceconomic\u201d quality of the damage which prevented recovery <i>but the reason why that damage had occurred</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Similarly, he, as Lord\u00a0Oliver in <i>Murphy</i> ([38] <i>supra</i>), reiterated this point (at 485):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[I]t is far from clear from these decisions [<i>ie</i>, the various economic loss cases which he had just referred to] that the reason for the plaintiff\u2019s failure was simply that the only loss sustained was \u201ceconomic.\u201d Rather they seem to have been based either upon the remoteness of the damage as a matter of direct causation or, more probably, upon the \u201cfloodgates\u201d argument of the impossibility of containing liability within any acceptable bounds if the law were to permit such claims to succeed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Unfortunately, as Bernstein notes in <i>Economic Loss</i> (at p\u00a021), the House of Lords in <i>Murphy</i> failed to realise that if the concerns articulated above do not in fact exist, then there is <i>no need</i> for the law to adopt an unduly restrictive approach towards the imposition of duties of care for <i>all</i> cases involving pure economic loss. To do so based <i>only</i> on the type of damages sustained (<i>ie</i>, economic loss as opposed to physical damage) would be to misunderstand the foundational principle upon which the restrictive principle towards cases of pure economic loss was conceptualised in the first place. There will be cases of pure economic loss in which the concern of indeterminate liability does not arise. Each case must be looked at on its own facts. Indeed, in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Sutherland</i> ([36] <i>supra</i>), Mason\u00a0J (as he then was) said (at 32):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The proposition that, in general, damages are not recoverable for economic loss unless it is consequential upon injury to the plaintiff\u2019s personal property is <i>by no means absolute or inflexible</i>; it is a reflection of the law\u2019s concern about endless indeterminate liability. In the absence of any such concern in a particular class of case, <i>there is no necessity to give effect to the proposition</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As Mason\u00a0CJ, he reiterated this point in <i>Bryan v Maloney</i> ([60] <i>supra</i>). Mason\u00a0CJ, when delivering the majority judgment (at 380), said:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]he policy considerations underlying the reluctance of the courts to recognise a relationship of proximity and a consequent duty of care in cases of mere economic loss are inapplicable to a relationship of the kind which existed between [the parties in this case] \u2026 [T]here is no basis for thinking that recognition of a relationship of proximity between builder and first owner with respect to that particular kind of economic loss would give rise to the type of liability \u201cin an indeterminate amount for an indeterminate time to an indeterminate class\u201d which the courts are reluctant to recognise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">69<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</i> We respectfully agree that there is no justification for a <i>general</i> exclusionary rule against recovery of all economic losses and indeed, this is already the position the Singapore courts have taken, following <i>Ocean Front</i>. In this connection, we would also note that the Singapore cases which have allowed claims for pure economic losses have all been related to the economic value of the land. Indeed, for the condominium cases, as we have considered above at [51], the common property was intended to be for the enjoyment of the condominium owners and, by purchasing the condominium units, each owner was also effectively purchasing a share of the common property, as contemplated by the statutory regime on strata titles. For this reason, the MC may be regarded as the alter ego of the owners of the condominium units. Without the artificial but necessary interposition of the MC, there would have been a direct contractual relationship between the developers and the condominium owners. This very close relationship between the developers and the MC alleviates any fear of indeterminate liability owing to the nature of pure economic losses. Although the Singapore decisions on pure economic loss have been largely restricted to such situations, we are of the view that there is no reason not to extend liability for pure economic loss to other situations, provided that the issues of indeterminate liability and policy can be adequately dealt with. In this connection, the incremental approach would provide a necessary safeguard against the unintended consequence of indeterminate liability as well as discourage arbitrariness in determining liability.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">70\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, the question then is whether we should continue to adopt a different <i>test</i> for cases of pure economic loss, as distinguished from cases of physical damage. In our opinion, quite apart from the doctrinal untidiness of having two applicable tests, depending on the <i>nature</i> of the damage (<i>ie</i>, the \u201ctwo-stage process\u201d in <i>Ocean Front</i> for cases of pure economic loss and the three-stage test in <i>Caparo</i> for cases of physical damage), this approach does not, in fact, address the concerns which prompted the more restrictive approach for <i>some,</i> but not all, cases of pure economic loss.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">71\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As such, in our view, a <i>single</i> test is preferable in order to determine the imposition of a duty of care in all claims arising out of negligence, <i>irrespective</i> of the <i>type</i> of the damages claimed, and this should include claims for pure economic loss, whether they arise from negligent misstatements or acts/omissions. In cases of <i>physical</i> damage, there is usually no difficulty with regard to a control mechanism to prevent indeterminate liability. However, the adoption of a single test would serve to constrain liability <i>even in</i> those extremely rare cases where <i>physical</i> damage <i>might possibly</i> result in indeterminate liability. It may well be that there are policy considerations in restricting recovery for pure economic loss in <i>certain</i> situations, but this in itself does not make it necessary for a wholly different approach in the form of a separate test altogether.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">72\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Ultimately, a single test to determine the existence of a duty of care for all claims of negligence would do well to eliminate the perception that there are, at once, two or more tests which are equally applicable. While it may be that all these tests could yield the same result, their serial applicability diminishes the desirability of having a general principle that can provide a coherent, consistent and reliable way of determining or recognising a duty of care. We now turn our attention to considering what the <i>single</i> applicable test may be.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The applicable test in Singapore</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">73\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, a coherent and workable test can be fashioned out of the basic two-stage test premised on proximity and policy considerations, if its application is preceded by a preliminary requirement of <i>factual</i> foreseeability. We would add that this test is to be applied <i>incrementally</i>, in the sense that when applying the test in each stage, it would be desirable to refer to decided cases in analogous situations to see how the courts have reached their conclusions in terms of proximity and/or policy. As is obvious, the existence of analogous precedents, which determines the current limits of liability, would make it easier for the later court to determine whether or not to extend its limits. However, the absence of a factual precedent, which implies the presence of a novel situation, should not preclude the court from extending liability where it is just and fair to do so, taking into account the relevant policy consideration against indeterminate liability against a tortfeasor. We would admit at this juncture that this is basically a restatement of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>, tempered by the preliminary requirement of factual foreseeability. Indeed, we should point out that this is the test applied in substance by many jurisdictions in the Commonwealth: see, for example, the Canadian case of <i>Cooper v Hobart</i> (2001) 206\u00a0DLR (4th) 193; the New Zealand case of <i>Rolls-Royce New Zealand Ltd v Carter Holt Harvey Ltd</i> <nobr>[2005] 1 NZLR 324</nobr>; and the general summary provided in Phang, Saw &amp; Chan ([26] <i>supra</i>) at 9\u201328.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">74\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now set out in detail the various elements in the approach outlined above. We will also illustrate how this approach is to be applied practically when we apply it to the facts of the present case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Factual foreseeability</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">75\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we mentioned earlier (see [34] above), there is some controversy in relation to the interpretation of the first stage of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s test in <i>Anns</i>, <i>ie</i>, whether it refers to mere factual foreseeability or legal foreseeability or proximity. In our view, factual foreseeability is too wide a criterion to be effective as a legal control mechanism if all that it means is that the defendant ought to have known that the claimant would suffer damage from his (the defendant\u2019s) carelessness. If this is the approach to be adopted, it would be fulfilled in almost all cases, because the two parties are likely to be in some degree of physical relationship in the relevant case. As Phang\u00a0J said in <i>Sunny Metal</i> ([49] <i>supra</i>) at [55]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The first part of the \u201cthree-part test\u201d (relating to \u201cforeseeability\u201d) is, in effect, a reference to the <i>factual</i> conception of reasonable foreseeability or proximity. It is, in other words, what I have earlier termed \u2026 as \u201creasonable foreseeability\u201d. Although this consideration has been incorporated as an element within the \u201cthree-part test\u201d itself, its incorporation is, with respect, <i>unnecessary</i>. As I have already pointed out above \u2026 the requirement of reasonable foreseeability from a <i>factual</i> perspective will <i>almost always be satisfied</i>, simply because of its very nature and the very wide nature of the \u201cnet\u201d it necessarily casts. There is therefore <i>no practical need</i> to include such a <i>factual</i> element within a <i>legal</i> formulation such as exists with regard to the existence (or otherwise) of <i>a duty of care</i>. \u2026 This is not to state that this last-mentioned (<i>factual</i>) element is to be discarded. As I have already mentioned, it will <i>almost always</i> be satisfied. [emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, that is not to say that it is not a necessary element in any claim in negligence, just that it is a threshold question which the court must be satisfied is fulfilled, failing which the claim does not even take off. Indeed, as the Privy Council said in <i>Yuen Kun Yeu</i> ([37] <i>supra</i>) at 191\u2013192:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Further, the expression of the first stage of the test [in <i>Anns</i>] carries with it a risk of misinterpretation. As Gibbs\u00a0C.J. pointed out in <i>Council of the Shire of Sutherland v Heyman</i>, 59<i>\u00a0</i> A.L.J.R. 564, 570, there are two possible views of what Lord Wilberforce meant. The first view, favoured in a number of cases mentioned by Gibbs\u00a0C.J., is that he meant to test the sufficiency of proximity simply by the reasonable contemplation of likely harm. The second view, favoured by Gibbs\u00a0C.J. himself, is that Lord Wilberforce meant the expression \u201cproximity or neighbourhood\u201d to be a composite one, importing the whole concept of necessary relationship between plaintiff and defendant described by Lord Atkin in <i>Donoghue v. Stevenson</i> [1932] A.C.\u00a0562, 580<i>.</i> In their Lordships\u2019 opinion the second view is the correct one. As Lord Wilberforce himself observed in <i>McLoughlin v. O\u2019Brian</i> [1983] 1\u00a0A.C. 410, 420, it is clear that foreseeability does not of itself, and automatically, lead to a duty of care. There are many other statements to the same effect. The truth is that the trilogy of cases referred to by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Anns v.
