Merton London Borough Council</i> [1978] A.C.\u00a0728, 751, each demonstrate particular sets of circumstances, differing in character, which were adjudged to have the effect of bringing into being a relationship apt to give rise to a duty of care. Foreseeability of harm is a necessary ingredient of such a relationship, but it is not the only one. Otherwise there would be liability in negligence on the part of one who sees another about to walk over a cliff with his head in the air, and forbears to shout a warning.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Proximity</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>first</i> stage of the test to be applied to determine the existence of a duty of care is that of proximity, <i>ie</i>, that there must be sufficient <i>legal</i> proximity between the claimant and defendant for a duty of care to arise. The focus here is necessarily on the closeness of the relationship between the parties themselves, as alluded to by Bingham\u00a0LJ in the Court of Appeal stage of <i>Caparo Industries Plc v Dickman</i> [1989] QB\u00a0653, where he said (at 679) that while \u201c[t]he content of the requirement of proximity, whatever language is used, is not \u2026 capable of precise definition\u201d and \u201c[t]he approach will vary according to the particular facts of the case, \u2026 the focus of the inquiry is on the <i>closeness and directness of the relationship between the parties</i>\u201d [emphasis added]. Indeed, in <i>Hedley Bryne</i> ([44] <i>supra</i>) itself, the House of Lords used language which pointed to the relationship between the parties as being determinative of duty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although Lord\u00a0Keith in <i>Yuen Kun Yeu</i> referred (at 194) to the concept of \u201cclose and direct relations\u201d, he did not clarify what the concept means. However, in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Sutherland</i> ([36] <i>supra</i>), Deane\u00a0J has observed thus (at 55\u201356):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The requirement of proximity is directed to <i>the relationship between the parties</i> in so far as it is relevant to the allegedly negligent act or omission of the defendant and the loss or injury sustained by the plaintiff. It involves <i>the notion of nearness or closeness and embraces physical</i> proximity (in the sense of space and time) between the person or property of the plaintiff and the person or property of the defendant, <i>circumstantial</i> proximity such as an overriding relationship of employer and employee or of a professional man and his client and what may (<i>perhaps loosely</i>) be referred to as <i>causal</i> proximity in the sense of the closeness or directness of the causal connection or relationship between the particular act or course of conduct and the loss or injury sustained. It may reflect <i>an assumption by one party of a responsibility</i> to take care to avoid or prevent injury, loss or damage to the person or property of another or <i>reliance</i> by one party upon such care being taken by the other in circumstances where the other party knew or ought to have known of that reliance. <i>Both the identity and the relative importance of the factors which are determinative of an issue of proximity are likely to vary in different categories of case.</i> That does <i>not mean</i> that there is scope for decision by reference to idiosyncratic notions of justice or morality or that it is a proper approach to treat the requirement of proximity as <i>a question of fact to be resolved merely by reference to the relationship between the plaintiff and the defendant in the particular circumstances.</i> The requirement of a relationship of proximity <i>serves as a touchstone and control of the categories of case in which the common law will adjudge that a duty of care is owed.</i> Given the general circumstances of a case in a new or developing area of the law of negligence, the question what (if any) combination or combinations of factors will satisfy the requirement of proximity is a <i>question of law to be resolved by the processes of legal reasoning, induction and deduction. On the other hand, the identification of the content of that requirement in such an area should not be either ostensibly or actually divorced from notions of what is \u201cfair and reasonable\u201d \u2026 or from the considerations of public policy which underlie and enlighten the existence and content of the requirement.</i> [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We respectfully agree with this analysis which merely unpacks \u201cproximity or neighbourhood\u201d as a composite idea, importing the whole concept of the necessary relationship between the claimant and the defendant described by Lord\u00a0Atkin in <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> (at 580). However, in this regard, we also acknowledge that there are numerous judicial pronouncements on the difficulty (and indeed, redundancy) in defining \u201cproximity\u201d. Some of these examples have already been cited above and it suffices only to reproduce Lord\u00a0Oliver of Aylmerton\u2019s speech in <i>Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police</i> [1992] 1\u00a0AC 310, where he said (at 411):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[I]n the end, it has to be accepted that the concept of \u201cproximity\u201d is an artificial one which depends more upon the court\u2019s perception of what is the reasonable area for the imposition of liability than upon any logical process of analogical deduction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding these judicial views, we agree with Phang, Saw &amp; Chan ([26] <i>supra</i> at 42) that these observations are \u201cpuzzling, to say the least\u201d. If indeed the \u201cproximity\u201d concept is merely a label or an artificial exercise in judicial creativity, then one must ask why the concept is still resorted to or utilised in the various tests. Its very presence suggests that it has some substantive content that is capable of being expressed in terms of legal principles. Rather than denouncing it as a mere \u201clabel\u201d, the courts should strive to infuse some meaning into it, if only so that lawyers who advise litigants and even law teachers can make some sense of the judicial formulations.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, Deane\u00a0J\u2019s analysis in <i>Sutherland</i>, that proximity includes physical, circumstantial as well as causal proximity, does provide substance to the concept since it includes the twin criteria of voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance, where the facts support them, as essential factors in meeting the test of proximity. Where A voluntarily assumes responsibility for his acts or omissions towards B, and B relies on it, it is only fair and just that the law should hold A liable for negligence in causing economic loss or physical damage to B: see Phang, Saw &amp; Chan at 47, where the authors wrote:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[B]oth</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">perspectives are, at bottom, <i>two different (yet inextricably connected) sides of the same coin and ought therefore to be viewed in an integrated and holistic fashion</i>. [emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We only need to add, further, that in determining proximity as expounded by Deane\u00a0J in <i>Sutherland</i>, the court should apply these concepts first by analogising the facts of the case for decision with those of decided cases, if such exist, but should not be constrained from limiting liability in a deserving case only because it involves a novel fact situation.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Policy considerations</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Assuming a positive answer to the preliminary question of factual foreseeability and the first stage of the legal proximity test, a <i>prima facie</i> duty of care arises. Policy considerations should then be applied to the factual matrix to determine whether or not to negate this duty. Among the relevant policy considerations would be, for example, the presence of a contractual matrix which has clearly defined the rights and liabilities of the parties and the relative bargaining positions of the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also recognise that the obvious objection to utilising policy as the overarching determinant of liability is its potential to result in arbitrary decisions. Although it is generally recognised that public policy is an unruly horse (<i>per</i> Burrough\u00a0J in <i>Richardson v Mellish</i> (1824) 2\u00a0Bing 229 at 252; 130\u00a0ER 294 at 303), it cannot be <i>completely</i> ignored. The danger is <i>not</i> with judges deciding cases based on policy considerations but rather with judges deciding cases based <i>solely</i> on them. We agree with Prof\u00a0Tan ([29] <i>supra</i> at 228) that \u201c[t]he truth lies somewhere in between pure principle-based decisions and policy-based decisions\u201d and that \u201c[i]t is obviously impossible to decide cases <i>in vacuo</i>, exclusive of the interests and the context of the community for which the decisions are made\u201d. In our view, it is inescapable that some measure of public policy must be considered but it must not be the sole determinant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would also caution that when applying policy considerations to negate the imposition of a duty of care, the courts must be careful to differentiate such considerations from the requirement of proximity in the first stage of the test we have articulated. The courts must, as far as possible, avoid giving the impression that there remain \u201cunexpressed motives\u201d behind their finding for or against a duty. The courts must also not have litigants believe, as J\u00a0A\u00a0Smillie put it in \u201cThe Foundation of the Duty of Care in Negligence\u201d (1989) 15\u00a0Monash U L Rev\u00a0302 at 302, that \u201cnone of [the tests articulated by the courts] is truly explanatory of judges\u2019 reasoning or provides a helpful framework for analysis of the duty question\u201d. If there is truly a <i>pertinent and relevant</i> policy consideration involving value judgments which reflect differential weighing and balancing of competing moral claims and broad social welfare goals, we feel that it would be better if the courts were to articulate these concerns under the requirement of policy considerations, rather than subsume these concerns within the proximity requirement, which may then lead to an overall distortion of the legal test to determine the existence of a duty of care. In this respect, we agree with Nicholas\u00a0J\u00a0Mullany when he notes in \u201cProximity, Policy and Procrastination\u201d (1992) 9\u00a0Aust Bar Rev 80 at 83 that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Judges should openly express the true premises of their decisions and, if recovery is considered to be undeserved, in the light of greater moral, social, economic, administrative or philosophical public perceptions, then these reasons and not others inherently uncertain in nature, should be expressed as the true foundation for denial of recovery.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">86\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With these general propositions in mind, we turn now to the facts of the present case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\"><strong>Duty of care in the present case</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Foreseeability of damage</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The parties\u2019 arguments</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">87\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Adopting the test which we have set out, the <i>threshold issue</i> was the foreseeability of damage to the appellant. In this respect, it contended that the respondent\u2019s responsibility under the PSSCOC, as the SO, included certification responsibilities under cl\u00a032. Given that payment to the appellant under the PSSCOC structure was entirely dependent on the issuance of payment certificates certified by the respondent, the appellant submitted that it must have been foreseeable to the respondent that any negligence in its certification would deprive the appellant of moneys he would otherwise have been entitled to.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In response, the respondent contended that the appellant had not even crossed the low threshold of reasonable foreseeability as it was not even able to show that the damage allegedly suffered by it could have been foreseeable. In particular, it was argued that the appellant was in effect saying that the alleged under-certification led to its financial difficulties and these difficulties led to the need for it to novate the Contract. If it had not novated the Contract, it might still have been able to recover the amounts under-certified. In other words, the appellant had relied on the correctness of the interim certificates issued by the respondent in deciding to enter into the novation agreement. However, the respondent contended that it could not have reasonably foreseen that the appellant would rely on the said certificates for the novation given that the appellant had since 29\u00a0September 2000 been challenging the correctness of the respondent\u2019s certifications.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Our decision</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We rejected the respondent\u2019s submission that this factual requirement was not satisfied because the respondent could not have foreseen (essentially) the <i>kind of losses</i> suffered by the appellant. This is because the test envisaged by the respondent (<i>ie</i>, foreseeability of the <i>kind</i> of losses) is properly the test for the remoteness of damages in tort, and is not the test for factual foreseeability in relation to the duty of care: see <i>Ho Soo Fong v Standard Chartered Bank</i> <nobr>[2007] 2 SLR 181</nobr>. As such, the factual requirement of foreseeability was satisfied in this case because, as the appellant rightly pointed out, it must have been foreseeable to the respondent that any negligence in its certification would directly deprive the contractor of moneys he would otherwise have been entitled to, and that if it had been paid the correct amounts, it might not have got into financial difficulties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Proximity</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The parties\u2019 arguments</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The issue of proximity obviously formed the main focus of contention between the parties, dominant as its role is in the determination of the existence of a duty of care (see [77] above). We therefore consider it useful to provide a closer analysis of the parties\u2019 arguments.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s arguments</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant submitted that it, as the contractor in the Project, had to rely on the professional judgment of the respondent, as the certifier, in agreeing to enter into a PSSCOC form of contract, under which it was held out to the contractor that payment for work done in the correct amount would depend entirely on the respondent, as an independent certifier, discharging its duties professionally, <i>ie</i>, fairly and impartially. Specifically, the appellant pointed out that the respondent must have known that any certificate it issued for payment would determine the amount payable to the appellant under cl\u00a032 of the Contract. It was therefore unrealistic for the respondent to deny knowledge of the obvious reliance that would be placed on its certificate since it was not open for the appellant under the PSSCOC framework to obtain payment for work done by it in any other way.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">92\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further, the appellant referred to cl\u00a02.8 of the Contract as providing some specific indications of the respondent\u2019s assumption of responsibility towards the contractor. As we mentioned earlier (at [4] above), this clause states that the SO or any of its representatives \u201cshall at no time be under any obligation or duty to the Contractor either on behalf of the Employer or his own account to exercise or not to exercise any of his powers under the Contract\u201d. The appellant contended that, properly construed, this clause meant that it would only apply if the respondent did nothing, but not if he did something, and that once he decided to exercise his power under the Contract it must follow that he had assumed responsibility to the appellant to do it properly and professionally.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">93\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, the appellant pointed out that cl\u00a032.8 of the Contract made it clear that the appellant had no remedy <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the Employer for \u201cany damages, whether by way of interest or otherwise, for any failure or delay by the [SO] in certifying any payment due or payable to the Contractor\u201d. Since cl\u00a032.8 had severely limited any recourse by the appellant to the Employer for damages arising from any failure or delay by the respondent in certifying any payment due or payable to the contractor, it was argued that the decision of the English Court of Appeal in <i>Pacific Associates Inc v Baxter</i> [1990] 1\u00a0QB 993 (\u201c<i>Pacific Associates</i>\u201d), which denied a duty of care in similar circumstances, was distinguishable as in that case there was no such restriction of the contractor\u2019s right of recourse to the employer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent\u2019s arguments</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">94\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent argued that the case was on all fours with <i>Pacific Associates</i> if the court took into account the existence of the appellant\u2019s right to arbitration under cl\u00a034 (see [5] above). It submitted that cl\u00a034 gave extensive rights to the appellant to submit disputes for arbitration including submitting a claim against the Employer for any under-certification by the respondent. As such, the respondent contended that, on the facts of the case, it could not be said that the SO had assumed any responsibility for the appellant for the consequences of any under-certification or that the appellant had relied solely on the respondent\u2019s certification to recover what was due to it for work done.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">95\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the appellant\u2019s interpretation of cl\u00a02.8, the respondent submitted that it was wholly misconceived and that it actually meant the opposite. It was argued that cl\u00a02.8 referred not only to the absence of a duty to exercise the SO\u2019s powers, but also of a duty not to exercise them, which meant that the SO could exercise them, if he wished, which he had done. Finally, as regards cl\u00a032.8, the respondent submitted that while cl\u00a032.8 precluded the appellant from claiming against the Employer damages for the failure or delay of the respondent in certification, the appellant had the right to claim the amounts under-certified and interest thereon by commencing arbitration proceedings against the Employer. This was clear from a perusal of cll\u00a032 and 34.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">96\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Ultimately, the respondent submitted that, given the carefully drafted and detailed provisions governing the rights and liabilities of the Employer and the appellant which took into account the role of the respondent, it would be wrong for the court to impose a duty of care on it <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the appellant. If the appellant had wanted the respondent to assume some liability to it in discharging the respondent\u2019s duties to the Employer, it could have proposed a direct contractual arrangement with the respondent or introduce the respondent as a further party to the Contract but it chose not to do so. Alternatively, the appellant could have decided not to tender for the work since it knew or must have known about the contractual structure before it even submitted its bid.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Our decision</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">97\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Adopting an incremental approach with respect to the requirement of proximity, we found the salient facts in <i>Pacific Associates</i> to be materially the same as those in the present case. The claimant in <i>Pacific Associates</i> was a contractor engaged in dredging work under the supervision of the defendant engineer who was retained by the employer. The claimant\u2019s contract with the employer contained clauses providing that the engineer would not be personally liable for acts under the contract and providing for the arbitration of disputes between the contractor and the employer. The contractor claimed that the geological information in the tender document issued by the engineer had under-estimated the amount of hard materials to be dredged and that the engineer had acted negligently in rejecting the contractor\u2019s claims for extra payment for removal of unforeseen hard materials. The contractor recovered some of its alleged losses from the employer following an arbitration settlement and then sought to recover the balance through a negligence action against the employer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">98\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court of Appeal held (at 1032) that it would not be reasonable to impose a <i>Hedley Byrne</i> ([44] <i>supra</i>) duty on the engineer because it \u201cwould cut across and be inconsistent with the structure of relationships created by the contracts, into which the parties had entered\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reasonable reliance and assumption of responsibility</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">99\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court in <i>Pacific Associates</i> also held that the engineer did not owe a duty of care to a contractor who had suffered economic loss as a result of his decisions as the contractor was safeguarded by the terms of its contract with the employer. Purchas\u00a0LJ considered that the courts should be slow to superimpose an added duty of care in excess of the rights the contractor was content to acquire against the owner in those cases where the parties came under a contractual framework which provided for compensation in the event of the failure of one of the parties involved. On the question of <i>reliance</i>, Purchas\u00a0LJ held that if the contractor required extra-contractual protection for the defaults of the engineer, it was open to the contractor to stipulate for it when contracting. By accepting the invitation to tender the contractor must be taken to accept the role to be played by the engineer as defined in the contract. As such, the court could not accept that the engineer had held himself out as accepting a duty of care outside the contractual framework, or that the contractor had relied on such an assumption of responsibility. Purchas\u00a0LJ, however, noted that the position might have been different if the arbitration clause had not been included in that contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">100\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Ralph Gibson\u00a0LJ gave a similar analysis. In his judgment, he noted that there was no <i>express or implied assumption of responsibility</i>, emphasising that there was no approach or request by the contractor inviting the provision of a service or advice or information directly to the engineer. The engineer\u2019s relationship with the contractor arose from the engineer\u2019s contract of employment with the owner. It was to the owner that the engineer owed his contractual duty to use proper care. Since the contract provided for correction by arbitration, the engineer was not employed to exercise due care in the interest of the contractor, so he could not be regarded as assuming responsibility to the contractor. The duty to act fairly and impartially was owed only to the employer. Essentially, Ralph Gibson\u00a0LJ denied the general duty on the grounds of both foreseeability (which he evidently regarded as a legal, as opposed to factual, requirement) and proximity, in view of the absence of voluntary assumption of responsibility.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">101\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the other hand, Russell\u00a0LJ, while reaching the same result, regarded the <i>policy</i> test as pivotal in the appeal. He thought that the engineer, in preparing tenders and contract documents, held himself out as an expert on whom the contractor was entitled to rely. However, on the policy test, he held that the contractor had freely entered into the contract and knew that a claim against the engineer must be ex-contractual. The contractor had its rights adequately protected by the contract with the owner and, had it thought the protection inadequate, it was at liberty to insist on a tri-partite contract. The parties having sought to regulate their relationships by contract, the law should be very cautious before grafting onto the contractual relationship what might be terms of a parasitic duty unnecessary for the parties\u2019 protection. In Russell\u00a0LJ\u2019s view, while the requirement of foreseeability and proximity might be satisfied, it was not just and reasonable that there should be imposed on the engineer a duty which the contractor chose not to make a contractual one because, <i>inter alia</i>, the arbitration clause provided an adequate remedy in the event of under-certification.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">102\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The core of the judgments, as Ian Duncan Wallace noted in \u201cCharter for the Construction Professional?\u201d (1990) 6\u00a0Const\u00a0LJ\u00a0207 at para\u00a013, lies in the view that, merely by virtue of the professional entering into a contract of employment under which he is to perform the various duties required by his client\u2019s contract with a contractor, and by so acting, it cannot be inferred as a fact that the professional (an engineer in <i>Pacific Associates</i>) has voluntarily assumed responsibility to the contractor for a careful discharge of his duties. As Ralph Gibson\u00a0LJ\u2019s judgment shows, only in circumstances in which the contractor makes some positive approach to the engineer for some service, advice, <i>etc</i>, followed by some positive statement or action on the part of the engineer on which it would be reasonable for the contractor to rely without further checking, may a voluntary assumption of responsibility be inferable.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Other jurisdictions following Pacific Associates</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">103<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pacific Associates</i> has been followed in the Australian case of <i>John Holland Construction and Engineering Pty Ltd v Majorca Projects Pty Ltd</i> (2000) 16\u00a0Const\u00a0LJ 114 (\u201c<i>John Holland</i>\u201d). Byrne\u00a0J thought that the lowest common denominator in <i>Pacific Associates</i>, which prevented the court from finding a duty, was the arbitration clause. Regarding the duties of a certifier generally, Byrne\u00a0J had the following to say (at 125\u2013126):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">To my mind it is reasonably foreseeable that the decisions of a certifying architect might cause loss to a contractor in a conventional building project if made negligently. Whatever that loss might be will depend upon the nature of the decision in question; it is in any event pure economic loss. This foreseeability is not removed by a right to review the decision by arbitration. Insofar as an entitlement to payment is concerned, a contractor who is successful upon arbitration must necessarily incur the cost of that arbitration and may suffer a deferment of payment, perhaps without a right to interest pending payment ... Nor am I troubled by either of the examples of policy consideration referred to in <i>Bryan v. Moloney</i> [<i>sic</i>] (1995) 182\u00a0C.L.R. at 618\u20139 ... The Builder in this case is clearly an identifiable member of the limited class of two persons who must have been in the contemplation of the Architect as being directly affected by its decisions. It is not an affront to the standards expected of a professional person that he or she should exercise the onerous responsibilities of certifier with due care and without partiality or unfairness. I suspect that the community, and particularly those concerned in the building industry, would expect no less.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The solution to the present problem must be found in the answer to the questions whether, in the contractual framework in which the parties to this project operated, it is established that the Builder relied on or depended upon the careful and impartial performance by the Architect of its certifying functions as here alleged and whether the Architect, for its part, assumed legal responsibility to the Contractor so to perform them.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">104\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Byrne\u00a0J went on to find (at 126), on the basis of the contractual background, that it was \u201cnot appropriate ... to seek to engraft upon the contractual background a tortious obligation\u201d. However, Byrne\u00a0J could see no policy reasons for not imposing a duty in appropriate circumstances and accordingly accepted that in principle a certifier had a duty to make \u201cdecisions which are professional, careful and even-handed, not in the interests of any one party\u201d (at 126). Further, Byrne\u00a0J expressed the view that the right to review an architect\u2019s decision by arbitration did not remove the foreseeability of economic loss being caused by a certifier\u2019s negligence. Seen in this light, the reasoning in <i>John Holland</i> appears to be tilted towards the <i>policy</i> aspect of the reasoning in <i>Pacific Associates</i>, as opposed to subsuming the ability of the contractor to seek recourse in arbitration under the rubric of \u201cproximity\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">105<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pacific Associates</i> has also been followed in the Hong Kong decision of <i>Leon Engineering &amp; Construction Co Ltd v Ka Duk Investment Co Ltd</i> (1989) 47\u00a0BLR 139, where the court refused to impose a duty on the professional on the ground that there was an adequate machinery under the contract for the contractor to pursue grievances, including those relating to under-certification, against the employer. At the close of the judgment, Bokhary\u00a0J said (at 151):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The principle which I extract from \u2026 <i>Pacific Associates ...</i> is one which I would state in these terms: Where, first, there is adequate machinery under the contract between the employer and a contractor to enforce the contractor\u2019s rights thereunder and, secondly, there is no good reason at tender stage to suppose that such rights and machinery would not together provide the contractor with an adequate remedy, then, in general, a certifying architect or engineer does not owe to the contractor a duty in tort coterminous with the obligation in contract owed to the contractor by the employer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">106\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Elsewhere, the effect of <i>Pacific Associates</i> has been distinguished, primarily on the basis that what the professional says or does before a contract is entered into is entirely different from what he does when he makes an interim certification of payment. However, it has never been expressly overruled and the legal principles which it stands for (as discussed above) remain good law, as far as we are aware, in all Commonwealth jurisdictions.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">107\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Canadian Supreme Court in <i>Edgeworth Constructions Ltd v ND Lea &amp; Associates Ltd</i> (1993) 107\u00a0DLR (4th) 169 has held that there might be situations where a negligent statement by the professional in <i>preparing the tender documents</i> would lead to liability under <i>Hedley Byrne</i> ([44] <i>supra</i>) but, in the absence of such a statement to the contractor, it seemed unlikely that a court would find a duty of care based on the mere conduct of the professional. Similarly, in <i>J\u00a0Jarvis and Sons Ltd v Castle Wharf Developments Ltd</i> [2001] EWCA Civ\u00a019, the English Court of Appeal distinguished <i>Pacific Associates</i> and held that the professional agent of an employer could be liable to a contractor for negligent misstatements made by that agent to the contractor with the aim of inducing the contractor to tender, provided that the contractor placed reliance on those statements. The question of whether a duty of care had arisen was dependent on the given facts and, in particular, on what had been said to the contractor.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Application to the present case</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">108\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Applying the findings in <i>Pacific Associates</i> in relation to proximity to the present case, we were of the opinion that the requirement of proximity was not satisfied. The trial judge at [79] of the Judgment stated that there was no assumption of direct responsibility by the respondent to the appellant, but did not explain <i>why</i> this was so. In view of the presence of the arbitration clause in the Contract, <i>ie</i>, cl\u00a034 (see [5] above) in the present case, it was not possible for this court to depart from the reasoning in <i>Pacific Associates</i> and hold that the respondent had a duty of care to the appellant to certify the payments for work done correctly. For this reason, we held that there was no legal proximity for a duty of care to arise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">109\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect to the arguments based on cl\u00a032.8, we were of the view that although the appellant had no remedy <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the Employer for \u201cany damages, whether by way of interest or otherwise, for any failure or delay by the [SO] in certifying any payment due or payable to the Contractor\u201d, thereby precluding the appellant from claiming damages against the Employer for failure or for delay of the respondent in certification, the appellant was always free to claim the amounts <i>under-certified</i> and interest thereon by arbitration proceedings against the Employer. This was clear from a perusal of cll\u00a032 and 34. In addition, cl\u00a022 specifically allowed the contractor to claim \u201cLoss and Expense\u201d against the Employer under many stated grounds. Hence, <i>Pacific Associates</i> was not distinguishable because of cl\u00a032.8.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">110\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the effect of cl\u00a02.8, we accepted the respondent\u2019s argument as set out in [95] above.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Policy considerations</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">111\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In reaching our decision, we had also considered the parties\u2019 arguments on whether if there had been proximity, there would have been any policy considerations that would have persuaded us to deny any remedy to the appellant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The parties\u2019 arguments</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">112\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this regard, the appellant first submitted that given the recognised and accepted position of the certifier having to be independent and impartial to both the employer and the contractor, it was logical that a duty of care be imposed on the certifier to ensure that he would discharge his duties professionally to all parties who might be affected by his certification. This would also help to improve the overall standards in the industry. To this submission, the respondent argued that it was merely speculative.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">113\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, the appellant stated that the trial judge\u2019s concern about opening the floodgates must be considered in its appropriate context. In particular, while there might be additional claims made (such as from sub-contractors), it was within the power of the courts to control the risk by recognising the appellant\u2019s claim and denying the other claims. In this case, the respondent\u2019s duties, certification and otherwise, were aimed at the party in direct contract with the Employer, <i>ie</i>, the main contractor, and there was no risk of indeterminate liability. The respondent\u2019s argument, in response, was that it would not be just or reasonable to impose a duty of care on the SO in view of the contractual framework to which the appellant had agreed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Our decision</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">114\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the facts of the present case, the same reasons above articulated by Russell\u00a0LJ in <i>Pacific Associates</i> can also be characterised as policy considerations under the second stage of the test in <i>Anns</i>. For the reasons considered above, <i>viz</i>, a duty of care should not be superimposed on a contractual framework, we considered that there were cogent policy reasons why, assuming that proximity was found, a duty of care should nonetheless <i>not</i> be imposed on the respondent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">115\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To recapitulate: A <i>single</i> test to determine the existence of a duty of care should be applied regardless of the nature of the damage caused (<i>ie</i>, pure economic loss or physical damage). It could be that a more restricted approach is preferable for cases of pure economic loss but this is to be done within the confines of a single test. This test is a two-stage test, comprising of, first, proximity and, second, policy considerations. These two stages are to be approached with reference to the facts of decided cases although the absence of such cases is not an absolute bar against a finding of duty. There is, of course, the threshold issue of factual foreseeability but since this is likely to be fulfilled in most cases, we do not see the need to include this as part of the <i>legal</i> test for a duty of care.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">116\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the circumstances, applying the two-stage test, we found that there was no duty of care as the appellant had contended for. As a result, we did not have to consider the additional issues of breach, causation and remoteness which had been canvassed before us. The appeal was dismissed with costs and with the usual consequential orders.</span></p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p 658.</span></font></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref2\" name=\"_ftn2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span id=\"ftn7\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref7\" name=\"_ftn7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span Part\u00a0I at 2328 to 2335.</span></font></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn8\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn8\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref8\" name=\"_ftn8\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span 28</Cit>\n    </Citation>\n    <CaseTitle>Projection Pte Ltd v The Tai Ping Insurance Co Ltd</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Projection Pte Ltd v The Tai Ping Insurance Co Ltd</SortTitle><SortDate>2001-04-19T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA  110/2000</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\"
