That summons makes it abundantly clear that they are objecting, and the fact that they ask for a decision upon their objection to be postponed until the outcome of the Greek proceedings is known is not in any way inconsistent with maintaining their objection. I can see no reason in principle or common sense why the respondents should not be entitled to say: \u201cWe object to the jurisdiction of the English courts, but we ask for the proceedings necessary to decide that and the other issues to be stayed pending the decision of the proceedings in Greece.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 By entertaining the application for a stay in this case, the court would be assuming (rightly) that it has jurisdiction to decide whether or not it has jurisdiction to deal with the merits, but would not be making any assumption about its jurisdiction to deal with the merits.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">On the basis of this passage, counsel for the Appellant contended that the Stay Application was an application involving the second kind of jurisdiction only, and not the first kind of jurisdiction, and that the meaning of Prayer\u00a02 should therefore be considered in that light.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we noted at [73] above, the Judge declined to consider the meaning of Prayer\u00a02 in that light and rejected these arguments. In the light of the Judge\u2019s reliance on the <i>Juan Ysmael</i> test to hold that the Appellant\u2019s claim to the Funds, not being illusory, was sufficient to stay the interpleader proceedings (see [25] above), it is understandable why the Judge had to construe Prayer\u00a02 as invoking the court\u2019s jurisdiction to release the Funds to the Appellant. The Judge\u2019s logic in dismissing the Stay Application despite finding that the Appellant\u2019s claim to the Funds was not merely illusory required that some meaning or purpose be given to Prayer\u00a02, and that could only be to require the court to adjudicate on the merits of the Appellant\u2019s claim and thereafter release the Funds to the Appellant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Appellant\u2019s contention before us was essentially that the Judge had misunderstood its argument on the purpose of Prayer\u00a02. The Stay Application, so it was argued, was premised on the court finding that the Funds belonged to the Appellant by virtue of the Forfeiture Order, and not on the finding that the Appellant\u2019s claim to the Funds was not illusory. The Appellant, so counsel submitted, intended Prayer\u00a02 to have a facilitative role, and not a destructive role.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the Appellant\u2019s approach or argument is founded on a fallacy and a misunderstanding of the nature of a stay application. Prayer\u00a02 is not and cannot be a consequence of an order of court to stay the proceedings. It is the very antithesis of such an order. As the Judge observed, a stay is a stay, and its only consequence is the suspension of all pending claims in the proceedings in question. What is abundantly clear, as the Appellant has admitted, is that the Appellant wanted the Funds to be released to it under Prayer\u00a02 (or, after the withdrawal of Prayer\u00a02, under prayer\u00a04 of the Stay Application).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Appellant might have avoided the fatal effect which Prayer\u00a02 had on the Stay Application if it had intended the prayer to operate only if the court found that it was the owner of the Funds, but not otherwise. Prayer\u00a02 would then simply not have become operational in the event of the court ruling against the Appellant on the issue of ownership. The conditionality of Prayer\u00a02 in such a scenario would have provided a credible explanation to what now appears to be inexplicable irrationality and self-destructiveness on the part of the Appellant in framing the Stay Application to include Prayer\u00a02. The Judge might even have accepted the argument just posited (<i>ie</i>, that Prayer\u00a02 was to operate only upon a ruling in favour of the Appellant <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the issue of ownership of the Funds) and construed Prayer\u00a02 in that light. However, since the Appellant denied that Prayer\u00a02 was meant to have this conditional effect, the Judge was left with the construction that Prayer\u00a02 meant what it said. In our view, Prayer\u00a02 was always intended to invoke the jurisdiction of our courts to release the Funds to the Appellant <i>irrespective of why (ie, the grounds on which) the interpleader proceedings were to be stayed, so long as those proceedings were stayed.</i> On the Appellant\u2019s own explanation, even if the Judge had decided to stay the interpleader proceedings on the basis that the Appellant had proved its title to the Funds, it would still have invoked Prayer\u00a02 to request the court to release the Funds to it<i>.</i> Accordingly, we find as a fact that the Appellant had always intended to take a step in the proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The effect of treating Prayer\u00a02 as independent of prayer\u00a01 of the Stay Application may be considered from another perspective. When the Appellant filed the Stay Application, it was aware that the Funds were under the control of the court for the credit of the proceedings (<i>ie</i>, they would only be released to the claimant(s) found by the court to be entitled thereto). The problem which the Appellant had to overcome in order to achieve its ultimate objective of securing the release of the Funds was to find a way to procure such release without submitting to the jurisdiction of the Singapore courts. The Appellant considered that the solution lay in asserting state immunity in a stay application. In other words, the Stay Application was merely a pretext to persuade the court to release the Funds. From this perspective, and given the Appellant\u2019s ultimate objective, the Appellant had always intended the court to consider the merits of its claim to the Funds.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Summary of our findings</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In summary, we find as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A sovereign state is not entitled to invoke the doctrine of state immunity in a case involving claims to debts or choses in action that are in the hands of a third party which is not an agent or a trustee of the state, and especially where, as in the present case, the disputed assets are held in escrow by the third party for the credit of the proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the facts of this appeal, the <i>Juan Ysmael</i> test is not sufficient as a test for determining whether or not the Appellant is entitled to assert immunity to the interpleader proceedings. This is because although the Appellant\u2019s claim to the Funds based on the Forfeiture Order is \u201cnot merely illusory\u201d, the legal effect of that order under Singapore law is disputed by the Respondents. If a stay were to be granted merely on the basis that the Appellant has satisfied the <i>Juan Ysmael</i> test, it would have the effect of leaving the threshold issue of whether the Forfeiture Order fulfilled the Escrow Condition undecided, and the Funds would remain in the control of the court indefinitely. This would be unjust to third party claimants (such as the Respondents) and is contrary to the public policy that there should be finality in court proceedings. (The Judge could have decided the above threshold issue, but he declined to do so and the Appellant has not appealed on this ground.)</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 PNB did not act as the Appellant\u2019s agent in the interpleader proceedings, and therefore the Appellant could not have submitted to the jurisdiction of the court via PNB.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prayer\u00a02, in seeking the release of the Funds to the Appellant, was a step in the proceedings for the purposes of s\u00a04(3)(<i>b</i>) of the SIA, and therefore amounted to a submission to the jurisdiction of the court. In any event, the Stay Application, construed as a whole, had the effect of a submission to the jurisdiction of the court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the basis of the above findings, we dismiss the appeal. As the Appellant has succeeded on issues\u00a0(b) and (c) as set out at [26] above but failed on issues\u00a0(a) and (d), we order that it bear 50% of the costs of the Respondents in the appeal, with the usual consequential orders.</span></p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref1\" name=\"_ftn1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 1]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See section\u00a01 of the Executive Order dated 28\u00a0February 1986.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref2\" para\u00a02 of the court order dated 24\u00a0March 2004.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn3\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref3\" name=\"_ftn3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 3]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See para\u00a05 of the affidavit of the Philippines Ambassador to Singapore dated 8\u00a0March 2006.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn4\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref4\" name=\"_ftn4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 4]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See para\u00a043 of the Appellant\u2019s skeletal arguments dated 26\u00a0July 2007.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn5\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn5\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref5\" name=\"_ftn5\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 5]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See paras\u00a043\u201344 of the Appellant\u2019s skeletal arguments dated 26\u00a0July 2007.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn6\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref6\" name=\"_ftn6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 6]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">At para 19 of the Appellant\u2019s rebuttal submissions.</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">21\u00a0April 2008</p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-author\">V\u00a0K\u00a0Rajah\u00a0JA (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>Introduction</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal raised an interesting but rather narrow point of law, <i>viz</i>, whether the court retains a residual jurisdiction to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt <i>after</i> the court has approved a scheme of arrangement pursuant to s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act (Cap\u00a050, 2006\u00a0Rev Ed). The judge in the court below (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) answered this question in the negative (see <i>Re Reliance National Asia Re Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2008] 1 SLR 569</nobr> (\u201cthe GD\u201d) at [2]). She then dismissed the application of the appellant, Oriental Insurance Co Ltd (\u201cOriental\u201d), for a three-week extension of time to file its proof of debt pursuant to the scheme of compromise and arrangement entered into between the respondent, Reliance National Asia Re Pte Ltd (\u201cReliance\u201d), and its creditors including Oriental (\u201cthe Scheme\u201d).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge\u2019s decision effectively meant that Oriental was prevented from recovering any portion of its outstanding claim of approximately US$20m from Reliance. Oriental appealed against the Judge\u2019s decision. We allowed Oriental\u2019s appeal and now give the detailed reasons for our decision.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>The facts</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Events leading up to the Scheme</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reliance was incorporated locally in July 1996 and was in the business of undertaking general insurance. At its inception, Reliance was a fully-owned subsidiary of Reliance Insurance Company (\u201cRIC\u201d), a company incorporated in the US. RIC ran into financial difficulties in 2000, and its financial frailty affected Reliance\u2019s operations, rendering it no longer feasible for Reliance to continue business. As a consequence, Reliance\u2019s management decided that the best commercial option would be to enter into a voluntary run-off of the company. This was initiated in April 2001 (see the GD at [3]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequently, Whittington Investment Guernsey Ltd (\u201cWIG\u201d) acquired the entire share capital of Reliance sometime in 2004. As the run-off proved to be both costly and time-consuming, Reliance, under its new ownership, decided that the most efficient and effective method of settlement with its creditors would be the implementation of a solvent scheme of arrangement (in the form of the Scheme) under s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act. Whittington Asia Pacific Pte Ltd, a company alleged by Oriental (and which appears) to be a wholly-owned subsidiary of WIG, was duty appointed as the scheme manager having conduct of the Scheme (\u201cthe Scheme Manager\u201d). It appears from para\u00a01.7 of the explanatory statement to the Scheme (\u201cthe Explanatory Statement\u201d), which is reproduced at [7] below, that the acquisition of Reliance by WIG in 2004 was motivated by business considerations, namely, an expedient conclusion of the run-off by means of the Scheme. According to Reliance, the Scheme would have the advantage of concluding the run-off of Reliance\u2019s business much earlier than would be the case if the run-off were to continue until all claims from Reliance\u2019s creditors (referred to as \u201cScheme Creditors\u201d in these grounds of decision) had materialised and had been agreed to and paid in the normal course of business (see the GD at [4]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To implement the Scheme, Reliance sent a letter dated 18\u00a0November 2005 to all the Scheme Creditors, including Oriental (an insurance company incorporated in India and wholly-owned by the Indian government), informing them about and seeking their support of the Scheme. The letter was sent to Oriental\u2019s general address at A-25/27, Asaf Ali Road, New Delhi 110002, India (\u201cthe General Address\u201d).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pursuant to s\u00a0210(1) of the Companies Act, Reliance applied on 19\u00a0May 2006 to the High Court for permission to convene a creditors\u2019 meeting. By an order of court dated 2\u00a0June 2006, a meeting of the Scheme Creditors (\u201cthe Court Meeting\u201d) was ordered to be convened to consider whether the Scheme should be approved. On 16\u00a0June 2006, Reliance sent the notice of the Court Meeting (which was to be held on 26\u00a0September 2006), the Explanatory Statement and the documents setting out the terms and conditions of the Scheme (\u201cthe</span> Scheme of Compromise and Arrangement\u201d) <span lang=\"EN-AU\">to Oriental at the General Address. The proxy form, voting form and a specimen proof of debt form were also bound together with the above documents (collectively, all the documents sent to the Scheme Creditors, including Oriental, will be referred to as \u201cthe Scheme Documents\u201d). It was not disputed that Oriental received the Scheme Documents (see the GD at [7]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Key provisions of the Scheme Documents</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purposes of this appeal, we think it would be helpful to set out some of the salient provisions of the Scheme Documents, particularly those relating to the purpose of the Scheme, the filing of proofs of debt by Scheme Creditors and the payment of Scheme Creditors\u2019 claims (\u201cScheme Claims\u201d).</span> Paragraph\u00a01.7 of the Explanatory Statement explained that the objectives of the Scheme <span lang=\"EN-AU\">were to <i>conclude the run-off of Reliance\u2019s business earlier</i> than would be the case if the run-off were to continue until all Scheme Claims had materialised and had been agreed to and paid, as well as to make <i>full payment</i> to all the Scheme Creditors:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>1.7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 REASONS FOR SCHEME AND FOR SCHEME CREDITORS TO APPROVE THE SCHEME</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The Company [<i>ie</i>, Reliance] does not expect the run-off of the Company\u2019s business to be completed for many years and as a result believes that a Scheme of Arrangement should be the most efficient and effective method of making <i>full payments</i> to Scheme Creditors in the shortest practicable time. <i>A Scheme will have the effect of concluding the run-off of the Company\u2019s business earlier than would be the case if it were to continue until all claims had materialised and had been agreed and paid in the normal course</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The aim of the acquisition of the Company by WIG was for WIG to conclude the run-off by use of a <i>solvent scheme of arrangement, which is intended to cover all creditors of the Company</i>. If the Company were unable to promote the Scheme, the costs of maintaining the run-off would be disproportionate and it is likely that the Company would explore other alternative methods of putting a close to the Company\u2019s business, such as by a solvent liquidation.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Similarly, cl\u00a02.1 of the Scheme of Compromise and Arrangement <span lang=\"EN-AU\">emphasised:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The primary purpose of the Scheme is to <i>conclude the run-off of the Company\u2019s business earlier than it would have been [concluded] in the normal course</i> by accelerating where necessary and providing a mechanism for payment of <i>all</i> Scheme Claims. To achieve such purpose, the Scheme establishes mechanisms by which all Scheme Claims (present and future) shall be ascertained and thereupon <i>paid in full</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the Scheme\u2019s objective of paying all the Scheme Creditors in full, para\u00a01.6 of the Explanatory Statement set out the financial position of Reliance and explained that, based on the company\u2019s audited accounts as at 31\u00a0December 2005, Reliance had sufficient assets to meet all the Scheme Claims:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-AU\">1.6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 FINANCIAL POSITION OF THE COMPANY</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">1.6.1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The audited balance sheet of the Company for the year ended 31\u00a0December 2005 shows the Company to be <i>solvent with assets of S$36,861,203 and liabilities of S$28,062,270, with a net asset value of S$8,798,933</i>. ...</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">1.6.2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The net asset value as at 31\u00a0December 2004 was S$11,390,701, while the net asset value as at 31\u00a0December 2005 was S$8,798,933. <i>There has been no material change in the financial position of the Company since 31\u00a0December 2005</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">1.6.3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Out of the total assets of S$36,861,203 (for the year ended 31\u00a0December 2005), the Company has cash and investments of S$27,208,416, and insurance and reinsurance assets worth S$8,361,398.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">1.6.4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Out of the total liabilities of S$28,062,270 (for the year ended 31\u00a0December 2005), the Company estimates that S$730,595 are non Scheme Liabilities. <i>The Scheme Liabilities as at 31\u00a0December 2005 amount to S$27,331,675</i>, of which, S$3,423,465 represents outstanding claims (agreed but as yet unpaid), S$16,061,000 represents loss reserves and Incurred But Not Reported (\u201cIBNR\u201d) claims, and S$7,847,210 represents amounts owing to retrocessionaires.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">As Reliance (as at 31\u00a0December 2005) had assets of $36,861,203 and liabilities of $28,062,270, of which an estimated $27,331,675 consisted of \u201cScheme Liabilities\u201d, the Scheme was (and remains) a <i>solvent</i> scheme of arrangement whereby all the Scheme Creditors would be paid in full. In fact, para\u00a01.7 of the Explanatory Statement (see [7] above) unequivocally described the Scheme as \u201ca <i>solvent</i> scheme of arrangement, which [was] intended to cover <i>all</i> creditors of the Company\u201d [emphasis added].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for how and when payments under the Scheme were to be effected, para\u00a02.2.1 of the Explanatory Statement provided as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>2.2.1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Payment under the Scheme</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company shall pay or procure to be paid to each Scheme Creditor, <i>who has delivered a Proof of Debt to the Scheme Manager at the Specified Address on or before 14\u00a0May 2007</i>, an amount in the Reference Currency equal to [its] Approved Scheme Claim. Payment to the Scheme Creditors in respect of their Approved Scheme Claims shall only be made by the Company after all Scheme Claims have been determined by the Scheme Manager and all Disputed Claims have been adjudicated by the Independent Adjudicator. \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(b)<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event that any Scheme Creditor fails to submit a Proof of Debt to the Scheme Manager at the Specified Address by the Claims Cut-Off [D]ate, that Scheme Creditor shall not be entitled to any payment of his Scheme Claim with effect from the Claims Cut-Off Date, and:</i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>the Company shall be completely and absolutely released and discharged from all claims, obligations and liabilities</i> (whether actual, contingent or otherwise) <i>and indebtedness</i> (whether as principal debtor or surety) <i>of the Company to that Scheme Creditor</i> whatsoever and howsoever arising out of or in connection with any and all agreements, transactions, dealings and matters effected or entered into or occurring at any time prior to the Court Meeting Date (including but not limited to the Scheme Claims of such Scheme Creditor);</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(ii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that Scheme Creditor shall, if called upon so to do, execute and deliver to the Company such forms of release and discharge thereof on such terms as the Company may reasonably require; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(iii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that Scheme Creditor shall forthwith, and in any event at the request of the Company discontinue and terminate, without any order as to costs, any and all legal proceedings commenced by it against the Company in any jurisdiction for or in this connection.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Thus, in order to receive payment under the Scheme, the Scheme Creditors had to file their proofs of debt on or before the claims cut-off date (\u201cthe Claims Cut-Off Date\u201d), which was stated to be 14\u00a0May 2007 in the table of \u201cKey Dates and Expected Timetable\u201d in the Explanatory Statement. Paragraph\u00a03.3.2 of the Explanatory Statement further explained that the effect of lodging a proof of debt after the Claims Cut-Off Date was that the particular Scheme Creditor\u2019s claim would be <i>deemed to be zero in value</i>:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>3.3.2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Lodgement After Claims Cut-Off Date</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Any Proofs of Debt received by the Scheme Manager after the Claims Cut-Off Date <i>shall not be admitted by the Scheme Manager</i> for the purpose of the Scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">If any Scheme Creditor fails to submit [its] Proof of Debt by the Claims Cut-Off Date, that Scheme Creditor\u2019s Scheme Claim <i>will be valued at zero</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Similarly, cl\u00a03 of the</span> Scheme of Compromise and Arrangement <span lang=\"EN-AU\">reiterated:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Proof of Debt and Barring of Claims</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>3.1</b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purpose of seeking payment in respect of a Scheme Claim, each Scheme Creditor of the Company shall, <i>no later than the Claims Cut-Off Date</i>, submit to the Scheme Manager at the Specified Address, a Proof of Debt relating to that Scheme Creditor\u2019s Scheme Claims.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>3.2</b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The value of all Scheme Claims of any Scheme Creditor who fails to submit a Proof of Debt on or before the Claims Cut-Off Date <i>shall be deemed to be zero</i>. For the avoidance of doubt, and as an independent stipulation, in such a situation, the relevant Scheme Creditor shall be bound by the terms of the Scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">In the</span> Scheme of Compromise and Arrangement<span lang=\"EN-AU\">, the Claims Cut-Off Date was likewise defined in cl\u00a01 as 14\u00a0May 2007.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Events after Oriental received the Scheme Documents</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After receiving the Scheme Documents, Oriental completed the voting form and the proxy form and sent them to Reliance on 15\u00a0September 2006, requesting that the latter attend the Court Meeting on its behalf. Oriental voted in favour of the Scheme and appointed the chairman of the Court Meeting as its proxy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the Court Meeting (which was held on 26\u00a0September 2006), a majority in number and a majority of three-fourths in value of the Scheme Creditors, voting either in person or by proxy, voted in favour of the Scheme. Reliance then applied to the High Court on 17\u00a0October 2006 for the Scheme to be sanctioned.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequently, Reliance sent <span lang=\"EN-AU\">a letter dated 18\u00a0October 2006 to Oriental at the General Address, addressed to Mr\u00a0S\u00a0L\u00a0Mohan (\u201cMr\u00a0Mohan\u201d), who was known to Reliance as a senior executive of Oriental. This letter notified Oriental that Reliance had applied to the High Court for the Scheme to be sanctioned. A copy of the notice of hearing for that application, which was to be heard on 7\u00a0November 2006 at 10.00am, was also enclosed with the letter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 7\u00a0November 2006, the High Court sanctioned the Scheme. Reliance subsequently wrote to Oriental on 14\u00a0November 2006 and informed it of this development. The letter was again sent to the General Address and addressed to Mr\u00a0Mohan. The letter further informed Oriental that the Scheme was now effective and reminded Oriental to file its proof of debt by 14\u00a0May 2007 (<i>ie</i>, the Claims Cut-Off Date):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]he High Court of the Republic of Singapore ha[s] at the hearing this morning sanctioned the Scheme under Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act (Chapter\u00a050).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Accordingly, the Scheme is now effective and applies to all Scheme Creditors regardless of whether and how they voted at the Court Meeting. Steps will now be taken to implement the terms of the Scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">You should note that, under the terms of the Scheme, all Scheme Creditors will have to file their Proofs of Debt to the Scheme [Manager], namely Whittington Asia Pacific Pte Ltd at the Specified Address (i.e. 1\u00a0George Street, #16-03 One George Street, Singapore 049145) by the Claims Cut-Off Date, ie. by <b>14\u00a0May 2007</b>. A copy of the Proof of Debt form is enclosed for your necessary action.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis in bold in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">The proof of debt form mentioned in the above quotation contained specific instructions on how the form was to be completed. The instructions specifically stated, <i>inter alia</i>, that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The deadline for submitting completed Proof of Debt Forms is the Claims Cut-Off Date, being 12.00 midnight Singapore time on <b><u>14\u00a0May 2007</u></b> ... Returned Proof of Debt Forms must reach the Scheme Manager on or before this date. If a Scheme Creditor does not complete and return a Proof of Debt Form to the Scheme Manager by the Claims Cut-Off Date, that Scheme Creditor\u2019s Scheme Claims shall be deemed to be zero.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[underlining and emphasis in bold in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Oriental alleged that it did not receive both the letter of 18\u00a0October 2006 and that of 14\u00a0November 2006. It contended that:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The letters had not been sent to the address provided in its completed voting form and completed proxy form.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The letters were addressed to Mr\u00a0Mohan, who had retired from Oriental in February 2005. In this regard, Oriental pointed out that as it had a very large workforce of some 16,000 employees and 1,000 offices all over India, letters that were not addressed to the correct individuals might go missing.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After November 2006, Reliance sent a further six e-mails to Oriental to remind the latter to submit its proof of debt before the Claims Cut-Off Date. These e-mails were sent to two different e-mail addresses, as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <span lang=\"EN-AU\">The first three e-mails were sent to the e-mail address \u201coic@oriental.nic.in\u201d on 11\u00a0January 2007, 13\u00a0February 2007 and 13\u00a0March 2007 respectively, and a copy of the proof of debt form was attached to each of the e-mails. Reliance had apparently obtained this email address from what it described as \u201cthe Insurance Directory of Asia 2004/2005\u201d</span><a id=\"_ftnref1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\" name=\"_ftnref1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">[note: 1]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-AU\">. Oriental contended that it had not received these e-mails as the e-mail address \u201coic@oriental.nic.in\u201d had been terminated as early as 1\u00a0April 2005</span>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <span lang=\"EN-AU\">The later three e-mails were addressed specifically to Mr\u00a0M\u00a0K\u00a0Jindal (\u201cMr\u00a0Jindal\u201d), who had been identified in Oriental\u2019s completed voting form as Oriental\u2019s \u201cDy. General Manager (Technical)\u201d. These e-mails were sent on 11\u00a0April 2007, 2\u00a0May 2007 and 10\u00a0May 2007 respectively to the e-mail address \u201cmkjindal@orientalinsurance.co.in\u201d, which was likewise obtained from Oriental\u2019s completed voting form. Once again, a copy of the proof of debt form was attached to each of the e-mails. Oriental maintained that Mr\u00a0Jindal had not received those e-mails.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reliance also alleged that it had tried to contact Oriental on 11\u00a0May 2007 twice via the fax number listed in Oriental\u2019s letter dated 15\u00a0September 2006 enclosing Oriental\u2019s completed proxy form and completed voting form. Both attempts were, however, unsuccessful.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Sometime in July 2007, Oriental was informed by the Indian Insurance Regulatory Authority (which had earlier been notified by the Monetary Authority of Singapore) that it had failed to file its proof of debt in time. On being apprised of this, Oriental immediately sent a letter on 16\u00a0July 2007 to Reliance seeking confirmation of the status of its monetary claim. Reliance replied on 18\u00a0July 2007 stating that as Oriental had failed to submit its proof of debt by the Claims Cut-Off Date, its claim of US$19,031,656 had been deemed to be of zero value (see the GD at [19]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Oriental then applied on 4\u00a0September 2007, under O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006\u00a0Rev Ed), for a three-week extension of time to file its proof of debt under the Scheme (see the GD at [20]). Order\u00a03 r\u00a04 provides as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>Extension, etc., of time (O.\u00a03, r.\u00a04)</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>4.</b>\u2014(1)\u00a0The Court may, on such terms as it thinks just, by order extend or abridge the period within which a person is required or authorised by these Rules or by any judgment, <i>order</i> or direction, to do <i>any act</i> in <i>any proceedings</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court may extend any such period as is referred to in paragraph\u00a0(1) although the application for extension is not made until after the expiration of that period.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The period within which a person is required by these Rules, or by any order or direction, to serve, file or amend any pleading or other document may be extended by consent (given in writing) without an order of the Court being made for that purpose, unless the Court specifies otherwise.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this Rule, references to the Court shall be construed as including references to the Court of Appeal.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Paragraph\u00a0(3) shall not apply to the period within which any action or matter is required to be set down for trial or hearing or within which any notice of appeal is required to be filed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>The decision below</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Oriental\u2019s application for an extension of time was dismissed by the Judge. The Judge held that the sole issue before her was whether the court had jurisdiction to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt after the court had approved a scheme of arrangement (see the GD at [2]), and she was of the view that, although this issue was a relatively narrowly-defined one, it had to be analysed \u201cwithin the entire framework of <span lang=\"EN-AU\">principles and procedures that govern[ed] compromises and schemes of arrangements\u201d (<i>id</i> at [22]). The Judge observed that the answer to the question turned on the nature of schemes of arrangement, and that there was \u201csome controversy as to whether a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from an order of court, or from the statute\u201d (<i>id</i> at [27]), given that the two jurisdictions from which s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act was derived (namely, the UK and Australia) had adopted radically different solutions to the same conundrum (<i>id</i> at [28]\u2013[31]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The English approach (which will be considered in greater detail at [48]\u2013[52] below), as embodied in the Privy Council decision of <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Kempe v Ambassador Insurance Co</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">[1998] 1\u00a0WLR 271 (\u201c<i>Kempe</i>\u201d), takes the position that a scheme of arrangement which has been approved by the requisite majority of the company\u2019s creditors derives its efficacy purely from statute and therefore operates as a statutory contract. Thus, save in cases of obvious mistakes in the documents setting out the scheme or fraud (where the court has inherent jurisdiction to make amendments to the scheme), once a scheme of arrangement has been approved by the necessary majority and sanctioned by the court, the court has no jurisdiction to make any substantive alterations to the scheme, including extending the time for creditors to file their proofs of debt pursuant to the scheme. In contrast, the Australian approach (considered at [53]\u2013[56] below) takes the position that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the order of court approving the scheme and in fact operates as an order of court. A court has inherent jurisdiction to vary its own orders. In any case, in our local context, O\u00a03 r\u00a04(1) of the Rules of Court (reproduced at [19] above), which provides that the court may by order \u201c</span>extend \u2026 the period within which a person is required or authorised by \u2026 any \u2026 <i>order</i> \u2026 to do <i>any act</i> in <i>any proceedings</i>\u201d [emphasis added]<span lang=\"EN-AU\">, would permit the court (after it has approved a scheme of arrangement) to grant a creditor an extension of time to file its proof of debt.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After assessing both approaches, the Judge regarded the English approach as the more persuasive one and accordingly adopted it. She held (see the GD at [32]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">In my view, the English position is more persuasive than the Australian one and I therefore adopted it in this case. At the very core of every sanctioned scheme lies a statutory contract of compromise that fully-informed creditors have agreed to</span></i></b><span lang=\"EN-AU\">. The statutory provision exists primarily to overcome the impossibility of obtaining the individual consent of each and every member. Theoretically speaking, it is not impossible for such a scheme to be effective even <i>without</i> the court\u2019s sanction if the company and <i>all</i> its creditors agreed to the proposal, <i>ie</i>, there were no dissentients. The scheme then operates purely by way of contract. Of course, in reality, this is rarely achievable (especially in big companies), but <b><i>the point is that the sanction of the court adds no magic to the scheme, other than to bind dissentient members to a scheme which the court accepts as fair and reasonable</i></b>. \u2026 [W]here the statutory requirements have been satisfied, the discretion of the court in deciding whether to sanction the scheme is limited. <b><i>In this sense, one can view the source of efficacy of the scheme as the statutory provisions, and not, strictly speaking, the court order sanctioning the scheme</i></b>. This is, of course, not to detract from the fact that the court retains an <b><i>inherent jurisdiction</i></b> to correct any obvious errors in the scheme ...</span> [emphasis added in bold italics].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge then considered the limited circumstances where a scheme of arrangement <i>which had already been approved by the court</i> (\u201ccourt-approved scheme\u201d) could be amended through the exercise of the court\u2019s inherent jurisdiction. She opined that an extension of a time limit set out in such a scheme was a \u201cmaterial alteration\u201d (see [38] of the GD, quoting from <i>Kempe</i> at 276) and, therefore, the court had no jurisdiction to make such an alteration. The Judge\u2019s reasoning was as follows (see the GD at [38] and [40]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Once a scheme of arrangement has been sanctioned and registered, it may only be amended in <i>very limited circumstances</i>. This is effected through the exercise of the court\u2019s inherent jurisdiction. <b><i>Thus, a court-sanctioned scheme may be set aside where consent to it has been obtained by fraud (Fletcher v Royal Automobile Club Ltd <nobr>[2000] 1 BCLC 331</nobr>), or where there are any \u201cobvious mistakes\u201d in the document (Kempe at 276)</i></b>. The general principle, however, is that the court cannot alter the <i>substance</i> of the scheme and impose upon creditors arrangements to which they did not agree (<i>Kempe</i> at 276). <b><i>It has been held that an amendment to time limits set out in a scheme constitutes a \u201cmaterial alternation\u201d</i></b> (<i>Kempe</i> at \u2026 276) and an \u201camendment of substance\u201d (<i>In</i> <i>Re Forklift Sales (SA) Pty Ltd</i> (1972) 3\u00a0SASR 21 at 25 \u2026 ).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <b><i>In my view, this proposition is in tandem with the principle that the court has no jurisdiction to alter the substance of the scheme and impose upon creditors an arrangement to which they had not agreed</i></b>. The s\u00a0210 procedure would need to be adhered to rigorously in any application for amendment to schemes of arrangement and the safeguards therein would ensure that terms to which the majority of the creditors do not agree will not be imposed on them \u2013 the original scheme is amended by the creditors, <i>not</i> by the court. Even then, the court is naturally reluctant to reopen [creditors\u2019] rights and obligations: <i>Re Elliott\u2019s</i> [<i>MF Services Pty Ltd</i> <nobr>[1965] VR 756</nobr>] (at 757). <b><i>This strengthens the view that a scheme of arrangement should be viewed as a statutory contract the terms of which have been agreed to by the parties rather than imposed on them by an order of court</i></b>. Where the amendments sought are material or substantial, the court has no jurisdiction to grant such amendments and thereby impose on creditors something which they had not considered or agreed to.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added in bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge concluded by noting (at [41] of the GD):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">The basis on which Oriental sought an extension of time was O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court ... As I accepted the English position enunciated in <i>Kempe</i>, and this was not a case of fraud or obvious mistake, I found that there was no jurisdiction to grant such an extension of time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In arriving at her decision, the Judge (as mentioned at [20] above) considered at some length certain established principles relating to schemes of arrangement (which will be discussed at [42]\u2013[46] below), and was of the opinion that these principles supported and were consistent with the position adopted in <i>Kempe</i> (see the GD at [36] and [40]). The Judge also took pains to stress that \u201c[t]he <span lang=\"EN-AU\">overarching principle here [<i>ie</i>, in the case of a court-approved scheme] is one of <i>clarity</i>, <i>certainty</i> and <i>finality</i>, without which a scheme of arrangement cannot be efficaciously implemented\u201d [emphasis added] (see the GD at [25]), and it appeared that this was one of the main reasons which persuaded her to adopt the English approach as laid down in <i>Kempe</i>. She stated (at [44] of the GD):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u2026 I was of the view that there would be serious repercussions if this application [by Oriental for an extension of time to file its proof of debt] was allowed, not only for Reliance, but also for future schemes of arrangement. <i>The most weighty consequence is that the certainty, efficacy and finality of schemes such as the present would be severely compromised</i>. If, on the facts of the present case, an application to extend time had been granted, the threshold for future creditors to seek an extension of time would be very low. There will then be no certainty and finality in a scheme such as the present because every time a creditor obtain[s] an extension of time, all the claims will have to be re-adjudicated. Much delay, which would be prejudicial to the scheme, will also ensue. This will be further complicated if, for example, interim dividends have already been paid out under the scheme, such as in <i>Kempe</i>. In fact, counsel for Reliance informed the court at the hearing that, were this application to be allowed, the entire scheme might have to be abandoned. This was in the light of the very nature and object of the Scheme, <i>viz,</i> to adjudicate and settle all claims more expeditiously than would be the case if Reliance continued to be in run-off. <i>In complex commercial arrangements such as the present where parties are legally advised and are fully informed, I am of the view that \u2026 the court should lean towards certainty as this is the course that is fairest and of most benefit to scheme creditors taken as a whole</i>. [emphasis added].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>The parties\u2019 arguments on appeal</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present appeal, the crux of Oriental\u2019s case was simply that \u201c[the Judge] erred in accepting the English authorities, and that the correct approach in law [was] the approach taken by the Australian courts \u2026 that the scheme [of arrangement was] essentially an order of court\u201d.<a id=\"_ftnref2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\" name=\"_ftnref2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 2]</span></span></a> Oriental contended that if the decision in <i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>) were to be accepted as laying down the general proposition of law, then the court would become <i>functus officio</i> the moment it approved a scheme of arrangement. Such a sterile approach, it was submitted, could lead to manifest injustice. In contrast, Reliance, reiterating the reasons given by the Judge in the GD for adopting the approach in <i>Kempe</i>, submitted that there were \u201ccompelling reasons\u201d<a id=\"_ftnref3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn3\" name=\"_ftnref3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 3]</span></span></a> for adopting that approach. Reliance also submitted that in <i>Daewoo Singapore Pte Ltd v CEL Tractors Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] 4 SLR 35</nobr> (\u201c<i>Daewoo</i>\u201d), a case which we will deal with in greater detail at [58]\u2013[59] below, \u201c[t]he Singapore Court of Appeal ha[d] <i>affirmed</i> that a scheme of arrangement [was] a <i>statutory contract</i> entered into between the company and scheme creditors\u201d<a id=\"_ftnref4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn4\" name=\"_ftnref4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 4]</span></span></a> [emphasis added].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the hearing before us, counsel for Oriental, Mr\u00a0N\u00a0Sreenivasan (\u201cMr\u00a0Sreenivasan\u201d), sought leave (which we granted) to introduce a new legal argument which had not been raised either in the court below or in Oriental\u2019s written case for this appeal and which had been made for the first time only in Oriental\u2019s written skeletal submissions for this appeal. This argument<a id=\"_ftnref5\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn5\" name=\"_ftnref5\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 5]</span></span></a> was premised on s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act. Oriental submitted that s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) gave the court the jurisdiction to grant an extension of time for, <i>inter alia</i>, creditors to file their proofs of debt under a scheme of arrangement, and thus afforded an alternative ground to the Rules of Court (if the Australian approach were adopted), <i>independent of the nature of schemes of arrangement</i>, for this court to allow Oriental\u2019s application for an extension of time. As this argument concerned purely a point of law, and as adequate notice had been given to Reliance\u2019s counsel, we gave leave to Mr\u00a0Sreenivasan to raise this new argument before this court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>The issues on appeal</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The main issue for our determination was whether the court had jurisdiction, be it pursuant to O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court (if the Australian approach were adopted) or s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act, to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt in respect of a court-approved scheme. An affirmative answer to this main issue would raise the corollary issue of whether an extension of time should be granted to Oriental on the facts of the present case. We should perhaps point out at this juncture, for the sake of clarity, that in respect of the main issue, the word \u201cjurisdiction\u201d is used in these grounds of decision in the sense of \u201cpower\u201d to denote jurisdictional power (see <i>Ng Swee Lang v Sassoon Samuel Bernard</i> <nobr>[2008] SGCA 7</nobr> (\u201c<i>Ng Swee Lang</i>\u201d) at [26]), and not in the strict sense of the authority of the court to hear and determine a dispute brought before it (which was the meaning adopted in <i>Muhd Munir v Noor Hidah</i> <nobr>[1990] SLR 999</nobr> (\u201c<i>Muhd Munir</i>\u201d) at 1007, [9]). In <i>Ng Swee Lang</i>, Chan Sek Keong\u00a0CJ illustrated the concept of \u201cjurisdiction\u201d as jurisdictional power with the following example (at [26]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[W]hen the court says that it has no jurisdiction to issue a Mareva injunction in aid of a foreign arbitration, it does not mean that the court does not have the authority to hear applications for Mareva injunctions in respect of pending or ongoing foreign arbitration. What it means, instead, is that that kind of injunction is not a relief which the court has jurisdiction (in the sense of jurisdictional power) or power to grant in the context concerned.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In the present appeal, it appears that the parties have, in their submissions before this court and in the court below, used the word \u201cjurisdiction\u201d interchangeably with \u201cpower\u201d. There is no doubt a distinction between \u201cjurisdiction\u201d (in the strict sense) and \u201cpower\u201d (see <i>Muhd Munir</i> at 1007, [9] for an elucidation of the distinction between the two), but, for the purposes of this appeal, we wish to make it clear that the word \u201cjurisdiction\u201d is employed in the sense of jurisdictional power, and we believe that this is what the parties meant as well by their use of this term in their submissions.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>Whether the court has jurisdiction to extend the time for filing proofs of debt in respect of a court-approved scheme</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The question of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend the time (either pursuant to O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court or s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act) for a creditor to file its proof of debt after the court has approved of a scheme of arrangement under s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act appears to be before the local courts for the first time; thus, the Judge quite rightly considered, at some length, the established principles in relation to schemes of arrangement before coming to her decision (see [20] and [25] above). We note, further, that whether or not the court can extend time in this context pursuant to the Rules of Court (as opposed to s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act) depends on the nature of schemes of arrangement, <i>viz</i>, whether they operate as statutory contracts or as orders of court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We agreed with the Judge that the above issues had to be resolved in the context of the established principles relating to and the nature of schemes of arrangement. In addition, we were of the opinion that it was equally important to give due consideration to the legislative history and purpose of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act. It would therefore be useful here for us to first examine the statutory context of s\u00a0210 before considering some of the established principles in relation to schemes of arrangement.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Legislative history and purpose of section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Legislative history</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act, which governs compromises and schemes of arrangements in Singapore, provides as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>Power to compromise with creditors and members</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>210.</b>\u2014(1)\u00a0Where a compromise or [an] arrangement is proposed between a company and its creditors or any class of them or between the company and its members or any class of them, the Court may, on the application in a summary way of the company or of any creditor or member of the company, or, in the case of a company being wound up, of the liquidator, order a meeting of the creditors or class of creditors or of the members of the company or class of members to be summoned in such manner as the Court directs.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A meeting held pursuant to an order of the Court made under subsection\u00a0(1) may be adjourned from time to time if the resolution for adjournment is approved by a majority in number representing three-fourths in value of the creditors or class of creditors or members or class of members present and voting either in person or by proxy at the meeting.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If a majority in number representing three-fourths in value of the creditors or class of creditors or members or class of members present and voting either in person or by proxy at the meeting or the adjourned meeting agrees to any compromise or arrangement, the compromise or arrangement shall, <i>if approved by order of the Court</i><i>, be binding on all the creditors or class of creditors or on the members or class of members, as the case may be, and also on the company or, in the case of a company in the course of being wound up, on the liquidator and contributories of the company</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subject to subsection\u00a0(4A) [which is not relevant to the present appeal], <i>the Court may grant its approval to a compromise or [an] arrangement subject to such alterations or conditions as it thinks just</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 An order under subsection\u00a0(3) shall have no effect until a copy of the order is lodged with the Registrar [of Companies], and upon being so lodged, the order shall take effect on and from the date of lodgment or such earlier date as the Court may determine and as may be specified in the order.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(11)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this section\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201carrangement\u201d includes a reorganisation of the share capital of a company by the consolidation of shares of different classes or by the division of shares into shares of different classes or by both these methods;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201ccompany\u201d means any corporation or society liable to be wound up under this Act.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act originally appeared as s\u00a0176 of the Companies Act 1967 (Act\u00a042 of 1967) (\u201cthe 1967 Act\u201d), which was Singapore\u2019s first piece of companies legislation. Save for the renumbering of s\u00a0176 of the 1967 Act as s\u00a0210 in the Companies Act (Cap\u00a050, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed) and the amendments made to s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act in 2007 via ss\u00a065(<i>b</i>)\u201365(<i>d</i>) of the Banking (Amendment) Act 2007 (Act\u00a01 of 2007) (these changes, which consisted of the insertion of ss\u00a0210(3A) and 210(4A) as well as the addition of the opening words \u201c[s]ubject to subsection\u00a04A\u201d to s\u00a0210(4), are immaterial for the purposes of this appeal), s\u00a0210 has remained (substantially) more or less the same over the years.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As indicated by the Companies Bill 1966 (Bill\u00a020 of 1966), s\u00a0176 of the 1967 Act was based on both s\u00a0206 of the Companies Act 1948 (c\u00a038) (UK) and s\u00a0181 of the Companies Act 1961 of Victoria, Australia (see also Walter Woon, <i>Butterworths\u2019 Annotated Statutes of Singapore:</i> <i>Companies and Securities</i> vol\u00a01 (Butterworths Asia, 1997 issue) (\u201c</span><i>Butterworths\u2019 Annotated Statutes</i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u201d) at p\u00a0588). Presently, s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act is substantially similar to</span> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">s\u00a0425 of the Companies Act 1985 (c\u00a06) (UK) (\u201cthe 1985 UK Companies Act\u201d). (With effect from 6\u00a0April 2008, s\u00a0895 of the Companies Act 2006 (c\u00a046) (UK) replaced s\u00a0425 of the 1985 UK Companies Act (\u201cthe UK s\u00a0425\u201d): see <i>Boyle &amp; Birds\u2019 Company Law</i> (John Birds <i>et al</i> eds) (Jordans, 6th\u00a0Ed, 2007) at p\u00a0819.) Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act is also substantively <i>in pari materia</i> with s\u00a0411 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) (\u201cthe 2001 Australian Corporations Act\u201d) (see</span> <i>Butterworths\u2019 Annotated Statutes</i> at p\u00a0588<span lang=\"EN-AU\">; see also the GD at [21]). Given the similarities between</span> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act on the one hand and</span> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">the UK s\u00a0425 and s\u00a0411 of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (\u201cthe Australian s\u00a0411\u201d) on the other, the English and the Australian cases on the respective provisions are instructive.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although the Australian s\u00a0411 has its origins in UK legislation (see</span> H\u00a0A\u00a0J\u00a0Ford, R\u00a0P\u00a0Austin &amp; I\u00a0M\u00a0Ramsay, <i>Ford\u2019s Principles of Corporations Law</i> (Butterworths, Looseleaf Ed, 1995) (\u201c<i>Ford</i>\u201d) at vol\u00a02, para\u00a024.050 (June 2007 release)<span lang=\"EN-AU\">), the wording of this provision in its present-day form is quite different from that of its UK counterpart; both provisions, however, provide substantially the same mechanism for setting up a scheme of arrangement. Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act appears to be a <i>hybrid</i> of both the UK and the Australian provisions as it uses language found in both provisions. For purposes of comparison, we set out the salient subsections of the UK s\u00a0425 and the Australian s\u00a0411 below.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The UK s\u00a0425 states as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>Power of company to compromise with creditors and members</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>425.\u2014</b>(1)\u00a0Where a compromise or [an] arrangement is proposed between a company and its creditors, or any class of them, or between the company and its members, or any class of them, the court may on the application of the company or any creditor or member of it or, in the case of a company being wound up, of the liquidator, order a meeting of the creditors or class of creditors, or of the members of the company or class of members (as the case may be), to be summoned in such manner as the court directs.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If a majority in number representing three-fourths in value of the creditors or class of creditors or members or class of members (as the case may be), present and voting either in person or by proxy at the meeting, agree to any compromise or arrangement, the compromise or arrangement, <i>if sanctioned by the court, is binding on all creditors or the class of creditors, or on the members or class of members (as the case may be), and also on the company or, in the case of a company in the course of being wound up, on the liquidator and contributories of the company</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court\u2019s order under subsection\u00a0(2) has no effect until an office copy of it has been delivered to the registrar of companies for registration; and a copy of every such order shall be annexed to every copy of the company\u2019s memorandum issued after the order has been made or, in the case of a company not having a memorandum, of every copy so issued of the instrument constituting the company or defining its constitution.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(6)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this section \u2026\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u201ccompany\u201d means any company liable to be wound up under this Act [<i>ie</i>, the 1985 UK Companies Act], and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u201carrangement\u201d includes a reorganisation of the company\u2019s share capital by the consolidation of shares of different classes or by the division of shares into shares of different classes, or by both of those methods.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">The Australian s\u00a0411 states as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where a compromise or [an] arrangement is proposed between a Part\u00a05.1 body [Part\u00a05.1 of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act is the part which deals with arrangements and reconstructions] and its creditors or any class of them or between a Part\u00a05.1 body and its members or any class of them, the Court may, on the application in a summary way of the body or of any creditor or member of the body, or, in the case of a body being wound up, of the liquidator, order a meeting or meetings of the creditors or class of creditors or of the members of the body or class of members to be convened in such manner, and to be held in such place or places (in this jurisdiction or elsewhere), as the Court directs and, where the Court makes such an order, the Court may approve the explanatory statement required by paragraph\u00a0412(1)(a) to accompany notices of the meeting or meetings.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court must not make an order pursuant to an application under subsection\u00a0(1) \u2026 unless:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 14 [days\u2019] notice of the hearing of the application, or such lesser period of notice as the Court or the Commission [<i>ie</i>, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission] permits, has been given to the Commission; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the Court is satisfied that the Commission has had a reasonable opportunity:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to examine the terms of the proposed compromise or arrangement to which the application relates and a draft explanatory statement relating to the proposed compromise or arrangement; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">(ii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to make submissions to the Court in relation to the proposed compromise or arrangement and the draft explanatory statement.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>A compromise or [an] arrangement is binding on the creditors, or on a class of creditors, or on the members, or on a class of members, as the case may be, of the body and on the body or, if the body is in the course of being wound up, on the liquidator and contributories of the body, if, and only if</i>:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 at a meeting convened in accordance with an order of the Court under subsection\u00a0(1) \u2026 :</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in the case of a compromise or [an] arrangement between a body and its creditors or a class of creditors \u2013 the compromise or arrangement is agreed to by a majority in number of the creditors, or of the creditors included in that class of creditors, present and voting, either in person or by proxy, being a majority whose debts or claims against the company amount in the aggregate to at least 75% of the total amount of the debts and claims of the creditors present and voting in person or by proxy, or of the creditors included in that class present and voting in person or by proxy, as the case may be; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">(ii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in the case of a compromise or [an] arrangement between a body and its members or a class of members \u2013 the compromise or arrangement is agreed to by a majority in number of the members, or of the members included in that class of members, present and voting, either in person or by proxy, being, in the case of a body having a share capital, a majority whose shares have nominal values that amount, in the aggregate, to at least 75% of the total of the nominal values of all the shares of the members present and voting in person or by proxy, or of the members included in that class present and voting in person or by proxy, as the case may be; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>it is approved by order of the Court</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(6)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>The Court may grant its approval to a compromise or [an] arrangement subject to such alterations or conditions as it thinks just</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(10)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 An order of the Court made for the purposes of paragraph\u00a0(4)(b) does not have any effect until an office copy of the order is lodged with the Commission, and upon being so lodged \u2026 the order takes effect, or shall be deemed to have taken effect, on and from the date of lodgment or such earlier date as the Court determines and specifies in the order.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(17)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court must not approve a compromise or [an] arrangement under this section unless:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it is satisfied that the compromise or arrangement has not been proposed for the purpose of enabling any person to avoid the operation of any of the provisions of Chapter\u00a06 [which deals with takeovers]; or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 there is produced to the Court a statement in writing by the Commission stating that the Commission has no objection to the compromise or arrangement;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">but the Court need not approve a compromise or [an] arrangement merely because a statement by the Commission stating that the Commission has no objection to the compromise or arrangement has been produced to the Court as mentioned in paragraph\u00a0(b).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 From the provisions cited above, it can be seen that s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act uses the same introductory subsection\u00a0(1) as that used in the UK s\u00a0425. However, like the Australian s\u00a0411 (and contrary to the UK s\u00a0425), s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act uses the words \u201c<i>approved</i> by <i>order</i> of the Court\u201d [emphasis added] (see s\u00a0210(3) of the Companies Act and</span> s\u00a0411(4)(b) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act<span lang=\"EN-AU\">) instead of \u201c<i>sanctioned</i> by the court\u201d [emphasis added] (see s\u00a0425(2) of the 1985 UK Companies Act). Section\u00a0210 of the Companies Act also has a subsection (<i>ie</i>, s\u00a0210(4)) like subsection\u00a0(6) of the Australian s\u00a0411, which allows a court to grant its approval to a compromise or scheme of arrangement \u201csubject to such alterations or conditions as it thinks just\u201d. Such a provision is conspicuously missing from the body of the UK s\u00a0425. As will be elucidated later (at [64] below), the similarities between the wording of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act and that of the Australian s\u00a0411, coupled with the differences in wording between these two statutory provisions and the UK s\u00a0425, have indeed a rather profound impact on whether the English or the Australian approach should be adopted in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">3</span>7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having discussed the legislative history of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act as well as the corresponding provisions in the UK and Australia, we turn now to consider the purpose underpinning the enactment of s\u00a0210.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\"><em>Purpose</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The explanatory statement in the Companies Bill 1966 as well as the relevant parliamentary debates do not shed much light on the purpose behind the enactment of s\u00a0176 of the 1967 Act (the predecessor of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act). However, the purpose behind legislative provisions on schemes of arrangement has been extensively considered and clarified by the English and the Australian courts. In <i>Re Norfolk Island And Byron Bay Whaling Co Ltd</i> (1969) 90\u00a0WN\u00a0(Pt\u00a01) (NSW) 351, Street\u00a0J summarised the purpose behind the then equivalent of the Australian s\u00a0411 as follows (at 354):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The section is intended to provide machinery (i)\u00a0for overcoming the impossibility or impracticability of obtaining the individual consent of every member of the class intended to be bound thereby [ie, by the scheme of arrangement], and (ii)\u00a0for preventing, in appropriate circumstances, a minority of class members frustrating a beneficial scheme</i>. As Younger\u00a0J. said in 1917 [in <i>In re Guardian Assurance Company</i> [1917] 1\u00a0Ch 431 at 441] of the corresponding English section [<i>viz</i>, s\u00a0120 of the Companies (Consolidation) Act 1908 (c\u00a069) (UK)], in terms later quoted by Astbury\u00a0J. in <i>In re Anglo-Continental Supply Co. Ltd.</i> [[1922] 2\u00a0Ch 723]: \u201cIts purpose is strictly limited; it does not confer powers; its only effect at any time is to supply, by recourse to the procedure thereby prescribed, the absence of that individual agreement by every member of the class to be bound by the scheme which would otherwise be necessary to give it validity.\u201d [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Street\u00a0J\u2019s view has been endorsed by the learned authors of <i>Australian Corporation Law: Principles and Practice</i> (Butterworths, Looseleaf Ed, 1991) (\u201c<i>Australian Corporation Law</i>\u201d) at vol\u00a02, para\u00a05.1.0010 (May 2005 release), and has been cited with approval by this court in <i>Daewoo</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>) at [24]. The learned authors of <i>Palmer\u2019s Company Law</i> (Geoffrey Morse ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, Looseleaf Ed, 1992) (\u201c<i>Palmer</i>\u201d) have also expressed a similar view (at vol\u00a02, para\u00a012.009 (April 2007 release)) in respect of the UK s\u00a0425, as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The aid of the section may be invoked when it is not otherwise possible to make some arrangement or compromise which would be in the interests of [the] company and the other party or parties to the arrangement</i>. It can be used whether the company is a going concern or is in the course of winding up. \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The value of the section is even more clearly shown when creditors are concerned. Prima facie no creditor can be bound by the agreement of the company with the other creditors or by an agreement between the latter. <i>A compromise approved by a great majority of creditors may be rendered ineffective if a comparatively small creditor were to object and to stand out against it. It is one of the purposes of s.\u00a0425 to meet this situation</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A leading local commentary on companies law shares the same view as well (see <i>Walter Woon on Company Law</i> (Tan Cheng Han gen ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell Asia, 3rd\u00a0Ed, 2005) (\u201c<i>Walter Woon</i>\u201d) at para\u00a016.2):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Section\u00a0210 [of the Companies Act (Cap\u00a050, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed)] provides for schemes of arrangement to be binding on creditors and members alike after the requisite approval by the specified majority and upon confirmation by the court. <i>This section obviates the need for a messy and complicated series of negotiations with a view to obtaining the unanimous approval of the members or creditors to a novation or assignment or other variation of their rights</i>. A scheme of arrangement may be proposed where it is desired to adjust members\u2019 or creditors\u2019 rights <i>inter se</i>, or to reorganize the share capital of the company, or in the case of a group, \u2026 [with a view to] reconstruction or merger. In particular, recourse to s\u00a0210 is often made when it [is] desired to compromise creditors\u2019 claims against an insolvent company. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Bearing in mind the purpose of statutory provisions on schemes of arrangements as outlined in the preceding paragraphs, we turn now to consider some of the established principles in relation to such schemes.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Certain established principles relating to schemes of arrangement</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As mentioned earlier (at [20], [25] and [29] above), in adopting the English approach and arriving at the decision that a court had no jurisdiction to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt after the court had approved a scheme of arrangement, the Judge took into consideration, <i>inter alia</i>, some of the established principles in relation to schemes of arrangement (see the GD at [22]\u2013[25], [33]\u2013[36] and [38]\u2013[40]).
