As such, it would be appropriate to set out here (in a summary fashion) an overview of these principles before going on to consider in greater depth the question of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to grant an extension of time for a creditor to file its proof of debt in respect of a court-approved scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Firstly, it is clear that a scheme of arrangement will not bind a company, its members and its creditors until the court approves it (see s\u00a0210(3) of the Companies Act, s\u00a0425(2) of <span lang=\"EN-AU\">the 1985 UK Companies Act,</span> s\u00a0411(4)(b) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act and <i>Walter Woon</i> at para\u00a016.11). The sanction of the court is not a mere formality (see <i>Buckley on the Companies Acts</i> (Dame\u00a0Mary Arden, Dan Prentice &amp; Sir\u00a0Thomas Stockdale gen eds) (LexisNexis UK, 15th\u00a0Ed, 2007) (\u201c<i>Buckley</i>\u201d), vol\u00a02 at para\u00a0425.53; <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Kempe</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([21] <i>supra</i>) at 276; and <i>Re British Aviation Insurance Co Ltd</i> <nobr>[2006] 1 BCLC 665</nobr> at [69]).</span> Before the court sanctions a scheme, it will have to be satisfied of three matters (see <i>Palmer</i> ([39] <i>supra</i>), vol\u00a02 at paras\u00a012.026\u201312.030 (July 2006 release); <i>Buckley</i>, vol\u00a02 at para\u00a0425.53; <i>Butterworths\u2019 Annotated Statutes</i> ([33] <i>supra</i>) at p\u00a0591; <i>Walter Woon</i> at paras\u00a016.11\u201316.15; <i>Gore-Browne on Companies</i> (Alistair Alcock gen ed) (Jordans, 45th\u00a0Ed, 2005) (\u201c<i>Gore-Browne</i>\u201d), vol\u00a02 at para\u00a046.27 (December 2004 release); <i>Ford</i> ([34] <i>supra</i>), vol\u00a02 at para\u00a024.160 (June 2007 release); <i>Re Halley\u2019s Departmental Store Pte</i> Ltd <nobr>[1996] 2 SLR 70</nobr> at 73, [12]; <i>Daewoo</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>) at [36]; and <i>Wah Yuen Electrical Engineering Pte Ltd v Singapore Cables Manufacturers Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2003] 3 SLR 629</nobr> at [10]), namely:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court must be satisfied that the statutory provisions have been complied with. For example, the court must be satisfied that the resolution is passed by the requisite statutory majority at a meeting of the company\u2019s creditors or members (as the case may be) duly convened and held in accordance with the court order convening the meeting.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court must be satisfied that those who attended the meeting were fairly representative of the class of creditors or the class of members (where applicable), and that the statutory majority did not coerce the minority in order to promote interests adverse to those of the class whom the statutory majority purported to represent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court must be satisfied that the scheme is one which a man of business or an intelligent and honest man, being a member of the class concerned and acting in respect of his interest, would reasonably approve.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In respect of the last of the requirements just mentioned, the learned authors of <i>Palmer</i> provide a concise summary (at vol\u00a02, para\u00a012.030 (July 2006 release)) of how the court assesses whether the proposed scheme is one which an intelligent and honest member of the class concerned would reasonably approve:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">In exercising its discretion whether or not to sanction a scheme, the court traditionally, as we have seen, has stressed that <i>its function does not extend to usurping the view of the members or creditors.</i> \u2026 That approach has never meant, however, that, provided that the resolutions are duly passed, and that there is no coercion of a minority by a majority the court is bound to confirm the scheme and has no discretion. <i>The court is not a mere rubber stamp.</i> \u2026 <i>It will look at the scheme to see that it is a reasonable one: if it concludes that there is \u201csuch an objection to [the scheme] as that any reasonable man might say that he could not approve it\u201d</i> [<i>per</i> Lindley\u00a0LJ in <i>In re Alabama, New Orleans, Texas, and Pacific Junction Ry. Co.</i> [1891] 1\u00a0Ch 213 at 239]<i>, then the court may refuse to confirm the scheme</i>. The issue is often whether the scheme strikes a balance between the various interests involved which could be reasonably approved by the meetings. \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The court will, however, in cases where the minority object, be strongly influenced by a big majority vote, for, provided that the scheme is fair and equitable, the court will not itself judge upon the commercial merits [of the scheme], which is the function of the class itself. The court in such cases will be slo</i><i>w to differ from the conclusion of the majority</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">The discretion of the court as to whether or not it should sanction a scheme is important since, once the scheme has been sanctioned, it binds all parties, even the dissentients (see <i>Buckley</i>, vol\u00a02 at para\u00a0425.53). In addition, we would add that, in Singapore, the court has the discretion pursuant to s\u00a0210(4) of the Companies Act to grant its approval \u201csubject to such alterations or conditions as it thinks just\u201d (in Australia, a similar discretion exists under s\u00a0411(6) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act). This is a broad discretion that allows the court to modify a scheme, circumscribed only by what it deems just. One would imagine, however, that if the court proposes to make an amendment or a modification that would result in a substantive rather than, say, a procedural change, the court would in all likelihood refer the proposed change back to the scheme manager and the company\u2019s creditors or members for further consideration.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, once the court gives its approval to a scheme, the scheme is binding on all the parties to the scheme (see also [43] above), and the scheme <i>cannot</i> <i>afterwards be</i> <i>altered</i>, even if the shareholders and the creditors of the company acquiesce in the alteration (see <i>Palmer</i>, vol\u00a02 at para\u00a012.032 (December 2006 release); <i>Buckley</i>, vol\u00a02 at para\u00a0425.63; <i>Gore-Browne</i>, vol\u00a02 at para\u00a046.30 (June 2005 release); <i>Srimati Premila Devi v Peoples Bank of Northern India, Ltd</i> [1938] 4\u00a0All\u00a0ER 337 (\u201c<i>Devi</i>\u201d); <i>Eltraco International Pte Ltd v Sennet Electrical Engineering Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2003] SGHC 40</nobr> (\u201c<i>Eltraco</i>\u201d); and <i>Chew Eu Hock Construction Co Pte Ltd v Central Provident Fund Board</i> <nobr>[2003] 4 SLR 137</nobr> (\u201c<i>Chew Eu Hock</i>\u201d)). The binding nature of the court\u2019s sanction is so wide-reaching that if the court sanctions a scheme which is beyond the capacity of the company or in conflict with other statutory provisions, the scheme is nonetheless still binding on the parties, notwithstanding that it is <i>ultra vires</i> the objects of the company (see <i>British and Commonwealth Holdings\u00a0plc v Barclays Bank\u00a0plc</i> [1996] 1\u00a0All\u00a0ER 381 (\u201c<i>British and Commonwealth Holdings\u00a0plc</i>\u201d)). However, it should be noted that the effect of the <i>ultra vires</i> doctrine has been much diminished in Singapore because of ss\u00a023(1) and 25(1) of the Companies Act (see <i>Walter Woon</i> ([40] <i>supra</i>) at para\u00a03.76, as well as <i>Bee See &amp; Tay v Ong Hun Seang</i> <nobr>[1997] 2 SLR 193</nobr>, where this court held (at [61]) that \u201cs\u00a025 [of the Companies Act (Cap\u00a050, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed) was] so clear that there [was] no answer\u201d to the vendors\u2019 argument in that case that the company in question could not rely on its lack of capacity to take a transfer of property to invalidate the transfers).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nevertheless, the court retains an inherent jurisdiction to amend or set aside a scheme in limited circumstances, for instance, if consent to the scheme was obtained by fraud (<i>Fletcher v Royal Automobile Club Ltd</i> <nobr>[2000] 1 BCLC 331</nobr>) or where there are obvious mistakes in the documents setting out the scheme (<i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>) at 276). It is also possible for a subsisting scheme of arrangement to be amended by another scheme approved by the court (see <i>Re Elliott\u2019s MF Services Pty Ltd</i> <nobr>[1965] VR 756</nobr>; <i>Re Application of Gasweld Pty Ltd</i> (1986) 5\u00a0NSWLR 494; and <i>Re Challenger Group Holdings Ltd</i> (2003) 48\u00a0ACSR 498).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thirdly, in line with the first two principles stated above, a creditor or member \u201cshould raise his objections at the hearing for court sanction and not any later\u201d (see <i>Walter Woon</i> at para\u00a016.18; see also <i>Eltraco</i> and <i>Chew Eu Hock</i>). As explained in <i>Chew Eu Hock</i>, the rationale for this principle is that any late objections after a scheme of arrangement has been approved by the court would be \u201c<i>unfair</i>, <i>unreasonable</i> and <i>prejudicial</i>\u201d [emphasis added] (at [26]) to the other parties to the scheme, and (more importantly) there is a need to ensure that there is <i>certainty</i> as to the validity of a court-approved scheme:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A consideration which I took into account was the defendants\u2019 failure to attend the creditors\u2019 meeting and voice the objections which they now seek to raise in Ng\u2019s affidavit. As was rightly pointed out by counsel for the JM [judicial manager], the defendants raised their objections <i>far too late</i> (on 17\u00a0December 2002), well after the order sanctioning the scheme had been obtained and lodged with the Registry of Companies pursuant to s\u00a0210(5) of the Companies Act [Cap\u00a050, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed]. <i>To accept the defendants\u2019 objections at such a late stage would be unfair, unreasonable and prejudicial to the JM, the new investor (Hiap Hoe) of the Company and to other creditors</i> <i>alike.</i> \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the Australian decision of <i>Chief Commissioner of Pay-Roll Tax v Group Four Industries Pty Ltd</i> (1984) 8\u00a0ACLR 973 the plaintiff sought a declaration that he was not bound by the scheme of arrangement reached between the defendant company with certain of its creditors (and approved by the court under s\u00a0315(4)(b) of the Companies (NSW) Code), by virtue of his having statutory priority in a liquidation. McLelland\u00a0J at 976 refused the application and held that the Commissioner was bound as:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">otherwise, <i>despite approval by the court there could never be any certainty that a compromise or [an] arrangement was legally operative</i>, and it might remain open to collateral challenge indefinitely on grounds not susceptible to ready discovery or investigation.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Consequently, McLelland\u00a0J held that once the court made an order under s\u00a0315(4)(b) approving a compromise or [an] arrangement and an office copy had been lodged with the Commission pursuant to s\u00a0315(12), the compromise or arrangement was binding, notwithstanding any defect or irregularity that [might] have occurred in the steps leading up to the making of the order. The judge further endorsed the comments of Hart\u00a0J in <i>Frick Australia Pty Ltd v Pen Pak Ocean Products Pty Ltd</i> [1971] Qd\u00a0R\u00a0286 that</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201cthe public would never be safe in treating a scheme as valid and great inconvenience would result to companies, to creditors, to shareholders and to the community\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">if a court accepts the contention of a party that he is not bound by a scheme of arrangement approved by the court, on the ground that there had been no separate meeting of a distinct class of creditors to which he claimed to belong.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With these established principles in mind, we turn now to address the question of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt <i>after</i> the court has approved a scheme of arrangement. We will consider, first, the position under the Rules of Court. This will entail a review of the conflicting English and Australian approaches, as well as a consideration of the nature of schemes of arrangement.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Whether the court has jurisdiction under the Rules of Court to extend the time for filing proofs of debt</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>The English approach</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It appears that the question of extension of time in the context of court-approved schemes has, to date, not arisen squarely in England. However, the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>), which concerned an appeal from Bermuda, considered the question in relation to a scheme of arrangement which had been approved by the Bermudian court under a similar statutory framework, namely, s\u00a099 of Bermuda\u2019s Companies Act 1981 (which is <i>in</i> <i>pari materia</i> with the UK s\u00a0425). Clause\u00a02.3.1 of the scheme in <i>Kempe</i> imposed a 21-day time limit for a creditor to apply to the court to reverse or vary any assessment by the liquidators of its claims. One of the creditors (\u201cAmbassador\u201d)</span> filed a notice of claim, the bulk of which was rejected by the liquidators. As a result of an administrative lapse, Ambassador failed to file a summons challenging the liquidators\u2019 decision within 21 days. It then sought an order that the time limit be extended (although <i>Kempe</i> concerned an extension of time for a creditor to file an appeal against a rejection of its claim as opposed to an extension of time for a creditor to file its claim (or proof of debt), the same principles should apply in both scenarios). The Court of Appeal of Bermuda granted Ambassador the extension of time sought. On appeal by the liquidators, the Privy Council reversed the Bermudian Court of Appeal\u2019s decision. Lord\u00a0Hoffmann, delivering the judgment of the Privy Council, considered the nature of a scheme of arrangement before reaching the decision that a court had no jurisdiction to grant an extension of time. As the Judge\u2019s decision in the present case centred on the holding in <i>Kempe</i>, we reproduce below the relevant extracts from Lord\u00a0Hoffmann\u2019s judgment at 275\u2013276:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]he \u2026 question is whether it [the time limit laid down in cl\u00a02.3.1 of the scheme] has been \u201cfixed by any order of the court.\u201d On the answer to this question depends \u2026 whether [the court] has inherent jurisdiction to [extend time], \u2026 [which is] as Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0M.R. said in <i>Reg. v. Bloomsbury and Marylebone County Court, Ex parte Villerwest Ltd</i>. [1976] 1\u00a0W.L.R. 362, 365, a power \u201cto enlarge any time which a judge has ordered.\u201d Is the period of 21 days in clause\u00a02.3.1 a time which was ordered by the Chief Justice [of Bermuda] when he approved the scheme? In the [Bermudian] Court of Appeal, Kempster\u00a0J.A. thought that it was. He said that the clauses of the scheme would have been \u201cwithout effect\u201d but for the order of the Chief Justice giving the sanction of the court on 23\u00a0March 1993 and the subsequent delivery of that order to the registrar. Although the case was not cited to him, his view has the support of the decision of the Supreme Court of Western Australia in <i>Caratti v. Hillman</i> [1974] W.A.R.\u00a092. Jackson\u00a0C.J. said, at p.\u00a094, that the scheme was \u201can integral part of the court\u2019s order\u201d and Burt\u00a0J. said, at p.\u00a095, that \u201cthe rights [under the scheme] are ... in my opinion created by the order and the procedure whereby those rights are to be established or ascertained is a procedure which is also created by the order.\u201d Accordingly, the court could extend any period prescribed by the scheme under its power to extend periods fixed by its orders. The case has since been followed at first instance in Australia and in <i>Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. v. State of Western Australia (No.\u00a02)</i> (1992) 7\u00a0W.A.R.\u00a061, 68 Anderson\u00a0J. said its reasoning was that \u201conce the order is made, it is the order, \u2018speaking in terms of the scheme\u2019 [<i>per</i> Burt\u00a0J. in <i>Caratti v. Hillman</i> at p.\u00a095] that has effect, not the resolution of the creditors and not the statute.\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Their Lordships respectfully disagree</i>. It is true that the sanction of the court is necessary for the scheme to become binding and that it takes effect when the order expressing that sanction is delivered to the registrar. <i>But this is not enough to enable one to say that the court (rather than the liquidators who proposed the scheme or the creditors who agreed to it) has by its order made the scheme. It is rather like saying that because royal assent is required for an Act of Parliament, a statute is an expression of the royal will</i>. Under section\u00a099 [of the Bermudian Companies Act] it is for the liquidators to propose the scheme, for the creditors by the necessary majority to agree to it and for the court to sanction it. <i>It is the statute which gives binding force to the scheme when there has been a combination of these three acts, just as the rules of the constitution give validity to [A]cts duly passed by the Queen in Parliament</i>: see <i>In re Garner\u2019s Motors Ltd</i>. [1937] Ch.\u00a0594, 598\u2013599 and <i>Devi v. People\u2019s Bank of Northern India Ltd</i>. [1938] 4\u00a0All\u00a0E.R. 337, 343.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Having held that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the statute and not from the court order sanctioning the scheme, Lord\u00a0Hoffmann went on to hold (at 276) that it was not open to a court to extend the time limits laid down in a scheme as this would be a <i>material alteration</i> that would detract from certainty and expedition, which were the chief objects of any scheme:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">It is of course true that the sanction of the court is by no means a formality. Furthermore, in giving its sanction, the court has an inherent jurisdiction to correct any obvious mistakes in the document which sets out the scheme. <i>But it cannot alter the substance of the scheme and impose upon the creditors an arrangement to which they did not agree. The question of whether the time limits in the scheme are fixed or flexible is in their Lordship\u2019s opinion one of substance</i>. Mr.\u00a0Crystal [counsel for Ambassador] accepts that if there is jurisdiction to enlarge the period for filing an appeal against the rejection of a claim, there must also have been jurisdiction to extend the final filing deadline for filing the original claims. But their Lordships think that <i>this would have been a material alteration, detracting from the certainty and expedition which were the chief objects of the scheme. If creditors felt that in providing fixed time limits the scheme was creating traps into which the unwary might fall, the time to raise this question was when the scheme was under consideration or by way of objection when the court was asked to give its sanction</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It will be noted, from the first of the two passages cited at [48] above, that Lord\u00a0Hoffmann relied on the cases of</span> <i>In re Garner\u2019s Motors, Limited</i> [1937] Ch\u00a0594 (\u201c<i>Re Garner\u2019s Motors</i>\u201d) and <i>Devi</i> ([44] <i>supra</i>) in support of the holding that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the statute. In <i>Re Garner\u2019s Motors</i>, the question before the court was whether a scheme of arrangement entered into between a creditor and one of its joint and several debtors would discharge the liability of the other joint and several debtor. In answering the question in the negative, Crossman\u00a0J considered the effect of the court\u2019s sanction of a scheme of arrangement at 598\u2013599 (in a passage which was subsequently cited by Lord\u00a0Hoffmann in <i>Kempe</i> at 276), as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>In my judgment the effect of s.\u00a0153 of the Companies Act, 1929</i> [(c\u00a023) (UK)]<i>, is to give to a scheme when sanctioned by the Court under the section a statutory operation</i>. The scheme when sanctioned by the Court becomes something quite different from a mere agreement signed by the parties. <i>It becomes a statutory scheme</i>. In my judgment, therefore, the discharge of Sentinel Waggon Works, Ld. [the debtor which entered into the scheme of arrangement], from the debt to Temple Press, Ld. [the creditor], which was effected under clause\u00a015 of the scheme sanctioned by the Court on March\u00a023, 1936, did not have the effect of discharging Garner\u2019s Motors, Ld. [the other joint and several debtor of the creditor], from its liability in respect of the debt. It is settled law that a discharge of one of several judgment-debtors by operation of law does not release the other debtors. <i>But in my judgment the effect of s.\u00a0153 of the Companies Act, 1929, is to give a scheme when sanctioned by the Court a statutory operation</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Devi</i>, the directors of an Indian bank (\u201cthe bank\u201d) purported to forfeit the appellants\u2019 shares in the bank by reason of the appellants\u2019 non-payment upon the bank\u2019s calls on these shares. The calls on the shares had been made via a resolution that was passed in complete ignorance of the terms of an amended scheme of arrangement that had been approved by the court. The bank contended on appeal that the forfeitures had subsequently been ratified by the whole body of its creditors and shareholders. The Privy Council held that the forfeitures were <i>ultra vires</i> the bank as a court-approved scheme could not be amended or departed from by the mere acquiescence of the company\u2019s shareholders and creditors. The Privy Council held (<i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Romer) at 343, in a passage which was subsequently relied upon by Lord\u00a0Hoffmann in <i>Kempe</i> (at 276), as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Upon confirmation by the court of the amended scheme of arrangement, that scheme became, by virtue of sect.\u00a0153 of the Indian Companies Act, binding upon the creditors, the shareholders and the bank alike. Its terms could thereafter only be varied by order of the court after the variation had been approved at meetings of the creditors and shareholders</i>. It was not, therefore, possible for the bank or its directors or shareholders, whether by resolution or ratification or otherwise, to alter the dates fixed by cl.\u00a06 of the scheme for payment of the 20\u00a0per cent. called up in Mar., 1932, or the 5\u00a0per cent. called up on Jan.\u00a018, 1933. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In contrast to Crossman\u00a0J\u2019s judgment in <i>Re Garner\u2019s Motors</i> (see the passage quoted at [49] above), it would appear that the above passage in <i>Devi</i> does not quite support Lord\u00a0Hoffmann\u2019s holding in <i>Kempe</i> that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the statute, although it emphasises the corollary point that a court-approved scheme is binding on all parties to the scheme. <span lang=\"EN-AU\">However, we note that in an English work published before the decision of the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> (namely, David Brown, <i>Corporate Rescue: Insolvency Law in Practice</i> (John Wiley &amp; Sons, 1996)), the learned author cited (at para\u00a018.54) the two cases of <i>Re Garner\u2019s Motors</i> and <i>Devi</i> as authority for the proposition that the effect of the court\u2019s approval of a scheme of arrangement was as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The scheme, founded originally in contract, becomes statutory</i> and thus cannot be altered by contractual agreement, other than by a supplemental scheme sanctioned by the court. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As mentioned at [48] above, it appears that, to date, the question of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend the time for filing proofs of debt in respect of a court-approved scheme has not directly arisen for consideration in England whether before or after the Privy Council\u2019s decision in <i>Kempe</i>. <i>Kempe</i> has, however, been followed by the Hong Kong courts in two cases, <i>viz</i>,</span> <i>Re Universal Dockyard Ltd</i> <nobr>[2003] 3 HKEC 893</nobr> and <i>Re UDL Holdings Ltd</i> <nobr>[2006] 3 HKLRD 84</nobr><span lang=\"EN-AU\">. In both cases, the Hong Kong High Court simply unquestioningly accepted the holding in <i>Kempe</i> as correct, and no (or little) comments were made in relation to Lord\u00a0Hoffmann\u2019s judgment (see</span> <i>Re Universal Dockyard Ltd</i> at [20] and <i>Re UDL Holdings Ltd</i> at [58]<span lang=\"EN-AU\">).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Kempe</i> is also cited by the learned authors of <i>Buckley</i></span> ([43] <i>supra</i>) <span lang=\"EN-AU\">for the following proposition (at vol\u00a02, para\u00a0425.64):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">A scheme does not operate as an agreement between the parties affected but <i>it has binding force by virtue of statute</i> once an application to the court has been made and the consent of the relevant parties and the sanction of the court [have] been obtained. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><i>Kempe</i> is likewise cited by the learned authors of <i>Gore-Browne</i> ([43] <i>supra</i>) for a similar proposition (at vol\u00a02, para\u00a046.30 (June 2005 release)):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">It has been held that, although a scheme of arrangement requires the court\u2019s approval, it is not made solely by reason of the court\u2019s order. It comes into effect as a result of the application to the court by the appropriate persons, approval by the court and the court order. <i>It is not proper to say that it is solely the order that makes the scheme</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>The Australian approach</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Contrary to the approach taken by the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>), the Australian courts have consistently taken the position that once a scheme of arrangement is approved by the court, it becomes an order of court, <span lang=\"EN-AU\">and thus, the statutory provisions on civil procedure (the Rules of Court, in our local context) permit the court to grant an extension of time for, <i>inter alia</i>, a creditor to file its proof of debt.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A good starting point is the decision of the Supreme Court of Western Australia in <i>Caratti v Hillman</i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\"><nobr>[1974] WAR 92</nobr> (\u201c<i>Caratti</i>\u201d), which was rejected by the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> at 276 (see the first of the two passages from Lord\u00a0Hoffmann\u2019s judgment reproduced at [48] above)</span>. In <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Caratti</span></i>, cl\u00a09(e) of a court-approved scheme provided that any creditor whose claim was rejected by the scheme manager had 14 days to commence legal proceedings, failing which the creditor \u201cshall be forever barred from bringing any such proceedings\u201d. The scheme manager sent letters to three creditors informing them that their claims were not admitted, and these letters, together with the relevant documents, were subsequently forwarded by the creditors to their solicitors. The letters and documents were, unfortunately, mislaid in the solicitors\u2019 office, and by the time they were discovered, the 14-day time limit laid down in cl\u00a09(e) of the scheme for commencing legal proceedings had expired. On appeal to the Supreme Court of Western Australia, the lower court\u2019s refusal to grant the three creditors an extension of time to commence legal proceedings was reversed and an extension of time granted. Jackson\u00a0CJ held at 93\u201394:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026 I have reached the conclusion, in agreement with the other members of this court, that <i>we have power to extend the time under O.\u00a03, r.\u00a05 of the Supreme Court Rules</i> [the Western Australian equivalent of O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court] which are made applicable to proceedings under the Companies Act by r.\u00a04 of the Supreme Court (Companies) Rules 1963. \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>[I]n my view, the approved scheme is an integral part of the court\u2019s order [such] that the time fixed by cl.\u00a09(e) of the scheme is a period within which \u201ca person is \u2026 authorized\u201d by that order \u201cto do any act in any proceedings\u201d, to quote the words of O.\u00a03, r.\u00a05(1) of the Supreme Court Rules</i>. The \u201cproceedings\u201d for this purpose are those commenced on 15\u00a0November 1971, by the summons numbered 43 of 1971 [<i>ie</i>, the application by which the court\u2019s sanction of the scheme of arrangement was sought], under s.\u00a0181 of the [Companies] Act for an order convening a meeting of creditors, and those proceedings are not concluded, in my opinion, by the order approving the scheme, but remain on foot for the purpose of enabling the court to supervise the acts and decisions of the scheme manager under cl.\u00a018 of the scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Similarly, Burt\u00a0J stated at 94\u201395:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>In my opinion this Court has power to extend the time within which those proceedings can be brought</i> and \u2026 the effect of such an extension if granted is to defer the time at which \u201cthe claimant shall be forever barred \u2026\u201d [from bringing legal proceedings].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Order\u00a03, r.\u00a05 of the Rules of the Supreme Court is a rule which by r.\u00a04 of the Supreme Court (Companies) Rules 1963 applies to proceedings to which those rules relate and hence applies to proceedings being an application for an order that a compromise or [an] arrangement under s.\u00a0181 of the [Companies] Act be approved by the Court. \u2026 <i>If such an order is made, the scheme so approved being in the terms of this scheme, the release and discharge of the debts is effected not by the resolution of the creditors agreeing to the compromise but by the order and upon the order taking effect</i>: <i>Hill v. Anderson Meat Industries Ltd.,</i> [1971] 1\u00a0N.S.W.L.R. 868, at p.\u00a0877, per Street,\u00a0J. <i>And the rights which are given in substitution for the debts so released are likewise in my opinion created by the order and the procedure whereby those rights are to be established or ascertained is a procedure which is also created by the order</i>. <i>The order speaking in the terms of the scheme then can be seen to fix a period within which a scheme creditor is authorized to lodge his claims or, in the terms of O.\u00a03, r.\u00a05 the order fixes the period within which a person is \u201cauthorized \u2026 to do any act in any proceedings\u201d the relevant proceeding being a working out of the order, i.e., the scheme</i>. And if an order extending the time within which a claimant may take legal proceedings to establish his debt is made then, as it seems to me, the claim of the rejected claimant is not barred until that extended time has expired.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Caratti</i> was subsequently followed by the Supreme Court of New South Wales in <i>Re AGL Gas Networks Ltd</i> (2001) 37\u00a0ACSR 441 (\u201c<i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i>\u201d), where Santow\u00a0J elaborated further on the Australian approach and carefully explained why the approach in <i>Kempe</i> should not be followed. It would be helpful to set out here, in full, his reasons (see <i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i> at [46]\u2013[47]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">46 \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <b><i>In Australia, [the] authorities</i></b> [namely, <i>Hill v Anderson Meat Industries Ltd</i> <nobr>[1971] 1 NSWLR 868</nobr>, <i>Caratti</i> and <i>Bond Corp Holdings Ltd v Western Australia</i> (1992) 7\u00a0ACSR 472] <b><i>establish that an approved scheme does indeed derive its force from the court order, [and] not from the antecedent resolutions of members and creditors.</i></b> In this respect Street\u00a0J found (at 877) in <i>Hill v Anderson Meat Industries Ltd</i> in relation to a creditors [<i>sic</i>] scheme:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">\u201cThe approval by the court of the scheme amounts to a discharge of the debtor company\u2019s liability by operation of law. The discharge is effected by the court order and not by the events antecedent thereto, albeit that these antecedent events are indispensable statutory prerequisites of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to make an order approving a scheme and thus rendering it binding on the company and on the creditors.\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The effect of these cases is that, once approved, there is no \u201cscheme\u201d separate from the order of the court. Rather, any \u201cscheme\u201d in the sense of the proposal decided at the relevant meetings is subsumed into and by the order of the court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Re Matine Ltd</i> (1998) 28\u00a0ACSR 268, the above authorities were considered by me and their apparent conflict with the Privy Council decision in <i>Kempe</i> \u2026 noted. While it was unnecessary for me to decide that issue for the purpose of that case, I did indicate a tentative view that I would prefer to follow the Australian cases were it necessary.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Unless satisfied that the Australian decisions to which I have referred are plainly wrong, I should, especially in national legislation, follow them as a matter of comity: <i>Australian Securities Commission v Marlborough Gold Mines Ltd</i> (1993) 177\u00a0CLR 485; 112\u00a0ALR 627.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <b><i>With respect, I do not find the reasoning in Kempe\u2019s case compels me to a different conclusion. Their Lordships proceed[ed] on the assumption that a scheme does not derive its efficacy from the order of a court. Rather a scheme is given binding force by a statute which operates on a number of ingredients</i></b> (in the case of a scheme, a scheme put forward by the scheme proponent, the necessary majorities of members or creditors and the sanction of the court). <b><i>Taken to its logical conclusion, that reasoning would produce incongruous consequences. Take, for example, the jurisdiction of a court which is conferred by statute. The fact that the jurisdiction is conferred by statute does not make any decisions of the court under the statutory jurisdiction any less orders of the court deriving their efficacy from being made</i></b>. The statute may be an indispensable statutory prerequisite to the [court\u2019s] jurisdiction. But it is, in causative terms, a \u201cbackground\u201d fact behind that efficacy, part of the \u201cres inter alios acta\u201d. It is like saying that the birth of Lee Harvey Oswald \u201ccaused\u201d the death of President Kennedy.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The fact that their Lordships [in <i>Kempe</i>] were proceeding from what may be <b><i>attackable reasoning</i></b> does not necessarily mean that their conclusion is wrong. <b><i>However, an analysis of the facts of Kempe\u2019s case indicate[s] that the reasoning is indeed vulnerable</i></b>. The scheme considered in <i>Kempe\u2019s</i> case allowed a dissatisfied scheme creditor to apply to the court for an order reversing or varying certain decisions of <i>the</i> <i>liquidators</i>. Their Lordships proceeded on the basis that there was nothing untoward in this. <b><i>However, their Lordships [did] not indicate where the court obtains jurisdiction to exercise the functions conferred. If schemes generally operate as an order of the court, jurisdiction is inherent. On the other hand, if schemes only operate by virtue of the relevant statute then the court would have no jurisdiction as the statute only refers to a compromise or [an] arrangement between a company and its creditors (or between a company and its members)</i></b>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Once one accepts that the scheme operates by virtue of the court order, then it is clear that the failure [of the plaintiff company in <i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i>] to obtain the approval within time was a failure to comply with a time specified in a court order.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, I am satisfied that it is open for me to exercise my discretion pursuant to Pt\u00a02 r\u00a03 [of the] Supreme Court Rules [the New South Wales equivalent of O\u00a03 r\u00a04(1) of the Rules of Court] and amend order\u00a01 of the orders made on 6\u00a0June 1994 so as to allow the plaintiff until 10 minutes after midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994 to satisfy the conditions precedent to the scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <b><i>In making any such order, it was submitted that I would not be amending the scheme as such as it would not involve a change to any substantive provision of the scheme</i></b>. Rather I would be extending the time in which an act required to be done under the <i>order</i> can be done, that order embodying the scheme and itself intrinsically capable of variation. While that conclusion is not beyond doubt, I am prepared to adopt it in making the various orders as I have done. In particular I do not consider the earlier cited Australian cases \u201cplainly wrong\u201d and will follow them as the basis for these orders, in preference to <i>Kempe</i>. It may be that at some future time, and with an effective contradictor, their reasoning may need to be further tested either at trial or appellate level.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added in bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 More recently,</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Caratti</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">was followed in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Ray Brooks Pty Ltd v New South Wales Grains Board (No\u00a02)</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">(2002) 43\u00a0ACSR 657 (\u201c<i>Ray Brooks Pty Ltd</i>\u201d). However, as rightly pointed out by Mr\u00a0Ashok Kumar, counsel for Reliance, it appears that Austin\u00a0J in the latter case preferred the approach in <i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>), but followed <i>Caratti</i> as a matter of precedent. This can be seen from the following passage in <i>Ray Brooks Pty Ltd</i> (at [88]\u2013[90]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The issue was addressed, admittedly in a different context, in <i>Caratti v Hillman</i> <nobr>[1974] WAR 92</nobr>; (1973) 4\u00a0ACLR 170. <i>In that case the Full Court of the Supreme Court of Western Australia took the view that the procedure leading to the extinguishment of rights of creditors under a scheme of arrangement under companies legislation was a procedure created by order of the court</i>. The order approving the scheme of arrangement fixed the period within which a creditor was authorised to lodge a claim under the scheme. <i>Therefore the order of the court approving the scheme was an order fixing the period within which a person was authorised to do an act, for the purposes of the rule of court comparable with Pt\u00a04, r\u00a04</i> [of the Supreme Court Rules (NSW), which is <i>in pari materia</i> with O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court]<i>. Consequently the rule of court was available to permit the court to extend the period for lodgment of claims by creditors</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">That reasoning has been accepted by later Australian cases on several occasions: <i>Re Terri Co Pty Ltd</i> (1987) 12\u00a0ACLR 457; <i>Bond Corp Holdings Ltd v Western Australia (No\u00a02)</i> (1992) 7\u00a0WAR 61; 7\u00a0ACSR 472; <i>Re Matine Ltd</i> (1998) 28\u00a0ACSR 268. However, it is inconsistent with the reasoning of the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The reasoning of Lord\u00a0Hoffmann [in Kempe] is highly persuasive. However, the approach taken in Caratti was the approach of an intermediate appellate court in Australia. According to the High Court in Australian Securities Commission v Marlborough Gold Mines Ltd (1993) 177\u00a0CLR 485; 112\u00a0ALR 627; 10\u00a0ACSR 230, a judge at first instance in this country should not depart from the interpretation of companies legislation adopted by an Australian intermediate appellate court</i>. Moreover, the <i>Caratti</i> decision has stood since 1973 and has been followed, as I have said, on several occasions. I note, in particular, that although Santow\u00a0J found it unnecessary to choose between <i>Caratti</i> and <i>Kempe</i> in <i>Re Matine</i>, he expressed the view (at 286) that he would follow the Australian cases were [it] necessary to do so. <i>As a matter of precedent, therefore, I shall follow the reasoning in Caratti in preference to the reasoning in Kempe</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also note with some interest that an approach not unlike that taken in <i>Carrati</i> was adopted by the Bermudian Court of Appeal in <i>Ambassador Insurance Company v Charles W\u00a0Kempe and Nigel Hamilton</i> Civil Appeal No\u00a013 of 1995 (14\u00a0March 1996) (unreported) (whose decision was, however, reversed in <i>Kempe</i> on further appeal to the Privy Council), where it was held that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the court order sanctioning that scheme:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Though the Scheme makes no provision for extension of [the] time [period] within which to appeal against the rejection of a claim in the liquidation <i>its clauses would be without effect but for the delivery to the Registrar of the Order of the Chief Justice made on 23\u00a0March 1993</i> [<i>ie</i>, the court order sanctioning the scheme] as subsection\u00a0(3) of section\u00a099 of the [Bermudian Companies] Act makes clear. \u2026 Section\u00a0157 of the Companies Winding-up Rules, which is applicable under clause\u00a08.1.1 [of the scheme of arrangement] and allows the Court to extend \u201cthe time \u2026 fixed by <i>any order of the Court</i> for doing any act\u201d, may therefore be invoked by Ambassador \u2026 to extend any time limits which a judge has ordered whether or not a creditor\u2019s rights have notionally been extinguished. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Which approach should prevail in Singapore?</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before giving our reasons as to why we preferred the Australian approach, we first need to address Reliance\u2019s submission (see [26] above) that \u201c[t]he Singapore Court of Appeal ha[d] <i>affirmed</i> that a scheme of arrangement [was] a <i>statutory contract</i> entered into between the company and scheme creditors\u201d<a id=\"_ftnref6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn6\" name=\"_ftnref6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 6]</span></span></a> [emphasis added] in <i>Daewoo</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>). If Reliance\u2019s submission is correct, it would mean that the question of the nature of a scheme of arrangement (and the related question of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt where the court has already approved the scheme) has already been decided in Singapore. The passage relied on by Reliance for its submission is to be found at [24] of <i>Daewoo</i> (<i>per</i> Yong Pung How\u00a0CJ):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">It is trite law that, where a scheme of arrangement or compromise \u2026 is approved by <i>all</i> the creditors of the company, it is binding on the company as well as its creditors. In such a case, there is no need on the part of the company to invoke s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act [Cap\u00a050, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed]. <i>The scheme is wholly a contractual scheme</i>. Where, as is usually the case, it is not practical or practicable to secure the unanimous agreement of all the creditors, s\u00a0210 is invoked. And when s\u00a0210 is invoked, and the scheme is approved by the requisite majority of the creditors and the court, the scheme becomes binding on all the creditors or the class of creditors (as the case may be). That is provided in s\u00a0210(3) of the Act. <b><i>The binding effect of the scheme is given by the court order approving the scheme</i></b>. As Street\u00a0J said in <i>Re Norfolk Island and Byron Bay Whaling Co</i> (1969) 90\u00a0WN\u00a0(Pt\u00a01) (NSW) 351 at 354 with reference to s\u00a0181 of the Companies Act 1961 of the State of New South Wales (which is the equivalent of our s\u00a0210), the section is intended to provide a machinery (1)\u00a0for overcoming the impossibility or impracticability of obtaining the individual consent of every member of the class intended to be bound thereby, and (2)\u00a0for preventing, in appropriate circumstances, a minority of class members [from] frustrating a beneficial scheme. [emphasis added in italics and bold italics]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we do not see how the above passage could even begin to remotely support Reliance\u2019s submission. If anything, Yong\u00a0CJ went only as far as to say that a scheme of arrangement, when approved by all the creditors of the company, was a \u201ccontractual scheme\u201d (<i>Daewoo</i> at [24]); he did not describe such a scheme as, to use Reliance\u2019s words, a \u201cstatutory contract\u201d. In fact, the words in bold italics in the quotation from <i>Daewoo</i> (at [58] above) would appear to support the <i>Australian</i> position that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the <i>court order</i> approving that scheme. We note that the Judge, in arriving at her decision that the English approach was more persuasive, appeared to have found some penumbral encouragement in Yong\u00a0CJ\u2019s comments in <i>Daewoo</i> (see the GD at [30]), but she certainly did not go as far as to say that <i>Daewoo</i> <i>decided</i> that a scheme of arrangement was in the nature of a statutory contract. If the Judge had regarded <i>Daewoo</i> as laying down such a legal principle, there would have been no need for her to elaborate (at length) on her reasons for adopting the English approach. As such, we rejected Reliance\u2019s submission on what this court held in <i>Daewoo vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the nature of a scheme of arrangement.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note, however, that in <i>Eltraco</i> ([44] <i>supra</i>), a High Court decision concerning the scope and the operation of a scheme of arrangement, MPH\u00a0Rubin\u00a0J held at [23] that the effect of a court-approved scheme was as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The effects of a court-sanctioned scheme of arrangement came up for discussion in New South Wales in <i>Hill v Anderson Meat Industries Ltd</i> <nobr>[1971] 1 NSWLR 868</nobr> as well as before the Singapore Court of Appeal in <i>Daewoo</i> ... <i>Both Street\u00a0J in Hill v Anderson and Yong Pung How\u00a0CJ in Daewoo reaffirmed the view that a scheme of arrangement duly passed and sanctioned by the court inherited a <b>statutory effect</b> upon the relationship between the debtor company and its creditors</i>. <span lang=\"EN-AU\">[emphasis added in italics and bold italics]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">The above passage may plausibly be read as suggesting that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the statute (which is the English position). However, as clarified at [59] above, the decision in <i>Daewoo</i> certainly does not stand for this proposition. As for the New South Wales case of <i>Hill v Anderson Meat Industries Ltd</i> <nobr>[1971] 1 NSWLR 868</nobr>, that case was, in fact, relied on by Burt\u00a0J in <i>Caratti</i> ([54] <i>supra</i>) at 95 and by Santow\u00a0J in <i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i> ([55] <i>supra</i>) at [46] for the contrary (Australian) position that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the court order approving the scheme. One should, therefore, be slow to read <i>Eltraco</i> as <i>correctly</i> supporting the proposition (and also the English position) that a scheme of arrangement derives its efficacy from the statute and operates as a statutory contract.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We noted earlier (at [25] above) that the Judge justified her preference for the English approach on the basis that the purpose of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act, the established principles relating to schemes of arrangement and the overarching need for clarity, certainty and finality in this area of the law cumulatively supported the position in <i>Kempe</i> ([21] <i>supra</i>). Nevertheless, we are of the view that the Australian approach is also consistent with these established principles. Adopting the Australian approach does not necessarily mean that clarity, certainty and finality would be sacrificed on the altar of expediency or that the objectives of s\u00a0210 can no longer be properly achieved. Between the English and the Australian approaches, we are not entirely comfortable with the former approach, which, with respect, appears to be unnecessarily strict and mechanical, leading perhaps to potentially unjust consequences in some instances. We now elaborate on the reasons for our decision.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The English approach will invariably mean that once the court has approved a scheme of arrangement, it no longer has jurisdiction to grant an extension of time for a creditor to file its proof of debts in respect of that scheme <i>regardless</i> of the circumstances, save in cases of \u201c<i>obvious mistakes</i> in the document which sets out the scheme\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>Kempe</i> at 276 (see the second of the two passages reproduced at [48] above)) or where consent to the scheme was obtained by fraud (see the GD at [38], citing <i>Fletcher v Royal Automobile Club Ltd</i> ([45] <i>supra</i>)). This seems intuitively restrictive as it is not difficult to envisage a situation, such as that in <i>Caratti</i> ([54] <i>supra</i>) or in the other Australian cases cited at [55]\u2013[56] above (we will elaborate on the factual matrices of those cases below at [71]\u2013[78]), where the failure to file a claim in time is not in any way attributable to the fault of the creditor and where allowing the creditor an extension of time to file its claim does not prejudice any of the parties, and yet (under the English approach), an extension of time cannot be granted because there is no obvious mistake in the documents setting out the scheme or no fraud. Perhaps, on the facts of <i>Kempe</i>, the Privy Council\u2019s decision can arguably be said not to be unduly harsh or unfair, given that the Privy Council had found, as a <i>fact</i>, that it was a \u201c<i>principal feature</i>\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>id</i> at 273) of the scheme in question to impose a strict deadline for filing claims, after which creditors would be altogether barred from participating in the liquidation. (By logical implication, that feature of the scheme in <i>Kempe</i> would entail that the deadline for a creditor to apply to court to challenge the liquidators\u2019 decision in respect of its claim likewise had to be strictly observed.) However, the same cannot be said for all other schemes of arrangement without such a feature. We would reiterate here that, as a general principle, the court should be slow to abdicate the powers conferred on it by s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> schemes of arrangement, especially when doing so would allow an injustice to stand.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Santow\u00a0J in <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([55] <i>supra</i>)</span> pointed out at [46] that <i>Kempe</i> proceeded on \u201cattackable reasoning\u201d which was \u201cvulnerable\u201d (see the passage quoted at [55] above). Referring to the assumption that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the statute and not from the court order sanctioning it, Santow\u00a0J persuasively argued that if this approach was taken to its logical conclusion, it would produce \u201cincongruous consequences\u201d (<i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i> at [46]). He drew an analogy with the court\u2019s statutorily-conferred jurisdiction to illustrate his argument, pointing out that \u201c[t]he fact that the [court\u2019s] jurisdiction is conferred by statute does not make any decisions of the court under the statutory jurisdiction any less orders of the court deriving their efficacy from being made\u201d (<i>ibid</i>). According to Santow\u00a0J, the statute might be an indispensable statutory prerequisite to the existence of the court\u2019s jurisdiction, but it was nonetheless \u201ca \u2018background\u2019 fact\u201d (<i>ibid</i>) behind that efficacy, and to say that it was the statute which gave a court order its binding authority \u201c[was] like saying that the birth of Lee Harvey Oswald \u2018caused\u2019 the death of President\u00a0Kennedy\u201d (<i>ibid</i>). While we see the merit in Santow J\u2019s analogy in <i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i>, the same cannot be said about the analogy of royal assent given by the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> to support its holding that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the statute. The Privy Council had (at 276 (see the first of the two passages quoted at [48] above)) likened the court\u2019s sanction of schemes of arrangement to royal assent to Acts of the UK parliament; the fact that royal assent was required for an Act did not make the statute an expression of royal will and, likewise, the same reasoning applied to the court\u2019s sanction of schemes of arrangement. We note that this analogy is apt only if the court\u2019s sanction of a scheme is regarded as a <i>mere formality</i> like the royal assent required for UK Acts. However, as we have seen (at [43] above), cases (including English ones) have established that the court\u2019s sanction is not just a formality and that the court, in fact, has a crucial role to play in deciding whether a scheme is to be approved. Further, under the Singapore and the Australian provisions governing schemes of arrangement, the court has the expressly-defined power to impose such conditions on or make such amendments to the terms of a scheme as it deems fit before approving any scheme (see s\u00a0210(4) of the Companies Act (reproduced at [31] above) and s\u00a0411(6) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (reproduced at [35] above); the significance of these provisions will be dealt with in greater detail shortly). In the light of this, we do not see how (at least in Singapore and Australia) the court\u2019s sanction of schemes of arrangement can be approximated to royal assent to Acts of the UK parliament. Another flaw in the reasoning in <i>Kempe</i> is exposed by the facts of the case itself. This was astutely pointed out by Santow\u00a0J in <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">at [46] (see the passage quoted at [55]</span> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">above), where he noted</span> that the scheme in <i>Kempe</i> allowed a dissatisfied scheme creditor to apply to the court in respect of certain decisions made by the liquidators, and their Lordships had proceeded on the basis that there was nothing untoward in this. However, if indeed a court loses all jurisdiction in respect of a scheme of arrangement once it has sanctioned the scheme (save for its inherent jurisdiction to intervene in cases of fraud or obvious mistakes in the documents setting out the scheme), this begs the question of where the court obtains the necessary jurisdiction to exercise the appellate function conferred by the scheme in <i>Kempe</i>. We agree with Santow\u00a0J that if a scheme of arrangement operates as an order of court instead of as a statutory contract, no such difficulty arises since the jurisdiction of the court to vary an order which it made earlier would continue.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Crucially, the approach adopted in <i>Kempe</i> does not comport with the plain <i>wording</i> of the relevant UK, Australian and Singapore provisions on schemes of arrangement, all of which stipulate that a scheme becomes <i>binding</i> only \u201c<i>if sanctioned by the court</i>\u201d (s\u00a0425(2) of the 1985 UK Companies Act (see [35] above)) or if it is \u201c<i>approved by order of the Court</i>\u201d (s\u00a0411(4) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (see [35] above) and s\u00a0210(3) of the Companies Act (see [31]) above)). The plain wording of these subsections would suggest that the efficacy of a scheme (or, at least, its binding nature, which is the key to the ability of a scheme of arrangement to fulfil its intended function of serving as machinery to overcome the impossibility of obtaining the individual consent of every creditor or member to a proposed scheme) stems from the court order which sanctions or approves it. This is <i>all the more so</i> under the Australian and the Singapore provisions, which use the specific words \u201c<i>order</i> of the Court\u201d. Further, under the Australian and the Singapore provisions, there are specific subsections (namely, s\u00a0411(6) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (see [35] above) and s\u00a0210(4) of the Companies Act (see [31] above)) that stipulate that the court \u201cmay grant its approval to a compromise or [an] arrangement <i>subject to such alterations or conditions as it thinks just</i>\u201d [emphasis added]. We accept that these provisions only allow a court to substantially amend the terms of a scheme <i>before</i> the court\u2019s approval of the scheme is given and, contrary to what counsel for Oriental contended, do not go as far as to allow the court to amend the terms of a scheme <i>after</i> approving the scheme. As seen earlier (at [44] above), it is an established principle that the terms of a scheme cannot be substantially amended (save in exceptional circumstances) after it has been approved by the court. However, these provisions do nonetheless somewhat reinforce the view that under the Australian and the Singapore companies legislation, the courts are allowed a more active participatory role in respect of schemes of arrangement as compared to the position under the UK\u2019s companies legislation, given that there is no equivalent of s\u00a0210(4) of the Companies Act or s\u00a0411(6) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act in the 1985 UK Companies Act. It would seem incongruous that the court has such wide powers to amend the terms of a scheme before giving its approval to the scheme, but promptly loses all jurisdiction after it approves the scheme. A more tenable view would be that a scheme, when approved by the court, takes effect as an order of court and, like any other court order, can be varied, but only in deserving circumstances (which we will elaborate on at [70]\u2013[82] below).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, we note that the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> considered the amendment of time limits laid down in a scheme of arrangement to be one of <i>substance</i> and, thus, a \u201cmaterial alteration\u201d (<i>id</i> at 276). Accordingly, the Privy Council dismissed Ambassador\u2019s application for an extension of time. As emphasised at [44] above, it is an established principle that a scheme cannot be altered after the court\u2019s sanction has been given to it so as to impose upon the creditors or the members an arrangement to which they did not agree. With respect, however, it is doubtful, to say the least, whether an extension of time to file a proof of debt (or to commence legal proceedings in respect of the liquidator\u2019s decision on a proof of debt, as in the case of <i>Kempe</i>) should be treated, in the first place, as a material alteration or amendment of the substance of a court-approved scheme. It also appears to us that the Privy Council in <i>Kempe</i> did not consider this point carefully, but merely accepted it as a valid assumption (<i>id</i> at 276). In contrast to the cases cited at [44] above (namely, <i>Devi</i>, <i>British and Commonwealth Holdings plc</i>, <i>Eltraco</i> and <i>Chew Eu Hock</i>, all of which support the above-mentioned established principle), where the creditors in question (or, on the facts of <i>Devi</i>, the directors of the debtor company) sought to amend or object to the substantive terms of a court-approved scheme such that they were, in fact, trying to <i>resile</i> from the original scheme which had been agreed to by the requisite majority of supporting creditors and sanctioned by the court, the applicant in an extension of time case (such as Oriental in the present appeal) is usually not trying to substantially amend or resile from the scheme that it has entered into. <i>In fact, the applicant in such a scenario usually wholeheartedly supports the court-approved scheme and wants to take part in it, and the purpose of seeking an extension of a time limit laid down in the scheme is precisely for the purpose of participating in the scheme</i>. It appears that the significance of this distinction was also, at least partially, appreciated by the Judge in the proceedings below when she noted (at [37] of the GD):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">While <i>the applicant in the present case [ie, Oriental] did not seek to amend the scheme</i>, in my view, the principles governing this issue are important as they form another part of the framework in which the issue should be analysed. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">A better view, perhaps, is to treat an extension of time in respect of a court-approved scheme simply as a matter of <i>procedure</i>, rather than as a matter going to the substance or materiality of the commercial dimension of the scheme (an amendment of the latter nature would entail seeking the views of all the parties bound by the scheme). We note that Santow\u00a0J himself in <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([55] <i>supra</i>)</span> accepted (at [47]) the submission that in making an order to extend the time for the plaintiff company in that case to comply with a particular condition stipulated in a court-approved scheme, \u201c[the court] would not be amending the scheme as such as it [<i>ie</i>, the extension of time] would not involve a change to any <i>substantive</i> provision of the scheme\u201d [emphasis added]. If the view that an extension of time is usually a matter of procedure is accepted, then the grant of an extension of time will not be seen as detracting from the established principle that a court-approved scheme should not be altered in substance. An application for an extension of time after the court has approved a scheme should then likewise not be viewed as being tantamount to raising a late objection to the scheme that will jeopardise the certainty of the scheme\u2019s validity (see, in this regard, [46] above).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Viewed in this light, the Australian approach is in no way inconsistent with the established principles relating to schemes of arrangement, and also gives due consideration to the overarching need for clarity, certainty and finality in this area of the law (a point made briefly earlier at [61] above). We would also add, in respect of the latter concern, that a court order is in no way less binding than a statutory contract on the parties to a scheme of arrangement, and it is trite law as well as common sense that a court order cannot be altered at will by the parties who are subject to the order. As such, it is hard to see, with due respect, why there would invariably be less commercial certainty if the Australian approach is adopted: Any court order, once finalised, can only be amended in very limited circumstances, and any application to amend a court order would be subject to due process. It follows from the binding nature of a court order that the Australian approach can also achieve the legislative intent that schemes of arrangement should function as machinery to overcome the impossibility of attaining absolute consensus from all the company\u2019s creditors or members on a proposed scheme and to bind minority dissentients to the scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There is also no reason why the Australian approach cannot embrace the legal concept that a <span lang=\"EN-AU\">scheme of arrangement which is approved by <i>all</i> the creditors of a company</span> \u201c<span lang=\"EN-AU\">is wholly a <i>contractual</i> scheme</span>\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>Daewoo</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>) at [24]); the court order sanctioning such a scheme (<i>ie</i>, a scheme which is approved by all of the company\u2019s creditors) can be seen, in essence, as a <i>consensual order</i>. Viewed in this light, the sanctity of contract which lies at the heart of a scheme that has been duly approved by the company\u2019s creditors or members is preserved.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further, the Australian approach will have the added advantages of:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 avoiding a strained construction of the plain wording of s\u00a0210(3) of the Companies Act, which, as demonstrated above at [64], suggests that a scheme of arrangement is made binding only upon its approval by the court; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 avoiding the unfairness or injustice which may potentially be caused to an innocent creditor who is not to be blamed for its failure to file its proof of debt in time.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">69\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note that the Judge did not take the view that the Australian approach was wrong; rather, she decided that \u201cthe English position [was] more persuasive\u201d (see the GD at [32]). The question of whether the court has jurisdiction to extend time in respect of a court-approved scheme is essentially a question of discretion, and invariably requires a judge to take a considered view on what best accords with the need for commercial certainty and fairness in this area of the law. The Judge was unduly concerned with the overarching need for clarity, certainty and finality (all of which are crucial to the efficacious implementation of schemes of arrangement), and thus mistakenly concluded that anything less than the strict English approach would be undesirable. However, as we have shown, there are real practical conundrums with the strict English approach, and the reasoning in <i>Kempe</i> is, with respect, sharply flawed. On the other hand, adopting the Australian approach does not necessarily entail sacrificing clarity, certainty and finality. In fact, the Australian approach mitigates some of the injustice that may potentially result under the English approach. It also gives due consideration to the established principles relating to schemes of arrangement while meeting, at the same time, the objectives of the legislative framework governing such schemes. We have therefore adopted the Australian approach as according with both the underlying policy and the objectives of s\u00a0210 of the Companies Act.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Circumstances where the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend time will be exercised</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">70\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having adopted the Australian approach, it would be helpful to provide some guidelines as to when the court should exercise its jurisdiction in favour of extending the time for a creditor to file its proof of debt (or extending other time limits prescribed in a scheme of arrangement) in respect of a court-approved scheme. Before doing so, it would be helpful to examine the factual matrices of the Australian cases in which such extensions of time have been granted.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>(1)\u00a0The Australian cases</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">71\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We begin first with the case of <i>Caratti</i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([54] <i>supra</i>). As mentioned earlier (at [54] above),</span> in <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Caratti</span></i>, three creditors under a court-approved scheme filed their claims in time, but failed to commence proceedings for a review of the scheme manager\u2019s decision to reject their claims (\u201creview proceedings\u201d) within 14 days of the notice of rejection as stipulated in the scheme. It transpired that the scheme manager had sent letters to those creditors informing them that their claims had not been admitted, and the letters, together with the relevant documents, had been forwarded by the creditors to their solicitors. <i>The letters and the documents were, unfortunately, mislaid in the office of the creditors\u2019 solicitors</i>, and by the time they were discovered, the 14-day time period for commencing review proceedings had expired.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">72\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As noted by Wallace\u00a0J at 96, the creditors\u2019 failure to commence review proceedings in time was due to an \u201caccident\u201d. Given those circumstances, the Supreme Court of Western Australia reversed the decision of Wickham\u00a0J in the court below and granted the three creditors an extension of time to commence review proceedings. Besides the fact that the creditors themselves were not to be blamed for failing to commence review proceedings in time, (more importantly) the court took into consideration the fact that no prejudice would be suffered by any party bound by the scheme if an extension of time was granted, <i>given that no distribution had been made yet under the scheme</i>. In fact, a refusal to grant an extension would have disadvantaged the three creditors. As Burt\u00a0J explained at 95:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>If, as I think is the case, there is power to extend the time, then a sound exercise of the discretion on the facts of this case requires that it be exercised</i>. It may be that in some cases the extension would be granted on terms, i.e., that if the debt be established, the claimant is to be excluded from any distribution made before that date. <i>In the present case however no distribution has been made and on the merits of the case the scheme manager does not oppose the making of an unconditional order. To refuse to make such an order might have the effect of a creditor\u2019s debt being released with no compensating advantage. This is not the idea of the scheme, or as Brightman,\u00a0J., put it in Re NFU Development Trust, [1972] 1\u00a0W.L.R. 1548, at p.\u00a01555; [1973] 1\u00a0All\u00a0E.R. 135: \u201cConfiscation is not my idea of an arrangement.\u201d</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">73\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second case, <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([55] <i>supra</i>), concerned a scheme of amalgamation and reconstruction of a gas company (\u201cAGL\u201d) and its related companies. The scheme was perceived to have numerous advantages such as eliminating the duplication of record-keeping, accounting and maintenance procedures and bringing about greater flexibility and potential for improved growth for the whole organisation. The scheme was approved by an order of court made on 6\u00a0June 1994, and other related orders were also made at the same time to provide for the</span> transfer of all the properties, powers and liabilities of the subsidiary companies to their parent company. The relevant orders (other than the order approving the scheme) were all subjected to certain conditions precedent stipulated in the scheme. Six years after the orders were made (and the scheme effected), it was discovered that the scheme had never become operative as one of the conditions precedent, <i>viz</i>, the amendment of AGL\u2019s then existing authorisation under the Gas Industry Restructuring Act 1986 (NSW) (\u201cthe NSW Gas Act\u201d) before midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994, had never been fulfilled (AGL had received notification of its amended authorisation a few seconds after midnight on 1\u00a0July 1994). In the words of Santow\u00a0J (at [2]), \u201c[t]he non-fulfilment [of the condition precedent] was <i>technical in the extreme</i> and <i>entirely accidental</i>\u201d [emphasis added].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">74\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In fact, Santow\u00a0J found that it would have been <i>impossible</i> in the first place for that condition precedent (<i>ie</i>, the amendment of AGL\u2019s then existing authorisation under the NSW Gas Act before midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994) to be fulfilled. He explained (at [5]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]he formulation of that condition and in consequence the 1994 court orders, was inherently circular in its terms. <i>Thus fulfilment of the scheme condition depended on the scheme transfer of assets while the scheme transfer of assets depended on fulfilment of the scheme condition. On that basis, the 1994 orders read literally could never bring the scheme into effect</i>. This was contrary to the expectation of all involved in the scheme process, including, it can be assumed, the judge\u2019s. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Consequently, Santow\u00a0J found that the parties had been labouring under a mistake of fact as to the fulfilment of the condition precedent (at [33]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">I infer from all the evidence before me that at the hearing on 6\u00a0June 1994, the plaintiff [AGL] and its representatives honestly and reasonably believed that all the conditions precedent (including the requirement for the authorisation held by the plaintiff to be amended) were capable of being satisfied and would be satisfied prior to midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994. The court was not misled deliberately in relation to the orders that were sought. <i>Instead both the parties and the court were operating under a mistake of fact</i> (that is, that the authorisation would be obtained prior to midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994). [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">75\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In these circumstances, one of the questions before Santow\u00a0J was whether the court could, pursuant to the Supreme Court Rules (NSW), amend the orders made on 6\u00a0June 1994 and extend the time for AGL to obtain amendment of its authorisation under the NSW Gas Act to 10 minutes after midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994 so that the unfulfilled condition precedent would be retrospectively satisfied. As seen above (at [55]), Santow\u00a0J held that the court had the jurisdiction to do so since the efficacy of the scheme was derived from an order of court. Besides taking into account the fact that the non-compliance in question was technical and accidental, Santow\u00a0J also considered the question of prejudice before concluding that the court\u2019s jurisdiction to grant an extension of time should be exercised in that case. At the outset, he made the following observation (at [3]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><i>What now is to be done?</i> <i>Clearly no-one would be prejudiced if the scheme were able to be rendered operative, along with the consequential steps purportedly taken</i></b>. If possible this should be retroactive, though that involves an element of retrospective fiction. Indeed if it were <i>not</i> possible to achieve that rectification and validation, <b><i>prejudice would flow both for the AGL group of companies, and the many who have dealt with it on the assumption that the scheme was effective</i></b>. [emphasis added in bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Further in his judgment, Santow\u00a0J made the following essential findings of fact (at [21]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">I find as a matter of fact that:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As at about one second past midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994 and thereafter, the plaintiff [AGL] and the subsidiary companies (to the extent that the effectiveness of their dissolution and other associated steps is questioned) <i>acted on the basis that the conditions precedent to the scheme of arrangement and the court orders had been complied with so that the scheme was assumed to be operative</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994, <i>the affairs of the plaintiff and the subsidiary companies have been conducted on the assumption that the scheme and its associated steps have been fully
