implemented</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the event the court is able to and does make orders validating, rectifying or confirming the validity of the scheme and its associated steps retroactively, <i>no injustice will be occasioned to any person now or in the future</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If no such orders are made, then <i>substantial injustice in the form of inconvenience, cost and confusion will inevitably be occasioned to the scheme companies, their ultimate shareholders, customers and to the public generally in so far as it has dealings with the scheme companies</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In essence, Santow\u00a0J was satisfied that no prejudice would be caused to any of the parties bound by the scheme if an extension of time was granted since all the parties concerned had assumed and acted on the basis that the scheme was valid right from the start. Instead, certain parties would suffer prejudice if an extension was not granted. In view of this, coupled with the fact that the failure to comply with the condition precedent in question was technical and accidental, there was every reason to grant AGL an extension of time.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to the case of <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Ray Brooks Pty Ltd</span></i> ([56] <i>supra</i>). Like the present appeal, <i>Ray Brooks Pty Ltd</i> was a case where a creditor (\u201cRay Brooks\u201d) had filed a (second, amended) proof of debt after the stipulated deadline for lodging proofs of debt. In that case, the administrator of an insolvent company (\u201cMr\u00a0Smith\u201d) had developed and proposed a scheme of arrangement as an alternative to liquidation, with a view to achieving a better return for the company\u2019s creditors than would be available in liquidation. The scheme was eventually approved by the court. Pursuant to the scheme, Ray Brooks lodged a proof of debt on 28\u00a0November 2001, which was before the stipulated deadline of 3\u00a0December 2001. Mr\u00a0Smith subsequently wrote to Ray Brooks on a few occasions requiring further particulars of its claim. To assist it in responding to Mr\u00a0Smith\u2019s queries, Ray Brooks engaged a consultancy firm, which sought (and was granted) an extension of time from Mr\u00a0Smith to provide the necessary particulars and supporting documents. The consultancy firm subsequently advised Ray Brooks that the claim originally submitted was significantly understated, and the latter thus submitted an amended proof of debt on 18\u00a0February 2002. Mr\u00a0Smith rejected this amended proof of debt on the basis that it had been submitted out of time, although the first proof of debt submitted was accepted as valid.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In exercising the court\u2019s jurisdiction to extend the deadline for filing proofs of debt from 3\u00a0December 2001 to 18\u00a0February 2002 so as to admit Ray Brooks\u2019 amended proof of debt, Austin\u00a0J held at [91]\u2013[92]:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>In my opinion, this is a case where considerations of fairness, in the exercise of its discretion under Pt\u00a040 r\u00a04 [of the Supreme Court Rules (NSW)], should lead the court to vary the time for Ray Brooks to lodge a formal proof of claim from 3\u00a0December 2001\u201318\u00a0February 2002</i>, so as to treat the second claim as the claim of Ray Brooks for the purposes of the scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">In reaching this conclusion, I take specifically into account <i>the difficulties to which the company was subjected in preparing proof of its claim during the extremely busy grain harvesting period, and the propensity for error that this circumstance created</i>. I also take into account the <i>very large discrepancy between the first claim and the second claim</i>, reflecting a considered assessment by Ray Brooks that its entitlement was much higher than originally framed. I also take into account that, according to counsel for Ray Brooks, <i>his client does not seek to be able to rank for a distribution of a net amount greater than the amount of the first claim. It seems to me that unfair prejudice to the administration and other creditors can be avoided if orders are appropriately framed to limit the participation of Ray Brooks in a further distribution by reference to counsel\u2019s concession</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As noted above, although the company was insolvent, Austin J felt that no prejudice could possibly be caused to the other creditors if an extension of time was granted as Ray Brooks had undertaken to rank equally with the other creditors for only the amount stated in its first proof of debt.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\"><em>(2)\u00a0Distilling some principles</em></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As seen from the cases above, <i>prejudice</i> to the company which is the subject of the scheme of arrangement, the other parties to the scheme as well as <i>the party who seeks the extension of time</i> is a significant (if not the most important) factor that the court takes into consideration in deciding whether to exercise its jurisdiction to grant an extension of a deadline contained in a court-approved scheme. In considering whether prejudice will be caused to any party (including the party seeking the extension of time), the court must consider the <i>entire</i> circumstances of the case, <i>notably</i>:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether any distribution has been made under the scheme;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether allowing the application for extension of time will inconvenience the other creditors or substantially affect the dividends that they can expect to receive;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether the order for extension of time can be framed to avoid any potential prejudice to other creditors; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 how much the creditor seeking the extension of time stands to lose if no extension is granted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">We would stress that this list of factors is not exhaustive and the court must always consider the circumstances of the case <i>as a whole</i> in deciding if prejudice would be caused to any of the interested parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Leaving aside the factor of prejudice, it appears that another factor that the court takes into consideration in deciding whether to exercise its jurisdiction to extend time in this context is the <i>reason</i> behind the failure of the party seeking the extension of time to comply with the timeline originally stipulated. A common theme that runs through the cases discussed above (at [71]\u2013[78]) is that the party seeking an extension of time in each case was not <i>blameworthy</i> for its non-compliance with the original timeline \u2013 in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Caratti</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([54] <i>supra</i>), the creditors\u2019 solicitors had mislaid the documents in their office; in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([55] <i>supra</i>), Santow\u00a0J found that it was impossible in the first place for AGL to have complied with the condition precedent in question; and in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Ray Brooks Pty Ltd</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([56] <i>supra</i>), Ray Brooks had filed its first proof of debt in time and had a valid excuse for not providing the correct figure in that proof of debt (which had been prepared during the busy grain harvesting period), thus necessitating the filing of an amended proof of debt after the original deadline.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Besides prejudice, the conduct of the party seeking an extension of time (including its reasons for failing to comply with the original deadline) and, of course, the extent of the delay involved, it is difficult (or perhaps impossible) for us to list here all the other factors that may be relevant. Many of the other relevant factors would in any case be subsumed under the consideration of prejudice (see [79] above). What other factors are relevant will depend on the facts of each case, and it would always be important for a court considering an application for an extension of time to have regard to the entire factual matrix. However, we emphasise (and this point also emerges from the Australian cases discussed above) that the <i>overriding consideration</i> remains (and should remain) that of prejudice \u2013 <i>ie</i>, whether prejudice would be caused to any party bound by the scheme if the extension of time is or is not granted, and, if so, whether such prejudice can be redressed. Thus, a creditor who is late in filing its proof of debt due to a genuine oversight should not be penalised with forfeiture of its entire debt if no prejudice would be caused to the other creditors or the company by granting an extension of time. That is not to say, however, that a creditor can be as negligent or lackadaisical as it wants in filing its proof of debt.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It should not come as a surprise that prejudice and the conduct of the party seeking an extension of time are relevant considerations in the present context (<i>viz</i>, extension of a time frame contained in, specifically, a court-approved scheme), given that they are the same factors that a court considers when deciding whether to exercise its discretion to extend or abridge time pursuant to O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court in other types of legal proceedings (see, generally, <i>Singapore Court Practice 2006</i> (Jeffrey Pinsler gen ed) (LexisNexis, 2006) at paras\u00a03/4/1\u20133/4/10 and <i>Singapore Civil Procedure 2007</i> (G\u00a0P\u00a0Selvam chief ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell Asia, 2007) at paras\u00a03/4/1\u20133/4/8). However, one difference, we would add, between an application for an extension of time in the context of a court-approved scheme and the same application in other contexts is that a court deciding whether to exercise its jurisdiction to extend time in the former should have regard to the</span> overarching need for clarity, certainty and finality, all of which are crucial for the proper functioning of schemes of arrangement. A court must therefore be circumspect when considering an application to extend time in the context of a court-approved scheme.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Whether an extension of time pursuant to the Rules of Court should be granted in the present case</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the court below, the Judge held that \u201ceven if there <span lang=\"EN-AU\">were jurisdiction to give an extension \u2026 the facts of this case did not merit the court\u2019s indulgence\u201d (see the GD at [42]). She noted that Oriental had been reminded on a number of occasions about the deadline for filing its proof of debt as well as the consequences of not filing one in time. More importantly, she held that</span> \u201ccontrary to Oriental\u2019s arguments that Reliance would suffer minimal prejudice if the present application was allowed \u2026 there would be <i>serious repercussions</i> if this application was allowed \u2026 for Reliance\u201d [emphasis added] (see the GD at [44]), and accepted Reliance\u2019s submission that \u201c<span lang=\"EN-AU\">the entire scheme might have to be <i>abandoned</i></span>\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>id</i>) if the application was allowed. Unfortunately, the Judge did not elaborate on what \u201cserious repercussions\u201d Reliance would suffer if Oriental\u2019s application for an extension of time were allowed or why the Scheme might have to be abandoned in that event. Indeed, this appeared to be nothing short of a bare submission by Reliance, unsupported by the facts before us. We therefore could not agree with the Judge that the facts of this case merited such a conclusion.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We found, on the contrary, that no prejudice would be caused to Reliance or the other Scheme Creditors if we were to allow Oriental\u2019s application; in fact, Oriental would be severely prejudiced if we were to dismiss its application. Our reasons for coming to this conclusion are as follows.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Firstly, as mentioned earlier (see [8] above), the Scheme was a <i>solvent</i> one. Based on Reliance\u2019s audited accounts as at 31\u00a0December 2005, Reliance had sufficient assets to pay <i>all</i> the Scheme Creditors, including Oriental, <i>in full</i> (a point which counsel for Reliance acknowledged at the hearing before this court). In fact, it was clear from the Scheme Documents (see [7] above) that the purpose of the Scheme was to make <i>full payment</i> to all the Scheme Creditors so as to conclude the run-off of Reliance\u2019s business more expeditiously than would be the case if the run-off were to continue until all claims from Scheme Creditors had materialised and had been paid. It followed then that if an extension of time were granted to Oriental to file its proof of debt and its claim subsequently admitted, the rest of the Scheme Creditors would not in any way be prejudiced given that all of them would, in any event, be receiving full payment for their ascertained claims. Indeed, counsel for Reliance, upon being queried by us, conceded that Reliance had thus far not received any objection from any of the Scheme Creditors in respect of Oriental\u2019s application for an extension of time to file its proof of debt and for its claim to be admitted. The fact that the Scheme was a solvent one was an important factor (although by no means a decisive one) that we took into consideration in assessing if any prejudice would be caused to the rest of the Scheme Creditors or any other parties bound by the Scheme if Oriental\u2019s application were to be allowed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">86\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, at all material times, Oriental was a creditor <i>known</i> to Reliance, and Reliance was always prepared to meet Oriental\u2019s claim. Mr\u00a0Andy Campbell, a director of Reliance, had flown to India to garner Oriental\u2019s support for the Scheme, and Reliance had admitted Oriental\u2019s claim of approximately US$20m for the purposes of voting at the Court Meeting. It appeared from the Explanatory Statement that Oriental was (by virtue of the size of its claim) by far the largest creditor of Reliance, and if Oriental (voting by proxy at the Court Meeting) had not voted in favour of the Scheme, the Scheme might not have received the requisite approval of three-fourths in value of the Scheme Creditors present and voting either in person or by proxy at the Court Meeting as stipulated by s\u00a0210(3) of the Companies Act, and might in turn never have been implemented in the first place. In such circumstances, we could not see how Reliance would in any way be prejudiced if Oriental\u2019s claim were admitted as a result of our granting Oriental an extension of time to file its proof of debt. This was certainly not a case of a creditor suddenly materialising out of thin air.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">87\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thirdly, Oriental was only two months late in filing its proof of debt, and when Oriental first notified Reliance that it wished to file its proof of debt out of time in its letter dated 16\u00a0July 2007 (see [18] above), there was still a good six months before the targeted payment date of 28\u00a0February 2008 under the Scheme. Had Oriental\u2019s claim been admitted then (<i>ie</i>, in July 2007), the Scheme Manager would have had more than adequate time to ascertain Oriental\u2019s claim. Given also that no payment has been made under the Scheme thus far, we do not see how Reliance or any of the other Scheme Creditors would be prejudiced even if Oriental files its proof of debt now and has its claim admitted at this late stage. If anything, this would only mean that payment has to be deferred to a later date, but we note that the original <i>targeted</i> payment date was only a <i>tentative</i> date in the first place.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, we were of the opinion that the only prejudice that could potentially arise in the present case would be that which would be caused to Oriental if its application for an extension of time were not granted. Oriental has a claim of <span lang=\"EN-AU\">US$19,031,656</span>, and, although this figure is an estimate, the ascertained claim would in any case still be a significant sum. This was what was at stake for Oriental in the present appeal, and if we had refused its application for an extension of time, we would, as contended by counsel for Oriental, literally be handing to the shareholder(s) of Reliance (WIG, in this case) an unmerited windfall. Oriental would be left with virtually nothing, although it had voted in favour of the Scheme and was all along a creditor known to Reliance to have an apparently genuine claim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This brings us to the question then of whether Oriental could only blame itself for not filing its proof of debt in time and whether it should be entitled to a second bite of the cherry. The Judge was clearly of the view that Oriental should not be given a second chance, given the numerous reminders that Reliance had purportedly sent out. We note that there was some dispute in the court below as to whether Oriental did receive those reminders. The Judge was of the view that since the letter of 14\u00a0November 2006 (see [14] above) had been sent to Oriental at the General Address (which was the address that the Scheme Documents had been sent to, and Oriental had confirmed receipt of those documents), and since at least three of the e-mails sent after November 2006 had been sent to the e-mail address provided by Oriental in its completed voting form, Reliance had done <span lang=\"EN-AU\">as much as it could to notify Oriental of the need to file its proof of debt before the Claims Cut-Off Date (see the GD at [42]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we do not share the Judge\u2019s view that Reliance had done its best to notify Oriental of the deadline for filing its proof of debt. The crucial letter of 14\u00a0November 2006, which informed Oriental that the Scheme had been sanctioned by the High Court and which enclosed a proof of debt form as well as instructions for filing up the form, was addressed to Mr\u00a0Mohan, who had retired from Oriental in February 2005 (see [15] above). Although it was not wrong for Reliance to have sent this letter to the General Address, we would have thought that, as a matter of prudence and common sense, a copy of the letter, clearly addressed to Mr\u00a0Jindal (who had signed the voting form on behalf of Oriental), should also have been forwarded to the address provided in Oriental\u2019s completed voting form. As for the three e-mail reminders that were sent to Mr\u00a0Jindal\u2019s e-mail address (see [16] above), we note that although Reliance had produced \u201cDelivery Status Notification (Relay)\u201d reports to prove that those e-mails were indeed sent out, the reports did not in any way prove that Mr\u00a0Jindal had received the e-mails. We are also puzzled as to why Reliance only made two attempts (both unsuccessful) to contact Oriental by telephone and why those telephone calls were made to Oriental\u2019s fax number instead of Oriental\u2019s telephone number (see [17] above). Even if Reliance did not have Oriental\u2019s telephone number, it would have been able to obtain the number if it had genuinely resolved to do so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nonetheless, we accept that Oriental was certainly not blameless (unlike the parties seeking an extension of time in the Australian cases discussed at [71]\u2013[78] above) for its failure to file its proof of debt in time. Even if Reliance had not informed Oriental that the Scheme had been sanctioned or had not reminded the latter about the deadline for filing its proof of debt, it would have been prudent for Oriental to make the necessary enquiries itself. However, as mentioned above (at [81]), the overriding consideration in determining whether the court\u2019s jurisdiction should be exercised in favour of granting an extension of time would be whether any prejudice will be caused to any party bound by the scheme if an extension of time were granted (or not granted), even though the court is also entitled to take into account, <i>inter alia</i>, the conduct of the party seeking an extension of time. The present case was not one of a patent oversight. Rather, there seemed to have been a slip between the cup and the lip on Oriental\u2019s part that ought to have been viewed with a measure of leniency. The facts we have referred to plainly show that no discernible prejudice would be caused to either the rest of the Scheme Creditors or Reliance if the present application for an extension of time were allowed; on the contrary, dismissing the application would have grave and irreparable consequences for Oriental. We are of the view that the failure by Oriental to file its proof of debt in time here was a case of inadvertent oversight on Oriental\u2019s part. Upon learning of its failure in this regard two months after the deadline for filing its proof of debt had passed, Oriental immediately wrote to notify Reliance of its wish to submit its claim, and, at that time, there was still approximately six months before the targeted payment date under the Scheme. Given these circumstances, we are of the view that the present case was one that warranted the exercise of the court\u2019s jurisdiction to grant an extension of time. Accordingly, we granted Oriental an extension of time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Whether the court has jurisdiction under section\u00a0392(4)(</em>d<em>) of the Companies Act to extend the time for filing proofs of debt</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">92\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In view of our reliance on O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court to allow Oriental\u2019s appeal (and, thus, its application for an extension of time), it was not strictly necessary for us to consider the new (and alternative) legal argument raised by Oriental in its written skeletal submissions for this appeal (see [27] above), <i>viz</i>, that s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act conferred on the court jurisdiction (which was independent of the nature of schemes of arrangement) to grant an extension of time for a creditor in Oriental\u2019s position to file its proof of debt. In the interests of completeness, however, we will now deal with this issue.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Legislative history of section\u00a0392(4)(</em>d<em>)</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">93\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act provides as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subject to the following provisions of this section and without limiting the generality of any other provision of this Act, the Court <i>may</i>, on application by any interested person, make all or any of the following orders, either unconditionally or subject to such conditions as the Court imposes:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(<i>d</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an order <i>extending the period</i> for doing any act, matter or thing or instituting or taking any proceeding under this Act or <i>in relation to a corporation</i> (including an order extending a period where the period concerned expired before the application for the order was made) or abridging the period for doing such an act, matter or thing or instituting or taking such a proceeding,</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">and may make such consequential or ancillary orders as the Court thinks fit.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">94\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) further provides that an order under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) can only be made if such an order will not cause \u201c</span>substantial injustice\u201d to any person:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(6)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court shall not make an order under this section unless it is satisfied\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(<i>c</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in every case, that no <i>substantial injustice</i> has been or is likely to be caused to any person.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">95\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a0392 of the Companies Act, which was first enacted in 1987 (via the Companies (Amendment) Act 1987 (Act\u00a037 of 1987)), was inspired by s\u00a0539 of the Companies Act 1981 (Cth) (see</span> <i>Butterworths\u2019 Annotated Statutes</i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([33] <i>supra</i>) at p\u00a0940). As there appears to be no equivalent provision in the UK\u2019s companies legislation, s\u00a0392 seems to have been derived entirely from Australian legislation. Presently, s\u00a0392 of the Companies Act is <i>in</i> <i>pari materia</i> with s\u00a01322 of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act, of which s\u00a01322(4)(d) (the subsection corresponding to s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act) reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subject to the following provisions of this section <i>but</i> without limiting the generality of any other provision of this Act, the Court may, on application by any interested person, make all or any of the following orders, either unconditionally or subject to such conditions as the Court imposes:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an order extending the period for doing any act, matter or thing or instituting or taking any proceeding under this Act or in relation to a corporation (including an order extending a period where the period concerned ended before the application for the order was made) or abridging the period for doing such an act, matter or thing or instituting or taking such a proceeding \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Thus, save for the word \u201cbut\u201d (italicised in the quotation above) in the opening words of s\u00a01322(4)(d) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act, the wording of that provision is exactly the same as the wording of s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act. Section\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>)</span> of the Companies Act is also substantially the same as s\u00a01322(6)(c) of the 2001 Australian <span lang=\"EN-AU\">Corporations Act, which reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(6)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Court must not make an order under this section unless it is satisfied:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in every case \u2013 that no substantial injustice has been or is likely to be caused to any person.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Section\u00a0392(4)(</em>d<em>): its scope and its applicability to extensions of time in respect of court-approved schemes</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">96\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It appears that s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act has hitherto not been interpreted by the local courts. However, a plain reading of this provision would suggest that it has a rather broad remit. The learned authors of</span> <i>Australian Corporation Law</i> ([39] <i>supra</i>) note (at vol\u00a03, para\u00a09.4.0080 <span lang=\"EN-AU\">(April 2007 release)) in relation to the corresponding Australian provision (<i>ie</i>, s\u00a01322(4)(d) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Section\u00a01322(4)(d) confers power on a court to extend or abridge the period for doing <i>any</i> act \u201cin relation to a corporation\u201d. <i>The section does not identify the instrument or authority that has the prescribed period which the court is able to extend or abridge</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">It would thus follow that as long as the act in respect of which an extension of time is sought is \u201cin relation to a corporation\u201d, but subject to the qualification in s\u00a01322(6) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act, the court will be able to grant an extension of time if it deems it fit to do so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">97\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before we proceed further to discuss some of the cases that have applied the Australian provision, a clarification is perhaps first needed. It will be seen shortly that some of the cases discussed below concern legislation that predates the 2001 Australian Corporations Act. These cases are nonetheless relevant as they deal with essentially the same provision as the present s\u00a01322(4)(d) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act. Some brief comments on the background of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act are necessary to understand this (see, generally, <i>Ford</i> ([34] <i>supra</i>]), vol\u00a01 at paras\u00a02.170\u20132.320 (March 2002 release); <i>Halsbury\u2019s Laws of Australia</i> vol\u00a07 (J\u00a0D\u00a0Heydon gen ed) (Butterworths, Looseleaf Ed, 1993) at para\u00a0120-130 (March 2007 release); and Phillip Lipton &amp; Abe Herzberg, <i>Understanding Company Law</i> (Lawbook Co, 10th\u00a0Ed, 2001) at pp\u00a07\u20139). Companies legislation in Australia used to be under the purview of each state\u2019s legislature, but, in 1989, the Commonwealth parliament enacted the Corporations Act 1989 (Cth) (\u201cthe Commonwealth Corporations Act\u201d) as a national law governing companies. Although enacted in 1989, this Act did not take effect because of a successful constitutional challenge to it in <i>The State of New South Wales v The Commonwealth of Australia</i> (1990) 169\u00a0CLR 482, where the Australian High Court held that the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia did not confer power on the Commonwealth to make laws on the incorporation of companies generally. Pursuant to this decision, the Commonwealth, the various states and the Northern Territory, through co-ordinated legislation, sought to put in place a uniform companies law. The Commonwealth Corporations Act was amended such that it became the companies legislation of the Australian Capital Territory only, and s\u00a082 of that Act (as amended) set out what was termed \u201cthe Corporations Law\u201d. Instead of each state and the Northern Territory passing different statutes on companies law, each of them enacted as its companies legislation the Corporations Law set out in s\u00a082 of the Commonwealth Corporations Act (as amended) (\u201cthe Australian Corporations Law\u201d). This state of affairs continued until the 2001 Australian Corporations Act was enacted following a reference of power by the various states to the Commonwealth. Section\u00a01322(4)(d) of the Australian Corporations Law is, in fact, equivalent to s\u00a01322(4)(d) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (the same applies in respect of s\u00a01322(6)(c) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act). Many Australian textbooks, when referring to s\u00a01322(4)(d), do not state whether they are referring to this provision as it is set out in the 2001 Australian Corporations Act or as it is set out in the Australian Corporations Law. References to s\u00a01322(4)(d) in cases dealing with legislation predating before the 2001 Australian Corporations Act are, in fact, references to s\u00a01322(4)(d) of the Australian Corporations Law, and we shall use the generic term \u201cs\u00a01322(4)(d)\u201d in these grounds of decision to denote this subsection regardless of the particular piece of Australian legislation which it appears in . With this in mind, we proceed now to consider some of these cases.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">98\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In Australia, s\u00a01322(4)(d) has been applied in a number of instances where the time for doing a certain act was prescribed by the Australian Corporations Law and/or the 2001 Australian Corporations Act (see, for instance, <i>Village Roadshow Broadcasting Pty Ltd v Austereo Ltd</i> (1997) 24\u00a0ACSR 185, where Goldberg\u00a0J used s\u00a01322(4)(d) to abridge the period during which dissenting offerees to a takeover offer could apply under s\u00a0701(6) of the Australian Corporations Law in respect of notices given to them by the offeror, and <i>National Roads and Motorists\u2019 Association Ltd v Parkin</i> (2004) 49\u00a0ACSR 485, where Campbell\u00a0J used s\u00a01322(4)(d) to extend by two months the time for the applicant company to hold a general meeting pursuant to a requisition from its members under s\u00a0249D of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act; see also, generally,</span> <i>Ford</i> ([34] <i>supra</i>), vol\u00a01 <span lang=\"EN-AU\">at para\u00a07.583 (November 2005 release)). The Australian courts have, however, also held that s\u00a01322(4)(d) does not apply in some instances (see, for example, <i>Re Panbio Pty Ltd</i> (2000) 35\u00a0ACSR 458, where it was held that s\u00a01322(4)(d) could not be used to extend or abridge the one-month period specified in s\u00a0164 of the Australian Corporations Law for a company which had changed its company type to alter the details of its registration as to invoke s\u00a01322(4)(d) in this manner would undermine the protection provided in s\u00a0164(7) of the Australian Corporations Law; and <i>S\u00a0T\u00a0(2) Pty Ltd v Lockwood</i> (1998) 27\u00a0ACSR 667, where it was held that s\u00a01322(4)(d) did not apply to cure a failure to comply with s\u00a0444B(2)(a) of the Australian Corporations Law, which required a company to execute a deed of company arrangement within 21 days after the end of the creditors\u2019 meeting at which it was resolved that the company should execute such a deed, as s\u00a0444B(2) already contained within it a specific remedial provision (<i>viz</i>, s\u00a0444B(2)(b)) in the event that an extension of time was needed). It appears that in instances where a specific time period is prescribed by the 2001 Australian Corporations Act and/or the Australian Corporations Law, whether s\u00a01322(4)(d) can operate to extend that time period will depend upon the particular statutory context (<i>Brown v DML Resources Pty Ltd (No\u00a06)</i> (2002) 40\u00a0ACSR 669). Section\u00a01322(4)(d) has also been applied in instances where the time period was not directly fixed by statute, such as in <i>Re Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd</i> (2006) 57\u00a0ACSR 99, where Finkelstein\u00a0J held that the subsection permitted the court to extend the time for doing certain acts fixed by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission in class orders made under s\u00a0341 of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">99\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for the applicability of s\u00a01322(4)(d) to the extension of time <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> schemes of arrangement, this was considered by Santow\u00a0J in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">([55] <i>supra</i>). He opined at [51]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span class=\"Judg-quote-1Char\">Although it is not necessary finally to decide whether s\u00a01322(4)(d) applies in these circumstances, and especially with no contradictor, clearly <i>s\u00a01322(4)(d) was drawn in very wide terms as a remedial provision</i>. Moreover, the words \u201cin relation to\u201d are well recognised as words of expansive meaning (see, eg, <i>Tooheys Ltd v Cmr of Stamp Duties</i> (1961) 105\u00a0CLR 602) but gathering its meaning \u201cfrom the context in which it appears ... which will determine the matters to which it extends\u201d: per Deane, Dawson and Toohey\u00a0JJ in <i>Workers\u2019 Compensation Board (Qld) v Technical Products Pty Ltd</i> (1988) 165\u00a0CLR 642 at 653; 81\u00a0ALR 260. It allows the court to make an order extending or abridging time whether for any proceeding under the [Australian Corporations] Law or \u201crelating to a corporation\u201d. <i>A scheme of arrangement clearly \u201crelates to a corporation\u201d being the corporation which proposed the scheme.</i> [emphasis added</span>]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">100\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Since Santow\u00a0J had already decided that the court could grant AGL the extension of time sought pursuant to the Supreme Court Rules (NSW) (on the basis that a scheme of arrangement derived its efficacy from the order of court approving the scheme), his comments above were strictly <i>obiter</i>. We note that Santow\u00a0J himself prefaced the above passage with the caveat that \u201cit [was] not necessary finally to decide whether s\u00a01322(4)(d) [applied] in these circumstances\u201d, and he made it clear again later in his judgment (at [53]) that he was not deciding if the subsection would apply in the case before him:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The plaintiff [AGL] submits that in the circumstances of this case the operation of the section [<i>ie</i>, s\u00a01322(4)(d)] is enlivened and that as a matter of discretion I could make appropriate orders. If I had not been minded to make orders on the bases set out above, I would have needed to reach a conclusion on that; but <i>I do not need to do so and prefer to leave that question for another day</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">101\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for Reliance submitted that <span lang=\"EN-AU\">s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act would not be of avail to Oriental in the present case as it has been held in <i>Diversified Mineral Resources NL v Amusmet Investments Pty Ltd</i> (1991) 24\u00a0NSWLR 77 (\u201c<i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i>\u201d) that the corresponding Australian provision (<i>ie</i>, s\u00a01322(4)(d)) did not apply in a situation where an event occurred automatically upon the termination of a prescribed time frame, as opposed to a case where some act must be undertaken in order for the event in question to occur within the stipulated time frame</span>. <span lang=\"EN-AU\">Reliance contended that Oriental\u2019s claim:</span><a id=\"_ftnref7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn7\" name=\"_ftnref7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">[note: 7]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u2026 was, pursuant to the Scheme, deemed zero automatically when it failed to submit its Proof of Debt on time; no further action was required on the part of [Reliance]. Thus, Section\u00a0392(4)(d) of the [Companies] Act cannot avail [Oriental].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">At the hearing before this court, counsel for Reliance pointed out, in support of the above submission, that Santow\u00a0J himself in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">at [51] had observed that <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i> was authority for the proposition that s\u00a01322(4)(d) did not apply where time expired automatically.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">102\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we do not agree with Reliance\u2019s submission. In relation to Santow\u00a0J\u2019s observation, the relevant part of his judgment in <i>Re AGL</i> <i>Gas Networks</i> at [51] reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]here is authority for the proposition that where time expires automatically, for example under the [Australian Corporations] Law or the [company\u2019s] articles \u2013 and it might be suggested a scheme condition \u2013 s\u00a01322(4)(d) cannot be used to extend it: <i>Diversified Mineral Resources NL v Amusmet Investments Pty Ltd</i> (1991) 5\u00a0ACSR 465; 9\u00a0ACLC 1047 per McLelland\u00a0J. <i>Dicta by the High Court may suggest that that constraint does not apply at least where the step is one directly for the corporation or its creditors to take, rather than one which less directly merely</i> <i>concerns</i> <i>the corporation</i>: <i>Australasian Memory Pty Ltd v Brien</i> (2000) 172\u00a0ALR 28; 34\u00a0ACSR 250 at 260. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">From the above passage, it appears that Santow\u00a0J was of the view that <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i> represented the proposition that if a stipulated time period for doing an act expired automatically under the Australian Corporations Law or the articles of association of a company, s\u00a01322(4)(d) could not be used to extend that time period. However, he qualified his view by commenting that that constraint did not appear to apply at least where the step to be taken within the stipulated time period was one <i>directly</i> for the corporation or its creditors to take. As discussed earlier (see [73]\u2013[75] above), in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">, an extension of time was sought for AGL to fulfil a condition precedent laid down in the scheme, namely, an amendment of its then existing authorisation under the NSW Gas Act before midnight on 30\u00a0June 1994. Santow\u00a0J noted that such an amendment was not exactly \u201ca step directly relating to a corporate proceeding though indispensable to it taking effect\u201d (</span><i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">id</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">at [51]). However, as he had already decided that the court could extend time pursuant to the Supreme Court Rules (NSW), he felt that there was no need to decide if s\u00a01322(4)(d) applied on the facts (see [99]\u2013[100] above). Unlike the factual scenario in <i>Re AGL Gas Networks</i>, the present appeal concerns the filing of a proof of debt by a company\u2019s creditor (<i>ie</i>, Oriental) under a court-approved scheme (<i>ie</i>, the Scheme). Unlike the fulfilment of the particular condition precedent which was considered in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">, the filing of a proof of debt, on Santow\u00a0J\u2019s own view that</span> a scheme of arrangement \u201cclearly \u2018relate[d] to a corporation\u2019 being the corporation which proposed the scheme\u201d (<i>id</i> at [51]) and \u201cso too [did] performance of all the scheme steps\u201d (<i>ibid</i>), <span lang=\"EN-AU\">is clearly a step directly \u201cin relation to a corporation\u201d for the purposes of s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act</span>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">103\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The present case is also distinguishable from <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i> on two points. Firstly, the latter case involved a statutory provision, <i>ie</i>, s\u00a0388(1) of the Australian Corporations Law, which prescribed a 14-day time period for a shareholder to pay up upon a demand for payment pursuant to a call by the company on that shareholder\u2019s shares, failing which the shareholder\u2019s shares would be automatically forfeited for non-payment. Thus, unlike the scenario in this appeal, <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i>, to begin with, was not concerned with a situation where the time period in question was not prescribed by statute.</span> Secondly, <span lang=\"EN-AU\">in <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i>, the interlocutory application brought by the defendant shareholder was for an extension of the time period set out in s\u00a0388(1) of the Australian Corporations Law, upon the expiry of which a shareholder\u2019s shares could be automatically forfeited for non-payment pursuant to a call made on those shares. McLelland\u00a0J held (<i>inter alia</i>) at 78 that s\u00a01322(4)(d) did not apply because under s\u00a01322(4)(d), the relevant power conferred on the court was to extend the period \u201cfor <i>doing</i> any act, matter or thing or instituting or taking any proceeding under this Law or in relation to a corporation\u201d [emphasis added]; since forfeiture for non-payment upon a call on shares occurred automatically under s\u00a0388(1) without occasion for anyone to do any act, matter or thing or institute or take any proceeding in order for forfeiture to occur, s\u00a01322(4)(d) was inapplicable. This appeared to be the holding relied on by Reliance (see [101] above) in its submission that s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act was similarly of no avail to Oriental in this appeal. With respect, Reliance has misapplied McLelland\u00a0J\u2019s holding in <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i>. In that case, the time period in question related to the <i>forfeiture</i> of shares; the defendant shareholder was seeking to delay forfeiture by obtaining an extension of the time period set out in s\u00a0388(1) of the Australian Corporations Law pending the hearing of the substantive proceedings as to whether there was in fact any money owing on its shares. In contrast, the relevant time period in this appeal related to the <i>filing</i> of a proof of debt, and not the <i>deeming</i> of a Scheme Creditor\u2019s claim to be zero if its proof of debt was not filed by the Claims Cut-Off Date. The filing of a proof of debt would certainly be an act \u201cin relation to a corporation\u201d within the meaning of s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act if Santow\u00a0J\u2019s reasoning in</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-AU\">Re AGL Gas Networks</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">at [51] (see the passage cited at [99] above) is accepted. It can, perhaps, plausibly be said that in <i>Diversified Mineral Resources</i>, the defendant shareholder was effectively seeking an extension of time to make payment following the company\u2019s call on its shares, and although such payment would certainly have been an act in relation to a corporation, the court held that s\u00a01322(4)(d) did not apply. However, this was not how the application for extension of time was framed before McLelland\u00a0J (perhaps, if the application in that case had indeed been framed in that way, McLelland\u00a0J might have allowed it, but we need say no further on this). In any event, as mentioned at [98] above, whether s\u00a01322(4)(d) can be applied to extend a time limit prescribed by a provision in the Australian Corporations Law and/or the 2001 Australian Corporations Act would invariably depend on the particular statutory context. No such consideration arises where the time period which is sought to be extended is <i>not</i> prescribed by statute, such as in the present appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">104\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Given the plain wording of s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act, we are of the view that there is no reason why this subsection cannot, in principle, apply to any step to be taken by a creditor under a court-approved scheme, such as the filing of a proof of debt in this case, subject to the caveat that no order under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) can be made unless the court is satisfied that no substantial injustice would be caused to any party by the making of such an order (see s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>)).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>\u201cSubstantial injustice\u201d for the purposes of section\u00a0392(6)(</em>c<em>)</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">105\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It remains to be seen what the meaning of \u201csubstantial injustice\u201d in s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) of the Companies Act is. The learned authors of <i>Ford</i> ([34] <i>supra</i>) explained the requirement of \u201cno substantial injustice\u201d in the corresponding Australian provision (<i>ie</i>, s\u00a01322(6)(c) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act) as follows (at vol\u00a01, para\u00a07.584 (November 2005 release)):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Section\u00a01322(6)(c) prescribes a condition which affects all four kinds of order [which can be made under s\u00a01322]. <i>The court must be satisfied that no substantial injustice has been or is likely to be caused to any person</i>. As it appeared in s\u00a0366 of the Uniform Companies Act 1961 (Cth), this condition was considered in <i>Re Compaction Systems Pty Ltd</i> <nobr>[1976] 2 NSWLR 477</nobr>; (1976) 2\u00a0ACLR 135; (1977\u201378) CLC\u00a040-313. Bowen\u00a0CJ in Eq said (ACLR at 150):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><i>In my view, the word \u201cinjustice\u201d in this provision requires the court to consider any real, and not merely insubstantial or theoretical, prejudice which will be suffered by, for example, a member by the making of an order, and to weigh this in the scales against the prejudice to the company, other members and creditors, if an order is not made</i>. In other words, it is insufficient to show that there may be some prejudice to a member if, on a consideration of the whole matter, the overwhelming weight of justice, as it were, is in favour of making the order (see <i>Re Australian Continental Resources Ltd</i> (1975) 10\u00a0ACTR 19; 1\u00a0ACLR 405 per Blackburn\u00a0J at 33\u20134; see also <i>Re Castlereagh Securities Ltd</i> <nobr>[1973] 1 NSWLR 624</nobr>; (1971\u201373) CLC\u00a040\u2013066 and <i>Elderslie Finance Corporation Ltd v ASC</i> (1993) 11\u00a0ACSR 157 at 160; 11\u00a0ACLC 787).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">106\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Essentially, Bowen\u00a0CJ held in <i>Re Compaction System Pty Ltd</i> <nobr>[1976] 2 NSWLR 77</nobr> that it was necessary to show <i>real</i> rather than <i>insubstantial</i> or <i>theoretical</i> prejudice in order to dissuade the court from making an order under the then equivalent of s\u00a01322(4) of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act. The prejudice against a particular party if an order were made must be weighed against the prejudice to the other members and creditors of the company as well as to the company itself if the order were not made, and thus, a decision as to whether substantial injustice exists is \u201ca <i>balancing act</i>\u201d [emphasis added] (see <i>Australian Corporation Law</i> ([39] <i>supra</i>), at vol\u00a03, para\u00a09.4.0080 (April 2007 release)). Bowen\u00a0CJ\u2019s observations as set out above have been approvingly referred to locally in <i>Golden Harvest Films Distribution (Pte) Ltd v Golden Village Multiplex Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 940</nobr> at [54], where this court suggested that the determination of substantial injustice under s\u00a0392 of the Companies Act involved \u201ca holistic weighing and balancing of the various interests of all the relevant parties\u201d.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">107\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our opinion, the <i>same</i> balancing act is undertaken by the court when it considers the potential prejudice that may be caused to the interested parties if it were to exercise or decline to exercise its jurisdiction to extend time under O\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court (see [79] and [81] above). A question that then arises is whether the test of \u201cno substantial injustice\u201d in s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) of the Companies Act entails a consideration of the same factors as those relating to prejudice which the court takes into account in determining whether an extension of time should be granted under the Rules of Court. We agree with Bowen\u00a0CJ\u2019s observation in <i>Re Compaction Systems Pty Ltd</i> (see the passage quoted at [105] above) that \u201cinjustice\u201d in s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) refers to the same thing as (real) prejudice. As for the word \u201csubstantial\u201d, it is defined in A\u00a0S\u00a0Hornby, <i>Oxford Advanced Learner\u2019s Dictionary of Current English</i> (Oxford University Press, 5th\u00a0Ed, 1995) at p\u00a01192 as \u201clarge in amount or value; considerable\u201d. In our opinion, the court can grant an extension of time under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act so long as it is satisfied that no <i>considerable</i> prejudice would be caused to any of the interested parties if the order is made. It thus appears to us that \u201csubstantial injustice\u201d in s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) amounts to something greater than just ordinary prejudice.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">108\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we would stop short of saying that a party who fails to obtain an extension of time under the Rules of Court can, in contrast, do so under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act if, say, it is shown that some prejudice may be caused to a relevant party, but the prejudice does not amount to \u201csubstantial injustice\u201d. It must be borne in mind that the power conferred on the court by s\u00a0392(4) is <i>discretionary</i>, given that the provision directs that the court \u201c<i>may</i>, on application by any interested person, make all or any of the following orders [in ss\u00a0392(4)(<i>a</i>)\u2013392(4)(<i>d</i>)], either unconditionally or <i>subject to such conditions as the Court imposes</i>\u201d [emphasis added] (see [93] above). Thus, the learned editors of <i>The Laws of Australia</i> vol\u00a04 (Thomson Lawbook Co, Looseleaf Ed, 1993) have, in regard to the making of orders under s\u00a01322 of the 2001 Australian Corporations Act, commented as follows (at para\u00a04.2.1320 (April 2006 release)):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Even where the court is satisfied of the matters specified in s\u00a01322(6) [<i>ie</i>, that no substantial injustice has been or is likely to be caused to any party], it retains a <i>discretion</i> whether or not to make a validating order, and does not do so unless it considers intervention to be justified. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">It follows that notwithstanding that the court is satisfied that no substantial injustice would be caused to any party if an order is made under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act, the court can decline to make the order, having regard to the entire circumstances of the case. In our opinion, the same considerations that a court takes into account in deciding if an extension of time should be granted under the Rules of Court (as summarised at [79]\u2013[81] above) should equally apply for the purposes of deciding if an extension of time should be granted under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act. This would mean that the court in the latter situation could, besides prejudice, also take into consideration, <i>inter alia</i>, the reason(s) why the party seeking an extension of time failed to comply with the timeline originally stipulated. It would be anomalous if an extension of time can be granted to a creditor to file its proof of debt under the Rules of Court, but not under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act, or <i>vice versa</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em>Whether section\u00a0392(4)(</em>d<em>) was of avail to Oriental in the present case</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">109\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We have already given our reasons as to why we would exercise our jurisdiction pursuant to the Rules of Court to grant Oriental an extension of time to file its proof of debt in the present case (see [85]\u2013[91] above). For the same reasons, we would have been prepared to grant Oriental an extension of time pursuant to s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of the Companies Act.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">110\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In any event, since granting Oriental an extension of time pursuant to the Rules of Court to file its proof of debt would not cause any prejudice to either the rest of the Scheme Creditors or Reliance, we do not see how these parties would suffer any \u201csubstantial injustice\u201d within the meaning of s\u00a0392(6)(<i>c</i>) of the Companies Act if we were to allow, in the alternative, the extension of time under s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) of that Act. We therefore held that s\u00a0392(4)(<i>d</i>) would be of avail to Oriental in the present case.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">111\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Considering para\u00a01.7 of the Explanatory Statement and cl\u00a02.1 of the Scheme of Compromise and Arrangement (see [7] above), it was clear beyond peradventure that the unmistakeable objective of the Scheme was to ensure accelerated <i>full payment</i> to all the Scheme Creditors. Given the fact that Reliance had <i>prima facie</i> not only acknowledged Oriental as a legitimate creditor, but had also sought as well as obtained the latter\u2019s support as a majority creditor, was it not plainly consistent with the Scheme\u2019s declared intent and purport to grant Oriental an extension of time to file its proof of debt so that its claim could be processed? Reliance\u2019s stance in relying on a barren procedural obstacle (namely, Oriental\u2019s failure to file its proof of debt by the Claims Cut-Off Date), which would not in the overall scheme of things prejudice the implementation of the Scheme, to reject (effectively) Oriental\u2019s claim was unmeritorious, to say the least. In the result, we allowed Oriental\u2019s appeal with costs here, but not below (we ordered each party to bear its own costs of the proceedings in the court below), and granted Oriental an extension of time until 5.00pm on 22\u00a0January 2008 to file its proof of debt.</p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref1\" name=\"_ftn1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 1]</span></span></a> See para\u00a020 of Reliance\u2019s written submissions filed on 11\u00a0October 2007 for the hearing of Oriental\u2019s application for an extension of time to file its proof of debt.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref2\" name=\"_ftn2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 2]</span></span></a> See para\u00a09 of Oriental\u2019s skeletal arguments filed on 2\u00a0January 2008 for this appeal.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn3\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref3\" name=\"_ftn3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 3]</span></span></a> See p\u00a010 of Reliance\u2019s skeletal arguments filed on 10\u00a0January 2008 for this appeal.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn4\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref4\" name=\"_ftn4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 4]</span></span></a> See para\u00a049 of Reliance\u2019s written case filed on 27\u00a0December 2007 for this appeal.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn5\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn5\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref5\" name=\"_ftn5\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 5]</span></span></a> See paras\u00a027\u201328 of Oriental\u2019s skeletal arguments filed on 2\u00a0January 2008 for this appeal.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn6\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref6\" name=\"_ftn6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 6]</span></span></a> See n\u00a04, <i>supra</i>.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn7\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref7\" name=\"_ftn7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 7]</span></span></a> See para\u00a059 of Reliance\u2019s skeletal arguments filed on 10\u00a0January 2008 for this appeal.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9
