cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">26\u00a0June\u00a02009</p>\n</td>\n<td width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">Judgment reserved.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\">Chan Sek Keong\u00a0CJ (delivering the judgment of the court):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Introduction</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_1\"/>1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The appellant in this appeal was at all material times an insurer that offered insurance policies known as \u201cinvestment-linked policies\u201d. Each investment-linked policy offered by the appellant (referred to hereafter in the singular as \u201cILP\u201d and in the plural as \u201cILPs\u201d) provided a cover on the life of the insured and allowed the policyholder to invest the premiums in the appellant\u2019s investment funds. The appellant was at all material times the trustee of all the units in its investment funds.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_2\"/>2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The respondents in this appeal were policyholders/investors in the ILPs. A dispute arose between the respondents and the appellant around June 2008 concerning the ILPs, culminating in the filing of a suit (\u201cthe Suit\u201d) by the appellant, in its own capacity as well as in its capacity as trustee for other policyholders, against the respondents. After the filing of the Suit, the respondents\u2019 investments in the ILPs were liquidated and the proceeds (\u201cthe Stake\u201d) were held in a joint stakeholder\u2019s account pending the resolution of the Suit. The respondents subsequently requested for the release of certain sums of moneys from that account but the appellant refused to accede to the request.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_3\"/>3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In response, the respondents brought an application for interim payment of certain sums of money (\u201cthe Application\u201d). This appeal arose from the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) on the Application. In his decision, the Judge ordered an interim payment of $1,019,300 to the respondents (see <em>American International Assurance Co Ltd v Wong Cherng Yaw</em> <nobr>[2009] SGHC 89</nobr> (\u201cthe GD\u201d)). Before proceeding further, it would be apposite to summarise the salient facts of this dispute.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Background facts</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_4\"/>4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The first and second respondents were agents of the appellant and sold ILPs to the third to tenth respondents. The sixth to tenth respondents subsequently assigned their ILPs to the first to fifth respondents. The respondents collectively invested a total of $1,059,300 under 21 ILPs with the appellant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_5\"/>5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Under each of the ILPs, premiums paid by the policyholder were used to invest in units in funds listed in a \u201cSchedule of Funds\u201d annexed to each of the contracts. The funds listed differed between different ILPs. The number of units in a fund which a policyholder could purchase with any given sum under an ILP depended on the price at which the units were to be issued. When a policyholder liquidated his or her units in the fund, the proceeds due to the policyholder were determined by the price at which the units were to be redeemed. Under the ILPs, policyholders were also entitled to switch between funds as many times as they wanted, chargeable at $25 for every switch after the first four switches which were free. These fund switches were done by the policyholders submitting a formal request to the appellant. The policyholder\u2019s right to switch funds was set out in each of the ILPs as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"center\"><b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 FUND SWITCH</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[The policyholder] may, from time to time, instruct [the appellant] to switch all or any of the Units of a Fund via a Fund Switch in writing in such manner and subject to such conditions as [the appellant] may from time to time impose. [The appellant] reserve[s] the right to revise at any time in [its] discretion any minimum fund switch amount imposed and to terminate or suspend this Fund Switch facility. [The appellant] shall not be responsible for any losses arising from or attributable to [its] decision to terminate or suspend this facility.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">...</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[The policyholder has] 4 free switches per policy year, and the switches thereafter shall be subject to a Fund Switch Fee of S$25 per switch payable by [the policyholder] through the cancellation of Units. No Fund Switch Fee, however, will be payable on any fund switch into or out of the AIA S$ Money Market Fund [which was one of the funds from which policyholders could choose]. Any unused free switches will be forfeited at the end of the policy year.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_6\"/>6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Through numerous fund switches over the course of two years from July 2006 to August 2008, the respondents were able to make large profits. Their investments peaked on 7\u00a0August 2008 with the ILPs valued at a total of $18,759,523.27, giving the respondents a paper gain of $17,700,223.27, representing a 1,671% rate of return.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_7\"/>7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0According to the third respondent, Mr\u00a0Lim Wee Chee, in his affidavit filed on 13\u00a0October 2008 on behalf of the other respondents, he purchased his first ILP effective from 24\u00a0March 2006 and incurred losses within the first few months. He started analysing the fund movements and their underlying markets. By keeping up with the trends of fund prices, he was able to take calculated risks by switching from one fund to another to avoid adverse fluctuations in prices and to ride on positive trends. He alone made more than 300 fund switches over the span of two years. The other respondents also made similar fund switches in reliance on his decisions.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_8\"/>8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0On 8\u00a0August 2008, the third respondent applied to withdraw $495,420 from one of his ILPs. The appellant refused to allow the withdrawal. Attempts by the third respondent and other respondents subsequently to partially withdraw or surrender their ILPs were similarly unsuccessful. Furthermore, the respondents\u2019 applications made from 25\u00a0August 2008 to 29\u00a0August 2008 to switch funds were rejected.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_9\"/>9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Eventually, the third respondent\u2019s solicitors wrote to the appellant on 3\u00a0September 2008 demanding payment of the partial withdrawal that the third respondent had sought. After an exchange of correspondence, the appellant commenced the Suit. The basis of the Suit, that emerged later, was that the appellant had made a mistake in valuing the funds by using one-day-old bid prices (unit prices) to effect the fund switches and this resulted in the respondents being given a larger share of the units or liquidated proceeds than what they should have been entitled to, at the expense of other policyholders. In support of the appellant\u2019s case, Mr\u00a0Martin Knight (\u201cMr\u00a0Knight\u201d), the appellant\u2019s vice-president of the Actuary Department, filed an affidavit on 21\u00a0November 2008, in which he explained the mistake and how it led to the respondents making enormous gains artificially from the switches.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_10\"/>10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The appellant claims that the respondents had knowingly exploited the mistake <em>vis-\u00e0-vis</em> the bid prices. The appellant investigated the respondents\u2019 fund switching activities between March 2008 and May 2008 but the appellant\u2019s case is that it did not discover its mistake at that time. According to Mr\u00a0Knight\u2019s affidavit, the appellant only realised its mistake in late July 2008 when it looked into the large amounts being switched and the excessively high returns recorded under the respondents\u2019 ILPs.<span class=\"FootnoteRef\"><a id=\"Ftn_1_1\" href=\"#Ftn_1\"><sup>[note: 1]</sup></a></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_11\"/>11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In its written submissions before the Judge, the appellant contended as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_a\"/>(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the appellant had made a mistake in valuing the relevant funds by using one-day-old bid prices in determining the bid prices for the fund switches and that the respondents had been unjustly enriched by exploiting the appellant\u2019s mistake in determining the bid prices for the fund switches;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_b\"/>(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the respondents had exploited the appellant\u2019s mistake, and thereby knowingly caused a loss of about $11,040,000 to the other policyholders;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_c\"/>(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the respondents were liable as constructive trustees for the loss and damage caused to the other policyholders;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_d\"/>(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the respondents were liable to the appellant for damages for tortious conspiracy;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_e\"/>(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the first and second respondents were in breach of their fiduciary duties and contracts to the appellant in their capacity as agents of the appellant;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_f\"/>(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the appellant was entitled to an account and an inquiry to trace and recover the units and/or the proceeds on liquidating the units;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_g\"/>(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the appellant was entitled to recover the sums of $239,945.50 and $189,490.93 previously paid out to the second and fourth respondents respectively; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><a id=\"p1_11-p2_h\"/>(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the appellant was entitled to an indemnity from the respondents for any liability that the appellant might incur to the other policyholders.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_12\"/>12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0After the Suit was filed on 9\u00a0September 2008, the respondents agreed with the appellant on 22\u00a0October 2008 to liquidate their positions in the ILPs they held on a \u201cwithout prejudice\u201d basis. As a result, the proceeds of liquidation amounting to $10,323,621.71, <em>ie</em>, the Stake, were put in a joint stakeholder\u2019s account pending the disposal of the Suit. The appeal before us stemmed from the Application, which was for, <em>inter alia</em>, the following orders:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">Without prejudice to the parties\u2019 respective positions in the Suit, the [appellant] do release to the [respondents] an interim payment in the sum of:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">a.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0$1,579,098.65 being the sums [sought by the respondents through their request for partial withdrawal and/or full surrender of the ILPs they held]; or alternatively</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">b.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0$1,059,300 being the [respondents\u2019] capital invested with the [appellant]; or alternatively</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">c.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0such other sum as the [c]ourt shall deem fit.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_13\"/>13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The respondents took out the Application as they claimed they needed the money to repay the bank loans which they had taken to invest in the ILPs and that they needed funds to obtain expert evidence on the disputed issues and to pay for legal services to conduct the current litigation.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">The rules on interim payment</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong>Order 29 rule 2</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_14\"/>14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Before the Judge below, counsel for the respondents decided not to ground his submissions on O\u00a029 r\u00a011 or r\u00a012 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Rules\u201d), which pertains specifically to interim payments. Instead, he invoked the court\u2019s inherent jurisdiction, and, in the alternative, O\u00a029 r\u00a02(4). We can immediately dismiss as irrelevant O\u00a029 r\u00a02 (which relates to the detention, custody or preservation of any property which is the subject matter of a cause or matter) since the parties have already placed the liquidated proceeds with a stakeholder on a \u201cwithout prejudice\u201d basis.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong>Order\u00a029 rule\u00a012(<em>c</em>)</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_15\"/>15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Despite counsel for the respondents\u2019 decision not to ground his submissions on O\u00a029 r\u00a011 or r\u00a012 of the Rules, the Judge considered the Application under O\u00a029 r\u00a012(<em>c</em>) and made an order for interim payment, which is the subject matter of this appeal. Order\u00a029 r\u00a012 provides as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>Order for interim payment in respect of sums other than damages (O. 29, r. 12)</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>12</b>.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If, on the hearing of an application under Rule 10, the Court is satisfied \u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>a</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the plaintiff has obtained an order for an account to be taken as between himself and the defendant and for any amount certified due on taking the account to be paid;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>b</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that the plaintiff\u2019s action includes a claim for possession of land and, if the action proceeded to trial, the defendant would be held liable to pay to the plaintiff a sum of money in respect of the defendant\u2019s use and occupation of the land during the pendency of the action, even if a final judgment or order were given or made in favour of the defendant; or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>c</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0that, <em>if the action proceeded to trial, the plaintiff would obtain judgment against the defendant for a substantial sum of money apart from any damages or costs</em>,</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">the Court may, if it thinks fit, and without prejudice to any contentions of the parties as to the nature or character of the sum to be paid by the defendant, order the defendant to make an interim payment of such amount as it thinks just, after taking into account any set-off, cross-claim or counterclaim on which the defendant may be entitled to rely.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong>The Judge\u2019s application of Order\u00a029 rule\u00a012(<em>c</em>)</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_16\"/>16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0With reference to the judgment of Neill\u00a0LJ in <em>Schott Kem Ltd v Bentley</em> [1991] 1\u00a0QB 61 (\u201c<em>Schott Kem</em>\u201d), the Judge applied a two-stage test to determine whether to order an interim payment under O\u00a029 r\u00a012(<em>c</em>) of the Rules. Having regard to the evidence before him, he was satisfied that the respondents would obtain judgment for a substantial sum, after taking into account the claims of the appellant. He then decided that he was justified in exercising his discretion to order interim payment of $1,019,300 to the respondents. In the course of reaching his decision, the Judge also commented on the English Court of Appeal decision in <em>Shanning International Ltd v George Wimpey International Ltd</em> [1989] 1\u00a0WLR 981 (\u201c<em>Shanning</em>\u201d). The Judge read <em>Shanning</em> as having decided that any independent counterclaim was <em>also</em> a relevant consideration at the <em>first</em> stage (see the GD at <a href=\"#p1_23\">[23]</a>), and expressed his dissent from such approach. He took the view that, in an application under O\u00a029 r\u00a012(<em>c</em>), the court should consider, under the first stage, any defences and counterclaims which qualify as set-offs, but not <em>all</em> counterclaims.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_17\"/>17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In our view, it may well have been unnecessary for the Judge to have disagreed with <em>Shanning</em>. In <em>Civil Procedure 2009</em>, vol\u00a02 (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 2009) (\u201cthe English White Book\u201d), the authors explained the effect of <em>Shanning</em> in this manner (at para\u00a015-103):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">The application should be considered by the court in two stages (<em>Schott Kem Ltd v Bentley</em> [1991] 1\u00a0Q.B. 61; [1990] 3 All E.R. 850, CA). The court must first be satisfied that, if the action proceeds to trial, the claimant will obtain judgment for a substantial sum, and, if so, the court should then consider whether, in its discretion, it should order an interim payment. At the first stage the claimant must satisfy the court on the balance of probabilities, but to a high standard, that he will obtain judgment for a substantial sum; <em>the likelihood of a set-off or any other defence succeeding must be considered by the court</em>. At the second stage the rules also require \u2026 the court to take into account any set-off claimed by the defendant, <em>and any counterclaim arising out of some other transaction and not available as a defence</em> (<em>Shanning International Ltd v George Wimpey International Ltd</em> [1988] [<em>sic</em>] 1\u00a0W.L.R. 981; [1988] 3\u00a0All E.R. 475, CA). [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_18\"/>18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The authors of the English White Book do not appear to read <em>Shanning</em> to hold that independent counterclaims should be considered by the court at the first stage. However, the authors of <em>Commercial Litigation: Pre-Emptive Remedies</em> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 4th\u00a0Ed, 2002, Looseleaf, Release\u00a09, April 2007) (Iain S\u00a0Goldrein\u00a0QC ed) hold a contrary view (see para\u00a0A6-185). There is also another English Court of Appeal decision, namely, <em>Smallman Construction Ltd v Redpath Dorman Long Ltd</em> (1988) 47\u00a0BLR 15, which expressed the view that independent counterclaims must be considered by the court at both the <em>first</em> stage and second stage.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_19\"/>19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It is not necessary for this court to decide what the true position under our O\u00a029 r\u00a012(<em>c</em>) is at present. In our view, the result would be the same in relation to the Application, regardless of the approach adopted.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Our decision</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_20\"/>20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Were the respondents entitled to obtain judgment for a substantial sum of money on the evidence before the court? The Judge held that they were, because even after taking into account the appellant\u2019s cross-claims against the respondents\u2019 claims, there would still be a substantial sum left from the Stake representing the capital of their investments in the ILPs (their \u201ccapital investment\u201d). The respondents were entitled to recover their capital unless the appellant could show that it had a genuine claim on those moneys. As the appellant\u2019s claim was effectively based on the respondents\u2019 alleged unjust enrichment, the claim, even if successful, would not have an impact on the respondents\u2019 claim to the return of their capital investment.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_21\"/>21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Before us, the appellant argued that the Judge erred in his reasoning as the respondents\u2019 investments in the ILPs were not capital guaranteed. Counsel for the appellant also submitted that the amounts prayed for in the appellant\u2019s cross-claims could exceed the Stake. He referred to the affidavit filed on 21\u00a0November 2008 of Mr\u00a0Knight, who had estimated the loss suffered by the other policyholders (as a result of the dilution of their positions due to the respondents\u2019 fund switches) to be about $11m.<span class=\"FootnoteRef\"><a id=\"Ftn_2_1\" href=\"#Ftn_2\"><sup>[note: 2]</sup></a></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_22\"/>22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Counsel also contended that the interim payment procedure in O\u00a029 r\u00a012 of the Rules was not appropriate where the factual issues were complicated or where difficult points of law arose, as in the present case (see the English White Book (<a href=\"#p1_17\">[17]</a> <em>supra</em>) at para\u00a015-95 citing <em>Schott Kem</em> (<a href=\"#p1_16\">[16]</a> <em>supra</em>), <em>Chiron Corporation v Murex Diagnostics Limited (No\u00a013)</em> (1996) 23\u00a0FSR 578 (\u201c<em>Chiron</em>\u201d) and <em>Bovis Lend Lease Ltd v Braehead Glasgow Ltd</em> (2000) 71\u00a0Con LR 208).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_23\"/>23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We are in agreement with this submission. This case does disclose, on the face of the pleadings, sufficient complex issues of fact and law to require a full trial to resolve them. However, this factor alone would not prevent the court from ordering an interim payment in respect of \u201cpart of a complex claim where (without venturing too far into disputed areas of fact or law) there is evidence establishing with reasonable certainty the minimum sum likely to be recoverable\u201d (English White Book at para\u00a015-113 citing <em>Chiron per</em> Robert Walker\u00a0J at 584). It is necessary to note that, in the present case, it is <em>not</em> the appellant\u2019s case that the respondents are not entitled to the return of their capital investment. The appellant\u2019s case is that there might be no capital to be returned, because of its cross-claims and, further, because the capital was not guaranteed. Its counsel submitted that its cross-claims might exceed the Stake. This submission is speculative because the only claim of the appellant that would affect the amount of the capital investment returnable to the respondents would be general damages which the appellant has claimed in respect of the alleged conspiracy to injure the appellant. But beyond recovering what the other policyholders have allegedly lost from the appellant\u2019s own mistake, it is difficult to see what loss the appellant itself has suffered on its own account. Accordingly, while it is relevant, we are not prepared to place too much weight on this submission.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_24\"/>24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0If, as here, the respondents are entitled to recover their capital investment, which itself is a substantial sum, it is our view that the burden is on the appellant to satisfy the court why it should not order interim payment of any sum that is in law repayable to the respondents. The court should try to assess the irreducible sum that can be paid in the exercise of its discretion. The respondents should not be denied their own moneys to defend what appears to be a complex (and therefore costly) case on law and finance. Of course, it is possible that the court, in exercising its discretion to order interim payment, may err in paying out too much. The interim payment scheme under O\u00a029 of the Rules provides for such a contingency, as O\u00a029 r\u00a017 states as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>Adjustment on final judgment or order or on discontinuance (O.\u00a029, r.\u00a017)</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>17</b>.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Where a defendant has been ordered to make an interim payment or has in fact made an interim payment, whether voluntarily or pursuant to an order, the Court may, in giving or making a final judgment or order, or granting the plaintiff leave to discontinue his action or to withdraw the claim in respect of which the interim payment has been made, or at any other stage of the proceedings on the application of any party, make such order with respect to the interim payment as may be just, and in particular\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>a</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an order for the repayment by the plaintiff of all or part of the interim payment;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>b</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an order for the payment to be varied or discharged; or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">(<em>c</em>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0an order for the payment by any other defendant of any part of the interim payment which the defendant who made it is entitled to recover from him by way of contribution or indemnity or in respect of any remedy or relief relating to or connected with the plaintiff's claim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Order\u00a029 r\u00a017 shows that the role of the court in an application under O\u00a029 r\u00a012(<em>c</em>) is primarily to determine liability first. If the court makes a mistake in the amount awarded under an interim payment, it has wide powers under O\u00a029 r\u00a017 to make the necessary adjustment in the final judgment or order. The court will be mindful that, in making an interim payment award, it must take into account the applicant\u2019s ability to repay should a mistake in the amount awarded occur (see the English White Book at para\u00a015-106).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_25\"/>25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We turn now to the facts on record. The appellant has conceded that the amount of money it can recover from the respondents, based on its claim for unjust enrichment by the respondents, would be the amount to which the respondents have been unjustly enriched. Mr\u00a0Knight made this point clear in his affidavit filed on 21\u00a0November 2008, where he said:<span class=\"FootnoteRef\"><a id=\"Ftn_3_1\" href=\"#Ftn_3\"><sup>[note: 3]</sup></a></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">The [respondents\u2019] \u201cgains\u201d were made at the expense of other policyholders who held units in the Affected funds at relevant times during the Frequent Fund Switching Period (hereinafter referred to as the \u201cAffected Policyholders\u201d).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">These gains are now comprised in: (a)\u00a0the amount of the Stake; and (b)\u00a0the sum of $429,436.43 (which includes the capital sum of $40,000) withdrawn by the second and fourth respondents under two ILPs. However, the Stake would also include the capital investment of the respondents which amounted to $1,019,300 (being the balance of the initial total investment of $1,059,300, after taking into account the $40,000 capital withdrawn earlier). The Judge ordered the sum of $1,019,300 to be paid out to the respondents because the appellant had conceded that the respondents were entitled to the return of their capital.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_26\"/>26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Before us, the appellant advanced two arguments that the Judge was wrong in ordering interim payment of the capital sum of $1,019,300. The first is that it has a claim for damages for conspiracy, and, if successful, it will be entitled to set off the damages against the capital sum in the Stake. The second is that the investments are not capital guaranteed, and therefore the capital sum might not be $1,019,300 at the material time (which has yet to be determined).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_27\"/>27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0As to the first argument, counsel admitted that he was unable to estimate what the damages were likely to be. We have earlier indicated that we are not persuaded of the prospect of the appellant being able to prove that it had suffered substantial loss personally, given that the real basis of the appellant\u2019s claim appeared to rest on unjust enrichment (the amount of which claim is now preserved in the Stake). However, counsel has also suggested that the appellant would have to incur considerable costs and expenses in pursuing the Suit in the form of expert and legal services. We do not think that costs and expenses are matters that the court is obliged to take into account at this stage of the proceedings or for the purposes of determining the amount of an interim payment order. They are speculative, as the appellant may not succeed in its claim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_28\"/>28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There is another way of looking at the relative rights of the appellant and the respondents with respect to their capital investment. The respondents are entitled to recover their capital investment (although the appellant has argued that the ILPs are not capital guaranteed). But subject to any such capital loss as may be proved and to any sum which might be awarded to the appellant on its claim for damages for conspiracy, the appellant has effectively been given a security for its claim on the respondents\u2019 capital investment. The position is analogous to that of the appellant having obtained a Mareva injunction to freeze the assets of the respondents to meet its claim. As pointed out by counsel for the respondents, even in a Mareva injunction scenario, the affected party would be entitled to withdraw sufficient funds from the \u201cfrozen\u201d funds to defray his legal and other expenses in order to defend the action against him. We think there is substance in this argument. Indeed, if the appellant had applied for a Mareva injunction in the circumstances of this case, we do not think that such an injunction would have been granted. There is no reason why the appellant should have the benefit of what is, in effect, a Mareva injunction in the light of the circumstances of this case.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_29\"/>29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0As to the argument based on the potential loss of capital, the appellant has contended that, had the correct bid prices been applied at all material times, the value of the respondents\u2019 ILPs as at 31\u00a0July 2008 (being the last dealing day in which one-day-old bid prices were used for all the relevant funds) would have stood at $994,999 and would have dropped to $566,604 when the ILPs were finally liquidated on 22\u00a0October 2008. Like the Judge, we are also of the view that the relevance of these computations is dubious. What the true figure would have been is entirely speculative because any such figure would have to be based on the assumption that the respondents would have switched and continued to switch funds if the appellant had used the correct bid prices at all material times. It should be borne in mind that the appellant\u2019s case is that the respondents knew that the appellant had made a mistake in its terms of switching and that the respondents had taken advantage of the mistake. But when did this take place? Since the appellant is claiming that the respondents had been unjustly enriched by their fraudulent or tortious switches, the court will need to know the relevant date or dates from which the unjust enrichment is alleged to have started. The appellant has not identified the starting point of time but has only pleaded that the switching activities started sometime in July 2006 and continued until August 2008. Against this background of the appellant\u2019s claims and the pleadings, it is not necessary at this stage of the proceedings to decide whether counsel or the Judge is right. What we have on record are three figures that the appellant has produced in evidence, <em>viz</em>: (a)\u00a0$1,059,300 (less $40,000); (b)\u00a0$994,999 (as at 31\u00a0July 2008); and (c)\u00a0$566,604 (as at 22\u00a0October 2008).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_30\"/>30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0As the appellant has failed to show <em>prima facie</em> that the amount that it is likely to be able to recover would be more than the Stake (after taking into account the respondents\u2019 capital investment), we consider it proper and reasonable to exercise our discretion in favour of the respondents and to order interim payment of as much money as is prudent, having regard to the relative strengths of the claims of the parties to the respondents\u2019 capital investment, and also the capacity of the respondents to repay any amount that might eventually turn out to be overpaid. In our view, we consider that a lump sum of $600,000 would be fair to both parties, as there is no evidence to suggest that each of the respondents would not be good for up to the amount of $60,000. We therefore propose to vary the Judge\u2019s interim payment order accordingly, subject to any order necessary under O\u00a029 r\u00a017 upon the final determination of the issues in the Suit.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_31\"/>31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Before we conclude our judgment, we would like to make an observation on one aspect of the Judge\u2019s decision in order to clarify a matter which is obviously a matter of grave concern to the appellant. The Judge, in ordering interim payment, had also embarked on a construction of the provisions in the ILPs (see the GD at [46]\u2013[49]) that pertained to fund switching (\u201cthe Switching Provisions\u201d) and had come to the conclusion that the appellant had not made any mistake, as it had alleged, in allowing the respondents to switch funds applying one-day-old bid prices (see the GD at [46]\u2013[53]). However, as this interpretation would completely undermine the appellant\u2019s claims, the appellant has raised this issue for the decision of this court. Its contention was that the Judge\u2019s construction of the Switching Provisions was wrong. In our view, we regard the Judge\u2019s determination on the construction of the Switching Provisions as <em>obiter</em> as it was not necessary for him to embark upon this exercise since the order for interim payment could have been justified on the amounts conceded by the appellant as being recoverable by the respondents from their capital investment (see <a href=\"#p1_29\">[29]</a> above). In fact, the Judge had relied on this latter ground and the construction of the Switching Provisions was merely an alternative basis for the interim payment order made by him. We therefore do not propose to examine this issue at this stage of the proceedings. We have indicated to counsel for the appellant that this issue should be determined at the substantive hearing of the Suit.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Conclusion</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_32\"/>32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0For the above reasons, we order that the sum of $600,000 be paid to the respondents as interim payment. As the appeal has, in substance, been dismissed, costs are awarded to the respondents with the usual consequential orders.</p>\n\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><sup><a id=\"Ftn_1\" href=\"#Ftn_1_1\">[note: 1]</a></sup>At para 20.7.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><sup><a id=\"Ftn_2\" href=\"#Ftn_2_1\">[note: 2]</a></sup>At para 8.4.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><sup><a id=\"Ftn_3\" href=\"#Ftn_3_1\">[note: 3]</a></sup>At para 8.4.</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government   </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2364\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Insurance</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2378\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Liability insurance</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Indemnity</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">'All risk' policy</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Third party claims</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Insured causing damage to property resulting in loss to third party</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">Insured subsequently wound up</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"9\">Judgment obtained by third party against insured</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"10\">Action by third party against insurers for judgment sum</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"11\">Insurer aware of third party's claim against insured but not getting involved</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"12\">Whether judgment between insured and third party binding on insurer</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"13\">Third's party right of subrogation</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"14\">Whether insurer may reopen issue of amount of third party's loss or liability</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"15\">s 1(1) Third Parties (Rights against Insurers) Act (Cap 395, 1994 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>395) \u2013 Construction of s 1(1) \u2013 Whether earlier judgment binding on insurer\n\n\u2013 Whether s 1(1) requires third party to prove the extent of the insured\u2019s\n\nliability once again</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <b><p align=\"justify\"/></b>The respondents, Chiu Teng, were the main contractors of a\n\n  housing development know as \"The Countryside\" (the \"estate\"). Sometime\n\n  in early January 1996, Brentford Construction, which was carrying out construction work at\n\n  an adjacent lot to the estate, caused damage to some of the houses in the estate. As a\n\n  result of the damage, Chiu Teng had to carry out rectification works and sought to recover\n\n  the loss it suffered on account of the rectification works from Brentford. On 24 April\n\n  1998, Brentford was wound up by an order of court and the Official Receiver was appointed\n\n  as liquidator. In view of Brentford\u2019s winding up, Chiu Teng had to obtain leave of\n\n  court to commence proceedings against it. On 11 May 1999, an interlocutory judgment was\n\n  obtained with the consent of the Official Receiver. On 30 May, judgment for the sum of $\n\n  466,600.08 was granted to Chui Teng. Hartford who was informed of this action chose not to\n\n  get involved as it felt that it was not liable to Brentford under the policy. \n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Chiu Teng, in reliance of s 1(1) of the Third party (Rights against\n\n  Insurers) Act commenced the present action against Hartford seeking payment of the\n\n  judgment sum. In the court below, Harford raised two main lines of defence. The first line\n\n  related to policy defences which the court ruled was without any merits. The second line\n\n  of defence was that the judgment sum obtained by Chiu Teng against Brentford was not\n\n  binding on Hartford and that Chiu Teng should prove all over again the quantum of the\n\n  loss. In this defence, Hartford did not dispute Brentford\u2019s liability to Chiu Teng,\n\n  but only the reasonableness of the latter\u2019s claim. The trial judge held that Hartford\n\n  was, by virtue of the earlier judgment, estopped from challenging the extent of liability\n\n  or the quantum which the court had held Brentford to be liable to Chiu Teng. This was\n\n  because under the insurance policy, Brentford was entitled to be indemnified by Hartford\n\n  as to the judgment sum. Since under s1(1) of the Act, following the winding up of\n\n  Brentford, Chiu Teng stepped into the shoes of Brentford, Chiu Teng should similarly be\n\n  entitled to be indemnified by Hartford. Hartford appealed against the trial judge\u2019s\n\n  ruling that the earlier judgment obtained by Chiu Teng against Brentford was binding and\n\n  conclusive as against Hartford. It contended that estoppel does not apply in the present\n\n  case and that it is entitled to question the quantum of the loss suffered by Chiu Teng.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\"><strong>Held</strong>, dismissing the appeal :</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(1) A judgment is generally only binding as between the parties to the\n\n  action, except in the case of an express indemnity given by a third party to a party to\n\n  the action: see Mercantile Investment &amp; General Trust. At common law, Chiu Teng would\n\n  have no claim against Hartford, the insurer: Re Harrington Motor Co [1928] 1 Ch 105.\n\n  However, because of the winding up of Brentford, s 1(1) enables Chiu Teng to step into the\n\n  shoes of Brentford. Brentford\u2019s right to be indemnified in respect of the liability\n\n  is, under s 1(1), transferred to Chiu Teng. ( 25 \u2013 26)</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) It is not open to Hartford, who was notified of the previous\n\n  action, to reopen the question of quantum of loss. Judgment had already been obtained on\n\n  that. To permit such a challenge as to the extent of liability of Brentford to Chiu Teng,\n\n  and consequently the quantum thereof, would risk there being an inconsistent judgment and\n\n  the insured being indemnified less (or none at all) than what the policy provides. And as\n\n  by virtue of s 1(1), Chiu Teng stepped into the shoes of Brentford, Chiu Teng should be\n\n  indemnified by Hartford. There is no question of Chiu Teng being given any additional\n\n  advantage which would not be available to Brentford in any action instituted by Brentford\n\n  against Hartford. ( 24) </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) Where an insurer forms the view that he is not liable to indemnify\n\n  his insured, then he has at least two options. The first is to refuse or withdraw cover in\n\n  respect of any defence to the pursuer\u2019s action. In that event, if the third party\n\n  proceeds with his action and secures decree against the person thought to be insured, the\n\n  amount of the decree will be determinative of the liability of the insured to the third\n\n  party unless and until that decree is reduced on the grounds of, for example, fraud or\n\n  collusion. The insurer cannot normally re-open the question of the amount of the liability\n\n  in circumstances where he has declined to enter the process and fund the defence to the\n\n  action or has withdrawn his instructions and funding in the course of the action. The\n\n  question of liability between the third party and the insured has to be litigated in an\n\n  action between those two parties and a decree in that action has to be seen as a final\n\n  determination of that liability so long as the decree stands unreduced. The second option\n\n  is for the insurer to offer to instruct the defence to the action but make it clear ab\n\n  ante, or at least as soon as possible, both to the third party and the insured, that his\n\n  position is to remain that he is not liable under the policy. The choice is entirely for\n\n  the insurer. If it chooses not to intervene, then, if a judgment is obtained against the\n\n  insured, it would have to indemnify the insured if the policy defences pleaded by it\n\n  should fail. ( 28 \u2013 29)</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><strong>Cases Referred to</strong></p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Ben Shipping Co (Pte) Ltd v Ah Bord Bainne The C Joycei [1986] 2 All ER\n\n177 (distd)<br/>\n\nCheltenham &amp; Gloucester plc v Royal Sun Alliance Insurance Co (unreported, delivered\n\non 30 May 2001) (not folld)<br/>\n\nMercantile Investment &amp; General Trust Co v River Plate Trust, Loan and Agency Co\n\n[1894] 1 Ch 578 (distd)<br/>\n\nParker v Lewis [1873] 8 Chancery App 1035 (folld)<br/>\n\nPost Office v Norwich Union Fire Insurance Society Ltd [1967] 1 All ER (refd)<br/>\n\nRe Harrington Motor Co [1982] 1 Ch 105 (refd)<br/>\n\nTee Liam Toh v National Employer\u2019s Mutual General Insurance Association Ltd\n\n(unreported, OM No 50 of 1963) (refd)<br/>\n\nWest Wake Price &amp; Co v Ching [1957] 1 WLR 45 (refd)</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><strong>Legislation Referred to</strong></p>\n\n<p>Application of English Law Act (Cap 7A)<br/>\n\nThird Parties (Rights Against Insurers) Act (Cap 395) s 1(1)<b/></p>\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font color=\"#000080\" size=\"4\"><strong>Judgment</strong></font></p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font color=\"#800000\"><strong><u>GROUNDS OF DECISION</u></strong></font></p>\n\n<font size=\"4\">\n\n<p/></font>1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This is an appeal by an insurer, Hartford Insurance Co\n\n(Singapore) Ltd, against a decision of the High Court which held that Hartford is liable\n\nto indemnify an injured third party, the respondents, under an \"all risk\" policy\n\n(the policy). The issue which arose for consideration concerns the construction of s 1(1)\n\nof the English Third Parties (Rights against Insurers) Act 1930 (the 1930 Act), which\n\nstatute was made applicable in Singapore by virtue of the Application of English Law Act\n\n(Cap 7A).\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nThe background</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The facts of the case are quite straightforward. The respondents,\n\nChiu Teng Construction Co Pte Ltd (\"Chiu Teng\"), were the main contractors of a\n\nhousing development located at the junction of Yio Chu Kang Road and Lentor Avenue known\n\nas \"The Countryside\" (the \"estate\"). Sometime in early January 1996,\n\nthe insured under the policy, Brentford Construction (S) Pte Ltd (\"Brentford\"),\n\nwas carrying out sheet-pile extraction works at an adjacent lot to the estate. These works\n\ncaused soil movement which resulted in damage to some of the houses in the estate. Because\n\nof that, rectification works had to be carried out by Chiu Teng, which included the\n\ninstallation of some 30 micropiles as foundation supports for the boundary walls and\n\nretaining walls of the affected houses. Chiu Teng\u2019s engineer had doubts whether the\n\nfrictional resistance of the existing foundation would be adequate to secure the\n\nstructures and thus advised that the micropiles be installed. The costs of this item alone\n\namounted to slightly more than 50% of the total expenses incurred by Chiu Teng in relation\n\nto the rectification works.</p>\n\n<p>3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under the terms of the policy, Hartford agreed to indemnify\n\nBrentford against \"such sums which Brentford shall become legally liable to pay as\n\ndamages\" consequent upon accidental loss or damage to property belonging to third\n\nparties occurring in direct connection with the construction or erection works carried out\n\nby Brentford. Hartford also agreed, in respect of a claim for compensation to which the\n\nindemnity applied, that it would, in addition, indemnify Brentford against all costs and\n\nexpenses of litigation which Brentford had to pay to the third party claimant.</p>\n\n<p>4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 24 April 1998, Brentford was wound up by an order of court,\n\nwith the Official Receiver being appointed liquidator. Chiu Teng sought to recover the\n\nloss it suffered on account of the rectification works from Brentford. In view of\n\nBrentford\u2019s winding up, on 12 February 1999, leave of court was obtained by Chiu Teng\n\nto commence proceedings against it. A writ was duly issued on 16 March 1999. On 11 May\n\n1999, an interlocutory judgment was obtained with the consent of the Official Receiver. On\n\n30 May 2000, an assessment of damages was conducted. Witnesses were called on behalf of\n\nChiu Teng. The Official Receiver chose not to participate in the assessment. Judgment for\n\nthe sum of $466,600.08 was granted to Chiu Teng, with interest at 6% p.a. from the date on\n\nwhich the writ was served on Brentford (collectively referred to as \"the judgment\n\nsum\"). We should add that Hartford was informed of this action but chose not to get\n\ninvolved as it felt it was not liable to Brentford under the policy. For convenience, this\n\njudgment shall hereinafter be referred to as \"the earlier judgment\".</p>\n\n<p>5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 11 August 2000, in reliance on s 1(1) of the 1930 Act, Chiu\n\nTeng commenced the present action against Hartford seeking payment of the judgment sum.</p>\n\n<p>6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the court below, Hartford raised two main lines of defence. The\n\nfirst line related to policy defences (i.e., that the damage caused did not fall within\n\nthe scope of the policy), which the court below ruled were without any merits. Of course,\n\nif the court had held in favour of Hartford on these defences, then Chiu Teng, who stepped\n\ninto the shoes of Brentford, could have no better claim against Hartford. A related\n\ndefence, based on limitation, also failed. We need say no more on these policy defences\n\nbecause before us Hartford is not challenging these rulings of the court below.</p>\n\n<p>7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second line of defence was that the judgment sum obtained by\n\nChiu Teng against Brentford was not binding on Hartford and, that Chiu Teng should prove\n\nall over again the quantum of their loss. In this defence, Hartford did not dispute\n\nBrentford's liability to Chiu Teng, but only the reasonableness of the latter's claim and,\n\nspecifically, it said that it was wholly unnecessary for Chiu Teng to install the\n\nmicropiles and that the costs incurred thereby should be irrecoverable.</p>\n\n<p>8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge below, Woo Bih Li JC, also rejected this second line of\n\ndefence. He held that Hartford was, by virtue of the earlier judgment, estopped from\n\nchallenging the extent of liability or the quantum which the court had held Brentford to\n\nbe liable to Chiu Teng. It was unnecessary for Chiu Teng to establish all over again the\n\nreasonableness of its claim. His reasoning was simply this: under the policy, Brentford\n\nwas entitled to be indemnified by Hartford as to the judgment sum and as under s 1(1) of\n\nthe 1930 Act, following the winding up of Brentford, Chiu Teng stepped into the shoes of\n\nBrentford, Chiu Teng should similarly be entitled to be indemnified by Hartford.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nAppeal</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, the main contention of Hartford is that the judge below\n\nerred when he held that the earlier judgment obtained by Chiu Teng against Brentford was\n\nbinding and conclusive as against Hartford. It argued that such a decision would require\n\nan insurer to engage itself in legal proceedings even before it is established that the\n\ninsurer is liable to indemnify the insured in respect of the losses allegedly caused by\n\nthe insured to a third party. This could not be correct. Unnecessary costs would thereby\n\nhave to be incurred by the insurer and this, in turn, would have a detrimental effect on\n\ninsureds in general, as it could lead to an escalation of premiums payable.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nThe authorities</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The starting point for the consideration of the issue must be the\n\ncase <i>Parker v Lewis</i> [1873] 8 Chancery App 1035 where the facts were somewhat\n\ncomplicated. The case involved the directors of a bank and two related companies in a\n\nscheme to deceive the Stock Exchange by making it appear that one of the two companies had\n\nmoneys which it did not have and to also make it appear that the company had allotted\n\n40,000 shares which were paid for and which was not the case. The scheme was intended to\n\ndeceive all the persons, who might be induced by means of that sham, into taking up shares\n\nin the company. Shareholders of the bank brought an action against the directors of the\n\nbank for an indemnity. The substantive decision of the case concerned a procedural point\n\nas to the proper party to bring an action on behalf of the company. However, Mellish LJ\n\nexpressed the following <i>obiter dicta</i> as to what an indemnifier could dispute in a\n\ncase of an express contract of indemnity:-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"I think that the law with reference to express contracts of\n\n  indemnity is, that if a person has agreed to indemnify another against a particular claim\n\n  or a particular demand, and an action is brought on that demand, he may then give notice\n\n  to the person who has agreed to indemnify him to come in and defend the action, and if he\n\n  does not come in, and refuses to come in, he may then compromise at once on the best terms\n\n  he can, and then bring an action on the contract of indemnity. On the other hand, if he\n\n  does not choose to trust the other person with the defence to the action, he may, if he\n\n  pleases, go on and defend it, and then, if the verdict is obtained against him, and\n\n  judgment signed upon it, I agree that at law that judgment, in the case of express\n\n  contract of indemnity is conclusive. But I apprehend it is conclusive on account of what\n\n  the law considers the true meaning of such a contract of indemnity to be. It is obvious\n\n  that when a person has entered into a bond, or bought land, or altered his position in any\n\n  way on the faith of a contract of indemnity, and an action is brought against him for the\n\n  matter against which he was indemnified, and a verdict of a jury obtained against him, it\n\n  would be very hard, indeed, if, when he came to claim the indemnity, the person against\n\n  whom he claimed it could fight the question over again, and run the chance of whether a\n\n  second jury would take a different view and give an opposite verdict to the first.\n\n  Therefore, by reason of that contract of indemnity, the judgment is conclusive; but in my\n\n  opinion it is conclusive because that is the meaning of the contract between the parties,\n\n  for it unquestionably is not the general rule of law that a judgment obtained by A against\n\n  B is conclusive in an action by B against C.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Post Office v Norwich Union Fire Insurance Society Ltd [</i>1967]\n\n1 All ER, the Court of Appeal reaffirmed the need for an insured (and in turn the injured\n\nthird party who steps into the shoes of the insured under s 1 of the 1930 Act) to\n\nestablish that he is legally liable to pay compensation to the third party before an\n\naction against the insurers to seek indemnity may be made. In that case the public\n\nliability policy provided that the insurer \"will indemnify (the insured) against all\n\nsums which (the insured) shall become legally liable to pay as compensation in respect of\n\n\u2026 loss of or damage to property.\" The Post Office (the third party) sued the\n\ninsurers claiming for the loss of damage in the sum of about 839, as statutory assignees\n\nof the insured by virtue of s 1(1) of the 1930 Act. The Court of Appeal noted that while\n\nthe liability of the insured to the Post Office arose at the time of the accident, the\n\n\"rights\" of the insured against the insurers did not arise at that time but\n\nhaving regard to the scope of the policy, only when the insured\u2019s liability \"to\n\nthe injured person has been established\" and, that liability must be\n\n\"ascertained and determined to exist, either by judgment of the court or by an award\n\nin an arbitration or by agreement.\" Lord Denning MR specifically addressed the\n\nprocedural problem which would arise where the insured was a company and had been wound\n\nup, as follows:-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"How is this to be done? If there is an unascertained claim for\n\n  damages in tort, it cannot be proved in the bankruptcy, nor in the liquidation of the\n\n  company; but the injured person can bring an action against the wrongdoer. In the case of\n\n  a company, he must get the leave of the court. No doubt leave would automatically be\n\n  given. The insurance company can fight that action in the name of the wrongdoer. In that\n\n  way liability can be established and the loss ascertained. Then the injured person can go\n\n  against the insurance company.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Hartford relies on the case <i>Mercantile Investment &amp;\n\nGeneral Trust Co v River Plate Trust, Loan and Agency Co</i> [1894] 1 Ch 578 to contend\n\nthat estoppel does not apply in the present case and that it is entitled to question the\n\nquantum of the loss suffered by Chiu Teng. In that case, an English company purchased the\n\nundertaking and property of an American company and covenanted to indemnify the American\n\ncompany against its debts and obligations. Pursuant to a power of compromise contained in\n\na debenture trust deed given by the American company, a resolution was passed by a\n\nmajority of the debenture holders accepting, in lieu of the debentures, shares in the\n\nEnglish company. The Mercantile Company, which did not agree with the resolution on the\n\nground that the condition necessary for the exercise of the power had not existed,\n\nabsented itself from the meeting. It subsequently sued and obtained a judgment against the\n\nAmerican company for arrears of interest due on their debentures. The English company\n\nassisted the American companies in defence of that action and even paid the costs thereof.\n\nIn a second action, the Mercantile Company, suing on behalf of all the debenture holders,\n\nsought to enforce against the English Company and the lands assigned to them by the\n\nAmerican company, the charge on such lands purported to be given by the debentures. The\n\nlands were located in Mexico. Due to an omission to effect registration of the charge,\n\nwhich registration was essential, the debenture holders thus never acquired a valid charge\n\non the land according to the law of Mexico. </p>\n\n<p>13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Romer J held that the judgment obtained by the Mercantile Company\n\ndid not estop the English company from adducing evidence to show that through\n\nnon-registration of the charge under the debenture, circumstances had existed which were\n\nsufficient to bring the power of compromise into operation and the resolution was\n\ntherefore binding on the Mercantile Company.</p>\n\n<p>14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the decision in that case is distinguishable and\n\nthis can be gleaned from the following passage of Romer J (at 595):</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"In that action the (Mercantile company) were only seeking to\n\n  enforce in this country a personal claim against the American Company; and the American\n\n  Company in their defence and counter-claim were seeking to free themselves and their\n\n  assets, including the land in question, from a personal claim and not from a claim\n\n  constituting, if established, a valid charge on the land. Nothing was decided in that\n\n  action which in any way bound the land,</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Lastly, it was said that, inasmuch as the American Company defended\n\n  with the knowledge and approval of the English Company, the latter would be estopped under\n\n  their covenant of indemnity from disputing the judgment as against the American Company\n\n  suing them on the express covenant of indemnity. That is quite true. But this is not an\n\n  action on the covenant of indemnity. The estoppel last referred to is only between the\n\n  party indemnifying and the party indemnified, and arises only by virtue of a term implied\n\n  in an express covenant of indemnity.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Apart from the peculiar features in the case, it is important to\n\nnote that there was, then, no equivalent provision to s 1(1) of the 1930 Act which the\n\ncourt there had to consider. But it would be seen that Romer J held that estoppel would\n\nhave applied if the American company were to sue the English company on the indemnity. The\n\neffect of s 1(1) is to enable Chiu Teng to step into the shoes of Brentford. On the\n\nprinciple spelt out by Romer J, if Brentford were to sue Hartford, the latter would be\n\nestopped. And since under s 1(1) Chiu Teng stepped into the shoes of Brentford, Hartford\n\nshould similarly be estopped in the action by Chiu Teng.</p>\n\n<p>16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A Malaysian case, <i>Tee Liam Toh v National Employer\u2019s\n\nMutual General Insurance Association Ltd </i>(unreported) (OM No 50 of 1963), is also\n\npertinent. There, the plaintiff who was the employer of an employee-driver, took out a\n\nworkman\u2019s compensation policy with the insurers. The driver, while loading some goods\n\ncollapsed and died of heart failure. The dependants of the driver claimed for\n\nworkmen\u2019s compensation. The employer disputed the claim. The arbitrator under the\n\nWorkmen\u2019s Compensation Ordinance ruled against the employer-plaintiff (first\n\narbitration). The plaintiff claimed for indemnity under the policy against the insurers\n\nwho resisted the claim. The dispute went before an arbitrator (second arbitration) who\n\nheld that the driver\u2019s death was due to natural causes and that the injury did not\n\narise out of or in the course of the employment. Accordingly, the insurers were held not\n\nliable to indemnify the employer-plaintiff and the latter in turn moved the High Court to\n\nhave the second award remitted for re-consideration or set aside. Ong J held that as the\n\nfirst arbitration was properly constituted and an award was given, the insurers were\n\nprecluded from raising the same question again before the second arbitration and they\n\nshould pay the employer-plaintiff in accordance with the Workmen\u2019s Compensation\n\npolicy unless they could show that the employer-plaintiff was in breach of any of the\n\nconditions of the policy. As there was an error on the face of the second award in not\n\ngiving effect to the estoppel, Ong J remitted the second award for re-consideration by the\n\narbitrator. In coming to his decision, Ong J had relied upon the views expressed by\n\nMellish LJ in <i>Parker v Lewis</i> (quoted in 10 above). He amplified his ruling as\n\nfollows:-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"\u2026 with full notice of a claim against their insured, the\n\n  insurance company elected to lift not a finger to assist their insured or protect\n\n  themselves by defending the claim. Under condition three they had the right to take over\n\n  conduct of the defence against the claim put forward by the dependants of the deceased,\n\n  and, if dissatisfied with the decision, they should have appealed. Having left their\n\n  insured to carry the burden, they nevertheless subsequently insisted on raising the very\n\n  same questions before the arbitrator which had already been decided by a competent\n\n  tribunal against their insured. Of course, they are precluded by the decision of the\n\n  learned President, as arbitrator, from agitating these questions again.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should add that counsel for Hartford does not question the\n\ndecision in <i>Tee Liam Toh</i> but only seeks to distinguish it from the present case on\n\nthe basis that in the earlier action by Chiu Teng against Brentford, the latter did not\n\ndispute the quantum of claim of Chiu Teng, whereas in <i>Teo Liam Toh</i> the questions of\n\nliability and quantum were thrashed out in the first arbitration. It is therefore\n\nnecessary for us to determine whether this distinction is really valid in the context of s\n\n1(1).</p>\n\n<p>18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are two other cases cited by Hartford which we must refer\n\nto. The first is <i>Ben Shipping Co (Pte) Ltd v An Bord Bainne The C Joyce</i> [1986] 2 All ER 177. There, cargo owners claimed damages against the shipowners for damage to cargo\n\nand short delivery. The shipowners invited the charterers to take over the defence on the\n\nbasis that under the terms of the charterparty the ultimate responsibility for the loss of\n\nthe cargo would rest with the charterers. The charterers refused to accept the invitation\n\npresumably because they did not think they had to indemnify the shipowners. The shipowners\n\nsettled the claim and sought to be indemnified by the charterers. Bingham J (as he then\n\nwas) held that the charterers were not liable under the charterparty to indemnify the\n\nshipowners. However, he went on to express the view that, even if the charterers were so\n\nliable, they were not precluded from contesting the liability of the shipowners to the\n\ncargo owners and/or the reasonableness of the settlement of the claim. We think it highly\n\nrelevant to note the conclusion of Bingham J where he said (at p. 187):-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\" \u2026 to succeed in their estoppel claim, the shipowners must\n\n  establish as a matter of law that having given notice to the charterers of the claim made\n\n  against them (the shipowners) in South Africa, and the charterers having declined to\n\n  conduct the defence, and the shipowners having compromised the claim, they (the\n\n  charterers) are estopped from contesting the liability of the shipowners to the third\n\n  party in South Africa and the reasonableness of the compromise and the incurring of costs,\n\n  <u>even though there was no express contract of indemnity and the charterers bona fide and\n\n  on reasonable grounds challenged the shipowners\u2019 right to indemnity and the claim was\n\n  settled without immediate reference to the charterers.</u> I do not think any such\n\n  principle can be clearly found in the authorities relied on. Nor do I think it desirable\n\n  to attempt to lay down such a far reaching principle. It is of course good sense and\n\n  common practice for a defendant to give notice of a claim against him and any proposed\n\n  settlement to a person against whom he intends to seek indemnity or contribution, if such\n\n  person is not joined as a third party. This gives that person the opportunity to raise any\n\n  points or objections he wishes, and will make it somewhat harder for him to raise\n\n  arguments later which he could have raised at the time. It is, however, a large stride\n\n  from a commonsense tactical practice to a rule of law. The present case is a good example\n\n  of how unfairly such a rule could work. The charterers did not (it seems reasonable to\n\n  infer) believe they were bound to indemnify the shipowners against the South African\n\n  claim. <u>Even if one assumes that they were wrong in that belief, it remains the fact\n\n  that they need have had and in all probability had no knowledge at all of how the cargo\n\n  damage occurred. Having dissociated themselves from the proceedings they knew nothing of\n\n  the terms of settlement.</u> The rule contended for would present the charterers with a\n\n  choice between taking over the defence of a claim which they believed to be nothing to do\n\n  with them and thereafter (if that belief was falsified) finding themselves bound to\n\n  indemnify the shipowners against settlement of a claim even though the claim could be\n\n  shown to be ill-founded or the settlement unreasonable. The authorities may well support,\n\n  and I can see virtue in, a much more limited principle, but that would not avail the\n\n  shipowners here.\" (emphasis added).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second is the recent Scottish case, <i>Cheltenhem &amp;\n\nGloucester plc v Royal &amp; Sun Alliance Insurance Co</i> (delivered on 30 May 2001)\n\nwhere the Inner House (Court of Session), overruling a decision of the Outer House and\n\nheld that the insurers were entitled to dispute the insured\u2019s liability to the third\n\nparty as part of a defence to a claim under the insurance policy bought by the insured,\n\neven if that liability had already been established by a court judgment. There, the\n\nplaintiffs sued a solicitor for professional negligence. The solicitor\u2019s insurers\n\ninvestigated the plaintiff\u2019s claim and, for a time, conducted the solicitor\u2019s\n\ndefence, before withdrawing from that proceeding in the belief that they could avoid\n\nliability under the policy. The solicitor did not thereafter defend the action and\n\njudgment was given against him. The Inner House held that, in those circumstances, the\n\ninsurers were entitled to dispute the insured\u2019s liability to the plaintiffs in the\n\naction brought by the plaintiffs under s 1(1) of the 1930 Act. The court, proceeding on\n\nthe basis that there was no authority on point, reasoned (at 10):-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"In other words, the pursuers\u2019 rights are co-extensive with,\n\n  but no greater than, St Clair\u2019s (the solicitor\u2019s) rights against the defenders.\n\n  That being so, the decree in the sheriff court action between the pursuers and St Clair\n\n  will be conclusive as to St Clair\u2019s liability in damages for the purposes of the\n\n  present action at the instance of the pursuers only if it would also be conclusive for the\n\n  purposes of an action against the defenders at the instance of St Clair. So, supposing\n\n  that St Clair had been found liable in damages to the pursuers in the sheriff court\n\n  action, would the defenders have been prevented from challenging that liability and its\n\n  amount in any proceedings which he brought against them to enforce the indemnity under the\n\n  insurance policy? In general terms, part, at least, of the answer is clear: the matter\n\n  would not be <i>res judicata</i>, since the parties to the two actions would be different\n\n  and the <i>media concludendi</i> would also be different. The existence of the sheriff\n\n  court decree would therefore give St Clair the necessary interest to sue the defenders but\n\n  it would not prevent them from reopening the matter in an action against them at his\n\n  instance. For this reason the existence of the sheriff court decree cannot, in itself,\n\n  prevent the defenders from reopening the matter in the present action where the pursuers\n\n  stand in St Clair\u2019s shoes.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Inner House also dealt with the prevailing problem which the\n\nenactment of the 1930 Act was intended to overcome as follows (at 12):-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"Parliament solved the problem by enacting the provisions of\n\n  Section 1 which in effect assigned the insured\u2019s rights against the insurer to the\n\n  third party. But there is nothing in the terms of the 1930 Act or in the aims of the\n\n  legislation that would justify the inference that Parliament intended to give the third\n\n  party any additional advantage which would not be available to the insured in any action\n\n  at his instance against the insurer.\"</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As far as <i>Ben Shipping</i> case is concerned, it is clearly\n\ndistinguishable as it did not deal with an express obligation to indemnify but with a\n\nsupposedly implied obligation of indemnity. It must be confined to its fact situation as\n\nthe passage of Bingham J which we have cited at 18 above shows. There were also special\n\nfeatures there which seemed to have played a part in the overall determination of the\n\ncase. It would be noted that Bingham J did not rule that the indemnifier could never be\n\nbound. He recognised that the authorities could well support a \"much more limited\n\nprinciple.\"</p>\n\n<p>22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As regards <i>Cheltenhem &amp; Gloucester</i> case, we note that\n\nthe Inner House, in coming to its decision, had relied upon <i>Ben Shipping</i>. With\n\nrespect, we think insufficient consideration was given to the distinguishing factors in <i>Ben\n\nShipping</i> which we had identified above. </p>\n\n<p>23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for Chiu Teng further seeks to distinguish <i>Cheltenhem\n\n&amp; Gloucester</i> on the basis that the wording of the operative clause of the\n\nindemnity was different. There, it was stated that the insurers would \"indemnify the\n\ninsured against liability at law for damages and claimant\u2019s costs and expenses in\n\nrespect of a claim \u2026 made against the insured \u2026 by reason of any negligent act,\n\nneglect or omission on the part of the \u2026 insured \u2026 occurring or committed \u2026\n\nin good faith.\" In contrast, in our case, the insurer was to indemnify Brentford\n\nagainst \"such sums which Brentford shall become legally liable to pay as\n\ndamages.\" While the two clauses are indeed different, we do not think there is any\n\nreal difference in effect, since in this case and in <i>Cheltenhem &amp; Gloucester</i>\n\nthere is, in each instance, a judgment against the insured.</p>\n\n<p>24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What is clear is that the Inner House seemed to be concerned with\n\nthe doctrine of <i>res judicata</i>. As we see it, the real point is one of contract. The\n\nquestion to ask is, following from the first judgment, is there a sum which Brentford is\n\nlegally liable to pay to Chiu Teng as damages. The answer is a definite yes. The wording\n\nof the policy is clear: the insurer (Hartford) shall indemnify the insured (Brentford)\n\nagainst such sums which Brentford shall become legally liable to pay as damages. This\n\ncondition is satisfied. It is not open to Hartford to challenge that judgment; they were\n\nnotified of the claim. To permit such a challenge as to the extent of liability of\n\nBrentford to Chiu Teng, and consequently the quantum thereof, would risk there being an\n\ninconsistent judgment and the insured being indemnified less (or none at all) than what\n\nthe policy provides. And as by virtue of s 1(1), Chiu Teng stepped into the shoes of\n\nBrentford, Chiu Teng should be indemnified by Hartford. There is no question of Chiu Teng\n\nbeing given any additional advantage which would not be available to Brentford in any\n\naction instituted by Brentford against Hartford.</p>\n\n<p>25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Generally, and as stated by Romer J in <i>Mercantile Investment\n\n&amp; General Trust</i> (supra), a judgment is only binding as between the parties to the\n\naction, except in the case of an express indemnity given by a third party to a party to\n\nthe action. </p>\n\n<p>26.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At common law, Chiu Teng would have no claim against Hartford,\n\nthe insurer: <i>Re Harrington Motor Co</i> [1928] 1 Ch 105. Now, because of the winding up\n\nof Brentford, s 1(1) enables Chiu Teng to step into the shoes of Brentford.\n\nBrentford\u2019s right to be indemnified in respect of the liability is, under s 1(1),\n\ntransferred to Chiu Teng. It is not open to Hartford to reopen the question of quantum of\n\nloss. Judgment had already been obtained on that. As stated by Devlin J in <i>West Wake\n\nPrice &amp; Co v Ching</i> [1957] 1 WLR 45 at 49, \"The essence of the main indemnity\n\nclauses is that the assured must prove a loss. The assured cannot recover anything under\n\nthe main indemnity clause or make any claim against the underwriters until they have been\n\nfound liable and so sustained a loss.\"</p>\n\n<p>27.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We do not think it should make a difference whether the judgment\n\nobtained against the insured is after a trial or on admission, so long as notice was given\n\nto the insurer to defend the claim of the injured third party if it wished. Unlike the\n\ncharterers in <i>Ben Shipping</i>, who did not know how the loss occurred, here it is\n\nHartford who is raising the point that the installation of the micropiles was unnecessary\n\nafter judgment was given against Brentford. We would mention that Hartford\u2019s loss\n\nadjusters were kept informed by Chiu Teng\u2019s loss adjusters on the list of defects and\n\nthe proposed rectification works. Nothing was raised by Hartford\u2019s loss adjusters\n\nabout the need or otherwise of the micropiles. It is absurd to require an insured to\n\ncontest a claim, or the quantum thereof, if he does not have any basis to contest it.</p>\n\n<p>28.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would, therefore, respectfully decline to follow the decision\n\nof the Inner House in <i>Cheltenhem &amp; Gloucester</i> and instead say that we agree\n\nwith the approach taken by the Outer House, which broadly followed the opinion expressed\n\nby Mellish LJ in <i>Parker v Lewis</i> (see 10 above). It said:-</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Where the insurer, on the other hand, forms the view that he is not\n\n  liable to indemnify his insured, then he still has at least two options. The first is to\n\n  refuse or withdraw cover in respect of any defence to the pursuer\u2019s action. In that\n\n  event, if the pursuer proceeds with his action and secures decree against the person\n\n  thought to be insured, the amount of the decree will be determinative of the liability of\n\n  the insured to the pursuer unless and until that decree is reduced on the grounds of, for\n\n  example, fraud or collusion. The insurer cannot normally re-open the question of the\n\n  amount of the liability in circumstances where he has declined to enter the process and\n\n  fund the defence to the action or has withdrawn his instructions and funding in the course\n\n  of the action. The question of liability between the pursuer and the insured has to be\n\n  litigated in an action between those two parties and a decree in that action has to be\n\n  seen as a final determination of that liability so long as the decree stands unreduced.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The second option is for the insurer to offer to instruct the defence\n\n  to the action but make it clear <i>ab ante, </i>or at least as soon as possible, both to\n\n  the pursuer and the insured, that his position is to remain that he is not liable under\n\n  the policy.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>29.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The choice is entirely for the insurer. If it chooses not to\n\nintervene, then, if a judgment is obtained against the insured, it would have to indemnify\n\nthe insured if the policy defences pleaded by it should fail. As regards the concern\n\nraised that if this court should uphold the decision of the court below, it could lead to\n\nan escalation in premiums, we would make three observations. First, this is not a legal\n\npoint. Secondly, a term which gives the insurer the right to conduct the defence of the\n\ninsured is commonplace in most insurance contracts and such a term is in the policy issued\n\nby Hartford to Brentford. Thirdly, while each insurer will set its own premium rates, in a\n\nfree and competitive economy, the market will ultimately dictate the acceptable levels.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nJudgment</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>30.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, the appellant\u2019s (Hartford\u2019s) appeal is\n\nhereby dismissed with costs. The security for costs, together with any accrued interest,\n\nshall be paid out to the respondent (Chiu Teng) or its solicitors to account of its costs.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 </p>\n\n<p>Sgd: </p>\n\n<p>YONG PUNG HOW<br/>\n\nCHIEF JUSTICE</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>L P THEAN<br/>\n\nJUDGE OF APPEAL</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>CHAO HICK TIN<br/>\n\nJUDGE OF APPEAL</p>\n\n\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of
