\n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0November 2008</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Judgment reserved.</span></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Introduction</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This is an appeal against the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in which he disallowed, in part, the appellant\u2019s application to amend her statement of claim (see <i>Murakami Takako v Wiryadi Louis Maria</i> <nobr>[2008] 3 SLR 198</nobr> (\u201cthe GD\u201d)). These proceedings are yet another chapter in the long history of litigation between the parties, the background of which we have previously set out in <i>Murakami Takako v Wiryadi Louise Maria</i> <nobr>[2007] 4 SLR 565</nobr> (\u201c<i>Murakami Takako</i>\u201d) at [3]\u2013[5].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In these proceedings, the appellant, acting on behalf of the estate of her late father, Takashi Murakami Suroso (\u201cthe Testator\u201d), applied to include certain amendments which would expand her claim to include the following:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 moneys contained in two bank accounts with Westpac Bank in Australia (\u201cthe moneys in the Australian bank accounts\u201d);</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 five immovable properties and sale proceeds from three other immovable properties situated in Australia; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 four immovable properties and sale proceeds from one other immovable property situated in Indonesia.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge allowed only the amendments pertaining to the moneys in the Australian bank accounts. He held that the court had no jurisdiction over the claims to the specified foreign immovable properties (\u201cthe foreign immovable properties\u201d) and the sale proceeds from the other specified foreign immovable properties (\u201cthe other foreign properties\u201d), and that, even if the court had jurisdiction, he would have declined to exercise it on the ground of <i>forum non conveniens</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The issues on appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondents have not appealed against the decision of the Judge to allow the amendments pertaining to the moneys in the Australian bank accounts and their counsel has confirmed that they are content to rest with that decision. Therefore, the issues that arise for our consideration pertain only to whether the Judge rightly disallowed the amendments with regard to the foreign immovable properties and the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge held that the appellant\u2019s claims to the foreign immovable properties and the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties (\u201cthe Claims\u201d) were caught by the rule in <i>The British South Africa Company v The Companhia de Mo\u00e7ambique</i> [1893] AC 602 (\u201cthe <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule\u201d), the effect of which is that the court has no jurisdiction to determine the title to, or the right to possession of, any immovable property situated outside the forum. The Judge considered one of the main exceptions to the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule, <i>viz</i>, that jurisdiction could be assumed where the claim was in equity (\u201cthe personal equities exception\u201d), and held that it did not apply on the facts of the present case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the words of a leading expert in the field (see Adrian Briggs, <i>Civil Jurisdiction and Judgments</i> (LLP, 4th\u00a0Ed, 2005) at para\u00a04.06), the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">... reflects the practical fact that only at the <i>situs</i></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">of the land can there be an effective determination of title. Even if an English court [in these proceedings, a Singapore court] were to hear the case, and were to choose and apply the law which a court at the <i>situs</i> would itself have applied, it is probable that its judgment will be ignored at the <i>situs</i> as one coming from a court with no jurisdiction to adjudicate on the issue. Acceptance of this fact is the pragmatic reason why the court has no jurisdiction to try questions of disputed title to foreign land. And because the issue is one where the court has no jurisdiction over the subject-matter of the claim, the purported submission of the defendant to the jurisdiction of the court is irrelevant: what the court lacks is subject-matter jurisdiction, not personal jurisdiction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[One] \u2026 exception [to the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule] is ancient and equitable in origin. According to the principle laid down in <i>Penn</i> v. <i>Lord\u00a0Baltimore</i> [(1750) 1\u00a0Ves\u00a0Sen 444; 27\u00a0ER 1132], though a court may have no jurisdiction to try a question of title to the land, this does not affect its jurisdiction to adjudicate on and enforce a contract, or fiduciary or other equitable obligation, between and binding on the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although a vigorous assault was made on the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule in the House of Lords decision of <i>Hesperides Hotels Ltd v Muftizade</i> [1979] AC 508, the rule (as well as its exceptions, including the personal equities exception) was ultimately affirmed in that case (notwithstanding the court\u2019s acknowledgment of the various critiques of the rule itself). Indeed, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce was of the view that the nature of the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule was such that any possible reform would need to be effected via legislation instead of judicial decision (see <i>id</i> at 537).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is important to note \u2212 particularly in the context of the present proceedings and for reasons that will become apparent in the course of this judgment \u2212 that the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule is one of <i>subject-matter</i> <i>jurisdiction</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is equally important to note that the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule and the personal equities exception are part of Singapore law (see the decision of this court in <i>Eng Liat Kiang v Eng Bak Hern</i> <nobr>[1995] 3 SLR 97</nobr> (\u201c<i>Eng Liat Kiang</i>\u201d) at 100\u2013103, [11]\u2013[19], where the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule was assumed to be (as also noted in the preceding paragraph) one relating to <i>jurisdiction</i>). The court, therefore, generally has no jurisdiction over claims to foreign immovable properties except for, <i>inter alia</i>, claims in equity with respect to equitable obligations. In this case, the Claims lie in equity; they are trust claims. It follows that the personal equities exception <i>prima facie</i> applies and the court has jurisdiction over the Claims. The crux of this appeal is therefore twofold, namely:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether the Judge correctly found that the court did not have jurisdiction over the Claims; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if the court indeed has jurisdiction, whether the Judge rightly declined to exercise it on the ground of <i>forum non conveniens</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In addressing these issues, the court\u2019s jurisdiction over the foreign immovable properties and the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties will be considered together. We do not agree with counsel for the appellant that the claims to the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties are no different from the claim relating to the moneys in the Australian bank accounts. This argument ignores the different legal bases of the respective claims.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The basis of the appellant\u2019s claim to the moneys in the Australian bank accounts is the assertion that those were funds provided by the Testator. On the other hand, the success of the claims to the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties rests on the appellant demonstrating the Testator\u2019s interest, if any, in the other foreign properties before they were sold. This is because any interest which the Testator had in the said sale proceeds would have flowed from an interest in the other foreign properties. Therefore, in adjudicating on the claims to the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties, the court would necessarily have to consider the Testator\u2019s interest in those properties. This, in turn, raises the question of jurisdiction over those properties. We will therefore deal with the foreign immovable properties and the sale proceeds from the other foreign properties together.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The requirements for the assumption of equitable jurisdiction</span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge held that the court could not assume equitable jurisdiction for two reasons. First, the dispute was not sufficiently connected to the forum so as to warrant equity\u2019s assistance. Second, the Judge commented, by way of <i>obiter dicta</i>, that it was also arguable that the appellant\u2019s equity had already been extinguished by the <i>lex situs</i>. We will consider these reasons in turn.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Is a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum a prerequisite to the assumption of equitable jurisdiction?</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In support of the proposition that a sufficient connection between the forum and the dispute was required before the court could assume equitable jurisdiction, the Judge relied (see the GD at [24]) on an extract from R\u00a0W\u00a0White\u2019s article, \u201cEquitable Obligations in Private International Law: The Choice of Law\u201d (1986) 11\u00a0Syd\u00a0LR 92 (\u201cWhite\u2019s article\u201d) at 106, which was cited at para\u00a01.18 of T\u00a0M\u00a0Yeo, <i>Choice of Law for Equitable Doctrines</i> (Oxford University Press, 2004) (\u201cYeo\u2019s book\u201d), the leading work in the field. The above extract from White\u2019s article reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A defendant could not reasonably be expected to conform to the principles of English equity if his connection with England were as tenuous as mere presence at the time of service. It seems that instead of applying choice of law rules to a dispute the Court insisted that there be a sufficient connection between the parties or the cause of action and England.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">This short extract from White\u2019s article does, at first blush, appear to suggest that, in England, the courts of equity would only assume jurisdiction where the dispute was sufficiently connected to the forum. With respect, however, this extract must be read in the context of White\u2019s article as a whole. When so read, it becomes clear that the learned author was referring in the extract set out in the preceding paragraph to the strict jurisdictional rules of the Court of Chancery which held sway in England <i>prior to</i> 1873. White sought to explain how these old jurisdictional rules also functioned as a <i>proxy</i> for choice of law analysis in the past. Put simply, the net result was a <i>conflation</i> of the rules of jurisdiction on the one hand and those relating to the choice of law on the other. The main issue before us in the present appeal is whether or not the old jurisdictional rules just referred to <i>continue to apply today.</i> The related issue as to whether or not there ought to be a conflation of jurisdictional rules and choice of law rules will (as we shall see) figure prominently when we consider the case law that was relied upon by the Judge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the former issue mentioned at the end of the preceding paragraph is concerned, White recognised \u2013 correctly, in our view \u2013 that, with the enactment of the Judicature Act 1873 (c\u00a066) (UK) (as well as subsequent developments), the strict jurisdictional rules applied by the Court of Chancery, which required a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum, were <i>abandoned</i>, there having been a fusion of the administration of justice by both the courts of common law and the Court of Chancery. The learned author explains this (very significant) development as follows (see White\u2019s article ([13] <i>supra</i>) at 104\u2013105):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">... The concept of jurisdiction applicable in the Court of Chancery was not based on mere presence and service, but upon a sufficient connection being shown between the dispute and the forum. That connection existed if the defendant were resident or domiciled in England, the cause of action arose there, or the subject matter of the dispute was situated there.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Court would not adjudicate upon foreign disputes not so connected with England. It was a natural refinement of this concept of jurisdiction that if it were inappropriate to decide the case in England and there was a competent tribunal to decide it in the natural foreign forum, the requisites of jurisdiction would be held to be lacking even though there was a connection with England (for example [the] defendant\u2019s residence in England) which in other cases would suffice to found jurisdiction in the Court of Chancery. The reluctance to deal with foreign disputes produced in <i>Doss v. Secretary of State for India</i> [(1874\u201375) LR\u00a019\u00a0Eq 509] a liberal doctrine of <i>forum conveniens</i> which was part of the concept of jurisdiction and which did not depend on a distinction between the existence of jurisdiction and the discretion to exercise it. <i>On the passing of the Judicature Act 1873 the principles on which the Court of Chancery and the Courts of Law exercised jurisdiction were different. The Judicature Act 1873 did not itself resolve this difference, but it would have been manifestly inconvenient if the English Court had exercised jurisdiction on principles which varied according to whether the cause of action was legal or equitable. The problem was resolved in favour of the common law principles without discussion.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Since the Judicature Act 1873 it has been uniformly held that mere presence suffices to found jurisdiction. None of the English cases has concerned an equitable cause of action. Nonetheless they have been decided in the belief that the principle of jurisdiction based on mere presence is a fundamental rule that applies to the entire jurisdiction of the English High Court.</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">...</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Therefore, in England, <i>post</i>-1873, the jurisdiction of the courts of common law and that of the courts of equity were placed on an equal basis. Presence, submission or service of a writ or other originating process out of jurisdiction in accordance with the prevailing civil procedure rules was thenceforth sufficient for the courts to assume jurisdiction. <i>There was no longer any requirement that there had to be a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum before the court could assume equitable as well as common law jurisdiction.</i> This is also the position in Singapore today (see s\u00a016 of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 2007\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cSCJA\u201d)).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Once the court assumes equitable jurisdiction on any of the bases set out in s\u00a016 of the SCJA, it can act <i>in personam</i> against the defendant. The court can consider the personal equities exception and would (provided the exception is established on the facts before it) be free to issue an order which may indirectly affect foreign land. As has been observed in a leading textbook (see Sir\u00a0Peter North &amp; J\u00a0J\u00a0Fawcett, <i>Cheshire and North\u2019s Private International Law</i> (LexisNexis UK, 13th\u00a0Ed, 1999) at p\u00a0377):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The primary essential is that the defendant should be subject to the general jurisdiction of the court. This jurisdiction, as we have seen, is founded on his presence in England, but as regards the power to pronounce a decree in personam against him it is equally well founded by service of a claim form under Order\u00a011 [of the Rules of the Supreme Court (UK)]. Once the court is thus empowered to take cognizance of the matter, the doctrine that equity acts in personam may be freely and effectively applied. A decree may be issued which, though personal in form, will indirectly affect land abroad.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Hence, with respect, the Judge was wrong to require that a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum be established before equitable jurisdiction could be assumed by the court. This represented the position taken by the Court of Chancery <i>prior to</i> 1873, which has long been <i>abandoned</i> even in England itself and which certainly does not represent the position in Singapore today.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should also deal with a related point which was referred to briefly above (at [14]) as this will (as we shall see) aid us in assessing the case law that was relied upon by the Judge in arriving at the conclusion that a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum was required before equitable jurisdiction could be assumed by the court. This point is that the Court of Chancery not only assumed jurisdiction according to a strict rule prior to 1873, but also did so (as White perceptively argues) as the result of a reluctance to apply <i>choice of law</i> rules to the dispute at hand (see White\u2019s article ([13] <i>supra</i>) at 106 and the extracts from Yeo\u2019s book ([13] <i>supra</i>) set out below). With respect, the Court of Chancery\u2019s stance no longer represents the modern approach under which issues of jurisdiction and issues of choice of law are treated by the courts as being conceptually as well as practically distinct. Indeed, as just alluded to, the failure to distinguish between these two distinct issues gives us a clue as to why the case law (in particular, the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Lightning v Lightning Electrical Contractors Limited</i> [1998] EWHC\u00a0Admin 431 (\u201c<i>Lightning</i>\u201d)) <i>appeared</i> to support the Judge\u2019s view that there had to be a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum before equitable jurisdiction could be assumed by the court. Before we turn our attention briefly to such case law, the following pertinent observation by Prof\u00a0Yeo should be noted (see Yeo\u2019s book at para\u00a01.19):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">While there may have been a historical link between jurisdiction and choice of law in the Chancery court, <i>in the modern context there is insufficient justification for linking jurisdiction and choice of law for equitable doctrines</i> \u2026 [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The learned author proceeded to give six persuasive reasons for the above observation, including the following (<i>id</i> at paras\u00a01.23 and 1.25):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1.23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ... [T]he historical context is important. In tracing the historical development of English conflict of laws, Sack [A\u00a0N\u00a0Sack, \u201cConflict of Laws in the History of the English Law\u201d in <i>Law: A Century of Progress 1835\u22121935</i> (A\u00a0Reppy ed) (Oxford University Press, 1937) vol\u00a03 at p\u00a0342] noted the widespread use of jurisdiction as an early technique to limit the application of the law of the forum, <i>before</i> choice of law rules were developed. The <i>underdeveloped</i> rules for choice of law in respect of equitable doctrines must be borne in mind when considering the practice of the eighteenth-century courts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1.25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ... [C]hanges of jurisdiction rules brought about by the Judicature Act 1873 put the jurisdiction of the courts of common law and equity <i>on an equal basis</i>. The broad bases upon which jurisdiction can be assumed today make application of the law of the forum even more unreasonable. Any slender links that existed between the Chancery court\u2019s exercise of jurisdiction and the question of choice of law have <i>now been broken</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In this regard, we must respectfully disagree with the English High Court decision of <i>R\u00a0Griggs Group Ltd v Evans</i> [2005] Ch 153 in so far as it suggests (especially at [110]) that the personal equities exception to the <i>Mo\u00e7ambique</i> rule is one which relates to choice of law instead of jurisdiction, although it might be argued that the learned judge in that case was involved <i>only</i> in a choice of law analysis (as opposed to the issue of jurisdiction).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, now, to <i>Lightning</i>, the Judge, with respect, relied wrongly on this case as support for his view that there had to be a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum before the court could assume equitable jurisdiction. In <i>Lightning</i>, the court assumed equitable jurisdiction and applied English law to determine a trust claim to Scottish property. While the facts of that case disclosed, in <i>fact</i>, a close connection between the dispute and the forum, such a connection went only to the choice of law analysis and <i>not</i> to the issue of jurisdiction. The crucial passage in the judgment of Peter Gibson\u00a0LJ (with whom Henry and Millett\u00a0LJJ agreed) occurs at [23], and reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Lord [counsel for the defendant] said that these authorities [<i>ie</i>, the authorities considered at [18]\u2013[22] of <i>Lightning</i>] go only to the question of jurisdiction and do not go to the question of the applicable law. But, for my part, whilst that may be correct, it seems to me implicit that the English court not unnaturally regarded English law as applicable to the relationship between the parties before it in the absence of any event governed by the lex situs destructive of the equitable interest being asserted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We can, in fact, do no better than to adopt Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s perceptive observations on <i>Lightning</i> in general and the observations of Peter Gibson\u00a0LJ (<i>id</i> at [23]) in particular, as follows (see Yeo\u2019s book ([13] <i>supra</i>) at para 1.17):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Moreover, just because a court applied English law <b><i>after assuming jurisdiction</i></b> does not mean that it follows as a matter of law that English law was applicable. In <i>Lightning v Lightning Electrical Contractors Ltd</i>, Peter Gibson\u00a0LJ, said of the jurisdiction cases:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[Counsel] said that these authorities go only to the question of jurisdiction and do not go to the question of the applicable law. But, \u2026 whilst that may be correct, it seems to me implicit that <i>the English court not unnaturally regarded English law as applicable to the relationship between the parties before it</i> in the absence of any event governed by the <i>lex situs</i> destructive of the equitable interest being asserted. (Emphasis added.)</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The emphasized words show <b><i>a separate choice of law analysis</i></b> focusing on the law governing the relationship of the parties, which usually happened to be English law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added in bold italics]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Indeed, this interpretation of <i>Lightning</i> underlies the analysis by another writer who argues that equitable obligations should not automatically be governed by the <i>lex fori</i> as such (see generally Adeline Chong, \u201cThe Common Law Choice of Law Rules for Resulting and Constructive Trusts\u201d (2005) 54\u00a0ICLQ 855 at 863\u2013866).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Hence, the close connection between the dispute and the forum went only to the analysis of choice of law, and not jurisdiction, in <i>Lightning</i>. The same is true of <i>Webb v Webb</i> [1991] 1\u00a0WLR 1410, to which the Judge also referred. Consequently, the lack of a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum is not, in our view, a bar to the assumption of equitable <i>jurisdiction</i> by the court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Has the appellant\u2019s equity been extinguished by the</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">lex situs<em>?</em></span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we mentioned earlier (at [12] above), the Judge also observed, by way of <i>obiter dicta</i>, that it was arguable that the appellant\u2019s equity had already been extinguished by the <i>lex situs</i>. He was of the view that it was common ground between the parties that the communal property doctrine in Indonesian law was subject to the exception that spouses had full entitlement to properties acquired as gifts. The Judge thus observed that, if the first respondent had received the foreign properties as gifts, she would be fully entitled to those properties under Indonesian law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we are unable to agree with these observations.</span> <span lang=\"EN-AU\">Even if the <i>lex situs</i> did apply for the purposes of determining whether the appellant\u2019s equity had been extinguished (which issue we need not decide), no evidence of Indonesian law was adduced in the court below to support the Judge\u2019s finding. The appellant also vehemently denied that it was common ground between the parties that, under Indonesian law, spouses were fully entitled to properties acquired as gifts. As such, although we recognise that the Judge\u2019s comments were strictly <i>obiter</i>, we find that there simply is no basis on the evidence to support these comments.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The issue of <i>forum non conveniens</i></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The next issue that arises for our consideration is whether, although our courts do have jurisdiction over the Claims, we ought nevertheless to decline to exercise jurisdiction on the basis of <i>forum non conveniens</i>. We have previously stated that the relevant test in this regard is to determine whether there is a clearly or distinctly more appropriate forum than Singapore which meets the ends of justice, having regard to the interests of the parties (see the decision of this court in <i>Murakami Takako</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) at [49]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It has been firmly established that the principles laid down in <i>Spiliada Maritime Corporation\u00a0v Cansulex Ltd</i> [1987] AC 460 (\u201c<i>Spiliada</i>\u201d) apply (see, for example, the decisions of this court in <i>Brinkerhoff Maritime Drilling Corp v PT\u00a0Airfast Services Indonesia</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 SLR 776</nobr>, <i>Oriental Insurance Co Ltd v Bhavani Stores Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1998] 1 SLR 253</nobr>, <i>PT\u00a0Hutan Domas Raya v Yue Xiu Enterprises (Holdings) Limited</i> <nobr>[2001] 2 SLR 49</nobr>, <i>Rickshaw Investments Ltd v Nicolai Baron von Uexkull</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 377</nobr> (\u201c<i>Rickshaw</i>\u201d) at [12] and <i>CIMB Bank Bhd v Dresdner Kleinwort Ltd</i> <nobr>[2008] SGCA 36</nobr> (\u201c<i>CIMB</i>\u201d) at [25]). The principles set out in <i>Spiliada</i> were recently summarised in <i>CIMB</i> (at [26]) as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The gist of these principles is that, under the doctrine of <i>forum non conveniens</i>, a stay will only be granted where the court is satisfied that there is some other available and more appropriate forum for the trial of the action. The burden of establishing this rests on the defendant and it is not enough just to show that Singapore is not the natural or appropriate forum. The defendant must also establish that there is another available forum which is clearly or distinctly more appropriate than Singapore. The natural forum is one with which the action has the most real and substantial connection. In this regard, the factors which the court will take into consideration include not only factors affecting convenience or expense (such as the availability of witnesses) but also other factors such as the law governing the transaction and the places where the parties respectively reside or carry on business. If the court concludes, at this stage of the inquiry (\u201cstage one of the <i>Spiliada</i> test\u201d), that there is no other available forum which is clearly more appropriate for the trial of the action, it will ordinarily refuse a stay. If, at this stage, it concludes that there is some other available forum which <i>prima facie</i> is clearly more appropriate for the trial of the action, it will ordinarily grant a stay, unless there are circumstances by reason of which justice requires that a stay should nevertheless be refused. In this connection, the court will consider all the circumstances of the case. For this second stage [of the] inquiry (\u201cstage two of the <i>Spiliada</i> test[\u201d]), the legal burden is on the plaintiff to establish the existence of those special circumstances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the first stage of the analysis delineated in the above passage, the relevant factors are, <i>inter alia</i>, the general connecting factors and the choice of law (see <i>Rickshaw</i> at [15]). In the court below, the Judge was of the view that, as there was (in his view) a requirement that there be a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum before the court could assume equitable jurisdiction, the <i>lex fori</i> (here, Singapore law) ought to apply \u2013 notwithstanding the fact that the decision of this court in <i>Eng Liat Kiang</i> ([9] <i>supra</i>) appeared to be authority to the contrary (see the GD at [39]\u2013[40]). He nevertheless proceeded to hold that, in the light of the decision of this court in <i>Rickshaw</i>, the application of the <i>lex fori</i> in the context of the present proceedings would be unsuitable (see the GD at [41]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We have, in fact, held above (at [18] and [22]) that there need not be a sufficient connection between the dispute and the forum before the court can assume equitable jurisdiction. In any event, we have also held above (at [19]) that the issue of jurisdiction is separate and distinct from that relating to the choice of law. More importantly, as Prof\u00a0Yeo has very persuasively argued, the court can still proceed to engage in a choice of law analysis and apply a law other than the <i>lex fori</i> even after it has assumed equitable jurisdiction. We have previously endorsed Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s view in <i>Rickshaw</i>, as follows (<i>id</i> at [75]\u2013[76]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">75\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note, at the outset, that the principles relating to choice of law with regard to claims in equity are not entirely clear. We are therefore especially grateful to have the benefit of the views of the leading expert in the field in Singapore (and, indeed, the Commonwealth) as embodied in a very scholarly volume which, if we may say so, has justly received widespread praise: see T\u00a0M\u00a0Yeo, <i>Choice of Law for Equitable Doctrines</i> (Oxford University Press, 2004) (\u201c<i>Yeo</i>\u201d). Indeed, this is the seminal work in the field in the Commonwealth and is based on the author\u2019s doctoral thesis completed at Oxford University (a summary of his main theses can be found in Tiong Min Yeo, \u201cChoice of Law for Equity\u201d in ch\u00a07 of <i>Equity in Commercial Law</i> (Simone Degeling &amp; James Edelman eds) (Law Book Co, 2005)). There is in fact little by way of direct authority in this particular area of the law and the learned author does rely much on first principles. His views are therefore especially valuable in the circumstances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It used to be thought that the <i>lex causae</i> for claims in equity would generally be the <i>lex fori</i> (in these proceedings, Singapore law). The central insight of Prof\u00a0Yeo\u2019s book (referred to in the preceding paragraph) is the suggestion of a more nuanced approach. Put simply, there would not, <i>ipso facto</i>, be an automatic and blanket application of the <i>lex fori</i> in any and every situation of this nature. Instead, the nature and origins of the equitable obligations concerned would need to be closely examined in the context of their respective factual matrices. In our view, such an approach is undoubtedly sound. The adoption of the <i>lex fori</i> as the <i>lex causae</i> for <i>all</i> issues arising in equity would fail to recognise the disparate doctrines and causes of action arising in equity. Such an approach would be no different from a suggestion that all common law claims, whether arising in contract, tort, or otherwise, should be governed by the <i>lex fori</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">We also noted above (at [27]) that the Judge had, in any event, followed the above approach in <i>Rickshaw</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In these proceedings, the viability or otherwise of the Claims ultimately rests on whether or not the Testator had an interest in the foreign immovable properties as well as the other foreign properties (collectively referred to as \u201cthe disputed foreign properties\u201d), and this falls to be determined by the Testator\u2019s <i>lex domicilii</i>, which was Indonesian law. The question that arises for our consideration then is whether, given that the <i>lex causae</i> is Indonesian law, Indonesia is a clearly or distinctly more appropriate forum than Singapore for the adjudication of the Claims.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s claim that the Testator had an interest in the entire share of the disputed foreign properties requires the court to consider whether, under Indonesian law, those properties were excepted from being regarded as common marital assets such that the Testator had full entitlement to them. The matter is further complicated by the first respondent\u2019s counter-allegation that, on the contrary, she was fully entitled to the disputed foreign properties as gifts. These are issues which require a careful consideration of the scope of the communal property doctrine in Indonesian law. In addition, the appellant has also alleged a failure on the part of the first respondent to disclose to the Indonesian courts the disputed foreign properties as marital assets. The effect of such non-disclosure may or may not bring with it certain legal consequences under Indonesian law. In sum, the complexities raised by the Claims are, in our view, better dealt with by the Indonesian courts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are also other general connecting factors pointing to Indonesia as the clearly or distinctly more appropriate forum. Both the Testator and the first respondent were resident and married in Indonesia, and the present dispute arose out of ancillary proceedings in a divorce action commenced there as well. Further, the appellant had previously brought a claim relating to those of the disputed foreign properties situated in Indonesia (\u201cthe Indonesian properties\u201d) before the South Jakarta District Court. Her prior claim was dismissed merely on the ground of procedural defects (see <i>Takako Murakami v Louise Maria Wiryadi</i> Judgment No\u00a0924/Pdt.G/2006/PN.Jak.Sel. (3\u00a0October 2007) (unreported)). In particular, she failed to include, as parties to the action, the third parties in whose names the Indonesian properties were registered. Since the appellant\u2019s claim to the Indonesian properties has yet to be adjudicated on its merits, the appellant is not precluded from bringing another claim in Indonesia to those properties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as those of the disputed foreign properties situated in Australia (\u201cthe Australian properties\u201d) are concerned, the appellant also previously brought claims in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. Gzell\u00a0J, in <i>Murakami v Wiryadi</i> <nobr>[2006] NSWSC 1354</nobr> (\u201c<i>Murakami</i>\u201d), stayed those proceedings on the ground of <i>forum non conveniens</i>. The learned judge applied the Australian approach to <i>forum non conveniens</i> as set out in the Australian High Court decisions of <i>Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay</i> (1988) 165\u00a0CLR 197 (\u201c<i>Oceanic Sun Line</i>\u201d), <i>Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Proprietary Limited</i> (1990) 171\u00a0CLR 538 (\u201c<i>Voth</i>\u201d), <i>Henry v Henry</i> (1996) 185\u00a0CLR 571 and <i>CSR Limited v Cigna Insurance Australia Limited</i> (1997) 189\u00a0CLR 345 to the effect that the court may stay or dismiss proceedings if, having regard to the circumstances of the case and the availability of the foreign tribunal, the forum is clearly inappropriate for the determination of the dispute (reference may similarly be made to the (also) Australian High Court decision of <i>Regie Nationale des Usines Renault SA v Zhang</i> (2002) 210\u00a0CLR 491).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although the test applied in the Australian context to the issue of <i>forum non conveniens</i> is quite different from that set out in <i>Spiliada</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>), there would (on most occasions) be no difference in the actual result arrived at by the court (see, for example, <i>Oceanic Sun Line</i> at 251\u2013252 (<i>per</i> Deane\u00a0J) and 265\u2013266 (<i>per</i> Gaudron\u00a0J), <i>Voth</i> at 558 (<i>per</i> Mason\u00a0CJ and Deane, Dawson and Gaudron\u00a0JJ), <i>Eng Liat Kiang</i> ([9] <i>supra</i>) at 104, [23] and Peter Brereton, \u201c<i>Forum Non Conveniens</i> in Australia: A Case Note on <i>Voth</i> v. <i>Manildra Flour Mills</i>\u201d (1991) 40\u00a0ICLQ 895 at 897\u2013898; <i>cf</i>, however, <i>Civil Jurisdiction and Judgments</i> ([6] <i>supra</i>) at para\u00a04.20 (reference may also be made to Richard Garnett, \u201cStay of Proceedings in Australia: A \u2018Clearly Inappropriate\u2019 Test?\u201d (1999) 23\u00a0Melb\u00a0Univ\u00a0L\u00a0Rev 30)). That having been said, it is important to guard against simply equating the two tests because (if nothing else) their respective points of emphasis are quite different (see, for example, <i>Voth</i> at 558 <i>per</i> Mason\u00a0CJ and Deane, Dawson and Gaudron\u00a0JJ; the learned judges, however, also observed that, in applying the test under Australian law, \u201cthe discussion by Lord\u00a0Goff in <i>Spiliada</i> of relevant \u2018connecting factors\u2019 and \u2018a legitimate personal or juridical advantage\u2019 provide[d] valuable assistance\u201d (<i>id</i> at 564\u2013565) \u2013 observations which were also cited and applied by Gzell\u00a0J in <i>Murakami</i> at [39]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While we have previously rejected the Australian approach to <i>forum non conveniens</i> in favour of the test in <i>Spiliada</i>, which calls for a determination of whether there is another forum which is clearly or distinctly more appropriate than Singapore (see, for example, the decision of this court in <i>Eng Liat Kiang</i> at 105, [26]), Gzell\u00a0J\u2019s observations in <i>Murakami</i> ([32] <i>supra</i>) are nevertheless helpful. This is because the factors which the learned judge considered would apply with equal force in the context of the doctrine of <i>forum non conveniens</i> as set out in <i>Spiliada</i>. In particular, Gzell\u00a0J noted that (see <i>Murakami</i> at [45]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The connecting factors ... do not favour New South Wales against Indonesia. [The appellant] is not resident in New South Wales and [the first respondent] and [the fourth respondent] do not live in Australia. The events [which are] the subject of complaint are just as much centred in Indonesia where the non-disclosure of the New South Wales assets is alleged to have occurred as in New South Wales where the assets were acquired.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The learned judge also noted (<i>id</i> at [46]), just as we have (see [29] above), that the <i>lex causae</i> was Indonesian law. He further commented (at [47] of <i>Murakami</i>) that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">If matters are to be determined in the New South Wales court expert evidence will be required. If the issues are to be determined in the Indonesian courts there is no need for experts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Indeed, Gzell\u00a0J was of the view (<i>id</i> at [52]) that \u201cit [was] in the interests of the parties that a proper resolution of the issues be made in proceedings to be commenced in Indonesia\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The factors and the arguments considered by Gzell\u00a0J in the preceding paragraph, although analysed in the context of the Australian approach to <i>forum non conveniens</i>, apply equally in the context of the approach of this court as embodied in <i>Spiliada</i> ([26] <i>supra</i>). Indeed, there is a considerable overlap between the factors and the arguments considered by Gzell\u00a0J in <i>Murakami</i> and those discussed above in the context of the present proceedings. There is, in fact, good reason to believe that this is one instance where there would be no difference in result regardless of whether the Australian approach or the approach in <i>Spiliada</i> is adopted (see also above at [33]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the point of enforceability of judgments, we also note that, if indeed the appellant obtains a favourable judgment in Indonesia, the judgment would undoubtedly be enforceable with regard to the Indonesian properties. As for the Australian properties, an Indonesian judgment is also likely to be enforceable in Australia, given Gzell\u00a0J\u2019s recognition that it is appropriate for the Indonesian courts to address the appellant\u2019s claim. These are important practical considerations which we cannot ignore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In summary, the general connecting factors and the choice of law considerations point to Indonesia as constituting the clearly or distinctly more appropriate forum (as compared to Singapore) for the trial of the issues concerned. For that reason, although our courts have jurisdiction over the Claims, we should not exercise jurisdiction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Based, therefore, on the conclusion which we have arrived at with regard to the issue of <i>forum non conveniens</i>, we dismiss the appeal with costs and affirm the Judge\u2019s decision to disallow the appellant\u2019s application to include the Claims in her statement of claim. The usual consequential orders are to follow.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8 August 2008</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin JA (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal by the defendant appellant, CIMB Bank Berhad (\u201cCIMB\u201d), against a decision of the High Court refusing its application for a permanent stay of an action (\u201cthe present action\u201d) instituted by the plaintiff respondent, Dresdner Kleinwort Limited (\u201cDresdner\u201d), for the recovery of US$8,199,869.50 (\u201cthe Funds\u201d) in relation to the purported sale and purchase of eight promissory notes (\u201cthe Notes\u201d), on the ground of <i>forum non conveniens.</i> Instead, the High Court granted Dresdner\u2019s application that the action be temporarily stayed, pending the outcome of certain foreign proceedings in Germany where Dresdner is being sued by other parties also in connection with the Notes. We heard the appeal and, not being persuaded that the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) was wrong in the exercise of his discretion or had misapplied the relevant principles, dismissed it. We now give our reasons.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Dresdner is a foreign company with a registered office in England offering banking services, including the discounting of promissory notes. Its London branch (\u201cDresdner London\u201d) was the office that dealt with the purported transaction involving the Notes. CIMB is a Malaysian bank with branches in various places, including London and Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 6\u00a0May 2002, pursuant to a written agreement, Dresdner sought to purchase from CIMB the Notes,</span><a id=\"_ftnref1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\" name=\"_ftnref1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 1]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">which had a nominal value of US$10m, for the amount of the Funds. The Notes, with a maturity date of 3\u00a0February 2004, were issued on 1\u00a0February 2002 by Innaria Sdn Bhd, Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia (\u201cInnaria\u201d) to the order of V\u00a0V\u00a0Enterprise, Luyang, Sabah, Malaysia (\u201cV\u00a0V\u00a0Enterprise\u201d), and payable at Maybank Bhd, Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia. The Notes bore signatures that appeared to be those of two directors of Innaria, namely, Lye Kok Keng alias Harry (\u201cLye\u201d) and Mohamed Zulfikar bin Muzaffar (\u201cZulfikar\u201d). The Notes on their face also bore the guarantee of the Public Works Department of Sabah, Malaysia, with the alleged signatures of John Baptist Badai (\u201cBadai\u201d) and Lontou Ujum (\u201cUjum\u201d) against the signed stamp of a \u201cCommissioner for Oaths\u201d. The Notes were accompanied by a confirmation letter from Innaria stating <span class=\"Judg-1Char\">that the Notes \u201crelate to the financing of the import and installation of pipes under contract number JKR.JLN (S)\u00a0600 \u2013 1/5/6 Klt.16/144\u201d.</span></span><a id=\"_ftnref2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\" name=\"_ftnref2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 2]</span></span></span></span></a><span class=\"Judg-1Char\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As with the Notes, this confirmation letter bore the signatures of Lye and Zulfikar of Innaria and those of Badai and Ujum of the Public Works Department of Sabah. The agreement between CIMB and Dresdner was signed on behalf of CIMB by one George Chau, the sales officer of the Inanam branch of CIMB (\u201cCIMB Inanam\u201d).</span></span><a id=\"_ftnref3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn3\" name=\"_ftnref3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 3]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Subsequently, on 5\u00a0June 2002, payment for the transaction was effected by Dresdner, through its correspondent bank, the Bank of New York, to the Singapore branch of CIMB (\u201cCIMB Singapore\u201d) by SWIFT. In the SWIFT communication there was an express instruction that the Funds be credited to CIMB Inanam as the beneficial customer. The next day, CIMB Singapore transferred the Funds over to Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, Hong Kong (\u201cHSBC Hong Kong\u201d) in favour of New Speed Technologies Ltd, pursuant to what appeared to be instructions issued by George Chau and Ahmad Bin HJ\u00a0Khamis of CIMB Inanam for the attention of Paul Ma, the assistant general manager of CIMB Singapore.</span><a id=\"_ftnref4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn4\" name=\"_ftnref4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 4]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">That notification stated that CIMB Inanam had received such instructions from V\u00a0V\u00a0Enterprise. Before the Funds were remitted to Hong Kong, the general manager of CIMB Singapore, Raja Sulong Razak (\u201cRazak\u201d), confirmed with CIMB Inanam that the transfer should proceed.</span><a id=\"_ftnref5\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn5\" name=\"_ftnref5\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 5]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Upon payment, Dresdner London obtained the Notes from the London branch of CIMB (\u201cCIMB London\u201d) and endorsed them over to DF Deutsche Forfait AG (\u201cDF\u201d). It also warranted to DF as to the legal existence of the Notes and the avals contained therein. Subsequently, DF resold the Notes to Siemens Financial Services GmbH (\u201cSFS\u201d) and similarly assigned the warranty over to SFS.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We pause here to mention that this series of transactions involving the Notes were brokered by an English company, Bon Pour Aval Limited (\u201cBPAL\u201d). Eventually, the Notes were dishonoured upon presentation.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 9\u00a0November 2005, SFS sued Dresdner in Munich, Germany, on the warranty and on 18\u00a0August 2006 obtained a German judgment. Dresdner has filed an appeal against that decision and the determination of that appeal is now pending before the Superior Regional Court of Munich. We should hasten to add that there are further levels of appeal beyond the Superior Regional Court. The entire judicial process before the German courts is not likely to conclude before the end of 2009.</span><a id=\"_ftnref6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn6\" name=\"_ftnref6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 6]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As stated earlier, the written agreement was executed on behalf of CIMB by George Chau. CIMB alleged that the agreement could not bind CIMB, and thus it was of no validity, because George Chau, acting alone, had no authority to execute the agreement. Moreover, the limit of George Chau\u2019s authority was expressly communicated to Dresdner by way of a fax dated 21\u00a0May 2002 from Ms\u00a0Andrea Francis (\u201cMs\u00a0Francis\u201d), a trade finance officer of CIMB London, to Ms\u00a0Amanda Callaghan (\u201cMs\u00a0Callaghan\u201d) of Dresdner London, which stated that two authorised signatories were required for the endorsement of promissory notes that exceeded US$10,000.</span><a id=\"_ftnref7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn7\" name=\"_ftnref7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 7]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Here we should explain that earlier, on 15\u00a0May 2002, Yussof Bin Momin (\u201cMomin\u201d), a customer officer of CIMB Inanam, faxed a message to Ms\u00a0Callaghan confirming that George Chau was authorised to sign on behalf of CIMB and that his sole signature was sufficient and legally binding on CIMB in relation to the Notes.</span><a id=\"_ftnref8\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn8\" name=\"_ftnref8\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 8]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">On\u00a020 May 2002, Ms\u00a0Callaghan wrote to Ms\u00a0Francis seeking confirmation that Momin had authority to act on behalf of CIMB and to issue the fax of 15\u00a0May 2002. On 21\u00a0May 2002, the Head of Customer Service of CIMB Inanam, Ms\u00a0Linda Sia Henry Sum (\u201cMs\u00a0Sum\u201d), and Momin jointly faxed a message to CIMB London and copied it to Ms\u00a0Callaghan, confirming that one signatory was sufficient for the transaction of the Notes and that George Chau was so authorised. Again Ms\u00a0Callaghan immediately sought confirmation of this 21\u00a0May 2002 fax from Ms\u00a0Francis. Later, on the same day, CIMB Inanam sent a fax to CIMB London for the attention of Ms\u00a0Francis asking her to confirm to Ms\u00a0Callaghan that Momin and Ms\u00a0Sum were legal and authorised signatories of CIMB Inanam. This led to Ms\u00a0Francis\u2019 fax of the same day stating that George Chau\u2019s sole signature was valid only for transactions up to US$10,000 and two signatories were required for transactions beyond that limit.</span><a id=\"_ftnref9\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn9\" name=\"_ftnref9\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 9]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">On 23\u00a0May 2002, Ms\u00a0Mastulu Nurdin (\u201cMs\u00a0Nurdin\u201d), the Operations Manager of CIMB London, asked CIMB\u2019s headquarters in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (\u201cCIMB\u00a0KL\u201d) to verify the transaction for security purposes.</span><a id=\"_ftnref10\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn10\" name=\"_ftnref10\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 10]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Of course, this latter note was not communicated to Dresdner.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After the Notes were dishonoured, an internal investigation was carried out by CIMB which came to the conclusion that \u201cthe Project was non-existent, the supporting documents to validate the issuance of the Notes were fictitious and the Notes were issued in furtherance of a fraud\u201d.</span><a id=\"_ftnref11\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn11\" name=\"_ftnref11\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 11]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the statement of claim in the present action, Dresdner averred that the agreement with CIMB relating to the purchase and sale of the Notes was valid. This was also Dresdner\u2019s position in the German proceedings. Further, Dresdner pleaded in the alternative that if the agreement were in fact not valid and binding, it was entitled to reclaim the money from CIMB on the ground that the money was paid under a mistake of fact and that, consequently, CIMB had been unjustly enriched. A second alternative basis of Dresdner\u2019s claim was that the payment was made pursuant to a consideration which had totally failed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now explain why Dresdner had applied for a temporary stay of the present action. In view of the pending German proceedings, Dresdner took the position that if it could successfully resist the claim by SFS, then it, having suffered no loss, would not have to continue with its claim against CIMB. Indeed the institution of the present action in Singapore against CIMB was entirely precautionary as otherwise limitation would have set in on 6\u00a0June 2008.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In response to Dresdner\u2019s application for a temporary stay, CIMB applied to have the present action permanently stayed on the ground of <i>forum non conveniens</i>, asserting that England was the more appropriate forum to adjudicate on the dispute between them because much of the negotiations relating to the purported sale and purchase of the Notes were conducted by staff of the London offices of the two parties. The defence of CIMB, as disclosed in its affidavits filed in support of its stay application, was that the \u201cagreement\u201d signed by George Chau was not valid or binding. It also alleged that it had changed its position in good faith, <i>ie</i>, it had, in good faith, remitted the Funds received from Dresdner to HSBC Hong Kong.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Decisions below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before the assistant registrar it was decided that Dresdner\u2019s application for a temporary stay should be heard prior to CIMB\u2019s application. Having ruled in that manner, the assistant registrar granted Dresdner\u2019s application and did not proceed to hear CIMB\u2019s application. On appeal, the Judge decided that both applications should be heard together. At the hearing before the Judge, in order to ensure that Dresdner would not subsequently revive the validity of the agreement as an issue, Dresdner gave an undertaking (\u201cthe Undertaking\u201d) that, for the purposes of this action, it would not take the position that the agreement was valid (see the Judge\u2019s grounds of decision (\u201cthe GD\u201d) in <i>Dresdner Kleinwort Ltd v CIMB Bank Bhd</i> <nobr>[2008] SGHC 59</nobr> at [136]\u2013[140]). The effect of the Undertaking was that Dresdner agreed with CIMB that George Chau had entered into the agreement without authority and that there was no such agreement.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, the Judge dismissed CIMB\u2019s application for a permanent stay and varied the temporary stay granted by the assistant registrar in that CIMB was granted liberty to take all essential steps for it to commence any intended third-party proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Factors taken into account by the Judge</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In considering the question of whether England was the more appropriate forum to adjudicate on the present action, the Judge examined the following factors which CIMB averred connected the present action with England:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether the agreement was valid and enforceable;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the potential witnesses which both parties were likely to call in relation to the claim for unjust enrichment;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> whether Dresdner London made the payment as a result of a mistake; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the change of position of CIMB upon receipt of the payment and the involvement of its Singapore branch.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 CIMB also underscored the fact that the London offices of both Dresdner and CIMB were more closely involved with the transaction than its Singapore office which merely received the payment and transferred it out to HSBC Hong Kong.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge also considered the following issues or factors which, as alleged by Dresdner, connected the present action with Singapore:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether there was a failure of consideration for the payment of the Funds if the agreement was not valid;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether, in making the payment, Dresdner laboured under a mistake that the agreement was valid and binding;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether CIMB changed its position after receiving the payment;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether, in changing its position, CIMB acted in good faith;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the question of unjust enrichment and the proper law of the restitutionary obligations; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the question of third-party actions which CIMB intended to institute against HSBC Hong Kong and BPAL.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It would be apparent that some of these factors raised by Dresdner overlapped with those raised by CIMB.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to factors\u00a0(a), (b) and (c) (at [14] above), the Judge recognised that, in view of the fact that the negotiations leading to the purported agreement as well as the verification of the Notes and authorised signatories were carried out mainly by employees of both parties in London, the witnesses involved would be in London and so would the relevant documents. Thus these factors favoured London. However, the Judge also commented that as the potential witnesses of CIMB were still in its employment, there should not be too much difficulty in getting them to come over to Singapore to testify. Moreover, the relevant documents were also small in number.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for factor\u00a0(d) (at [14] above), the Judge noted that the Funds were received by CIMB Singapore which remitted them to HSBC Hong Kong in contravention of the express instructions contained in the SWIFT message (see [4] above). As regards CIMB\u2019s contentions that the broker, BPAL, could also have played a role in the remittance of the Funds to Hong Kong, that CIMB intended to take out third-party proceedings against BPAL and that consequently BPAL directors and staff, who were located in London, would be necessary witnesses, the Judge observed that in the light of the fact that there was reciprocal enforcement of judgments between Singapore and the United Kingdom, CIMB could bring third-party proceedings here against BPAL and he could not imagine that BPAL would ignore the third-party action so taken out here.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On factor\u00a0(a) (at [16] above), the Judge was of the view that that was primarily a question of law. As for factor\u00a0(b) (at [16] above), he observed that only Ms\u00a0Francis and George Chau of CIMB communicated with Ms\u00a0Callaghan of Dresdner London in relation to the payment. Therefore, only these three persons would really be able to shed any light on the issue of payment. Ms\u00a0Francis was still in the employment of CIMB so there should be no difficulty in getting her to come over to Singapore to testify; it was only a matter of some expense which was well within the means of CIMB. In his view, this was not a significant factor. George Chau had left CIMB\u2019s employment and his whereabouts were not known. The Judge rejected CIMB\u2019s argument that it would not be able to call the people from BPAL to be witnesses unless the trial was in London because, in his opinion, it was \u201cwholly unrealistic\u201d for CIMB to expect that the employees of BPAL would testify on its behalf given that it intended to take third-party action against BPAL (see the GD at [68]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On factors\u00a0(c) and (d) (at [16] above), the Judge stated that the event of CIMB\u2019s change of position upon receiving the Funds occurred in Singapore. But he also noted that what took place at CIMB Inanam was also material as it was that branch which purportedly gave the instructions to the Singapore branch to transfer the payment to Hong Kong in favour of another party, New Speed Technologies Ltd. As for the question of good faith in the remittance of the Funds from CIMB Singapore to Hong Kong, the evidence on that would depend on those same witnesses. If there was anyone who aided George Chau in the scam, it would likely be someone at CIMB Singapore. Two crucial witnesses of CIMB in this regard would be George Chau and Paul Ma, both of whom had ceased to be in the employment of CIMB and whose whereabouts were unknown. But the last-known address of Paul Ma was in Singapore and that of George Chau was in Malaysia. The Judge observed that, in any event, the relevant evidence in this connection was to be found in Singapore and Malaysia, not England.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At this juncture, we would refer to the remarks of the Judge on the general question of the location of the witnesses (at [82] of the GD):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[Dresdner] took pains during the hearing to impress upon me that it will facilitate the attendance of its London witnesses before the Singapore court, if the permanent stay application is not granted. Similarly, [CIMB] informed me that it will facilitate the attendance of its Singapore and Malaysian witnesses before the English court, if the action were stayed. As some of these potential witnesses are located in England and others in Singapore and Malaysia, I will not regard the convenience and cost factor to be weighing distinctly in favour either of Singapore or England for the trial. It is a fairly neutral factor in my judgment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for factor\u00a0(e) (at [16] above), in view of the position taken by Dresdner as evidenced by the Undertaking (see [12] above), the Judge came to the conclusion that there was, in truth, no contract in existence between the parties. This was not a case of a failed contract, <i>ie</i>, it was not a case where the parties had entered into a contractual relationship which failed. Effectively, it was a case of George Chau having perpetrated a fraud on both CIMB and Dresdner. In the circumstances, the Judge held that there was no prior relationship to which reference might be made or which might contribute to the identification of the proper law of the obligation to make restitution. The choice of law stated in the purported contract could not be relevant to the determination of the proper law that should govern the restoration of the alleged unjust enrichment. The obligation to make restitution would be governed by the law of the country with which the obligation to make restitution had the closest and most real connection. On this test, and taking into account all the circumstances of the case, the Judge concluded that the place with the closest and most real connection with the obligation to restore the benefit of the alleged enrichment was Singapore and not England.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to factor\u00a0(f) (at [16] above), the evidence suggested that CIMB was likely to make claims against HSBC Hong Kong and BPAL. On the claim against HSBC Hong Kong, the Judge noted that the governing law was likely to be Hong Kong or Singapore. It would certainly have nothing to do with England. As for the claim against BPAL, that claim would be either for negligence or breach of duty in respect of BPAL\u2019s failure to conduct due diligence on Innaria and the underlying project for which the Notes were issued, or for conspiracy, or both. Thus, the claim which CIMB was likely to bring against BPAL would be quite different, and indeed very wide-ranging, from the rather straightforward claim of unjust enrichment which Dresdner was making against CIMB. To link CIMB\u2019s claim against BPAL with the present action by Dresdner against CIMB would unnecessarily prolong the trial of the present action. The Judge accepted that if the nature of the third-party proceedings were to fall within the scope of O\u00a016 r\u00a01 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006\u00a0Rev Ed), it was generally convenient that all the proceedings should be tried in the same forum. However, without knowing the full facts of the third-party claim and the likely responses of BPAL, the Judge was inclined to the view, in a tentative way, that it was probably more appropriate to try the claim in England after the Singapore action had been disposed of. Therefore, the Judge gave very little weight to the third-party claim which CIMB would be making against BPAL.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, the Judge concluded that CIMB had not shown that London was the more appropriate forum to adjudicate on the present unjust enrichment claim by Dresdner against CIMB because (see the GD at [143]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 CIMB\u2019s unjust enrichment occurred in Singapore;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Dresdner\u2019s causes of action principally for restitution, payment under a mistake and for money had and received arose in Singapore;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 CIMB\u2019s alleged change of position occurred in Singapore;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 CIMB\u2019s state of mind, if and when it changed its position would, <i>inter alia</i>, be that of its employees in its Singapore branch. In any event, witnesses who were still employees of CIMB or Dresdner would be readily made available at the trial by the parties themselves wherever that trial was held;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for witnesses who were not employees, Paul Ma (if he could be found) was likely to be in Singapore, while George Chau (if he could be found) was likely to be in Malaysia;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(f) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the documents relating to CIMB\u2019s alleged change of position were mainly in Singapore;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the governing law of Dresdner\u2019s action in restitution was Singapore law;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it was undisputed that the Singapore courts had jurisdiction over Dresdner\u2019s present action; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it was undisputed that CIMB had a presence in Singapore and carried on business in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>General principles governing <i>forum non conveniens</i></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>locus classicus</i> on the question of when a stay would be granted on the basis of <i>forum non conveniens</i> is <i>Spiliada Maritime Corporation v Cansulex Ltd</i> [1987] AC\u00a0460 (\u201c<i>Spiliada</i>\u201d), a decision of the House of Lords where Lord Goff of Chieveley, in delivering the leading judgment, laid down certain guiding principles (at 476\u2013478) for determining the question of <i>forum non conveniens</i> (\u201cthe <i>Spiliada</i> test\u201d). Those principles have been adopted by this court in several cases such as <i>Brinkerhoff Maritime Drilling Corp v PT Airfast Services Indonesia</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 SLR 776</nobr>, <i>Eng Liat Kiang v Eng Bak Hern</i> <nobr>[1995] 3 SLR 97</nobr>, <i>PT\u00a0Hutan Domas Raya v Yue Xiu Enterprises</i> (<i>Holdings</i>) <i>Limited</i> <nobr>[2001] 2 SLR 49</nobr> and <i>Rickshaw Investments Ltd v Nicolai Baron von Uexkull</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 377</nobr> (\u201c<i>Rickshaw Investments</i>\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The gist of these principles is that, under the doctrine of <i>forum non conveniens</i>, a stay will only be granted where the court is satisfied that there is some other available and more appropriate forum for the trial of the action. The burden of establishing this rests on the defendant and it is not enough just to show that Singapore is not the natural or appropriate forum. The defendant must also establish that there is another available forum which is clearly or distinctly more appropriate than Singapore. The natural forum is one with which the action has the most real and substantial connection. In this regard, the factors which the court will take into consideration include not only factors affecting convenience or expense (such as the availability of witnesses) but also other factors such as the law governing the transaction and the places where the parties respectively reside or carry on business. If the court concludes, at this stage of the inquiry (\u201cstage one of the <i>Spiliada</i> test\u201d), that there is no other available forum which is clearly more appropriate for the trial of the action, it will ordinarily refuse a stay. If, at this stage, it concludes that there is some other available forum which <i>prima facie</i> is clearly more appropriate for the trial of the action, it will ordinarily grant a stay, unless there are circumstances by reason of which justice requires that a stay should nevertheless be refused. In this connection, the court will consider all the circumstances of the case.
