At best, even taking the position that English law is the applicable law for the restitution claim, we did not think, given the cause of action, that the relevant factors clearly point to England being the more appropriate forum to hear the dispute between the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>Stage two of the</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Spiliada <em>test</em></span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In case we were wrong in the determination of stage one of the <i>Spiliada</i> test, we come next to stage two of the <i>Spiliada</i> test (see [26] above). Dresdner argued that it would be severely prejudiced if its action were not heard in Singapore because it would be deprived of the opportunity to subpoena essential witnesses who would be required to demolish CIMB\u2019s defence of change of position in good faith. Here, quite clearly, Dresdner had in mind witnesses such as Paul Ma, Razak and Ms\u00a0Roshida.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The crucial question is, how does this weigh against CIMB\u2019s contention that if the main action were to be held here, it would not be able to subpoena BPAL\u2019s employees, who were in London, as well as its London employees who had left its employment, to testify? In any event, as stated in [83] above, and bearing in mind the third-party proceeding hanging over the head of BPAL, it would not be likely that BPAL\u2019s employees would co\u2011operate. If BPAL did not wish to co\u2011operate, it would be foolhardy for CIMB to call BPAL\u2019s employees to testify. If, on the other hand, BPAL were prepared to co\u2011operate, then the question of the compellability of BPAL\u2019s employees would become academic.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As submitted by Dresdner, the facts and issues in CIMB\u2019s claim against BPAL in negligence and conspiracy would be very different from those needed to prove the claim in the present action. There would be no common factual questions and no inextricable link between the present action and the third-party claim by CIMB against BPAL. The Judge thought that the appropriate forum to hear the action by CIMB against BPAL was probably England (at [127] of the GD). We agree, but ultimately in the present action, whether or not Dresdner would be able to succeed in its claim against CIMB would in fact depend on whether Dresdner could show bad faith when CIMB Singapore transferred the Funds to HSBC Hong Kong. For this critical question, the evidence would be here in Singapore. Thus, even if it were shown that the present action and the proposed CIMB\u2019s third-party claim against BPAL are intricately linked (which we do not think is the case), and that, contrary to what we hold, England is the more appropriate forum to hear the action, we were, for the aforesaid reasons, of the opinion that justice required that the action be nevertheless heard in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, we affirmed the Judge\u2019s decision that the present action would be temporarily stayed pending the completion of the German proceedings. In the meantime, CIMB could proceed with its intended third-party actions. In the result, CIMB\u2019s appeal was dismissed with costs with the usual consequential orders.</span></p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3233\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Negligence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3239\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Duty of care</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether tortfeasor owing duty of care not to cause psychiatric harm</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether communication of matters relating to accident sufficient to found duty of care</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">29\u00a0May 2008</p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-date-rsvd\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-author\">Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>Introduction</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against the decision of the trial judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d), who dismissed the appellants\u2019 claims for damages (see <i>Ngiam Kong Seng v CitiCab Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2007] SGHC 38</nobr>) (\u201cthe GD\u201d)). We dismissed the appeal and now give the reasons for our decision.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Spandeck Engineering (S) Pte Ltd v Defence Science &amp; Technology Agency</i> <nobr>[2007] 4 SLR 100</nobr> (\u201c<i>Spandeck</i>\u201d), this court set out the applicable test in Singapore for ascertaining the existence of a duty of care in cases involving claims for pure economic loss (\u201ccases of pure economic loss\u201d) and cases involving claims for personal injuries and/or physical damage (collectively, \u201ccases of physical damage\u201d). The present appeal raises the issue as to what the applicable principles are for ascertaining whether a duty of care exists <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> cases involving psychiatric illness or nervous shock (collectively referred to as \u201cpsychiatric harm\u201d in these grounds of decision).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While the focus of the hearing for the present appeal was on the decision of the Judge as to the question of whether the respondent had negligently caused the first appellant to suffer physical injuries, the second appellant\u2019s claim that the respondent had caused her to suffer clinical depression entailed a consideration of the applicable principles for ascertaining whether a duty of care exists in cases of psychiatric harm.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>The facts</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first appellant (the first plaintiff in the proceedings below), Ngiam Kong Seng, was the owner and the rider (at the material time) of motorcycle licence plate No\u00a0AZ\u00a03210\u00a0S (\u201cthe Motorcycle\u201d). The second appellant (the second plaintiff in the court below), Quek Sai Wah, is the wife of the first appellant. The respondent (the second defendant in the proceedings below), Lim Chiew Hock, was the driver of taxi licence plate No\u00a0SHA\u00a09997\u00a0P (\u201cthe Taxi\u201d).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first appellant, while riding the Motorcycle towards Ang Mo Kio, was involved in a traffic accident (\u201cthe Accident\u201d), which was allegedly caused by the respondent (who was then driving the Taxi), on 27\u00a0January 2004 at about 3.19pm along the Central Expressway. As a result of the Accident, the first appellant sustained severe injuries which rendered him a tetraplegic. The first appellant is now dependent for the rest of his life on a caregiver \u2013 the main caregiver being the second appellant \u2013 for activities relating to daily living and mobility.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the time of the Accident, the first appellant was 61 years old, and was working for the Port of Singapore Authority as an operations supervisor. He was due to retire a year later. The second appellant was 59 years old at the material time.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both immediately after and during the period following the Accident, the respondent represented himself to be a helpful bystander who had rendered assistance to the first appellant. The second appellant was, accordingly, led to believe that the respondent was a good Samaritan and developed feelings of gratitude towards him. The inquiries by the appellants\u2019 solicitors eventually led to the second appellant being told that the respondent had been involved in the Accident. She subsequently suffered from major depression and suicidal tendencies resulting from, she claimed, having been \u201cbetrayed\u201d (see the GD at [12]) by the respondent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants eventually started an action in negligence against the owner of the Taxi, CityCab Pte Ltd (the first defendant in the proceedings below), and the respondent. The claim against CityCab Pte Ltd was withdrawn before the trial in the High Court. The first appellant alleged that at the material time, the Taxi had collided into the rear of the Motorcycle, causing him to be flung backwards and onto the road. It was argued that the collision had been caused by the respondent\u2019s negligence, which was particularised to include, <i>inter alia</i>, driving at an excessive speed, failing to keep a proper lookout, failing to steer a safe and proper course, and failing to maintain a safe distance from the Motorcycle. The second appellant alleged that she had suffered from clinical depression as a result of:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the respondent\u2019s failure to inform her of the severity of the first appellant\u2019s injuries and of his (the respondent\u2019s) involvement in the Accident; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the respondent\u2019s conduct in causing her to believe that he had been a helpful bystander at the time of the Accident.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In his defence, it was argued by the respondent that the Accident had not been caused by a collision between the Taxi and the Motorcycle, but had instead occurred after the Motorcycle had \u201cself-skidded\u201d<a id=\"_ftnref1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\" name=\"_ftnref1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 1]</span></span></a>. The respondent was adamant that the Taxi had not hit the Motorcycle, and argued that even if there had been a collision between the two vehicles, it would have taken place after the Motorcycle had self-skidded. The respondent denied that the Accident had been caused or contributed to by his negligence, and argued that it had been caused or contributed to instead by the negligence of the first appellant in riding the Motorcycle. In so far as the second appellant\u2019s claim was concerned, the respondent argued that if the second appellant had indeed suffered the loss, damage and expense alleged, these would have been caused solely or partly by the negligence of the first appellant. The respondent also argued that the second appellant\u2019s claim should fail as she had not witnessed the Accident; nor had she been of sufficient proximity in time or space to the scene of the Accident such as would result in her alleged psychiatric problems.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the trial, in so far as the appellants\u2019 case was concerned, both appellants testified, along with their eldest son, Ngiam Peng Hong. They also adduced expert testimony from medical practitioners on the mental state of the second appellant. In so far as the respondent\u2019s defence was concerned, the respondent testified, along with an independent witness, his passenger at the material time, Ms\u00a0Maureen Andrew (\u201cMs\u00a0Andrew\u201d), as well as an accident reconstruction expert. The Traffic Police investigating officer who had investigated the case, Staff Sergeant\u00a0Andy Foo (\u201cMr\u00a0Foo\u201d), was also called upon by the respondent to testify as an independent witness. (At the time of the trial, Mr\u00a0Foo had already resigned from the Singapore Police Force to become an insurance agent.)</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>The decision below</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Liability was the only issue which had to be determined in the court below. For the first appellant\u2019s claim, the Judge had to consider whether the respondent, on the facts, was \u201cresponsible for the first [appellant\u2019s] condition\u201d (see the GD at [74]). This issue was also described as follows (see the GD at [26]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">What was common ground was that the first plaintiff [<i>ie</i>, the first appellant] lost control of the [M]otorcycle. What was in dispute was why he lost control. Was it because the [T]axi rear-ended the [M]otorcycle as the first plaintiff asserted? Or, as the second defendant [<i>ie</i>, the respondent] was to contend, \u2026 was [it] because the [M]otorcycle self-skidded due to the wet and slippery road and not because of any impact with the [T]axi[?]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge found the evidence of the first appellant to be inconsistent with regard to, <i>inter alia</i>, which part of the Motorcycle had been hit and how he had fallen off the Motorcycle. The Judge found the respondent\u2019s evidence, in contrast, to be consistent. Moreover, the evidence of the independent witnesses (Ms\u00a0Andrew and Mr\u00a0Foo), as well as other evidence including, <i>inter alia</i>, evidence of the absence of damage to the vehicles concerned supported the respondent\u2019s case. The Judge, accordingly, came to the conclusion that the respondent\u2019s version of the events should be accepted and that the first appellant\u2019s claim should therefore be dismissed (see the GD at [75]\u2013[83]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the second appellant was concerned, the Judge was of the view that the second appellant\u2019s case hinged on the first appellant\u2019s case, and, therefore, since the first appellant\u2019s claim had been dismissed, the second appellant\u2019s claim must, as a consequence, fail <i>in limine</i> (see the GD at [87]). The Judge also held that even if the respondent had been found to be liable to the first appellant, the second appellant\u2019s claim would still have been rejected on the grounds, <i>inter alia</i>, that (see the GD at [87]\u2013[90]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the claim had no basis in law and was too remote;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the depression suffered by the second appellant had been caused by her inability to cope with her new burden of being the first appellant\u2019s primary caregiver, rather than by the respondent\u2019s acts or omissions; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the claim had merely been an afterthought.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>The first appellant\u2019s case on appeal</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before this court, the first appellant argued that the decision of the Judge on the facts \u2013 that the respondent was not responsible for the Accident \u2013 should be overturned. The law on whether an appellate court should overturn a finding of fact by a trial judge is clear and need not be elaborated upon, save to state that a trial judge\u2019s finding of fact must be plainly wrong before it will be overturned by an appellate court. We rejected the first appellant\u2019s arguments on appeal as there was no basis for finding that the Judge\u2019s decision was plainly wrong.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The only witness who firmly testified that the Accident had been caused by the respondent was the first appellant himself. However, there were inconsistencies in his evidence, as correctly pointed out by the Judge. Even if we had disregarded the inconsistencies, more evidence would have been needed to establish the first appellant\u2019s claim on a balance of probabilities as the Motorcycle had (allegedly) been hit in the rear, meaning that the first appellant could not have actually witnessed any collision as he would, in all likelihood, have been looking ahead (thus facing the opposite direction) and not behind at the alleged point of contact between the Motorcycle and the Taxi.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The only other eyewitnesses of the Accident who testified were the respondent and Ms\u00a0Andrew. Of great significance was the fact that the evidence of Ms\u00a0Andrew, an independent witness, not only did not contradict the respondent\u2019s evidence, but also did not support the first appellant\u2019s evidence.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Of even greater significance was the lack of objective evidence in support of the first appellant\u2019s case. The Traffic Police accident reports and the post-accident pictures of the Motorcycle and the Taxi revealed that there had been no damage to the rear of the Motorcycle and the front of the Taxi. The only \u201cdamage\u201d that the first appellant could point to was a semi-circular black mark (which was described in the appellants\u2019 written submissions as an \u201cimprint\u201d<a id=\"_ftnref2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\" name=\"_ftnref2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\">[note: 2]</span></span></a>) located on the left side of the Taxi just below the left wing mirror. It was contended that this was proof that the Taxi had struck the storage box at the rear of the Motorcycle (\u201cthe rear box\u201d). Having examining photographs of the imprint, we agreed with the accident reconstruction expert\u2019s view, which was in fact consistent with common knowledge of the forces of nature, that it would have been physically impossible for the imprint to have been created by the Taxi hitting the rear box. The shape of the imprint was such that in order for the semi-circular arch to have been created, the rear box must have made contact with the Taxi initially at a point lower than the crest of the curve, with the point or area of contact then going up to the crest before going down again. In other words, the Motorcycle would have had to first fall, make contact with the Taxi, and then rise and fall again. This would be against the laws of gravity. Other than the rear box, only the tyres of the Motorcycle could possibly have caused the imprint on the Taxi, but we found this suggestion implausible. For one, as the accident reconstruction expert testified, the imprint was not consistent with the height of the front wheel of the Motorcycle, based on height measurements taken of that wheel and of the left side of the Taxi. As for the likelihood of the Motorcycle\u2019s rear tyre having caused the imprint, we likewise found this highly unlikely as that tyre was surrounded (or, loosely speaking, \u201cprotected\u201d) by protruding objects such as the exhaust pipes, the rear foot rest, the rear box and the rear suspension. If there had indeed been contact between the Motorcycle and the Taxi, these protrusions at the rear of the Motorcycle, rather than the rear tyre itself, would have come into contact with the Taxi first.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the foregoing reasons, we came to the conclusion that the first appellant had failed to establish his case on a balance of probabilities and, accordingly, dismissed the appeal as far as he was concerned.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>The second appellant\u2019s case on appeal</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second appellant argued that the Judge had erred in holding that her claim for damages for clinical depression should fail and challenged the latter\u2019s reasons for this decision. In our view, before considering the substantive merits of the second appellant\u2019s arguments, it would be appropriate, first, to set out the applicable principles relating to the ascertainment of liability in the context of claims in negligence for psychiatric harm.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>The law relating to claims in negligence for psychiatric harm</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Overview</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The general position in Singapore with respect to liability for negligence in cases of <i>pure economic loss</i> and cases of <i>physical damage</i> has now been settled by the recent decision of this court in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>). Briefly stated, the position in Singapore follows, in the main, the two-stage test laid down by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Anns</i> <i>v Merton London Borough Council</i> [1978] AC\u00a0728 (\u201c<i>Anns</i>\u201d), where the learned law lord observed, as follows (at 751\u2013752):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[I]n order to establish that a duty of care arises in a particular situation, <i>it is not necessary to bring the facts of that situation within those of previous situations in which a duty of care has been held to exist.</i> Rather the question has to be approached in two stages. First one has to ask whether, as between the alleged wrongdoer and the person who has suffered damage there is a sufficient relationship of proximity or neighbourhood such that, in the reasonable contemplation of the former, carelessness on his part may be likely to cause damage to the latter \u2013 in which case a prima facie duty of care arises. Secondly, if the first question is answered affirmatively, it is necessary to consider whether there are any considerations which ought to negative, or to reduce or limit the scope of the duty or the class of persons to whom it is owed or the damages to which a breach of it may give rise \u2026 [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 More specifically, Chan Sek Keong\u00a0CJ, delivering the judgment of the court in <i>Spandeck</i>, observed thus (at [73]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><i>In our view, a coherent and workable test can be fashioned out of the basic two-stage test premised on proximity and policy considerations, if its application is preceded by a preliminary requirement of</i></b> <i>factual</i> <i><b>foreseeability. We would add that this test is to be applied</b> incrementally</i>, <b><i>in the sense that when applying the test in each stage, it would be desirable to refer to decided cases in analogous situations to see how the courts have reached their conclusions in terms of proximity and/or policy.</i></b> As is obvious, the existence of analogous precedents, which determines the current limits of liability, would make it easier for the later court to determine whether or not to extend its limits. However, the absence of a factual precedent, which implies the presence of a novel situation, should not preclude the court from extending liability where it is just and fair to do so, taking into account the relevant policy consideration against indeterminate liability against a tortfeasor. <b><i>We would admit at this juncture that this is basically a restatement of the two-stage test in Anns, tempered by the preliminary requirement of factual foreseeability. Indeed, we should point out that this is the test applied in substance by many jurisdictions in the Commonwealth</i></b>: see, for example, the Canadian case of <i>Cooper v Hobart</i> (2001) 206\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th)\u00a0193; the New Zealand case of <i>Rolls-Royce New Zealand Ltd v Carter Holt Harvey Ltd</i> <nobr>[2005] 1 NZLR 324</nobr> \u2026 [emphasis in original in italics; emphasis added in bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In a similar vein, the learned Chief Justice summarised the applicable law in Singapore at the end of the judgment in <i>Spandeck</i> in the following terms (at [115]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">To recapitulate: A <i>single</i> test to determine the existence of a duty of care should be applied regardless of the nature of the damage caused (<i>ie</i>, pure economic loss or physical damage). It could be that a more restricted approach is preferable for cases of pure economic loss but this is to be done within the confines of a single test. <b><i>This test is a two-stage test, comprising of, first, proximity and, second, policy considerations. These two stages are to be approached with reference to the facts of decided cases although the absence of such cases is not an absolute bar against a finding of duty. There is, of course, the threshold issue of factual foreseeability but since this is likely to be fulfilled in most cases, we do not see the need to include this as part of the</i></b> <i>legal <b>test for a duty of care.</b></i> [emphasis in original in italics; emphasis added in bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court in <i>Spandeck</i> did not need to consider what ought to be the applicable legal rules and principles with respect to liability in the sphere of <i>psychiatric harm</i>. That particular issue, however, arises in the present appeal in relation to the second appellant and raises an important (and related) question: To what extent is the two-stage test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> applicable in the sphere of psychiatric harm? By way of a brief overview of the answer to this question, which will be elaborated upon in more detail in a moment, this same two-stage test applies in cases of psychiatric harm as well, although specific criteria would apply in this particular context.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The law relating to liability in negligence for psychiatric harm has had a lengthy and (to a large extent) chequered history (see, generally, Peter R\u00a0Handford, <i>Mullany and Handford\u2019s Tort Liability for Psychiatric Damage</i> (Lawbook Co, 2nd\u00a0Ed, 2006), especially at ch\u00a01). It is clear, however, that a significant legal watershed occurred when the leading decision of the House of Lords in <i>McLoughlin v O\u2019Brian</i> [1983] 1\u00a0AC 410 (\u201c<i>McLoughlin</i>\u201d) was delivered in 1982 (this was followed in subsequent decisions, notably, the (also) House of Lords decisions of <i>Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police</i> [1992] 1\u00a0AC 310 (\u201c<i>Alcock</i>\u201d) and <i>White v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police</i> [1999] 2\u00a0AC 455 (\u201c<i>White</i>\u201d)). The next major landmark in this area of the law (also laid down by the House of Lords) was the decision in <i>Page v Smith</i> [1996] AC\u00a0155 (\u201c<i>Page</i>\u201d). As we shall see, the decisions in <i>McLoughlin</i> and <i>Page</i>, whilst seminal in their own right, have engendered difficulties which require clarification (in the case of the former) and even rejection (in the case of the latter) in the context of what the position in Singapore ought to be. We will elaborate upon these observations in due course.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is apposite, in the meantime, to note that there is a dearth of case law in Singapore with regard to claims in negligence for psychiatric harm. Indeed, there appears to be only one significant decision which has analysed the duty of care in this area of the tort of negligence in any detail \u2013 the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Pang Koi Fa v Lim Djoe Phing</i> <nobr>[1993] 3 SLR 317</nobr> (\u201c<i>Pang Koi Fa</i>\u201d), where the principles laid down in <i>McLoughlin</i> were applied. These principles were also applied in the Malaysian High Court decision of <i>Jub\u2019il bin Mohamed Taib Taral v Sunway Lagoon Sdn Bhd</i> <nobr>[2001] 6 MLJ 669</nobr>. There is an older Malaysian High Court decision, <i>Zainab Binti Ismail v Marimuthu</i> <nobr>[1955] MLJ 22</nobr>, where <i>Bourhill v Young</i> [1943] AC\u00a092 (\u201c<i>Bourhill</i>\u201d) and <i>Hambrook v Stokes Brothers</i> [1925] 1\u00a0KB 141 (\u201c<i>Hambrook</i>\u201d) were cited. There is also a more recent decision (also of the Singapore High Court), <i>Man Mohan Singh s/o Jothirambal Singh v Dilveer Singh Gill s/o Shokdarchan Singh</i> <nobr>[2007] 4 SLR 843</nobr>, where there was some discussion of the issue (an appeal against the High Court\u2019s decision is currently pending before this court).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would be appropriate, in our view, if we examine \u2013 in greater detail \u2013 the decisions of the House of Lords in both <i>McLoughlin</i> and <i>Page</i> before setting out what we consider the law in Singapore ought to be with regard to liability in negligence for psychiatric harm and how this legal framework relates to the approach and principles laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>The decision in</em> McLoughlin</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>The decision itself</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although the law preceding the House of Lords\u2019 decision in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) was not by any means a legal vacuum (see, for example, the (earlier) House of Lords decision of <i>Bourhill</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>)), as alluded to earlier (above at [23]), <i>McLoughlin</i> was a major landmark in the law relating to liability for negligence that had inflicted psychiatric harm on the victim/plaintiff. It represented a detailed (and up-to-date) analysis of the law and laid down further guidelines for the courts.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The fact situation in <i>McLoughlin</i>, which is important to note, was as follows. There was a tragic and horrendous road accident which involved the plaintiff\u2019s husband (\u201cMr\u00a0McLoughlin\u201d), who was driving, and three of her children. Another child (\u201cthe fourth child\u201d), travelling in a following car, was (fortunately) not involved in the accident. The collision was between the car driven by Mr\u00a0McLoughlin and a lorry driven by the first defendant (and owned by the second defendant). That particular lorry had, in fact, been in a collision with another lorry driven by the third defendant (and owned by the fourth defendant). It was admitted that the accident to the car driven by Mr\u00a0McLoughlin was caused by the defendants\u2019 negligence.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0McLoughlin suffered bruising and shock. One child, a son aged 17 (\u201cthe first child\u201d), suffered injuries to his head and his face, cerebral concussion, fractures of both scapulae as well as bruising and abrasions. Another child, a daughter aged seven (\u201cthe second child\u201d), suffered concussion, a fracture of the right clavicle, bruising, abrasions and shock. A third child, a daughter who was nearly three years old (\u201cthe third child\u201d), was so seriously injured that she died almost immediately.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The plaintiff herself (\u201cMrs\u00a0McLoughlin\u201d) was at home at the time of the accident. This was about <i>two miles</i> from the scene of the accident. The person driving the car in which the fourth child (a son aged 11) was travelling reported the accident to Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin about <i>an hour or so later</i>. He told her that he thought that the first child was dying, and that he did not know the whereabouts of Mr\u00a0McLoughlin or the condition of her daughter. <i>He then drove her to the hospital</i> <i>to which her children and Mr\u00a0McLoughlin had been taken</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">30<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the hospital</i>, Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin met the fourth child (who had been in the other car, thereby escaping injury), who told her that the third child was dead. Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin was then taken down a corridor and, through a window, she saw the second child, who was crying, with her face cut and covered with dirt and oil. She could also hear the first child shouting and screaming. She was then taken to Mr\u00a0McLoughlin, who was sitting with his head in his hands and who was dishevelled and covered in mud and oil. He began sobbing when he saw Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin. The latter was then taken to see the first child, whose left face and left side were covered entirely. He appeared to recognise Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin, but then lapsed into unconsciousness. Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin was then taken to see the second child, who had by then been cleaned up. The latter was too upset to speak and simply clung on to Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin. As Lord\u00a0Wilberforce put it (see <i>McLoughlin</i> at 417):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">There can be no doubt that these circumstances, witnessed by the appellant [<i>ie</i>, Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin], were distressing in the extreme and were capable of producing an effect going well beyond that of grief and sorrow.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin subsequently brought proceedings against the defendants. It is important to note that it was <i>assumed</i> by the trial judge that Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin was a person of reasonable fortitude and had indeed suffered the condition complained of, which was described by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce as \u201csevere shock, organic depression and a change of personality\u201d, with \u201c[n]umerous symptoms of a physiological character \u2026 manifested\u201d (<i>ibid</i>). The type of psychiatric harm which Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin claimed she had suffered is a not unimportant point, simply because a <i>threshold</i> requirement (as described by Lord\u00a0Bridge of Harwich in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) at 431) which must be satisfied before there can be recovery for psychiatric harm is that the claimant must have suffered from <i>a recognisable psychiatric illness</i> (though <i>cf</i> the terminology utilised in Australian legislation at [113] below).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The trial judge gave judgment in favour of the defendants, holding that they owed no duty of care to Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin because it was not reasonably foreseeable that she would suffer nervous shock.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The English Court of Appeal affirmed the decision at first instance, albeit on somewhat different grounds. This was well-summarised by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce, as follows (<i>id</i> at 417):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Stephenson\u00a0L.J. took the view that the possibility of injury to the appellant by nervous shock <i>was</i> reasonably foreseeable and that the respondents [<i>ie</i>, the defendants] owed the appellant a duty of care. However, he held that considerations of policy prevented the appellant from recovering. Griffiths\u00a0L.J. held that injury by nervous shock to the appellant was \u201creadily foreseeable\u201d but that the respondents owed no duty of care to the appellant. The duty was limited to those on the road nearby. Cumming-Bruce\u00a0L.J. agreed with both judgments. [emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin then appealed to the House of Lords. Lord\u00a0Wilberforce set out, in succinct fashion, the fundamental issue in the case, as follows (<i>id</i> at 417\u2013418):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The critical question to be decided is whether a person in the position of the appellant, i.e. one who was not present at the scene of grievous injuries to her family but who comes upon those injuries at an interval of time and space, can recover damages for nervous shock.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The House of Lords held in favour of Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin and therefore allowed the appeal. The leading judgment was, in fact, delivered by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce. Significantly, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce had earlier also laid down the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>). The observations made by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) will be set out in full not only because (as just mentioned) he delivered the leading judgment, but also because it is important, in our view, to clarify any terminological uncertainty that might be generated (particularly if we compare Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations in <i>McLoughlin</i> with his formulation of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>). Indeed, we shall demonstrate that Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s approach in <i>McLoughlin</i> towards ascertaining whether a defendant owed a duty of care was consistent with his approach in <i>Anns</i> and, consequently, with the approach that this court adopted in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>)<i>.</i> In order to proceed in the clearest way possible, we propose to divide Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations (which are important, albeit relatively lengthy) into three parts. Before proceeding to do so, however, we should note that two other law lords in <i>McLoughlin</i> arrived at the same result by adopting what was, in our view, a <i>much broader</i> approach. In particular, Lord\u00a0Bridge and Lord\u00a0Scarman applied a \u201cpure\u201d test of reasonable foreseeabilty without more (reference may also be made to the views of Thomas\u00a0J in the New Zealand Court of Appeal decision of <i>van Soest v Residual Health Management Unit</i> <nobr>[2000] 1 NZLR 179</nobr>, which may, in turn, be contrasted with the views of the other four judges in the same case, who adopted Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s approach in <i>McLoughlin</i> instead). With respect, the approach taken by Lord\u00a0Bridge and Lord\u00a0Scarman in <i>McLoughlin</i> is, in our view, too broad. As we shall see in a moment, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce added three factors which served to constrain the otherwise extensive liability that might result if a \u201cpure\u201d test of reasonable foreseeability alone were applied.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations in</em> McLoughlin <em>(in three parts)</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the <i>first part</i> (\u201c<i>Part\u00a01</i>\u201d) of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), Lord\u00a0Wilberforce observed thus (at 420\u2013421):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[A]t the margin, the boundaries of a man\u2019s responsibility for acts of negligence have to be fixed <i>as a matter of policy</i>. Whatever is the correct jurisprudential analysis, it does not make any essential difference whether one says, with Stephenson\u00a0L.J., that there is a duty but, as a matter of policy, the consequences of breach of it ought to be limited at a certain point, or whether, with Griffiths\u00a0L.J., one says that the fact that consequences may be foreseeable does not automatically impose a duty of care \u2026 [and] does not do so in fact where policy indicates the contrary. This is an approach which <i>one</i> <i>can see very clearly from the way in which Lord\u00a0Atkin stated the neighbour principle</i> in <i>Donoghue v. Stevenson</i> [1932] A.C.\u00a0562, 580: \u201cpersons who are so closely and directly affected by my act that I ought reasonably to have them in contemplation as being so affected. \u2026\u201d This is saying that <i>foreseeability must be accompanied and limited by</i> the <i>law\u2019s judgment</i> as to persons who ought, <i>according to its standards of value or justice</i>, to have been in [the defendant\u2019s] contemplation. <b><i>Foreseeability</i></b>, which involves a hypothetical person, looking with hindsight at an event which has occurred, is a formula adopted by English law, not merely for defining, but also for limiting, the persons to whom [a] duty may be owed, and the consequences for which an actor may be held responsible. <i>It is <b>not merely an issue of fact</b> to be left to be found as such</i>. When it is said to result in a duty of care being owed to a person or a class, <i>the statement that there is a \u201cduty of care\u201d denotes a conclusion into the forming of which considerations of policy have entered</i>. <b><i>That foreseeability does not of itself, and automatically, lead to a duty of care is, I think, clear</i>.</b> I gave some examples in <i>Anns v. Merton London Borough Council</i> [1978] A.C.\u00a0728, 752, <i>Anns</i> itself being one. I may add what Lord\u00a0Reid said in <i>McKew</i> v. <i>Holland &amp; Hannen &amp; Cubitts (Scotland) Ltd.</i> [1969] 3\u00a0All\u00a0E.R. 1621, 1623:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201cA defender is not liable for a consequence of a kind which is not foreseeable. But it does not follow that he is liable for every consequence which a reasonable man could foresee.\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><i>We must then consider the policy arguments</i></b>. In doing so we must bear in mind that cases of \u201cnervous shock,\u201d and the possibility of claiming damages for it, are not necessarily confined to those arising out of accidents on public roads. To state, therefore, a rule that recoverable damages must be confined to persons on or near the highway is to state not a principle in itself, but only an example of a more general rule that <i>recoverable damages must be confined to those within sight and sound of an event caused by negligence or, at least, to those in close, or very close, <b>proximity</b> to such a situation</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added in italics and bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Lord\u00a0Wilberforce then proceeded, in the <i>second part</i> (\u201c<i>Part\u00a02</i>\u201d) of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i>, to enunciate what he viewed to be the \u201c<i>policy</i> arguments <i>against</i> a wider extension\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>id</i> at 421) of liability, as follows (<i>ibid</i>):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>The policy arguments against a wider extension</i> can be stated under <i>four heads.</i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>First, it may be said that such extension may lead to a proliferation of claims, and possibly fraudulent claims</i>, to the establishment of an industry of lawyers and psychiatrists who will formulate a claim for nervous shock damages, including what in America is called the customary miscarriage, for all, or many, road accidents and industrial accidents.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Secondly, it may be claimed that an extension of liability would be unfair to defendants, as imposing damages out of proportion to the negligent conduct complained of</i>. In so far as such defendants are insured, <i>a large additional burden will be placed on insurers, and ultimately upon the class of persons insured \u2013 road users or employers</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Thirdly, to extend liability beyond the most direct and plain cases would greatly increase evidentiary difficulties and tend to lengthen litigation</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Fourthly</i>, it may be said \u2013 and the Court of Appeal agreed with this \u2013 that <i>an extension of the scope of liability ought only to be made by the legislature, after careful research.</i> This is the course which has been taken in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The whole argument has been well summed up by Dean Prosser (<em>Prosser</em><em>,</em><em>Torts</em>, 4th\u00a0ed. (1971), p.\u00a0256):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201cThe reluctance of the courts to enter this field even where the mental injury is clearly foreseeable, and the frequent mention of the difficulties of proof, the facility of fraud, and the problem of finding a place to stop and draw the line, suggest that here it is the nature of the interest invaded and the type of damage which is the real obstacle.\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Since he wrote, the type of damage has, in this country at least, become more familiar and less deterrent to recovery. <i>And some of the arguments are susceptible of answer. Fraudulent claims can be contained by the courts, who, also, can cope with evidentiary difficulties. The scarcity of cases which have occurred in the past, and the modest sums recovered, give some indication that fears of a flood of litigation may be exaggerated \u2013 experience in other fields suggests that such fears usually are. If some increase does occur, that may only reveal the existence of a genuine social need: that legislation has been found necessary in Australia may indicate the same thing.</i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, in the <i>third part</i> (\u201c<i>Part\u00a03</i>\u201d) of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i>, the learned law lord observed as follows (<i>id</i> at 421\u2013422):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><i>But, these discounts accepted, there remains</i></b>, in my opinion, just because \u201cshock\u201d in its nature is capable of affecting so wide a range of people,<b><i>a real need for the law to place some limitation upon the extent of admissible claims. It is necessary to consider three elements inherent in any claim: the class of persons</i></b> <i>whose claims should be recognised</i>; the <b><i>proximity</i></b> <i>of such persons</i> <b><i>to the accident; and the means by which the shock is caused.</i></b> As regards the class of persons, the possible range is between the closest of family ties \u2013 of parent and child, or husband and wife \u2013 and the ordinary bystander. Existing law recognises the claims of the first: it denies that of the second, either on the basis that such persons must be assumed to be possessed of fortitude sufficient to enable them to endure the calamities of modern life, or that defendants cannot be expected to compensate the world at large. In my opinion, these positions are justifiable, and since the present case falls within the first class, it is strictly unnecessary to say more. <i>I think, however, that it should follow that other cases involving less close relationships must be very carefully scrutinised. I cannot say that they should never be admitted. The closer the tie (not merely in relationship, but in care) the greater the claim for consideration.</i> <b><i>The claim, in any case, has to be judged in the light of the other factors, such as proximity to the scene in time and place, and the nature of the accident.</i></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>As regards <b>proximity</b> to the accident, it is obvious that this must be close in both time and space. It is, after all, the fact and consequence of the defendant\u2019s negligence that must be proved to have caused the \u201cnervous shock.\u201d Experience has shown that to insist on direct and immediate sight or hearing would be impractical and unjust and that under what may be called <b>the \u201caftermath\u201d doctrine</b> one who, from <b>close proximity</b>, comes very soon upon the scene should not be excluded.</i> In my opinion, the result in <i>Benson</i> v. <i>Lee</i> [1972] V.\u00a0R.\u00a0879 was correct and indeed inescapable. It was based, soundly, upon</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201cdirect perception of some of the events which go to make up the accident as an entire event, and this includes \u2026 the immediate aftermath \u2026\u201d (p.\u00a0880.)</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The High Court\u2019s majority decision in <i>Chester</i> v. <i>Waverley Corporation</i> (1939) 62\u00a0C.L.R. 1, where a child\u2019s body was found floating in a trench after a prolonged search, may perhaps be placed on the other side of a recognisable line (Evatt\u00a0J. in a powerful dissent placed it on the same side), but, in addition, I find the conclusion of Lush\u00a0J. [in <i>Benson v Lee</i>] to reflect developments in the law.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Finally, and by way of reinforcement of \u201caftermath\u201d cases, I would accept, by analogy with \u201crescue\u201d situations, that a person of whom it could be said that one could expect nothing else than that he or she would come immediately to the scene \u2013 normally a parent or a spouse \u2013 could be regarded as being within the scope of foresight and duty. Where there is not immediate presence, account must be taken of the possibility of alterations in the circumstances, for which the defendant should not be responsible.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Subject only to these qualifications, I think that a strict test of <b>proximity</b> by sight or hearing should be applied by the courts.</i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>Lastly, as regards communication, there is no case in which the law has compensated shock brought about by communication by a third party.</i> In <i>Hambrook v. Stokes Brothers</i> [1925] 1\u00a0K.B. 141, indeed, it was said that liability would not arise in such a case and this is surely right. It was so decided in <i>Abramzik</i> v. <i>Brenner</i> (1967) 65\u00a0D.L.R. (2d)\u00a0651. <i>The shock must come through sight or hearing of the event or of its immediate aftermath. Whether some equivalent of sight or hearing, e.g. through simultaneous television, would suffice may have to be considered.</i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis added in italics and bold italics]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations considered</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">39<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Part\u00a01</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (reproduced above at [36]) is instructive in several ways. In its most <i>general</i> sense, this portion of the learned law lord\u2019s judgment not only reaffirms his earlier views in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) at 751\u2013752 (reproduced above at [20]), but also (and more importantly) supports and is consistent with the views of this court in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>), as reproduced above at [21]. These views constitute, in fact, the <i>general foundation</i> upon which a duty of care in claims in negligence for non-physical injury (including psychiatric harm) is based. Briefly, these views include the following:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court needs to draw clear <i>boundaries to (or place limits on)</i> liability in negligence for non-physical injury in order to ensure that such liability does not become indeterminate and/or arbitrary. As Prof\u00a0Tan Keng Feng aptly points out (see Tan Keng Feng, \u201cLiability for Psychiatric Illness \u2013 The English Law Commission\u201d (1999) 7\u00a0Tort Law Rev 165 (\u201cLiability for Psychiatric Illness\u201d)), there is <i>no</i> difficulty in so far as <i>physical</i> injury is concerned as the <i>very nature</i> of the injury <i>itself</i> constitutes the necessary boundary or limitation (which he terms the \u201cphysical impact limit\u201d (<i>id</i> at 166)). It should also be noted that this court in <i>Spandeck</i> was of the view (at [64] and [70]\u2013[72]) that there should not be different tests for determining whether a duty of care exists in cases of physical injury on the one hand and cases of non-physical injury on the other. Most importantly, perhaps, such boundaries or limits are drawn by the court as a matter of <i>policy</i>. <i>However</i>, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s reference to \u201cpolicy\u201d in <i>McLoughlin</i> will (as we shall see below) require some <i>clarification</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mere <i>factual</i> foreseeability, whilst a necessary condition or prerequisite to establish a duty of care, is <i>not</i> (<i>in and of itself</i>) sufficient (see <i>Spandeck</i> at [75]\u2013[76]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Proximity</i> between the plaintiff and the defendant is <i>also</i> a <i>condition or prerequisite</i> which must be satisfied in order to establish a duty of care (<i>id</i> at [77]) and, to this end, <i>policy</i> arguments must be considered.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before proceeding to consider <i>Part\u00a02</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> in more detail <i>and</i> in its <i>context</i>, an important clarification of the learned law lord\u2019s use of the concept of \u201c<i>policy</i>\u201d (at, <i>inter alia</i>, 421) is not only instructive, but also necessary in order to avoid the very real confusion that would otherwise result. Indeed, the danger of such confusion reminds us of the famous (and oft-cited) words of Burrough\u00a0J in the leading English decision of <i>Richardson v Mellish</i> (1824) 2\u00a0Bing 229; 130\u00a0ER 294 (at 252; 303) that public policy is:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[A] very unruly horse, and when once you get astride it you never know where it will carry you. It may lead you from the sound law.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">It is, of course, true that the ebullient Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR was, in comparison, more sanguine when he observed in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Enderby Town Football Club Ltd v Football Association Ltd</i> [1971] Ch\u00a0591 (at 606) that:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">With a good man in the saddle, the unruly horse can be kept in control. It can jump over obstacles.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">It is, nevertheless, clear that the concept of \u201cpublic policy\u201d is not an easy one and the court must be vigilant to ensure that it is properly conceived as well as properly applied. In the specific context of the present appeal, let us elaborate on how possible confusion can, in fact, be avoided.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The key to avoiding the possible confusion referred to in the preceding paragraph is to recognise that there are <i>different conceptions</i> of the <i>concept</i> of \u201c<i>policy</i>\u201d. Indeed, the concept of \u201c<i>public</i> policy\u201d referred to in that very same paragraph is but <i>one</i> conception of the concept of \u201cpolicy\u201d.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we shall illustrate in a moment, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce was, in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), referring to <i>two different conceptions</i> of the concept of \u201c<i>policy</i>\u201d.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>first</i> conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d does <i>not</i> refer to \u201c<i>public</i> policy\u201d as such. It is, rather, a reference to the <i>factors</i> that must be taken into account as between <i>the parties</i> to a negligence action (which constitute, in our view, an example of \u201c<i>legal</i> policy\u201d [emphasis added] as referred to in the House of Lords decision of <i>McFarlane v Tayside Health Board</i> [2000]\u00a02\u00a0AC 59 at 108, <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Millett). In particular, these factors will ensure that there is sufficient <i>proximity</i> between the parties. Indeed, as this court emphasised in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i> at [77]), <i>proximity</i> is the key <i>legal</i> focus in so far as the <i>first stage</i> of the two-stage test established therein is concerned. Looked at in this light, we would respectfully suggest that it is preferable (from both theoretical as well as practical points of view) <i>to avoid the use of the term \u201cpolicy\u201d altogether</i> when discussing <i>legal</i> policy and to refer, instead, to the concept of \u201c<i>proximity</i>\u201d. In other words, the term \u201cpolicy\u201d should be reserved exclusively for use in the context of \u201c<i>public</i> policy\u201d.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>second</i> conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d refers, as just mentioned, to \u201c<i>public</i> policy\u201d. Put simply, this particular conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d does <i>not</i> refer to the relationship between <i>the parties</i> as such (which, as we have emphasised in the preceding paragraph, is more appropriately characterised as well as analysed under the rubric of \u201c<i>proximity</i>\u201d), but refers, instead, to <i>broader societal</i> considerations. It is <i>this</i> particular conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d that constitutes the <i>second</i> stage of the two-stage test laid down by this court in <i>Spandeck</i>. In <i>Spandeck</i> itself, Chan\u00a0CJ elaborated upon this particular conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, as follows (at [83]\u2013[85]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Assuming a positive answer to the preliminary question of factual foreseeability and the first stage of the legal proximity test, a <i>prima facie</i> duty of care arises. Policy considerations should then be applied to the factual matrix to determine whether or not to negate this duty. Among the relevant policy considerations would be, for example, the presence of a contractual matrix which has clearly defined the rights and liabilities of the parties and the relative bargaining positions of the parties.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also recognise that the obvious objection to utilising policy as the overarching determinant of liability is its potential to result in arbitrary decisions. Although it is generally recognised that public policy is an unruly horse (<i>per</i> Burrough\u00a0J in <i>Richardson v Mellish</i> (1824) 2\u00a0Bing 229 at 252; 130\u00a0ER 294 at 303), it cannot be <i>completely</i> ignored. The danger is <i>not</i> with judges deciding cases based on policy considerations but rather with judges deciding cases based <i>solely</i> on them. We agree with [Prof\u00a0Tan Keng Feng, \u201cThe Three-Part Test: Yet Another Test of Duty in Negligence\u201d (1989) 31\u00a0Mal\u00a0L\u00a0Rev 223 at 228] that \u201c[t]he truth lies somewhere in between pure principle-based decisions and policy-based decisions\u201d and that \u201c[i]t is obviously impossible to decide cases <i>in vacuo</i>, exclusive of the interests and the context of the community for which the decisions are made\u201d. In our view, it is inescapable that some measure of public policy must be considered but it must not be the sole determinant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would also caution that when applying policy considerations to negate the imposition of a duty of care, the courts must be careful to differentiate such considerations from the requirement of proximity in the first stage of the test we have articulated. The courts must, as far as possible, avoid giving the impression that there remain \u201cunexpressed motives\u201d behind their finding for or against a duty. The courts must also not have litigants believe, as J\u00a0A\u00a0Smillie put it in \u201cThe Foundation of the Duty of Care in Negligence\u201d (1989) 15\u00a0Monash U\u00a0L\u00a0Rev\u00a0302 at 302, that \u201cnone of [the tests articulated by the courts] is truly explanatory of judges\u2019 reasoning or provides a helpful framework for analysis of the duty question\u201d. If there is truly a <i>pertinent and relevant</i> policy consideration involving value judgments which reflect differential weighing and balancing of competing moral claims and broad social welfare goals, we feel that it would be better if the courts were to articulate these concerns under the requirement of policy considerations, rather than subsume these concerns within the proximity requirement, which may then lead to an overall distortion of the legal test to determine the existence of a duty of care. In this respect, we agree with Nicholas J\u00a0Mullany when he notes in \u201cProximity, Policy and Procrastination\u201d (1992) 9\u00a0Aust Bar Rev 80 at 83 that:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">Judges should openly express the true premises of their decisions and, if recovery is considered to be undeserved, in the light of greater moral, social, economic, administrative or philosophical public perceptions, then these reasons and not others inherently uncertain in nature, should be expressed as the true foundation for denial of recovery.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Unfortunately, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce did <i>not</i>, with respect, distinguish between the two conceptions of \u201cpolicy\u201d referred to earlier (above at [43]\u2013[44]). For example, in <i>Part\u00a01</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> (reproduced above at [36]), the learned law lord was, in point of fact, referring to the <i>first</i> conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, <i>viz</i>, <i>legal</i> policy (or, to use the preferred term (see [43] above), <i>proximity</i>). <i>However</i>, in <i>Part\u00a02</i> of his judgment in the same case (reproduced above at [37]), Lord\u00a0Wilberforce appeared to be referring to aspects of the <i>second</i> conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, <i>viz</i>, <i>public</i> policy, instead. That <i>Part\u00a02</i> of his judgment <i>follows immediately from Part\u00a01</i> of the same judgment serves only to exacerbate the confusion in so far as the various conceptions of \u201cpolicy\u201d are concerned. It is admitted, however, that because the line between the universal and the particular (see the correlation between the two as pointed out by this court in <i>Spandeck</i> at [28]) is, by its very nature, not always clear (and may even be blurred), the opportunities for confusion are (unfortunately) multiplied. Nevertheless, a clear reading of <i>Part\u00a02</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> does, in fact, suggest (on <i>balance</i>) that it was the <i>second</i> (and <i>broader</i>) aspect of (<i>public</i>) \u201cpolicy\u201d that the learned law lord was referring to. That this is the correct interpretation to adopt is <i>confirmed</i>, <i>in no uncertain terms</i>, <i>by Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in the same case \u2013 to which our attention must now turn.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">46<i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment (reproduced above at [38]) is, in fact, the <i>most important</i> part of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>). It is, indeed, <i>this</i> particular part of the judgment that is cited most often. This is not surprising in view of the fact that the learned law lord set out in <i>Part\u00a03</i>, in detail, the \u201cthree elements\u201d (<i>id</i> at 422) which the court ought to consider in every claim founded on negligence that has resulted in <i>nervous shock</i>. Indeed, as already noted (above at [24]), these three elements were considered and applied by the <i>Singapore</i> High Court (in <i>Pang Koi Fa</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>)).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i>, the three elements referred to are clearly part of the first (and <i>narrower</i>) conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, <i>viz</i>, <i>legal</i> policy, which (as we have noted above at [43]) relates to the issue of <i>proximity</i> between <i>the parties</i> themselves. The learned law lord, in fact, <i>expressly stated</i> that this was so. He referred to the concept of \u201cproximity\u201d no fewer than five times in this part of his judgment. Indeed, he stated at 422 (see the passage reproduced above at [38]) that \u201c[t]he claim \u2026 ha[d] to be judged in the light of the other factors, such as <i>proximity</i> to the scene in time and place, and the nature of the accident\u201d [emphasis added]. It is also extremely significant, in our view, that <i>Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment <i>follows immediately from Part\u00a02</i> of the same judgment, where (as we noted above at [45]) there is a clear reference to the <i>second</i> (and <i>broader</i>) conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, <i>viz</i>, <i>public</i> policy. Indeed, the contrast between the second and the first conceptions of \u201cpolicy\u201d, <i>as embodied within Part\u00a02 and Part\u00a03 (respectively)</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i>, could not be clearer.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The upshot of the above analysis is that the apparent \u201cpolicy\u201d factors referred to by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> are, <i>in substance</i>, factors that relate to <i>proximity</i> between <i>the parties</i> instead. There would remain residuary \u201cpolicy\u201d factors that are, in our view, \u201ctrue\u201d policy factors inasmuch as they relate to <i>public</i> policy and thus fall within the purview of the <i>second</i> conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d. It will be seen that both these aforementioned stages of legal analysis \u2013 <i>ie</i>, consideration of, first, proximity, followed by public policy \u2013 <i>correspond precisely to the two-stage test set out by this court</i> in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>) (reproduced above at [21]). In other words \u2212 and this is an extremely important point \u2013 the two-stage test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> is <i>equally</i> applicable to a situation where there is a claim in negligence for psychiatric harm. There is therefore no need for a <i>separate</i> legal regime governing such a claim. It will be explained, further, <i>why</i> the two-stage test in <i>Spandeck</i> <i>should</i> be the legal approach that is to be adopted in <i>all</i> types of claims in negligence in <i>the Singapore context</i> in so far as establishing a legal duty of care on the part of the defendant is concerned. At this stage, it will suffice to state that such an approach, whilst simple, is by no means simplistic. On the contrary, it brings certainty to a much vexed (albeit extremely important) area of the law of tort that has engendered many difficulties, both confused and confusing, across Commonwealth jurisdictions.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>A comparison of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations in</em> McLoughlin <em>and in</em> Anns</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At this juncture, it remains for us to consider the possibility that, as a result of the approach which Lord\u00a0Wilberforce took in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), the two-stage test which he laid down in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) at 751\u2013752 (reproduced above at [20]) must now be reinterpreted as referring to <i>factual</i> foreseeability at the <i>first</i> stage, followed (at the <i>second</i> stage) by \u201c<i>policy</i>\u201d considerations in the <i>narrower</i> (and <i>first</i>) conception of \u201cpolicy\u201d, which (as we saw above at [43] and [45]) relates to <i>proximity</i>. We do not, however, think that this is what the learned law lord intended or meant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the first place, our analysis earlier (above at [42]\u2013[47]) clearly demonstrates that Lord\u00a0Wilberforce was referring to <i>two separate and distinct</i> conceptions of \u201cpolicy\u201d in <i>McLoughlin</i>. This, in all likelihood, means that he similarly had these two distinct conceptions of \u201cpolicy\u201d in mind when enunciating his two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, and on an even more important as well as closely-related note, Lord\u00a0Wilberforce referred, in <i>his very formulation</i> of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> itself, to the requirement, at the <i>first</i> stage, of \u201ca sufficient relationship of <i>proximity</i> or neighbourhood\u201d [emphasis added] (see <i>Anns</i> at 751).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thirdly, at least one subsequent House of Lords decision has adopted the interpretation of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment which we have advocated. In <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), the court treated the three factors enunciated by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) as falling within the sphere of <i>proximity</i> instead (<i>viz</i>, the first stage of the two-stage test set out in <i>Anns</i> (reproduced above at [20]) and in <i>Spandeck</i> (reproduced above at [21])). Amarjeet Singh\u00a0JC put it well in <i>Pang Koi Fa</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>), as follows (at 326, [33]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The additional consideration applied by their Lordships [in <i>Alcock</i>] was that of the \u2018relationship of proximity\u2019 according to the three proximities applied by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <em>McLoughlin</em>, <i>but unlike Lord\u00a0Wilberforce, their application of the three proximities was not a consideration of policy which limits the classes of cases where liability may be established.</i> Instead, their considerations of the three proximities were as a means of conditioning the duty of care, a further limitation to the existence and scope of the duty. In other words, <i>instead of considering the proximities as limitations to the classes where as a matter of policy, recovery may be permitted, the proximities were legal requirements defining the classes wherein recovery may be permitted, barring the additional considerations of justice and reasonableness</i>. As <i>legal</i> requirements, the threshold for their fulfilment is thus a <i>legal</i> threshold, and the extension of liability would be on an incremental basis by analogy with established categories, rather than on general principles of reasonable foreseeability. The parameters of the scope of the duty to avoid inflicting nervous shock had thus been redefined. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, and on the equally important level of general principle and development of the law in this difficult area, the approach which this court adopted in <i>Spandeck</i> (reproduced above at [21]) serves, simultaneously, to reconcile the <i>substance</i> of what appear to be rather inconsistent approaches (particularly under English law).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is, in the circumstances, <i>highly unlikely</i> that Lord\u00a0Wilberforce was referring to only <i>factual</i> foreseeability (<i>instead of proximity</i>) in the <i>first</i> stage of his two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>. If he was (and, as just mentioned, we do not think that this was the case in the first place), we must, respectfully, <i>disagree</i> with such an approach. However, it is vitally important to point out that, <i>even if</i> the <i>first</i> stage of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> is taken as referring to <i>factual</i> foreseeability <i>only</i>, <i>nothing</i> of <i>substance</i> would turn on it because, as this court explained in <i>Spandeck</i>, there must, in principle as well as in logic, justice and fairness, be a <i>holistic and integrated</i> analysis of the relevant factual matrix <i>both</i> from the perspective of <i>proximity</i> (as between <i>the parties</i>) <i>and</i> from the perspective of <i>public</i> policy (on a <i>broader societal</i> level). The latter may operate to exclude a duty of care for the purposes of the tort of negligence <i>even if</i> the situation concerned passes legal muster under the former (inasmuch as there is otherwise <i>proximity</i> between the parties in law).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Indeed, in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>), this court was clearly aware of the possible difficulties surrounding the meaning of the first stage of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>. As Chan\u00a0CJ put it (<i>id</i> at [34]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">It is well known that there is some controversy regarding the meaning of the first stage of the test: Did it relate only to the <i>factual</i> issue of reasonable foreseeability <i>or</i> did it introduce the <i>legal</i> conception of proximity \u2026 ? [emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The response to the question posed in the preceding paragraph was clear and unambiguous to this court. Chan\u00a0CJ observed thus (<i>id</i> at [75]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">As we mentioned earlier (see [34] above), there is <i>some controversy</i> in relation to <i>the interpretation of the first stage</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s test in <i>Anns</i>, <i>ie</i>, whether it refers to mere factual foreseeability or legal foreseeability or proximity. <i>In our view, factual foreseeability is too wide a criterion to be effective as a legal control mechanism if all that it means is that the defendant ought to have known that the claimant would suffer damage from his (the defendant\u2019s) carelessness. If this is the approach to be adopted, it would be fulfilled in almost all cases, because the two parties are likely to be in some degree of physical relationship in the relevant case.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Summary of our analysis of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s observations in</em> McLoughlin</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In summary, a close analysis of the observations of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (in the context of his earlier enunciation of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>)) reveals that his statements of principle in both of these cases are consistent with what this court decided in <i>Spandeck</i> (which adopted a two-stage test, with (legal) foreseeability or proximity as the focus at the first stage and (broader) public policy as the focus at the second stage) to the extent that the three factors set out in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of the learned law lord\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> are an integral part of the <i>first</i> stage of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>, which formed the basis of the (likewise) two-stage test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to consider the second major House of Lords decision, <i>viz</i>, <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>The decision in</em> Page</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>The decision itself</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The decision in <i>Page</i> was another major legal landmark in the law relating to liability in negligence for psychiatric harm. In that case, the House of Lords drew a clear distinction <i>between primary and secondary victims</i>. This distinction had, in fact, been drawn in earlier cases (for instance, <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Oliver of Aylmerton in <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) at 407). However, <i>Page</i> not only brought this distinction to the fore, but also elaborated upon it in some detail. More importantly, the House of Lords held in <i>Page</i> that where the plaintiff was the <i>primary</i> victim, he or she was entitled to recovery against the defendant <i>even when</i> the <i>psychiatric</i> harm suffered was <i>not reasonably foreseeable</i> by the latter <i>\u2013 provided that physical</i> injury to the plaintiff (which he or she <i>apprehended</i> <i>and</i> which need <i>not</i> have <i>actually occurred</i>) <i>was foreseeable and the apprehension of such physical injury resulted in the psychiatric harm</i>. Indeed, in <i>Page</i> itself, <i>physical</i> injury, whilst <i>foreseeable</i>, did <i>not</i>, in fact, <i>actually occur</i>. <i>Nevertheless</i>, it was held (consistent with the general principle just set out) that the plaintiff in that case (\u201cMr\u00a0Page\u201d) was <i>entitled to recover</i> against the defendant in that case (\u201cMr\u00a0Smith\u201d) for the <i>psychiatric</i> illness that ensued as a consequence of the collision between their cars.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is significant, in our view, that the decision in <i>Page</i> was <i>not a unanimous one</i>. Indeed, it was a decision based on the barest of majorities \u2013 three to two. As we shall see in a moment, the two dissenting judgments were not unpersuasive. More importantly, perhaps, we find, with respect, significant difficulties with the decision of the majority. Looked at in this light, it is important to proceed to consider these judgments in more detail.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 By way of factual background, there was, in <i>Page</i>, a motor accident in July 1987. Mr\u00a0Page was driving his car along a road when Mr\u00a0Smith, driving in the opposite direction, cut across his (Mr\u00a0Page\u2019s) path whilst entering a side road. A collision occurred in which Mr\u00a0Page sustained <i>no</i> <i>physical injury</i>. There was also no physical injury sustained by either Mr\u00a0Smith, his wife or his child, who were passengers in his car. Put simply, this was <i>a minor</i> motor accident (although there was considerable damage to both vehicles). However, Mr\u00a0Page had, for a very long time, suffered from a condition known as myalgic encephalomyelitis (\u201cME\u201d) (also known as chronic fatigue syndrome or post-viral fatigue syndrome). He had suffered a particularly severe attack of ME some four months earlier (in March 1987) as a result of a viral infection. Prior to the accident, he had been recovering from that attack and had hoped to return to work in September 1987. Mr\u00a0Page brought an action against Mr\u00a0Smith for damages for personal injuries caused by the latter\u2019s negligence. He argued that his condition (relating to ME) had become chronic and permanent as a result of the accident and that he would never be able to work again.
