According to Mr\u00a0Page, he had felt exhausted three hours after the accident and had taken to his bed, whereupon the exhaustion continued and his condition became chronic and permanent.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The House of Lords, as mentioned earlier (above at [59]), found in favour of Mr\u00a0Page, but only (as was noted above at [60]) by a bare majority of three to two. We turn now to consider the various judgments delivered by the court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, first, to the judgments delivered by the majority, the leading judgment was delivered by Lord\u00a0Lloyd of Berwick (with whom Lord\u00a0Ackner and Lord\u00a0Browne-Wilkinson agreed). The learned law lord drew a (crucial) distinction between a primary victim on the one hand and a secondary victim on the other. In <i>Page</i>, the facts related to a <i>primary</i> victim and the basic issue before the court was whether or not the <i>foreseeability</i> of <i>physical</i> injury (<i>as opposed to psychiatric</i> injury) to Mr\u00a0Page was sufficient to enable him to recover damages for nervous shock (bearing in mind that there had been <i>no actual physical</i> injury to Mr\u00a0Page himself).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Lord\u00a0Lloyd was of the view that \u201c[t]hough the distinction between primary and secondary victims [was] a <i>factual</i> one, it ha[d] \u2026 important <i>legal</i> consequences\u201d [emphasis added] (<i>Page</i> at 184). However, in our view, with respect, this merely <i>factual</i> distinction does <i>not, in and of itself,</i> translate into a <i>legal</i> distinction in the absence of <i>a normative legal justification</i>. Lord\u00a0Lloyd did observe that foreseeability of <i>psychiatric</i> harm was relevant only <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> <i>secondary</i> victims. However, in so far as <i>primary</i> victims were concerned, since foreseeability of <i>physical injury</i> was sufficient to found a duty of care on the part of the defendant, <i>and</i> given the fact that no distinction ought to be drawn between physical and psychiatric injury (given the expansion in the state of medical knowledge), there was no need for a plaintiff who was a primary victim to demonstrate (further) that <i>psychiatric</i> injury was also foreseeable. This last-mentioned legal control mechanism ought only to apply to <i>secondary</i> victims. In the learned law lord\u2019s words (<i>id</i> at 190):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">There is no justification for regarding physical and psychiatric injury as different \u201ckinds\u201d of injury. Once it is established that the defendant is under a duty of care to avoid causing personal injury to the plaintiff, it matters not whether the injury in fact sustained is physical, psychiatric or both.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning, next, to the judgments delivered by the minority, Lord\u00a0Keith of Kinkel was of the view (<i>id</i> at 169) that \u201c[r]easonable foreseeablility being the test, there [was] no logical ground for distinguishing between the two classes of claimants [<i>ie</i>, primary victims and secondary victims]\u201d. Lord\u00a0Jauncey of Tullichettle, who was the other dissenting judge, observed thus (<i>id</i> at 171\u2013172):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">When a plaintiff suffers damage as a result of the negligent act of another he must establish foreseeability of the general type of damage before he can succeed. The fact that personal injury is a likely consequence will not support a claim for pure economic loss. In the normal personal injury case arising from a factory or road accident the foreseeability of such injury arising from the negligent act seldom requires to be addressed since it is self evident from the circumstances. However that is not to say that the need for it is dispensed with. It is by no means impossible that a plaintiff could be directly involved in an accident caused by a negligent act where the circumstances required specific proof that injury was foreseeable. In <i>Overseas Tankship (U.K.) Ltd. v. Morts Dock &amp; Engineering Co. Ltd. (The Wagon Mound)</i> [1961] A.C.\u00a0388, 426, the judgment of the Board contained the following observations:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">\u201cTheir Lordships conclude this part of the case with some general observations. They have been concerned primarily to displace the proposition that unforeseeability is irrelevant if damage is \u2018direct.\u2019 In doing so they have inevitably insisted that the essential factor in determining liability is whether the damage is of such a kind as the reasonable man should have foreseen. This accords with the general view thus stated by Lord\u00a0Atkin in <i>Donoghue v. Stevenson</i> [1932] A.C.\u00a0562, 580: \u2018The liability for negligence, whether you style it such or treat it as in other systems as a species of \u201cculpa,\u201d is no doubt based upon a general public sentiment of moral wrongdoing for which the offender must pay.\u2019 It is a departure from this sovereign principle if liability is made to depend solely on the damage being the \u2018direct\u2019 or \u2018natural\u2019 consequence of the precedent act. Who knows or can be assumed to know all the processes of nature?\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">If therefore a plaintiff who is directly involved in an accident [is] require[d] to establish that the physical injuries sustained by him were the foreseeable consequences of a negligent act it is not easy to see in principle why such a plaintiff who suffers merely nervous shock and its consequences should not [be] require[d] to prove that it [<i>ie</i>, nervous shock] was similarly foreseeable. As a matter of common sense physical injuries are far more likely to result from an impact accident than is nervous shock causing subsequent illness. While it is not uncommon for a severe physical injury to give rise to some degree of psychiatric illness it is not the law that such illness is presumed to be a foreseeable consequence of every physical injury, rather \u2026 each case depend[s] on its own circumstances. If therefore the foreseeability of psychiatric illness consequent upon physical injury [is] require[d] to be established independently of the foreseeability of the physical injury why should the position be different where there was at the most a risk of physical injury which never eventuated?</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">The learned law lord also observed, later in his judgment, thus (<i>id</i> at 175):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[F]oreseeability of injury is necessary to determine whether a duty is owed to the victim. Unless such injury can be foreseen the victim is not a neighbour within the celebrated dictum of Lord\u00a0Atkin in <i>Donoghue v. Stevenson</i> [1932] A.C.\u00a0562 and cannot recover.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Criticisms of the majority\u2019s approach</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As alluded to earlier (above at [60]), we find, with respect, the decision of the majority in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) to be problematic for a number of reasons. Indeed, many of them are to be found in the characteristically perceptive judgment of Lord\u00a0Goff of Chieveley in the House of Lords decision of <i>White</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>). Whilst the learned law lord dissented in that particular decision, his criticisms of <i>Page</i> (being, strictly speaking, <i>obiter dicta</i>) were not commented on adversely by his brethren.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Lord\u00a0Goff was of the view that there were three broad grounds of criticism in respect of the majority\u2019s decision in <i>Page</i>. His observations in this regard merit (because of their importance) extensive quotation, as follows (<i>White</i> at 475\u2013476):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">In summary the basic grounds of criticism appear to be threefold.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There has been no previous support for any such approach, and there is authority in England and Australia to the contrary. \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The approach favoured by Lord\u00a0Lloyd [in <i>Page</i>] appears to be inconsistent not only with the adoption by Viscount\u00a0Simonds in <i>The Wagon Mound No.\u00a01</i> [1961] A.C.\u00a0388, 426, of Denning\u00a0L.J.\u2019s statement of principle [in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>King v Phillips</i> [1953] 1\u00a0QB 429], but also with the actual reasoning of the Privy Council in that case [<i>ie</i>, <i>The Wagon Mound No.\u00a01</i>]. There a particular type of damage to property, viz. damage by fire, was differentiated from other types of damage to property for the purpose of deciding whether the defendant could reasonably have foreseen damage of that particular type, so as to render him liable in damages in tort for such damage. That differentiation was made on purely common sense grounds, as a matter of practical justice. On exactly the same grounds, a particular type of personal injury, viz. psychiatric injury, may, for the like purpose, properly be differentiated from other types of personal injury. It appears to be in no way inconsistent with the making of that common sense judgment, as a matter of practical justice, that scientific advances are revealing that psychiatric illnesses may have a physical base, or that psychiatric injury should be regarded as another form of personal injury. Moreover the absence of any previous challenge to the general application of the principle stated by Denning\u00a0L.J., and adopted by Viscount\u00a0Simonds, perhaps provides the strongest endorsement of that common sense judgment.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The majority in <i>Page v. Smith</i> [1996] A.C.\u00a0155 may have misunderstood the so-called eggshell skull rule. In the course of his opinion, Lord\u00a0Lloyd said, at p.\u00a0187:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\"><span class=\"Judg-quote-2Char\">\u201cWe now know that the plaintiff escaped without external injury. Can it be the law that this makes all the difference? Can it be the law that the fortuitous absence of actual physical injury means that a different test has to be applied?</span>\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">These rhetorical questions Lord\u00a0Lloyd answered in the negative. Yet the effect of the \u201ceggshell skull\u201d rule, i.e. the rule that a wrongdoer must take his victim as he finds him, is that the absence (or, more accurately, the presence) of physical injury to the plaintiff, may make all the difference. Lord\u00a0Lloyd said, at p.\u00a0193:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-3\">\u201cThere is nothing in <i>Bourhill v. Young</i> [[24] <i>supra</i>] to displace the ordinary rule that where the plaintiff is within the range of foreseeable physical injury the defendant must take his victim as he finds him.\u201d</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">However, it appears from the passage from Lord\u00a0Wright\u2019s opinion in <i>Bourhill v. Young</i> [1943] A.C.\u00a092, 109\u2013110 \u2026 [<i>viz</i>, Lord\u00a0Wright\u2019s statement that \u201cif the wrong is established the wrongdoer must take the victim as he finds him\u201d] that that is not the ordinary rule. The maxim only applies where liability has been established. The criticism is therefore that Lord\u00a0Lloyd appears to have taken an exceptional rule relating to compensation and treated it as being of general application, thereby creating a wider principle of liability.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">I recognise that the impact of this new statement of principle [in <i>Page</i>] is likely to be relatively slight, in that it does no more than extend liability for psychiatric damage to those cases where physical damage is reasonably foreseeable (though none is suffered) but psychiatric damage is not. In any event, however, this situation does not arise in the present appeals, since none of the claimants was within the range of foreseeable physical injury; and your Lordships do not therefore have to form a view about the validity of the criticisms which I have summarised above. Your Lordships can therefore proceed on the basis that, for the purposes of the present appeals, the relevant test is, as in the past, the test of foreseeability of psychiatric damage.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would gratefully adopt the reasoning of Lord\u00a0Goff set out in the preceding paragraph, and add some observations of our own.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">69\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Leaving aside the issue of precedent (which was Lord\u00a0Goff\u2019s first point, and a not unimportant one at that), the basic difficulty centres on the issue of <i>characterisation</i>. The basic thrust of the approach of the majority in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) was as follows. The court ought not now to distinguish between physical injury on the one hand and psychiatric harm on the other. In the premises, if physical injury was foreseeable, then even if no actual physical injury resulted, the plaintiff was entitled to recover damages for any psychiatric injury inasmuch as such injury would be considered as part of the <i>extent</i> of the <i>physical</i> injury suffered as a result of the defendant\u2019s negligence pursuant to the \u201ceggshell skull rule\u201d.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">70\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, the premises upon which the majority in <i>Page</i> based their arguments are flawed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">71\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Whilst there ought not now to be an artificial distinction between physical injury on the one hand and psychiatric harm on the other in relation to the applicable test for determining whether a duty of care exists, it is clear that there nevertheless ought still to exist a distinction from the perspective of <i>legal control mechanisms to prevent a floodgate of litigation ensuing</i>. In other words, physical injury in the conventional sense (which excludes psychiatric harm) delimits, by its <i>very nature</i>, the extent of liability owed by the defendant concerned to potential plaintiffs. Put simply, the danger of a floodgate of litigation ensuing is minimal or non-existent where physical injury is concerned.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">72\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Contrast the situation where physical injury occurs, however, with two other situations.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">73\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first relates to cases of <i>pure economic loss</i>. This court in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>) has dealt with (the legal rules and principles relating to) this particular type of loss comprehensively (see above at [21]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">74\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second, which is one of the important issues in the present appeal, relates to negligence that results in <i>psychiatric harm</i>. <i>Not unlike pure economic</i> loss, the <i>potential reach</i> of a negligent act or statement that may cause <i>psychiatric harm</i> is potentially <i>open-ended</i>. <i>Unlike</i> the situation where <i>physical illness or injury</i> is caused (where the extent of the damage is <i>necessarily limited in space and time</i>, as noted above at [71]), this is <i>not</i> the situation with regard to <i>psychiatric harm</i> (and explains the increasingly stringent approach adopted by the House of Lords, particularly in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) and <i>White</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>)). In this regard, the following observations by Prof\u00a0Tan Keng Feng in Law Reform Committee, Singapore Academy of Law, <i>Discussion Paper on Liability for Negligently Inflicted Psychiatric Illness</i> (22\u00a0August 2000) (\u201c<i>Discussion Paper</i>\u201d) at pp\u00a02\u20133 should also be noted (a similar passage by the same author also appears in \u201cLiability for Psychiatric Illness\u201d ([39] <i>supra</i>) at 167):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The most cogent reason, however, for limiting liability for psychiatric illness is the fear of opening the floodgates of litigation. \u2026 <i>Non-impact psychiatric illness undoubtedly induces wider claims than impact physical damage</i>. It is better to accept some inevitable arbitrariness in drawing a line somewhere on \u2026 liability for psychiatric illness than to endure unmanageable chaos [resulting] from \u2026 unfettered recovery [for] such damage. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Tony Weir, in his review of Nicholas J\u00a0Mullany &amp; Peter R\u00a0Handford, <i>Mullany and Handford\u2019s Tort Liability for Psychiatric Damage: The Law of \u201cNervous Shock\u201d</i> (Lawbook Co Ltd, 1993) <em>at <nobr>[1993] CLJ 520</nobr>, stated, in a similar vein, thus (at 521):</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><em>Vulnerability to physical lesion is pretty standard throughout the population \u2013 a force which wounds you would wound me, too \u2013 but the range of psychic liability is very great indeed \u2013 a quite minor accident can throw one person into a serious decline \u2026 and leave another wholly unaffected.</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">75\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Hence, the majority of the court in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) was, with respect, in error when it <i>equated</i> physical injury with psychiatric harm <i>for the purposes of formulating legal control mechanisms</i>. As we have just seen, given the <i>nature</i> of each type of injury, the respective <i>legal control mechanisms</i> ought to be <i>different</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It may, however, be argued that the legal control mechanism <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> psychiatric harm <i>is</i> different inasmuch as the majority of the court in <i>Page</i> had distinguished between primary victims on the one hand and secondary victims on the other. <i>However</i>, the question that then arises is this: <i>Why should such a distinction be drawn if both categories of victims have suffered the same type of injury,</i> viz<i>, psychiatric harm?</i> The answer, presumably, would be that a primary victim who suffers both physical injury and psychiatric harm ought to be subjected to fewer legal preconditions with regard to recovery because both types of injury ought to be treated as being the same. <i>However</i>, for the reasons we have given earlier (above at [70]\u2013[74]), this answer is, in fact, flawed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 More important, perhaps, is the issue of <i>substantive justice</i> \u2013 or, as Lord\u00a0Goff put it in <i>White</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) at 475 (see the quotation set out above at [67]), \u201cpractical justice\u201d. Put simply, there is, in our view, no reason grounded in policy, principle or justice and fairness as to why a primary victim should be treated more favourably than a secondary victim; from this perspective, there is a powerful reason for doing away with the distinction between primary victims and secondary victims. Let us elaborate.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The law, as originally formulated, has moved (in the context of damages for psychiatric harm) from allowing recovery by a primary victim only to extending recovery to a secondary victim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the English High Court decision of <i>Dulieu v White &amp; Sons</i> [1901] 2\u00a0KB 669 (\u201c<i>Dulieu</i>\u201d), the plaintiff was permitted to recover for nervous shock which was caused by her apprehension of physical injury as a result of the negligent conduct of the defendant. What engendered controversy was Kennedy\u00a0J\u2019s <i>dictum</i> in that case (at 675) to the effect that the shock concerned must arise from <i>reasonable fear of immediate personal injury</i> <i>to oneself</i>. This <i>dictum</i> was, in fact, <i>rejected</i> by the majority of the English Court of Appeal in <i>Hambrook</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>). In <i>Hambrook</i>, the plaintiff\u2019s wife had <i>not herself been in any personal danger</i>. However, she had just parted with her three children (a daughter and two sons), having (as was her habit) accompanied them part of the way to school. Shortly thereafter, she witnessed a lorry, which the defendants\u2019 servant had negligently left unattended, charging down the steep incline (where she was standing) and rapidly round the bend in the direction of where she had left her children. Although her children were not within her sight, the plaintiff\u2019s wife became very anxious for their safety. She inquired of bystanders what had happened and discovered that a little girl who wore spectacles had been taken away injured. This fit the description of her daughter. She became agitated, tearing her hair and screaming. She then rushed to the school and found her two sons there. However, her daughter was missing. She went to the hospital, where she found her daughter, who had been knocked down by the lorry and had suffered serious injuries. The plaintiff\u2019s wife was three or four months pregnant at that time. As a result of what happened, she suffered a serious nervous shock and, as a consequence, a severe haemorrhage as well. She recovered partially, but then suffered a relapse. She was operated on and a dead foetus was removed. Unfortunately, she died a few days later. The plaintiff brought an action against the defendants under the Fatal Accidents Act 1846 (c\u00a093) (UK) in respect of the death of his wife to recover damages for the loss of her services as manageress of his restaurant. Although the defendants admitted the negligence alleged by the plaintiff, they argued that the shock alleged to have been sustained by the deceased wife was too remote. The majority of the court, however, held in favour of the plaintiff, although (unlike the situation in <i>Dulieu</i>) there had been no reasonable fear of personal injury to the plaintiff\u2019s wife herself. The majority\u2019s observations are particularly apposite and merit quotation in full.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 First, Bankes\u00a0LJ observed, in <i>Hambrook</i>, as follows (at 151):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Accepting the line of reasoning illustrated by these authorities [which included, <i>inter alia</i>, <i>Dulieu</i>], it follows that what a man ought to have anticipated is material when considering the extent of his duty. Upon the authorities as they stand, the defendant ought to have anticipated that if his lorry ran away down this narrow street, it might terrify some woman to such an extent, through fear of some immediate bodily injury to herself, that she would receive such a mental shock as would injure her health. <i>Can any real distinction be drawn from the point of view of what the defendant ought to have anticipated and what, therefore, his duty was, between that case and the case of a woman whose fear is for her child, and not for herself? Take a case in point as a test. Assume two mothers crossing this street at the same time when this lorry comes thundering down, each holding a small child by the hand. One mother is courageous and devoted to her child. She is terrified, but thinks only of the damage to the child, and not at all about herself. The other woman is timid and lacking in the motherly instinct. She also is terrified, but thinks only of the damage to herself and not at all about her child. The health of both mothers is seriously affected by the mental shock occasioned by the fright. Can any real distinction be drawn between the two cases? Will the law recognize a cause of action in the case of the less deserving mother, and none in the case of the more deserving one? Does the law say that the defendant ought reasonably to have anticipated the non-natural feeling of the timid mother, and not the natural feeling of the courageous mother? I think not.</i> In my opinion the step which the Court is asked to take, under the circumstances of the present case, necessarily follows from an acceptance of the decision in <i>Dulieu v. White &amp; Sons</i>, and I think that <i>the dictum of Kennedy\u00a0J</i>., laid down in quite general terms in that case, <i>cannot be accepted as good law applicable in every case</i>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Atkin\u00a0LJ observed, in the same case, thus (<i>id</i> at 157):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">I can find <i>no principle to support</i> the self-imposed restriction stated in the judgment of Kennedy\u00a0J. in <i>Dulieu v. White &amp; Sons</i>, <i>that the shock must be a shock which arises from a reasonable fear of immediate personal injury to oneself.</i> It appears to me inconsistent with the decision in <i>Pugh v. London, Brighton and South Coast Ry. Co.</i> [[1896] 2\u00a0QB 498], and with the decision in <i>Wilkinson v. Downton</i> [[1897] 2\u00a0QB 57]<i>,</i> in neither of which cases was the shock the result of the apprehension of the injury to the plaintiff. <i>It would result in a state of the law in which a mother, shocked by fright for herself, would recover, while a mother shocked by her child being killed before her eyes, could not, and in which a mother traversing the highway with a child in her arms could recover if shocked by fright for herself, while if she could be cross-examined into an admission that the fright was really for her child, she could not. In my opinion such distinctions would be discreditable to any system of jurisprudence in which they formed part.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Hambrook</i> is an important decision inasmuch as it <i>shifted</i> the English courts\u2019 approach <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> claims in negligence for psychiatric harm from what has commonly been described as the \u201cimpact theory\u201d to the \u201cshock theory\u201d (see, for example, Tan Keng Feng, \u201cNervous Shock to Primary Victims\u201d [1995] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a0649 at 653). This shift is also justified by considerations of justice and fairness (as embodied in the observations of Bankes and Atkin\u00a0LJJ in <i>Hambrook</i>, which have just been quoted in the preceding two paragraphs; significantly, the latter judge was later to formulate the famous \u201cneighbour principle\u201d in the seminal House of Lords decision of <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> [1932] AC\u00a0562).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) has, in substance, effected is a <i>return</i> to the \u201cimpact theory\u201d in so far as <i>primary</i> victims are concerned (see \u201cNervous Shock to Primary Victims\u201d at 653). As aptly stated in Nicholas J\u00a0Mullany, \u201cPsychiatric damage in the House of Lords \u2013 Fourth time unlucky: <i>Page v Smith</i>\u201d (1995\u20131996) 3\u00a0Journal of Law and Medicine 112 (\u201cPsychiatric damage in the House of Lords\u201d) at 119\u2013120:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Insistence on foreseeability of mental injury through shock does not drive one to the conclusion that there is a separate tort of causing psychiatric damage. Clearly there is not. It is simply an insistence on the application of the tort of negligence to a particular type of personal injury rather than subsumption of damage to the mind within the broader category \u2026 Lord\u00a0Lloyd [in <i>Page</i>] saw insistence on reasonable foreseeability of mental injury by shock in direct participant cases as \u201ca step backwards\u201d \u2026 <i>The exact opposite is true. English common law has now backtracked in relation to such cases to a position not all that far removed from the \u201cimpact\u201d theory</i> ... [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Reference may also be made, in this regard, to Peter Handford, \u201cA New Chapter in the Foresight Saga: Psychiatric Damage in the House of Lords\u201d (1996) 4\u00a0Tort Law Rev 5 (\u201cA New Chapter in the Foresight Saga\u201d), where the learned author observed thus (at 7):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Whatever may have happened to the law of psychiatric damage in its earlier formative period, for the past fifty years this category of claim has been regarded as conceptually separate from ordinary cases of personal injury, marked off by the requirement that there must be reasonable foresight of psychiatric harm, assessed on an ex post facto basis, and limited by various other principles of proximity of relationship, time and space, and manner of infliction which do not apply to ordinary personal injury cases. \u2026 Lord\u00a0Oliver has [in <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>)] made a valuable contribution to this branch of the law by distinguishing between primary and secondary victim cases, <i>but this is a distinction which merely goes to the issue of proximity and makes it easier to appreciate that psychiatric damage cases can arise in situations which do not involve an \u201caccident\u201d in the ordinary sense of the word</i>, for example cases in which such harm is occasioned by work conditions \u2026 <i>Under Lord\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s view [in</i> Page<i>], these developments are negated. Psychiatric damage as a category disappears except in cases involving secondary victims, thus putting the focus back on the traditional situation of witnessing accidents.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The result of the majority\u2019s approach in <i>Page</i> is <i>to favour primary victims over secondary victims</i> although, as the observations of both Bankes and Atkin\u00a0LJJ in <i>Hambrook</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>) illustrate (see above at [80] and [81], respectively), there is no reason in logic, principle or (for that matter) justice and fairness to adopt such an approach. Indeed, one would have thought that, <i>at the very least, both primary as well as secondary victims ought to be treated in the same way. If so, then the test for determining the existence of a duty of care</i> vis-\u00e0-vis <i>both of these categories of victims in the context of claims for nervous shock should be the same</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are also <i>other difficulties</i> that arise from adopting the approach of the majority in <i>Page</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">86\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are, first, <i>practical difficulties</i> in <i>defining as well as identifying who a primary victim is</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">87\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The relevant case law itself demonstrates that there are both broader as well as narrower views of who a primary victim is (as embodied in the judgments of Lord\u00a0Oliver in <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) at 407 and Lord\u00a0Lloyd in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) at 184, respectively).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Even more importantly, perhaps, it would, in our view, be invidious if the strictness of the applicable legal test as well as the possibility of completely contrary results ensuing were to depend on <i>how the relevant fact situation is characterised</i>. Put simply, a victim in the <i>same</i> fact situation could, <i>depending on how the relevant facts are perceived</i>, be <i>characterised</i> as either a primary victim or a secondary victim (and, on many occasions, with <i>equal persuasiveness</i>). In this regard, the following examples given by Prof\u00a0Trindade in a characteristically perceptive note on <i>Page</i> make the point both eloquently and pointedly, and are therefore quoted in full (see F\u00a0A\u00a0Trindade, \u201cNervous Shock and Negligent Conduct\u201d (1996) 112\u00a0LQR 22 at 24):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">It is implicit in the judgments of the majority in <i>Page v. Smith</i> that those who fall into the category of primary victims will be easy to identify; but is this likely to be the case? In <i>Page v. Smith</i> it was not difficult to conclude that the plaintiff was within the area of physical impact and that there was therefore a foreseeable risk of bodily injury to the plaintiff. But cases will not always be as simple as that. What of the passengers sitting on a bus with which a negligent motorist collides? Is it only the passengers who are in close proximity to the part of the bus where the impact occurs, or every passenger on the bus who could be said to be within the range of foreseeable physical injury? What of a passenger train which is derailed by the negligence of the engine driver? Is it only the passengers sitting in the derailed carriage or all the passengers on the train who are within the range of foreseeable physical injury? And what of the situation of a disabled aircraft which flies over a city and then crashes into a residential building \u2026 or a runaway lorry as in <i>Hambrook v. Stokes</i> [1925] 1\u00a0K.B. 141? Would there not be many people within the range of foreseeable injury? In the case of a runaway lorry would it matter that the plaintiff would have had ample time to step aside into a shop into a position of safety? Would that prevent the plaintiff [from] claiming to be a primary victim? And what of the example given by Lord\u00a0Ackner in <i>Alcock</i> \u2026 of a petrol tanker careering out of control into a school in session and bursting into flames? Who would be within the range of foreseeable physical injury? The children and teachers in the classrooms, those in the playground, parents or friends waiting to collect children, passers-by who fear that the petrol tanker might explode as a result of the collision?</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">If all these persons can be said to be within the range of foreseeable physical injury then all of them could be said to be primary victims of the defendant\u2019s negligence. If this is so, then as a result of <i>Page v. Smith</i> all of them would be able to recover for any psychiatric illness that might be suffered by them, provided only that they can prove that the psychiatric illness was shock induced, genuine and caused by the accident. They would not be subject to any of the control mechanisms insisted on by the courts until now to keep in check liability for nervous shock. Even the passer-by unconnected with any child in the school could recover for nervous shock merely because he was within the range of foreseeable physical injury from the collision. The fact that nervous shock to him would not ordinarily be within the range of reasonable foreseeability would be irrelevant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In a similar vein, Mrs\u00a0Hopkins has observed thus (see C\u00a0A\u00a0Hopkins, \u201cA New Twist to Nervous Shock\u201d <nobr>[1995] CLJ 491</nobr> at 493):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[I]s the distinction between primary and secondary victims, or between participants and non-participants, an entirely valid one? What of the \u201cnear miss\u201d? Would Mr.\u00a0Page [in <i>Page</i>] have succeeded if he had feared a collision because of the defendant\u2019s negligent driving but none had actually taken place? After a fifty-car motorway pile-up, is the driver of the fifty-first car who skilfully steers his vehicle safely onto the hard shoulder, witnessing scenes of carnage all around him and shaken in spite of his lucky escape, a primary or a secondary victim of the motorist who caused the initial crash? And, if all heads of illness can be lumped together as a type (which Lord\u00a0Lloyd regards [in <i>Page</i>] as \u201csensible\u201d because of the continuing expansion of medical knowledge), is there not a case for combining different types of property damage because of the continuing expansion of scientific knowledge? Is the phoenix of <i>Re Polemis</i> [1921] 3\u00a0K.B.\u00a0560 about to emerge from the ashes of <i>The Wagon Mound</i> [<i>ie</i>, <i>Overseas Tankship (UK) Ltd v Morts Dock Engineering Co Ltd</i> [1961] AC\u00a0188]? [The latter case overruled the former inasmuch as the latter laid down the general principle of remoteness of damage in tortious negligence based on reasonable foreseeability, whereas the former case had extended liability to everything that was the direct consequence of the defendant\u2019s initial negligent conduct.]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The practical (and related) result of the majority\u2019s approach in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) is well-put by two leading commentators in the field, who observe that \u201c[t]he result is that counsel will still be looking to squeeze plaintiffs into the primary [victim] category wherever possible\u201d (see Nicholas J\u00a0Mullany &amp; Peter R\u00a0Handford, \u201cMoving the Boundary Stone by Statute \u2013 The Law Commission on Psychiatric Illness\u201d (1999) 22\u00a0UNSW Law Journal 350 (\u201cThe Law Commission on Psychiatric Illness\u201d) at 405). Indeed, they also point to actual inconsistencies which have been generated in the case law itself (<i>id</i> at 404\u2013405; see also United Kingdom, <i>Liability for Psychiatric Illness</i> (Law Com No\u00a0249, 1998) (\u201c<i>The English Law Commission Report</i>\u201d) at para\u00a06.12). The learned authors further point \u2013 correctly, in our view \u2013 to the fact that \u201c[t]he [English] Law Commission was quite clearly uncomfortable with the developments stemming from <i>Page v Smith</i>\u201d (see \u201cThe Law Commission on Psychiatric Illness\u201d at 403), but nevertheless did not resolve the difficulties and made inconsistent recommendations instead (see generally <i>id</i> at 403\u2013407; see also (for an overview of the difficulties engendered by <i>Page</i> and the English Law Commission\u2019s recommendations) <i>The English Law Commission</i> <i>Report</i> at paras\u00a02.52\u20132.60, 5.11\u20135.16 and 5.45\u20135.54).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The following example by a local author illustrates both the difficulties referred to earlier (above at [77]\u2013[90]) in terms of distinguishing between primary and secondary victims, as well as the possible injustice that might result from the distinction itself (see Teo Cheng Seong, Daniel, \u201cThe New Orthodoxy in the Foresight Saga: A Look at <i>Page v Smith</i>\u201d (1997) 18\u00a0Sing\u00a0LR 300 at 309\u2013310):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">To illustrate the potential for injustice, consider the following example. A is slowly driving along a road in a long line of traffic and B is walking on the pavement alongside A\u2019s car. A crash barrier separates the road from the pavement so that a minor collision will not pose any foreseeable risk of physical injury to a passing pedestrian. Both A and B witness the car which is first in line negligently collide with a lorry, causing a pile-up which stops two cars short of A. Both consequently suffer nervous shock even though, owing to the relative mildness of the collision, nervous shock to either was not reasonably foreseeable. A may capitalize on the slight risk of physical injury to himself and recover for his psychiatric damage under <i>Page v Smith</i>, while B who is adequately protected from physical danger by the crash barrier fails in his action. To allow A\u2019s claim and deny recovery to B merely because some physical injury was foreseeable to the former seems as unfair as it is arbitrary.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">92\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, this is not to state that there are no substantive legal consequences whatsoever arising from the fact that one plaintiff is, in effect, a primary victim and another, a secondary victim \u2013 even if this distinction is only recognised as a matter of <i>fact</i> (rather than, as <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) mandates, as a matter of <i>law</i>). As Mullany pertinently pointed out (see \u201cPsychiatric damage in the House of Lords\u201d ([83] <i>supra</i>) at 116):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The only significance of the difference between a person who witnesses or is informed of an event and a person directly involved in it is that <i>psychiatric impact to the direct participant is more likely to be foreseeable than [psychiatric impact] to the secondary victims</i>. This does not warrant the introduction of different duty tests and consequent unnecessary and undesirable complexity in liability assessment. The traditional foreseeability test is sound in principle \u2026 [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Reference may also be made to \u201cA New Chapter in the Foresight Saga\u201d ([83] <i>supra</i>). Indeed, as Lord\u00a0Keith pertinently pointed out in <i>Page</i> (at 167):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Where the plaintiff is personally involved in a terrifying incident proof of proximity presents no problem. Where, however, the plaintiff is what may be described as a secondary victim proximity may be very difficult to establish.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">The following observations by Lord\u00a0Jauncey in the same case ought also to be noted (<i>id</i> at 176):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Lord\u00a0Oliver [in <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>)] was considering proximity as determinative of the existence of a duty of care <i>and drawing a distinction between a victim directly involved in an accident and one who merely witnessed it.</i> He certainly was <i>not</i> saying that a victim directly involved in an accident did not require to prove the foreseeability of the nervous shock from which he suffered as a result thereof. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">93\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Whilst it is true that Lord\u00a0Hoffmann pointed out, in the recent House of Lords decision of <i>Rothwell v Chemical &amp; Insulating Co Ltd</i> [2007] 3\u00a0WLR 876 (\u201c<i>Rothwell</i>\u201d), that <i>Page</i> \u201cdoes not appear to have caused any practical difficulties and is not \u2026 likely to do so if confined to the kind of situation which the majority in that case had in mind\u201d (at [32]), that observation itself cuts both ways, so to speak, inasmuch as given (as we pointed out above at [86]\u2013[90]) the difficulty of defining who a primary victim is as well as the possibility of substantive injustice being engendered by classifying a plaintiff in a particular way (<i>ie</i>, as either a primary victim or a secondary victim), the fact that <i>Page</i> is (according to Lord\u00a0Hoffmann in <i>Rothwell</i>) intended to apply in a very limited sphere only raises the question as to whether or not it is worth the effort to keep the legal principles laid down therein at all. Significantly, in <i>Rothwell</i> itself, the court was at pains to distinguish <i>Page</i> on the basis that the foreseeable event (<i>viz</i>, the development by the claimant of an asbestos-related disease due to exposure to asbestos in the course of his employment) had not occurred yet.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">94\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Since an initial draft of this judgment was prepared, the House of Lords has handed down another decision where <i>Page</i>, whilst not directly applicable to the fact situation concerned, was referred to \u2013 see <i>Corr v IBC Vehicles Ltd</i> [2008] 2\u00a0WLR 499. Significantly, the criticism of <i>Page</i> was acknowledged by two law lords in that case (<i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Scott of Foscote at [29] and <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Walker of Gestingthorpe at [40]), although the decision in <i>Page</i> itself was not directly challenged in that particular appeal. Even more significantly, Lord\u00a0Neuberger of Abbotsbury (with whom Lord\u00a0Mance agreed (at [46])), referring, <i>inter alia</i>, to Lord\u00a0Goff\u2019s critique of <i>Page</i> in <i>White</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (which is reproduced above at [67], and which we accepted (see above at [68])), clearly left the door open to a <i>reconsideration</i> of <i>Page</i> in the foreseeable future in the <i>English</i> context when he commented as follows (see <i>Corr v IBC Vehicles Ltd</i> at [54]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">The first point concerns the somewhat controversial decision of this House in <i>Page v Smith</i> [1996] AC\u00a0155. As Lord\u00a0Bingham [of Cornhill] has explained [in <i>Corr v IBC Vehicles Ltd</i> at [7]], neither party has criticised that decision, let alone invited the House to review it. At least for my part, I understood that was the position of the employer because, even if we had been persuaded that <i>Page v Smith</i> was wrongly decided, that would not have ensured the success of this appeal. I agree. Accordingly, not least in the light of the trenchant observations of Lord\u00a0Goff of Chieveley in <i>Frost v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police</i> [1999] 2\u00a0AC 455, 473D\u2013480F, I would not want to appear to prejudge any decision as to the correctness of the majority view in <i>Page v Smith</i>, if it comes to be challenged before your Lordships\u2019 House on another occasion.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">95\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although English decisions on the common law (in particular, those emanating from the House of the Lords) are accorded great respect by our courts, they ought not to be followed blindly. Given the various difficulties pertaining to both justification as well as justice and fairness with regard to <i>Page</i> as set out earlier (above at [66]\u2013[91]), this is one occasion when we would respectfully hold that the law as laid down by the majority in <i>Page</i> ought not to be followed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>The position in Singapore</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>The position stated</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">96\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is now appropriate to draw the various threads of analysis together and state what the position is in the Singapore context in so far as liability in negligence for psychiatric harm is concerned.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">97\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear that, as an extremely important threshold requirement, the plaintiff must prove that he or she has suffered what has often been termed a \u201crecognisable psychiatric illness\u201d (see, for example, the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Hinz v Berry</i> [1970] 2\u00a0QB 40 at 42 <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR). We should observe, parenthetically, that although it might be argued that this requirement should be considered, strictly speaking, under the rubric of \u201cdamage\u201d instead, from a practical perspective, it would be more appropriate that such a requirement (if it is considered by one (or more than one) party to constitute a live issue) is considered at the outset. Returning to the requirement proper, it is, in fact, a requirement that is more easily stated than ascertained (see, for example, generally, the discussion in <i>The English Law Commission</i> <i>Report</i> ([90] <i>supra</i>) at paras\u00a03.1\u20133.33). Psychiatric illness must be distinguished from sorrow and grief (no matter how severe), for the latter are considered as constituting part of the vicissitudes of life. It should also be noted that proof of a recognisable psychiatric illness will depend, in the main, upon the relevant expert psychiatric evidence tendered before the court, which, of course, retains the ultimate supervisory responsibility of ensuring that such expert evidence is defensible as well as grounded in logic and common sense (see, for example, the decision of this court in <i>JSI Shipping (S) Pte Ltd v Teofoongwonglcloong</i> <nobr>[2007] 4 SLR 460</nobr> at [49]\u2013[53] (citing the House of Lords decision of <i>Bolitho v City and Hackney Health Authority</i> [1998] AC\u00a0232)). Indeed, it seems to us that it may well not only save time and costs, but also aid the court immensely if <i>an independent psychiatrist</i> could be agreed upon by the parties or be appointed by the court in cases of this nature in the future.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">98\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also endorse the approach taken in <i>Pang Koi Fa</i> ([24] <i>supra</i>) inasmuch as it adopts the approach in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) \u2013 in particular, we accept the three factors set out in the latter decision by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment therein (reproduced at [38] above), <i>albeit with important modifications</i> (see below at [109]). On a related note, we are further of the view that a \u201cpure\u201d test of reasonable foreseeability alone (as advocated by Lord\u00a0Bridge and Lord\u00a0Scarman in <i>McLoughlin</i> (see above at [35])) is too wide and, hence, ought not to be adopted in preference to that set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in the same case. However, we disagree, with respect, with the view that Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s characterisation of the three factors in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> is to be construed as a qualifying \u201c<i>policy</i>\u201d (in the sense of public policy) within the <i>second</i> stage of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>). As we explained earlier (above at [45]\u2013[52]), this is not what we think the learned law lord meant to say. If it is, we would, with respect, disagree with it as it would be both confusing and misleading. As explained (at [48] above), we are of the view that these factors relate, instead, to the concept of <i>proximity</i> within the <i>first</i> stage of the two-stage test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>) (reproduced above at [21]), which is itself modelled (albeit with modifications) on the test in <i>Anns</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">99\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before turning to consider the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> proper, it would be useful to recount briefly the nature and function of the concept of <i>proximity</i> as set out in <i>Spandeck</i>. In that case, Chan\u00a0CJ observed as follows (at [77]\u2013[82]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>first</i> stage of the test to be applied to determine the existence of a duty of care is that of proximity, <i>ie</i>, that there must be sufficient <i>legal</i> proximity between the claimant and [the] defendant for a duty of care to arise. The focus here is necessarily on the closeness of the relationship between the parties themselves, as alluded to by Bingham\u00a0LJ in the Court of Appeal stage of <i>Caparo Industries Plc v Dickman</i> [1989] QB\u00a0653, where he said (at 679) that while \u201c[t]he content of the requirement of proximity, whatever language is used, is not \u2026 capable of precise definition\u201d and \u201c[t]he approach will vary according to the particular facts of the case, \u2026 the focus of the inquiry is on the <i>closeness and directness of the relationship between the parties</i>\u201d [emphasis added]. Indeed, in <i>Hedley Byrne</i> [<i>&amp; Co Ltd v Heller &amp; Partners Ltd</i> [1964] AC\u00a0465] itself, the House of Lords used language which pointed to the relationship between the parties as being determinative of duty.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although Lord\u00a0Keith in <i>Yuen Kun Yeu</i> [<i>v Attorney-General of Hong Kong</i> [1988] AC\u00a0175] referred (at 194) to the concept of \u201cclose and direct relations\u201d, he did not clarify what the concept mean[t]. However, in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Sutherland</i> [<i>ie</i>, <i>The Council of the Shire of Sutherland v Heyman</i> (1984\u20131985) 157\u00a0CLR 424], Deane\u00a0J has observed thus (at 55\u201356):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">The requirement of proximity is directed to <i>the relationship between the parties</i> in so far as it is relevant to the allegedly negligent act or omission of the defendant and the loss or injury sustained by the plaintiff. It involves <i>the notion of nearness or closeness and embraces physical</i> proximity (in the sense of space and time) between the person or property of the plaintiff and the person or property of the defendant, <i>circumstantial</i> proximity such as an overriding relationship of employer and employee or of a professional man and his client and what may (<i>perhaps loosely</i>) be referred to as <i>causal</i> proximity in the sense of the closeness or directness of the causal connection or relationship between the particular act or course of conduct and the loss or injury sustained. It may reflect <i>an assumption by one party of a responsibility</i> to take care to avoid or prevent injury, loss or damage to the person or property of another or <i>reliance</i> by one party upon such care being taken by the other in circumstances where the other party knew or ought to have known of that reliance. <i>Both the identity and the relative importance of the factors which are determinative of an issue of proximity are likely to vary in different categories of case.</i> That does <i>not mean</i> that there is scope for decision by reference to idiosyncratic notions of justice or morality or that it is a proper approach to treat the requirement of proximity as <i>a question of fact to be resolved merely by reference to the relationship between the plaintiff and the defendant in the particular circumstances.</i> The requirement of a relationship of proximity <i>serves as a touchstone and control of the categories of case in which the common law will adjudge that a duty of care is owed.</i> Given the general circumstances of a case in a new or developing area of the law of negligence, the question what (if any) combination or combinations of factors will satisfy the requirement of proximity is a <i>question of law to be resolved by the processes of legal reasoning, induction and deduction. On the other hand, the identification of the content of that requirement in such an area should not be either ostensibly or actually divorced from notions of what is \u201cfair and reasonable\u201d \u2026 or from the considerations of public policy which underlie and enlighten the existence and content of the requirement.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We respectfully agree with this analysis which merely unpacks \u201cproximity or neighbourhood\u201d as a composite idea, importing the whole concept of the necessary relationship between the claimant and the defendant described by Lord\u00a0Atkin in <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> [([82] <i>supra</i>)] (at 580). However, in this regard, we also acknowledge that there are numerous judicial pronouncements on the difficulty (and indeed, redundancy) in defining \u201cproximity\u201d. Some of these examples have already been cited above and it suffices only to reproduce Lord\u00a0Oliver of Aylmerton\u2019s speech in <i>Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police</i> [1992] 1\u00a0AC 310, where he said (at 411):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">[I]n the end, it has to be accepted that the concept of \u201cproximity\u201d is an artificial one which depends more upon the court\u2019s perception of what is the reasonable area for the imposition of liability than upon any logical process of analogical deduction.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding these judicial views, \u2026 these observations are \u2026 puzzling \u2026 If indeed the \u201cproximity\u201d concept is merely a label or an artificial exercise in judicial creativity, then one must ask why the concept is still resorted to or utilised in the various tests. Its very presence suggests that it has some substantive content that is capable of being expressed in terms of legal principles. Rather than denouncing it as a mere \u201clabel\u201d, the courts should strive to infuse some meaning into it, if only so that lawyers who advise litigants and even law teachers can make some sense of the judicial formulations.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, Deane\u00a0J\u2019s analysis in <i>Sutherland</i>, that proximity includes physical, circumstantial as well as causal proximity, does provide substance to the concept since it includes the twin criteria of voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance, where the facts support them, as essential factors in meeting the test of proximity. Where A voluntarily assumes responsibility for his acts or omissions towards B, and B relies on it, it is only fair and just that the law should hold A liable for negligence in causing economic loss or physical damage to B \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We only need to add, further, that in determining proximity as expounded by Deane\u00a0J in <i>Sutherland</i>, the court should apply these concepts first by analogising the facts of the case for decision with those of decided cases, if such exist, but should not be constrained from limiting liability in a deserving case only because it involves a novel fact situation.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">100\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The above observations have been set out in full above not only because they represent the leading <i>general</i> analysis of the concept of <i>proximity</i> in the <i>Singapore</i> context, but also because (as will be shown below at [101]\u2013[103]) they are in fact <i>consistent with</i> the more <i>specific</i> factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> (reproduced above at [38]) in the context of liability for <i>nervous shock</i>, which factors are somewhat different when compared to, for example, the factors to be considered in a situation involving liability for pure economic loss (where the twin criteria of voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance would more appropriately apply (although these criteria could also possibly apply in a situation of psychiatric harm, depending on the precise facts of the case at hand)). In particular, the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce are consistent with the broad categories set out by Deane\u00a0J in the Australian High Court decision of <i>The Council of the Shire of</i> <i>Sutherland v Heyman</i> (1984\u20131985) 157\u00a0CLR 424 (\u201c<i>Sutherland</i>\u201d) (see the quotation at [99] above), which were accepted by this court in <i>Spandeck</i> at [78]\u2013[79] (see, likewise, above at [99]) (see also the observations by Deane\u00a0J in the (also) Australian High Court decision of <i>Jaensch v Coffey</i> (1984) 155\u00a0CLR 549 (\u201c<i>Jaensch</i>\u201d) at 584\u2013585).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">101\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>first</i> factor set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), centring on <i>the class of persons</i> whose claims should be recognised, corresponds to the general category of <i>circumstantial</i> proximity referred to by Deane\u00a0J in <i>Sutherland</i> at 497.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">102\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>second</i> factor mentioned by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce, relating to <i>the proximity of the claimants to the accident</i>, corresponds to the general category of <i>physical</i> proximity referred to by Deane\u00a0J in <i>Sutherland</i> (<i>ibid</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">103\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>third</i> factor stated by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce, relating to <i>the means by which the shock is caused</i>, corresponds to the general category of <i>causal</i> proximity referred to by Deane\u00a0J in <i>Sutherland</i> (<i>ibid</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">104\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note, at this juncture, that <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>) has been the subject of very recent (and perceptive) critique by Prof\u00a0Kumaralingam Amirthalingam (see \u201cRefining the Duty of Care in Singapore\u201d (2008) 124\u00a0LQR 42 and \u201cLord\u00a0Atkin and the Philosopher\u2019s Stone: The Search for A Universal Test for Duty\u201d [2007] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a0350 (\u201cLord\u00a0Atkin and the Philosopher\u2019s Stone\u201d)). Prof\u00a0Amirthalingam makes many salient points. Foremost amongst them is the argument that the concept of reasonable foreseeability should be restored as a <i>legal</i> test for determining the existence of a duty of care for, in his view, this concept \u201cserves an important normative function\u201d (see \u201cLord\u00a0Atkin and the Philosopher\u2019s Stone\u201d at 353). This would, in effect, reinstate the three-part test laid down by the House of Lords in <i>Caparo Industries Plc v Dickman</i> [1990] 2\u00a0AC 605 (\u201c<i>Caparo</i>\u201d), which comprises the following elements: (a)\u00a0foreseeability, (b)\u00a0proximity, and (c)\u00a0the requirement that the imposition of any duty of care be \u201cfair, just and reasonable\u201d (<i>id</i> at 618). With respect, we do not think that the law would be advanced by such a change. Indeed, the concept of <i>proximity</i> <i>itself</i> represents a <i>legal (or normative)</i> concept of <i>reasonable foreseeability</i>. The <i>alternative</i> concept of reasonable foreseeability which is advanced by Prof\u00a0Amirthalingam is, in substance and effect, a <i>factual</i> one which we view as being <i>an integral part of the (legal) test of proximity in the first place.</i> In other words, if the threshold issue of <i>factual</i> foreseeability is not even satisfied in the first instance (an occurrence which, we should think, would, in the nature of things, be rare, as we noted in <i>Spandeck</i> itself at [75]), <i>then the court cannot possibly proceed to ascertain</i> whether or not there is the requisite (legal) proximity between the parties simply because there is <i>no factual foundation</i> on which (legal) proximity can be founded. This is <i>not</i> to state that the establishment of a factual foundation will <i>necessarily</i> lead to a finding of (<i>legal</i>) <i>proximity</i>. The former is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for the establishment of the latter. And, viewing the entire matter from a holistic as well as practical perspective, it is clear that there is no difference, <i>in substance</i>, between the approach adopted in <i>Spandeck</i> and that proposed by Prof\u00a0Amirthalingam.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">105\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It should also be noted that although the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>), which forms the basis of the test laid down by this court in <i>Spandeck</i>, has not been followed in England, the law in that particular jurisdiction continues (as this court noted in <i>Spandeck</i> at [46]\u2212[49]) to remain in a state of flux (see, for example, the House of Lords decision of <i>Customs and Excise Commissioners v Barclays Bank plc</i> [2007] 1\u00a0AC 181).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">106\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is also interesting to note that the position in Canada is similar to that presently applicable in Singapore, where (as mentioned earlier at [98] above) a somewhat modified version of the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i> has been adopted. In particular, whilst affirming the two-stage test in <i>Anns</i>, the Canadian courts have considered both reasonable foreseeability and proximity under the first stage (see, for example, the Canadian Supreme Court decisions of <i>Cooper v Hobart</i> (2001) 206\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 193 at [30]\u2013[31]; <i>Odhavji Estate v Woodhouse</i> (2003) 233\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 193 at [46]\u2212[50]; <i>Hill v Hamilton-Wentworth Regional Police Services Board</i> (2005) 259\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 676 at [47]; <i>Childs v Desormeaux</i> (2006) 266\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 257 at [9]\u2212[12]; and <i>Syl Apps Secure Treatment Centre v BD</i> (2007) 284\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 682 at [23]\u2212[30]). This approach is not necessarily at variance with that adopted in <i>Spandeck</i>, for (as we explained above at [104]) the concept of reasonable foreseeability is also an integral part of the process of ascertaining whether there is sufficient (legal) proximity between the plaintiff and the defendant, albeit on a preliminary (and factual) level.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">107\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The position in Australia appears to be somewhat in a state of flux (see generally Francis Trindade, Peter Cane &amp; Mark Lunney, <i>The Law of Torts in Australia</i> (Oxford University Press, 4th\u00a0Ed, 2007) at ch\u00a09).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">108\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is important, however, to emphasise that every application of the concept of proximity is heavily dependent on the precise factual matrix concerned. In other words, there is no mechanical formula that is to be applied by the court <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> these factors. In a similar vein, no one factor is more important than the other; nor is there any one unique way in which a particular factor is to be applied.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">109\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to consider a separate \u2013 albeit no less important \u2013 point (or, in fact, major requirement) which arises from the very nature of <i>psychiatric harm</i> itself, namely, the potentially limitless reach of liability in negligence for this particular type of injury (see also [71] and [74] above). Given this factor, we are of the view that after applying the test for proximity, which incorporates the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), the <i>second</i> stage of the two-stage test laid down by this court in <i>Spandeck</i> should likewise be applied in the context of claims for psychiatric harm (<i>cf</i> also the reference by Deane\u00a0J to the concept of \u201csome other overriding limitation\u201d or \u201cother overriding control\u201d in <i>Jaensch</i> ([100] <i>supra</i>) at 592, and 600 as well as 603, respectively; see also the reference to the question of whether \u201cthe court considers it fair, just and reasonable that the law should impose a duty\u201d <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Bridge in <i>Caparo</i> ([104] <i>supra</i>) at 618). <i>In other words, the test under Singapore law for determining the existence of a duty of care in the context of claims in negligence for psychiatric harm is the same two-stage test that was laid down by this court in</i> Spandeck <i>([2] supra). The first stage of this test encompasses the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in</i> Part\u00a03 <i>of his judgment in</i> McLoughlin <i>(as set out at [38] above), while the second stage comprises public policy considerations. Before the two-stage test applies, however, the presence of a recognisable psychiatric illness and factual foreseeability must, of course, first be established. This two-stage test is also (as emphasised in</i> Spandeck <i>at [73])</i> <i>(reproduced above at [21]) to be applied incrementally</i>. To this extent, therefore, the test which we have just laid down with regard to liability in negligence for psychiatric harm in the Singapore context is a <i>modified</i> version of the test enunciated by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> inasmuch as the learned law lord did <i>not</i> refer to those <i>policy considerations</i> which (as we have just mentioned) comprise the <i>second</i> stage of the two-stage test we have proposed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">110\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>However</i>, we would (for the reasons elaborated upon in detail above at [66]\u2013[91] and [95]) respectfully disagree with the distinction drawn in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) between primary and secondary victims. The result is that in order for a plaintiff to establish a duty of care on the part of the defendant in the context of psychiatric harm, the plaintiff will have to establish factual foreseeability as well as proximity in the context of <i>psychiatric harm</i> in accordance with the criteria stated at [99]\u2013[103] above (which include the factors set out in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> as part of the first stage of the two-stage test).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Possible reform of the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in</em> McLoughlin<em>?</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">111\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (which form part of the <i>first</i> stage of the two-stage test to be applied for determining liability in cases of psychiatric harm), we are cognisant of the fact that the English Law Commission has recommended that <i>only the first</i> factor (centring on the class of persons whose claims should be recognised) be retained (see item\u00a03 of the \u201cExecutive Summary\u201d of <i>The English Law Commission Report</i> ([90] <i>supra</i>)). In a similar vein, there have been suggestions by academic commentators to the effect that \u201c[p]erhaps one solution is a shift in emphasis to relational proximity [<i>viz</i>, the first factor], with resort to physical and perceptional proximity [<i>viz</i>, the second and third factors, respectively] only if the relationship is not a close one\u201d (see Lee Eng Beng, \u201cVindication of the Three Proximities\u201d [1992] Sing\u00a0JLS\u00a0528 at 539; see also F\u00a0A\u00a0Trindade, \u201cThe Principles Governing the Recovery of Damages for Negligently Caused Nervous Shock\u201d <nobr>[1986] CLJ 476</nobr> at 494\u2013495, which is cited in the former article). However, such a suggestion might well become (in substance and effect) a back-door means of introducing (whether intended or otherwise) reform to this area of the tort of negligence, which (as we point out below at [116]\u2013[120]) is a task not for the courts as such, but (rather) for the <i>Legislature</i>. Further, as Lee correctly admits (\u201cVindication of the Three Proximities\u201d at 540):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">However, once this position [of shifting the emphasis to relational proximity, with physical and perceptional proximity coming into play only if the requisite relational proximity is missing] is achieved, should not the law logically also include claims for psychiatric illnesses caused by having to care for an invalid husband, or by having to cope with having lost a child? <i>Again one faces the prospects of limitless liability. Ultimately, it has to be conceded that such a solution involves the mere substitution of one arbitrary line with another.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">It is significant that <i>The English Law Commission</i> <i>Report</i> recommended that the above change (or reform) in the law be effected via <i>legislation</i> (see, in this regard, the draft Negligence (Psychiatric Illness) Bill at Appendix\u00a0A of <i>The English Law Commission</i> <i>Report</i>). This signifies \u2013 by implication, if not expressly \u2013 that such a reform would <i>entail policy issues that are best decided by the Legislature</i>. We note that such a change in the law has in fact been effected in Australia via case law instead (see the Australian High Court decision of <i>Tame v New South Wales</i> (2002) 211\u00a0CLR 317 (\u201c<i>Tame</i>\u201d) (reference may also be made to the prescient observations of Deane\u00a0J in the earlier decision of the same court in <i>Jaensch</i> ([100] <i>supra</i> at 608\u2013609), as well as the perceptive comments on a leading South African decision (<i>viz</i>, <i>Barnard v Santam Bpk</i> 1999 (1)\u00a0SA\u00a0202): see Jonathan Burchell, \u201cAn Encouraging Prognosis for Claims for Damages for Negligently Inflicted Psychological Harm\u201d (1999) 116\u00a0S\u00a0African\u00a0LJ 697 (\u201cDamages for Negligently Inflicted Psychological Harm\u201d) and Nicholas J\u00a0Mullany, \u201cPersonal Perception of Trauma and Sudden Shock \u2013 South Africa Simplifies Matters\u201d (2000) 116\u00a0LQR 29 (\u201cPersonal Perception of Trauma and Sudden Shock\u201d)). However, it is also pertinent to note that well before <i>Tame</i> was decided, the Australian state of New South Wales had already promulgated <i>legislation</i> which allowed recovery by close relations (as defined therein) for \u201cmental or nervous shock\u201d under certain circumstances (see s\u00a04(1) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1944 (NSW) (\u201cthe 1944 NSW Act\u201d)). Section\u00a04 of the 1944 NSW Act read as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Extension of liability in certain cases</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The liability of any person in respect of injury caused after the commencement of this Act by an act, neglect or default by which any other person is killed, injured or put in peril, shall extend to include liability for injury arising wholly or in part from mental or nervous shock sustained by\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a parent or the husband or wife of the person so killed, injured or put in peril; or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 any other member of the family of the person so killed, injured or put in peril where such person was killed, injured or put in peril within the sight or hearing of such member of the family.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where an action is brought by a member of the family of any person so killed, injured or put in peril in respect of liability for injury arising wholly or in part from mental or nervous shock sustained by the plaintiff as aforesaid and claims have been made against or are apprehended by the defendant at the suit of other members of the family or such person in respect of liability arising by operation of subsection\u00a0one of this section out of the same act, neglect or default the defendant may apply to the court and the court may thereupon stay any proceedings pending at the suit of any such other member of the family arising out of the same act, neglect or default and may proceed in such manner and subject to such regulations as to making members of the family of such person parties to the action as to who is to have the carriage of the action and as to the exclusion of any member of the family who does not come in within a certain time as the court thinks just. The jurisdiction conferred by this subsection may be exercised by any judge of the court sitting in its Common Law Jurisdiction.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where any application under subsection\u00a0two of this section is made the action shall be for the benefit of such members of the family of the person so killed, injured or put in peril as are joined by the court as plaintiffs pursuant to such application and the jury may give such damages as they may think proportion[ate] to the injury resulting to the persons joined as plaintiffs respectively, and the amount so recovered after deducting the costs not recovered from the defendant shall be divided amongst the persons joined as plaintiffs in such shares as the jury by their verdict find and direct.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Any action in respect of a liability arising by operation of subsection\u00a0one of this section shall be brought in the Supreme Court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this section\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cMember of the family\u201d means the husband, wife, parent, child, brother, sister, half-brother and half-sister of the person in relation to which the expression is used.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cParent\u201d includes father, mother, grandfather, grandmother, stepfather, stepmother and any person standing in loco parentis to another.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cChild\u201d includes son, daughter, grandson, granddaughter, stepson, stepdaughter and any person to whom another stands in loco parentis.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">112\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The rationale for s\u00a04 of the 1944 NSW Act was recounted by McHugh\u00a0J in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Gifford v Strang Patrick Stevedoring Pty Ltd</i> (2003) 77\u00a0ALJR 1205 (\u201c<i>Gifford</i>\u201d), as follows (at [34]\u2013[35]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Section\u00a04 was a statutory response to the decision of this Court in <i>Chester v Waverley Corporation</i> [(1939) 62\u00a0CLR 1] and the decision of the House of Lords in <i>Bourhill v Young</i> [[1943] AC\u00a092]. In <i>Chester</i>, this Court held that no action for nervous shock could be brought by a mother who had suffered shock after seeing the dead body of her missing son in a trench under the control of the council. In <i>Bourhill</i>, the House of Lords denied a right of action to a woman who suffered nervous shock after hearing a motor cyclist collide with a motor vehicle. At the time she was unloading a basket from a platform on the other side of a nearby stationary tram. In the Second Reading Speech on the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill in the Legislative Council, the Minister for Justice said that s\u00a04 was \u201ca statutory extension of liability to meet the position created by the decision in <i>[Bourhill] v Young</i> ... It creates no new substantive right of action\u201d [citing New South Wales (Australia), Legislative Council, <i>Parliamentary Debates</i> (8\u00a0November 1944) at 830].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">When s\u00a04 was enacted, it was seen as a beneficial provision that expanded the ability of close family members to recover for nervous shock. It was a legislative response to the perceived inadequacies in the common law, as then understood, to provide compensation to family members for nervous shock suffered as the result of injury to their relatives [citing <i>Jaensch</i> ([100] <i>supra</i>) at 601\u2013602 <i>per</i> Deane\u00a0J]. It removed the need for a family member to show the existence of a duty to the family member or that psychiatric injury to that person was reasonably foreseeable.
