The Minister said that the [B]ill would \u201cprovide a considerable advance on the present law\u201d [citing New South Wales (Australia), Legislative Council, <i>Parliamentary Debates</i> (5\u00a0December 1944) at 1491]. Nothing in s\u00a04 or its history supports Strang\u2019s [the defendant\u2019s] submission that the section was intended to operate to the exclusion of the common law and cover the field in relation to claims for nervous shock by family members.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">113\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a04 of the 1944 NSW Act has since been repealed and the relevant statutory regime is now to be found in Pt\u00a03 of the Civil Liability Act 2002 (NSW) (\u201cthe 2002 NSW Act\u201d), which comprises a number of sections that read as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b>27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Definitions</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">In this Part:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cconsequential mental harm\u201d means mental harm that is a consequence of a personal injury of any other kind.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cmental harm\u201d means impairment of a person\u2019s mental condition.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cnegligence\u201d means failure to exercise reasonable care and skill.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cpersonal injury\u201d includes:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 pre-natal injury, and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 impairment of a person\u2019s physical or mental condition, and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 disease.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cpure mental harm\u201d means mental harm other than consequential mental harm.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Application of Part</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This Part (except section\u00a029) applies to any claim for damages for mental harm resulting from negligence, regardless of whether the claim is brought in tort, in contract, under statute or otherwise.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a029 applies to a claim for damages in any civil proceedings.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This Part does not apply to civil liability that is excluded from the operation of this Part by section\u00a03B [relating to civil liability excluded from the provisions of this particular Act].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Personal injury arising from mental or nervous shock</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">In any action for personal injury, the plaintiff is not prevented from recovering damages merely because the personal injury arose wholly or in part from mental or nervous shock.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Limitation on recovery for pure mental harm arising from shock</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This section applies to the liability of a person (\u201cthe defendant\u201d) for pure mental harm to a person (\u201cthe plaintiff\u201d) arising wholly or partly from mental or nervous shock in connection with another person (\u201cthe victim\u201d) being killed, injured or put in peril by the act or omission of the defendant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The plaintiff is not entitled to recover damages for pure mental harm unless:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the plaintiff witnessed, at the scene, the victim being killed, injured or put in peril, or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the plaintiff is a close member of the family of the victim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Any damages to be awarded to the plaintiff for pure mental harm are to be reduced in the same proportion as any reduction in the damages that may be recovered from the defendant by or through the victim on the basis of the contributory negligence of the victim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 No damages are to be awarded to the plaintiff for pure mental harm if the recovery of damages from the defendant by or through the victim in respect of the act or omission would be prevented by any provision of this Act or any other written or unwritten law.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this section:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cclose member of the family\u201d of a victim means:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a parent of the victim or other person with parental responsibility for the victim, or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the spouse or partner of the victim, or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a child or stepchild of the victim or any other person for whom the victim has parental responsibility, or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a brother, sister, half-brother or half-sister, or stepbrother or stepsister of the victim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">\u201cspouse or partner\u201d means:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a husband or wife, or</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the other party to a de facto relationship within the meaning of the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 [NSW],</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">but where more than one person would so qualify as a spouse or partner, means only the last person to so qualify.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pure mental harm \u2013 liability only for recognised psychiatric illness</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">There is no liability to pay damages for pure mental harm resulting from negligence unless the harm consists of a recognised psychiatric illness.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mental harm \u2013 duty of care</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A person (\u201cthe defendant\u201d) does not owe a duty of care to another person (\u201cthe plaintiff\u201d) to take care not to cause the plaintiff mental harm unless the defendant ought to have foreseen that a person of normal fortitude might, in the circumstances of the case, suffer a recognised psychiatric illness if reasonable care were not taken.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purposes of the application of this section in respect of pure mental harm, the circumstances of the case include the following:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether or not the mental harm was suffered as the result of a sudden shock,</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether the plaintiff witnessed, at the scene, a person being killed, injured or put in peril,</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the nature of the relationship between the plaintiff and any person killed, injured or put in peril,</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 whether or not there was a pre-existing relationship between the plaintiff and the defendant.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purposes of the application of this section in respect of consequential mental harm, the circumstances of the case include the personal injury suffered by the plaintiff.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This section does not require the court to disregard what the defendant knew or ought to have known about the fortitude of the plaintiff.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Liability for economic loss for consequential mental harm</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">A court cannot make an award of damages for economic loss for consequential mental harm resulting from negligence unless the harm consists of a recognised psychiatric illness.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">114\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A statutory equivalent of s\u00a04 of the 1944 NSW Act is still to be found in the Northern Territory (see s\u00a025 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1956 (NT)). In contrast, the Australian Capital Territory has replaced what used to be its statutory equivalent of s\u00a04 of the 1944 NSW Act (<i>ie</i>, s\u00a024 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1955 (ACT)) with legislation along the lines of Pt\u00a03 of the 2002 NSW Act (see the provisions in Pt\u00a03.2 of the Civil Law (Wrongs) Act 2002 (ACT)).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">115\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On a general level, it would appear that such statutory provisions (whether present or past) are in addition to, and not in derogation of, the common law (see <i>Gifford</i> ([112] <i>supra</i>) at [35]) (reproduced above at [112]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">116\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to the <i>Singapore</i> context, whilst we accept that there are cogent arguments for doing away with the second and third of the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (reproduced above at [38]), we are of the view that such a step ought, if at all, to be effected via <i>legislative reform</i>. The danger of a floodgate of litigation ensuing in the event that these factors are dispensed with is a very real one. The English Law Commission itself acknowledged that this would be the case, and estimated that there would be somewhere in the region of a 10% increase in the number of personal injury claims; it also observed that higher insurance premiums (in the range of 2% to 5%) would result (see <i>The English Law Commission</i> <i>Report</i> ([90] <i>supra</i>) at paras\u00a01.12\u20131.13).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">117\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prof\u00a0Tan agreed with this assessment (see <i>Discussion Paper</i> ([74] <i>supra</i>) at p\u00a010), as follows (see also, by the same author, \u201cLiability for Psychiatric Illness\u201d ([39] <i>supra</i>) at 176\u2013177):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><i>For every accident there will be two sets of plaintiffs: those physically injured (the immediate victims) and those close to the immediate victims in love and affection who suffer psychiatric illness as a result of this whether at or away from the accident (the related secondary victims). Psychiatric illness claims will automatically accompany the claims of those injured or killed if their loved ones can prove by expert psychiatric evidence that they actually suffered recognisable psychiatric illness as a result of the accident. Presently, with the existing common law restriction, such claims for psychiatric illness are exceptional. With the proposed legislative change [recommended by the English Law Commission] these psychiatric [illness] claims will become a regular additional feature in the relevant accident cases.</i> The [English Law] Commission guesstimates that extending the liability for psychiatric illness \u2026 will result in about a ten per cent increase in the number of personal injury claims and an increase of between two to five per cent in motor insurance premiums ([<i>The English Law Commission Report</i>], paras\u00a01.12 and 1.13). <i>The escalation of liability may be much more than what is estimated by the [English Law] Commission as the real increase in the number of such claims, after widespread public awareness of this liability and a greater claim consciousness of it, is difficult to quantify accurately at this stage.</i> [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">118\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we noted earlier (above at [111]), the Australian High Court has (in <i>Tame</i> ([111] <i>supra</i>)) effected reform in this aspect of the tort of negligence through the <i>common law</i>. However, it is interesting to note that Prof\u00a0Trindade arrived at precisely the <i>same</i> conclusion, <i>viz</i>, that such reform (albeit made by way of case law as opposed to by way of legislation) would generate a similar danger of opening the floodgates to negligence litigation (see F\u00a0A\u00a0Trindade, \u201cReformulation of the Nervous Shock Rules\u201d (2003) 119\u00a0LQR 204 at 209\u2013210).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">119\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On a more <i>general</i> level, it is interesting that Prof\u00a0Tan was also of the view that legislative reform in the <i>Singapore</i> context was <i>not</i> necessary. In his view (see <i>Discussion Paper</i> at p\u00a011):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">Legislative reform of the law, at this stage of its development, when the medical and legal knowledge is not sufficiently mature, may interrupt the proper development of the law on an incremental case-by-case basis and may give rise to legislative recovery in certain areas of psychiatric illness that could, on implementation, prove to be more generous than envisaged. The latter could be a more serious problem for Singapore given that \u2026 accident victims are already preferred as a class and are in many ways better catered for compared to \u2026 others who suffer similar hardship from non-accident circumstances as a consequence of socio-economic insecurity or natural misfortunes. This is not to say that the common law liability for psychiatric illness, at this juncture, is satisfactory. Indeed, parts of the development are clearly controversial, but they are not so problematic or unsatisfactory as to require urgent legislative change.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">120\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prof\u00a0Tan\u2019s <i>Discussion Paper</i> was accepted by the then Law Reform Committee of the Singapore Academy of Law. Some years have passed since it was considered, but the general arguments still appear to hold good even today. What is important for present purposes, however, is that whether or not reform of this area of the tort of negligence is to be effected is one that is best left to the <i>Legislature</i>. Indeed, many of the imponderables referred to above lie wholly outside the expertise of the court and relate to policy matters which require the <i>Legislature\u2019s</i> consideration (see also above at [116]). One might add that another issue <i>not</i> hitherto considered in the present judgment that might require legislative attention is the common law requirement prescribing the need for sudden shock as one of the prerequisites to recovery (this requirement has already been departed from in the Australian context as a result of the Australian High Court\u2019s decision in <i>Tame</i> and, presumably, also in the South African context (see \u201cDamages for Negligently Inflicted Psychological Harm\u201d ([111] <i>supra</i>) and \u201cPersonal Perception of Trauma and Sudden Shock\u201d ([111] <i>supra</i>)); its abolition was also advocated by the English Law Commission (see <i>The English Law Commission Report</i> ([90] <i>supra</i>)).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Summary of the applicable law relating to claims in negligence for psychiatric harm in Singapore</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">121<b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</b> It will be seen \u2013 primarily from our analysis of <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) as well as the position in the Singapore context above (see, especially, above at [57]) \u2013 that the present legal position on liability in negligence for psychiatric harm in the local context (assuming, of course, that there is the existence of a recognisable psychiatric illness to begin with) is <i>wholly consistent with</i> the two-stage approach adopted by this court in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>). This is especially the case once it is accepted (as we pointed out above at [100]\u2013[103]) that the three factors propounded by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> (reproduced above at [38]) fall within the <i>first</i> stage of this two-stage approach (and are, hence, an integral part of the inquiry as to whether there is sufficient (legal) <i>proximity</i> between the plaintiff and the defendant). We would reiterate that these three factors lend themselves to general application, regardless of whether the claimant was in the position of, say, Mr\u00a0Page (the plaintiff motorist) in <i>Page</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) or Mrs\u00a0McLoughlin (the plaintiff mother) in <i>McLoughlin</i>. Within this framework, the primary victim/secondary victim dichotomy established in <i>Page</i> is no longer relevant for the reasons set out earlier (above at [66]\u2013[91]).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">122\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>second</i> stage of the two-stage approach laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> involves considering whether, in the specific context and factual matrix of a given case, there are public policy factors that would entail the courts not imposing a duty of care even if there is otherwise sufficient proximity between the plaintiff and the defendant pursuant to the analysis carried out under the first stage. If, there are no applicable policy factors to negate the existence of a duty of care, then the courts will find a duty of care established on the part of the defendant, the breach of which would result in liability and the awarding of damages (subject, of course, to the established constraints on recovery of damages, including the doctrines of remoteness of damage, mitigation of damage as well as contributory negligence).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">123\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With this decision, therefore, this court has moved towards the ideal envisioned in <i>Spandeck</i> (at [71]) of having \u201ca <i>single</i> test \u2026 to determine the imposition of a duty of care in all claims arising out of negligence, <i>irrespective</i> of the <i>type</i> of the damages claimed\u201d [emphasis in original]. It is true that the three factors set out by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of his judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> relating to the ascertainment of whether there is sufficient proximity between the parties appear to differ somewhat from, for example, the factors highlighted in <i>Spandeck</i>, where the focus was on the twin criteria of the voluntary assumption of responsibility and reliance (<i>id</i> at [81], reproduced above at [99]). However, this difference is more apparent than real. As we pointed out earlier (above at [100]\u2013[103]), the <i>general rationale underlying as well as the categories relating to the concept of proximity</i> are <i>common.</i> More importantly, we also pointed out (above at [108]) that in determining whether the requisite proximity is present in a particular case, much will turn on the precise factual matrix concerned. In the particular context of psychiatric illness or nervous shock, it is not surprising that Lord\u00a0Wilberforce framed the three factors in the way which he did. Even then, the <i>application</i> of these factors to the facts of the case concerned will, as just mentioned, be all-important. Looked at in this light, it would be very rare to find a case which could be said to constitute a precedent that is directly on point and, hence, conclusive. This is not, of course, to state that prior precedents (especially those that emanate from Singapore) are never helpful; on the contrary, many precedents may (and often do) assist in elucidating the applicable law and may even assist the courts in deciding on certain specific issues (where the comparative factual matrices, at least for those particular issues, are factually and/or legally the same).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>Our decision with regard to the second appellant\u2019s case on appeal</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">124\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having covered the law applicable to the second appellant\u2019s claim against the respondent, we now turn to consider the merits of the second appellant\u2019s arguments before this court (on the assumption that she suffered a recognisable psychiatric illness). The second appellant essentially blamed the respondent\u2019s deceitful conduct for her plight. This conduct included, <i>inter alia</i>, the fact that the respondent had informed the second appellant that the physical condition of the first appellant was not serious when it was (in reality) quite the opposite, as well as the fact that the respondent had failed or neglected to tell the second appellant that the Taxi had collided into the rear of the Motorcycle.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>The second appellant\u2019s allegations against the respondent</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">125\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect to the allegation that the respondent had lied to the second appellant about the physical condition of the first appellant, the Judge made the following findings (see the GD at [62]\u2013[63]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As the second plaintiff [<i>ie</i>, the second appellant] rightly conceded under cross-examination, if the second defendant [<i>ie</i>, the respondent] proved that he did not lie to her, her claim would and must fail.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On her first allegation, the second plaintiff had conceded during cross-examination as well as on questioning by the court \u2026 that the second defendant [had] not lie[d] to her. It was the first plaintiff\u2019s [<i>ie</i>, the first appellant\u2019s] own evidence that he was wearing a helmet and a raincoat at the material time, that apart from his spinal injuries, he suffered no visible injuries other than bruises to his face and hands. Therefore, when the second defendant saw the first plaintiff lying on the road, the former could only see the latter\u2019s superficial injuries. Hence, the second defendant described to the second [plaintiff] what he actually saw. The second defendant would not know at that point of time, that the first plaintiff\u2019s other injuries were so serious as to render him a tetraplegic.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">126\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was the second appellant\u2019s submission that the fact that the first appellant was immobile meant that the respondent should have known that something was seriously wrong with the first appellant, even if the respondent did not have prior knowledge of the injuries incurred. The Judge rejected this argument for the reasons set out at [63] of the GD (see the passage reproduced in the preceding paragraph). We agreed with the Judge and found no merit in this submission.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">127\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also rejected the allegation that the respondent had failed or neglected to tell the second appellant that the Taxi had collided into the rear of the Motorcycle, as this was precisely one of the major issues that had to be decided by the court; in respect of this particular question, we had earlier found (for the reasons set out above at [14]\u2013[18]) that the Motorcycle had self-skidded and that there had therefore been no collision between the two vehicles, contrary to what the appellants alleged.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">128\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What remained was the respondent\u2019s alleged failure to be more candid with the second appellant <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> his involvement in the Accident. In so far as this was concerned, the Judge observed as follows (see the GD at [85]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">I would stress that I do not for a moment condone the second defendant\u2019s actions subsequent to the [A]ccident. His conduct was reprehensible; he should have been more candid in his telephone conversations and subsequent personal contacts with the second plaintiff. He should have disclosed to her that the [T]axi was involved in the [A]ccident, even if it meant facing the wrath of the [plaintiffs\u2019] family, as the plaintiffs and their sons would undoubtedly blame him for the first plaintiff\u2019s plight. I believe the second defendant genuinely feared (however unfounded) that he would be charged by the Traffic Police over the accident. His anxiety to find out from the second plaintiff whether the first plaintiff had implicated him in anyway in my view far outweighed his expressed concern for the wellbeing of the first plaintiff.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">129\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge\u2019s remarks were, with respect, misdirected. At that point in time, given the circumstances of the Accident, it would not be surprising that the respondent, as a layperson, would have been fearful of being somehow implicated in the Accident. Given the circumstances, he could not be seriously faulted for trying to find out whether he had been implicated by the first appellant. He might have taken advantage of the emotional state of the second appellant for his own benefit, but the question which the court has to ask itself is: However morally reprehensible his conduct might have been, was the respondent guilty of conduct that was tortious in law?</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">130\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The only possible conduct in respect of which the respondent could arguably be said to owe a duty of care to the second appellant would be his communication of matters relating to the Accident to the second appellant. For the sake of completeness, and giving due consideration to the seriousness of the appellants\u2019 plight, we decided to consider whether such a duty did of care did indeed exist on the facts of this case, applying the test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Foreseeability of damage</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">131\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As stated earlier (above at [21] and [104]), reasonable foreseeability \u2013 in the factual sense \u2013 of the damage or injury suffered is a preliminary threshold requirement which a plaintiff in a negligence action must satisfy. This requirement is almost always satisfied. As was stated in the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Sunny Metal &amp; Engineering Pte Ltd v Ng Khim Ming Eric</i> <nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 853</nobr> (at [55]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]he requirement of reasonable foreseeability from a <i>factual</i> perspective will <i>almost always be satisfied</i>, simply because of its very nature and the very wide nature of the \u201cnet\u201d it necessarily casts. There is therefore <i>no practical need</i> to include such a <i>factual</i> element within a <i>legal</i> formulation such as exists with regard to the existence (or otherwise) of <i>a duty of care</i>. \u2026 This is not to state that this last-mentioned (<i>factual</i>) element is to be discarded. As I have already mentioned, it will <i>almost always</i> be satisfied. [emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">132\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, even allowing for the naturally wide ambit of (factual) foreseeability, it was our view that this requirement was not satisfied in the present case in relation to the second appellant. To hold that it is reasonably foreseeable that the mere communication of the information in question without more could result in harm to a party boggles the imagination and stretches the realms of reality. We did (with great hesitation) acknowledge, however, that certain situations where information was communicated might, perhaps, result in the foreseeability of harm. But, this was not such a case. Nevertheless, on the assumption that the second appellant could establish the requisite factual foreseeability, we proceeded to consider the three factors set out in <i>Part\u00a03</i> of Lord\u00a0Wilberforce\u2019s judgment in <i>McLoughlin</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>) (see the passage reproduced at [38] above) in relation to the issue of (legal) proximity, which constitutes the first stage of the two-stage approach adopted in <i>Spandeck</i>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Proximity</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>The class of persons whose claims should be recognised</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">133\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The presence of a spousal relationship between the first appellant and the second appellant was a factor in favour of finding that the respondent did owe the second appellant a duty of care on the facts of the present appeal. As Lord\u00a0Wilberforce stated in <i>McLoughlin</i> (at 422):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">As regards the class of persons [whose claims should be recognised], the possible range is between the closest of family ties \u2013 of parent and child, or husband and wife \u2013 and the ordinary bystander. Existing law recognises the claims of the first \u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">It is therefore clear, on the facts of the present appeal, that the requisite relational proximity existed.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>Proximity to the tortious event</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">134\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In general, claims in negligence for damages for psychiatric harm usually arise in accident situations (<i>ie</i>, an accident is said to be the tortious event which caused the claimant to suffer psychiatric harm). In the present appeal, however, the alleged tortious event was the communication of information from the respondent to the second appellant, and not the Accident itself. If it were the latter, it was clear that the second appellant was not physically proximate to the alleged tortious event.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-3\"><em>The means by which psychiatric harm is caused</em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">135\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The traditional view in relation to causal proximity (<i>ie</i>, the means by which psychiatric harm is caused) was stated by Lord\u00a0Wilberforce in <i>McLoughlin</i>, as follows (at 422\u2013423):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[T]here is no case in which the law has compensated shock brought about by communication by a third party \u2026 The shock must come through sight or hearing of the event or of its immediate aftermath.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">This traditional focus of the common law on direct physical perception is also reflected in the following statement of Windeyer\u00a0J in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Mount Isa Mines Limited v Pusey</i> (1970) 125\u00a0CLR 383 (at 407):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">If the sole cause of shock be what is told or read of some happening then I think it is correctly said that, unless there be an intention to cause a nervous shock, no action lies against either the bearer of bad tidings or the person who caused the event of which [he] tell[s]. There is no duty in law to break bad news gently or to do nothing which creates bad news.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">136\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With this as a starting point, we turn to consider cases where the courts have departed from the traditional view <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> situations where the communication of information led to psychiatric harm.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">137\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The position of the second appellant was analogous to that of the plaintiff in cases such as the English High Court decisions of <i>Farrell v Avon Heath Authority</i> [2001] 1\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s\u00a0Rep\u00a0Med 458 (\u201c<i>Farrell</i>\u201d) and <i>Wilkinson v Downton</i> [1897] 2\u00a0QB 57 (\u201c<i>Wilkinson</i>\u201d), which she relied on. In <i>Farrell</i>, the plaintiff, who had fathered a son out of wedlock, was told to go to the hospital to see his newborn child. He was very excited at the prospect of fatherhood, but, upon arrival, was told that his son had died. He was asked whether he would like to see the dead baby. He replied in the affirmative and proceeded to kiss and cuddle the dead baby. A few minutes later, the nurses informed him that there had been a mistake and that his baby was alive. The plaintiff developed post-traumatic stress disorder as a result of this ordeal and sued for damages. Bursell\u00a0J held that the claimant could recover damages for the psychiatric harm suffered.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">138\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Wilkinson</i>, the defendant falsely and maliciously represented to the plaintiff that her husband had been seriously injured. The plaintiff developed psychiatric harm and sued for damages for the injury to her health. Wright\u00a0J held that the plaintiff should succeed in her claim. In our view, <i>Wilkinson</i> is authority for the principle that wilfully communicating false information is actionable if it causes physical, including psychiatric, harm. In the present case, however, there was no intention to cause harm, much less the type of harm that the second appellant complained of.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">139\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the decision in <i>Farrell</i> is concerned, it extended \u2013 erroneously, in our view \u2013 the boundaries of recovery for psychiatric harm and therefore ought not to be followed. As Gummow and Kirby\u00a0JJ stated in the Australian High Court decision of <i>Tame</i> ([111] <i>supra</i> at 395):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">[I]n the absence of a malign intention, no action lies against the bearer of bad news for psychiatric harm caused by the manner in which the news is conveyed or, if the news be true, for psychiatric harm caused by the fact of its conveyance. The discharge of the responsibility to impart bad news fully and frankly would be inhibited by the imposition in those circumstances of a duty of care to avoid causing distress to the recipient of the news. There can be no legal duty to break bad news gently. This is so even if degrees of tact and diplomacy were capable of objective identification and assessment, which manifestly they are not. Neither carelessness nor insensitivity in presentation will found an action in negligence against the messenger.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">140\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court should be slow to allow recovery for psychiatric harm arising from the communication of information in cases where no \u201cmalign intention\u201d (<i>Tame</i> at 395) on the part of the person communicating the information is present. This is clearly indicated by <i>Wilkinson</i> ([137] <i>supra</i>) (see above at [138]), as well as the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Janvier v Sweeney</i> [1919] 2\u00a0KB 316, which relates, in fact, to a special species of <i>intentional</i> torts, where the defendant wilfully does an act calculated to cause physical harm to the plaintiff (see also the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Malcomson Nicholas Hugh Bertram v Naresh Kumar Mehta</i> <nobr>[2001] 4 SLR 454</nobr> at [46]\u2212[48]). In those circumstances, that more harm than was anticipated resulted is immaterial. As we have already pointed out earlier (above at [138]), however, the present appeal did <i>not</i> involve an intentional tort in that the respondent had no intention to cause the second appellant harm.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">141\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would also note that case law indicates that a possible remedy for psychiatric harm resulting from the communication of information could exist in situations where there is a professional relationship between the parties. For example, in the Supreme Court of South Australia decision of <i>Brown v The Mount Barker Soldiers\u2019 Hospital Incorporated</i> <nobr>[1934] SASR 128</nobr>, the defendant hospital negligently burnt a newborn baby out of sight of the mother, who suffered shock when told of her child\u2019s injury. The mother, who was a patient of the hospital at the material time, sued the hospital for the psychiatric illness suffered. Piper\u00a0J held that the hospital owed the mother a duty of care. In a similar vein, in <i>Furniss v Fitchett</i> <nobr>[1958] NZLR 396</nobr>, the Supreme Court of New Zealand allowed a plaintiff to succeed in an action against her doctor for nervous shock caused by his negligent disclosure to her husband of his opinion as to her mental stability.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">142\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 No such professional relationship existed between the second appellant and the respondent in the present appeal. More generally and importantly, it is clear, in our view, that the second appellant did not satisfy the requirement of legal proximity which constitutes the first stage of the two-stage approach adopted in <i>Spandeck</i> (which approach, as we held earlier, likewise applies to cases of psychiatric harm).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Public policy</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">143\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having regard to our conclusion (as just stated in the preceding paragraph) in relation to the issue of legal proximity on the facts of the present appeal, it was, strictly speaking, unnecessary for this court to proceed to consider the second stage of the two-stage test laid down in <i>Spandeck</i> ([2] <i>supra</i>), which centres on public policy. However, as we shall elaborate upon in a moment, a consideration of the latter serves to underscore the conclusion that was reached at the first stage of this two-stage test. More specifically, it will be seen that considerations of public policy militate against the finding of a duty of care where communication of information is concerned, even assuming that legal proximity can be established at the first stage of the two-stage approach adopted in <i>Spandeck</i>, except in situations where a \u201cmalign intention\u201d (<i>Tame</i> ([111] <i>supra</i>) at 395) on the part of the person communicating the information is present.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">144\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Uppermost in our minds were the potential ramifications to the commonplace activity of communicating news, and, in particular, the communication of bad news. In <i>Alcock</i> ([23] <i>supra</i>), Parker\u00a0LJ observed (when the case was before the English Court of Appeal) as follows (at 363):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">It appears to me that if it can be reasonably foreseen that psychiatric illness can result from the shock of being told what has happened but the defendant is not liable, so also the defendant is not liable if the injury results from information conveyed by means of television and its commentary. If this is not correct it would, as it seems to me, follow that anyone who reports, at any rate promptly, the fact of death or serious injury would be liable for psychiatric illness resulting, as would the television company.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">145\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It can be expected that a decision to allow recovery in all situations where communication of information results in psychiatric harm would result in a changed (and more constrained) approach towards the communication of bad news. As Gummow and Kirby\u00a0JJ opined in <i>Tame</i> at 395 (in a passage which was set out earlier at [139] above), recovery for psychiatric harm caused by the communication of information should be limited to situations where a \u201cmalign intention\u201d (<i>Tame</i> at 395) on the part of the person communicating the information is present in order to prevent the inhibition of full and frank disclosure of news.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><strong><em>Other observations</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">146\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In order for a plaintiff to succeed in a claim founded on the tort of negligence, the following must be established:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the defendant owes the plaintiff a duty of care;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the defendant breached that duty of care by acting (or omitting to act) below the standard of care required of it;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the defendant\u2019s breach caused the plaintiff damage;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the plaintiff\u2019s losses arising from the defendant\u2019s breach are not too remote; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 such losses can be adequately proved and quantified.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">In so far as the issue of <i>liability</i> is concerned, the plaintiff is only required to establish that a duty of care was owed and that a breach of such duty occurred. The other requirements listed above are, strictly speaking, concerned with the assessment of damages and <i>not</i> with liability (see Harvey McGregor, <i>McGregor on Damages</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 17th\u00a0Ed, 2003) at para\u00a01\u2013019, where the learned author emphasises the distinction between the <i>existence</i> of liability and the <i>extent and measurement</i> of liability <i>once it has been established</i>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">147\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While the Judge purported to deal solely with the issue of liability, she expressly dealt with issues of remoteness and causation <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the second appellant, which issues, in the analysis of the learned author of <i>McGregor on Damages</i>, relate to the extent of liability (<i>viz</i>, the assessment of damages) and <i>not</i> the existence of liability. For the sake of completeness, however, we would express our agreement with the reasoning of the Judge with regard to both of these issues (as set out at [87] and [90] of the GD).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">148\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Our consideration of the evidence and the parties\u2019 arguments demonstrated that the Judge was not plainly wrong in arriving at her decision that the respondent was not responsible for the first appellant\u2019s injuries. In so far as the second appellant was concerned, we found that there was no duty of care owed by the respondent to her. In the circumstances, we dismissed the appeal with costs and the usual consequential orders.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">149\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 That the Accident was a tragic one is undeniable, and we have the utmost sympathy for the very real plight of both the appellants. In this regard, we must commend Mr\u00a0Quentin Loh\u00a0SC, who was lead counsel for the respondent. At the conclusion of this appeal, he not only expressed his sympathy for the appellants, but also assured the court that, although he had no instructions as to costs, he would consult with his client and recommend that costs not be enforced against the appellants. He added that, if necessary, his own costs would be reduced.</p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn1\"
