Must the courts choose only between two stark choices, <i>ie</i>, <i>the</i> <i>principle</i> that a party must prove its losses by establishing through direct evidence what its precise losses are on the one hand and <i>the</i> <i>pragmatism</i> that encourages the courts to support the sensible extra-judicial resolution of disputes on the other? Is it not open to the courts to approach the resolution of such a conundrum with <i>principled</i> <i>pragmatism</i>? Can it not be said that the principle of proving loss <i>finds expression</i> in the courts\u2019 scrutiny of the downstream settlement contracts for reasonableness? Ultimately, if liability is not an issue, the true loss suffered by such claimants is in fact <i>equivalent</i> to the settlement amount. The courts, in examining the reasonableness of these settlements, are in effect confirming and ensuring that these settlement amounts reasonably reflect the quantum of loss suffered by the claimants. In this sense then, the twin concepts of reasonableness and proof of actual loss are intertwined and, in reality, represent different sides of the same coin. Before we proceed to discuss the applicable law, it would be appropriate to turn first to the facts of the present case.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The facts</font></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Britestone Pte Ltd (\u201cthe appellant\u201d) is a company incorporated in Singapore which sources electronic components from traders, distributors and manufacturers for its clients. Smith &amp; Associates Far East, Ltd (\u201cthe respondent\u201d) is a company incorporated in Hong Kong which distributes electronic components, semiconductors and computer products. The N\u00a0F\u00a0Smith Group, including the respondent, have enjoyed an ongoing business relation with the appellant, the appellant\u2019s holding company (Britestone Limited) and Britestone Limited\u2019s other subsidiaries or associated companies (collectively referred to as \u201cthe Britestone Group\u201d) for more than ten years. During this period, the N\u00a0F\u00a0Smith Group purchased and sold electronic commodities to the Britestone Group in various countries for sub-sale to their customers.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 11\u00a0August 2003, the respondent purchased 52,000 units of \u201cAVX\u201d capacitors bearing the part number \u201cTPSC336K016R0300\u201d from the appellant. On 15\u00a0August 2003, the appellant delivered the capacitors to the respondent in Hong Kong. The respondent resold and shipped the capacitors to Celestica Thailand Ltd (\u201cCTL\u201d), a subsidiary of Celestica International Inc, which then installed the capacitors onto printed circuit boards for its customer, EMC Corporation (\u201cEMC\u201d), in Cork, United Kingdom and Franklin, United States of America.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In September 2003, CTL discovered that the capacitors supplied by the respondent were in fact counterfeit. This emerged after two capacitors caught fire at EMC\u2019s premises. By an e-mail dated 16\u00a0September 2003, AVX Corporation informed CTL that the capacitors were counterfeit. On 25\u00a0September 2003, CTL additionally claimed that the capacitors were inherently defective. As a result, a purging exercise was initiated, and the counterfeit capacitors were removed from the printed circuit boards and substituted with genuine capacitors. EMC claimed an amount of US$444,680 from CTL for expenses incurred in the purging exercises undertaken in Cork and Franklin.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 CTL in turn claimed the same amount of US$444,680 from the respondent. In support of its claim, CTL furnished the respondent with a written summary entitled \u201cEMC Global Summary \u2013 Purge Costing\u201d (\u201cthe FMC report\u201d). This summary was compiled by Kimberly Aube (\u201cAube\u201d), who was CTL\u2019s global programme manager in charge of the EMC account at the material time. As CTL agreed to assist EMC in resolving the unhappy situation, Aube became actively involved in the purging exercise. Aube\u2019s summary contained a breakdown of EMC\u2019s purging costs, and is set out in the following manner:</font></p>\n\n<p/>\n\n<table cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"90%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\"><strong>\u00a0 Cork</strong></font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\"><strong>\u00a0 Franklin</strong></font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"200\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Initial Purge Assessment</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$6,405</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$20,157</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Purge Execution</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$106,382</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$222,201</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Materials</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$18,306</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$36,595</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"250\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Management &amp; Administration</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$9,443</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$6,688</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"250\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Celestica Contractors</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$18,504</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 -</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">TOTAL</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$159,040</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$285,641</font></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"130\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">US$444,680</font></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Negotiations to assess the damage were carried out between representatives from CTL and the respondent, <i>ie</i>, Ng Lup Wai (\u201cNg\u201d), CTL\u2019s commodity manager at the material time, and Matthew Henry Hartzell (\u201cHartzell\u201d), the respondent\u2019s general counsel at the material time. After the initial negotiations, CTL offered the respondent a discount of US$50,000 from the claimed amount. The respondent did not agree to this and insisted on a more substantial reduction. Finally, after nine months of negotiations between CTL and the respondent, a settlement was arrived at on 1\u00a0July 2004. The respondent agreed to pay CTL a sum of US$300,000 in full and final settlement of all of CTL\u2019s claims against it. The respondent initially requested to pay CTL US$200,000 by way of a credit memo and US$100,000 in cash. This was rejected by CTL, which insisted that the respondent pay at least US$150,000 in cash. On 13\u00a0September 2004, the respondent paid CTL the sum of US$150,000 by way of a wire transfer, and on 15\u00a0September 2004, the respondent paid CTL a further US$150,000 by way of a credit memo against CTL\u2019s outstanding account receivables due to the respondent.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Throughout the period of negotiations between CTL and the respondent, the respondent repeatedly attempted to contact the appellant to involve it in the ongoing settlement discussions with a view towards seeking a contribution from it to the settlement amount. On 11\u00a0June 2004 and 4\u00a0August 2004 respectively, the respondent sent letters to the appellant seeking payment of the settlement sum of US$300,000, but there was no reply from the appellant. On 29\u00a0September 2004, the respondent\u2019s solicitors sent a letter to the appellant to demand payment of US$309,776 by 8\u00a0October 2004. On 8\u00a0October 2004, the appellant\u2019s solicitors finally responded to the respondent\u2019s solicitors stating that the appellant would not accede to the respondent\u2019s demand and seeking documentary proof to support the respondent\u2019s claim. More significantly, in the same letter, the appellant\u2019s solicitors said that the appellant was \u201cnot notified of the purpose for which [the respondent] had purchased tantalum capacitors from [the appellant]\u201d. This stance has been maintained in these proceedings by Tan Mee Yee (\u201cTan\u201d), the appellant\u2019s sales manager, who asserted that the respondent did not expressly inform her that it required the capacitors for resale to its customers to manufacture printed circuit boards.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 1\u00a0November 2004, the respondent\u2019s solicitors replied to the appellant\u2019s solicitors and furnished the appellant with several documents, including e-mails from AVX Corporation to CTL evidencing that the capacitors were counterfeit, the settlement agreement between CTL and the respondent as well as the credit memo and the wire transfer confirmation evidencing payment of the settlement sum of US$300,000. The appellant\u2019s solicitors, on 9\u00a0November 2004, wrote to the respondent\u2019s solicitors denying the allegations that the capacitors which the appellant had supplied were counterfeit. The appellant\u2019s solicitors requested for more documents, including clarification as to how the respondent had computed the alleged settlement sum of US$300,000. On 2\u00a0December 2004, the respondent\u2019s solicitors wrote to the appellant\u2019s solicitors asserting that the respondent\u2019s efforts in achieving an amicable settlement for the parties\u2019 mutual benefit were not being satisfactorily addressed.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent commenced proceedings against the appellant on 16\u00a0February 2005, alleging that the appellant had breached an implied condition of the contract under s\u00a013 of the Sale of Goods Act (Cap\u00a0393, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) in failing to ensure that the capacitors would conform to the description \u201cAVX\u201d and the required part number \u201cTPSC336K016R0300\u201d. The respondent claimed the settlement sum of US$300,000 that it had paid to CTL as well as US$2,184 as loss of profits. Ultimately, on 20\u00a0March 2006, both parties agreed to a consent judgment by which the appellant admitted liability for the damage caused, leaving the issue of quantum to be assessed by the court.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the hearing for assessment of damages, the assistant registrar awarded damages in the sum of US$302,184 in the respondent\u2019s favour. In addressing the issue of remoteness, Tan attempted to disavow knowledge of the use of the capacitors in printed circuit boards. The assistant registrar, however, accepted the testimony of John Bernhardt Prymmer\u00a0III, the respondent\u2019s managing director, who stated during cross-examination that the capacitors were used to control the flow of electricity on these boards and \u201c[o]n their own \u2026 they do nothing\u201d. We find it helpful to also refer to the assistant registrar\u2019s grounds of decision in <span class=\"title1\"><i>Smith &amp; Associates Far East, Ltd v Britestone Pte Ltd</i><nobr>[2006] SGHC 186</nobr> (\u201cGD\u201d).</span>She held (GD at [40]) that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">It [was] surely within the [appellant\u2019s] contemplation that the capacitors [might] be sold from customer to customer, and ultimately be used in relation to a [printed circuit board] or some other related use.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the issue of the reasonableness of the settlement reached between the respondent and CTL, the assistant registrar found that there had been sufficient legal advice in the circumstances and held (GD at [48]) that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[A]n in-house legal counsel would certainly seek to settle the claim at the lowest possible quantum. \u2026 Hartzell had successfully reduced the initial sum claimed by [CTL], and had not simply accepted the original claim \u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Further, she noted that opportunities to participate in the settlement negotiations had been given to the appellant in so far as the respondent had made conscious efforts to contact the appellant seeking contribution, but the appellant had \u201cfailed to respond\u201d to its letters: GD at [50]. A significant factor that impressed the assistant registrar was the length of the negotiations, which lasted some nine months. The length of this period, she pithily observed (GD at [52]), was:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[F]ar from suggestive that the final sum of US$300,000 and the EMC Global Summary were accepted by the [respondent] hastily without due consideration of the merits of [CTL\u2019s] case. Moreover, Matthew Hartzell stated that he had questioned various aspects of the EMC Global Summary, such as \u201cwhy it cost so much money\u201d and \u201cwhy rectification and purging had to be done so quickly\u201d.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">More importantly, we noted that the assistant registrar took into account evidence which demonstrated the <i>bona fide</i> nature of the settlement. She summarised her findings of fact thus (GD at [54] and [57]):</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 Although Kimberly Aube conceded that certain pages of the EMC Global Summary were submitted by EMC, she clearly considered the entire document to be her own report, albeit prepared with the assistance of EMC. While she stated that certain pages were prepared \u201c100% based on EMC\u2019s input\u201d, she had also testified that she had verified the figures by looking at the corresponding receipts, bills and orders. Kimberly Aube had also incorporated information contained in this document into her own affidavit of evidence-in-chief. <i>When questioned about various parts of the document during cross-examination, she displayed intimate knowledge of all the details of the document. Furthermore, she had personally supervised the entire purging process in Franklin as well as Cork, as well as monitored the operating time, costs and expenses. I find therefore that there is no hearsay as Kimberly Aube had personal knowledge of the details of EMC\u2019s costs. On the contrary, I was impressed by Kimberly Aube\u2019s methodical and meticulous manner of tracing the steps of the entire purging process, as well as documenting all the costs incurred. It can hardly be concluded that it was unreasonable for the [respondent] to have accepted the costs claimed in this document.</i></font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In sum, I find that the settlement was a reasonable one. There was proper legal advice given by the [respondent\u2019s] own legal counsel, who had properly taken into account the possibility of incurring exorbitant costs in the event that litigation took place. [CTL] had properly supervised every step of the purging process and was aware of the costs incurred. Matthew Hartzell, on behalf of the [respondent], had also asked for support of the claim. The [respondent] had spent substantial time attempting to reduce the sum claimed by [CTL]. The quantum that was settled for was more than reasonable, since [CTL\u2019s] own costs in purging were finally excluded and only EMC\u2019s costs were claimed. There was also a quid pro quo, as [CTL] was given permission to audit the [respondent\u2019s] work processes in the future. <em>As explained by Kimberly Aube, the large sum for purging was due to the urgency in rectifying the [printed circuit boards]. There were only two weeks for all the products to be repaired and tested to meet EMC\u2019s demands to its customers. On all counts, this was, in my opinion, a reasonable settlement.</em></font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant appealed against the assistant registrar\u2019s decision. The resulting registrar\u2019s appeal was heard by a judge, and his decision is reported in <span class=\"title1\"><i>Smith &amp; Associates Far East Ltd v Britestone Pte Ltd</i><nobr>[2007] 1 SLR 958</nobr>.</span> The appellant, in the course of that appeal, did not dispute its liability for US$2,184, being the respondent\u2019s loss of profit (see [11] above). The sole issue for determination by the judge was whether the appellant had to pay the respondent the US$300,000 that the respondent had paid in full and final settlement of CTL\u2019s claim against it. The judge dismissed the appeal. He held that the damages were plainly within the parties\u2019 contemplation and were not too remote. He stated at [12] and [16] of his grounds of decision:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is pertinent to note that in <i>Monarch Steamship Co, Limited v Karlshamns Oljefabriker (A/B)</i> [1949] AC\u00a0196 at 224, Lord\u00a0Wright observed that reasonable businessmen \u201cmust be taken to understand the ordinary practices and exigencies of the other\u2019s trade or business\u201d and that need not generally be the subject of special discussion or communication. In the present case, Smith and Britestone had traded with each other for a long time and Britestone\u2019s sales manager, Ms\u00a0Tan, accepted during cross-examination that when Smith ordered the capacitors, it was stated that the capacitors were for its customers.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present case, the capacitors sold by Britestone to Smith became an \u201cintegral\u201d part of the printed circuit boards in the same way the vinyl film in <i>Bence Graphics</i> [see [18] <i>infra</i>] became an integral part of the decals. The fact that it was CTL and not Smith who fixed the capacitors onto the printed circuit boards should not matter in the circumstances of the case, <i>and especially so since the testimony of Smith\u2019s Mr\u00a0Prymmer that the capacitors sold by Britestone to Smith had no use other than to be installed onto printed circuit boards was not contradicted by Britestone</i>.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis in original]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In addition, the judge held that the settlement sum was reasonable and properly arrived at in the light of the legal advice provided by Hartzell and the length of the negotiations between CTL and the respondent. He observed (at [22]\u2013[23] of his grounds of decision):</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 Mr\u00a0Hartzell was clearly on top of things for when he was asked how he arrived at the conclusion that more than the settlement sum of US$300,000 would have had to be paid in damages if the parties had not reached a settlement, he testified as follows:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[D]rawing on my experience in 20 years of commercial litigation \u2026. I have seen this type of claim both inside and outside private legal practice and legal practice as general counsel of Smith &amp; Associations. In my experience, unless you settle a case where you have a claim of $400,000, you are never going to see a lower number from that claimant. I know from this case, from document[s] I reviewed and discussions with CTL, that we were talking about costs, their lost profits, any time delays, any damage to reputation they might have from their customer and so forth. We did not even know at that time whether the entire problem had been solved. They hurried to get to [<i>sic</i>] customer to fix [the] problem. As legal advisor to Smith, \u2026 I know that those damages could only have been worse.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is also pertinent to note that the negotiations between Smith and CTL lasted nine months and that CTL\u2019s own costs in purging the printed circuit boards were finally excluded, leaving only EMC\u2019s own costs to be claimed from Smith. <i>The length as well as the nature of the negotiations suggest that the settlement sum of US$300,000 was not hastily arrived at and without due consideration by Smith of the merits of CTL\u2019s case</i>.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Dissatisfied with the judge\u2019s decision, the appellant appealed to this court. Before us, the same two legal issues that were raised before the judge were once again canvassed. To reiterate, the first issue was whether the damages claimed by the respondent were too remote (\u201cthe remoteness issue\u201d), and the second issue entailed a consideration of whether the settlement reached between the respondent and CTL was reasonable and could be relied on as reflecting the actual loss suffered by the respondent (\u201cthe reasonableness issue\u201d). We now consider these issues in turn.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The remoteness issue</font></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The applicable law</font></em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The law in this area is relatively uncontroversial. The appellant\u2019s position was that the damages claimed were not within its reasonable contemplation. At the hearing before us, the appellant\u2019s counsel, Mr\u00a0Sham Chee Keat (\u201cMr\u00a0Sham\u201d), submitted that the fact that the capacitors would only be employed on printed circuit boards was not disclosed to the appellant and, hence, the damages claimed were too remote. This was, with respect, a far too simplistic approach. In view of the unchallenged evidence that the capacitors could not be used as stand-alone items but only on printed circuit boards, the rule in <i>Browne v Dunn</i> (1893) 6\u00a0R 67 <i>prima facie</i> applied. This rule stands for the well-settled proposition that (<i>per</i> Colin Tapper, <i>Cross and Tapper on Evidence</i> (Butterworths, 8th\u00a0Ed, 1995) at p\u00a0319, which was cited in <i>Arts Niche Cyber Distribution Pte Ltd v PP</i> <nobr>[1999] 4 SLR 111</nobr> at [48]; see also M\u00a0N\u00a0Howard <i>et al,</i> <i>Phipson on Evidence</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 14th\u00a0Ed, 1990) at para\u00a012-13):</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Any matter upon which it is proposed to contradict the evidence-in-chief given by the witness must normally be put to him so that he may have an opportunity of explaining the contradiction, and failure to do this may be held to imply acceptance of the evidence-in-chief ...</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">In the course of the proceedings before the assistant registrar, Mr\u00a0Sham did not take issue at all with the respondent\u2019s unequivocal evidence on this issue. In such circumstances, it was not open to the appellant to challenge on appeal, either before the judge or us, the fact that the capacitors could not be used as stand-alone items but only on printed circuit boards.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Following from his failure to convince us that the factual finding mentioned in the preceding paragraph could be challenged, Mr Sham then argued that the appellant was not aware of the respondent\u2019s intention to use the capacitors in the particular manner in which they had actually been used. In this connection, Mr\u00a0Sham attempted to distinguish the present case (wrongly, in our view) from <i>Bence Graphics International Ltd v Fasson UK Ltd</i> [1998] QB 87 (\u201c<i>Bence Graphics</i>\u201d) by arguing that in that case, the defendant knew of the plaintiff\u2019s intention to use the products in a particular manner, while, in this case, the appellant was unaware of any such intention. In <i>Bence Graphics</i>, which involved the purchase of vinyl film, the seller knew that the buyer intended to make the vinyl film into identification decalcomania (\u201cdecal\u201d) for sale to container owners, who would in turn sell containers marked with the decals to shipping lines and other users. It was a condition of the contract of sale that the film should be able to survive for use in good legible condition for at least five years, and the defendant warranted its quality. The film was defective and some decals became illegible. Otton\u00a0LJ in <i>Bence Graphics</i> approved the <i>dicta</i> of Devlin\u00a0J (as he then was) in <i>Biggin &amp; Co Ld v Permanite Ld</i> [1951] 1\u00a0KB 422 (\u201c<i>Biggin &amp; Co (HC)</i>\u201d) at 436, where Devlin\u00a0J held that \u201c[i]f \u2026 a subsale is within the contemplation of the parties, I think that the damages must be assessed by reference to it, whether the plaintiff likes it or not\u201d. For the reasons to follow (see [21]\u2013[23] below), the facts of <i>Bence Graphics</i> could not be distinguished from those in the present case. Bearing in mind the fact that the capacitors could only be used on printed circuit boards, it must surely have been within the appellant\u2019s reasonable contemplation that the capacitors would be used in such a manner by the respondent.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding this preliminary conclusion, it will be helpful to briefly summarise at this point the salient facts of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (HC)</i> ([18] <i>supra</i>), since the case will feature prominently in our later discussion on the reasonableness issue and is also of relevance to the present remoteness issue. In <i>Biggin &amp; Co (HC)</i>, the plaintiff, Biggin &amp; Co Ltd, bought defective goods from the defendant, Permanite Ltd. The plaintiff sold the goods to the Dutch government. Subsequently, the Dutch government alleged that it had suffered damage as a result of the resale. The plaintiff agreed to pay the Dutch government an amount in settlement of the claim brought by the latter against it. The plaintiff, in turn, sought to recover from the defendant the amount which it had paid the Dutch government as settlement. At first instance, Devlin\u00a0J held that the damages which the plaintiff sought to recover were not too remote. He held (at 432):</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">I do not think that the application of the principle is to be determined by the number of links in the chain. If what happened at the end was within the contemplation of the parties, I do not think it matters how long the chain is.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">He added that the contracts along the chain connecting them must be the same and found (at 432) that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[I]n claims based upon sub-sales by the Dutch government, the description of the compound and any warranties of quality must be substantially the same in all the contracts in the chain. It is not disputed that the necessary similarity exists in the contracts between the defendants and the plaintiffs, and the plaintiffs and the government respectively. \u2026 The second qualification is that claims arising after the government knew or ought to have known of the defects in the compound should be excluded. On this point I have already found the facts.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Devlin\u00a0J\u2019s decision was appealed against. Although the English Court of Appeal in <i>Biggin &amp; Co Ld v Permanite Ld</i> [1951] 2\u00a0KB 314 (\u201c<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>\u201d) ultimately reversed the decision, only one finding was in fact reversed, <i>viz</i>, Devlin\u00a0J\u2019s conclusion at 430 that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[T]he plaintiffs cannot prove their damages by reference to the settlement which they made with the Dutch government and \u2026 evidence relating to such a settlement is irrelevant and inadmissible.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">This issue relating to the permissibility of relying on a reasonable settlement will be scrutinised in further detail shortly ([25]\u2013[41] below). The English Court of Appeal more recently in <i>Bence Graphics</i> ([18] <i>supra</i>) approved Devlin\u00a0J\u2019s <i>dicta</i> in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (HC)</i> ([18] <i>supra</i>) on the remoteness of damages. The pertinent portions of the headnote of <i>Bence Graphics</i> read:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[T]hat the prima facie measure of damages for breach of warranty of quality provided by section\u00a053(3) of the Sale of Goods Act 1979 would be displaced \u2026 [if it was] in the contemplation of the parties at the time the warranty was given that the goods sold would be used in making a product which would be sold on; that in such a case the measure of damages would be based not on the difference between the value of the goods as delivered and that warranted but on the buyer's liability to the subsequent or ultimate users of the product arising from the defects constituting a breach of the seller's warranty; \u2026 <i>since the defendants had been aware that the vinyl film would be used by the plaintiffs in making decals which would be sold on to customers requiring five-year durability, the parties must be taken as having contemplated that any latent defect in the film might on becoming apparent render the plaintiffs liable to claims for damages by subsequent or ultimate users and the measure of damages should therefore be based on any such liability of the plaintiffs</i> \u2026 [emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">We agree with this common-sense approach.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Application of the law to the facts</font></em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to the facts of the present case, it is significant that this was not the first time that the parties had transacted with each other. There had been previous dealings, and it was patently the case that the appellant had knowledge of the purpose of the capacitors. Mr\u00a0Sham argued that since Tan claimed that she did not know of the purpose for which the respondent were going to use the capacitors, the appellant had no knowledge that the capacitors would be used in conjunction with printed circuit boards. In our view, this was an unmeritorious argument. <i>Benjamin\u2019s Sale of Goods</i> (A\u00a0G\u00a0Guest gen ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 7th\u00a0Ed, 2006) correctly summarises the position on imputed knowledge at para\u00a016-045 thus:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Imputed knowledge.</font></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Lord\u00a0Wright [in <i>Monarch Steamship Co Ltd v Karlshamns Oljefabriker (A/B)</i> [1949] AC\u00a0196 at 224] has said that the test for imputed knowledge is \u201cwhat reasonable business men must be taken to have contemplated as the natural and probable result if the contract was broken. As reasonable business men, each must be taken to understand the ordinary practices and exigencies of the other\u2019s trade or business.\u201d Thus, a buyer or seller of goods normally knows more about the other\u2019s business than the carrier of goods knows about the business of the consignor or the consignee, or than the seller of land knows about the intentions of the purchaser to use it in a particular way. [footnotes omitted]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is axiomatic that the law usually affixes a party such as the appellant with the knowledge that is reasonably expected of commercial men in that trade. For example, in <i>Pinnock Brothers v Lewis and Peat, Limited</i> [1923] 1\u00a0KB 690, the buyers bought East African copra cake, which they resold to sub-buyers who manufactured the cake into feeding materials for cattle. The copra cake was later found to contain an admixture which made it poisonous for cattle. The court found (at 697) that \u201cit was within the contemplation of the parties that this copra cake should used \u2026 for cattle food <i>and nothing else</i>\u201d [emphasis added]. It was held that the buyers were entitled to recover from the original seller the damages which they had to pay to the sub-buyers.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s submission that it was not aware or affixed with knowledge of the intended usage of the capacitors lacked both substance and logic. To countenance such an argument would be to disregard the obvious. For example, one cannot in good conscience say that one is buying or selling animal feed and yet claim to be oblivious to what it is used for. The same reasoning applies here. Surely, the appellant, having been in the electronics industry for many years and having had several similar sales transactions with the respondent, must have known that such capacitors are not stand-alone articles. On their own, the capacitors serve no function; they are component parts which are used in conjunction with electrical circuit boards. We accepted the respondent\u2019s submission that dealers in the electronic business would know the end-use of these capacitors, especially in this case where the parties had not just a long-standing relationship, but also extensive experience in the electronic parts industry. Therefore, we found that the damages were plainly within the appellant\u2019s reasonable contemplation and, hence, not too remote.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before we proceed to discuss the next point on whether the settlement sum was reasonable, it is apposite to reiterate that in the present case, liability was not in issue. The issue before us was not whether liability can be compromised through a settlement agreement, but, rather, whether a court should allow reliance on a reasonable settlement as satisfactorily evidencing actual loss when liability is not disputed, and, if so, how the reasonableness of the settlement is to be determined.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><strong><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The reasonableness issue</font></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\"><em>The authority of</em> Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</font></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the reasonableness issue, the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) stood as a formidably unfavourable authority against the appellant. The English Court of Appeal in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>, it will be remembered, had reversed Devlin\u00a0J\u2019s decision on just one issue (see [20] above]. It disagreed with Devlin\u00a0J that the evidence of the settlement between the plaintiff and the Dutch government was irrelevant because the making of the settlement had been a voluntary act by the plaintiff. In this regard, the English Court of Appeal held at 325:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">If, upon the evidence, the judge is satisfied that the damages would be somewhere around the figure at which the plaintiffs had settled, he would be justified in awarding the settlement figure. \u2026 The plaintiffs must establish a prima facie case that the settlement was a reasonable one. If the defendants fail to shake that case, the amount of settlement can properly be awarded as damages.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">In this connection, Mr\u00a0Sham relied on the Australian High Court decision of <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) and the Australian Court of Appeal decision of <i>White Industries Qld Pty Ltd v Hennessey Glass &amp; Aluminium Systems Pty Ltd</i> [1999] 1\u00a0Qd\u00a0R 210 to water down the standing of the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>, which had been earlier adopted by this court in <span class=\"title1\"><i>Brown Noel Trading Pte Ltd v Donald &amp; McArthy Pte Ltd</i><nobr>[1997] 1 SLR 1</nobr> (\u201c<i>Brown Noel Trading</i>\u201d)</span>.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant contended that the legal standing of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) has now been considerably diminished, and maintained that the Australian courts have recently declined to follow that decision. Mr\u00a0Sham argued that <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) had criticised <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> for its failure to consider issues of causation and remoteness, and relied, in purported support of his stance, on certain observations of McHugh\u00a0J at [31] and [34]\u2013[35]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With great respect to the Court of Appeal, the reasoning is far from clear. First, it is not clear whether their Lordships even considered issues of causation and remoteness. Perhaps their Lordships assumed that the settlement was causally connected with the breach and that it was not too remote a consequence of that breach if the settlement was reasonable. But they did not say so. Moreover, the reference to public policy in the judgment of Somervell\u00a0LJ suggests that they did not consider the case in terms of causation or remoteness.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u00a0 \u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0<em>\u00a0 In my opinion, Biggin should not be used as an authority in this country.</em> \u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u2026</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 Somervell\u00a0LJ expressed the opinion that, while the client can prove that the settlement was made as the result of legal advice, the evidence of the advisers is not ordinarily relevant or admissible. With great respect, I am unable to accept that the evidence of legal advisers is not normally relevant or admissible in such a case. On the contrary, in most cases where the settlement is made on legal advice, the evidence of the relevant legal advisers is vital.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before we discuss the actual legal issues considered and determined in <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>), it would be helpful to summarise the facts of the case. That was a case where the insured (the respondent) sued an insurance broker (the appellant) for breach of contract in relation to an insurance policy arranged by the broker, the insurer (NZI Insurance Australia Ltd (\u201cNZI\u201d)) having refused to pay on the respondent\u2019s claim. The respondent had leased premises to sell fruit and vegetables. It had appointed the appellant as its insurance broker, and the appellant had arranged an industrial special risks policy for the respondent with NZI. One of the risks covered by the policy was damage to the respondent\u2019s premises and its plant, machinery, stock and contents by fire. The appellant negligently failed to fully disclose the respondent\u2019s claims history to NZI. Subsequently, the premises and its plant, machinery, stock and contents were damaged by fire. NZI refused to pay the full amount which would have been payable under the policy but for the non-disclosure. The respondent brought proceedings against the appellant and NZI, in which NZI paid the respondent a lesser sum of A$900,000 by way of compromise in full settlement of the claim. The respondent continued with its proceedings against the appellant and sought to claim the balance from the appellant. Hayne\u00a0J made these pertinent observations in relation to <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) at [127]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">It may be doubted whether the reasons for judgment are as unequivocal as the headnote suggests. Further, there is little discussion of the underlying principles. Other than a reference by Somervell\u00a0LJ to the law encouraging reasonable settlements, the reasons of the members of the Court do not identify why the settlement should be taken as the measure of the plaintiffs\u2019 damages, and do not discuss in any detail what is meant by \u201creasonable\u201d in this context. [footnotes omitted]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Further, he stated at [135]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The Court of Appeal in <i>Biggin &amp; Co Ltd</i> held that it was relevant for the client that had compromised to give evidence that this step had been \u201cmade under advice legally taken\u201d, but Somervell\u00a0LJ went on to suggest that the advisers would not \u201cnormally\u201d be relevant as admissible witnesses. \u2026 I do not accept that the evidence of the advisers would be irrelevant or inadmissible. [footnotes omitted]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A more careful and closer reading of <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) does not, contrary to Mr\u00a0Sham\u2019s submissions, suggest that <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) has been wholly disavowed in Australia. Indeed, the headnote of <i>Unity Insurance</i> states that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[T]he insured\u2019s damages should be calculated according to the difference between what it would have recovered under the policy [which] the broker ought to have arranged and the amount [which] it recovered under the settlement, as long as the settlement was reasonable when judged objectively by reference to the circumstances at the time, including the reasoning supporting the advice upon which the insured acted in accepting it.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">This appears broadly consistent with the main holding of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> <i>apropos</i> the importance of the objective reasonableness of a settlement. We interpose here to mention that <i>Unity Insurance</i> has also recently been applied in the 2001 Supreme Court of Queensland decision of <i>C\u00a0A &amp; M\u00a0E\u00a0C Mcinally Nominees Pty Ltd v HTW Valuers (Brisbane) Pty Ltd</i> (2001) 188\u00a0ALR 439, where Chesterman\u00a0J held at [65]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">It is clear from the judgment in the High Court [in <i>Unity Insurance</i>] that an insured seeking damages from an insurer for breach of its promise to grant indemnity must prove what loss it has suffered by reason of the breach. The loss claimed by the insured must have been caused by the breach and must not be too remote from it in the sense that it must have been reasonably foreseeable and/or within the reasonable contemplation of the parties to the contract when they made it. <i>In some cases proof of such loss will be established by the insured having made a reasonable compromise, but in other cases that will not suffice for the purpose. That case itself illustrates the difficulty of determining the circumstances in which a settlement will be sufficient proof</i>. [emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Granted that <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) may have been criticised by some members of the court in <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) for its bare reasoning (and a fair criticism this may well be), this does not detract from the key holding in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> that a settlement can be relied on as against a responsible party if it is reasonable and thereby reasonably reflects actual loss. We noted the appellant\u2019s mantra that the respondent was obliged to prove all the elements of its settlement amount all over again, but that is not, in the final analysis, what the decision of the majority in <i>Unity Insurance</i> either stands for or illustrates. <i>Unity Insurance</i> broadly held that in assessing whether a settlement could be relied on to prove a claim for loss, the court had first to be satisfied that the terms of the settlement were reasonable, and that this acid test comprised an amalgam of considerations. This includes the existence of legal advice and the prospects of success if the dispute had actually been litigated based on the materials available at the time of the settlement. In this regard, the decision of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> can be said to have been generally endorsed by the majority (Brennan\u00a0CJ, McHugh and Hayne\u00a0JJ) in <i>Unity Insurance</i>. To borrow the words of Brennan\u00a0CJ in <i>Unity Insurance</i> at [6]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The plaintiff must show that the sum accepted in settlement was reasonable [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> at 321, <i>per</i> Somervell\u00a0LJ; at 326, <i>per</i> Singleton\u00a0LJ]. The test of reasonableness is, as Hayne\u00a0J says, an objective one. Evidence of the advice which the insured received to induce it to accept the settlement is not proof in itself of the reasonableness of the settlement advised. The factors which lead to the giving of the advice are factors relevant to the reasonableness of the settlement but the only relevance of advice given by the insured\u2019s legal advisers to settle is that it tends to negative the hypothesis that the insured acted unreasonably in accepting the settlement.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the Australian High Court in <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) had rightly expressed its reservations about certain aspects of the English Court of Appeal\u2019s decision in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>), in that the latter did not adequately address the principles of causation and treated the issue of remoteness as not relevant. The English Court of Appeal simply assumed the satisfaction of the requisite element of causation and the absence of remoteness. However, the majority in <i>Unity Insurance</i> did not depart from the approach articulated in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> that before a settlement could be relied on, it had to be reasonable, and a factor evidencing reasonableness was that the settlement had been made pursuant to legal advice. It is this point that is relevant to us in relation to the reasonableness issue, and we find that there is no difference in essence between the broad common-sense approach towards recognising settlements adopted in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> and that adopted in <i>Unity Insurance</i>. Singleton and Birkett\u00a0LJJ in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> were of the view that the fact that a settlement had been made under legal advice was relevant in determining its reasonableness. With regard to Somervell\u00a0LJ\u2019s comments at 321 that the evidence of advisers would not \u201cnormally be relevant\u201d, it should be noted that Somervell\u00a0LJ went on to add that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[I]f there is evidence \u2026 on which the court can come to the conclusion that this was a reasonable settlement in the circumstances, then ... it should be the measure.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">It is our view that Somervell\u00a0LJ, by the above comments, was merely emphasising the importance of the plaintiff leading evidence to prove that the settlement sum was reasonable.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In fact, this court\u2019s previous observations in <i>Brown Noel Trading</i> ([25] <i>supra</i>) buttress our view that there is no conflict between the two jurisdictions on the relevance of the reasonableness of settlements in determining whether such settlements can be treated as evidencing the actual loss suffered. In <i>Brown Noel Trading</i>, the plaintiffs and the defendants entered into a contract whereby the defendants were to sell steel reinforcing bars to the plaintiffs. The defendants contracted to purchase the same from a third party, with the third party to deliver the goods by a certain date and the defendants to open a letter of credit in favour of the third party prior to that. The defendants opened and delivered the letter of credit to the third party late. Subsequently, the third party informed the defendants that it had problems supplying the goods and offered alternative specifications which the plaintiffs refused to accept. The plaintiffs then commenced an action against the defendants claiming damages for breach of contract, and the defendants in turn commenced third party proceedings against the third party. The plaintiffs and the defendants arrived at a settlement. The third party proceedings carried on. In dealing with the third party proceedings, this court, applying the reasoning in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>), concluded (at [67]) that the settlement arrived at was reasonable and thus allowed a claim by the defendants against the third party for the settlement amount:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">In reaching the settlement the defendants were advised by their solicitors and there was nothing to suggest that their solicitors\u2019 advice was patently wrong or that there was anything suspicious. In all the circumstances, the settlement arrived at was reasonable, and the amount the defendants had paid to [the plaintiffs] should have been allowed.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Further, this court held at [70]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">In the Australian case of <i>Wong v Hutchison</i> [(1950)] 68\u00a0WN (NSW) 55 a trader who failed to deliver goods to his buyer was held liable to the buyer for damages which the latter settled with the sub-buyer. Owen\u00a0J of the Supreme Court of New South Wales held [that] the settlement reached in that case was prima facie reasonable. He said, at p\u00a058:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Apart however from these considerations, it seems to me that where a trader fails to deliver goods and thereby commits a breach of contract to which he has no apparent answer and thereafter proceeds to settle a claim for damages for that breach by making payment of an amount which, on the face of it, does not appear to be exorbitant having regard to the value of the goods which he has undertaken to deliver and the difficulties of replacing them, such a settlement should prima facie be regarded as reasonable, since as a matter of common sense it is surely the exception rather than the rule for a commercial man to settle a claim made against him by paying an extravagant or unreasonable amount because he has a remedy \u2026 against a third party who may or may not be worth and [<i>sic</i>] shot. <i>In the absence of anything to raise a suspicion to the contrary, I think it is a fair presumption that a business man who settles a business claim made against him has acted reasonably in doing so</i>.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">We do, however, have some reservations in relation to this court\u2019s earlier unqualified adoption of the suggestion (as set out in the above passage) that there is an evidential presumption that business settlements are made reasonably. In our view, the <i>fact</i> that a settlement has been effected or adopted between businessmen adds nothing to the requirement that the party seeking to rely on such a settlement must show that it is reasonable. Settlements can be made for a number of reasons, not all of which are objectively reasonable. Settlements are sometimes made to preserve business relationships regardless of the legal merits and/or reasonableness of a claim. It is noteworthy that the decision by the Supreme Court of New South Wales in <i>Wong v Hutchison</i> (1950) 68\u00a0WN (NSW) 55, which this court in <i>Brown Noel Trading</i> relied on for this proposition, pre-dates the decision in <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>). Having provided a broad overview of the applicable law and the standing authority of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>, it is perhaps now appropriate to examine the approaches taken by the other common law jurisdictions in greater detail. By undertaking such a comparative approach, we intend to distil certain common guiding principles which can then be applied in the Singapore context.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Approaches in other common law jurisdictions</font></em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The English approach</font></em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It appears that the approach in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) remains good law in England. Footnote\u00a02 to para\u00a045 of <i>Halsbury\u2019s Laws of England,</i> vol\u00a04(3) (Butterworths, 4th\u00a0Ed Reissue, 2002) reads:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">If the main contractor compromises the employer\u2019s claim arising from the sub-contractor\u2019s breach, the amount paid in settlement is admissible prima facie evidence of the amount of loss and damage caused by the sub-contractor, although liability would still need to be established: see eg [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>].</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we have mentioned (at [30] above), <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) stands, <i>inter alia</i>, for the proposition that in determining whether a settlement is reasonable such that it can be relied upon to evidence the actual loss suffered, the courts should have regard to the fact that most settlement agreements are entered into on the basis of responsible legal advice. In addition, it is not the function of the court to dissect the elements of a settlement if it comes to the conclusion that the settlement is, in the round, reasonable. The recent Queen\u2019s Bench Division (Commercial Court) case of <i>BP\u00a0plc v Aon Ltd</i>[2006] 1\u00a0All ER (Comm) 789 is illustrative of this pragmatic approach sired by <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>. In that case, <span lang=\"EN\">Aon Ltd(\u201cAon\u201d) was appointed by the Amoco group (\u201cAmoco\u201d) as its insurance broker to devise and place a global construction all risks open cover facility (\u201copen cover\u201d) to insure Amoco\u2019s offshore construction projects worldwide. In order to obtain cover in respect of any project, that project had to be expressly declared under the open cover. Amoco merged with BP\u00a0plc (\u201cBP\u201d). The open cover that was then placed by Aon was a standing offer of insurance that ran for 18\u00a0months between 1\u00a0January 1998 and 1\u00a0July 2000. As is usual with open covers in the energy sector, subject to the projects notified being embraced by the terms of the cover, the projects declared would be binding on the insurers. During the life of the open cover, the market (in which rates for open covers had previously been relatively soft) turned and BP made as many declarations of eligible projects as possible towards the end of the cover period as it could then make considerable savings on the premiums payable. As a result, there was a rush of purported declarations shortly before the expiry of the open cover. Some of the underwriters objected to the cascade of last-minute declarations. BP entered into a settlement agreement with two lead insurers who agreed to accept a number of declarations on certain terms. Although Aon (the insurance broker) persuaded some of the insurers to enter into the settlement agreement, it was unable to persuade a considerable proportion of the insurers (\u201cthe defendants\u201d) to do so. BP commenced proceedings against the defendants. These proceedings were later compromised when BP entered into a settlement agreement with the defendants. Subsequently, BP commenced proceedings against Aon based on the latter\u2019s failure to declare projects to each of the defendants within the period of the open cover. BP\u2019s claim was for the shortfall in recovery from the defendants in its earlier action against the latter as well as the costs of that action. One of the defences raised by Aon was in relation to the global settlement which BP had reached. In particular, it was argued that BP had not negotiated vigorously enough with some of the insurers and had, therefore, compromised its rights for too little.</span> In determining the question of <span class=\"documentbody1\">whether, in all the circumstances, the settlement was reasonable</span>, the court adopted the reasoning in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> and held at [282]\u2013[283]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span class=\"documentbody1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">282\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this connection, the fact that the terms of a settlement were entered into upon legal advice establishes, at least, that those terms were prima facie reasonable. It is then for the defendant to displace that inference by evidence to the contrary, by establishing, for example, that some vital matter was overlooked (see [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>] at 321 per Somervell\u00a0LJ). However, the evaluation of the reasonableness of a settlement should not involve the court in arriving at a conclusive judgment on the merits of substantial issues which were contentious in the settled litigation. The court does not need to resolve those issues unless the answer is beyond doubt. The reason for this is that it is testing the reasonableness of the settlement by reference to the perception as to success or failure which the parties would have been expected to hold at the time when the settlement was entered into and the issues remained unresolved: see generally <i>Mander v Commercial Union Assurance Co plc</i> \u2026 [1998] Lloyd's Rep IR 93 at 148\u2013149.</font></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span class=\"documentbody1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">283\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further, as Mr\u00a0Popplewell submitted on behalf of BP, it is only necessary for a claimant to establish that the settlement arrived at was at a figure within the range of what would have been reasonable. This may be quite a wide range because the views of experienced commercial lawyers and businessmen as to the particular strength of their party's case relative to the strength of the opposing party's case can differ quite widely. <i>The test is therefore whether the settlement arrived at was, in all the circumstances which the settling party knew or ought reasonably to have known at the time of the settlement, within the range of settlements which reasonable commercial men might have made. To the extent that such settlement was excessive, the settling party cannot recover. However the range would have to be defined by reference to the benefits and detriments of any settlement for all parties to it</i>.</font></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span class=\"documentbody1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We find it helpful, at this juncture, to also set out here for comparative purposes the rather similar observations made out by Hayne\u00a0J in <i>Unity Insurance</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) at [132]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">What is a reasonable compromise of the claim will almost always require consideration of the chances of the parties succeeding in their respective claims or defences and that prediction of likely outcomes must always be imperfect and imprecise. <i>To state the obvious, that is why the compromise of a claim, which is a monetary claim that will succeed entirely or fail entirely, will usually fasten upon a figure that is less than [what] would be recovered if the claim were to succeed and why it is that there will be a range of figures within which the reasonable observer may conclude that settlement of the claim would be reasonable</i>. [emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In another earlier Queen\u2019s Bench Division (Commercial Court) case, Onderlinge Verzekering Maatshcappij \u201cTegen Zeegevaar\u201d v Hogg Robinson &amp; Gardner Mountain Reinsurance Ltd (5\u00a0March 1990) (unreported), the question that the court had to decide was whether the defendants were entitled to succeed in their third party claim against the third party for damages, the main action having been earlier compromised on legal advice. Steyn\u00a0J (as he then was), in referring to Biggin &amp; Co (CA) ([20] supra), held:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The approach that has been adopted is perfectly consistent with established principles. The fact that a settlement was concluded on this basis comes as no surprise, and in dealing with the present indemnity proceedings I am entitled on the principles of [<i>Biggin v Co (CA)</i>] to have regard to the fact that that settlement agreement was entered into on the basis of responsible legal advice. I regard that sum as recoverable.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Similarly, it was stated in the Queen\u2019s Bench Division (Technology and Construction Court) case of <i>Bodycote HIP Ltd v Vanguard Engineering Ltd</i> (19\u00a0July 2000) (unreported) at [56]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">As regards the claim relating to settlement with HIP it was not disputed, save in relation to the question of costs, that the settlement was reasonable. Vanguard are entitled to rely on their settlement to determine the quantum of damages recoverable: see [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>]. As regards the relatively high figure paid in respect of HIP\u2019s costs, I find that this was part of an overall settlement package and that the figure taken overall was itself reasonable. It is not the function of the Court to dissect the elements of a settlement, having come to the conclusion that it was reasonable overall. Vanguard were, therefore, entitled to recover the whole sum paid.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) was also adopted in a 1998 Queen\u2019s Bench Division (Technology and Construction Court) decision in <i>P\u00a0&amp;\u00a0O Developments Ltd v Guy\u2019s and St Thomas\u2019 National Health Service Trust</i> (1998) 62\u00a0Con LR 38 (\u201c<i>P\u00a0&amp;\u00a0O Developments Ltd</i>\u201d), where the court held at [30]:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">A settlement between A and B, however reasonable it may be from the point of view of A and B, cannot determine C\u2019s liability to B. A submission to the contrary was firmly rejected by a strong Court of Appeal in <i>Fletcher &amp; Stewart v Peter Jay &amp; Partners</i> (1976) 17\u00a0BLR 38 (Megaw, James and Geoffrey Lane\u00a0LJJ). In that case, the Court of Appeal approved the statement of the Official Referee, Sir\u00a0William Stabb\u00a0QC:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u2018I am bound to say that I regard the decision in <i>Biggin v Permanite</i> as being concerned only with the question of whether a reasonable sum paid in settlement of a claim can be regarded as the proper measure of damages in a subsequent action, <i>where liability is not in issue</i>. <i>Where liability is in issue between a defendant and a third party, I cannot think that a defendant can impose liability on a third party by settling a plaintiff's claim against him, where the obligations of the defendant to the plaintiff are the same as those of the third party to the defendant</i>.\u2019</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">[emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">We respectfully agree with this statement of principle. A prior settlement cannot be imposed when the liability of the alleged defaulter has neither been agreed to nor determined.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The Hong Kong approach</font></em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Similarly, it appears that the approach in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) has been followed in Hong Kong: see the Supreme Court of Hong Kong\u2019s decision in <i>Hop Fat Garments Factory Limited v Siber Hegner and Company (HK) Limited</i> <nobr>[1987] HKCU 93</nobr>; <nobr>[1987] HKCFI 214</nobr> (unreported) (\u201c<i>Hop Fat Garments</i>\u201d). Also, in <i>Atico International (HK) Ltd v Sparko (Far East) Ltd</i> <nobr>[2006] HKCU 1915</nobr>; <nobr>[2006] HKCFI 1025</nobr>, the Hong Kong Court of First Instance held at [46] that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">If the plaintiff reasonably settled [the third party\u2019s] claim out of court, it may recover as damages from the defendant a reasonable amount paid under the settlement (para\u00a017-078 <i>Benjamin\u2019s Sale of Goods</i>; [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>]).</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The Canadian approach</font></em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The approach established in <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>) has also been adopted in Canada as well. The British Columbia Supreme Court in <i>Matsumoto Shipyards Limited v Forward Machine Shop Ltd</i> (1984) 25\u00a0ACWS (2d) 114; <nobr>[1984] BCWLD 981</nobr> observed at [50] that \u201cwhen a settlement of differences is reached under legal advice, it is prima facie taken to be reasonable: [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>]\u201d. In addition, the British Columbia Supreme Court in <i>Westcoast Transmission Company Limited v Cullen Detroit Diesel Allison Ltd</i> (1986) 39\u00a0ACWS (2d) 267 (\u201c<i>Westcoast Transmission</i>\u201d) (the appeal against which decision was dismissed by the British Columbia Court of Appeal in <i>Westcoast Transmission Co Ltd v Cullen Detroit Diesel Allison Ltd</i> (1990) 70\u00a0DLR (4th) 503; 45 BCLR (2d) 296; 48\u00a0BLR 17) quoted <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> at [115] as \u201cthe leading case\u201d and did not expressly disapprove of the decision of <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> which it summarised as follows:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The Court of Appeal acknowledged that proof of all the facts in a ... complex case might be long and costly (as here) but without proving every detail if the whole of the evidence showed to the judge that the sum paid was a reasonable one and was \u201cin the neighbourhood\u201d of what would likely have been awarded as damages, then the settlement itself was the proper sum.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The British Columbia Supreme Court in <i>Westcoast Transmission</i> further held at [119] that \u201c[t]here is no room on our facts for the applications of the [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>] rule\u201d as it found that there was no liability owed.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The British Columbia Supreme Court in <i>Rivtow Straits Limited v B\u00a0C\u00a0Marine Shipbuilders Limited</i> <nobr>[1978] 2 ACWS 370</nobr> cited at [77] Harvey McGregor, <i>McGregor on Damages</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 13th\u00a0Ed, 1972), which in turn cited <i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i> ([20] <i>supra</i>), and agreed at [79] that \u201cthe onus rests upon Rivtow to show that its defence was a reasonable one, and the issue is one of fact to be decided by this court\u201d. It further held at [82] that:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">The circumstances here were very similar to those which existed in the case of <i>Fisher v. Val de Travers</i> [(1875-76) LR\u00a01 CPD 511] as reported in [<span class=\"term1\"><i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>]</span> As Mr.\u00a0Justice Somerville reports it in the <i>Biggin</i> case,</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">\u201cOn receiving notice of H.'s claim the tramway company gave notice to the plaintiffs to meet it, and the plaintiffs handed on the notice to the defendants. The defendants refused to meet the claim, and the plaintiffs were compelled to undertake the case themselves, and forthwith entered into negotiations with H., which eventually resulted in a compromise of the claim for a certain sum paid to H. by way of compensation, with costs of settlement. In an action by the plaintiffs ... against the defendants to recover promise [<i>sic</i>] to H. and the costs the sum paid by way of com [<i>sic</i>], incidental thereto, the jury found that the compromise was reasonable and that the costs were reasonably incurred.\u201d</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear from our examination of the various jurisdictions above that the courts deem it permissible to refer to the amount reached in settlement between two downstream parties in deciding the amount to be awarded to one of these downstream parties in a claim against an upstream defendant. The broad principle at play is that the claimant must prove its actual loss and, to this extent, the courts adopt the pragmatic approach that if the settlement is reasonably reached and reasonable in nature, the amount agreed therein will be regarded as accurately reflecting the actual loss suffered by the downstream claimant. Indeed, the criterion of \u201creasonableness\u201d permeates the judicial inquiry as to whether a settlement agreement can be relied upon against an upstream defendant as accurately reflecting the actual losses suffered by a downstream claimant, and the predominant factor taken into account by the courts in assessing reasonableness appears to be whether legal advice was undertaken. As the present case involves the recovery of a prior settlement made with a third party, we think that it would be helpful to clarify the circumstances in which the courts ought to acknowledge such settlements, namely, when liability is not or is no longer an issue between the parties before the court. To recapitulate, liability was not an issue before us (see [24] above).</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Relevant considerations to be taken into account in assessing the reasonableness of settlements</font></em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-3\"><em><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">General overview</font></em></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In relation to the relevant considerations to be taken into account in ascertaining the reasonableness of settlements, Lord\u00a0Eassie in <i>E\u00a0&amp;\u00a0J Glasgow Limited v UGC Estates Limited</i> <nobr>[2005] CSOH 63</nobr> (\u201c<i>E\u00a0&amp;\u00a0J Glasgow Limited</i>\u201d) made the following incisive observations (at [55]) which we found helpful:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">In my view, there are plainly a variety of methods whereby a settlement of a third party claim may come about, these ranging through <i>a spectrum extending from a direct negotiation or discussion between principals in meetings of greater or less formality to negotiation through lawyers or other agents to ultimate judicial determination at final appellate level</i>. Mr\u00a0Cormack, for the defenders, whose submissions were unreservedly adopted by Mr\u00a0Connal, recognised arbitration as one such method within the spectrum. In the event of litigation, judicial reference to a \u201cman of skill\u201d ie an expert, might be appropriate. There is, of course, increasing recognition of the role of alternative dispute resolution procedures in the settlement of commercial affairs. Accordingly I do not consider that \u2013 at least at this stage \u2013 I can accept the proposition that it was not <i>foreseeable that in advance of the raising of this litigation the pursuers and Kier might confide the settlement of the claims arising between them to a binding expert determination</i>. [emphasis added]</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also find it useful to set out Judge\u00a0Peter Bowsher\u00a0QC\u2019s observations in <i>P\u00a0&amp;\u00a0O Developments Ltd</i> ([37] <i>supra</i>) at [38] on when an agreement made with a person who is not a party to the action may be relevant and admissible:</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font face1=\"Times New Roman, Times\">Why is an agreement made with a person [who is] not a party to the action relevant or admissible at all? [<i>Biggin &amp; Co (CA)</i>] provides two answers to that question. (a) A rule of evidence. The Court of Appeal in that case stressed that it is the policy of the court to encourage settlements.
