xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#216\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Judith Prakash J</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Aqbal Singh (Unilegal LLC) for the Appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Philip Fong, Josephine Choo (Harry Elias Partnership) for the Respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2653\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Limitation of Actions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Acknowledgment of debt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Inclusion of disputed sum in estate duty affidavit</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether creditor entitled to rely on letter as acknowledgement</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed) s 27</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2653\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Limitation of Actions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Acknowledgment of debt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Debtor referred to sum as an 'alleged' debt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether there was acknowledgement</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed) s 27</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2653\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Limitation of Actions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Acknowledgment of debt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether claim may be acknowledged after it is time-barred</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Effect of acknowledgment of time-barred claim</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed) ss 26(2), 28(5)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Words and Phrases</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">'Acknowledgment'</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed) ss 26, 27</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Words and Phrases</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">'Made to'</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Limitation Act (Cap 163, 1996 Rev Ed) s 27(2)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Decision\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">\n        <em>\n          <strong>Delivered by Chao Hick Tin JA</strong>\n        </em>\n      </span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">1 This appeal raises the question whether the present action instituted by the plaintiff-appellant against the defendant-respondent for the recovery of a sum of $7,164,304.64 has become time-barred. This question in turn rests upon the question whether two documents emanating from the respondent constitute \"acknowledgment\u2019 within the meaning of s 27 of the Limitation Act (the Act).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>The background</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">2 The appellant, Chuan &amp; Company Pte Ltd (Chuan), is a family company, now under voluntary liquidation. It was formed by one Ong Toh. Before its incorporation, it was run by him as a sole proprietorship for some twenty years.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">3 Ong Toh passed away on 30 March 1995 and the respondent, Ong Soon Huat, a nephew of his, is the executor of his estate.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">4 During his lifetime, Ong Toh dealt with the assets of Chuan as if they were his own. Even after he had on 26 November 1990 transferred all his shares in Chuan to his two daughters (Ms Ong Kim Hong and Ms Ong Thian Hong) by his third wife, and had ceased to be a director, he continued to treat the property of Chuan in any way he pleased. He simply withdrew money from Chuan.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">5 From 1987, Ong Toh would acknowledge the moneys taken by him from Chuan by signing on the yearly confirmation of debts statements sent to him by the company auditors, Chan Hock Seng &amp; Company. The last statement of debts was signed by him on 10 March 1994, where he acknowledged owing Chuan the sum of $7,164,304.64. This is the sum which the liquidator of Chuan is seeking to claim back from the estate of Ong Toh in this action.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">6 On 9 December 1995, the executor filed an estate duty affidavit with the Estate Duty Department (EDD) in which the said sum was included as a debt owed by the estate to Chuan.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">7 On 17 January 2001, pursuant to a request of EDD, the executor\u2019s solicitors wrote to Chuan\u2019s auditors asking for copies of documents relating to the alleged debt. The relevant parts of the letter read:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">2. We recently took over conduct of the matter \u2026 and we would be grateful if you could assist us with queries from the Commissioner of Estate Duties.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">3. First, the Commissioner has asked for documents in support of:-</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">....</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">....</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">(ii) Chuan &amp; Co Pte Ltd\u2019s allegation that a debt of $7,164,304.64 was owing by the deceased to the company as at 30 March 1995.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">4. Without such documents, the Commissioner will refuse to make a deduction for the alleged debts. In the circumstances, please let us have copies of all the documents substantiating the alleged debts\u2026</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1-FirstPara\" align=\"justify\">The documents requested in the letter were duly furnished by Chuan.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>Decision below</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">8 At the request of the parties, the court below decided, before commencing trial, to determine the question as to whether the claim by Chuan had become time-barred as a preliminary question. The judge ruled that the claim was barred by limitation on 10 March 2000, six years from the date Ong Toh signed the last statement of debts. She held that neither the estate duty affidavit nor the letter of 17 January 2001 constituted an acknowledgement of a debt within the meaning of s 27 of the Limitation Act.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>The statutory provisions</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">9 Section 6(1)(a) of the Limitation Act provides that an action founded on a contract or on tort \"shall not be brought after the expiration of six years from the date on which the cause of action accrued.\" However, s 26(2) provides that where the person liable for any debt \"acknowledges the claim or makes any payment in respect thereof\" the right of action to recover the debt shall be deemed to have accrued on the date of the acknowledgement.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">10 What would constitute an acknowledgement is prescribed in s 27, and as this question is central to the issue before us, we shall set out the provisions in full:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">27(1) Every such acknowledgment as is referred to in section 26 shall be in writing and signed by the person making the acknowledgment.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">(2) Any such acknowledgment or payment as is referred to in section 26 may be made by the agent of the person by whom it is required to be made under that section, and shall be made to the person, or to an agent of the person, whose title or claim is being acknowledged or, as the case may be, in respect of whose claim the payment is being made.</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>Estate duty affidavit</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">11 We shall first examine the estate duty affidavit. In the schedule to the affidavit filed by Ong Soon Huat, the sum of $7,164,304.64 was listed as a debt owing by Ong Toh to Chuan. What needs to be determined is whether the affidavit can be considered to be an acknowledgment of the debt \"made to (Chuan) or to an agent of (Chuan)\" within the meaning of s 27(2).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">12 Chuan accepts that to constitute an \"acknowledgment\" there must be a clear admission of liability. Relying upon <i>Bank of America National Trust Savings Association v Cheong Hoon Choy</i> <nobr>[1982] SLR 60</nobr><i>,</i> Chuan argues that it does not matter that the affidavit was not, according to its terms, expressly or impliedly, addressed to Chuan, so long as it was \"delivered to the creditor or his agent by or with the authority of the debtor or his agent.\" The fact that the acknowledgment was addressed to a third party, the Commissioner of Estate Duties, instead of Chuan, is not necessarily an impediment to it being an effective acknowledgment.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">13 In <i>Bank of America National Trust Savings Association v Cheong Hoon Choy</i>, the defendant executed a charge over a property owned by him and another person, who had become a bankrupt, to secure overdraft and other facilities granted to that other person. In May 1973, the Official Assignee at Kuala Lumpur paid, on behalf of the defendant and the bankrupt, the sum of M$140,000 to the plaintiffs on the understanding that the charge executed by the defendant would be released. Later the plaintiff claimed the balance sum of M$70,454.43 from the defendant. One of the defences raised was that the claim was time-barred. In response, the plaintiff averred that there was an acknowledgement of the debt by the defendant in April 1973 when the defendant\u2019s solicitors wrote to the Official Assignee. The relevant part of the letter read:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">The aforesaid land is charged in favour of Bank of America \u2026 and the amount outstanding to-date is $206,029.69. We understand that you are in the process of selling the said bankrupt\u2019s half share in the said land for redemption of the said charge.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">Kindly withhold further action in the proposed sale as our client is able to obtain a better offer \u2026</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1-FirstPara\" align=\"justify\">It is significant to note that this letter was specifically copied to and was received by the plaintiff\u2019s solicitors in Kuala Lumpur.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">14 There, it was contended that the letter did not amount to an acknowledgement under s 27(2) because it was not addressed to the plaintiff or its agent, and the Official Assignee was not an agent of the Bank. However, as the letter had expressly acknowledged the debt, and a copy of the letter was sent to the plaintiff\u2019s solicitors, the court held that the letter would constitute a sufficient acknowledgement for the purpose of s 27(2).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">15 In coming to its decision, the court there had relied on the English case of <i>Re Compania de Electricidad de la Provincia De Buenos Aires Ltd</i> <nobr>[1980] CH 146</nobr> where Slade J, after noting that there did not appear to be any authority on the meaning of the expression \"made to the person, or to an agent of the person, whose title or claim is being acknowledged\", enunciated the following proposition (at 193):-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">.. a written acknowledgment cannot be said to be \"made to\" a creditor or his agent, within the meaning of section 24(2) unless either (a) it is delivered to the creditor or his agent by or with the authority of the debtor or his agent or (b) it is expressly or implicitly addressed to and is actually received by the creditor or his agent.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">In my judgment, in case (a) it would not matter that the acknowledgment was not, according to its terms, expressly or implicitly addressed to the recipient. In case (b) it would not matter that the acknowledgment reached the hands of the creditor otherwise than by or with the authority of the debtor. In either case, however, it would be necessary that the creditor should actually receive the acknowledgment before he could rely on it.</font></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">A company\u2019s balance sheet must in my judgment be regarded as implicitly addressed to (among other persons) those creditors whose debts are referred to in it. It follows that in my judgment, as Miss Arden submitted, and, as I understood him, Mr Sykes did not contend to the contrary, an effective \"acknowledgment\" of a debt must be said to have been \"made\" by the company to any creditor who can establish by appropriate evidence that (i) he has actually received, from whatever source, a copy of a balance sheet of the company, signed by directors of the company and referring to \"sundry creditors\"; (ii) he is one of the \"sundry creditors\" so referred to. In such circumstances the balance sheet of the company would constitute an effective acknowledgment of the relevant debt, not as at the date on which it was actually signed by the directors or received by the creditor, but as at the date of the balance sheet, being the date to which the signature of the directors related; and the cause of action would be deemed to have accrued at that date:\u2026</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">16 However, the fact situation in the present case is not the same as that in <i>Cheong Hoon Choy</i>, where the letter in question was copied to the creditor\u2019s solicitors and was in fact received. Here, the estate duty affidavit was not \"made to\" Chuan or its solicitors. It was addressed to the Commissioner of Estate Duties. It was never received by Chuan or its solicitors. The executor even refused to give a copy of it to Chuan\u2019s solicitors when requested. Chuan only secured a copy by virtue of an order of court obtained in the present action. Such a delivery, by compulsion of an order of court, can hardly suffice to constitute an acknowledgment. It would be noted from the dicta of Slade J, that to constitute an acknowledgment, there must be some intention to convey the contents of the document to the creditor or his agents. Under the first category of delivery enunciated by Slade J, the delivery to the creditor is deliberate. Under the second category, it is implied. Chuan can hardly claim to have relied on a document which it had never seen before the commencement of the action.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">17 Moreover, in <i>Bowring-Hanbury\u2019s Estate v Bowring Hanbury</i> [1943] 1 All ER 48, Bennett J held that the admission of a debt contained in an affidavit relating to the estate of a deceased person sworn for probate purposes could not constitute a sufficient acknowledgment since it was made to the probate court and not to the creditor.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">18 We accept the argument of Chuan that if an affidavit, though by its terms not addressed to the creditor, is nevertheless sent by the debtor to the creditor, that could amount to an effective acknowledgment of the debt. This would fall within the first category of delivery enunciated by Slade J. It seems clear to us that the concept of \"acknowledgment\" within the meaning of the Limitation Act envisages a voluntary desire to admit a debt. Otherwise, it would mean that a letter written to a complete third party, admitting to a debt to the creditor, would amount to an acknowledgement of the debt to the creditor if the latter should somehow come into possession of it. An acknowledgement to make time run afresh in respect of a claim, or to revive a time-barred claim, cannot be obtained by way of a sidewind.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">19 Thus, it is our opinion that the first ground raised by Chuan to defeat the defence of time-bar must fail.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>Letter of 17 January 2001</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">20 We now turn to examine the second document, i.e., letter of 17 January 2001. We have in \u00b67 above set out the pertinent parts of the letter which Chuan asserts contained an acknowledgment of the debt. As this document was addressed to Chuan\u2019s auditors, Chan Hock Seng &amp; Co, it is just as good as being made to Chuan. What is left to be considered is whether there was an acknowledgment of the debt in the letter.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">21 Counsel for Chuan argued that the court below had taken too narrow a view of the document when it held that the letter did not contain an acknowledgment of the debt and that it only contained an allegation by Chuan that Ong Toh owed Chuan the sum of $7,164,304.64. He further argued that the letter should be read together with the estate duty affidavit; the context is all important. It would be fair to assume that the Commissioner of Estate Duty had asked for documentary proof of the debt because the respondent, the executor of the estate of Ong Toh, must have stated in the affidavit that the estate owed Chuan the said sum. Counsel also contended that the words \"Chuan &amp; Co Pte Ltd\u2019s allegation\" appearing in the letter should be construed as referring to the Commissioner\u2019s query on the respondent\u2019s admission of debt to Chuan set out in the affidavit.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><i>22 Good v Parry</i>\u00a0[1963] 2 All ER 59 is a case where the English Court of Appeal had the opportunity to consider s 23(4) of the <i>English Limitation Act 1939</i> [which is in <i>pari materia</i> with our s 27(2)] and where it held that, unlike the previous law, for a document to constitute an acknowledgment, there need not be an express or implied promise to pay. But there must, nevertheless, be a clear acknowledgment of a debt or other liquidated damage, although the specific sum was not stated. In the latter event, reference could be made to extrinsic evidence to ascertain the amount. Lord Denning MR explained that (at 61):-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">\u2026 the debt must be quantified in figures or, at all events, it must be liquidated in this sense that it is capable of ascertainment by calculation, or by extrinsic evidence, without further agreement of the parties.</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">23 In <i>Good v Parry</i> the court held that the sentence, \"The question of outstanding rent can be settled as a separate agreement as soon as you present your account\" did not acknowledge any debt as due. It merely acknowledged that there might be a claim.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">24 In contrast, in <i>Dungate v Dungate</i> [1965] 3 All ER 818, a certain G, took several loans from his brother, the plaintiff. On 23 February 1962, G wrote a letter to the plaintiff containing the sentence, \"Keep a check on totals and amounts I owe you and we will have account now and then.\" The English Court of Appeal held that this letter was a clear acknowledgment of a debt due to the plaintiff. In Diplock LJ\u2019s view, the letter in question \"made it quite plain that there were amounts owing and outstanding.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">25 A third case, <i>Kamouh v Associated Electrical Industries International Ltd &amp; Anor</i> <nobr>[1979] 2 WLR 795</nobr>, is also highly illustrative. There, the plaintiff\u2019s brother had in April 1967 procured a contract for the defendants and had incurred expenses in connection therewith. The next month, May 1967, the first defendants in a letter to the brother stated that they recognised that he was in effect out of pocket to the extent of \u00a3100,000 for those activities. In reply to a letter from him, the defendants wrote in March 1970 to deny that there was any agreement to pay him remuneration and added:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">Turning now to your out-of-pocket expenses, you will appreciate that you have had substantial payments on account although I understand that so far no detail or corroborative evidence has been produced by you. You will appreciate that it is quite impossible for this company to make any further payment to you in respect of your disbursements without a detailed account supported by appropriate and acceptable evidence of payment. If you will provide the required information it will have early consideration.</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">26 We should mention that the plaintiff in <i>Kamouh</i> commenced the action in a representative capacity. Parker J held that the above paragraph could not amount to an acknowledgment. All it meant was \"we do not admit that you were entitled to even that which you have already been paid. Before you can have anything more, you will have to show that that and more was due.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">27 The plaintiff there sought to argue that this letter of March 1970 should be read together with the letter of May 1967. While Parker J accepted that the letter in question should properly be read in its context, and, for that purpose, reference could be made to the earlier letters, including that of May 1967, he nevertheless held that the letter of March 1970 could not be viewed to be an acknowledgment, as it did not admit that any sum was due to the plaintiff\u2019s brother as expenses. It was no more than an acknowledgment that there might be something owing.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">28 It is of interest to note that in <i>Agricultural</i> <i>Mortgage Corporation v Williams &amp; Ors</i>, a decision of the English Court of Appeal of 15 May 1995, the court affirmed the principle that in determining whether a letter constituted an acknowledgment earlier correspondence could be looked into. In that case the defendants argued that if the earlier correspondence was taken into account, it would be seen that there was no intention to acknowledge the title of the plaintiffs as mortgagees. However, the court held that the expression \"they are amply secured\" in the letter in question clearly suggested that the plaintiffs were secured as mortgagees under the mortgage.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">29 In our view, the rules governing the construction of a document to determine whether it constitutes an acknowledgment should be no different from those applicable to the construction of other documents. Their ultimate object is to determine the intention of the maker in the light of the words he has used. Where the words in a document are clear, it is not permissible to refer to extrinsic material and give them a meaning which is at variance with the express words. It is only where the words used in a document are ambiguous that extrinsic material may be referred to to assist in determining the intended meaning. But where, as in <i>Agricultural Mortgage Corporation</i> and <i>Dungate v Dungate</i>, and particularly in the present case, the express words are clear, the court should not rewrite the document into something it is not. Here, the letter in question referred to Chuan\u2019s \"allegation\" of a debt and asked Chuan for documents \"substantiating the alleged debts\". We are unable to read this letter as amounting to an acknowledgment of a debt. To do so would do violence to the plain words of the document.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>Existing debt</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">30 Before we conclude we would like to refer to a statement made by the judge below which requires clarification. It reads:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">The law requires there to be \u2018an unequivocal admission of a subsisting debt, that is subsisting at the time of the acknowledgment\u2019 (per Lord Evershed at p. 482 of <i>Consolidated Agencies Ltd v Bertram Ltd</i> <nobr>[1956] AC 470</nobr> quoted with approval by the Malaysian Federal Court in <i>Wee Tiang Teng v Ong Chong Hooi</i> <nobr>[1978] 2 MLJ 54</nobr> at 56). It is noteworthy that as at 17 January 2001, the debt was already time-barred, it no longer subsisted.</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">31 It seems to us that the judge thought that where limitation has set in, a debt could not be revived by a subsequent acknowledgment. In coming to that view the judge relied upon the Malaysian Federal Court case of <i>Wee Tiang Teng v Ong Chong Hooi &amp; Anor</i> <nobr>[1978] 2 MLJ 54</nobr> which in turn relied upon the Privy Council decision in <i>Consolidated Agencies Ltd v Bertram Ltd</i> <nobr>[1956] AC 470</nobr>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">32 What seems to have been overlooked is that the applicable statutory provision (s 19 of the Indian Limitation Act) in the <i>Bertram</i> case is quite different from s 26(2) of our Act. There, the provision read:-</p>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font size=\"4\"><em>Where, before the expiration of the period prescribed for a suit or application in respect of any property or right</em>, an acknowledgment of liability in respect of such property or right has been made in writing signed by the party against whom such property or right is claimed, or by some person through whom he derives title or liability, a fresh period of limitation shall be computed from the time when the acknowledgment was so signed. [Emphasis added].</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">33 Our section 26(2) reads:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" align=\"justify\"><font size=\"4\">Where any right of action has accrued to recover any debt or other liquidated pecuniary claim, or any claim to the personal estate of a deceased person or to any share or interest therein, and the person liable or accountable therefor acknowledges the claim or makes any payment in respect thereof, the right shall be deemed to have accrued on and not before the date of the acknowledgment or the last payment.</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">34 While the Malaysian limitation provision was very similar to ours, the fact of the matter was that in <i>Wee Tiang Teng v Ong Chong Hooi</i> the acknowledgment in question was given before the limitation period had expired. So there the question whether a time-barred claim could be revived by subsequent acknowledgment did not arise for consideration.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">35 Moreover, the position in Singapore on this point is made all the clearer by s 28(5) of the Act, which reads:-</p>\n\n<blockquote dir=\"ltr\" style=\"MARGIN-RIGHT: 0px\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><font size=\"4\"><em>An acknowledgment made after the expiration of the period of limitation</em>\u00a0prescribed for the bringing of an action to recover the debt or other claim shall not bind any successor on whom the liability devolves on the determination of a preceding estate or interest in property under a settlement taking effect before the date of the acknowledgment. [Emphasis added].</font></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1-FirstPara\" align=\"justify\">There is also a corresponding provision in s 28(7) where part payment of the debt is made after the expiry of the limitation period.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">36 Under our statutory scheme, where the limitation period has expired, what it means is that the debt is irrecoverable. If the debtor is sued, he may plead the defence of limitation. However, this defence must be expressly pleaded: see s 4 of the Act, O 18 r 18(1) of the Rules of Court and the House of Lords\u2019 decision in <i>Ketteman v Hansel Properties</i> <nobr>[1987] AC 189</nobr> at 219. Thus, a judgment may be entered on such a claim unless the debtor raises the limitation defence. A judgment may also be entered if there is a subsequent acknowledgment of the debt. Therefore, our scheme of things does not render a debt which is time-barred non-existent; it only renders the debt irrecoverable if limitation is pleaded.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><b>Judgment</b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">37 Notwithstanding the erroneous view of the judge below on the abovementioned point, the present appeal must still be dismissed as neither the estate duty affidavit nor the letter of 17 January 2001 is an acknowledgment within the meaning of s 27(1) and (2) of the Act. The respondent shall have the costs of this appeal. The security for costs, together with any accrued interest, shall be released to the respondent\u2019s solicitors to account of costs.</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1345\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Courts and Jurisdiction</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">s 36(1) Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322, 1999 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Words and Phrases</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">'At the trial'</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">s 34(2)(a) Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322, 1999 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <p align=\"justify\">On 30 Nov 2001, Lai Siu Chiu J delivered her judgment. Tan Chiang\n\n  informed PPH on 26 Dec 2001 of their intention to appeal, and on 31 Dec 2001 they filed\n\n  their notice of appeal against part of the judgment. However, the notice was not served on\n\n  PPH until 11 Jan 2002. Subsequently, on 25 Jan 2002, PPH notified Tan Chiang that the\n\n  notice of appeal was not validly filed and asked them to rectify the same. As Tan Chiang\n\n  disagreed, PPH filed Motion No. 3 of 2002/D on 2 Feb 2002 to set aside the notice of\n\n  appeal on two broad grounds: first, that leave to appeal should have been obtained as\n\n  required under s 34(2)(a) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap.\n\n  322)(\u2018SCJA\u2019); and second, that the notice of appeal was not served on PPH within\n\n  the period of one month from the date of the judgment as prescribed under O 57 r 4 of the\n\n  Rules of Court. </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Rajendran J, who heard Motion No. 3/2002/D on 15 Feb 2002 as a single\n\n  judge of the Court of Appeal pursuant to s 36(1) SCJA, was inclined to grant an extension\n\n  of time to serve the notice of appeal on PPH. Nevertheless, he struck out the notice filed\n\n  on 31 Dec 2001 on the ground that it was necessary for Tan Chiang to have first obtained\n\n  leave of court before any notice of appeal could be filed. He ruled that such leave was\n\n  required under s 34(2)(a) SCJA because the value of the subject matter was less than\n\n  $250,000. Although it was not in dispute that the amount of Tan Chiang\u2019s claim at the\n\n  trial well exceeded $250,000, the contention was that they had only appealed against,\n\n  firstly, a part of the claim in which they had not succeeded, and secondly, PPH\u2019s\n\n  counterclaim awarded against Tan Chiang, and the total of these two items did not exceed\n\n  $250,000.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Tan Chiang filed the present Motion No. 8 of 2002/A to ask the Court of\n\n  Appeal to review and set aside the ruling made by Rajendran J on Motion No. 3/2002/D. The\n\n  substantive issue concerned the interpretation of s 34(2)(a) SCJA.<b/></p>\n\n  \n\n\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Held, </p></b>allowing the application:\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p>(1) A single judge did not have the jurisdiction under s 36(1) SCJA to set aside a\n\n  notice of appeal and correspondingly to strike out an appeal. The orders that could be\n\n  made under s36(1)(i) and (ii) were premised on the existence of an appeal and the need for\n\n  certain interim orders or directions to safeguard the interest of the parties pending\n\n  disposal of the appeal. An application to strike out an appeal could not be considered to\n\n  be an order of that interlocutory nature (see  9).</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(2) Whichever way the jurisdictional issue was determined, the Court of\n\n  Appeal was properly seized of the matter \u2013 if the single judge had no such\n\n  jurisdiction under s 36(1), then the Court of Appeal could deal with the issues in N/M No.\n\n  8/2002/A as if the order made in N/M No. 3/2002/D was never made; if the single judge had\n\n  such jurisdiction, then by virtue of s 36(3) SCJA, this Court had the power to review the\n\n  order made as an application for review is not an appeal (see  10 and 11); Boyd v\n\n  Bishoffsheim [1895] 1 Ch 1 followed.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) The words \"at trial\" in s 34(2)(a) SCJA should not be\n\n  read to mean \"at the appeal\". To do so would do violence to the ordinary meaning\n\n  of that word and would be wholly unwarranted. Since the quantum of Tan Chiang\u2019s claim\n\n  at trial was well in excess of S$250,000, there was no need to obtain leave of court to\n\n  file the present appeal, namely Civil Appeal No. 600133 of 2001 (see  20 to 23 and 25);\n\n  Chan Kee Beng v Ramasamy Naidu [1939] MLJ 92, Yai Yen Hon v Teng Ah Kok &amp; Sim Huat Sdn\n\n  Bhd &amp; Anot <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=42886&amp;freetext=\">[1997] 1 MLJ 136</a>, Dreesman v Harris (1854) 9 Exch 485 followed.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(4) It could be different if bad faith could be shown in the\n\n  formulation of the claim (see  24); Mason v Burningham [1949] 2 KB 545, Mayer v Burgess\n\n  (1855) 4 E&amp;B 655 followed; There was no suggestion here that this was not a bona fide\n\n  claim. Furthermore, a party who unreasonably inflates his claim may be penalised when the\n\n  question of costs arises for consideration. </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(5) PPH\u2019s argument, that although s 34(2)(a) SCJA spoke of the\n\n  value of the subject matter at trial, it was also intended to refer to the amount of the\n\n  subject matter on appeal, could have arisen from a misunderstanding of the decision of the\n\n  Court of Appeal in Spandeck Engineering (S) Pte Ltd v Yong Qiang Construction [1999] 4 SLR   401. All that the court decided was that the word \u2018trial\u2019 should not be read to\n\n  mean only a \"hearing in open court with the calling of witnesses\". There could\n\n  be a \u2018trial\u2019 when the \u2018hearing\u2019 was based purely on affidavits.\n\n  Nothing in Spandeck Engineering suggested that the words \"at the trial\" in s\n\n  34(2)(a) SCJA should be read to mean \"at the appeal\". To that extent, the views\n\n  expressed by the High Court in Twin Enterprises Pte Ltd v Peter Lim Heng Wah (S1712/94)\n\n  would be overruled (see  15 and 20).</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(6) The factors which a court should take into account in exercising\n\n  its discretion whether or not to extend time to enable a party to file a notice of appeal\n\n  out of time are: (i.) the length of the delay; (ii.) the reason of the delay; (iii.) the\n\n  chances of the appeal succeeding if the application is granted; and (iv.) the degree of\n\n  prejudice to the would-be respondent if the application is granted (see  27); Pearson v\n\n  Chen Chien Wen Edwin [1991] SLR 212, Nomura Regionalisation Venture Fund Ltd v Ethical\n\n  Investments Ltd <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=59541&amp;freetext=\">[2000] 4 SLR 46</a> followed.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(7) In the circumstances of the case, an extension of time for service\n\n  ought to have been given. First, the Electronic Filing System of the Supreme Court was\n\n  only recently extended to include documents filed in Civil Appeals to the Court of Appeal.\n\n  Second, Tan Chiang initiated the process to file the notice of appeal on 28 Dec 2001 but\n\n  due to certain technicalities only managed to file the notice on 31 Dec 2001. Third,\n\n  certain situations arose which had a bearing on the oversight. Fourth, and most\n\n  importantly, PPH were notified on 26 Dec 2001 that Tan Chiang were filing a notice of\n\n  appeal. In view of this and the fact that the delay was only some nine days, there could\n\n  be no question of any prejudice (see 28 to 30). </p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Case(s) referred to</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"/></b>Twin Enterprises Pte Ltd v Peter Lim Heng Wah (Unreported) S\n\n1712/94 \u2013 delivered on 29 Nov 2000 (overd)<br/>\n\nSpandeck Engineering (S) Pte Ltd v Yong Qiang Construction <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=49525&amp;freetext=\">[1999] 4 SLR 401</a> (refd)<br/>\n\nChan Kee Beng v Ramasamy Naidu [1939] MLJ 92 (folld)<br/>\n\nYai Yen Hon v Teng Ah Kok &amp; Sim Huat Sdn Bhd &amp; Anot <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=42886&amp;freetext=\">[1997] 1 MLJ 136</a> (folld)<br/>\n\nDreesman v Harris (1854) 9 Exch 485 (folld)<br/>\n\nMason v Burningham [1949] 2 KB 545 (folld)<br/>\n\nMayer v Burgess (1855) 4 E&amp;B 655 (folld)<br/>\n\nPearson v Chen Chien Wen Edwin [1991] SLR 212 (folld)<br/>\n\nNomura Regionalisation Venture Fund Ltd v Ethical Investments Ltd <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=59541&amp;freetext=\">[2000] 4 SLR 46</a> (folld)\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Legislation referred to</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"/></b>Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322, 1999 Rev. Ed.), ss\n\n34(2)(a), 36(1), 36(3) <br/>\n\nRules of Court, O 57 r 4<b>\n\n</b>\n\n<p align=\"left\"><font color=\"#000080\" size=\"4\"><strong>Judgment</strong></font></p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font color=\"#800000\"><strong><u>GROUNDS OF DECISION</u></strong></font></p>\n\n<font size=\"4\">\n\n<p/></font>1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This motion (No 8/2002A), filed by the appellants, Tan\n\nChiang Brother\u2019s Marble (S) Pte Ltd (Tan Chiang), was essentially to ask this Court\n\nto review and set aside a ruling made by Rajendran J, in exercise of the power of a single\n\nJudge of the Court of Appeal under s 36 of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap 322)\n\n(SCJA) on an earlier motion (No 3/2002D) filed by the respondents. The substantive issue\n\nin question concerned the interpretation of s 34(2)(a) of the SCJA. At the conclusion of\n\nthe hearing we set aside the ruling of the Judge and now give our reasons.\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nThe background</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 By three separate contracts, Tan Chiang were engaged by the\n\nrespondents, Permasteelisa Pacific Holdings Ltd (PPH), as sub-contractors to carry out\n\nworks in relation to three projects namely, the Cuppage Centre project, the Goldbell Tower\n\nProject and the China Square project. Tan Chiang instituted Suit No 14/2001/D against PPH\n\nfor the balance of the payments due under the three projects.</p>\n\n<p>3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 PPH did not dispute the claim of Tan Chiang in relation to the\n\nGoldbell Tower and China Square projects. In essence, what was in dispute concerned 46\n\nitems of variation works undertaken by Tan Chiang in relation to the Cuppage Centre\n\nproject. Eventually, on account of amendments made to the pleadings, the dispute was\n\nreduced to 36 items. On 33 of the items, PPH disputed only the quantum thereof. But in\n\nrespect of the remaining 3 items, PPH disputed both liability and quantum.</p>\n\n<p>4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should add that PPH had also counterclaimed against Tan Chiang\n\nin respect of the work done on the Cuppage Centre and the Goldbell Tower projects.</p>\n\n<p>5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After a 5-day trial, Lai Siu Chiu J delivered her judgment on 30\n\nNovember 2001. On 31 December 2001 Tan Chiang filed their notice of appeal against part of\n\nthe judgment, having on 26 December 2001 informed PPH of their intention to appeal.\n\nHowever, the notice was not served on PPH until 11 January 2002. Subsequently, on 25\n\nJanuary 2002, PPH notified Tan Chiang that the notice of appeal filed was not valid and\n\nasked Tan Chiang to rectify the same. As Tan Chiang disagreed, PPH, on 2 February 2002,\n\nfiled a Motion (No. 3 of 2002/D) to set aside the notice of appeal on two broad grounds: \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) leave to appeal should have been obtained as required under s\n\n  34(2)(a) of SCJA; and, </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(ii) that the notice of appeal was not served on PPH within the period\n\n  of one month from the date of the judgment as prescribed under O 57 r 4 of the Rules of\n\n  Court.</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Motion No 3/2002/D came before Rajendran J on 15 February 2002,\n\nsitting as a single Judge of the Court of Appeal under s 36(1) of SCJA. Though he was\n\ninclined to grant an extension of time to serve the notice of appeal on PPH, he\n\nnevertheless struck out the notice filed on 31 December 2001 on the ground that it was\n\nnecessary for Tan Chiang to have first obtained the leave of court before any notice of\n\nappeal could be filed. He ruled that such leave was required because the value of the\n\nsubject matter of the appeal was less than $250,000.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nPreliminary issues</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us counsel for Tan Chiang submitted that a single Judge has\n\nthe jurisdiction under s 36(1) of the SCJA to set aside a notice of appeal and\n\ncorrespondingly strike out an appeal. Section 36(1) and (3) provides as follows:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"(1) In any proceedings pending before the Court of Appeal any\n\n  direction incidental thereto not involving the decision of the appeal, any interim order\n\n  to prevent prejudice to the claims of the parties pending the appeal, and any order for\n\n  security for costs and for the dismissal of an appeal for default in furnishing security\n\n  so ordered, may at any time be made by a Judge.</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(3) Every order so made may be discharged or varied by the Court of\n\n  Appeal.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for PPH did not disagree that a single Judge has the\n\njurisdiction to make such an order. After all, it was PPH who asked the single Judge to\n\nmake the order. It would lie ill in the mouth of PPH to contend otherwise. If a single\n\nJudge does have the power under s 36(1) to make such an order, this Court would, under s\n\n36(3), have the power to set it aside or vary it. Both parties went before Rajendran J\n\nassuming that he had the jurisdiction to consider and, if thought appropriate, grant the\n\napplication. Thus, the Judge\u2019s attention was not drawn to the issue of the extent of\n\nhis power. </p>\n\n<p>9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we had serious reservations whether such an order may be\n\nmade by a single Judge pursuant to s 36(1). There are three broad categories of orders\n\nwhich a single Judge may make under that provision: \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) any incidental direction;</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(ii) any interim order to prevent prejudice; and </p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(iii) any order for security for costs and the consequential order for\n\n  dismissal of appeal for default. </p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Quite clearly, the present case does not come within the third\n\ncategory. The question is whether the order made falls within the first two categories. As\n\nwe see it, the order made on 15 February 2002 could hardly be considered to fall within\n\nthose two categories. The orders to be made under both categories are premised on the\n\nexistence of an appeal and the need for certain interim orders or directions to safeguard\n\nthe interest of the parties pending the disposal of the appeal. An application to strike\n\nout an appeal can, in no circumstances, be considered to be an order of that interlocutory\n\nnature. Indeed, it is an application with the object of putting an end to an appeal and\n\nnot to obtain any interlocutory or further reliefs. Accordingly, it was and is our opinion\n\nthat such an application cannot be heard by a single Judge pursuant to s 36(1).</p>\n\n<p>10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reverting to the matter in hand, we would add that whichever way\n\none may determine the jurisdictional issue of the single Judge under s 36(1), this Court\n\nwas properly seized of the matter. If, as we thought, a single Judge has no jurisdiction\n\nto order the setting aside and striking out of an appeal then the order of the single\n\nJudge made on 15 February 2002 in N/M No. 3/2002/D was not valid and could have no effect.\n\nThus, this Court could deal with the issues raised in N/M No. 8/2002/A as if the order\n\nmade in N/M No 3/2002/D had never been made.</p>\n\n<p>11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the other hand, if we assumed that the single Judge could make\n\nthe order as he actually did in N/M No. 3/2002/D, then by virtue of s 36(3), this Court\n\nwould have the power to review the order made by the Judge. Such an application to the\n\ncourt for a review is not an appeal: see <i>Boyd v Bischoffsheim</i> [1895] 1 Ch 1.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nSection 34(2)(a) of SCJA</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to consider section 34(2)(a) which provides that\n\nwhere \"the amount or value of the subject matter at the trial is $250,000 or\n\nless\" no appeal will be brought to the Court of Appeal except with the leave of the\n\nCourt of Appeal or a Judge. It will be seen that this operates as a restriction on the\n\nright of appeal from a decision of the High Court.</p>\n\n<p>13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Decisions of the High Court can either be in relation to an\n\naction commenced in the High Court or in relation to an action commenced in the\n\nSubordinate Courts which comes on appeal before the High Court. The jurisdictional limits\n\nof the District Court is $250,000 or less. A claim exceeding that limit must be commenced\n\nin the High Court. Implicit in the scheme of things is that there should, as a rule, be\n\nonly one-tier of appeal. In 1998, when the figure in s 34(2)(a) of SCJA was raised to make\n\nit fall in line with the enhanced civil jurisdiction of the District Court, the Minister\n\nof Law, Prof S Jayakumar, in his second reading speech in Parliament when moving an\n\namendment Bill to the SCJA, said: \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"In view of the enhanced District Courts\u2019 jurisdiction to\n\n  $250,000 in civil matters, the Chief Justice has proposed that the existing $30,000 limit\n\n  in section 34(2)(a) be raised to $250,000. In other words, bring its limit in line with\n\n  the enhancement. If the limit is not raised to $250,000, District Court cases of less than\n\n  $250,000 can first go on appeal to the High Court and then Court of Appeal. This would\n\n  strain the limited resources of the Court of Appeal.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present case, it was not in dispute that the amount of Tan\n\nChiang\u2019s claim at the trial well exceeded $250,000. The contention of PPH was that as\n\nTan Chiang had only appealed against (i) a part of the claim which they had not succeeded;\n\nand (ii) the counterclaim of PPH awarded against them, and as the total of these two items\n\ndid not exceed $250,000, Tan Chiang must, as required under s 34(2)(a), first have\n\nobtained leave before they could proceed to file their notice of appeal.</p>\n\n<p>15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 PPH also relied upon the views expressed by the High Court in the\n\nunreported decision of <i>Twin Enterprises Pte Ltd v Peter Lim Heng Wah </i>(S 1712/94\n\n\u2013 delivered on 29 November 2000) where the judge said:\u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"Although the said section (s 34(2)(a)) bespeaks the value of\n\n  subject matter at the trial, it is also intended to refer to the amount of the subject\n\n  matter on appeal.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It seems to us that the arguments raised by counsel for PPH could\n\nbe due to a misunderstanding of the decision of this Court in <i>Spandeck Engineering (S)\n\nPte Ltd v Yong Qiang Construction</i> <a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=49525&amp;freetext=\">[1999] 4 SLR 401</a>. In 30 of PPH\u2019s written\n\nsubmission they stated \u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"this Court has in <i>(Spendeck)</i> construed the term\n\n  \u2018amount in dispute or the value of the subject matter\u2019 in s.21(1) of the SCJA to\n\n  mean the amount in dispute or the value of the subject or matter against which the appeal\n\n  was brought.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We will deal with the <i>Spendeck Engineering</i> case in some\n\ndetail. There, a sub-contractor instituted a writ in the District Court claiming a sum of\n\n$62,275.51 from the main contractor. Judgment was entered against the main contractor in\n\ndefault of defence. Later, the main contractor filed an application to set aside the\n\ndefault judgment. The Deputy Registrar granted the application. On appeal, the District\n\nJudge reinstated the default judgment. On further appeal, the High Court affirmed the\n\ndecision of the District Judge. The main contractor appealed to the Court of Appeal. This\n\nCourt granted the sub-contractor\u2019s application to strike out the appeal.</p>\n\n<p>18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the main contractor argued that s 34(2)(a) only\n\napplied where there was a trial below. As in that case there was no trial, the provision\n\ncould have no application. This Court ruled that a \"trial\" did not necessarily\n\ninvolve the calling of witnesses and the taking of oral evidence. A trial could be based\n\non the evidence given in affidavits. This court ruled that if the main contractor\u2019s\n\narguments were to be accepted it would lead to anomalous results and gave this\n\nillustration (at p. 404):- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"For instance, an interlocutory or final judgment is given in the\n\n  District Court (in which there has not been a trial) in a suit in which the value of the\n\n  subject matter exceeds $50,000 but not $250,000, as in the present case. From such\n\n  judgment, whether it be interlocutory or final, an appeal may be taken to the High Court\n\n  as of right. Now, if the appellants\u2019 contention is accepted, the decision of the High\n\n  Court on that appeal may be taken further on appeal, as of right, to this Court (without\n\n  leave) on the ground that s 34(2)(a) of the SCJA is not applicable as there has been no\n\n  \"trial\" before either the District Court or the High Court. On the other hand,\n\n  if the suit is finally disposed of by the District Court at a trial resulting in a final\n\n  judgment being given, that judgment may be taken on appeal to the High Court, but from the\n\n  decision of the High Court on that appeal, there would be no further appeal to this court,\n\n  unless leave under s 34(2)(a) is obtained.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In order to ensure that the application of s 34(2)(a) does not\n\nlead to anomalous results this Court felt that the word \"trial\" should be\n\ninterpreted purposively. It noted that as the limit of $250,000 in s.34(2)(a) was also the\n\nupper limit of the District Court\u2019s jurisdiction, the objective of s.34(2)(a) was to\n\nensure that where appeals from the decision of the District Court had been heard and\n\ndisposed of by the High Court, there should be no further appeals therefrom to the Court\n\nof Appeal unless (on sufficient grounds shown) leave of either the High Court or this\n\nCourt was obtained. The provision provide for a process to screen appeals to be brought to\n\nthis Court, thus preventing the clogging up of this Court by all kinds of appeals. What\n\nwas contemplated by the legislature in relation to an action commenced in the District\n\nCourt was that there should be only two tiers of hearing \u2013 the first instance hearing\n\nand an appeal. A further appeal to the Court of Appeal was only possible with leave.</p>\n\n<p>20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nothing in <i>Spandeck Engineering</i> suggests that the words\n\n\"at the trial\" in s 34(2)(a) should be read to mean \"at the appeal\".\n\nAll that <i>Spandeck Engineering </i>decided was that the word \"trial\" should\n\nnot be read to mean only a \"hearing in open court with the calling of\n\nwitnesses\". There could be a \"trial\" when the \"hearing\" was based\n\npurely on affidavits. In our judgment, to read the word \"trial\" to mean\n\n\"appeal\" would do violence to the ordinary meaning of that word and would be\n\nwholly unwarranted.</p>\n\n<p>21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this regard two Malaysian cases are germane. In <i>Chan Kee\n\nBeng v Ramasamy Naidu</i> [1939] MLJ 92, the material provision was \"if the amount or\n\nvalue of the subject matter of any civil suit does not exceed $100, no appeal shall\n\nlie.\" Mill J held that the determining factor was not the amount or the value of the\n\nsubject matter of the appeal, but the amount or value of the subject matter of the civil\n\nsuit.</p>\n\n<p>22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In a recent Malaysian Federal Court case, <i>Yai Yen Hon v Teng\n\nAh Kok &amp; Sim Huat Sdn Bhd &amp; Anor </i><a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=42886&amp;freetext=\">[1997] 1 MLJ 136</a>, a similar point arose.\n\nUnder the Malaysian Courts of Judicature Act 1964, leave to appeal was required \"when\n\nthe amount or value of the subject matter of the claim\" was less than M$100,000/-.\n\nThere, the plaintiff\u2019s claim was well in excess of M$100,000 but the High Court only\n\ngave judgment to the plaintiff in the sum of M$62,400. The Federal Court held that whether\n\nthere was a right to appeal depended on the value of the claim and not the award given by\n\nthe trial judge.</p>\n\n<p>23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A much earlier English case, <i>Dreesman v Harris</i> (1854) 9\n\nExch 485, had also decided to a similar effect. That was an action in the county court for\n\nbreach of contract and the claim exceeded 20, though the judge gave judgment only for\n\n12. The court held that no leave need be obtained to appeal. It was argued there that\n\nsuch a construction would mean that a plaintiff could reserve to himself the right of\n\nappeal in all cases by extending his claim to a sum exceeding 20. This argument was\n\nrejected.</p>\n\n<p>24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We accept that it could be different if bad faith could be shown\n\nin the formulation of the claim: see <i>Mason v Burningham</i> [1949] 2 KB 545 and <i>Mayer\n\nv Burgess</i> (1855) 4 E&amp;B 655. We would further add that a party who unreasonably\n\ninflates his claim may be penalised when the question of costs arises for consideration.\n\nThis would undoubtedly act as a deterrence.</p>\n\n<p>25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the instant case, the quantum of the claim at the trial was\n\nwell in excess of S$250,000. There was no suggestion that this was not a <i>bona fide</i>\n\nclaim. Accordingly, we held that no leave of court need be obtained by Tan Chiang to file\n\nthe present appeal (CA 600133/2001), which is now pending.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nExtension of time for service</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>26.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, we turn to consider briefly the question of an extension\n\nof time to enable Tan Chiang to serve the notice of appeal on PPH out of time. As\n\nmentioned before, the notice was served on PPH on 11 January 2002. It is clear that under\n\nO 57, r 4 the notice should have been served on PPH on 31 December 2002, the day it was\n\nfiled. This is because the filing and service must both be done within a month of the\n\njudgment appealed against.</p>\n\n<p>27.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The factors which a court should take into account in exercising\n\nits discretion whether or not to extend time to enable a party to file a notice of appeal\n\nout of time were considered and reiterated by this Court in <i>Pearson v Chen Chien Wen\n\nEdwin</i> [1991] SLR 212. The factors are: (i) the length of the delay; (ii) the reason of\n\nthe delay; (iii) the chances of the appeal succeeding if time for appealing is extended;\n\nand (iv) the degree of prejudice to the would-be respondent if the application is granted.\n\nThe governing principles were recently reviewed by this Court in <i>Nomura Regionalisation\n\nVenture Fund Ltd v Ethical Investments Ltd </i><a target=\"LWBMainFrame\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"/scripts/lp/dll/prospect.dll?GetHTML_lpqs&amp;type=1&amp;CaseID=59541&amp;freetext=\">[2000] 4 SLR 46</a>.</p>\n\n<p>28.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There were circumstances in the case which deserved the\n\ncourt\u2019s consideration. First, the electronic filing system (EFS) of the Supreme Court\n\nwas only recently extended to include documents filed in Civil Appeals to the Court of\n\nAppeal. Second, Tan Chiang initiated the process to file the notice of appeal at 1.00pm on\n\n28 December 2001. Due to certain technicalities, Tan Chiang only managed to file the\n\nnotice on 31 December at 11.51am. Third, certain situations arose which had a bearing on\n\nthe oversight and here we would quote from an affidavit filed by the solicitor on behalf\n\nof Tan Chiang:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"The Applicants waited for the Certificate for Security for Costs\n\n  and Notice of Appeal to be approved before service on the respondents. My staff who was in\n\n  charge of the EFS filing of the Notice of Appeal left our employment. Another staff was\n\n  assigned to monitor the same.</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The appellants were distracted the next few days by a dispute between\n\n  the applicants and the respondents over the wording of the judgment of the court below.</p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">The new staff retrieved the Notice of Appeal from the EFS system on 9\n\n  January 2002 and served the same on 11 January 2002.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">Further amplification of these was set out in a later affidavit.\n\nFourth, and more importantly, PPH were notified on 26 December 2001 that Tan Chiang were\n\nfiling a notice of appeal.</p>\n\n<p>29.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The delay in the service was only some nine days, as 1 January\n\n2002 was a public holiday. Tan Chiang had provided some reasons to explain the delay,\n\ncaused in part by the change in the system of filing following the expansion of the EFS to\n\ncivil appeals. It could not be seriously argued that the appeal was without merits. In\n\nview of the fact that the delay was only some nine days and PPH was notified that an\n\nappeal was being filed, there could be no question of any prejudice.</p>\n\n<p>30.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we have stated, Rajendran J was favourably inclined towards\n\ngranting an extension of time for service if not for the fact that he held the view that\n\nthe notice of appeal was invalid because leave was required and not obtained. For the\n\nforegoing reasons, we were similarly of the opinion that in the circumstances of this case\n\nan extension of time for service ought to be given, which we duly granted.</p>\n\n<font face=\"CG Times,CG Times\" size=\"4\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\"/></font>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\n\n<p    <CaseTitle>Lee Hiok Tng (in her personal capacity) v Lee Hiok Tng and another (executors and trustees fo the estate of Lee Wee Nam, deceased) and Others</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Lee Hiok Tng (in her <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2065\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2088\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Proof of evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2093\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Presumptions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Presumption of advancement</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord
