85, 91(1), 91(6), 93(1)(a) Factories (Shipbuilding and Ship-repairing) Regulations (Cap 104, Rg 11, 1999 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3198\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tort</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3233\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Negligence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3236\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contributory negligence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Employee claiming damages for personal injury suffered due to employer's alleged breach of duty to provide safe place of work and safe access thereto</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether employee contributorily negligent by failing to observe ordinary care which ordinary prudent person would take for own safety</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16 November 2006</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Judgment reserved.</span></i></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Belinda Ang Saw Ean\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This is an appeal against the decision of the trial judge (\u201cthe judge\u201d) dismissing the appellant\u2019s claim for damages for personal injuries suffered in an accident at his workplace on 22\u00a0June 2002 (see <nobr>[2006] 1 SLR 697</nobr>). The respondents are BT\u00a0Engineering Pte Ltd (\u201cBT\u00a0Engineering\u201d) and Keppel Shipyard Limited (\u201cKeppel\u201d). It was agreed between the parties that only the question of liability would be determined at the trial, with damages to be assessed separately.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appellant\u2019s case in the court below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Some two months before the accident, the appellant, Sim Cheng Soon (\u201cSCS\u201d), who was a welder by trade, and other workers from BT\u00a0Engineering were deployed to carry out welding work on board the <i>Falcon</i> (\u201cthe vessel\u201d), a tanker which was being converted to a floating production storage and offloading vessel at Keppel\u2019s shipyard. Multiheight Scaffolding Pte Ltd (\u201cMultiheight\u201d) was engaged by BT\u00a0Engineering to erect the scaffolding and the working platform required for the conversion works.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 22\u00a0June 2002 at about 8.00am, the appellant started work in an area of the vessel known as Module\u00a010. On the day of the accident, he was working at level\u00a03 of the module. At about 11.30am, just before his lunch break, the appellant went about detaching his welding torch and putting away his equipment pail in a temporary storage area located at level\u00a02. Thereafter, he walked along the working platform at level\u00a02 towards the access ladder (identified by the judge as \u201cladder\u00a03\u201d) to descend to the vessel\u2019s deck. The appellant\u2019s account of the accident was, in effect, this: He said that before he could reach ladder\u00a03, he fell through an uncovered and unfenced opening at the level\u00a02 working platform where there should have been a platform of planks. At this point, instead of stepping onto a platform, the appellant, as the judge put it, \u201cstepped into empty space\u201d and fell through the opening to the deck below, thereby sustaining serious personal injuries. According to the appellant, he fell from a height of more than 3m. The respondents, however, maintained that the fall was from a height of not more than 3m. The appellant was alone when the accident happened.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant challenged the admissibility of the photographs which the respondents adduced in evidence. According to the respondents, the photographs were taken by one of Keppel\u2019s safety officers, Ng Sze Kiat (\u201cNg\u201d), shortly after the accident on the same day. The appellant argued that the photographs could not have been taken on the day of the accident itself because they depicted barricades at the place where he had fallen when there were in fact no such barricades present at the time of the accident. The appellant also claimed that there had originally been planks covering the opening through which he fell, but that the planks must, unknown to him at the material time, have been removed one day before the accident. He complained that there were no signs or notices put up to warn him of the resultant opening in the working platform.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the trial, the appellant claimed that BT\u00a0Engineering owed him a duty of care as an employer, and also statutory duties under the Factories Act (Cap\u00a0104, 1998\u00a0Rev Ed) and the Factories (Shipbuilding and Ship-repairing) Regulations (Cap\u00a0104, Rg\u00a011, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Factories Regulations\u201d) made pursuant to ss\u00a068 and 102 of the Factories Act. As against Keppel, the appellant claimed that it was in breach of its statutory duties under the Factories Act and the Factories Regulations as the occupier of the work site in question. The earlier claim against Keppel based on its common law duty as occupier was abandoned on appeal and as such, we need not go into that.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The defence</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondents served a joint defence which not only questioned the appellant\u2019s account of how the accident happened, but also went on to explain how the accident probably happened and why the appellant\u2019s injuries were so serious. In the court below, the respondents set out to prove that the appellant lost his grip while he was descending ladder\u00a03 and thus fell from the ladder, and not from the working platform at level\u00a02 as the appellant claimed. The respondents called two witnesses to establish that it was not possible for the appellant to have fallen from either the working platform at level\u00a02 or the top of the generator to the right of ladder\u00a03. They were Mohamed Aliffi bin Ismail (\u201cIsmail\u201d), the safety manager of Keppel, and Lim Nyuk Kok (\u201cLim\u201d), a site manager of Multiheight. Accompanied by Ng, who took the photographs at the scene of the accident and who subsequently prepared the investigation report, Ismail was at the scene of the accident within an hour of the accident. Ismail confirmed that the photographs were of the place of the accident and its surroundings. He testified that the open sides of the working platform at level\u00a02 were barricaded with railings. He also saw the edges of the top of the generator \u201call ... railed up\u201d. The judge admitted the photographs as evidence. Lim was called to interpret the photographs and explain the structures depicted therein. He confirmed that the scaffolding poles shown in photograph\u00a02 and marked \u201cA\u201d to \u201cF\u201d were barricades put up to prevent any worker from falling from the open sides of the working platform. As such, and contrary to the appellant\u2019s assertions, there could not have been planks placed outside the area barricaded by the scaffolding poles because no worker was meant to have access to the area to begin with.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 According to Keppel\u2019s investigations (which, incidentally, did not include interviewing the appellant), the appellant was not, at the material time, wearing his safety helmet. The respondents submitted that if the appellant had worn a safety helmet, the extent of the injuries which he sustained would not have been so serious.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The decision below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge rejected the appellant\u2019s version of how the accident happened and concluded that on the balance of probabilities, the effective cause of the accident was the appellant\u2019s fall from ladder\u00a03 during descent, which was entirely due to his negligence. Accordingly, the judge dismissed the action against the respondents.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge\u2019s findings were, <i>inter alia</i>, as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The photographs adduced in evidence were taken on the day of and after the accident. Ismail was present when all the photographs were taken except in respect of photographs\u00a09 and 10.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The photographs showed barriers surrounding the opening through which the appellant purportedly fell. On one side of photograph\u00a02 were three barriers marked \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d and on the opposite side were three barriers marked \u201cD\u201d, \u201cE\u201d and \u201cF\u201d. All the barriers met and were connected by a vertical pole at three places marked as \u201cG\u201d, \u201cH\u201d and \u201cI\u201d on photograph\u00a02. The judge said that the photographs also showed railings surrounding the edges of the top of the generator next to ladder\u00a03. The judge then concluded that the photographs showed the appellant\u2019s version of the accident to be \u201cinherently improbable\u201d. She further found that there could not have been planks (parallel with the I-beam which was directly opposite the generator and to the left of ladder\u00a03) at the opening which had been removed a day before the accident.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant had not discharged the burden of proof, which was upon him, to explain how he fell or how the accident happened. He said he had stepped into \u201cempty space\u201d instead of onto a platform of planks and had fallen. The judge found the appellant\u2019s testimony to be vague and evasive. She was also not satisfied with the appellant\u2019s explanation of the discrepancy between his version of the accident as set out in his lawyer\u2019s letter to the respondents dated 13\u00a0November 2002 and the version which he gave in court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant was found lying on his back on the deck. That position was consistent with the appellant falling off ladder\u00a03 during descent. A person using a ladder would fall backwards and land on his back.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant was not wearing a safety helmet at the time of the accident. If he had worn a safety helmet, he would not have sustained the serious head injuries that rendered him a quadriplegic.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In coming to the above findings of fact and conclusions, the judge would have been persuaded by the overall impressions and considerations of the respondents\u2019 evidence. Some of these may not have been expressly specified by the judge in coming to her decision, but they were nonetheless implicit from her narration of the evidence and her reasoning. In rejecting the appellant\u2019s version of the accident as \u201cinherently improbable\u201d, the judge would have to first accept, which she did, that the open sides of the working platform at level\u00a02 were fenced or barricaded by the scaffolding poles marked \u201cA\u201d to \u201cF\u201d in photograph\u00a02, and that these poles could adequately function as guard rails. Having found that the scaffolding poles marked \u201cA\u201d to \u201cF\u201d acted as guard rails, the judge accepted Lim\u2019s evidence that, contrary to the appellant\u2019s testimony, there could not have been any planks placed parallel to the I-beam on the opposite side of the generator and then removed just a day before the accident. Lim\u2019s reasoning was that a scaffolding contractor would not ordinarily erect a working platform or place any planks outside a fenced or barricaded opening. By ruling in the respondents\u2019 favour, the judge accepted the respondents\u2019 case that (a)\u00a0access to ladder\u00a03 was from the working platform behind ladder\u00a03 at the area near the scaffolding poles marked as \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d in photograph\u00a02, and (b) the appellant was already on ladder\u00a03 when he fell. In contrast, the appellant\u2019s testimony was that he fell from the level\u00a02 working platform even before he reached ladder\u00a03. At the material time, he was approaching ladder\u00a03 from the front rather than from the working platform behind ladder\u00a03. According to the appellant, the scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d impeded safe access to ladder\u00a03 from the working platform behind ladder\u00a03.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge held, <i>obiter</i>, that even if she was wrong in her finding that the appellant fell off ladder\u00a03 instead of in the manner which he had described, the respondents were still not liable to the appellant as there was no breach of ss\u00a033(2) and 33(3) of the Factories Act. The respondents had provided the appellant with a safe means of access to the work site (<i>ie</i>, the vessel) and a safe place of work there. There was a safe system of work due to the stringent safety checks that were put in place by Keppel. In any case, the opening in question was visible and large. The judge was of the view that had the appellant kept a proper lookout, he would have seen the opening. Finally, the judge had no doubt that there was no breach of duty by Keppel as the occupier of the work site as there was no concealed or unusual danger on the vessel that Keppel was aware of.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s main grounds of appeal were as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge erred in admitting the photographs. Ng was not called as a witness to prove the photographs and there was no evidence that the photographs were taken soon after the accident on the same day.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge erred in finding that the photographs showed that the appellant\u2019s version of how the accident happened was inherently improbable.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge erred in finding that the appellant was not wearing his safety helmet, and that he would not have been rendered a quadriplegic had he done so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge erred in finding that the respondents did not breach s\u00a033 of the Factories Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Alternatively, as between the appellant and the respondents, the former\u2019s contributory negligence should be apportioned at a lower percentage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In addition, in the event that his main grounds of appeal should be rejected, the appellant adopted a fall-back position, which was for relief under s\u00a033 of the Workmen\u2019s Compensation Act (Cap\u00a0354, 1998\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cWCA\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Photographic evidence</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the first two main grounds of appeal, these relate to the photographic evidence (see [12] above). The question here is the admissibility of the photographic evidence and whether such evidence, if received, supported the view that scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d, \u201cE\u201d and \u201cF\u201d functioned as guard rails fencing the open side of the level\u00a02 working platform from where the appellant purportedly fell.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should point out that central to the circumstances of the accident, and hence to this appeal, was the finding that the open sides of the level\u00a02 working platform were barricaded with scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d to \u201cF\u201d which functioned as guard rails. It was not necessary in this appeal for this court to make a specific finding as to whether there had originally been planks covering the spot from which the appellant fell (see [4] above). In the court below, the appellant did not call any witness to corroborate his claim that the missing plank(s) (or \u201cplatform\u201d as the judge called it) was on the level\u00a02 working platform the day before the accident. This was surprising, as other workers working on Module\u00a010 would also have made use of ladder\u00a03. However, fortunately for the appellant, he needed only to prove that he fell from an unfenced or insufficiently fenced opening at the edge of the working platform at level\u00a02. Furthermore, even though the judge found the appellant evasive in his evidence, this would have no bearing on whether there was in fact an unfenced or an insufficiently fenced opening at the edge of the working platform at level\u00a02.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the appellant, Mr\u00a0N\u00a0Sreenivasan, argued that the appellant\u2019s account of the accident should have prevailed before the judge. It was submitted that the photographs were wrongly admitted as the photographer, Ng, was not called to prove that they were taken by him on the day of the accident. Effectively, the only evidence available before the court as to the cause of the accident was the appellant\u2019s testimony. The accident, it was argued, was due to the respondents\u2019 breaches of duty: the appellant fell from the level\u00a02 working platform as there was no or inadequate fencing along the open side of the working platform.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the respondents, Ms\u00a0Edwina Fan, accepted that the photographs were critical as they showed barriers surrounding the alleged open side of the working platform from which the appellant had purportedly fallen. She contended that the photographs were properly admitted in evidence. The judge was right to have accepted Ismail\u2019s evidence that he was present and saw Ng take the photographs. Lim\u2019s interpretation of the photographs was crucial in explaining why the appellant\u2019s version of how the accident happened was improbable. Ms\u00a0Fan argued that the judge was right to have accepted Lim\u2019s testimony that the photographs showed that there were barriers erected at the side of the working platform from which the appellant allegedly fell, such that it was \u201cinherently improbable\u201d for the appellant to have fallen from the working platform in the way which he claimed. If anything, the accident was due to the appellant\u2019s fault. He was careless and did not keep a proper lookout for his own safety.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the question of the photographic evidence, we agree with the judge\u2019s ruling that the photographs were admissible in evidence through the testimony of Ismail, who was with Ng at the time the latter took the photographs. Ismail had testified that the photographs depicted what he saw at the site of the accident and the surrounding scaffolding. Ismail also saw the photographs after they were developed in the course of Ng\u2019s preparation of the investigation report and during his discussion with Ng. The investigation report was later approved and confirmed by Ismail. Since the photographs could be proved through Ismail, Ng\u2019s attendance in court was unnecessary. Therefore, contrary to the appellant\u2019s submissions, there was nothing adverse to infer from the respondents\u2019 failure to call Ng as a witness. The respondents had earlier explained that Ng had left Keppel\u2019s employment and was presently working in China.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The onus of proof was always on the appellant to explain how he fell from the working platform and also to explain why this fall was due to the negligence of the respondents or a breach of statutory duty on the part of Keppel. Contrary to the respondents\u2019 submissions, from the transcripts of the evidence, the appellant steadfastly maintained throughout that scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d were not guard rails as they were too low to prevent any person from falling from the working platform. From our analysis of the photographs, we agree. Notably, the focal point of the important photographs was ladder\u00a03. Photograph\u00a02 shows an I-beam to the left of the photograph. To its immediate right is ladder\u00a03, next to which is the generator at the other end of scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d. Scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d, which were erected horizontally, are parallel to each other at varying heights. Scaffolding pole \u201cD\u201d is attached perpendicular to \u201cB\u201d above the top of the generator at that end of \u201cB\u201d which is away from the I-beam. The spot from which the appellant allegedly fell is at the edge of the two wooden planks shown in the foreground of photograph\u00a02. Scaffolding pole \u201cF\u201d runs under one of the two wooden planks and also ends there. These two wooden planks are not in photograph\u00a03 as it was taken from a different angle. Photograph\u00a03 shows ladder\u00a03 and a small section of scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d, \u201cE\u201d and \u201cF\u201d. It is impossible to see from photographs\u00a02 and 3 whether scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d were of heights which correspond with scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d or \u201cC\u201d. Significantly, there were no photographs showing the full length of poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. There were also no photographs showing the railings surrounding the edges of the top of the generator. We found it surprising that Ismail did not ask that photographs be taken of the area immediately above the top of the generator as proof that the edges were, as he put it, \u201call ... railed up\u201d (see [6] above) since, if he was to be believed, the investigations which would typically be done in a case like this, where a workman had a bad fall, ought to identify or rule out any unsafe open sides. The judge did not draw the necessary inference from these matters when considering the photographic evidence. The judge did, however, observe that the railings which Ismail saw in relation to the small gap of about 180mm wide on the working platform at level\u00a02 immediately behind ladder\u00a03 were scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d in photograph\u00a02, and that they were not on the same side of the working platform as the side from which the appellant fell.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Given the photographic evidence and the appellant\u2019s account of how he fell into empty space, the absence of proper guard rails at the edge of the level\u00a02 working platform is, in our view, the only credible explanation as to how the appellant fell. It follows that the judge should not have accepted Lim\u2019s testimony that the edge of the working platform at level\u00a02 was barricaded.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Besides, there were two important features of Lim\u2019s evidence in particular which rendered it inadmissible evidence. The first is that Lim was not a witness of fact or an expert witness. He was from the company engaged to erect the scaffolding on the vessel\u2019s decks (<i>ie</i>, Multiheight). However, he was not responsible for and did not supervise the construction of the scaffolding and working platform. Lim had no personal knowledge of what scaffolding had been erected at the material time since he had not visited the vessel on 22\u00a0June 2002 either before or after the accident. Lim also admitted under cross-examination that he was not in a position to know whether the scaffolding in Module\u00a010 of the vessel had been properly constructed or maintained as that was a temporary scaffolding. There were no written instructions or drawings as to where Multiheight was supposed to construct or dismantle the scaffolding and working platforms in Module\u00a010. Similarly, there were no construction drawings that could confirm that there were guard rails made up by scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. Lim was, therefore, not competent to give evidence on matters he had not seen or otherwise had no personal knowledge about.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is an accepted principle that only expert witnesses may give opinion evidence. Notably, Lim was not called as an expert witness. Yet, he gave what was substantially opinion evidence under the guise of interpreting and explaining the layout and function of the scaffolding poles and the working platform in the photographs. This offends the general rule that inferences of fact must be made by the court and not the witness. The present situation is unlike those cases where a layman who has observed the primary facts is allowed to give inferential or opinion evidence on a state of affairs or a condition, for instance, that a person whom he had observed was drunk or ill or angry or looked old. Evidence of that nature can be received, but its weight and probative value are for the court to evaluate. In breach of the hearsay rule, Lim gave opinion evidence on what was in the photographs as though the contents of the photographs were proof of matters of fact.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second feature which follows from the hearsay point is that the judge should not have accepted Lim\u2019s views on the height of scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d, \u201cC\u201d, \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. As stated (see [19] above), scaffolding poles \u201cA\u201d, \u201cB\u201d and \u201cC\u201d were erected horizontally and parallel to each other at varying heights. Scaffolding pole \u201cD\u201d was attached perpendicular to \u201cB\u201d at that end of \u201cB\u201d which was away from the I-beam and above the top of the generator. Although no evidence in terms of actual measurements was given, Lim stated that scaffolding pole \u201cA\u201d functioned as the upper rail and was waist-high; \u201cB\u201d was the middle rail and was knee-high; and \u201cC\u201d was above the ankle. The height of scaffolding pole \u201cD\u201d was important to the respondents\u2019 case and no doubt, appreciating the limitations posed by the available photographic evidence which we have highlighted earlier at [19], Lim\u2019s opinion was material. Lim was asked \u201cto advise\u201d on the height of scaffolding pole \u201cD\u201d without the benefit of any photographs showing the full length and overall view of scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. Lim opined that scaffolding pole \u201cD\u201d functioned as the upper rail. That was because the top of the generator was lower than the working platform by about \u201c2 to 3 feet\u201d. His opinion was not only based on his observations and the inferences which he drew from what he saw in photographs\u00a02 and 3; his testimony went beyond what was in the photographs. He was allowed to express his subjective opinion on what was essentially a disputed issue of fact. As we stated earlier at [20] above, the judge should have rejected Lim\u2019s testimony that the open side from which the appellant said he fell was \u201cfenced and barricaded\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A related and important consideration is whether there was sufficient objective evidence for the judge to make her own evaluation on the height of scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. No one took measurements of the height of scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d, so there was no evidence that \u201cD\u201d was a safety rail 1.1m high as required by the Factories Regulations. The evidential deficiency or gap could not be made good by assessing the height of the poles from the photographs, as Mr\u00a0Sreenivasan sought to do when he submitted on the dimensions of the scaffolding based upon a visual assessment of the distance between each rung of ladder\u00a03. It must be remembered that a photograph is not proof of the dimensions of the objects depicted. It is not possible to work out distances and calculate measurements based on objects depicted in photographs under the guise of submissions. Instead, this is a matter for expert testimony, as can be seen from <i>United States Shipping Board v The Ship St Albans</i> <nobr>[1931] AC 632.</nobr> That case concerned a collision between two vessels. The point in the harbour at which the collision occurred was material. Photographs taken from a third moving ship showing the vessels just before and after the collision, with the frontage of the harbour in the background, were adduced in evidence. Based on the photographs, a surveyor fixed the focal point of the camera from which each photograph was taken, and then by reference to the background, attempted to geometrically determine and localise the collision. The surveyor\u2019s evidence was rejected by the House of Lords as the task mentioned required the science or skill of a qualified person and the surveyor was not such an expert witness. Lord\u00a0Merrivale said (at 642):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Clearly a photographic picture cannot be relied upon as proof in itself of the dimensions of the depicted object or objects, and cannot be made properly available to establish the relative proportions of such objects except by evidence of personal knowledge or scientific experience to demonstrate accurately the facts sought to be established.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Likewise, it was not permissible to gauge the height of poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d and the distance between the top of the generator and the working platform based upon a mere visual inspection of the photographs as Lim did. In the same way, it was not permissible to ascertain the height of the poles based on the distance between each rung of ladder\u00a03 from the photographs as Mr\u00a0Sreenivasan tried to do.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, for the reasons stated, there was no countervailing evidence to contradict the appellant\u2019s evidence that scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d were much too low to qualify as guard rails or operate as safety barriers. The appellant would not have seen pole \u201cF\u201d which was under the two wooden planks shown in the foreground of photograph\u00a02 (see [19] above). In these circumstances, it is open to this court to accept, which we do, that on a balance of probabilities, the appellant fell from the side of the insufficiently barricaded or guarded working platform at level\u00a02, and not from ladder\u00a03.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was foreseeable that a workman like the appellant would fall from the insufficiently fenced side of the working platform and sustain injuries. Keppel\u2019s health, safety and environmental manual (\u201cKeppel\u2019s safety manual\u201d) highlights in particular falls from a working platform or from the edge of a structure as one of the major types of accidents in the shipbuilding and ship repairing industry where the fallen persons either die or suffer serious multiple injuries. Common causes of falls from heights are likely to be an unguarded platform, an unfenced opening or an unfenced edge. Safety measures to prevent persons from falling from heights are, <i>inter alia,</i> the provision of guard rails at the open sides of scaffolding. Keppel\u2019s safety personnel were to ensure that BT\u00a0Engineering, its employees and subcontractors observed Keppel\u2019s safety manual.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We accept that it was probable that the appellant did not exercise sufficient care to keep a proper lookout as to where he was walking. Even then, his lack of care as he made his way towards ladder\u00a03 would not necessarily defeat the claim in its entirety. If BT\u00a0Engineering was in breach of its duty of care to the appellant as his employer or if Keppel had failed to provide the safety provisions required of it under the Factories Act as the occupier of the shipyard, and as a result a workman, such as the appellant, was injured in a way which could have resulted from the breach, the onus of proof would shift to the respondents to show that their breaches of their duties of care to the appellant were not the proximate cause of the appellant\u2019s fall. The question in this case is whether the appellant would have fallen but for the absence of proper guard rails that could function as a barrier. If either BT\u00a0Engineering or Keppel were in breach of their respective duties, then the appellant here would not in any sense be taking advantage of his own wrong if BT\u00a0Engineering\u2019s or Keppel\u2019s breaches of duties coincided with his own negligence and continued up to the very moment of the accident. If the court is satisfied that there was fault on the part of both the appellant and the respondents, the issue then is one of determining the extent to which it is just and equitable to reduce the damages which would otherwise be recoverable by the appellant. We will be considering these aspects of the case below.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><strong><em>Liability of the respondents</em></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">the present case, the non-delegable duty of care owed by BT\u00a0Engineering to the appellant to provide a safe place of work continued even though Multiheight was engaged as the scaffolding contractor and despite the fact that the appellant was working at Keppel\u2019s premises: see <i>Charlesworth &amp; Percy on Negligence</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 10th\u00a0Ed, 2001) at para\u00a010-31. The appellant had suffered injuries while he was on the working platform set up by and under the charge of Multiheight. BT\u00a0Engineering was required to erect scaffolding and working platforms for the conversion works. Multiheight had a scaffolding supervisor on site. This scaffolding supervisor from Multiheight was the person in charge of the erection and dismantling of the scaffolding, and it was he who had to observe, <i>inter alia</i>, Keppel\u2019s safety manual.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both Keppel as occupier and BT\u00a0Engineering as employer were obliged to comply with the Factories Regulations. Regulation\u00a04(1), which was in force at the time of the accident, imposes a duty on every occupier, contractor or employer to comply with the requirements of the Factories Regulations as they affect him or any other person employed by him, which in this case was the appellant. Regulation\u00a04(2) imposes a duty on every occupier, contractor or employer who, <i>inter alia</i>, erects any scaffolding to comply with that part of the Factories Regulations which relates to the erection of scaffolding having regard to the purpose or purposes for which the scaffolding is designed at the time of erection.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The burden of proof was on Keppel and BT\u00a0Engineering to prove that they had complied with the statutory obligations under the Factories Regulations. The respondents have failed to do so for the reasons set out below.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Keppel was in charge of the overall safety of the site, which was a \u201cfactory\u201d within the meaning of the Factories Act. The insufficiently fenced or guarded working platform pointed <i>prima facie</i> to a definite breach of the safety provision imposed on the occupier of a \u201cfactory\u201d under reg\u00a085 which states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">There shall be no opening in any working platform except to allow access to that working platform.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondents argued that reg\u00a085 was not applicable as the opening through which the appellant fell was found outside that part of the working platform which was barricaded by the scaffolding poles and that the same reasoning applied in the case of regs\u00a091(1) and 91(6). These arguments are no longer valid in the light of our finding that there were in fact no proper guard rails that could have served as a barrier against a careless worker falling off the edge of the working platform at level\u00a02.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondents also argued that there was no breach of reg\u00a09 read with reg\u00a093(1)(<i>a</i>) as the height of the working platform was not more than 3m in this case. There was therefore no obligation to provide guard rails of adequate strength to a height of at least 1.1m above the working platform. The relevant regulations read as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Every open side or opening into or through which a person may fall more than 3 metres shall be covered or guarded by an effective barrier to prevent falls except where free access is required by persons or for the movement of materials.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">93.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2014(1)\u00a0Subject to paragraphs\u00a0(4),(5) and (6), every side of a working platform or working place, being a side from which a person is liable to fall a distance of more than 3 metres, shall be provided with \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a suitable guardrail or guardrails of adequate strength to a height of at least 1.1 metres above the platform or working place and above any raised standing place on the platform \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As stated, no measurement was taken of the height of the generator or the height of the working platform and scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and \u201cE\u201d. Ismail\u2019s testimony was ambiguous. He said that ladder\u00a03 was 3m in height and that the top of the generator was \u201cslightly lower\u201d than ladder\u00a03. He did not testify as to the distance between the working platform and the top of the generator which was marked X on photograph\u00a03. In our view, the respondents had not discharged the burden of proof, which was on them, to establish that (a)\u00a0the height of the working platform from the deck up was not more than 3m, or that (b)\u00a0the height of scaffolding poles \u201cD\u201d and E\u201d was at least 1.1m. The appellant fell from the open side of the working platform and not from the top of the generator. It is more probable than not, and we so find, that the working platform at level\u00a02 was more than 3m from the deck. Before the judge, the respondents\u2019 position was that the open sides of the working platform were barricaded as required by law. By that, they accepted, albeit tacitly, that the height of the working platform from the deck was more than 3m and not lower as they claimed in this appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36<b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</b> Having reached the conclusions above, it is unnecessary to deal with the other statutory provisions under s\u00a033 of the Factories Act. However, we should briefly comment on ss\u00a033(2) and 33(3) of the Factories Act as the judge considered them and was of the view that the respondents were not in breach of the subsections. Besides, it was an issue raised in this appeal (see [12] above).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 First, the appellant fell from the edge of the working platform, which cannot be regarded as an opening in the floor within the meaning of s\u00a033(2) of the Factories Act. This court in <i>Bohman v Jurong Town Corp</i> <nobr>[1980-1981] SLR 167</nobr> held that unfenced edges of a platform were not \u201copenings in floors\u201d within the contemplation of the s\u00a033(2). Accordingly, s\u00a033(2) does not apply in this case. Second, s\u00a033(3) is concerned with a safe means of access to and a safe place of employment. Given our findings at [26] and [35] above, the respondents were in our view in breach of s\u00a033(3) of the Factories Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Contributory negligence</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the question of contributory negligence. The respondents contended that the appellant was wholly to blame for the accident and should bear full responsibility for the accident. We have to again emphasise that this was not a case where the only breach on the part of BT\u00a0Engineering as the appellant\u2019s employer and Keppel as the occupier of the shipyard consisted of the sole act of the workman himself (for instance, where the workman fails to operate a machine in accordance with the safety features provided).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The accident took place in broad daylight and there was no challenge that there was enough natural lighting for the appellant to see where he was going. The appellant admitted that he had ample time to get to level\u00a01. He had worked at shipyards in the past and had undergone safety courses at Keppel\u2019s shipyard. He had also attended organised safety talks and meetings both generally and specifically for the conversion works to be done of the vessel. He was familiar with the layout of level\u00a02, having worked there for about a week before moving up to level\u00a03. He had also gone up and down ladder\u00a03 several times over a period of two to three weeks. The appellant\u2019s familiarity with the surrounding areas of level\u00a02 would be a factor to be taken into account when assessing his culpability.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <span lang=\"EN-GB\">This accident could have happened if there was a degree of inattention or carelessness on the part of the appellant for his own safety: for instance, if he banged his shins on one of the scaffolding poles, walked into one of the poles and tripped over or fell from the insufficiently-fenced side of the working platform. It therefore behoved the appellant to keep a careful lookout. The fact of the matter was that the appellant had not looked at where he was going and this was the immediate cause of the accident. It was because of the appellant\u2019s neglect in this regard that he failed to notice the edge of the working platform and thus stepped off the edge of the platform. We find that the appellant was negligent in failing to observe the ordinary care which an ordinary prudent person would have taken for his own safety. Blameworthiness was there and to a higher degree than that of the respondents as employer and occupier of the site respectively. Accordingly, we apportion liability at 40% to the respondents and 60% to the appellant by way of contributory negligence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now come to the remaining issue in this appeal. The judge\u2019s finding, that (a)\u00a0the appellant was not wearing a safety helmet and (b)\u00a0the position in which he landed on the vessel\u2019s deck, was consistent with his having fallen off ladder\u00a03 is, with respect, neither here nor there. First, we cannot readily draw any conclusion from the fact that the appellant was not wearing a safety helmet when he fell, as the appellant\u2019s head injuries were minimal according to the medical reports. The head injuries did not render him a quadriplegic. Instead, he became a quadriplegic because he broke his spine as a result of the fall. Second, the judge regarded the undisputed evidence that the appellant was found lying on his back as a strong indicator supporting the respondents\u2019 case that the appellant fell off ladder\u00a03. This was understandable given the judge\u2019s finding that the spot on the level\u00a02 working platform where the appellant fell was fenced or barricaded. But we have in this judgment come to a different conclusion. In any case, accidents because of their very nature often happen in the most unlikely of ways. It is common experience that people sometimes perform feats by accident that they are unable to duplicate with deliberation. The judge herself acknowledged that the appellant could have been flailing around as he tried to save himself by grabbing something on the way down. This could have explained why he landed on his back.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Given the conclusion reached in this appeal, there was no need for this court to consider the appellant\u2019s fall-back claim for relief under s\u00a033 of the WCA.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For these reasons, we allow the appeal to the extent that the appellant is entitled to 40% of the damages that are ultimately assessed as payable to him by the respondents. As for the costs here and below, we are of the view that the appellant is the successful party despite the apportionment of liability. The point is that the appellant\u2019s claim is not defeated by a finding of some fault on the part of the appellant in the light of s\u00a03(1) of the Contributory Negligence and Personal Injuries Act (Cap\u00a054, 2002\u00a0Rev Ed). In the court below, the judge had found that the appellant was entirely to blame for the accident. In contrast, we have found that he should bear only 60% of the blame. Accordingly, in the exercise of our discretion, we award the appellant full costs for this appeal and for the trial below. The security for costs furnished by the appellant is to be returned to the appellant or his solicitors.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n",
