He argued that, in any event, it was unconscionable for the defendants to raise any objections to the authenticity of the Documents and that such objections constituted an abuse of the process of the court; in the premises, he argued that the defendants ought to be estopped from raising such objections.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The other main plank relied upon by Mr\u00a0Shanmugam was that since HR filed his SAEIC together with the attached documents, the authenticity of these documents was no longer in issue; only the truth or veracity of the documents remained to be determined.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is apposite to note, at this juncture, that even if the plaintiffs succeeded in the present appeal on the issue relating to the authenticity of the Documents, they had to surmount one further legal hurdle. Indeed, this particular hurdle has already been mentioned above but bears repeating. The plaintiffs had also to prove, to the satisfaction of the present court, that the contents of the Documents were true. In particular, they had to surmount the objection stemming from the rule against hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn, now, to consider each of the main planks relied upon by counsel for the plaintiffs with regard to the issue of the authenticity of the Documents before proceeding to consider the objection stemming from the rule against hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The plaintiffs\u2019 first argument</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first main plank derives, firstly (and examining the situation from the perspective of dealing with documentary evidence), from a series of correspondence between the lawyers for the plaintiffs on the one hand and the lawyers for Cameron and Stork on the other.</span><a id=\"_ftnref6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn6\" name=\"_ftnref6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 6]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">On close examination of this correspondence, however, we are unable to find that there had been an agreement as such between the parties that the Documents would be admitted into evidence. On the contrary, there is nothing in this series of correspondence which suggests that counsel for the defendants had in fact resiled from, or compromised in any way, the <i>objections</i> that they had taken during the trial itself and which we refer to in more detail below (at [68]\u2013[71]). In their written submissions, the plaintiffs do refer to the facsimile from <i>their own</i> lawyers dated 5\u00a0November 2004 to the defendants\u2019 lawyers.</span><a id=\"_ftnref7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn7\" name=\"_ftnref7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 7]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">However, the <i>plaintiffs\u2019</i> own understanding of the situation does <i>not necessarily</i> translate into an agreement on the part of all the parties concerned \u2013 especially when we take into account their obvious self-interest in the matter. It is true that the facsimile from counsel for Stork dated 6\u00a0November 2004</span><a id=\"_ftnref8\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn8\" name=\"_ftnref8\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 8]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">might lend some ostensible support to the plaintiffs\u2019 arguments in this regard. However, this last-mentioned response is not, in our view, unambiguous and, in any event, there does not appear to be a similar response from counsel for Cameron.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first main plank of the plaintiffs\u2019 argument also derives from the following exchange during the second day of the trial which, because of its obvious importance, is set out in full as follows:</span><a id=\"_ftnref9\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn9\" name=\"_ftnref9\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 9]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan [Counsel for Stork]: I have no further questions.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her Honour: Re-examination?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra [Counsel for the plaintiffs]: Your Honour, just one point. Under <i>order\u00a027, rule\u00a04</i>, the \u201cAdmission and production of documents specified in list of documents\u201d, specifically in rule 4 it says:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cSubject to paragraph\u00a0(2) and without prejudice to the right of a party to object to the admission in evidence of any document, a party on whom a list of documents is served in pursuance of any provision of order 24 or any order made thereunder shall, unless the court otherwise orders, be deemed to admit --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that any document described in the list as an original document ...</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that any document described herein as a copy is a true copy.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">So the authenticity question insofar as I have no objections, therefore I will now, if my learned friend says he challenges that authenticity, which they have never said --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her Honour: He has lost the right by now to do that.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: Yes, he has lost his right. He is making a separate point.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: He is making a separate point.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: He is making a point really on -- I need to know the parameters here of interpretation or authenticity.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: What he really means <i>if</i> he has given up the right <i>under order\u00a027, rule\u00a04</i>, you don't have to bring the maker.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: Yes, I don\u2019t have to bring the maker.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: But you still need to prove the document in the sense that you have to bring somebody who knows of the document so that they can cross-examine the person on the document.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: Very well.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: So somebody who was involved and can give some personal knowledge is really somebody who you should bring.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: Very well, Your Honour. In that case, may I have five minutes to confer with my clients before I just resume the re-examination of the witness on those issues that he is able to speak of directly, because there are some issues that he can, clearly on the operational aspect, there are some issues that he can\u2019t clearly as he said he wasn\u2019t involved in it. So I just want to segregate those two points, speak to my instructing solicitors on this matter and then commence re-examination, if I could have --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: All right, we will take a five-minute recess.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Chandra: Until quarter to 4, Your Honour?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: Yes.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, however, the exchange set out above ought not be read in isolation. In other words, it must be read in the <i>context</i> of the proceedings as a whole. We would observe that if this particular argument by the plaintiffs is to succeed, there must be clear evidence of an agreement by the parties concerned to the effect that the authenticity of the documents in question was not an issue. We do not see this arising at all from the exchange set out above. Indeed, the Judge appears to have nevertheless alluded to the fact that authenticity was still an issue. In any event, the focus appeared to be on O\u00a027 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2004\u00a0Rev Ed), which we find is not ultimately relevant in the context of the present proceedings (see [73] below). On the whole, in fact, this particular exchange appears to be rather ambiguous, at best.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the contrary, what clinches the case, so to speak, against the plaintiffs in so far as this particular argument is concerned is the fact that we find <i>the precise opposite</i> occurring in the form of <i>clear</i> <i>objections taken by the defendants and which were noted by the Judge herself</i> (see generally below at [72]). Further, in so far as the exchange last quoted was concerned, this took place on the <i>same day</i> of trial as the <i>objections</i> taken by the defendants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the plaintiffs also briefly relied, as noted above, on a broader argument that had its source in the concept of fairness in general and the doctrine of estoppel in particular. In this regard, he relied on the Australian High Court decision of <i>The Commonwealth of Australia v Verwayen</i> (1990) 170\u00a0CLR 394.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The doctrine of estoppel, like all legal doctrines, must be proved. It is not even clear that counsel for the plaintiffs was utilising the doctrine proper although he was certainly relying on the <i>spirit</i> underlying it \u2013 which is to prevent unconscionable conduct. This much is, in our view, clear from his reference to an alleged abuse of the process of court by the defendants. With respect, however, the argument was run too vaguely and altogether too briefly. As for the argument from fairness, this is dealt with when we consider a similar argument in a related context below (at [40]\u2013[65]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Most importantly, however, is the fact that <i>the Judge herself</i> made a clear finding to the effect that the parties had <i>not</i> entered into the agreement so strenuously argued for by Mr\u00a0Shanmugam. As she put it, \u201c[t]here was also <i>no agreement</i> to dispense with formal proof of the claims for damages\u201d [emphasis added] (GD at [145]). Indeed, as we shall see below, the Judge actually held <i>the precise opposite \u2013</i> that the defendants had, instead, <i>objected to</i> the introduction of the Documents (see [68]\u2013[71] below). Mr\u00a0Shanmugam, however, sought to argue that the Judge had somehow been mistaken and had missed what in his view was the crucial exchange set out above. In the first instance, we have found that that exchange did not support the argument that there had indeed been an agreement between the parties with regard to the introduction of the Documents. More to the point, it is highly unlikely, in our view, that the Judge could have overlooked this very crucial point, dealing with a very crucial part of the case. Mr\u00a0Shanmugam argued that this was possible in the light of the length of the proceedings. We are of the view that the length of the proceedings as well as the volume of documents are not material considerations in this regard. A trial judge is present throughout the proceedings and is fully cognisant of all that has transpired. More importantly, the trial judge constantly sifts the substantive legal wheat from the irrelevant legal as well as extra-legal chaff and notes the former down accordingly. Indeed, it is <i>precisely</i> because this issue was a crucial one that all the relevant facts that had led the Judge to the conclusion she arrived at must have been of <i>especial significance</i> to her <i>in the midst of</i> the lengthy proceedings themselves. She would have in fact been the <i>best</i> person to assess whether or not the defendants had objected to the Documents simply because she was, as we have mentioned, present throughout the proceedings. In the circumstances, the plaintiffs\u2019 argument on this particular issue must fail.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The plaintiffs\u2019 second argument</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The second main plank of the plaintiffs\u2019 case with respect to the issue of the authenticity of the Documents centred on the Malaysian Federal Court decision of <i>Palaniappa Chettiar v Tan Jan</i> <nobr>[1965] 1 MLJ 182</nobr> (\u201c<i>Palaniappa Chettiar</i>\u201d). In that case, Thomson\u00a0LP held that a document which was exhibited to an affidavit of evidence-in-chief (\u201cAEIC\u201d) should be treated as though it were copied out in the affidavit itself. Counsel for the plaintiffs therefore argued that, in the present proceedings, the Documents were admitted into evidence when the SAEIC was filed in court and tendered through its deponent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This argument was attractive at first blush. However, on closer scrutiny, we found that it could not apply to the present proceedings and, in particular, that <i>Palaniappa Chettiar</i> was not in fact applicable in the context of the present case. Let us elaborate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What <i>Palaniappa Chettiar</i> decided was that where the deponent of an AEIC signed the affidavit concerned, he or she was also deemed to have signed the documents exhibited to it as well. In other words, the <i>contents</i> of the AEIC would be deemed to <i>include</i> the <i>contents</i> of the documents exhibited to it as well. <i>However</i>, the crucial issue before this court was <i>quite different</i>; it concerned the issue as to whether or not <i>the actual documents themselves were admitted into evidence together with the affidavit itself</i>. If, in fact, documents such as those involved in the present appeal were <i>automatically</i> admitted <i>into evidence</i> by virtue of the fact that they were exhibited to the affidavit concerned <i>without more</i>, this would, in our view, <i>enable parties to circumvent the relevant rules and principles embodied within the Evidence Act (Cap\u00a097, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed) which are intended to ensure that only the best evidence is admitted into evidence</i>. Indeed, such an argument, if accepted, would, with respect, make <i>a mockery of</i> the rules and principles in the Evidence Act. In an extreme situation, <i>wholly bogus documents</i> could be admitted simply because the deponent of the affidavit had exhibited them to the affidavit itself. To be sure, the documents concerned would constitute part of his AEIC, but <i>whether or not such documents could be admitted into evidence as authentic documents would depend on whether or not they satisfied the requisite criteria contained in the Evidence Act or fell within the relevant exceptions contained therein</i>. To take another (and less extreme) situation, if the plaintiffs\u2019 argument is accepted, then the deponent of the affidavit could exhibit <i>any manner</i> of document. In such a situation, is the court to <i>assume</i> that such documents have satisfied the legal requirements under the Evidence Act? Is not the other party (the defendants in the present proceedings) legally entitled to object to the authenticity of the Documents and require that they be admitted <i>in accordance with the proper rules of evidence</i>? After all, do not the rules and principles of evidence (particularly as embodied within the Evidence Act) serve a <i>purpose</i> (indeed, an <i>important</i> purpose)? These rules and principles are not, in other words, mere window-dressing. Indeed, it would be appropriate at this juncture to set out briefly the rationale of the relevant rules and principles themselves in order to demonstrate how important a role they play in the administration of justice.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The relevant provisions are ss\u00a063 to 67 of the Evidence Act, although the focus in the present proceedings will be on ss\u00a066 and 67. The provisions themselves (without the accompanying Explanation(s) and/or Illustration(s)) read as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Proof of contents of documents</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>63.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</strong> The contents of documents may be proved by primary or by secondary evidence.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Primary evidence</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>64.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</strong> Primary evidence means the document itself produced for the inspection of the court.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Secondary evidence</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>65.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</strong> Secondary evidence means and includes \u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 certified copies given under the provisions hereinafter contained;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 copies made from the original by electronic, electrochemical, chemical, magnetic, mechanical, optical, telematic or other technical processes, which in themselves ensure the accuracy of the copy, and copies compared with such copies;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>c</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 copies made from or compared with the original;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>d</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 counterparts of documents as against the parties who did not execute them;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>e</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 oral accounts of the contents of a document given by some person who has himself seen it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Proof of documents by primary evidence</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>66.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</strong> Documents must be proved by primary evidence except in the cases mentioned in section\u00a067.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Cases in which secondary evidence relating to documents may be given</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>67.</strong>\u2014(1)\u00a0Secondary evidence may be given of the existence, condition or contents of a document admissible in evidence in the following cases:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the original is shown or appears to be in the possession or power of \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the person against whom the document is sought to be proved;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(ii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 any person out of reach of or not subject to the process of the court; or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 any person legally bound to produce it,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">and when, after the notice mentioned in section\u00a068, such person does not produce it;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the existence, condition or contents of the original have been proved to be admitted in writing by the person against whom it is proved or by his representative in interest;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>c</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the original has been destroyed or lost, or when the party offering evidence of its contents cannot for any other reason not arising from his own default or neglect produce it in reasonable time;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>d</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the original is of such a nature as not to be easily movable;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>e</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the original is a public document within the meaning of section\u00a076;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>f</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the original is a document of which a certified copy is permitted by this Act or by any other law in force for the time being in Singapore to be given in evidence;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>g</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the originals consist of numerous accounts or other documents which cannot conveniently be examined in court, and the fact to be proved is the general result of the whole collection.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In cases (<i>a</i>), (<i>c</i>) and (<i>d</i>), any secondary evidence of the contents of the document is admissible.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In case (<i>b</i>), the written admission is admissible.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In case (<i>e</i>) or (<i>f</i>), a certified copy of the document but no other kind of secondary evidence is admissible.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In case (<i>g</i>), evidence may be given as to the general result of the documents by any person who has examined them and who is skilled in the examination of such documents.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The provisions set out above (in particular, s\u00a066) have, as their core rationale, the aim of ensuring that the <i>best evidence</i> is available before the court (see GD at [146] as well as <i>Sarkar\u2019s Law of Evidence</i> (Wadhwa and Company, 15th\u00a0Ed, 1999) vol\u00a01 (\u201c<i>Sarkar</i>\u201d) at pp\u00a01059, 1073, 1078\u20131079 and <i>Sir\u00a0John Woodroffe &amp; Syed Amir Ali\u2019s Law of Evidence</i> (Butterworths, 17th\u00a0Ed, 2001) vol\u00a0II (\u201c<i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i>\u201d) at pp\u00a02849\u20132850 and 2884). That is why the general rule (again, in s\u00a066) is that all documents must be proved by primary evidence, with \u201cprimary evidence\u201d being defined (in s\u00a064) as meaning \u201c<i>the document itself</i> produced for the inspection of the court\u201d [emphasis added]. Section\u00a066 does, however, expressly provide for an exception where <i>secondary</i> evidence might be given <i>in the circumstances set out in s\u00a067</i>. Applying these straightforward principles to the present appeal, it is clear, first, that the requirements in s\u00a066 have not been satisfied. At <i>no</i> stage in the proceedings before the Judge were the <i>original documents</i> produced. Secondly, it is equally clear that the requirements in s\u00a067 were not satisfied either.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At this juncture, because Mr\u00a0Shanmugam did make some passing reference to the parol evidence rule as embodied within ss\u00a093 and 94 of the Evidence Act, we need to observe (also in passing) that this last-mentioned set of provisions must be <i>distinguished from</i> those presently considered (<i>viz</i>, ss\u00a063\u201367 of the Evidence Act). It is true that there could be some overlap or even coincidence where the evidence concerned falls within the purview of ss\u00a093 and 94. However, absent such a <i>factual</i> coincidence, these last-mentioned provisions do in fact serve quite different purposes (and see, for example, <i>Sarkar</i> at p\u00a01074). As a leading textbook also puts it (see <i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i> at pp\u00a02886\u20132887):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The provisions [<i>sic</i>] of s\u00a064 [of the Indian Evidence Act, which is the equivalent of s\u00a066 of the Singapore Evidence Act] must be distinguished from those of s\u00a091 [of the Indian Evidence Act, which is the equivalent of s\u00a093 of the Singapore Evidence Act]. The latter deals with matters which the parties have put in writing or which the law requires to be in writing. In such cases, except where secondary evidence may be given, the document is an exclusive record of that which it embodies. The parties are not at liberty to resort to other evidence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">All that the present section [<i>viz</i>, s\u00a064 of the Indian Evidence Act] says is that if it is desired to prove the contents of a document, the document itself must, save in certain exceptional cases, be produced. But, if a writing does not fall within either of the classes already described, no reason exists, why it should exclude oral evidence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Of impracticality, unfairness and balance</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the plaintiffs sought \u2013 indirectly, at least \u2013 to suggest that it was both impractical as well as unfair to expect the plaintiffs to satisfy the above-mentioned provisions, especially since the number of documents was voluminous. However, such arguments from practicality and fairness must have a legal basis. In fact, the legal basis that is relevant to the present proceedings appear to point in the <i>opposite</i> direction in so far as the plaintiffs are concerned. As we have seen, the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act (in particular, ss\u00a066 and 67 thereof) indicate that the plaintiffs have not in fact satisfied the requisite legal requirements from an evidential perspective. Indeed, in so far as the concept of fairness is concerned, the whole rationale underlying these various provisions is to ensure that fairness results to <i>both</i> parties, including (here) <i>the defendants</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note, however, that our Evidence Act was promulgated in its original form over one hundred years ago. The quantity and quality of documents has, unsurprisingly, increased as well as changed in the interim. Hence, the arguments that counsel for the plaintiffs have raised in so far as practicality and fairness are concerned cannot be dismissed out of hand. They embody the classic tensions that often run through most areas of the law. One is the tension between efficiency and fairness. However, the two are not incompatible. In fact, the former is itself one conception of fairness. Further, fairness is, as we have alluded to in the preceding paragraph, a concept that ought to result to both parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another tension is to give effect both to the original intention underlying the statutory provisions concerned as well as to the changed circumstances which were not (in the nature of things) envisaged or contemplated at the time those provisions were enacted. It is true that it is often the case that both are irreconcilable. One issue that arises is whether or not this is the situation here. If so, then this court must leave any reform to the Singapore parliament itself.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Put simply in the context of the present proceedings, the tension appears to be as follows: How should the court give effect to the underlying rationale of (in particular) ss\u00a066 and 67 of the Evidence Act on the one hand, as well as ensure, on the other hand, that by giving effect to this rationale, inefficiency and unfairness do not ensue as a result? This latter consideration \u2013 not, perhaps, present at the time the Evidence Act was <i>originally</i> introduced in the local context \u2013 should not, in our view, be ignored because to do so would be tantamount to ignoring the practical realities in a changed (and ever-changing) legal milieu.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 By way of preliminary observation, although it is true that a copious number of documents were involved in the present proceedings, it is equally true that any problems of authenticity could have been surmounted (as they often are in cases of this nature) by an agreed bundle of documents, although (unfortunately) this was not the case here. However, it must be emphasised that whilst formal proof of the documents concerned is dispensed with by an agreed bundle of documents, the <i>truth</i> of their contents will still have to be proved in the absence of any agreement or admission to the contrary. In this regard, the observations in the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Goh Ya Tian v Tan Song Gou</i> [1980\u20131981] SLR\u00a0578 at 581, [12] are too broad inasmuch as they suggest that the proof of the truth of the contents of the documents concerned is also dispensed with and, to that extent, ought not to be followed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Indeed, when counsel for Stork, Mr\u00a0Alvin Yeo\u00a0SC, was posed a question as to practicality when so many documents were involved, he referred precisely to the solution in the form of an agreed bundle of documents; where there was no such agreed bundle, which situation he conceded was the right of any party in litigation to insist upon, Mr\u00a0Yeo argued that parties (again, pursuant to their respective rights in litigation) had the prerogative of objecting to any documents tendered \u2013 with any sanctions lying in the sphere of an order for costs. As we explain below, we are of the view that this last-mentioned point is (subject to the issue of timing) generally correct. If the parties cannot come to the more felicitous arrangement where there is in fact an agreed bundle, then each must face the consequences of a potentially \u201cmessier\u201d situation in so far as the admission of documents into evidence is concerned. Unfortunately, this was precisely the situation here \u2013 but with a slight (albeit vitally significant) difference. The defendants were within their legal rights to object to the Documents tendered by the plaintiffs. But we did not perceive counsel for the plaintiffs to be arguing that the Damages Bundle should have been admitted on the basis that no objections had in fact been taken by the defendants in the instant case to it. As we have seen, counsel for the plaintiffs relied, instead, on the argument to the effect that the defendants had in fact agreed to admit the Damages Bundle, which was a somewhat different argument and indeed imposed, in our view, a heavier onus of proof on the plaintiffs and which we did not accept.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The plaintiffs were therefore under at least a <i>prima facie</i> legal duty to comply with the requirements of the relevant provisions under the Evidence Act. They did not. The relevant statutory provisions are there for a purpose. However, as we have already pointed out above, an insistence \u2013 without more \u2013 on a strict compliance with these provisions might lead to undesirable practical consequences. Is there a <i>balanced</i> approach that enables the objectives of such provisions to be achieved without deleterious practical effects?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, a balanced approach might entail the following principles. However, because we were <i>not</i> (unfortunately, in our view) addressed <i>fully</i> on them (<i>cf</i>, especially, [66] below), they are proffered only by way of preliminary observations only. More importantly, any <i>definitive</i> approach adopted would have <i>wide-ranging</i> <i>implications</i> in an extremely important area of legal practice; hence, there is a need for a more considered hearing before a definitive approach is laid down by this court. It is therefore hoped that this court will hear fuller arguments in a future decision. Nevertheless, we do not feel that, the point having been necessarily raised as an integral part of the present proceedings, we can simply ignore it. However, we would also like to emphasise the fact that <i>even if</i> the principles we are about to set out by way of an exploratory analysis, so to speak, are in fact applicable (and hence applied) to the present case, it would make <i>no difference</i> to the result we have arrived at \u2013 as will be evident from our analysis below (at [67]\u2013[73]). Given the fact that the difficulties centring on the application of the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act were in effect raised by the parties in the present case, we feel that our (albeit preliminary) views not only provide a point of departure for a future decision of this court but also (if we may be permitted this musical analogy) constitute (in part at least) a closing bar of sorts to what would otherwise have been an awkward and jarring pause in a movement initiated (but unfinished) by the parties themselves. We now turn, therefore, briefly to these views.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Firstly, we must begin with the general principle that the party who wishes to introduce the documents concerned into evidence must comply with the salient provisions of the Evidence Act (and see, for example, the Indian Privy Council decision of <i>Krishna Kishori Chowdhrani v Kishori Lal Roy</i> (1887) 14\u00a0IA 71). To begin with, any other premise would ignore the clear provisions of the Act. Worse still, it would be a signal to parties to be indisciplined in so far as the introduction of documents is concerned. It would then be the thin end of the procedural wedge and might even lead to the fraudulent introduction of documents. The fact that there is another legal barrier in the form of testing the truth of the contents of documents is no excuse for lowering the barrier in relation to the authenticity of documents under the salient provisions of the Evidence Act, and which would itself constitute an important threshold safeguard.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, however, it is also important to ensure that \u2013 at the other extreme \u2013 parties who wish (in <i>good faith</i>) to introduce documents to support their case are not put through an unnecessary procedural treadmill. An extreme example would be a situation where a party has to rely upon thousands of documents to establish his or her case in complex litigation.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There is also a broader policy reason why an overly punctilious insistence on compliance with the provisions in the Evidence Act for its own sake is undesirable. If it is the case that a party is placed with the positive burden of producing original documents or calling the maker of the documents sought to be introduced into evidence, this would entail (particularly in situations akin to that outlined in the preceding paragraph) an enormous waste of court time and resources in the event that the party seeking to introduce the documents concerned is seeking to do so in good faith. That being said, it is of course open to the opposing party to <i>object</i> to the admission of the documents concerned and insist that the other party produce the original documents or the maker of the documents concerned. That is his or her prerogative. But what if such an objection is frivolous or vexatious? It is our view that if it can be demonstrated that this is in fact the case, then sanctions can be imposed by way of an order for <i>costs</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are therefore of the view that whilst, as an important point of departure, a party seeking to introduce documents into evidence ought to comply with the provisions in the Evidence Act, if these documents are in fact marked and admitted into evidence without that party in fact satisfying the requirements in the Evidence Act <i>and</i> where there has been <i>no objection taken by the other party at that particular point in time</i>, then that other party <i>cannot</i> object to the admission of the said documents later. This last-mentioned proposition applies, of course, in an <i>a fortiori</i> manner when the party who had not objected to the introduction of the documents subsequently <i>cross-examines</i> the relevant witnesses on these documents in an attempt to discredit the truth of the contents stated therein. We note that whilst this particular argument was in fact raised in the plaintiffs\u2019 <i>written submissions</i>, they were <i>not</i> the <i>direct</i> focus during oral argument before this court. This particular argument was addressed <i>indirectly</i> inasmuch as counsel for the plaintiffs emphasised (as we have noted above) the argument from both impracticality and unfairness. However, if at all, this would have constituted the <i>legal basis</i> for the much more general argument just referred to. As a result, however, this particular point was not really (let alone effectively) addressed by all counsel concerned. More importantly, the extremely important issue as to how a <i>balance</i> was to be achieved in the light of the presence of the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act was not addressed by counsel for the parties. This was indeed the much more important (and broader) legal canvas of which this point from objecting to the introduction of documents into evidence (although an important point) is only a part.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We pause here to note that the approach suggested in the preceding paragraph relating to the fact as well as time of objecting to the introduction of documents is in fact supported by an extremely lengthy line of Indian case law. Bearing in mind the fact that the Singapore Evidence Act (as already noted) had its roots in the Indian Evidence Act, these authorities are of no inconsiderable persuasive value if they are otherwise consistent with general logic, principle as well as justice and fairness, and are not inconsistent with the socio-economic mores of Singapore itself. As just noted, the number of Indian decisions is enormous (and see generally <i>Sarkar</i> at pp\u00a01076 and 1084 as well as <i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i> at pp\u00a02855, 2860\u20132861, 2876, 2900\u20132901 and 2902), and we can but touch on some illustrative cases only. Significantly, none of these foremost textbooks on the law of evidence avoids the analysis of the equivalent of ss\u00a063\u201367 of the Evidence Act; on the contrary, the discussion and analysis in these works is both scholarly and perceptive <i>and</i> includes the discussion of this point <i>without any sense of contradiction at all</i> (see generally <i>Sarkar</i> at ch\u00a0V and <i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i> at ch\u00a05). This supports the approach adopted here to the effect that a <i>balance</i> can (and ought to be) struck between upholding the rationale and integrity of ss\u00a063\u201367 of the Evidence Act on the one hand and achieving a practical and workable result on the other. Suffice it to state that these cases just mentioned have one basic theme that is embodied within the following words by Sir\u00a0George Rankin, delivering the judgment of the Board in the Indian Privy Council decision of <i>Gopal Das v Sri Thakurji</i> AIR 1943 Privy Council 83, as follows (at 87):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where the objection to be taken is not that the document is in itself inadmissible but that the mode of proof put forward is irregular or insufficient it is essential that the objection should be taken at the trial before the document is marked as an exhibit and admitted to the record. A party cannot lie by until the case comes before a Court of appeal and then complain for the first time of the mode of proof. A strictly formal proof might or might not have been forthcoming had it been insisted on at the trial. In the present instance, it does not appear that the objection was taken at the proper time or that it would have been of any avail had it been taken.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53</span><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span></i> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Although the concepts of primary and secondary evidence as embodied within the provisions of the Evidence Act are of fundamental importance, the principle of <i>waiver</i> might apply if no objection is raised at the point in time when the evidence concerned is adduced: see, for example, <i>A\u00a0V\u00a0S Perumal v Vadivelu Asari</i> AIR\u00a01986 Mad 341 at [5]; <i>Rama Chandra Majhi v Hambai Majhi</i> 65\u00a0(1988) CLT 586 at 593; <i>The Land Acquisition Officer, Vijayawada Thermal Station v Nutalapati Venkata Rao</i> AIR\u00a01991\u00a0AP 31 at [19]; as well as <i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i> at pp\u00a02904\u20132905. On the other hand, a failure to object could simply be construed as <i>an admission</i> that the requirements under the Evidence Act were complied with: see, for example, <i>State of Rajasthan v Jeo Raj</i> AIR\u00a01990\u00a0Raj 90 at [7].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reference may also be made, for example, to the Indian Supreme Court decisions of <i>Haji Mohammad Ekramul Haq v The State of West Bengal</i> AIR\u00a01959\u00a0SC 488 and <i>P\u00a0C\u00a0Purushothama Reddiar v S\u00a0Perumal</i> AIR\u00a01972\u00a0SC 608; the more recent Indian state decision of <i>S\u00a0A\u00a0Quddus v S\u00a0Veerappa</i> AIR\u00a01994\u00a0Kant 20; as well as (closer to home, so to speak) the Privy Council decision on appeal from the Court of Appeal of the Federated Malay States of <i>Bhagat Ram v Khetu Ram</i> AIR\u00a01929 Privy Council 110.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There has, however, been some suggestion that whilst the concept of objecting is relevant, the document concerned must also satisfy the criteria laid down for secondary documents under s\u00a065 of the Evidence Act (see, for example, <i>Kalyan Singh v Smt Chhoti</i> AIR\u00a01973\u00a0Raj 263, especially at [15]). The difficulty with such an approach is, however, that by its very terms, s\u00a065 does <i>not</i> appear to limit secondary documents <i>solely</i> to the categories listed therein.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We believe the approach we have outlined above would best achieve the balance required between ensuring that the best evidence is before the court without simultaneously burdening the party seeking to introduce the documents concerned <i>unnecessarily</i>. It would also ensure that the court\u2019s and the parties\u2019 valuable time is not wasted. The other party is of course free to object to the introduction of such documents at any time before the said documents are actually marked and admitted into evidence. If the objections are in fact effected frivolously or vexatiously, there can (as already mentioned) be sanctions imposed \u2013 principally in the form of an appropriate order as to costs. We would, however, strongly urge parties to have recourse \u2013 as far as is possible \u2013 to an agreed bundle of documents, leaving out only those significant documents that are the subject of dispute and ensuring that they are clearly objected to, at which time they will need to satisfy the relevant criteria laid down in the Evidence Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We pause here to observe, parenthetically, that given the fact that the relevant provisions in the Evidence Act (especially ss\u00a063\u201367) had been enacted over a century ago, there might be some justification for further legislative refinement. In this regard, we observe that the \u201cbest evidence rule\u201d has been eroded even in other jurisdictions over the intervening years. In particular, and this is particularly germane having regard to what we have just stated at the outset of this paragraph, one major issue that arises is whether or not this particular rule has kept pace, as it were, with changes in context. As was aptly put by the authors of a leading Canadian textbook on the law of evidence, \u201cthe rules of evidence should reflect the practices of modern society\u201d (see John Sopinka, Sidney N\u00a0Lederman &amp; Alan W\u00a0Bryant, <i>The Law of Evidence in Canada</i> (Butterworths, 1992) at p\u00a0940). More specifically, in another leading (here, English) textbook, it is observed thus of the \u201cbest evidence rule\u201d (see <i>Phipson on Evidence</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 16th\u00a0Ed, 2005) at para\u00a07-39):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">About the beginning of the nineteenth century, however, a notable reaction set in; and from that date forward, \u2026 the decisions of the courts show <i>a persistent rescission from the \u201cbest evidence\u201d principle.</i> [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Further, this particular work concludes thus (at para\u00a07-45):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Thus, it would appear that the best evidence rule has, <i>in civil cases at least</i>, been <i>consigned to the history books</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>modern</i> approach towards the \u201cbest evidence rule\u201d, is in fact encapsulated within the following words of Balcombe\u00a0LJ in the English Court of Appeal decision in <i>Ventouris v Mountain (No\u00a02)</i> <nobr>[1992] 1 WLR 887</nobr> at 899:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The modern tendency in civil proceedings is to admit all relevant evidence, and the judge should be trusted to give only proper weight to evidence which is not the best evidence \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In a similar vein, in an earlier decision of the English Divisional Court in <i>Kajala v Noble</i> (1982) 75\u00a0Cr\u00a0App\u00a0R 149, Ackner\u00a0LJ (as he then was) observed thus (at 152):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The old rule, that a party must produce the best evidence that the nature of the case will allow, and that any less good evidence is to be excluded, has gone by the board long ago. The <i>only remaining instance</i> of it is that, if an original document is available in one\u2019s hands, one must produce it; that one cannot give secondary evidence by producing a copy. Nowadays we <i>do not confine</i> ourselves to the best evidence. <i>We admit all relevant evidence. The goodness or badness of it goes only to weight, and not to admissibility</i>: Garton <i>v.</i> Hunter [1969] 1\u00a0All E.R. 451, <i>per</i> Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0M.R. at 453e; see also <i>Archbold, Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice</i> (40th\u00a0ed.), para.\u00a01001. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>However</i>, even \u201cthe only remaining instance\u201d referred to in the quotation in the preceding paragraph was \u201cdiluted\u201d in the English Divisional Court decision of <i>Regina v Governor of Pentonville Prison, Ex parte Osman</i> <nobr>[1990] 1 WLR 277</nobr>, where Lloyd\u00a0LJ, delivering the judgment of the court, observed thus (at 308):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">What is meant by a party having a document available in his hands? We would say that it means that a party who has the original of the document with him in court, or could have it in court without any difficulty. In such a case, if he refuses to produce the original and can give no reasonable explanation, the court would infer the worst. The copy should be excluded. If, in taking that view, we are cutting down still further what remains of the best evidence rule, we are content. On the facts, the magistrate was entitled to hold that the prosecution had given a reasonable explanation for the absence of such originals as they failed to produce.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It is also significant, in our view, that the learned lord justice did (on a more general level) in fact re-emphasise the emaciation of the \u201cbest evidence rule\u201d a little earlier on in his judgment (at 308), as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]his court would be more than happy to say goodbye to the best evidence rule. We accept that it served an important purpose in the days of parchment and quill pens. But since the invention of carbon paper and, still more, the photocopier and the telefacsimile machine, that purpose has largely gone.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The situation appears, in fact, to have been taken a stage further, with \u201cthe only remaining instance\u201d referred to at [59] above being recently <i>rejected</i> by Jonathan Parker\u00a0LJ in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Springsteen v Masquerade Music Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] EMLR 25</nobr> (with whom Laws and Waller\u00a0LJJ agreed); in the learned judge\u2019s words (at [80]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">For my part, I would not even recognise the continuing existence of that \u201cremaining instance\u201d of the application of \u201cthe old rule\u201d. In my judgment, the \u201cobligation\u201d of a party who has a document to produce the original in evidence is founded not on any rule of law but is simply a reflection of the fact that a party to whom a document is available will by reason of that very fact be unable to account to the satisfaction of the court for his non-production of it when inviting the court to admit secondary evidence of its contents, with the practical consequence that the court will attach no weight to the secondary evidence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 And, in a more general vein, the Jonathan Parker\u00a0LJ observed thus (at [85]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In my judgment, the time has now come when it can be said with confidence that the best evidence rule, long on its deathbed, has finally expired. In every case where a party seeks to adduce secondary evidence of the contents of a document, it is a matter for the court to decide, in the light of all the circumstances of the case, what (if any) weight to attach to that evidence. Where the party seeking to adduce the secondary evidence could readily produce the document, it may be expected that (absent some special circumstances) the court will decline to admit the secondary evidence on the ground that it is worthless. At the other extreme, where the party seeking to adduce the secondary evidence genuinely cannot produce the document, it may be expected that (absent some special circumstances) the court will admit the secondary evidence and attach such weight to it as it considers appropriate in all the circumstances. In cases falling between those two extremes, it is for the court to make a judgment as to whether in all the circumstances any weight should be attached to the secondary evidence. Thus, the \u201cadmissibility\u201d of secondary evidence of the contents of documents is, in my judgment, entirely dependent upon whether or not any weight is to be attached to that evidence. And whether or not any weight is to be attached to such secondary evidence is a matter for the court to decide, taking into account all the circumstances of the particular case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Once again, we find the modern approach reiterated to the effect that, generally speaking, all evidence will be admitted, with the focus being on the <i>weight</i> to be accorded to the evidence concerned instead.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the more specific issue of <i>photocopied or xeroxed documents</i> is concerned, there are a number of Canadian decisions which are useful inasmuch as they demonstrate a <i>contrast</i> in approach. In the Provincial Court (Judicial District of Peel, Ontario) decision of <i>Regina v Lutz</i> (1978) 44\u00a0CCC (2d) 143, Langdon Prov Ct\u00a0J adopted a very pragmatic approach towards such documents that (in our view) is consistent with the modern context, as follows (at 150):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In 1978 the fact and reliability of the photostatic copying machine is a matter of such common experience that it needs no <i>person</i> to vouch for it. For example, voluminous authorities cited by counsel in argument on the issues in this case were handed to the Court in the form of obvious photostatic copies in the cases in questions [<i>sic</i>]. Counsel, I am sure, would be justifiably offended if I had requested an affidavit of comparison or notarial certificate before reading the documents submitted to the Court. The practice is one of obvious convenience and courtesy on the part of counsel for which the Court is grateful.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">That is not to say that a photostatic copying machine is foolproof or cannot be tampered with or cannot be so manipulated that it produces something other than a true copy, perhaps even indeed under appropriate circumstances, a false copy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">But surely, these are matters that go to the weight to be attributed to a photostatic copy, not to its admissibility.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In contrast, however, Dryer\u00a0J, in the British Columbia Supreme Court decision of <i>Rogers v Hill</i> (1972) 29\u00a0DLR (3d) 628, required that a photocopy of a crucial document had to comply with the usual requirements stemming from the \u201cbest evidence rule\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We find, with respect, the approach adopted in <i>Regina v Lutz</i> to be more persuasive. It is also consistent with the modern approach that has already been set out in some detail above. We nevertheless reiterate that if the relevant provisions of the Evidence Act need to be amended to take into account an approach that is more consistent with the present context and societal mores, this will need to be effected by the Singapore parliament. We have set out the important changes in both law as well as legal principles in other jurisdictions only to highlight the obvious point that we must never lapse into \u201clegal complacency\u201d and that, as far as is possible, the law will need to move with the times.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>However</i>, and returning to the possible approach we have suggested above, we must reiterate, at this juncture, the crucial point that we were <i>not</i> addressed <i>fully</i> on this approach as well as the principles associated therewith. This being the case, we will leave it to a later decision of this court, which has in fact been addressed fully, to lay down a definitive and conclusive approach. In the meantime, however, we trust that parties will try their level best to arrive at agreed bundles of documents. If that is not possible, then we would strongly urge <i>both</i> parties to pay close attention to (especially) ss\u00a063\u201367 of the Evidence Act <i>as well as to</i> objections that might be taken to the introduction of specific documents themselves.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nevertheless, as we have already pointed out above, <i>even if</i> the above principles were <i>applied</i> to the facts of the present case, we would affirm the Judge\u2019s decision on this particular issue. To begin with, we have found that there had <i>not</i> been an agreement between the plaintiffs and the defendants that the Damages Bundle be admitted into evidence. However, in accordance with the principles which we have set out above, this is not the end of the matter. The issue then arises as to whether or not the defendants had <i>objected</i> to the introduction of the Damages Bundle into evidence. At this juncture, we should point out that what constitutes an objection depends on precisely what transpired in point of fact. More importantly, as the trial judge is in the best position to determine the issue, his or her views will necessarily carry great weight with this court; indeed, on many occasions, they may even be conclusive of the issue.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having closely perused the notes of evidence, we find that the defendants <i>had</i> indeed objected to the admission of the Documents. It is true that they did not object to specific documents but it must be borne in mind that the Damages Bundle constituted 12 volumes of documents. However, it is clear that counsel for the defendants were certainly unhappy with the introduction of these documents. We will not canvass each and every occasion which constituted an objection. However, the following exchanges are both instructive and illustrative. It is highly significant, in our view, that these exchanges occurred very early on (<i>viz</i><i>, the second day of the trial</i>) \u2013 the <i>very same day</i> on which the exchange relied upon by <i>the plaintiffs</i> took place (see [28] above). <i>Indeed, these exchanges will, as we shall see, demonstrate that the defendants were clearly objecting to all the plaintiffs\u2019 documents.</i> This is, of course, the <i>very antithesis</i> of an agreement that the Documents be admitted \u2013 a point which, as we have seen, counsel for the plaintiffs was arguing vigorously for.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">69\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the first exchange, this is what transpired:</span><a id=\"_ftnref10\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn10\" name=\"_ftnref10\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 10]</span></span></span></span></a></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Gurbani [Counsel for Cameron]: Can I show you a letter. There is nobody to prove the document, and why Mr\u00a0Tan is asking questions about the document that this man says he cannot prove I do not know, if it is his case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Gurbani:\u00a0 As far as the first defendant is concerned, I am not taking this particular point, because it is quite obvious from the assignment --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her Honour: Which point? But invariably there will be documents, Your Honour.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: So what is your position on all these three documents?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan: \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 I take the point up, Your Honour, primarily --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: You are challenging the assignment?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan: \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Yes, I am challenging the assignment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: The legal effect of the assignment, of the documents?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan: \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Yes.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: But you are not challenging the authenticity of these documents?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan: \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Perret is not in a position to prove these documents either.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: Yes, so what position do you want to take? If he is not in a position to prove the document and nobody is coming to court to prove these documents, they are running --</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Mr\u00a0Tan: \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Perhaps the best way, Your Honour, is mark this for identification only, rather than as an agreed bundle.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Her\u00a0Honour: All right. We will renumber AB4, 5 and 6 to PI, P2 and P3 for identification only.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">71\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear from the above exchanges that the defendants were in fact <i>objecting</i> to <i>all</i> of the plaintiffs\u2019 documents. It appeared, indeed, to be a war of attrition amongst the parties on the documentary front as well.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">72\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 More importantly, however, <i>the Judge herself</i> was of the view that the defendants were indeed <i>objecting</i> to the introduction of the Documents. In this regard, the following observations in her judgment are more than instructive (GD at [145]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As it transpired, there was no inspection of the documents in the two supplementary lists. There were no agreed bundles of documents. The documents were produced at the trial as plaintiffs\u2019 documents <i>and objections were taken on the documents in the course of the trial</i>. I agree with counsel for both the defendants that authenticity of the documents forming the \u201cDamages Bundle\u201d was not deemed admitted under O\u00a027 r\u00a04(1) as the time limit stipulated in r\u00a04(2) to which r\u00a04(1) is subject was not triggered. There was also no agreement to dispense with formal proof of the claims for damages. If O\u00a027 r\u00a04(1) applied or if an agreed bundle had been produced at trial, there would have been no need to produce the originals nor prove the existence or execution of the documents in question. However, it should be noted that O\u00a027 r\u00a04(1) is not concerned with admissibility. It is expressly stated in r\u00a04(1) that the sub-rule does not affect the right of a party to object to the admissibility of any document. Admissibility of the plaintiffs\u2019 documents was an issue before me. I should add that in the course of the trial, certain documents in the plaintiffs\u2019 bundle of documents were marked for identification. Marking a document for identification at a stage of a trial was a means of avoiding a debate then about authenticity and/or admissibility, <i>objections having been taken to the tender of the documents</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">73\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear, in our view, that the defendants had in fact objected to the introduction of the Documents. In the circumstances, the plaintiffs ought therefore to have satisfied the requisite requirements under the Evidence Act \u2013 in particular those contained in s\u00a066. On this ground alone, the Judge was correct in finding that the Documents were not admitted into evidence. That was, of course, fatal to the plaintiffs\u2019 case in so far as the quantum of damages claimed was concerned. We should add that, in the light of this holding, it is unnecessary to delve into great detail on the possible issues arising from O\u00a027 r\u00a04 of the Rules of Court, except to note that our interpretation of O\u00a027 r\u00a04 differed from that of the Judge. At [145] of her GD, the Judge was of the view that authenticity of the Documents was not deemed admitted under O\u00a027 r\u00a04(1) as the time limit stipulated in r\u00a04(2) to which r\u00a04(1) is subject was not triggered. In our view, however, O\u00a027 r\u00a04(1) expressly provides that subject to r\u00a04(2), a party is deemed to admit the authenticity of the documents in his opponent\u2019s lists of documents. This suggests that the default position under the Rules of Court is that provided for in r\u00a04(1), namely, that a party is deemed to admit the authenticity of a document contained in his opponent\u2019s lists. That being the case, a party is generally deemed to admit authenticity unless he can bring himself within O\u00a027 r\u00a04(2) by showing that he had actually issued a notice of non-admission within the requisite window of time. Despite this, it is important to note that because we have found that the defendants had in fact objected to the Damages Bundle being introduced into evidence, it is no longer necessary to consider O\u00a027 r\u00a04.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The objection from hearsay</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">74\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to the issue of the truth or veracity of the documents in the Damages Bundle. Here, as we have already pointed out, the main objection by the defendants centres on the doctrine of hearsay (for an excellent discussion and analysis of the doctrine in the local context, see Jeffrey Pinsler, <i>Evidence, Advocacy and the Litigation Process</i> (LexisNexis, 2nd\u00a0Ed, 2003) at ch\u00a04). The plaintiffs of course argue otherwise. The underlying rationale for the rule against hearsay is set out in a leading textbook as follows (see <i>Woodroffe &amp; Amir Ali</i> ([38] <i>supra</i>) at p\u00a01726):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The purpose and reason of the hearsay rule is the key to the exceptions to it, which are mainly based on two considerations: a necessity for the evidence and a circumstantial guarantee of trustworthiness. <i>Hearsay is excluded because it is considered not sufficiently trustworthy</i>. <i>It is rejected because it lacks the sanction of the tests applied to admissible evidence, namely, the oath and cross-examination</i>. But where there are special circumstances which give a guarantee of trustworthiness to the testimony, it is admitted even though it comes from a second-hand source.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">But it has not always been a question of absolute necessity. Sometimes practical convenience, sometimes inability to get evidence of the same value from the same or other source, have been regarded as sufficient. Impossibility, convenience, expediency have all played a part. It may be impossible, or it may cause unreasonable expense or delay, to procure the attendance of a witness who, if present, the court could give direct evidence on the matter in question, and it may also be that this witness has made a statement, either written or verbal, with reference to such matter under such circumstances that the truth of this statement may reasonably be presumed. In such a case, the law, as enacted by s 32, dispenses with direct oral evidence of the fact and with the safeguard for truth provided by cross-examination, and the sanction of an oath, the probability of the statement being true depending upon other safeguards which are mentioned in the following paragraphs. The truth of the declaration is deemed to be prima facie guaranteed by the special conditions of admissibility imposed. All the eight clauses of the section are based upon the principle that the statements are of such a nature or were made under such circumstances as to guarantee their being true.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">And, in the local context, Yong Pung How\u00a0CJ, in the Singapore Court of Appeal decision of <i>Soon Peck Wah v Woon Che Chye</i> <nobr>[1998] 1 SLR 234</nobr>, observed thus (at [27]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The rationale for the hearsay principle is that the witness cannot verify the truth of the facts of which he has no personal knowledge. As the person who does have personal knowledge of the facts is not in court, the accuracy of his perception and his veracity cannot be assessed and tested in cross-examination. Such evidence is unreliable and should hence be excluded from consideration. In Singapore, the rule against hearsay is reflected in s\u00a062 Evidence Act (Cap\u00a097, 1990\u00a0Ed).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">75\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should point out at this juncture that even if the plaintiffs succeed on the various arguments as to authenticity (which we have held they do not), in order to prevail, they must <i>also</i> prevail on this particular issue. Indeed, our findings on the issue of authenticity render it, strictly speaking, unnecessary to consider the objections based on hearsay. However, in deference to the vigorous arguments rendered by counsel and, in particular, in deference to the efforts made by counsel for the plaintiffs, we turn now to consider the arguments centring on hearsay. However, we should point out at the outset that we do not find the arguments for the plaintiffs on this particular issue persuasive and we find that they therefore fail on this particular issue as well.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">76\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is trite law that even where there is an agreed bundle of documents, the <i>truth</i> of the contents of the Documents nevertheless remains at issue and is subject to, <i>inter alia</i>, objections centring on the doctrine of hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">77\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, it is also true that the rule against hearsay has come under increasing criticism and consequent calls for reform in many other jurisdictions. Significantly, perhaps, the rule itself was abolished in England in the context of civil proceedings (see, in particular, s\u00a01 of the UK Civil Evidence Act 1995 (c\u00a038) as well as <i>Cross and Tapper on Evidence</i> (LexisNexis, 10th\u00a0Ed, 2004) at ch\u00a0XIII and <i>Phipson on Evidence</i> ([57] <i>supra</i> at ch\u00a029)). But the rule against hearsay still serves an important function in the context of <i>criminal</i> proceedings (and see, especially, s\u00a0377 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap\u00a068, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed)). As we have already emphasised, however, any reform in this area, based as it must be on many policy factors, must necessarily be effected by the Singapore legislature, if at all. In other words, the plaintiffs in the present case must also be able to demonstrate that they can surmount any legal obstacles stemming from the rule against hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">78\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we have already mentioned, we are of the view that the plaintiffs fail on this ground as well. They did not bring themselves within any of the potentially applicable exceptions to the rule against hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">79\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note, first, Mr\u00a0Shanmugam\u2019s reliance on s\u00a035 of the Evidence Act (relating to computer output as evidence). However, this particular provision would appear to be more germane to the issue of <i>liability</i> (as opposed to the quantum of damages). The more salient provision would appear to be s\u00a032 of the same Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">80\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as s\u00a032 of the Evidence Act is concerned, the plaintiffs contended that the Judge had failed to consider evidence from John Sheed (the Vessel\u2019s subsea engineer) and Sean Roche (the Vessel\u2019s rig superintendent) that the makers of the documents had left JDL and their whereabouts were unknown. They went on to assert that courts often accepted that the conditions under s\u00a032 of the Evidence Act were satisfied as long as some evidence had been adduced on the unavailability of the relevant witnesses. We find the plaintiffs\u2019 arguments unpersuasive and agree with the Judge that s\u00a032(<i>b</i>) does not assist the plaintiffs in surmounting the rule against hearsay. Section\u00a032(<i>b</i>) itself reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span></b> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Statements, written or verbal, of relevant facts made by a person who is dead or who cannot be found, or who has become incapable of giving evidence, or whose attendance cannot be procured without an amount of delay or expense which under the circumstances of the case appears to the court unreasonable, are themselves relevant facts in the following cases:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">or is made in course of business;</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when the statement was made by such person in the ordinary course of business, and in particular when it consists of any entry or memorandum made by him in books kept in the ordinary course of business or in the discharge of professional duty, or of an acknowledgment written or signed by him of the receipt of money, goods, securities or property of any kind, or of a document used in commerce, written or signed by him, or of the date of a letter or other document usually dated, written or signed by him[.]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">81\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The requirements of s\u00a032(<i>b</i>) of the Evidence Act have not, in our view, been satisfied. In particular, it has been held that whether or not there is ground for holding that the relevant evidence cannot be procured without unreasonable delay or expense within the meaning of s\u00a033 of the Evidence Act is \u201cpurely a question of fact\u201d (see the Madras decision of <i>A\u00a0L\u00a0S\u00a0K\u00a0Kadappa Chetti v R\u00a0S\u00a0S\u00a0T Thirupathi Chetti</i> AIR\u00a01925\u00a0Mad 444 at 444, <i>per</i> Venkatasubba Rao\u00a0J).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">82\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In any event, we also agree with the Judge that the plaintiffs had not surmounted the considerable evidential difficulties surrounding their claim. In particular, the Judge had found that there had been no expert evidence led as to the market or resale value of the equipment lost or damaged beyond repair. She also found that the loss of income on prospective future contracts was too remote. We agree with these findings which are supported by both the facts concerned as well as the relevant legal principles she has cited. Hence, even if the plaintiffs had managed to surmount the evidentiary difficulties (which we hold they had not), their claim would still have failed on more substantive grounds. In the event, the Judge, attempting her level best on the limited evidence left available to her, awarded US$1m for the lost BOP. We find nothing untoward in this commendable attempt to do justice between the parties in very difficult circumstances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">83\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the premises, we hold that the defendants ought to succeed with regard to <i>both</i> the issues of authenticity as well as hearsay, albeit for somewhat different reasons than that adopted by the Judge.
