In any event, we agree with the Judge\u2019s holding on the substantive issues and therefore affirm her decision on this particular issue relating to the quantum of damages in general and the legal status of the Damages Bundle in particular.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The issue of indemnity between Cameron and Stork</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Issues in the present proceedings</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">84\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning now to consider issues concerning <i>liability</i>, rather than <i>quantum</i>, the key question before us was whether Cameron should be entitled to a complete indemnity from Stork against its liability to the plaintiffs. Cameron averred that the sole cause of its liability to the plaintiffs was Stork\u2019s appointment of an inexperienced and unqualified person to conduct the investigation of the Standby Slip Joint. Under the refurbishment contract, Stork had an obligation to conduct a visual and dimensional inspection, which it failed to do. Thus, Stork was clearly in breach of the refurbishment contract, and was liable to Cameron for damages, which would be the entire amount of Cameron\u2019s liability to the plaintiffs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">85\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At first instance, the Judge held that Stork was liable to \u201cindemnify\u201d Cameron for 50% of the total damages payable to the plaintiffs. Such a result is <i>not</i>, however, possible <i>if</i> it is found that, under the <i>contract</i> between <i>Cameron and Stork</i>, Stork was in breach of contract. In <i>that</i> event, Stork would be liable to indemnify Cameron for the entire amount of Cameron\u2019s liability to the plaintiffs. By the same reasoning, if it is found that, under the contract between these parties, Cameron was in breach of contract, then Cameron would be liable to indemnify Stork for the entire amount of Stork\u2019s liability to the plaintiffs. In summary, therefore, what is crucial is an examination of the precise <i>contractual</i> terms \u2013 both express and (if any) implied \u2013 between the parties in the context of the relevant factual matrix in order to ascertain which party was in breach of contract. In this regard, we find that there was no real argument on the point made by counsel for the parties concerned. It is not surprising, therefore, that the Judge did not really consider the point.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">86\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>contract</i> between Cameron and Stork for refurbishment of the Standby Slip Joint imposed an obligation upon Stork to detect any deficiencies in the thickness of the Riser Box wall. In particular, Stork was under an obligation under the contract to conduct a dimensional inspection of the Riser Box in order to detect and repair any deficiencies found therein. That this is so is clear from the various provisions in the purchase order as well as the Quotation, both of which formed the documentary basis for the contract itself. We also note that Stork had issued a letter of compliance to Cameron, which represented that the Standby Slip Joint had been \u201cinspected, repaired and remanufactured and/or tested in accordance with the requirements of \u2026 Cooper Cameron Specs\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">87\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As it turned out, Prabhuram\u2019s failure to conduct a dimensional inspection of the Riser Box constituted, in our view, a breach of contract on the part of his employer, Stork. If so, then if Cameron\u2019s liability to pay damages to the plaintiffs can be regarded as \u201cthe <i>natural consequence</i> of [Stork\u2019s] breach of contract, or, in other words, a consequence which might reasonably be supposed to have been within the contemplation of the parties\u201d [emphasis added] (see <i>Mowbray v Merryweather</i> <nobr>[1895] 2 QB 640</nobr> at 643), then Cameron would be entitled to a full indemnity from Stork in so far as liability to the plaintiffs is concerned.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">88\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>However</i>, this is not, in our view, an end to the matter. Notwithstanding Stork\u2019s breach of contract, it is also the case that Cameron had not furnished it (Stork) with the requisite dimensional drawings. In this respect, Cameron submitted that it was <i>entitled</i> to assume that Stork knew how to carry out the dimensional inspection and what documents or drawings would be required for such an inspection. In response, Stork averred that Cameron, being the original equipment manufacturer for the Standby Slip Joint, had the primary responsibility to determine the scope of work to be carried out thereon. Accordingly, it was reckless for Cameron not to have provided the dimensional drawings to Stork.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">89\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is true that one would be hard-pressed to argue that the requirement to furnish such drawings was an express term of the contract. However, whilst this was <i>not</i> the breach of an <i>express</i> term of the contract as such, it was, in our view, nevertheless the breach of <i>an implied term to exercise reasonable care</i>. Mr\u00a0Gurbani had, nevertheless, argued that such an implied term, if it indeed existed, had not in any event been pleaded. Whilst a persuasive point at first blush, it is our view that such an implied term was not one that was implied \u201cin <i>fact</i>\u201d but was, rather, one that was implied under that <i>broader</i> category of \u201cterms implied in <i>law</i>\u201d. As I observed in the Singapore High Court decision of <i>Forefront Medical Technology (Pte) Ltd v Modern-Pak Private Ltd</i> <nobr>[2006] 1 SLR 927</nobr> at [42]\u2013[44]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There is a <i>second</i> category of implied terms [<i>viz</i>, \u201cterms implied in law\u201d] which is wholly different in its nature as well as practical consequences. Under this category of implied terms, once a term has been implied, such a term will be implied in <i>all future</i> contracts of <i>that particular type</i>. The precise terminology utilised has varied. In the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Shell UK Ltd v Lostock Garage Ltd</i> <nobr>[1976] 1 WLR 1187</nobr> at 1196, for example, Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR utilised the rubric of contracts \u201cof common occurrence\u201d, whilst Lloyd\u00a0LJ in the (also) English Court of Appeal decision of <i>National Bank of Greece SA v Pinios Shipping Co No\u00a01</i> <nobr>[1990] 1 AC 637</nobr> (reversed in the House of Lords but not on this particular point) referred to such a category as encompassing \u201ccontracts of a defined type\u201d (at 645). But the central idea is clear: it is that the term implied is implied in a <i>general</i> way for <i>all</i> specific contracts that come within the purview of a broader umbrella category of contracts (reference may also be made, for example, to the House of Lords decisions of <i>Scally v Southern Health and Social Services Board</i> <nobr>[1992] 1 AC 294</nobr>, especially at 307 and <i>Malik v Bank of Credit and Commerce International SA</i> <nobr>[1998] AC 20</nobr> at 45).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To distinguish this particular category of implied terms from the first, legal scholars have referred to it as the category of \u201cterms implied in <i>law</i>\u201d (see generally, for example, Sir\u00a0Guenter\u00a0Treitel, <i>The Law of Contract</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 11th\u00a0Ed, 2003) (\u201cTreitel\u201d) at pp\u00a0206\u2013213). The first or former category has, in turn, been referred [to as] the category of \u201cterms implied in <i>fact</i>\u201d (see generally Treitel, at pp\u00a0201\u2013206).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The <i>rationale as well as test</i> for this broader category of implied terms is, not surprisingly, quite <i>different</i> from that which obtains for terms implied under the \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d and \u201cofficious bystander\u201d tests. In the first instance, the category is much broader inasmuch (as we have seen) the <i>potential</i> for application <i>extends</i> to <i>future</i> cases relating to the same issue with respect to the <i>same category</i> of contracts. In other words, the decision of the court concerned to imply a contract \u201cin law\u201d in a particular case <i>establishes a precedent</i> for similar cases in the future for <i>all</i> contracts of <i>that particular type</i>, unless of course a higher court overrules this specific decision. Hence, it is my view that courts ought to be as \u2013 if not more \u2013 careful in implying terms on this basis, compared to the implication of terms under the \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d and \u201cofficious bystander\u201d tests which relate to the <i>particular contract and parties only</i>. Secondly, the test for implying a term \u201cin law\u201d is broader than the tests for implying a term \u201cin fact\u201d. This gives rise to difficulties that have existed for some time, but which have only begun to be articulated relatively recently in the judicial context, not least as a result of the various analyses in the academic literature (see, for example, the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Crossley v Faithful &amp; Gould Holdings Ltd</i> [2004] 4\u00a0All ER 447 at [33]\u2013[46]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">90\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The category of \u201cterms implied in law\u201d is not without its disadvantages. A certain measure of uncertainty will always be an integral part of the judicial process and, hence, of the law itself. This is inevitable because of the very nature of life itself, which is \u2013 often to a very large extent \u2013 unpredictable. Such unpredictability and consequent uncertainty is of course a double-edged sword. It engenders both the wonder and awe as well as the dangers and pitfalls in life. Given this reality, however, one of the key functions of the courts is not to add unnecessarily to the uncertainty that already exists. Looked at in this light, the category of \u201cterms implied in law\u201d does tend to generate some uncertainty \u2013 not least because of the broadness of the criteria utilised to imply such terms, which are grounded (in the final analysis) on reasons of public policy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">91\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, the category of \u201cterms implied in law\u201d has now been firmly woven into the tapestry of our local contract law. It also aids, on occasion at least, in achieving a just and fair result. Most importantly, perhaps, it has formed both the theoretical as well as practical basis for <i>statutory</i> implied terms, such as those found in the UK Sale of Goods Act 1979 (c\u00a054) (applicable in Singapore <i>via</i> the application of English Law Act (Cap\u00a07A, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed) and reprinted as Cap\u00a0393, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">92\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What is clear, in our view, is that general reasons of justice and fairness as well as of public policy justify the implication of a \u201cterm implied in <i>law</i>\u201d in cases such as the present to the effect that each party (here, Cameron and Stork) would owe each other a duty to take reasonable care in the performance of the respective parts of the <i>contract</i> they had entered into. In the circumstances, Cameron\u2019s breach of contract would, if it stood <i>alone</i>, have entitled <i>Stork</i> to a complete indemnity from Cameron based on the same criteria set out above.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">93\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We do note Mr\u00a0Gurbani\u2019s argument on behalf of Cameron (and briefly alluded to above) that the issue relating to a \u201cterm implied in law\u201d was not pleaded. However, given the <i>very nature</i> of such a category of implied terms, we are of the view that it ought to be recognised by the court <i>as a matter of law</i>. We do reiterate that the parties themselves had not canvassed in an adequate manner the broader issue, of which the argument from implied terms is only a part. This was the issue of the <i>contractual position in relation to the respective claims for an indemnity by Cameron and Stork</i>. It was a vital issue. It was not something which this court could, with any sort of equanimity, afford to ignore. After all, the issue relating to an <i>indemnity</i> was raised in the pleadings and, of course, at the trial itself. But, at the risk of belabouring the point, it was not canvassed adequately. We could not now leave it \u201changing in the air\u201d, so to speak, especially since we are the final appellate court in so far as these proceedings are concerned. During the hearing before us, Mr\u00a0Gurbani himself was given an ample opportunity to argue that, based on the <i>contractual terms</i> between Cameron and Stork, Cameron was entitled to a full indemnity from Stork. Needless to say, he took this opportunity. Mr\u00a0Yeo was also given an ample opportunity to argue the point and he, too, took the opportunity, arguing his case on a number of different fronts (including, significantly in our view, the argument from an implied term). We see no injustice resulting to the parties. Indeed, as we have observed, a duty to take reasonable care in the performance of the contract arising from the implication of a term \u201cin law\u201d was applicable to <i>both</i> Cameron <i>and</i> Stork.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">94\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Given that Cameron had breached an implied term (in law) to take reasonable care <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> its contract with Stork inasmuch as it had not furnished the requisite dimensional drawings to Stork, what, then, is the position with regard to Stork inasmuch as it (Stork) has <i>also</i>, as we have held, breached the same contract by not (according to the express terms of the contract) conducting a dimensional inspection of the Riser Box in order to detect and repair any deficiencies found therein?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">95\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There are, in our view, two approaches open to this court with respect to the present factual matrix.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">96\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first is that the contractual duty by way of an implied term placed upon Cameron as discussed above is a <i>condition precedent</i> to the performance of the contractual duty placed by way of an express term upon Stork to conduct the dimensional inspection of the Riser Box. However, it is not in our view wholly clear that such an implied term was indeed a condition precedent. In any event, it is unnecessary to pursue this particular issue as we are of the view that by proceeding with the dimensional inspection of the Riser Box, Stork had <i>waived</i> any condition precedent that would have otherwise existed. Indeed, it might be persuasively argued that Stork had even waived the breach of the implied term by Cameron.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">97\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A second (and alternative) approach is to consider the situation on the basis that the implied term placed upon Cameron was <i>not</i> a <i>condition precedent</i>. This is in fact the approach that we must now focus on, given our rejection of the first approach as set out briefly in the preceding paragraph. In the circumstances, therefore, we must proceed on the basis that <i>both</i> Cameron and Stork had breached their contract and consider the legal consequences of the respective breaches accordingly.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">98\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This situation (where both parties are in breach of contract) has not, to the best of our knowledge, received much treatment in the case law. However, the following observations by Kerr\u00a0LJ in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>State Trading Corporation of India Ltd v M Golodetz Ltd</i> [1989] 2\u00a0Lloyd\u2019s Rep 277 at 286 are apposite:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The fact that in the present case both parties had committed breaches before one of them elected to treat the contract as repudiated appears to me to make no difference whatever; nor the fact that (assumedly) both had been breaches of condition. <i>If A is entitled to treat B as having wrongfully repudiated the contract between them and does so, then it does not avail B to point to A\u2019s past breaches of contract, whatever their nature.</i> A breach by A would only assist B if it was still continuing when A purported to treat B as having repudiated the contract <i>and</i> [this emphasis is in the original text] if the effect of A\u2019s subsisting breach was such as to preclude A from claiming that B had committed a repudiatory breach. In other words, B would have to show that A, being in breach of an obligation <i>in the nature of a condition precedent</i>, was therefore not entitled to rely on B\u2019s breach as a repudiation. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">99\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The observations just quoted are both logical and principled. Applying them to the facts before us, we have already held that the implied term of the contract which was breached by Cameron was <i>not</i> a condition precedent. Hence, this particular breach of contract by Cameron did <i>not</i>, in our view, preclude Cameron from claiming an indemnity from Stork for the latter\u2019s breach of contract in not conducting a proper dimensional inspection of the Riser Box. But this is not an end to the matter. Let us elaborate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">100\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the contractual obligation on the part of Stork to conduct a dimensional inspection of the Riser Box was not an absolute one. It only required Stork to perform this obligation with reasonable care. Such a contractual duty would of course be <i>coincident</i> with its duty of care in the <i>tortious</i> context. This is an important point because the fact that the concept of contributory negligence has <i>not</i> been introduced in the sphere of contract law <i>generally</i> is immaterial to the extent that the duty owed by Stork to Cameron was, as just stated, a <i>concurrent</i> one in contract and tort. The Singapore position in this regard is clear: the doctrine of <i>contributory negligence</i> is applicable where the defendant\u2019s liability in contract is the same as his or her liability in the tort of negligence independently of the existence of any contract (see the decision of this court in <i>Fong Maun Yee v Yoong Weng Ho Robert</i> <nobr>[1997] 2 SLR 297</nobr> (\u201c<i>Fong Maun Yee</i>\u201d), where the leading English decision in <i>Forsikringsaktieselskapet Vesta v Butcher</i> <nobr>[1989] AC 852</nobr> (\u201cthe <i>Vesta</i> case\u201d) was adopted and followed (the House of Lords did not, however, deal specifically with this particular point although the Court of Appeal and High Court did, with the Court of Appeal decision also being reported in the citation just given)). As an interesting aside, the Judge did in fact refer to both <i>Fong Maun Yee</i> and the <i>Vesta</i> case (see GD at [119]\u2013[121]), but this was in relation to the reliance by Cameron on the doctrine of contributory negligence with respect to its alleged liability to <i>the plaintiffs</i> (with whom it had, of course, a <i>contractual</i> relationship as well). Unfortunately, however, counsel concerned did <i>not</i> apply these cases to the issue of indemnity between <i>Cameron and Stork</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">101\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the <i>Vesta</i> case itself, Hobhouse\u00a0J (as he then was) helpfully set out (at first instance) the three categories which might arise in relation to the possible invocation of the defence of contributory negligence in contract, as follows (see <i>Forsikringsaktieselskapet Vesta v Butcher</i> [1986] 2\u00a0All\u00a0ER 488 at 508):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The question whether the 1945 Act [the UK Law Reform (Contributory Negligence) Act 1945, on which the Singapore Contributory Negligence and Personal Injuries Act (Cap\u00a054, 2002\u00a0Ed) is in fact based] applies to claims brought in contract can arise in a number of classes of case. <i>Three categories</i> can conveniently be identified.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where the defendant\u2019s liability arises from some contractual provision which does not depend on negligence on the part of the defendant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where the defendant\u2019s liability arises from a contractual obligation which is expressed in terms of taking care (or its equivalent) but does not correspond to a common law duty to take care which would exist in the given case independently of contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where the defendant\u2019s liability in contract is the same as his liability in the tort of negligence independently of the existence of any contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">As already alluded to above, the House of Lords did not deal with the issue of contributory negligence as a defence in contract. However, both Hobhouse J (at first instance) and the Court of Appeal held (as we have also noted above) that the doctrine of contributory negligence was available as a defence in contract \u2013 but only in <i>category (3)</i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">, as set out in the above quotation, which relates to a situation of <i>concurrent</i> liability in contract and tort.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Contributory negligence in contract \u2013 developments and devices</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">102\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although the position in Singapore is (as we have already noted) presently that as set out in the <i>Vesta</i> case, the position with regard to the issue of contributory negligence in contract is still, however, in a state of development across many Commonwealth jurisdictions. A succinct account of developments across various jurisdictions may in fact be found in the UK Law Commission\u2019s Report entitled <i>Contributory Negligence as a Defence in Contract</i> (Law Com No\u00a0219, 1993) at paras\u00a02.7\u20132.19.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">103\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To take but a more specific sampling of various positions and developments in the sphere of the common law, the High Court of Australia held, in <i>Astley v Austrust Ltd</i> (1999) 161\u00a0ALR 155 (Callinan\u00a0J dissenting), that the defence of contributory negligence would not apply <i>even in</i> a situation of concurrent liability in contract and tort. This decision was not well received generally and it came as no surprise when various Australian state legislatures effected various amendments to the equivalent of the Singapore Contributory Negligence and Personal Injuries Act (Cap\u00a054, 2002\u00a0Rev Ed) (see, for example, J\u00a0W\u00a0Carter &amp; D\u00a0J\u00a0Harland, <i>Contract Law in Australia</i> (Butterworths, 4th\u00a0Ed, 2002) at para\u00a02129 and N\u00a0C\u00a0Seddon &amp; M\u00a0P\u00a0Ellinghaus, <i>Cheshire &amp; Fifoot\u2019s Law of Contract</i> (LexisNexis Butterworths, 8th\u00a0Australian Ed, 2002) at para\u00a023.28). In contrast, the New Zealand position is the same as that which exists in Singapore and England: see the New Zealand High Court decision of <i>Rowe v Turner Hopkins &amp; Partners</i> <nobr>[1980] 2 NZLR 550</nobr> (reversed on appeal in <nobr>[1982] 1 NZLR 178</nobr>, but not on this point and where the New Zealand Court of Appeal left open for future consideration an even <i>broader</i> approach), which was in fact cited and applied in the <i>Vesta</i> case (though it might be noted that Cooke\u00a0P in the New Zealand Court of Appeal decision of <i>Mouat v Clark Boyce</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 NZLR 559</nobr> at 564 preferred the view that contributory negligence could apply in contract in its <i>widest sense</i> (which would encompass the first class of cases referred to in the <i>Vesta</i> case as well)). The position embodied in the <i>Vesta</i> case was in fact ultimately advocated by the UK Law Commission in their Report ([102] <i>supra</i>) and was in contrast to its earlier Working Paper (also entitled <i>Contributory Negligence as a Defence in Contract</i> (Working Paper No\u00a0114, 1990)) which advocated that contributory negligence be permitted as a defence in contract in its <i>widest</i> sense (see also <i>per</i> Cooke\u00a0P in <i>Mouat v Clark Boyce</i>). Indeed, the New Zealand Law Commission also proposed a similarly wide legislative reform (see <i>Apportionment of Civil Liability</i> (Report\u00a047, May 1998)).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">104\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also note that courts in other jurisdictions have sought to achieve the same effect as the introduction of contributory negligence in contract by resort to <i>other contractual devices</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">105\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 One such device is that of \u201c<i>anticipatory mitigation</i>\u201d (see, for example, the oft-cited decision of Saunders\u00a0J in the Ontario High Court of Justice case of <i>Tompkins Hardware Ltd v North Western Flying Services Ltd</i> (1982) 139\u00a0DLR\u00a0(3d) 329 (\u201cthe <i>Tompkins Hardware</i> case\u201d), applied (most notably) in the (also oft-cited) Ontario High Court of Justice case of <i>Ribic v Weinstein</i> (1982) 140\u00a0DLR\u00a0(3d) 258 and described by Lacourci\u00e8re\u00a0JA, delivering the judgment of the Ontario Court of Appeal in <i>Cosyns v Smith</i> (1983) 146\u00a0DLR\u00a0(3d) 622 at 628, as embodying an \u201cattractive conclusion\u201d). As Saunders\u00a0J put it in the <i>Tompkins Hardware</i> case (at 341), where the negligence of the plaintiff \u201ccreated the situation where the damage occurred\u201d, \u201cthere should \u2026 be apportionment whether the action be brought in contract or in tort\u201d. We do <i>not</i> think that the learned judge intended to impose a stringent condition to the effect that the plaintiff must be <i>wholly</i> responsible for the situation where the damage occurred and that his observation must be read in the light of the <i>actual facts</i> of the <i>Tompkins Hardware</i> case itself (see also the New Brunswick Court of Appeal decision of <i>Coopers &amp; Lybrand v H E Kane Agencies Ltd</i> (1985) 17\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 695 at 708 (reference to the plaintiff being the cause of his or her loss \u201cin part\u201d)). Nevertheless, this device of \u201canticipatory mitigation\u201d might run into another difficulty \u2013 that the concept of mitigation in the law of contract refers to a situation that occurs <i>after</i> the breach concerned (see also, for example, John Burrows, Jeremy Finn &amp; Stephen Todd, <i>Law of Contract in New Zealand</i> (LexisNexis, 2nd\u00a0Ed, 2002) at p\u00a0799). Notwithstanding the logical persuasiveness of this last-mentioned argument, we would not dismiss this device out of hand (which was in fact endorsed in S\u00a0M\u00a0Waddams, <i>The Law of Contracts</i> (Canada Law Book Inc, 4th\u00a0Ed, 1999) at para\u00a0773). It is, however, unnecessary for us to decide on this point in the light of our finding above that there is concurrent liability in contract and tort in the present proceedings and that the principle in <i>Fong Maun Yee</i> ([100] <i>supra</i>) applies. We therefore say no more about it in the context of the present proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">106\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another contractual device centres on the possible application of the principles of <i>remoteness of damage</i> that have their genesis in the seminal English Court of Exchequer decision of <i>Hadley v Baxendale</i> (1854) 9\u00a0Exch 341; 156\u00a0ER 145. Indeed, most recently, the Singapore High Court decision of <i>CHS CPO GmbH v Vikas Goel</i> <nobr>[2005] 3 SLR 202</nobr> reaffirms the fact that the principles established in <i>Hadley v Baxendale</i> continue to be the law in the Singapore context despite doubts expressed in the New Zealand context (see at [87], not following the New Zealand Court of Appeal decision of <i>McElroy Milne v Commercial Electronics Ltd</i> <nobr>[1993] 1 NZLR 39</nobr>). In so far as the present case is concerned, the argument would be to the effect that where the plaintiff has been guilty of contributory negligence, any damage caused as a result would be too remote as it would fall outside the scope of the first limb set out in <i>Hadley v Baxendale</i>, which relates to \u201cordinary\u201d or \u201cnatural\u201d damage (and <i>cf</i> the New Brunswick Court of Appeal in <i>Doiron v Caisse Populaire d\u2019Inkerman Lt\u00e9e</i> (1985) 17\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 660 (\u201cthe <i>Doiron</i> case\u201d) at 680\u2013681 as well as the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Sayers v Harlow Urban District Council</i> <nobr>[1958] 1 WLR 623</nobr>, especially at 625). This, however, does raise a related issue as to whether or not such damage would also be too remote as it would <i>also</i> fall outside the <i>second</i> limb of <i>Hadley v Baxendale</i> as well, which relates to \u201cspecial\u201d or \u201cnon-natural\u201d damage (<i>cf</i> the <i>Doiron</i> case at 682). Here, <i>actual</i> knowledge must be brought home to the defendant in order that the damage might not be considered to be too remote. This is, generally speaking, also an interesting argument but, once again, it is unnecessary for us to decide on this point in the light of our finding above and we therefore also say no more about it in the context of the present proceedings.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">107\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 One further possible contractual device is to utilise the concept of the <i>implied term</i> to the effect that the plaintiff would exercise due care for his or her own interest (see Nick Seddon, \u201cContract Damages Where Both Parties Are at Fault\u201d (2000) 15\u00a0JCL 207 at 215\u2013216). Again, this is an argument that we need not deal with at the present time although it must be emphasised that a court will <i>not lightly</i> imply a term into a contract. There are of course two established categories of implied terms \u2013 \u201cterms implied in fact\u201d and \u201cterms implied in law\u201d, respectively. We have already dealt with the latter (and broader) category briefly above (see [89]\u2013[92]). In so far as the former category is concerned, the criteria, whilst different, are no less stringent. Indeed, there are two oft-cited tests in order to find \u201cterms implied in fact\u201d, which I have summarised in <i>Forefront Medical Technology (Pte) Ltd v Modern-Pak Private Ltd</i> ([89] <i>supra</i>), as follows (at [29]\u2013[32]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It has always been acknowledged that particular terms might be implied into particular contracts. However, in order not to undermine the concept of freedom of contract itself, terms would be implied only rarely \u2013 in exceptional cases where, as one famous case put it, it was <i>necessary</i> to give \u201c<i>business efficacy</i>\u201d to the contract (see <i>per</i> Bowen\u00a0LJ (as then was) in the English Court of Appeal decision in <i>The Moorcock</i> (1889) 14\u00a0PD 64). In the words of Bowen\u00a0LJ himself (at 68):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Now, an implied warranty, or, as it is called, a covenant in law, as distinguished from an express contract or express warranty, really is in all cases founded on the presumed intention of the parties, and upon reason. The implication which the law draws from what must obviously have been the intention of the parties, the law draws with the object of giving efficacy to the transaction and preventing such a failure of consideration as cannot have been within the contemplation of either side; and I believe if one were to take all the cases, and there are many, of implied warranties or covenants in law, it will be found that in all of them the law is raising an implication from the presumed intention of the parties with the object of giving to the transaction such efficacy as both parties must have intended that at all events it should have. In business transactions such as this, what the law desires to effect by the implication is to give such business efficacy to the transaction as must have been intended at all events by both parties who are business men; not to impose on one side all the perils of the transaction, or to emancipate one side from all the chances of failure, but to make each party promise in law as much, at all events, as it must have been in the contemplation of both parties that he should be responsible for in respect of those perils or chances.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Indeed, Lord\u00a0Esher\u00a0MR adopted a similar approach, although it is Bowen\u00a0LJ\u2019s judgment that is most often cited. This is probably due to the fact that a close perusal of Lord\u00a0Esher\u00a0MR\u2019s judgment will reveal that the learned Master of the Rolls did not <i>explicitly</i> adopt the \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d test as such. It might be usefully observed at this juncture that the third judge, Fry\u00a0LJ, agreed with both Bowen\u00a0LJ and Lord\u00a0Esher\u00a0MR (see [29] <i>supra</i> at 71).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was another test, which soon became equally famous. It was by MacKinnon\u00a0LJ in another English Court of Appeal decision. This was the famous \u201c<i>officious bystander</i>\u201d test which was propounded in <i>Shirlaw v Southern Foundries (1926) Limited</i> <nobr>[1939] 2 KB 206</nobr> at 227 (\u201c<i>Shirlaw</i>\u201d) (affirmed, <nobr>[1940] AC 701</nobr>), as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">If I may quote from an essay which I wrote some years ago, I then said: \u201cPrima facie that which in any contract is left to be implied and need not be expressed is something so obvious that it goes without saying; so that, if, while the parties were making their bargain, an officious bystander were to suggest some express provision for it in their agreement, they would testily suppress him with a common \u2018Oh, of course!\u2019\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">At least it is true, I think, that, if a term were never implied by a judge unless it could pass that test, he could not be held to be wrong.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Interestingly, the essay referred to above was in fact a public lecture delivered at the London School of Economics in the University of London: see Sir\u00a0Frank MacKinnon, <i>Some Aspects of Commercial Law \u2013 A Lecture Delivered at the London School of Economics on 3\u00a0March 1926</i> (Oxford University Press, 1926) (and see, especially, p\u00a013).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both these tests are firmly established in the local case law (in addition to the cases cited below, see also, for example, <i>Lim Eng Hock Peter v Batshita International (Pte) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1996] 2 SLR 741</nobr> at 745\u2013746, [13]\u2013[15] (affirmed in <i>Batshita International (Pte) Ltd v Lim Eng Hock Peter</i> <nobr>[1997] 1 SLR 241</nobr>) and <i>Chai Chung Ching Chester v Diversey (Far East) Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1991] SLR 769</nobr> at 778, [34] (affirmed in <i>Diversey (Far East) Pte Ltd v Chai Chung Ching Chester</i> <nobr>[1993] 1 SLR 535</nobr>), with regard to the \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d and \u201cofficious bystander\u201d tests, respectively.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">108\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Yet another (even more fundamental) device is simply to argue that the breach of contract did <i>not cause</i> the damage concerned (see, for example, the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Quinn v Burch Bros (Builders) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1966] 2 QB 370</nobr>). Indeed, where it can be established that a <i>novus actus interveniens</i> has broken the chain of causation, the defendant will be freed from liability (see, for example, the (also) English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Beoco Ltd v Alfa Laval Co Ltd</i> <nobr>[1995] QB 137</nobr>). It should be noted, however, that this device almost invariably results in an \u201call or nothing\u201d result (though <i>cf</i> the English Court of Appeal in <i>Tennant Radiant Heat Ltd v Warrington Development Corporation</i> <nobr>[1988] 1 EGLR 41</nobr>, which was endorsed in English High Court decision of <i>W\u00a0Lamb Ltd v J\u00a0Jarvis &amp; Sons plc</i> (1998) 60\u00a0Con\u00a0LR 1; though <i>cf</i>, in turn, the <i>obiter</i> observations by the (also) English Court of Appeal in <i>Bank of Nova Scotia v Hellenic Mutual War Risks Association (Bermuda) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1990] 1 QB 818</nobr> at 904). However, we find that this particular device is not applicable on the facts of the present proceedings and therefore say no more about it here.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">109\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The rationale of fairness has been a powerful underlying legal impetus for the various attempts to introduce the doctrine in contract (or devices that would, in substance, achieve the same result). For example, La Forest\u00a0JA (as he then was), delivering the judgment of the New Brunswick Court of Appeal in the <i>Doiron</i> case, observed thus ([106] <i>supra</i> at 673):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">What the \u2026 authorities demonstrate to me is that the doctrine of apportionment of loss where contributory negligence arises in contract cases is here to stay. There are strong underlying policy reasons favouring this approach and the courts, using one technical device or another, will, I venture to think, continue to respond to these by applying the doctrine.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">110\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having determined that the equivalent of our Contributory Negligence and Personal Injuries Act did not apply to a situation involving a breach of contract, the learned judge was nevertheless of the view (at 677) that \u201cthere does not seem to be any inherent requirement in contract law dictating an absolutist doctrine of liability\u201d. La Forest\u00a0JA was of the view (at 679) that \u201c[a]s 19th century judges responded to the ethos of their times, so must we to ours\u201d and that \u201c[c]ontribution is now consistent with prevailing theories of both the law and the market-place\u201d; he then added, simply albeit significantly, thus (see <i>ibid</i>): \u201cAnd it meets our sense of fairness.\u201d While not advocating contribution as a mandatory rule as such, the learned judge appeared ultimately to adopt a test akin to the remoteness test in <i>Hadley v Baxendale</i> (see [106] above).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">111\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 La Forest\u00a0JA also referred to the concept of legitimate expectations (at 682). This concept has in fact been endorsed in the Singapore context, in the Singapore Court of Appeal decision of <i>Tribune Investment Trust Inc v Soosan Trading Co Ltd</i> <nobr>[2000] 3 SLR 405</nobr>, for example, Yong Pung How\u00a0CJ observed in no uncertain terms (at [40]) that \u201cthe function of the court is to try as far as practical experience allows, to ensure that the reasonable expectations of honest men are not disappointed\u201d (see also the extrajudicial lecture by Lord Steyn, \u201cContract Law: Fulfilling the Reasonable Expectations of Honest Men\u201d (1997) 113\u00a0LQR 433). However, whilst the concept of reasonable expectations is an important one, it has not, at this point in time at least, attained the status of a substantive legal doctrine in and of itself. In this regard, therefore, any argument in favour of contributory negligence in contract must be premised, in our view, on established and substantive doctrines such as those referred to above.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">112\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, in the New Brunswick Court of Appeal decision of <i>Coopers &amp; Lybrand v H E Kane Agencies Ltd</i> ([105] <i>supra</i>), Stratton\u00a0JA, who delivered the judgment of the court, adopted an extremely broad, albeit (with respect) vague, approach as follows (at 708):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whether one accepts the argument that at common law damages could be apportioned in actions in contract as well as in actions of tort and that the <i>Contributory Negligence Act</i> \u2026 should be applied by analogy, or adopts the theory of the reasonable expectations of the parties, or the notion of reliance that was either qualified or unreasonable, <i>or simply that in fairness and to do justice</i> the damages ought to be apportioned, I do not think that in the circumstances of this case the trial judge erred in concluding that the actions of the company president, Harold Kane, and of Charles Kane, its employee, contributed to the company\u2019s loss. Nor am I able to say that the apportionment of the degrees of fault of each party is wrong. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">113\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In summary, developments in other jurisdictions are instructive and relevant inasmuch as they give legal food for thought in so far as development of the law in the Singapore context along the lines of legislation and/or case law are concerned. But there is no need to explore \u2013 let alone invoke \u2013 them in the present proceedings as the position in <i>Singapore</i>, as we have noted, is clear at the present time. It follows that established in the <i>Vesta</i> case (and see generally [100] above). And it is to the <i>application</i> of those principles to the facts of the present proceedings that our attention must now turn. We note, however, that in situations where (unlike the present) there is <i>no concurrent</i> liability in tort and contract, the invocation of one or more of the devices just mentioned may be important in order to ensure that justice and fairness is achieved if the Singapore legislature does not amend the law in the meantime. We should hasten to add that by utilising the terminology of \u201cdevices\u201d, we do not intend to imply any pejorative meaning. After all, these are perfectly valid legal doctrines in their own right, although they are not conventionally invoked (hence, the terminology utilised).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Our decision in the present proceedings</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">114\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Returning to the facts of the present case, the issue that arises (given the present legal position in the Singapore context as established in this court\u2019s decision in <i>Fong Maun Yee</i> ([100] <i>supra</i>)) is whether or not there was contributory negligence on the part of Cameron, given our finding above that Stork owed Cameron <i>concurrent</i> duties in <i>both</i> contract <i>and</i> tort. We have already noted that Cameron had not furnished Stork with the requisite dimensional drawings. We have also held that this was in fact a breach of an implied term (in law) by Cameron. In so far as the issue of contributory negligence is concerned, we do not even need to go so far. Indeed, the existence of a legal duty is not necessary for the purposes of establishing contributory negligence on the part of the plaintiff. For example, in the English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Lewis v Denye</i> <nobr>[1939] 1 KB 540</nobr>, du Parcq\u00a0LJ observed thus (at 554\u2013555):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In order to establish the defence of contributory negligence, the defendant must prove, first, that the plaintiff failed to take \u201cordinary care for himself,\u201d or, in other words, such care as a reasonable man would take for his own safety, and, secondly, that his failure to take care was a contributory cause of the accident. The doctrine of contributory negligence \u201ccannot be based upon a breach of duty to the negligent defendant.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">115\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 And, in the (also) English Court of Appeal decision of <i>Davies v Swan Motor Co (Swansea) Ld</i> <nobr>[1949] 2 KB 291</nobr>, Denning\u00a0LJ (as he then was) observed as follows (at 324\u2013325):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">When a man steps into the road he owes a duty to himself to take care for his own safety, but he does not owe any duty to a motorist who is going at an excessive speed to avoid being run down. Nevertheless, if he does not keep a good lookout, he is guilty of contributory negligence. <i>The real question is not whether the plaintiff was neglecting some legal duty, but whether he was acting as a reasonable man and with reasonable care.</i> [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">116\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, the failure by Cameron to furnish Stork with the requisite dimensional drawings did, having regard to the relevant facts and circumstances, in fact constitute <i>contributory negligence</i>. In this regard, the following observations in the following article by Ariel Porat, \u201cContributory Negligence in Contract Law: Toward a Principled Approach\u201d (1994) 28\u00a0UBC\u00a0L\u00a0Rev 141 at 153 might also be usefully noted:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Lack of information essential to contract performance is sometimes liable to result in a breach. If the aggrieved party possesses such information but fails to convey it to the party in breach, even knowing it to be essential to performance, it might be appropriate to reduce damages to the aggrieved party on account of contributory negligence. In extreme cases, when non-disclosure is either deliberate or fraudulent, the conduct of the aggrieved party should be viewed as justifying the full exoneration of the party in breach.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">117\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Whilst there was no fraud or similar conduct on the part of Cameron, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, we find that there was contributory negligence on the part of Cameron to the extent of 50%.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">118\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At this juncture, we need to clarify the amounts payable by both Cameron and Stork and, to this extent, the respective amounts awarded by the court below will need to be modified accordingly.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">119\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It will be recalled that the Judge had held that</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Cameron and Stork were equally liable to the plaintiffs, and therefore ordered Stork to indemnify Cameron for 50% of the total damages. In other words, Stork was liable to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$500,000 for the total amount of US$1m awarded to the plaintiffs with respect to the loss of the BOP stack, leaving aside the nominal damages payable in respect of the other pleaded heads of damage. With respect, we note that there has been some confusion inasmuch as there has been some (unintentional) conflation of two separate and distinct issues.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">120\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The first concerns Cameron\u2019s and Stork\u2019s respective liability to the plaintiffs. Here, the Judge held that the former parties were equally liable to the latter. This would mean, in so far as the BOP stack was concerned, that, notwithstanding Cameron\u2019s <i>prima facie</i> liability for the full sum of US$1m awarded with regard to this particular item, Stork ought to share in that liability as well (to the extent of 50%). In other words, Cameron and Stork were liable in the sum of US$500,000 each <i>to the plaintiffs</i> (a holding which we endorse). Looked at in this light, the concept of \u201cindemnity\u201d as utilised by the Judge was, with the greatest of respect, liable to lead to some confusion inasmuch as it suggested that the concept applied to the relationship between <i>Cameron and Stork</i>. We do not in fact think that the Judge intended the concept to be utilised in that fashion. She was, in our view, utilising the concept of \u201cindemnity\u201d in a <i>broader</i> sense in so far as it referred to the respective liability of Cameron and Stork <i>to the plaintiffs</i>. Perhaps the more appropriate concept to utilise would be that of \u201ccontribution\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">121\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The conceptual distinction between contribution and indemnity, in its true form, was discussed in <i>Driver v William Willett (Contractors) Ltd</i> [1969] 1\u00a0</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">All\u00a0ER 665, a case that was cited by Cameron. In that case, an employer and its consultants were found to be jointly liable for injury caused to an employee. The court found that the employer and the consultants were respectively liable to the employee for 40% and 60% of his loss respectively. The court then went on to consider whether the employer was entitled to recover its 40% liability to the employee as damages for breach of contract from the consultants. Rees\u00a0J clearly drew a distinction between apportionment and indemnity, opining (at 674):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 I apprehend that the question which I have to answer is as to whether the evidence established that the damage suffered by <i>the employers</i> as a result of the plaintiff\u2019s claim was caused by the consultants\u2019 breach of contract. The apportionment of responsibility for the accident as between tortfeasors, both held to be liable to an injured plaintiff, involves considerations of causative potency as well as blameworthiness.</span> <i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It does not necessarily decide the issue of damages for breach of a contract as between the two tortfeasors</span></i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">.</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">122\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding the Judge\u2019s determination that Stork was liable for 50% of the plaintiffs\u2019 losses, there remained the issue of how the concept of \u201cindemnity\u201d applies (in its <i>narrower</i> sense) to <i>the specific legal relationship between Cameron and Stork</i> (and which we alluded to briefly at the outset of this part of our judgment). In other words, would (as was in fact claimed by counsel for Cameron) Cameron be entitled to claim a <i>full</i> indemnity for US$500,000 <i>from Stork</i> on the basis that <i>Stork had breached its contractual obligations to Cameron</i>? If so, then Cameron would not have to pay any damages at all since <i>Stork</i> would then <i>wholly</i> bear the legal responsibility in so far as the amount of US$1m awarded to the plaintiffs with regard to the BOP stack was concerned. Given our finding that Stork had indeed breached its contractual duty to conduct a dimensional inspection of the Riser Box, this would appear to be the result at first blush. <i>However</i>, having regard to our finding of <i>contributory negligence</i> <i>in so far as the contract between Cameron and Stork is concerned (to the extent of 50%)</i>, we are of the view that Cameron is <i>not</i> entitled to a <i>full</i> indemnity from Stork. We therefore allow Cameron\u2019s appeal in part only on this particular issue, and order Stork to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$250,000 instead. To the extent that <i>Stork</i> is <i>itself</i> liable for 50% of the damages of US$1m payable <i>to the plaintiffs</i> (<i>viz</i>, US$500,000), it would, <i>in toto</i>, have to indemnify (and we note, here, that the concept of indemnity is used in a very <i>general</i> sense, and not as a term of art) Cameron <i>in the (total) sum of US$750,000</i>. Perhaps the more <i>accurate</i> manner of putting it would be to state that Stork is liable to contribute US$500,000 to Cameron for its part in the damage caused <i>to the plaintiffs</i> <i>and</i> is also liable to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$250,000 for breaching its contractual obligation which it owed to Cameron. If, of course, we had found no contributory negligence on the part of Cameron, then Stork would have had to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$500,000. In other words, Cameron would not, in the final analysis, have been liable to pay any damages at all with regard to the loss of the BOP stack as Stork would have had to bear Cameron\u2019s share of the liability in this regard as well since it had breached its contractual obligation to Cameron. In the circumstances, however, we <i>did</i> in fact find that there had been contributory negligence on the part of Cameron. We reiterate that the doctrine of contributory negligence was applicable to the <i>contractual</i> relationship between Cameron and Stork simply because Stork owed <i>concurrent</i> duties in both contract <i>and</i> tort to Cameron. As we have observed, there might well be a case for <i>broadening</i> the law in this area by allowing contributory negligence to apply even where the duties in contract and tort are not identical. Of course, the <i>broadest</i> application would be to allow this doctrine to apply even where there is a <i>strict</i> <i>contractual</i> duty <i>only</i> (<i>ie</i>, a <i>category (1)</i> case as described at [101] above). That said, as we have also briefly alluded to above, there are <i>other contractual devices</i> that might serve as <i>possible alternatives</i> to the doctrine of contributory negligence. However, it is <i>unnecessary</i> to consider any of these broader applications and/or contractual devices in the present case. We would simply apply the previous decision of this court in <i>Fong Maun Yee</i> ([100] <i>supra</i>), which held that the doctrine of contributory negligence applies in a contractual context where the defendant owes the plaintiff <i>concurrent</i> duties in contract <i>and</i> tort.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">123\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, we reiterate the need to distinguish clearly amongst the various legal relationships concerned. In particular, the respective liability of the defendants to the plaintiffs is (as we have endeavoured to point out) quite different from that between the defendants themselves. This latter relationship is contractual in nature and it would, in our view, conduce towards clarity if the concept of \u201cindemnity\u201d is confined to this particular relationship. We observe that counsel concerned could have been more helpful to the Judge in this regard as this would have avoided the slight legal wrinkle which we have now had to iron out. We turn now to consider the other issues arising in the instant case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Other issues</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Introduction</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">124\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We turn now to the remaining issues. They can be dealt with briefly. They were not the focus of counsel\u2019s argument on appeal. More importantly, we are in full agreement with the reasoning of the Judge with regard to these issues. Indeed, she dealt with them in a comprehensive and (if we may say so) admirable fashion. In our view, when justice has therefore been achieved at first instance in accordance with the relevant legal rules and principles, words from the appellate court ought, from the perspectives of logic, common sense and fairness, to be few.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Identity of the fractured slip joint</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">125<b><i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</i></b> The issue of the identity of the fractured slip joint was, in our view, a question of fact for the Judge and, based on existing legal principles well known to all concerned and which permit an appellate court to interfere with the findings of fact by a trial judge in limited circumstances only, we find no reason to interfere with her findings of fact. We found her analysis to be both thorough and persuasive and therefore do not find it necessary to add anything to it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Title to sue</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">126<b><i>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</i></b> We also find the Judge\u2019s analysis and findings on the issue of title to sue with respect (in particular) to both JDL and MEP to be both cogent and fair, and have nothing to add.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The legal liability of Cameron to the plaintiffs</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">127\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The legal liability of Cameron to the plaintiffs was premised on contract as well as tort.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">128\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning briefly to arguments in the contractual sphere, we find the Judge\u2019s holding to the effect that Cameron had been in breach of the implied terms to utilise skill and care to be justified by the facts as well as the context of the case. We would only add that although the Judge appeared to characterise these implied terms as \u201cterms implied in fact\u201d, there was no reason in principle why the learned judge could not have characterised them as \u201cterms implied in law\u201d instead (see also generally the analysis at [89]\u2013[92] above).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">129\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as liability in tort was concerned, the Judge, correctly in our view, characterised the duty of care as being co-extensive with that which existed in contract. We also note that the learned judge had utilised the three-part test enunciated by the House of Lords in <i>Caparo Industries Plc v Dickman</i> <nobr>[1990] 2 AC 605.</nobr> This particular test is well established and has been applied in the Singapore context (see, for example, the Singapore Court of Appeal decisions of <i>Ikumene Singapore Pte Ltd v Leong Chee Leng</i> <nobr>[1993] 3 SLR 24</nobr>; <i>Mohd bin Sapri v Soil-Build (Pte) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1996] 2 SLR 505</nobr>; <i>RSP Architects Planners &amp; Engineers v MCST Plan No\u00a01075</i> <nobr>[1999] 2 SLR 449</nobr>; and <i>United Project Consultants Pte Ltd v Leong Kwok Onn</i> <nobr>[2005] 4 SLR 214</nobr>). The law relating to the tortious duty of care in the context of recovery for pure economic loss is, however, a confused and confusing one. On a positive note, however, it is also gradually evolving and the legal position is by no means the same in all Commonwealth jurisdictions. It may well be the case that Singapore law might need to be refined at some future point in time in order to integrate the best from these other cases. This would ensure that there is rich legal soil from which the fruit of justice and fairness can emerge. However, this is not an appropriate occasion. Whichever test is adopted, it is clear, on the facts, that Cameron owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs and had breached it. The Judge\u2019s analysis and reasoning in this regard was thorough and persuasive and we have nothing useful to add. Indeed, it might even be argued that the present proceedings involved a straightforward situation of physical damage involving an equally straightforward application of the principles laid down in the seminal House of Lords decision of <i>Donoghue v Stevenson</i> <nobr>[1932] AC 562.</nobr> However, we need not even go so far for, as we have already noted, even applying the narrower test with regard to the tortious duty of care in the context of recovery for pure economic loss, we would also hold that Cameron was indeed liable to the plaintiffs for the breach of a duty of care.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">130\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We also agree with the Judge that the plaintiffs\u2019 argument, that the certificate of compliance (\u201cCOC\u201d) dated 23\u00a0December 1998 was itself a warranty, ought to be rejected, having regard to the circumstances of the case (see GD at [64]). Indeed, the context clearly demonstrates that there had been no intention to create legal relations and there was, therefore, no contractual relationship established in the first instance. We also note that the Judge considered whether or not the statements in the COC constituted negligent misstatements instead under the principle first enunciated in the seminal House of Lords decision of <i>Hedley Byrne &amp; Co Ltd v Heller &amp; Partners Ltd</i> <nobr>[1964] AC 465.</nobr> In this last-mentioned regard, we agree with her application of the law to the facts in the present proceedings (in particular, her holding that no reliance on the COC had been proved, the element of reliance being of course a crucial element in this particular sphere of the law of negligence).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The legal liability of Stork to the plaintiffs</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">131\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We agree with the findings of the Judge on the issue of the legal liability of Stork to the plaintiffs. It was clear that Stork was indeed in breach of a duty of care owed to the plaintiffs. We have nothing useful to add to the analysis and findings of the Judge in this particular regard.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Exception clauses</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">132\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Judge held that Cameron could not rely upon the exception clauses concerned <i>vis-\u00e0-vis</i> the plaintiffs. In particular, she held that these clauses had not been incorporated into the contract in question and that, in any event, the clauses themselves did not cover the situation that was the subject of the present proceedings. We agree with the Judge\u2019s analysis and reasons and have nothing useful to add, save to state that there was some suggestion that there might have been a possible course of dealings (see GD at [112]). However, this point was not pursued by Cameron. Not surprisingly, there is in fact no evidence in this particular regard.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><em>The doctrine of</em></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">novus actus interveniens</span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">133<b>\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</b> The reliance by Cameron on an alleged <i>novus actus interveniens</i> on the part of the plaintiffs is, in our view, without merit. In particular, Cameron alleged a failure on the part of the plaintiffs (principally, on the part of JHL and JSL) to properly inspect or maintain the Standby Slip Joint as well as to properly inspect the said slip joint prior to using it on 16\u00a0March 2001. However, we agree with the Judge that the plaintiffs were entitled to assume that Cameron had fulfilled its contractual obligations owed to them without having to carry out any inspections or maintenance. It seems to us that this is not only just and fair but also commonsensical. In any event, Cameron had not furnished the plaintiffs with the requisite drawings that would have enabled them to carry out inspections or maintenance, even assuming that there was a duty on the plaintiffs to do so in the first instance. Further, the essence of a <i>novus actus interveniens</i> required an act on the part of the plaintiffs whose nature was sufficient to break the chain of causation. We agree with the Judge that the alleged act (or omission, rather) fell short of constituting a <i>novus actus interveniens</i> on the part of the plaintiffs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>The doctrine of contributory negligence</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">134\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Cameron also relied on the doctrine of contributory negligence with respect to its alleged liability to the plaintiffs. Although, as we have noted (at [114] and [115]), the existence of a legal duty is not necessary for the purposes of establishing contributory negligence, we are of the view that the plaintiffs were not guilty of not taking the requisite care. Indeed, as we have alluded to in the preceding paragraph, a reasonable person in the shoes of the plaintiffs would have assumed that Cameron would fulfil its contractual obligations without any further action on their (the plaintiffs\u2019) part.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">135\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we have already mentioned, the Judge dealt with the issues in the court below in a comprehensive and fair manner.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">136\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We differ somewhat in the reasoning with regard to two issues only. Of those two issues, we would modify the Judge\u2019s decision in part only with respect to one of them. In summary, in so far as the first issue is concerned, whilst we agree with the Judge that the documents in the Damages Bundle could not be admitted, we hold (in so far as the threshold issue with respect to the very introduction of the Documents is concerned) that this holding is based not so much on the fact (as the Judge found) that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated that they had satisfied a positive burden placed on them to comply with the requisite provisions of the Evidence Act <i>per se</i> but, rather, because the defendants had in fact objected to the introduction of the Documents. At <i>that</i> point, the plaintiffs were <i>then</i> under a legal obligation to in fact satisfy the requisite provisions of the Evidence Act, which they did <i>not</i>. In addition (and here we agree with the holding of the Judge), <i>in any event</i>, the plaintiffs did <i>not</i> meet the legal hurdles posed by the doctrine of hearsay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">137\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the second issue is concerned, we agree with the Judge that both Cameron and Stork were <i>equally</i> liable to <i>the plaintiffs</i>. Where we differ, with respect, from her decision is the fact that insufficient consideration was given (in so far as the issue of an <i>indemnity</i> was concerned) to <i>the legal relationship</i> <i>between Cameron and Stork</i>. In the event, we hold that Stork was liable to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$250,000 for breach of its contractual obligations which it owed to Cameron (in addition to its liability to pay the plaintiffs US$500,000 for the breach of the duty of care which it owed to them).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">138\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Returning to the dearth of argument in the court below, unfortunately, in an adversarial system, much depends upon the efforts of counsel concerned. Nevertheless, we ought, in fairness, point out that this last-mentioned issue has not been actively canvassed in the case law as well as textbooks and is, to that extent, a subtle one. However, we trust that it will be neither subtle nor esoteric after the clarification in the present case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">139\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the circumstances, we allow Cameron\u2019s appeal with regard to the issue of the indemnity claimed under its contract with Stork in part. In other words, in so far as the BOP stack is concerned, Stork is liable to indemnify Cameron in the sum of US$250,000. In addition, Stork remains liable in the sum of US$500,000, which represents its own liability to the plaintiffs with respect to this particular item and, to that extent, must contribute to any damages payable by Cameron to the plaintiffs to that extent. In all other respects, however, we affirm the decision of the Judge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">140\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the issue of costs is concerned, we find nothing wrong with the decision of the Judge (as set out in the costs judgment). However, in the light of our specific finding on the issue of indemnity as set out in the preceding paragraph, we would modify the Judge\u2019s order as to costs inasmuch as Cameron should be awarded half of its costs of the third party proceedings. In addition, Stork should indemnify Cameron to the extent of 25% of the costs (including disbursements) payable to the plaintiffs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">141\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as the present proceedings are concerned, the plaintiffs are to pay the costs of the defendants in Civil Appeals Nos\u00a096 and 122 of 2005. The first defendant (Cameron) is to bear 25% of the costs of the plaintiffs and the second defendant (Stork) is to bear 75% of the costs of the plaintiffs in Civil Appeals Nos\u00a097, 98, 128 and 129 of 2005. As between themselves, the first and second defendants are to bear their own costs in Civil Appeals Nos\u00a097, 98, 128 and 129 of 2005.</span></p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref1\" name=\"_ftn1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 1]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">See Item 1, Quotation No</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">QT2279-GA.R1 at Cameron\u2019s Appellant\u2019s Core Bundle (\u201cCACB\u201d) at p 147.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref2\" name=\"_ftn2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 2]</span></span></span></span></a>\u00a0<span lang=\"EN-GB\">See CACB at p 147.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn3\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn3\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref3\" name=\"_ftn3\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 3]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">See the Appellants\u2019 Case (\u201cAC\u201d) at [152].</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn4\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn4\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref4\" name=\"_ftn4\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See AC at [86].</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn6\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn6\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref6\" name=\"_ftn6\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span pp 473-478.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn7\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn7\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref7\" name=\"_ftn7\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 7]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0See ACB at p 477.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn8\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn8\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref8\" name=\"_ftn8\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 8]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0See ACB at p 478.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn9\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn9\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref9\" lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0See NE at pp 88-90.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn10\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn10\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref10\" name=\"_ftn10\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 10]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0See NE at pp 38-41.</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn11\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn11\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref11\" name=\"_ftn11\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[note: 11]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0See NE at pp 77-80.</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n
