</CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0March 2006</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Tay Yong Kwang\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prior to the grant of the temporary occupation permit (\u201cTOP\u201d) for a shopping mall, the taxpayer company (\u201cthe taxpayer\u201d) incurred certain expenses and sought to have those expenses deducted and carried forward as losses. The Comptroller of Income Tax (\u201cthe Comptroller\u201d) refused to allow the deduction and to treat the expenses as losses. The taxpayer appealed to the Income Tax Board of Review (\u201cthe ITBR\u201d) which upheld the decision of the Comptroller. The taxpayer then appealed to the High Court in District Court Appeal No\u00a014 of 2004 where Andrew Ang\u00a0J (\u201cthe judge\u201d) affirmed the ITBR\u2019s decision but disagreed with it on one of two issues. The taxpayer then appealed to the Court of Appeal. We dismissed the appeal with costs and now give the reasons for our decision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The Agreed Statement of Facts</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appeal before the ITBR, as was the appeal before the judge and before us, was based on an Agreed Statement of Facts dated 25\u00a0September 2002 which stated as follows (the taxpayer is referred to therein as \u201cT\u00a0Ltd\u201d and particulars which would identify it have been omitted in order to preserve its anonymity):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant, T\u00a0Ltd (\u201cthe Company\u201d), is a company incorporated in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company was incorporated by a firm of lawyers on 24\u00a0July 1989 as a private limited company. It had a $2 paid-up capital and did not carry on any business. In 1992 it was acquired by the D\u00a0Land Group upon which its name was changed to T Ltd and its first object to:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To purchase, take on lease or otherwise acquire from the Housing and Development Board the land described as Land Parcel P4, Tampines in the Republic of Singapore and any estate or interest in and any rights connected with such land.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 To carry on the business of constructing or otherwise developing a building on Land Parcel P4, Tampines, for the purpose of owning, managing and operating a property letting business.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">On 24\u00a0June 1998, the Company was converted to a public company.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company was awarded the land from the HDB on 6\u00a0June 1992. It signed a building agreement with the HDB on 1\u00a0December 1992 under which it undertook to develop the land. The proposed development project was described as a \u201ccomprehensive retail complex with 3 basements (2 for carparks and 1 for shops and supermarket), a 4-storey shopping podium \u2026 and two towers \u2026\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The purchase of the land was funded by share capital and interest-bearing shareholders\u2019 loans. Subsequently, and during the construction phase, part of the shareholders\u2019 loans was converted to share capital and part (but not all) replaced by external borrowing which bore interest.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company submitted plans on 16\u00a0December 1992 to develop the complex and obtained provisional planning approval on 6\u00a0February 1993. The chronology of significant events from then on was:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Date of award of main building contract: 19\u00a0October 1993</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Date of commencement of superstructure works:2\u00a0November 1993</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Date of Temporary Occupation Permit (\u201cTOP\u201d):\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 15\u00a0November 1995</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Date when first tenancy commenced:\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 15\u00a0November 1995</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the accounts for 1990 and 1991, the principal activity of the Company was described in the Directors\u2019 Report as that of \u201cinvestment in and development of properties. Such activities, however, have not commenced since the date of incorporation of the company.\u201d In the accounts for 1992 (the year in which the land was acquired) to 1995, the principal activity was described as \u201cproperty investment and development\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company\u2019s intention in developing the building was for long-term investment by letting out to various tenants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company incurred interest and other expenses such as administrative, marketing and advertising expenses from 28\u00a0October 1993 to 15\u00a0November 1995, the date of the granting of the TOP. The amount of these pre-TOP expenses brought forward to the year of assessment 1997 (the subject year of this appeal) was $5,213,184, comprised as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Interest\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $4,825,015</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">General and administrative expenses\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $ 86,401</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Advertising and promotion expenses,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">agency fees and marketing expenses\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 $ 301,768</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company claimed these expenses (\u201cthe said expenses\u201d) as deductions under section\u00a014 of the Income Tax Act and sought to carry forward the excess of the said expenses over income as losses under section\u00a037 of the Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Comptroller of Income Tax refused to allow the deductions of the said expenses (and hence the carry-forward of the losses) incurred prior to the date of the granting of the TOP.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Company applied to the Comptroller under section\u00a076(2) of the Act, for the said assessment to be reviewed and revised.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 20\u00a0October 2000 the Comptroller issued a Notice of Refusal to Amend in respect of the said assessment and the Company on 20\u00a0October 2000 filed with the Comptroller and the Clerk to the Board of Review a Notice of Appeal under section\u00a079(1) of the Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The relevant statutory provisions</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The arguments centred on whether the expenses set out in the Agreed Statement of Facts were deductible under the general formula in s\u00a014(1) of the Income Tax Act (Cap\u00a0134, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d) and, where the interest was concerned, whether it was deductible specifically under s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>). As the inclusionary provisions in s\u00a014 are subject to the exclusionary provisions in s\u00a015 of the Act, the arguments then flowed to whether the interest was disallowed as a deduction under s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) in any event. If the deductions were allowed, they would reduce the taxpayer\u2019s assessable income pursuant to s\u00a037. The said provisions, including s\u00a010 on \u201cCharge of income tax\u201d, read:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Income tax shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, be payable at the rate or rates specified hereinafter for each year of assessment upon the income of any person accruing in or derived from Singapore or received in Singapore from outside Singapore in respect of \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 gains or profits from any trade, business, profession or vocation, for whatever period of time such trade, business, profession or vocation may have been carried on or exercised; \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(1) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purpose of ascertaining the income of any person \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for any period from any source chargeable with tax under this Act (referred to in this Part as the income), there shall be deducted all outgoings and expenses wholly and exclusively incurred during that period by that person in the production of the income, including \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 except as provided in this section, any sum payable by way of interest upon any money borrowed by that person where the Comptroller is satisfied that the interest was payable on capital employed in acquiring the income;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding the provisions of this Act, for the purpose of ascertaining the income of any person, no deduction shall be allowed in respect of \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>c</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 any capital withdrawn or any sum employed or intended to be employed as capital except as provided by section\u00a014(1)(<i>h</i>);</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0(1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The assessable income of any person from all sources chargeable with tax under this Act for any year of assessment shall be the remainder of his statutory income for that year after the deductions allowed in this Part have been made.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There shall be deducted \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the amount of a loss incurred by that person during any year preceding the year of assessment in any trade, business, profession or vocation which, if it had been a profit would have been assessable under this Act, and which has not been allowed against his statutory income of a prior year[.]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The decisions of the ITBR and the High Court</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The parties proceeded on the basis of two issues compendiously identified as the \u201cPre-Commencement Issue\u201d and the \u201cCapital Expenditure Issue\u201d. It was agreed that expenses were not deductible under s\u00a014 of the Act if there was no business in existence at the time the said expenses were incurred. Under the first issue, the ITBR was of the view that the said expenses of the taxpayer were incurred before the commencement of the business of letting out the shopping mall in question as that business commenced only when the TOP was granted. In respect of the second issue, the ITBR held that the interest paid, being capital in nature, was specifically disallowed under s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) of the Act.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge agreed with the ITBR on the pre-commencement issue but disagreed with its decision on the capital expenditure issue. He was of the opinion that the interest incurred was of a revenue nature and would therefore have been deductible if not for his decision on the pre-commencement issue. However, since the taxpayer had to succeed on both issues, the judge dismissed the appeal accordingly.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, the taxpayer contended that the judge had erred in his determination of the pre-commencement issue. The taxpayer also submitted that even if its appeal failed before us, each party should bear its own costs here and below as this was a test case and the Comptroller had succeeded on only one of the two issues in contention.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Comptroller did not file a cross-appeal but urged us to dismiss the taxpayer\u2019s appeal on the pre-commencement issue and to overturn the judge\u2019s ruling on the capital expenditure issue. He sought the second order on the basis of O\u00a057 r\u00a09A(5) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2004\u00a0Rev Ed) which permits a respondent in an appeal who, not having appealed from the decision of the High Court, but desiring to contend on appeal that the said decision should be affirmed on grounds other than those relied upon by that court, to do so by stating the grounds of that contention in its Case. The Comptroller also submitted that there was no good reason why the costs order sought by the taxpayer should be made in this case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The decision of the Court of Appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Issue 1 \u2013 The pre-commencement issue</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge framed this issue in the following manner (see <nobr>[2005] 4 SLR 285</nobr> at [10]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Was the appellant carrying on business at the time it incurred the said expenses? If it was not, the expenses are not allowable, being pre-commencement expenses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In our view, in order to ascertain whether the taxpayer had commenced business, we have to enquire what that business was: <i>Esso Australia Resources Ltd v Commissioner of Taxation</i> (1998) 84\u00a0FCR 541 at 557. Both the taxpayer and the Comptroller agreed that the taxpayer\u2019s business included the management of the shopping mall and the generating of rental income from letting out the various units therein. Their positions diverged on the issue of whether the business extended to matters that had occurred at any time before the grant of the TOP.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The taxpayer argued that its business extended to the acquisition of the land on which the shopping mall was subsequently built as well as the construction of the shopping mall. If that was the correct position, the taxpayer\u2019s business would have commenced from the time it committed itself financially. It accepted that a mere mental commitment to purchase the land was not sufficient. On 4\u00a0July 1992, it paid 25% of the price for the land and on 4\u00a0September 1992, it paid the balance. It was seeking to deduct only the expenses incurred after the superstructure works had commenced and not the costs of construction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The taxpayer sought to characterise its business by reference to the objects enumerated in its memorandum of association (see para\u00a02 of the Agreed Statement of Facts). Relying on the words of Pollock\u00a0MR in <i>Inland Revenue Commissioners v Westleigh Estates Company, Limited</i> <nobr>[1924] 1 KB 390</nobr> at 409, it argued that if a company\u2019s objects were business objects and were in fact carried out, then the company should be regarded as carrying on business. Since its objects encompassed the purchase of land and the construction of the shopping mall, the very things that it proceeded to carry out, it submitted that its business must extend to such purchase and construction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While the objects clause in a company\u2019s memorandum of association could provide some useful guide as to the nature of its business, it has to be noted that many companies have very broadly defined objects in a wide range of businesses in their memoranda. Indeed, some may seek to have invisible boundaries by having all-encompassing clauses such as \u201cand such other lawful businesses and activities as may be decided by the directors from time to time\u201d. It was therefore for good reason that Lord\u00a0Diplock in <i>American Leaf Blending Co Sdn Bhd v Director-General of Inland Revenue</i> <nobr>[1979] AC 676</nobr> at 683 observed that Pollock\u00a0MR\u2019s words in the case cited above should be read in the context of a company carrying out one of its principal objects and that not every isolated act authorised by its memorandum of association necessarily qualified as the carrying on of a business. Similarly, in <i>Mitsui-Soko International Pte Ltd v The Comptroller of Income Tax</i> (1998) MSTC 7,349 at 7,352\u20137,353 (\u201c<i>Mitsui-Soko</i>\u201d), Warren Khoo\u00a0J in the High Court cautioned against adopting Pollock\u00a0MR\u2019s words as a statement of a rule or principle because the practice of having widely worded memoranda of association often obfuscated the purpose for which a particular company was formed, and a literal application of Pollock\u00a0MR\u2019s <i>dictum</i> might result in almost every economic activity undertaken by a company as constituting the carrying on of business.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The inquiry should therefore focus on what a company actually carries on rather than what it professes to carry on in order to know what its true business is (<i>The</i> <i>Commissioners of Inland Revenue v The Hyndland Investment Company, Limited</i> (1929) 14\u00a0TC 694 at 699; <i>Mount Elizabeth (Pte) Ltd v Comptroller of Income Tax</i> <nobr>[1986] SLR 421</nobr>). The facts of each case should then be examined to determine whether the activities in issue are merely preparatory acts or whether they constitute the carrying on of that business. We agree that a commonsensical and pragmatic approach, as advocated in <i>Mitsui-Soko</i>, ought to be adopted. We also agree with the following observation made by the judge below ([8] <i>supra</i> at [18]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In tax cases where the issue was whether the taxpayer company was either investing or dealing in property, the courts have not been timorous to disregard objects which they considered to be self-serving and to look instead at the operations of the company to determine what its true business was. It should be no different where the enquiry is into the date of commencement of a company\u2019s business as such enquiry will bring in tow the question what the business of the company is. Each case will have to be examined on its facts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As found by the judge, the letting out of the shopping mall was the only regular activity and the primary source of the taxpayer\u2019s income. The business of the taxpayer was therefore the letting out of the shopping mall. Since this was the business of the taxpayer, it followed that its business could not have commenced before the TOP was granted for the shopping mall as it would not have been able to embark on its income-generating activity, which was the taking in of tenants. It was only upon the grant of the TOP that the shopping mall was capable of producing income and the taxpayer company was ready to begin its ordinary business operations. The purchase of the land and the construction works were preparatory steps taken towards the ultimate object of owning, managing and operating the business of letting out. Although this court said in <i>Pinetree Resort Pte Ltd v Comptroller of Income Tax</i> <nobr>[2000] 4 SLR 1</nobr> at [47] that in determining whether the nexus between the incurrence of an expense and the production of income in s\u00a014 is present, \u201cthe business has to be looked at <i>as a whole set of operations</i> directed toward producing income, in which case an expenditure which is not capital expenditure is usually considered as having been incurred in gaining or producing income\u201d [emphasis added], that statement was made in the context of a business which had already commenced and was producing income. It was not meant to be a statement on when a business could be said to have commenced.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Indian decision in <i>Commissioner of Income Tax, Gujarat I v Saurashtra Cement and Chemical Industries Ltd</i> <nobr>[1973] 91 ITR 170</nobr> does not assist the taxpayer as the facts there were exceptional, apart from the peculiarities of Indian revenue law pointed out by the judge below (at [41] of his judgment, that there was a distinction between \u201csetting up\u201d of a business and \u201ccommencement of business\u201d in Indian revenue law). In that case, the taxpayer was in the business of manufacturing and selling cement. The three activities in issue were the extraction of limestone, the manufacture of cement and the sale thereof. The parties there agreed that the extraction of limestone did not constitute a distinct and independent business of the taxpayer. The court there concluded that the business commenced when the company started to quarry limestone and not at the later time when it commenced the manufacture of cement. It was held that all three activities constituted the business of the taxpayer and that the business could not be carried out without any one of them. The extraction of limestone, although not forming the core of the business, was a regular or continuous exercise in the day-to-day operations and was such an indivisible or intrinsic part of the business that it could be said that the business commenced with the extraction of limestone. In the present appeal, the taxpayer\u2019s purchase and development of the land was a one-off activity and, as we have indicated, its business could not have commenced before it was in a position to let out the various spaces available in the shopping mall.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge\u2019s decision certainly did not imply that a business could never commence unless it turned in profits. If it were otherwise, s\u00a037(2)(<i>a</i>) of the Act would be rendered otiose. Indeed, it is common for many a business to be making losses in the initial stages of its operations. However, this is different from a business which produces no income because it is not yet in a position to generate any. For a business to commence in a situation like the present case, the taxpayer must have established an income-generating asset or income-earning structure. In this case, that would be the shopping mall upon the grant of the TOP. The taxpayer could not invoke s\u00a037(2)(<i>a</i>) because it was unable to show that the expenses constituted a loss incurred in \u201cany trade, business, profession or vocation\u201d. It was unable to do that as it did not have in place at the material time the business of letting out of the shopping mall and therefore could not come within the terms of s\u00a014(1).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We therefore agree with the judge\u2019s decision on the pre-commencement issue and, like him, would hold that the expenses in issue were not deductible under s\u00a014 of the Act. On this ground alone, the appeal ought to be dismissed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Issue 2 - The capital expenditure issue</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this case, there was no dispute that the loans taken out were applied to the purchase of the land and that such loans were capital expenditure. The issue was whether the interest incurred on such loans was deductible. Applying ss\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) and 15(1)(<i>c</i>) to the facts of this case, the Comptroller argued that interest on the loans before the grant of the TOP was of a capital nature or was \u201cin respect of \u2026 any sum employed \u2026 as capital\u201d and should therefore be disallowed as a deduction. The taxpayer contended that interest was inherently of a revenue nature and that the interest incurred was not caught by the prohibition in s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On this capital expenditure issue, the judge was of the view that s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) was worded differently from its equivalent in the UK tax legislation and that case law on the latter, which held that the nature of interest depended on the nature of the underlying loan, was therefore inapplicable here. He reasoned as follows ([8] <i>supra</i> at [54] to [58]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the UK, the provision corresponding to our s\u00a015(1)(c) prescribes that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[N]o sum shall be deducted in respect of \u2026 any sum employed or intended to be employed as capital \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In <i>The European Investment Trust Co Ltd v Jackson (Inspector of Taxes)</i> (1932) 18\u00a0TC 1 (\u201c<i>European Investment Trust</i>\u201d), the Court of Appeal in England apparently decided that whether or not interest was of a revenue or capital nature depended on whether the loan itself (which gave rise to the interest) was employed as capital in the business. This view was widely criticised and subsequently abrogated by legislation. In <i>Beauchamp (Inspector of Taxes) v F W Woolworth plc</i> <nobr>[1988] STC 714</nobr> (\u201c<i>Woolworth</i>\u201d), the English Court of Appeal had occasion to consider its \u00a0\u00a0 earlier decision in the <i>European Investment Trust</i> case. Nourse\u00a0LJ who delivered the judgment of the court described it as \u201ca very curious case\u201d. He then went on to say (at 717\u2013718):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Having read and re-read the report of <i>The European Investment Trust Co Ltd v</i> <i>Jackson</i> several times, I have come to a clear conclusion that it can only be explained on the footing that it was conceded throughout that the status of the interest as a deductible item was governed by the status of the advances, and that that concession was made because it was assumed that the words \u2018in respect of\u2019 were the equivalent of \u2018in connection with\u2019 or the like. Perhaps the words of the 1842 Act had been forgotten. If that assumption is made, I can well see that it can be said that the interest on the advances would be sums in respect of the advances and thus no more deductible than the advances themselves. However, a concession on that point is not the equivalent of a binding decision. Indeed, it is no decision at all. So I think that we are free to disregard that case so far as it related to interest, although its authority would no doubt be unimpeachable in regard to the advances themselves.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Although the decision of the Court of Appeal in the <i>Woolworth</i> case was reversed by the House of Lords, there is nothing in the House of Lords\u2019 judgment delivered by Lord\u00a0Templeman which detracts from the Court of Appeal\u2019s criticism of this aspect of the <i>European Investment Trust</i> case ([54] <i>supra</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 So much then as to how the UK provision was construed in the <i>European Investment Trust</i> case. Should the Singapore provision be interpreted likewise? Although counsel for the appellant argued cogently why it ought not be likewise construed, he may have been a little generous in conceding that the language of the Singapore provision is close to its UK counterpart. As noted, the UK provision prescribes that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[N]o sum shall be deducted in respect of \u2026 any sum employed or intended to be employed as capital \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In other words, \u201cno sum \u2026 in respect of any sum employed as capital \u2026\u201d is to be deducted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As framed, it is possible to construe the \u201csum\u201d first referred to as separate and distinct from the second. On this basis, it did no violence to the language of the UK provision for the <i>European Investment Trust</i> case ([54] <i>supra</i>) to construe the first sum as being referable to interest while the second referred to the principal amount on which the interest accrued.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Singapore provision is differently worded. It states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[N]o deduction shall be allowed in respect of \u2026 any sum employed or intended to be employed as capital.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The provision makes no mention of any sum other than the sum employed or intended to be employed as capital. Whereas the words \u201cin respect of\u201d in the UK provision could be read to mean \u201cin connection with\u201d without doing violence to the statutory provision, the same words \u201cin connection with\u201d could not, in my view, comfortably substitute for \u201cin respect of\u201d in the Singapore provision. It would immediately invite the question \u201cDeduction of what?\u201d To my mind, the words \u201cin respect of\u201d in the Singapore provision is the equivalent of \u201cfor\u201d or \u201con account of\u201d. Thus, what is prohibited is the deduction of the sum employed or intended to be employed as capital.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is inconceivable that the legislature would provide in unambiguous terms in s\u00a014(1)(a) for the deduction of \u201cinterest upon any money borrowed \u2026 where \u2026 the interest was payable on capital employed in acquiring the income\u201d and then in the very next section prescribe in s\u00a015(1)(c) that interest on any sum employed as capital is not deductible. Neither was this the position taken by Revenue before the decision in <i>Wharf Properties Ltd v Commissioner of Inland Revenue (Hong Kong)</i> [[1997]] STC\u00a0351 (\u201c<i>Wharf</i>\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge then went on to consider <i>Wharf</i> (a Hong Kong tax case which went before the Privy Council) and the High Court of Australia\u2019s decision in <i>Steele v DFC of T</i> 99 ATC 4242 (\u201c<i>Steele</i>\u201d). He concluded that <i>Steele</i>, which held by a 4:1 majority that interest outgoings were not of a capital nature, accorded more with the conventional and well-known distinction between revenue and capital expenditure and was to be preferred to the reasoning in <i>Wharf</i>. In <i>Wharf</i>, the issue before the Privy Council was whether interest on loans, taken out for the purchase of a train depot to redevelop it as a commercial complex, was deductible for tax purposes. The judge reasoned in the following manner before arriving at his conclusion that s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) was never intended to apply to interest on loans ([8] <i>supra</i> at [58] to [70]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u2026 The relevant provisions of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap\u00a0112) (Hong Kong) are as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a016(1)(a) provides that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 there shall be deducted all outgoings and expenses to the extent to which they are incurred during the basis period for that year of assessment by such person in the production of profits \u2026 including \u2013</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 sums payable \u2026 by way of interest upon any money borrowed by him for the purpose of producing such profits \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a017 then contains a list of expenditures for which no deduction is allowed. It includes:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-3\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 any expenditure of a capital nature.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The Privy Council held that the interest was of a capital nature and, therefore, not an allowable deduction to the taxpayer. Apparently, as a result of this decision, the Revenue in Singapore changed their interpretation of s\u00a015(1)(c) despite the fact that s\u00a017(c) of the Hong Kong legislation is in terms much wider than s\u00a015(1)(c), disallowing, as it does, deduction for \u201cany expenditure of a capital nature\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further support for the appellant\u2019s construction of s\u00a015(1)(c) may be found in the history of the Singapore legislation. The Singapore Income Tax Ordinance was introduced in 1948, some 16 years after the <i>European Investment Trust</i> case ([54] <i>supra</i>). In his report to the Governors of the Malayan Union and Singapore in 1947, the draftsman, R\u00a0B\u00a0Heasman, a tax expert from the UK, had this to say about the draft legislation (in which our present s\u00a014 was cl\u00a011):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <b>Part\u00a0IV \u2013 Ascertainment of Income</b> \u2013 Clause\u00a011 gives authority in general terms for the deduction of all outgoings and expenses wholly and exclusively incurred in earning the income. Certain deductions are mentioned specifically, e.g<i>.,</i> interest on borrowed money used in the business; rent payable by a trader in respect of land and buildings occupied by him for business purposes; bad and doubtful debts; contributions under the Widows &amp; Orphans\u2019 Funds; and contributions to pension, provident or similar funds approved by the Commissioner.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Note the simple formulation to describe the coverage of s\u00a014(1)(a): \u201cinterest on borrowed money used in the business\u201d. Counsel for the appellant submitted that that is what s\u00a014(1)(a) was intended to cover and how it should be read. If so, then specific provision was already made in the Singapore Income Tax Ordinance from its inception to overcome the effect of the decision in the <i>European Investment Trust</i>. That this was the intention is reinforced when it is remembered that at that time s\u00a015 was subject to the express provisions of s\u00a014. Thus an item of interest expense qualifying for deduction under s\u00a014 could not be disallowed by the general provisions of s\u00a015(1)(c) (\u201c\u2026 any sum employed or intended to be employed as capital\u201d). The <i>European Investment Trust</i> case, therefore, was inapplicable to Singapore as long ago as 1948.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prior to 1979, s\u00a015(1) commenced with the words \u201csubject to the provisions of this Act\u201d. However, the relationship between the two sections was regarded as one where the specific disallowances in s\u00a015(1) would override the general deduction provision of s\u00a014(1), but that if an item of expenditure passed the general positive test in s\u00a014(1), it would not be disqualified under a general disallowance under s\u00a015(1), especially s\u00a015(1)(b). As counsel for the appellant pointed out, this made sense as the legislature could not have intended that an item of expenditure which qualified under the general test in s\u00a014(1) should be disqualified under what was the reverse of the same test in s\u00a015(1)(b).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Malaysian Federal Court in <i>Director-General of Inland Revenue v Rakyat Berjaya Sdn Bhd</i> <nobr>[1984] 1 MLJ 248</nobr> endorsed this view of the relationship between the equivalent Malaysian sections (the Malaysian and Singapore income tax legislation both originating from the same colonial model):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Section\u00a039(1)(b) disallows \u201cany disbursements or expenses not being money wholly and exclusively laid out or expended for the purpose of producing the gross income.\u201d If we substitute the words \u201cfor the purpose of\u201d for the word \u201cin\u201d the wording would then be the same as that of \u201cthe wholly and exclusively\u201d test in section\u00a033(1). On the basis that the Taxpayer\u2019s interest payments pass that test and are deductible under section\u00a033(1), they will not be disallowed under section\u00a039(1)(b).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[<i>per</i> Lee Hun Hoe\u00a0CJ (Borneo) at 254]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As matters stood before 1979, if the general allowance provision in s\u00a014(1) was not overridden or qualified by the general disallowance provision in s\u00a015(1)(b), even less would a specific allowance provision such as s\u00a014(1)(a).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">63\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the appellant correctly pointed out that this was but an application of the maxim of statutory construction <i>generalia specialibus non derogant</i>, <i>ie</i>, general provisions will not abrogate special provisions. As was stated in <i>Craies on Statute Law</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 7th\u00a0Ed, 1971) at p. 378, quoting the Privy Council in the case of <i>Barker v Edger</i> <nobr>[1898] AC 748</nobr> at 754:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">When the legislature has given its attention to a separate subject, and made provision for it, the presumption is that a subsequent general enactment is not intended to interfere with the special provision <i>unless it manifests that intention very clearly</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">64\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In 1979, the Act was amended by the Income Tax (Amendment) Act (No\u00a07 of 1979). A new paragraph was added to s\u00a015(1) to disallow expenses in respect of a motor car which was not a business service passenger vehicle (or \u201cQ-plate\u201d car). The words \u201cSubject to\u201d in s\u00a015(1) were replaced by \u201cNotwithstanding\u201d. In order to preserve the deductibility of some of the specific items under s\u00a014(1) which would otherwise obviously run foul of the general disallowances in s\u00a015(1), exceptions were carved out of some of the paragraphs in s\u00a015(1).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">65\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the appellant submitted that it was never envisaged that a specific deduction for interest on borrowed capital (provided for in s\u00a014(1)(a)) was required to be saved from the general words of s\u00a015(1)(b) or (c) because the accepted view was that the interest mentioned in s\u00a014(1)(a) was of a revenue and not capital nature. I would go further to say that on the construction which I have placed on the words in s\u00a015(1)(c), what is disallowed is a deduction in respect of the loan or advance and not the interest thereon. Accordingly, no saving words were required to be carved out of s\u00a015(1)(c).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">66\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the appellant\u2019s contention that the opening words \u201cSubject to\u201d were replaced by \u201cNotwithstanding\u201d to confer primacy on the disallowance for non Q-plate cars appears to be borne out by the Explanatory Memorandum to the Income Tax (Amendment) Bill (No\u00a09 of 1979) and the Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Reports (30\u00a0March 1979) that sets out the speech of the Minister for Finance at the Second Reading of the Bill.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">67\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The entire explanation in the Explanatory Memorandum on the clause amending s\u00a015(1) reads:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Clause\u00a05 amends section\u00a015 of the Act to disallow deduction of expenses incurred in respect of a motor vehicle which is not registered as a business service passenger vehicle.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">68\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Minister\u2019s speech is similarly confined to an exposition of the \u201canomalous situation\u201d being targeted:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A sole proprietor or a partner of a professional firm can register his car as a private vehicle, use it in connection with his business, and claim tax deduction for expenses under section\u00a014 of the Income tax Act without having to pay the double road tax and Area Licence Fees applicable to business vehicles. To rectify this anomaly, clause\u00a05 of the Bill seeks to amend section\u00a015 of the Act to restrict the deduction for expenses only to motor cars which are registered as business service passenger vehicles.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">69\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the appellant therefore submits that the legislature did not intend that the general disallowance provisions of s\u00a015(1)(c) were a \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 limit or interference with the specific allowance under s\u00a014(1)(a). I accept that but more because, in my view, s\u00a015(1)(c) was never intended to apply \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 to interest.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">70\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the basis of this construction of s\u00a015(1)(c), the <i>Wharf</i> case would have no application in Singapore. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With the greatest respect to the judge, we do not think the different sentence structures adopted in our s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) and in the UK equivalent were meant to convey different meanings. In our view, the two provisions were effectively stating the same thing. The word \u201cdeduction\u201d in our s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) appears to us to refer to the same thing as the first \u201csum\u201d in the UK provision. The phrase \u201cin respect of\u201d has been said to be the widest of any expressions intended to convey some connection between two related subject matters (<i>Nowegijick v The Queen</i> 83\u00a0DTC 5041 at 5045). A plain reading of s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) does not compel us to exclude interest expenditure from its scope. The said provision applies to all capital expenditure. Interest in respect of a capital purpose is capital expenditure and is therefore incurred as a \u201csum employed or intended to be employed as capital\u201d within the meaning of s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reading s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) in the way we have indicated above need not result in a conflict with s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>). For the provisions to conflict, it would have to be assumed that s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) allows the deductibility of all interest, including interest in respect of sums employed as capital, which is what s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) would prohibit if it does apply to interest. However, s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) allows the deductibility of interest payable on a loan only if it was \u201cpayable on capital employed in acquiring the income\u201d. Where a taxpayer has borrowed money for investment and incurred interest on the loan, the investment must produce income for the interest expense to be deductible under the Act (<i>Andermatt Investments Pte Ltd v Comptroller of Income Tax</i> <nobr>[1995] 3 SLR 451</nobr> at 460, [27] (\u201c<i>Andermatt</i>\u201d); <i>JD Ltd v Comptroller of Income Tax</i> <nobr>[2006] 1 SLR 484</nobr> at [48] (\u201c<i>JD Ltd</i>\u201d)). If the loan is applied towards an accretion of capital, the interest incurred thereon is not a deductible item. This means, in the context of this appeal, that only the interest incurred after the grant of the TOP qualifies for deduction under s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>). The operative provision that excludes interest on loans taken out for the acquisition of capital is therefore s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) and there is no need to resort to s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Is s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) therefore redundant? It may be said that ss\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) and 15(1)(<i>c</i>) approach the issue of interest expenditure from different angles and mirror each other in effect. However, s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>) still operates to preserve the exception (to the capital expenditure rule) embodied in s\u00a014(1)(<i>h</i>) (which permits capital expenditure in respect of mines or other sources of mineral deposits of a wasting nature to be deducted according to the rules made under s\u00a07), thereby ensuring that s\u00a014(1)(<i>h</i>) does not lose all effect after s\u00a014 was made subordinate to s\u00a015 by the legislative changes to the Act in 1979 (see [64] of the judge\u2019s judgment quoted above for the said changes).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In so far as reliance was placed on the Australian decision of <i>Steele</i> ([19] <i>supra</i>), we note that the Australian tax position has already been shown to be different from ours in that the former requires a weaker link between deductible expenses and the source of income (see <i>Andermatt</i> and <i>JD Ltd</i>). We also note that the three judges (Gleeson\u00a0CJ, Gaudron and Gummow\u00a0JJ) in <i>Steele</i> who made the remarks at [29] of that case quoted by the judge here ([8] <i>supra</i> at [72]), also said (at [27] and [33]) that the distinction between capital and revenue expenditure was not a critical one in Australian tax law:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 An example of the difference between the British and Australian systems is provided by the <i>European Investment Trust Co Ltd v Jackson</i>, a case decided eight years before Dixon\u00a0J\u2019s observation, where Finlay\u00a0J said that in the British system it was \u201cthoroughly well established by a long line of cases that [interest] is not deductible if it is in truth the interest on capital\u201d. In that case, a distinction was drawn between a sum expended in order to earn profits, which formed a valid deduction in arriving at the profits, and a sum expended to obtain capital. That has never been the critical distinction in Australia.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As was explained in <i>Australia National Hotels v FC of T</i>, interest is ordinarily a recurrent or periodic payment which secures, not an enduring advantage, but, rather, the use of the borrowed money during the term of the loan. According to the criteria noted by Dixon\u00a0J in <i>Sun Newspapers Ltd and Associated Newspapers Ltd v FC of T</i> it is therefore ordinarily a revenue item. This is not to deny the possibility that there may be particular circumstances where it is proper to regard the purpose of the interest payments as something other than the raising or maintenance of the borrowing and thus, potentially, of a capital nature. However, in the usual case, of which the present is an example, where interest is a recurrent payment to secure the use for a limited time of loan funds, then it is proper to regard the interest as a revenue item, and its character is not altered by reason of the fact that the borrowed funds are used to purchase a capital asset. \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 \u2026 In particular, the distinction between acquiring a capital asset and holding it as an income-producing investment, which may be related to the concept of calculating the profits of a business activity, is not one upon which the Australian legislation turns.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Interest is derivative in nature. It owes its existence to a loan. Whether it is a capital or a revenue expense depends on the purpose for which the loan is employed. If the loan is used for developing a capital asset, the interest payable on that loan is not deductible for tax purposes. If the loan is employed in acquiring income, the interest thereon becomes deductible under s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>). We therefore agree with the following statements made by the Privy Council in <i>Wharf</i> ((1997)\u00a0MSTC 11,025 at 11,028 and 11,029):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Thus, while the question of whether money is intended to be used for a capital or revenue purpose is inconclusive as to whether its receipt is a revenue receipt or an addition to the company\u2019s capital, the purpose of the loan during the period for which the interest payment was made is critical to whether it counts as a capital or revenue expense.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Each payment of interest must be considered in relation to the purpose of the loan during the period for which the interest is paid. Once the asset has been acquired or created and is producing income, the interest is part of the cost of generating that income and therefore a revenue expense.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Accordingly, we respectfully disagree with the judge that the interest incurred is inherently revenue in nature. As the loans in question were used to purchase and develop a capital asset in this case, the interest incurred thereon could not qualify as a deductible under s\u00a014(1)(<i>a</i>) as it was a capital expense. It would naturally also be disallowed under s\u00a015(1)(<i>c</i>). We would therefore uphold the decision of the ITBR on this second issue as well.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Costs</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As indicated earlier, should we uphold the decision of the judge, the taxpayer urged us to order that each party bear its own costs because the Comptroller had succeeded on only one of the two grounds of appeal before the judge and since this was a test case. In the light of our decision above, the first basis for this submission has disappeared. On the second basis, this was a test case only in the sense that the taxpayer had decided to challenge established legal norms. The pre-commencement issue could hardly be said to be a novel point of law and the factual situation of the taxpayer was certainly not unique.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We saw no reason why costs should not follow the event in this appeal. We therefore dismissed the taxpayer\u2019s appeal with costs. The deposit for the appeal is to be paid out to the Comptroller as part of his costs.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9    <CatchWord order=\"6\">Holding cross-directorships</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Breach of duty to act honestly</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">s 157 (1) Companies Act (Cap 50, 1994 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3198\"
