<CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1030\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Conflict of Laws</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1032\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Choice of jurisdiction</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1033\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Exclusive</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Stay of proceedings</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Clause providing that \"Any claims that may arise hereunder must be made at the port of delivery for determination and settlement at that port only\"</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether clause an exclusive jurisdiction clause</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether court should refuse to order stay of proceedings</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR><SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Decision\">\n      <strong>\n        <i>\n          <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Delivered by Chao Hick Tin JA</span>\n        </i>\n      </strong>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 These are two appeals which raised before us an identical issue, namely, whether each of the two separate actions instituted in Singapore by the respondent, UCO Bank (\u201cUCO\u201d), against two shipowners, the appellants in the two appeals, for their wrongful delivery of cargo without the production of the relevant bills of lading (B/L), should be stayed on the ground that there is an exclusive jurisdiction clause in the B/Ls in favour of India.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Except in one respect which we need not go into, the facts surrounding the two actions are similar.\u00a0 Accordingly, the parties have argued before us on the basis that the ruling in Civil Appeal 55/2003 will apply to Civil Appeal 53/2003.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The background</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 UCO is an Indian bank carrying on business here through a local branch.\u00a0 One of its customers was SOM International Pte Ltd (\u201cSOM\u201d), a Singapore incorporated company.\u00a0 SOM was controlled by Mr Som Nath Sood (\u201cSood\u201d).\u00a0 SOM arranged for cargoes to be shipped from various East Malaysian ports to the Port of Kandla in India.\u00a0 One set of cargo was loaded on board the <i>\u201cAsean Pioneer\u201d</i> owned by Golden Shore Transportation Pte Ltd (\u201cGolden Shore\u201d), the appellants in CA 55/2003.\u00a0 The appropriate B/Ls were issued for the shipment (\u201coriginal bills\u201d).\u00a0 Each\u00a0 B/L expressly stated on the front page that it is governed by the law of Singapore and the consignee is \u201cto the order of UCO Bank\u201d.\u00a0 The parties to be notified were SOM and UCO.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pursuant to the application of SOM, letters of credit were issued by UCO to the sellers of the cargo.\u00a0 UCO eventually became the holders of the B/Ls.\u00a0 However, around the same time, SOM procured the issuance of a second set of B/Ls (\u201cswitched bills\u201d) by promising to the shipowner, Golden Shore, that the original bills would be returned to them.\u00a0 In the switched bills, SOM was named as the shipper, instead of SOM\u2019s suppliers.\u00a0 However, the original bills, which were held by UCO, were never returned to Golden Shore as promised by SOM.\u00a0 SOM never paid UCO to obtain the original bills.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The present action of UCO against Golden Shore is based entirely on the original bills which are still in their possession.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The switched bills were transferred by SOM to buyers in India.\u00a0 The vessel, <i>Asean Pioneer,</i> arrived at its destination on 15 January 2001 and the cargo was, between 15 and 25 January 2001, delivered to Indian receivers upon presentation of the switched bills.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After some six months, Golden Shore asked for the return of the original bills but UCO refused.\u00a0 UCO did not at any time, prior to this request for the return of the original bills, enquire about the shipment or ask for the delivery of the cargo.\u00a0 At the same time, UCO repeatedly asked SOM for repayment of the loan.\u00a0 On 20 December 2001, UCO, as holders of the B/L, instituted the present action.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 11 January 2002, Golden Shore applied to have the action stayed on the ground that clause 17 of the B/L, which is an exclusive jurisdiction clause, required that any dispute between the parties has to be adjudicated upon at the port of delivery.\u00a0 The application first came before the Assistant Registrar, who ordered a stay.\u00a0 On appeal, the judge-in-chambers (\u201cthe Judge\u201d), reversed that order and refused a stay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Decision below</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before the High Court, two main issues arose for consideration.\u00a0 The first was whether clause 17 is, in fact, an exclusive jurisdiction clause.\u00a0 The second was, if the answer to the first issue was in the affirmative, whether there are exceptional circumstances indicating \u201cstrong cause\u201d, such that the court should exercise its discretion in UCO\u2019s favour and assist them in breaching the exclusive jurisdiction clause.\u00a0 The Judge answered both issues in the affirmative and refused to order a stay of the present proceeding.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Jurisdictional Clause</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, the same two issues were canvassed and we shall deal with each in turn.\u00a0 As the question on the scope of clause 17 is one of construction, it is necessary that we set it out in full in order that its effect could be appreciated:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Claims.\u00a0 Any claims that may arise hereunder must be made at the port of delivery <i>for determination</i> and settlement at that port only.\u00a0 The Carrier\u2019s liability in case of loss or damage to goods for which they are responsible within the limits of this Bill of Lading to be calculated on and in no case to exceed the net invoice cost and disbursement or pro rata on that basis in the event of partial loss or damage.\u00a0 Unless <i>notice of loss or damage</i> and the general nature of such loss or damage be given in writing to the Carrier or their agents at the port of discharge before or at the time of the removal of the goods into the custody of the person entitled to delivery thereof under the contract of carriage, or if, the loss or damage be not apparent, within three days, such removal shall be prima facie evidence of the delivery by the Carrier of the goods as described in the Bill of Lading.\u00a0 In any event, the Carrier shall be discharged from all liability in respect of loss or damage unless <i>suit</i> is brought within one year after delivery of the goods or the date when the goods should have been delivered.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In no circumstances shall liability exceed the actual loss or damage sustained, the carrier shall not be liable for any consequential or special damages and shall have the option of replacing any lost or damaged goods.\u00a0 Any sum paid to or recovered by Customs Authorities under any Bond for exportation given by the shippers or owners of goods shall not be considered to form part of any actual loss or damage sustained by or in connection with such goods for which the carrier is or shall be liable.\u00a0 If the ship comes into collision with another ship as a result of the negligence of the other ship or object and any act, neglect or default of the master, mariner, pilot or the servants of the Carrier in the navigation or in the management of the ship, the owners of the goods carried hereunder will indemnify the Carrier against all loss or liability to the other or non-carrying ship or object or the owners in so far as such loss or liability represents loss of, or damage to, any <i>claim</i> whatsoever of the owners of said goods, paid or payable by the other non-carrying ship or object or her owners to the owners of said goods and set off, recouped or recovered by the other or non-carrying ship or object or her\u00a0 owners as part of their claim against the carrying ship or Carrier.\u00a0 At any port where, in accordance with Customs regulations, the goods have to be landed into the charge of the Customs or other Authorities no <i>claims</i> for shortage or damage will be considered by the Carrier, beyond that noted by the Authorities at the time of receiving the goods into their charge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the case of any actual or apprehended loss or damage, the Carrier and the receiver shall give all reasonable facilities to each other for inspecting and tallying the goods.\u00a0 The carrier shall not be liable to pay any compensation if the nature or the value of the goods has been wilfully mistated.\u00a0 The above includes <i>claims</i> in the nature of General Average.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">This clause in its entirety shall also apply in any cause of loss sustained as a result of mis-delivery, non-delivery, wrongful delivery or delivery to any person whomsoever not entitled to the goods.\u00a0 (Emphasis added).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is true that this clause is unlike some other jurisdiction clauses which we see in other cases.\u00a0 As an example, in <i>The Jian He</i> [2000] 1 SLR, a case which featured very prominently in the arguments of both parties, the jurisdiction clause read:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cJurisdiction:\u00a0 This Bill of Lading is governed by the laws of the People\u2019s Republic of China.\u00a0 All disputes arising under or in connection with this Bill \u2026 shall be determined by the laws of the People\u2019s Republic of China and any action against the carrier shall be brought before the Maritime Court in Guangzhou or Shanghai or Tianjin or Qingdao or Dalian where the principal place of business of the relevant company is situated.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It cannot be denied that this clause in <i>The Jian He</i> is more explicit and there it was not really in dispute that the clause was an exclusive jurisdictional clause.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Similarly, in <i>The Asian Plutus</i> <nobr>[1990] SLR 543</nobr>, the jurisdiction clause was also very explicit and it read:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe contract evidenced by or contained in this bill of lading shall be governed by Japanese law, except as may be otherwise provided for herein and any action against the carrier thereunder shall be brought before the Tokyo District Court in Japan.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, it does not therefore follow that, just because the clause here is worded differently, it could not be such an exclusive jurisdiction clause.\u00a0 It is still necessary to construe the clause in its entirety to determine its real import.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Contentions of UCO</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The main argument of UCO is that, looking at the clause as a whole, what it provides for is the place for \u201cthe notification and making of a claim for the purposes of the owner\u2019s consideration and settlement.\u201d\u00a0 In this regard, UCO relied on the opening words of the clause \u201cclaims \u2026 must be made at the port of delivery for determination and settlement at that port only.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 UCO also relied upon the word \u201csuit\u201d which appear later in the same paragraph of clause 17 to contend that the word \u201cclaim\u201d in the opening sentence of that clause could not have been intended to mean \u201csuit\u201d.\u00a0 They\u00a0 submitted that it is a canon of construction that where different words are used in a document, they could not be construed to mean the same thing; a \u201csuit\u201d would connote a legal process and a \u201cclaim\u201d does not necessarily connote that.\u00a0 It is entirely in line with common sense and practicality for a claim to be notified at the port of delivery.\u00a0 UCO argued that it is altogether another thing to say that just because a claim must be made at the port of delivery, an action must also be instituted at the same place.\u00a0 One does not necessarily follow from the other.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Moreover, UCO argued that if indeed \u201cclaim\u201d means \u201csuit\u201d and if we were to substitute the word \u201csuit\u201d for the word \u201cclaim\u201d in the clause, it will not make sense in some places.\u00a0 UCO took, <i>inter alia</i>, the example of the phrase \u201cno claims for shortage or damage will be considered by the carrier\u201d and argue that if the word \u201cclaims\u201d were to be substituted by \u201csuits\u201d, the phrase would not make sense.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 UCO also referred to clause 6 to argue that clause 17 does not relate to the institution of proceedings. Clause 6 provides that \u201c\u2026 claims for services by other vessels belonging to the carrier, wherever rendered, may be adjudicated upon in the Singapore Court whose decisions shall bind the owners of the goods \u2026\u201d\u00a0 In contrast, clause 17 does not mention courts or adjudication.\u00a0 Thus, clause 17 could not be a jurisdiction clause.\u00a0 \u201cClaims\u201d means nothing more than notification of loss or damage and the entire clause deals with notification and consideration of claims.\u00a0 It has nothing to do with the institution of legal proceedings.\u00a0 In any event if there is any ambiguity as to the scope of clause 17, the <i>contra proferentum rule</i> should apply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Arguments of Shipowners</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Golden Shore adopted the interpretation accepted by the judge below, that the word \u201cclaims\u201d in the first sentence of clause 17 includes \u201csuits\u201d.\u00a0 But they explained that not every reference to \u201cclaim\u201d in clause 17 would necessarily include a suit; much would depend on the context.\u00a0 Golden Shore referred to the sentence \u201cno claims for shortage or damage will be considered by the carrier.\u201d\u00a0 The word \u201cclaims\u201d in that context could not mean \u201csuits\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Golden Shore argued that sufficient regard must be given to the two key words in the first sentence of clause 17: \u201cclaims\u201d and \u201cdetermination\u201d. The word \u201cdetermination\u201d means \u201cadjudication\u201d.\u00a0 That sentence required all suits under the B/L to be determined at the port of delivery only.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The authorities</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Golden Shore relied upon the case of <i>Maharani Woollen Mills Co v Anchor Line</i> [1927] 29 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 169 <i>(\u201cMaharani\u201d</i>) in support of its construction of clause 17.\u00a0 There the clause in question provided that \u201cAll claims arising shall be determined at the port of destination according to British laws.\u201d\u00a0 The goods were carried from Liverpool to Bombay.\u00a0 The plaintiff brought an action in England.\u00a0 But the shipowners asserted that the action must be instituted in Bombay and sought a stay.\u00a0 The High Court ordered a stay, which order was affirmed by the Court of Appeal.\u00a0 Scrutton LJ, the illustrious shipping law judge, in a short judgment, construed this clause to mean that \u201cdisputes as to the condition of the goods and the damage done to them shall be settled where the goods \u2026 are.\u201d\u00a0 He said that he did not see any difficulty with the jurisdiction clause and it was reasonable to hold the plaintiff to his contractual term.\u00a0 He construed the word \u201cclaims\u201d to include \u201cdisputes\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In contrast, UCO relied upon the Malaysian case of <i>The Sinar Mas</i> <nobr>[1982] 1 MLJ 279</nobr> for the construction of clause 17.\u00a0 There the clause was very similar to the present clause 17 and it read: \u201cClaims. Any claims that may arise hereunder must be made at the port of delivery for determination and settlement at that port only \u2026\u201d\u00a0 The High Court construed this clause to have nothing to do with jurisdiction and its reasoning was as follows:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cIn <i>Shorter Oxford Dictionary</i>, \u201cclaims\u201d means a demand for something as due; an assertion of a right to something.\u00a0 In my view, a claim in the context of Clause 17 does not amount to a litigation which, according to the same dictionary, means the action of carrying on a suit in law or equity; legal proceedings; and disputation.\u00a0 Having regard to the judgments in <i>The Fehmarn</i> and <i>The Adolf Warski</i>, I think there is a distinction between \u201cclaims\u201d and \u201cdisputes\u201d.\u00a0 Clause 17 does not envisage any dispute on litigation.\u00a0 It is confined to \u201cclaims\u201d pure and simple as, for example, where a consignee wishes to claim for the goods under the Bill of Lading, then it must be done only in Kuching, which is the port of delivery.\u00a0 I am, therefore, of the view that Clause 17 is not a jurisdiction clause or even a forum clause.\u00a0 The court should not import extra words into Clause 17 so as to give it new meaning with regard to the intention of the contracting parties.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As pointed out by the Judge, the court in <i>The Sinar Mas</i> did not give consideration to the word \u201cdetermination\u201d in that clause.\u00a0 Furthermore, it is not clear why the court in <i>The Sinar Mas</i> relied upon <i>The Fehmarn</i> [1958] 1 All ER 333 and <i>The Adolf Warski</i> [1976] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 107.\u00a0 In <i>The Fehmarn,</i> the relevant condition was:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cAll claims and disputes arising under and in connexion with the bills of exchange shall be judged in the USSR.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The dispute was in relation to short delivery and contamination.\u00a0 The Court of Appeal there did not examine the two words \u201cclaims\u201d and \u201cdisputes\u201d.\u00a0 What can be said about that clause is that the parties there had expressly used both terms.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Similarly, in <i>The Adolf Warski</i>, Brandon J was in no sense construing the two words \u201cclaim\u201d and \u201cdispute\u201d.\u00a0 The case concerned two jurisdiction clauses in two different bills of lading.\u00a0 The first provided that \u201cAny claim \u2026 shall at the option of the carriers be settled direct with the carriers in Poland according to the Polich law to the exclusion of proceedings in the courts of any other country\u201d.\u00a0 The second provided that \u201cany dispute \u2026 to be decided in Poland according to Polish law except as provided elsewhere.\u201d\u00a0 There was no doubt that these two clauses were jurisdiction clauses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are unable to see how these two cases, <i>The</i> <i>Fehmarn</i> and <i>The Adolf Warski</i>, were germane to the interpretation of the jurisdiction clause in <i>The Sinar Mas</i>.\u00a0 While it is clear that the word \u201cclaim\u201d and the word \u201cdispute\u201d are different, what each word means must depend on its context.\u00a0 For example, in the clause \u201cany claim \u2026 shall \u2026 be settled direct with the carriers in Poland according to the Polish law to the exclusion of proceedings in the courts of any other country\u201d in <i>The Adolf Warski</i>, the word \u201cclaim\u201d would surely include \u201cdispute\u201d.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would observe that the result reached in <i>The Sinar Mas</i> would also\u00a0 have been the same even if the court were to have held that the clause was an exclusive jurisdiction clause.\u00a0 This is because, as the judge there noted, the clause could not be invoked in the circumstances of the case.\u00a0 The contention there was that the action should have been filed in the Kuching High Court instead of the Kuala Lumpur High Court.\u00a0 The judge effectively ruled there was no difference.\u00a0 He said (at 279):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe carriage by sea was from Penang to Kuching.\u00a0 Both ports are in Malaysia \u2026 The High Courts in Borneo and States of Malaya have similar jurisdiction and adopt the same admiralty practice.\u00a0 I am inclined to the view that a jurisdiction or forum clause does not apply to a litigation commenced in another court of similar jurisdiction and situated in the same country as the court envisaged by the parties to the contract.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another case which has been referred to by the parties is <i>Oriental Insurance Co Ltd v Bhavani Stores Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1998] 1 SLR 253</nobr>, a decision of this Court.\u00a0 We do not think this case is helpful either.\u00a0 There two adjacent clauses in an insurance policy read: \u201cClaims are payable in India or Singapore in US dollars\u201d and \u201cIn the event of loss or damages which may involve a claim under this insurance, immediate notice thereof and application for survey should be given to: (agents in India)\u201d\u00a0 The court rejected the suggestion that the first clause amounted to a jurisdiction clause. \u00a0 The wording there is clearly different from that in the first sentence of our clause 17.\u00a0 Moreover, in relation to an insurance claim, notification to the insurer is a standard feature to enable the insurer to conduct investigations.\u00a0 While we recognise that it is just as important for a carrier to conduct investigation into a claim for loss or damage to cargo, there is no compelling reason why the carrier must be notified at the port of delivery.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another case Golden Shore relied upon is <i>The Media</i> [1931] 41 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 80, where the clause read:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cAll claims arising under this bill of lading shall be determined at the port of destination of the goods according to British law, or, at the shipowners\u2019 option, they shall be determined in the UK, and to the exclusion of the jurisdiction of any other country.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">There was no dispute in the case that that was an exclusive jurisdiction clause, with only one exception, that the shipowner would have the option to have any dispute determined in the UK.\u00a0 What is of interest about the clause is that its first half is similar to the first sentence of clause 17 in the present case.\u00a0 However, we recognise the last limb of the clause in <i>The Media</i> removed any possible doubt that it was a jurisdiction clause.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Our opinion</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Though the clauses in <i>Maharani</i> and <i>The Media</i> are not identical with clause 17, as there is no reference in clause 17 itself to governing law, or the exclusion of the jurisdiction of another country, they are similar in significant respects.\u00a0 In both <i>Maharani</i> and <i>The Media</i>, the word \u201cclaims\u201d was effectively held to encompass \u201csuits\u201d or \u201cdisputes\u201d.\u00a0 A \u201cclaim\u201d means a demand for something as due or an assertion of a right to something.\u00a0 A claim can be manifested in various forms.\u00a0 It can take the form of a letter or an action.\u00a0 There is no reason why a claim in the form of an action or suit could not come within the meaning of the first sentence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another word of importance in the first sentence is \u201cdetermination\u201d.\u00a0\u00a0 To suggest that the sentence only imports the concepts of\u00a0 \u201cnotification\u201d and \u201cinvestigation\u201d is to ignore the plain words there and give no sense at all to it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the argument on the last sentence of the first paragraph of clause 17 where the word \u201csuit\u201d appeared, we would say it reinforces the view that the scope of the first sentence is much wider than just \u201cnotification\u201d and \u201cinvestigation\u201d.\u00a0 At this juncture, it may be instructive to see what the second and third sentences in the paragraph say.\u00a0 The second sentence puts a cap as to the carrier\u2019s liability for loss or damage.\u00a0 The third sentence deems the goods delivered in proper condition unless notification was given at the time of delivery or within three days (if the loss or damage be not apparent).\u00a0 We should think that with this sentence there would have been no need to have the first sentence if all that the first sentence means is to give \u201cnotification\u201d.\u00a0 The fourth sentence (which is also the last sentence) of the paragraph prescribes a limitation period of one year.\u00a0 As the Judge rightly found, the word \u201csuit\u201d was more appropriate in the context of that last sentence.\u00a0 Indeed the second, third and fourth sentences were adopted from clause 6 of the Hague Rules.\u00a0 The three sentences either cap or qualify the liability of the carrier.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for clause 6 of the B/L, while it is true that there there is an express reference to adjudication by the Singapore courts, what is of interest to note is that the clause also uses the word \u201cclaims\u201d and in the context the word \u201cclaims\u201d would encompass \u201cactions\u201d or \u201cdisputes\u201d, precisely the sort of meaning which UCO sought to place on the word \u201cclaims\u201d in clause 17.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Thus, we agree with the trial judge that the word \u201cclaims\u201d in the first sentence should be construed to include \u201csuits\u201d, and in our opinion even \u201cdisputes\u201d.\u00a0\u00a0 A claim which is not met becomes a dispute which would require determination.\u00a0 We would reiterate that if the first sentence is only meant to provide for notification, as contended by UCO, why have it at all when the third sentence clearly provides for notification.\u00a0 Moreover, that contention would have disregarded the word \u201cdetermination\u201d.\u00a0 Accordingly, we hold that the first sentence is an exclusive jurisdiction clause.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whether a stay should be ordered</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is settled law that where a party seeks to bring an action in a Singapore court in breach of an exclusive jurisdiction clause, he must show exceptional circumstances amounting to \u201cstrong cause\u201d why the court should exercise its discretion in his favour and assist him in breaching his promise to bring the action in the contractual forum: see <i>The Jian He</i> <nobr>[2000] 1 SLR 8</nobr>.\u00a0 The burden to show such strong cause obviously rests with the plaintiff, because <i>prima facie</i> he should be held to his contractual commitment.\u00a0 The factors which a court will take into account in determining whether there is a \u201cstrong cause\u201d were elaborated in <i>The El Amria</i> [1981] 2 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 119 and adopted by this court in <i>Amerco Timbers Pte Ltd v Chatworth Timber Corp Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1977] 2 MLJ 181</nobr>.\u00a0 They are:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0 In what country the evidence on the issues of fact is situated or more readily available, and the effect of that on the relative convenience and expense of trial as between the Singapore and foreign courts.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0 Whether the law of the foreign court applies and, if so, whether it differs from Singapore law in any material respects.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0 With what country either party is connected and, if so, how closely.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0 Whether the defendants genuinely desire trial in the foreign country, or are only seeking procedural advantages.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0 Whether the plaintiffs would be prejudiced by having to sue in the foreign court because they would:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(i)\u00a0 be deprived of security for their claim;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(ii)\u00a0 be unable to enforce any judgment obtained;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iii)\u00a0 be faced with a time-bar not applicable here;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0 or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iv)\u00a0 for political, racial, religious or other reasons</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be unlikely to get a fair trial.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0 The burden here is more than just establishing that Singapore is the more convenient forum to hear the case.\u00a0 The principles applicable to a case involving an exclusive jurisdiction clause are different from those applicable to determining <i>forum non conveniens</i>: see <i>Citi-March Ltd v Neptune Orient Lines Ltd</i> [1997] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 72 at 76 per Colman J.\u00a0 As this Court noted in <i>The Vishva Apurva</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 SLR 175</nobr> at 182:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cIn a case involving an exclusive jurisdiction clause, the discretion of the court should not be exercised just by balancing the conveniences.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this case, the factors which the judge took into account in coming to his conclusion that there is strong cause for refusing a stay are \u2013</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><font size=\"5\">(i)\u00a0 that both parties were more closely connected with Singapore;</font></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(ii) that Singapore law is the governing law under the B/L;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iii)\u00a0 that in respect of the main issue as to whether UCO had consented or acquiesced in the switching of the B/L such as to preclude them from relying on the original bills, the evidence is primarily to be found in Singapore; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iv)\u00a0 that Golden Shore did not genuinely desire trial in India</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">We should add that another factor which the judge had considered, but ruled that it is neutral, is the fact that the action has become time-barred in India.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Golden Shore, in reliance on, <i>inter alia</i>, <i>British Aerospace v Dee Howard</i> [1993] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 368, <i>Import Export Metro Ltd v Compania Sud Americana de Vapores</i> [2003] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 405 and <i>Ace v Zurich Insurance</i> [2001] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 618, argued that many of the factors considered by the judge relating to matters of convenience should not carry much weight as they are not exceptional; indeed they were all foreseeable.\u00a0 Here, counsel for Golden Shore relied upon the words of Rix LJ in <i>Ace</i> (at 630):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cIf a party agrees to submit to the jurisdiction of the courts of a state, it does not easily lie in its mouth to complain that it is inconvenient to conduct its litigation there \u2026\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Golden Shore also submitted that there was no basis for the judge to hold that it has no genuine desire for a trial in India.\u00a0 It has raised several defences to UCO\u2019s claim among which is the defence that UCO consented or acquiesced to the switching of the original bills.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Our analysis</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As far as the first and second factors mentioned in \u00b635 above are concerned, namely, that the parties are more connected with Singapore and the governing law of the B/L was Singapore law, while these two factors would favour a trial in Singapore, we recognise that they are not exceptional matters.\u00a0 Accordingly, the weight to be given to these two factors would have to be limited as they were known to the parties at the time of the contract and notwithstanding such knowledge, they had nevertheless provided in the B/L that the contractual forum should be India.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As regards the third factor, it is on balance true that the evidence relating to the main defence of consent is to be found more in Singapore.\u00a0 We note that physically two witnesses will be in India.\u00a0 One is Mr S Srinivasan, UCO\u2019s then Manager for Credit Sanction, who is now there.\u00a0 But UCO have undertaken to bring him to Singapore for the trial.\u00a0 So Mr Srinivasan must effectively be treated as being in Singapore.\u00a0 The other is the Managing Director of SOM, Sood, who is now residing in India.\u00a0\u00a0 He dealt with UCO.\u00a0 Golden Shore submitted that if the trial were to be held in Singapore, they would not be able to compel Sood to attend the trial here.\u00a0 But his evidence may still be obtainable in India pursuant to Order 39 of the Rules of Court.\u00a0 Of course, the Judge did not think much of the importance of Sood, as Golden Shore is not even able to indicate what evidence Sood will be able to give.\u00a0 It is not known whether Sood will be saying that UCO knew and consented to the switch.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for the other witnesses of UCO, they will be in Singapore.\u00a0 So will the bank documents relating to the transaction.\u00a0 While evidence as to the market price of the cargo will be in India, there should not be any great difficulty in obtaining such evidence.\u00a0 Thus, the factor relating to witnesses and other evidence would favour a trial in Singapore.\u00a0 But for the same reasons as for the first two factors, the weight to be given to this factor would not be as great as if this were a <i>forum non conveniens</i> case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the fourth factor, whether Golden Shore genuinely desire a trial in India, there are a few matters we need to consider.\u00a0 Golden Shore have raised a number of defences but the only one which merits any consideration at all is that of consent/acquiescence.\u00a0 On this, Golden Shore relied on two circumstances.\u00a0 First is the delay by UCO in seeking delivery of the goods and its total absence of inquiry with regard thereto.\u00a0 Second, is the fact that UCO negotiated the switched bills.\u00a0 As the details relating to the cargo on the original bills and the switched bills are identical, Golden Shore contended that UCO would thus have known of the switch or, in the alternative, it confirms that UCO had consented to the same.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0 Like the Judge, we are unable to see why it would be reasonable to infer consent or knowledge on UCO\u2019s part just because there was some delay in UCO making a claim or inquiries relating to the cargo.\u00a0 In fact UCO was told that there was delay because of an earthquake at the port of destination.\u00a0 Moreover, UCO was negotiating with SOM.\u00a0 As mentioned before, there is no indication as to what Sood would say on the matter.\u00a0\u00a0 There is nothing on which it can reasonably be inferred that UCO consented to the switch.\u00a0\u00a0 Neither has it been alleged that Golden Shore had checked with UCO before issuing the switched bills, bearing in mind that the original bills were stated \u201cto the order of UCO\u201d and UCO was also\u00a0 the notify party on the original bills.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As regards the negotiation by UCO of the switched bills, here again there was nothing to indicate to UCO that the switched bills related to the same cargo as the original bills.\u00a0 The \u201cshipper\u201d stated on the switched bills was different from that on the original bills even though the cargo described was the same in the generic sense.\u00a0 No reasonable banker would think that the switched bills related to the \u201csame\u201d cargo as it would have been unimaginable that a carrier would issue another B/L for the same cargo without withdrawing the earlier B/L.\u00a0 Thus, the entire defence of consent/acquiescence is highly speculative.\u00a0 Even if it could be shown that the bank officers were careless in scrutinizing the switched bills, that could in no way suggest consent, which requires actual knowledge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It\u00a0 is on these four factors that the Judge ruled that a strong cause has been established that the case should be allowed to proceed in Singapore. In refusing to order a stay, the Judge was exercising a discretion and in order for this court to upset that determination it must be shown that the Judge had erred on principles or had reached a conclusion which is plainly wrong.\u00a0 On all the four factors above, they, in varying degrees, favour the continuation of the case in Singapore.\u00a0 There is, therefore, no basis for us to hold that the Judge was wrong in coming to the conclusion that strong cause\u00a0 has\u00a0 been\u00a0 shown and a stay should be refused.\u00a0 In refusing a stay the Judge was exercising a discretion, and there is no way in which we can say that he was plainly wrong.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Time-bar</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Considerable arguments were advanced by the parties, particularly by Golden Shore, on the facts that the defence of time-bar has accrued in India.\u00a0 If on other grounds a plaintiff, having reviewed the situation, thinks that he is entitled to bring an action in a forum other than the contractual forum and does not institute a protective action in the contractual forum, giving rise to a time-bar defence from arising, this factor should not be taken against the plaintiff.\u00a0 Here, we would quote the words of Colman J in <i>Citi-March</i> (at 75) for the rationale:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201c \u2026 if, notwithstanding the foreign jurisdiction clause, there are factors \u2026 in the interests of justice and all the parties, provide strong cause for treating the English Courts as the appropriate forum, the plaintiff\u2019s omission to protect time in the contractual forum will not condemn him to a stay of the English action.\u00a0 In such a case his self-induced prejudice, or putting it obversely, the defendants\u2019 accrued defence, is merely a consequence of the plaintiff having given effect by his own conduct to the principles which underly the exercise by the Court of its own discretion.\u00a0 For the Court to take into account against a plaintiff a time bar arising in such circumstances would involve an inconsistency of approach which cannot be justified in principle.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Amerco,</i> where the situation is similar to the present and where the action was time-barred in Indonesia, the accrual of this defence in favour of the defendant was not taken into account in refusing a stay.\u00a0 Indeed, in that case, where there was an indication that under Indonesian law it was not open to the defendant to waive the time-bar, the court said that it would either attach no weight to this factor or, adopting the views of Brandon J in <i>The Adolf Warski</i>, refuse a stay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reverting to the present case, there is also an indication that under Indian law, the limitation cannot be waived, even though Mr Toh for Golden Shore said that his clients would be willing to waive the point.\u00a0 The Indian law allows the court a discretion to extend the limitation period by three months and nothing more and this extended three month period\u00a0 had long expired.\u00a0 Applying the approach of this Court in <i>Amerco</i> to the fact-situation here, the application for a stay would also have to be refused.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Now we would like to turn to the argument of Golden Shore that as the Judge had found that UCO had acted unreasonably in failing to institute a protective writ in India, the factor of time-bar should work in their favour.\u00a0 It should not be treated to be a neutral point as the Judge did.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is no doubt true that UCO could have instituted a protective writ in India to prevent limitation from setting in. \u00a0 But even if UCO had done so, it would not have helped to determine whether in all the circumstances, a strong cause had been established that the case should be allowed to continue in Singapore.\u00a0 As we have held that by the other factors UCO had shown a strong cause, their failure to institute a protective writ in India is inconsequential.\u00a0 It is in this sense that the court in <i>The Jian He</i> had held that the failure of the plaintiffs to institute an action in China to be a neutral point.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>The Jian He</i>, where time-bar had also set in in the contractual forum, the court having reviewed the cases of <i>Citi-March v\u00a0 Neptune</i> (supra), <i>The MC Pearl</i> [1997] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 566 and <i>The K H Enterprise</i> [1994] 1 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 593, made the following general proposition (at 21):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cthe mere fact that the action would be time-barred in China is not of itself a sufficient ground for the court to exercise its discretion in favour of a plaintiff.\u00a0 It is really a neutral point, as refusing a stay would deprive the defendants of their accrued rights and granting a stay would defeat the plaintiffs\u2019 claim altogether.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court then went on to consider how a plaintiff could turn the factor in his favour (at 21):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe plaintiffs must justify their conduct in allowing limitation to arise in the contractual forum.\u00a0 They must show that they did not act unreasonably in failing to commence proceedings within time in the contractual forum, such as, by issuing a protective writ: see also <i>Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd</i> <nobr>[1987] AC 460</nobr> and <i>The El Amria</i> [1981] 2 Lloyds Rep 119.\u00a0 They must explain fully and fairly to the court why they allowed time to lapse in the contractual forum: <i>The Bergen</i> [1997] 2 Lloyd\u2019s Rep 710.\u00a0 Therefore, the factor of time-bar in the contractual forum is a two-edged sword, depending very much on the reasons given\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court next considered whether the plaintiffs in <i>The Jian He</i> had shown that they had acted reasonably in not taking out a protective writ in the contractual forum.\u00a0 It came to the view that the plaintiffs had not shown that and therefore the time-bar factor remained a neutral factor, i.e., it could not assist the plaintiffs to show strong cause.\u00a0 Here we would like to make a clarification on the reference in <i>The Jian He</i> to the factor of time-bar in the contractual forum being a two-edged sword.\u00a0 That perhaps is not an entirely happy description.\u00a0 In a case where the plaintiff could satisfactorily explain why he did not institute a protective writ in the contractual forum, this factor would assist the plaintiff in establishing strong cause.\u00a0 But if he could not, this factor would not assist him.\u00a0 However, this did not mean that the plaintiff could not rely on other factors to show strong cause.\u00a0 As for the defendant, where the plaintiff could not explain the failure to institute a protective writ within time in the contractual forum, the \u201cbenefit\u201d to the defendant would be that the plaintiff could not rely on it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the end of the day, it is the overall justice of the case that is going to be decisive.\u00a0 In the words of Colman J in <i>Citi-March</i> (at 77):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cAt the end of the day the Court must consider whether in the interests of justice it is more appropriate to permit a plaintiff to proceed in England, although he has omitted to preserve time in the contractual forum, and although England is not clearly the more appropriate forum\u00a0 than to deprive him of all opportunity of pursuing his claim in any forum.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In a sense this observation of Colman J went further than the facts of the present case necessitate because here, as we have determined earlier, Singapore is the more appropriate forum for the case.\u00a0 We shall leave this aspect of the matter to another case on another day.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Judgment</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, we would agree with the Judge that strong cause had been shown that both the actions (in respect of which Civil Appeal 53/2002 and Civil Appeal 55/2003 arose) should continue in Singapore.\u00a0 Accordingly, the two appeals are dismissed with costs.\u00a0 The security for costs in relation to both appeals, together with any accrued interest, shall be released to the respondents, to account of costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There shall only be one set of costs for the respondents, except with regard to disbursements.\u00a0</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n (counsel) and Jason Chan (Allen &amp; Gledhill) for the respondent in CA 69/2005</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2799\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Infringement</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Appropriate approach in construing patent claims</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether purposive approach to be preferred</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\"
