<DecisionDate>2004-05-19T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</DecisionDate>\n    <IndexYear>2004</IndexYear>\n    <NeutralCitation>\n      <Year>2004</Year>\n      <Court>SGCA</Court>\n      <No>22</No>\n      <NCit>[2004] SGCA 22</NCit>\n    </NeutralCitation>\n    <Citation>\n      <Year>2004</Year>\n      <Series>SGCA</Series>\n      <PageNo>22</PageNo>\n      <Cit>[2004] SGCA 22</Cit>\n    </Citation>\n    <CaseTitle>Man B and W Diesel S E Asia Pte Ltd and Another v PT Bumi International Tankers and Another Appeal</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Man B and W Diesel S E Asia Pte Ltd and Another v PT Bumi International Tankers and Another Appeal</SortTitle><SortDate>2004-05-19T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 75/2003, 79/2003</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#3\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appellant</Role>\n        <Name>Man B and W Diesel S E Asia Pte Ltd</Name>\n        <Name>Mirrlees Blackstone Ltd</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#6\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Respondent</Role>\n        <Name>PT Bumi International Tankers</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#7\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <AdditionalCaseDetails>\n      <IndexEntries>\n        <Entry>Mirrlees Blackstone (SE Asia) Pte Ltd</Entry>\n        <Entry>PT Bumi Indonesia Tankers</Entry>\n        <Entry>Man B&amp;W Diesel S E Asia Pte Ltd</Entry>\n      </IndexEntries>\n      <OtherCases xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"OtherCases.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Another Appeal</OtherCases>\n    </AdditionalCaseDetails>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#499\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tan Lee Meng J</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#627\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Yong Pung How CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>N Sreenivasan and Collin Choo (Straits Law Practice LLC) and Charles Lin Ming Khin (Donaldson and Burkinshaw) for appellants</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Philip Tay Twan Lip (Rajah and Tann) for respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#841\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Offer to settle</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Appellant made offer in settlement of claim at trial</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Respondent rejected offer</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Respondent lost on appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether appellant entitled to indemnity costs from date of offer</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">Order 22A r 9(3) Rules of Court (Cap 322, R 5, 1997 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"284\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0May 2004\u00a0</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\u00a0<i>Judgment reserved.</i></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1-FirstPara\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 9\u00a0March 2004 we delivered a judgment (reported at <nobr>[2004] 2 SLR 300</nobr>) allowing an appeal by the appellants-defendants against a decision of the High Court granting damages to the respondent-plaintiff in an action in tort, on account of the fact that an engine supplied by the appellants for use on a vessel of the respondent was defective, thus resulting in the respondent suffering economic losses. We ruled that, in the circumstances of the case, the respondent was not entitled to claim in tort for the economic losses against the appellants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was also a related appeal which was filed by the respondent who was dissatisfied with the quantum of damages awarded by the judge. In view of our ruling on the defendants\u2019 appeal, it followed that the respondent\u2019s appeal had to be dismissed. The full facts of the case were set out in our earlier judgment and we do not propose to repeat them here.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Following our judgment, the appellants\u2019 solicitors wrote to inform this court that on the third day of the trial, 24\u00a0April 2002, the appellants made an offer in the prescribed form to pay the respondent the sum of US$1.5m in settlement of its claim. The offer, which was open for acceptance within 14 days, was not accepted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our judgment, we awarded costs to the appellants in respect of both the appeal as well as the trial below. What the appellants now seek is that, in view of the respondent\u2019s non-acceptance of their offer, they be awarded, pursuant to O\u00a022A r\u00a09 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed), indemnity costs instead of just standard costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The governing provision for our present purposes is O\u00a022A r\u00a09(3), and it reads:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where an offer to settle made by a defendant \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 is not withdrawn and has not expired before the disposal of the claim in respect of which the offer to settle is made; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 is not accepted by the plaintiff, and the plaintiff obtains judgment not more favourable than the terms of the offer to settle,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">the plaintiff is entitled to costs on the standard basis to the date the offer was served and the defendant is entitled to costs on the indemnity basis from that date, unless the Court orders otherwise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent made the following points to argue that the appellants should not be granted indemnity costs:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The offer was not serious and genuine, being substantially less than what the trial judge held to be the damages which the respondent was entitled to.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The offer was made very late, after the trial had commenced. The respondent failed in the claim because this court held that the appellants did not owe the respondent a duty of care, a point which was only raised at the start of the trial when leave to amend the defence was obtained. This court has a wide discretion in the matter and should consider all the circumstances before awarding indemnity costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The issue of law in question was a highly controversial one and the court only came to its conclusion after much deliberation. It was a novel point.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Much of the time at trial was spent on establishing the fact that the engine supplied by the appellants was defective and the cause of it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Quite clearly, the court is not obliged to award indemnity costs just because the offer made by one party is more favourable than what the opposing party eventually obtained from the court. This is explicitly spelt out in O\u00a022A r\u00a09(5) which reads:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Without prejudice to paragraphs (1), (2) and (3), where an offer to settle has been made, and notwithstanding anything in the offer to settle, the Court shall have full power to determine by whom and to what extent any costs are to be paid, and the Court may make such a determination upon the application of a party or of its own motion.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">and in O\u00a022A r\u00a012 which reads:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Without prejudice to Rules\u00a09 and 10, the Court, in exercising its discretion with respect to costs, may take into account any offer to settle, the date the offer was made, the terms of the offer and the extent to which the plaintiff\u2019s judgment is more favourable than the terms of the offer to settle.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>The Endurance\u00a01</i> <nobr>[1999] 1 SLR 661</nobr>, this court, recognising that O\u00a022A was of recent origin, took into account the approaches taken by some Commonwealth countries, where provisions similar to our O\u00a022A exist, <i>eg</i>, Canada and Australia, and held that, generally speaking, the element of compromise should be present in an offer to settle. It said at [43] that \u201cthe lack of compromise would be a material consideration in determining whether the plaintiff or the defendant should be penalised with higher costs in cases where there are genuine issues of liability raised\u201d. This is because the rationale behind O\u00a022A is to encourage the speedy termination of litigation by agreement of the parties. The offer to settle should therefore be a serious and genuine offer and not just to entail the payment of costs on an indemnity basis. It should contain in it an element which would induce or facilitate settlement: see <i>Singapore Airlines Ltd v Fujitsu Microelectronics (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd (No\u00a02)</i> <nobr>[2001] 1 SLR 532</nobr> (\u201c<i>SIA v Fujitsu</i>\u201d) at [10]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Even though the relevant [New South Wales] rules are not identical in wording with ours, we would respectfully agree with those views. In our opinion, for an offer to have the effect contemplated in O\u00a022A r\u00a09, it must contain in it an element which would induce or facilitate settlement. When such an element is missing, then, as held in <i>Data General</i> [see [63] <i>infra</i>], that would be a ground for the court to exercise its discretion to vary the norm relating to costs laid down in r\u00a09.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we would add one rider to this. Where there is no defence of any substance to a liquidated claim, then compromise is not a necessary element in an offer to settle: see <i>The Endurance\u00a01</i> at [43]. The reason for this was explained by Morden\u00a0ACJO in <i>Data General (Canada) Ltd v Molnar Systems Group Inc</i> (1991) 85\u00a0DLR\u00a0(4th) 392 (\u201c<i>Data General</i>\u201d) at 399 as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The purpose of the rule is to discourage a defendant from using the judicial process, at the increased cost to the plaintiff, to delay the granting of the inevitable judgment and, in my view, there is no valid policy reason why a plaintiff should have to forgo part of its claim in order to be able to avail itself of the benefit of the rule. In such a case, I do not think there is any unfair prejudice to the defendant in being faced with such an offer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What would constitute a serious and genuine offer to settle must depend on the circumstances and issues of the case. In <i>Data General</i>, the plaintiff offered to settle at 100% of the liquidated sum claimed. In view of the complexity of the case which gave rise to uncertainty as to liability, the Ontario Court of Appeal did not consider it appropriate to order costs against the defendant on an indemnity basis.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Tickell v Trifleska Pty Ltd</i> (1991) 25\u00a0NSWLR 353, the plaintiff made an offer to compromise for 100% of the amount claimed. There the court held that there was no element of compromise in the offer and refused to grant costs on an indemnity basis.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the other end of the spectrum, in <i>Burton v Global Benefit Plan Consultants Inc</i> (1999) 93\u00a0ACWS\u00a0(3d) 223; (1999) 556\u00a0APR 86, the fifth defendant offered to settle the plaintiffs\u2019 claim for $1 in full settlement, inclusive of costs. The plaintiffs, who eventually lost the action, did not accept the offer. The court held the offer to be a nominal one as it effectively asked the plaintiff to capitulate. Indemnity costs were refused to the fifth defendant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another interesting comparison is <i>SIA v Fujitsu</i>, where the issue was whether the defendant air carrier was entitled to enjoy the limitation of liability under the amended Warsaw Convention in respect of goods conveyed by the carrier. The plaintiff was the owner of the goods. The defendant offered to pay a sum based on the limitation of liability prescribed in the Convention. The defendant succeeded in the defence of limitation. However, this court refused to grant indemnity costs to the defendant because (at [11]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]he offer to settle \u2026 was not really an offer to settle as it did not in substance contain any incentive to settle. The crux of the dispute related to the difference between the actual value of the lost package and the sum laid down in the amended Convention as being payable to the respondents for the loss. On that real issue, there was no genuine or serious effort to seek a compromise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would be noted that one common feature in all these four cases discussed above is the fact that in each instance the offeror effectively expected the other party to capitulate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The offer in the present case was US$1.5m, though without mentioning costs. The trial judge who ruled in favour of the respondent quantified its loss at US$2,979,589. It could broadly be said that the sum offered was about half of the actual loss, even taking costs into account. Bearing in mind that the question of liability was complex and to an extent novel, the offer could not be said to be anything other than serious and genuine.\u00a0 It was a substantial offer with a view to seeking a speedy and amicable solution.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the other arguments raised by the respondent to resist an indemnity costs order. The first is that the offer was made rather late, after trial had started. There is nothing in O\u00a022A which restricts the time by which an offer to settle may be made. In the scheme of things, such an offer could be made at any time. Obviously, the later it is made, the less it would serve the purpose of the scheme which is to resolve a litigation speedily and less expensively. The trial of the action commenced on 22\u00a0April 2002. It was part-heard. The resumed hearing was in October 2002. This was followed by submissions of the parties. Judgment was delivered only on 18\u00a0July 2003. An acceptance of the offer would, of course, have brought the action to an early close and saved costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Next is the point that the question of law in issue in the action was a highly controversial one. That is not in dispute. It will be recalled that in <i>Data General</i> the offer by the plaintiff to settle was at 100% of the sum claimed but in view of the complex nature of the case, the court exercised its discretion in not ordering indemnity costs against the defendant. In the present case, it was not the plaintiff (the respondent) who made the offer but the defendant (the appellants), and, more importantly, the offer was substantial and constituted more than 50% of the sum eventually awarded by the court below (not including costs). It is precisely in a case such as this, where the question of law involved is of some complexity, that there should be some give and take on both sides. Viewed in this light, the offer of the appellants was a serious one, deserving of consideration.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The last point of the respondent is that much of the time at the trial was spent in establishing the fault of the engine. This is neither here nor there. To establish its claim, the respondent had to prove three things: (a)\u00a0a duty of care on the part of the appellants; (b)\u00a0there was a breach of that duty; and, (c)\u00a0the respondent had suffered losses. The fact that the respondent managed to establish two of the three elements does not mean that the respondent should only bear the costs relating to the element on which it failed. The respondent failed in the action and must bear the costs of the action. It would be different where a defendant raised unmeritorious defences which were rejected by the court and if the defendant should nevertheless succeed on one of the defences the court would be entitled to refuse the defendant costs in relation to work done on those failed defences.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, there is one other matter that may stand in the way of the appellants in their claim for indemnity costs. In [59], we have set out O\u00a022A r\u00a09(3) which governs an offer to settle made by a defendant. For a defendant to be entitled to indemnity costs from the date of the offer to settle, two conditions must be satisfied. First, the offer must be on the table up to the disposal of the claim. Second, the plaintiff has obtained a judgment which is not more favourable than the terms of the offer. In our present case, the appellants\u2019 offer to settle was valid only for 14 days. Thus the first condition is not satisfied. However, the appellants say that r\u00a09(3) is not applicable to a case like the present, where the plaintiff fails completely. There appears to be some merit in this point as r\u00a09(3) talks about the plaintiff being \u201centitled to costs on the standard basis to the date the offer was served\u201d. The appellants aver that they are relying on the general discretionary powers of the court under O\u00a022A r\u00a09(5) and r\u00a012. These two rules are quoted in [61] above.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The question which remains is whether the court, in the exercise of its discretionary power, should have regard to the fact that the offer made by the appellants was valid only for 14 days and had lapsed long before the trial judge rendered her verdict and even longer still by the time the action was concluded on appeal. The term \u201cdisposal of the claim\u201d in O\u00a022A r\u00a09(3) must refer to the final disposal of the claim where there is an appeal. The corresponding provision applying to an offer to settle emanating from a plaintiff, which is set out in O\u00a022A r\u00a09(1), also contained a similar condition. Therefore, the question is whether the court should apply a different consideration where the plaintiff fails completely. We are unable to see any rational basis for waiving that condition just because a plaintiff fails completely instead of partially. It seems to us that the rationale for requiring an offer to remain on the table until judgment, before penalising the offeree party with indemnity costs, is that that party would have been able to accept the offer at all times but had refused to do so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, in the circumstances of the present case, we are not inclined to accede to the appellants\u2019 request for indemnity costs.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text/html; charset=UTF8\"/>\n    <meta name=\"filePath\"    <CaseTitle>Romar Positioning Equipment Pte Ltd v Merriwa Nominees Pty Ltd</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Romar Positioning Equipment Pte Ltd v Merriwa Nominees Pty Ltd</SortTitle><SortDate>2004-09-21T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 8/2004</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" <Counsel>Jimmy Yim SC (Drew and Napier LLC), Josephine Chong and Victor Leong Wai Ming (Chan Kam Foo and Associates) for appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>B Mohan Singh (K K Yap and Partners) for respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#848\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Pleadings</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#849\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Amendment</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether late amendment to Reply introducing inconsistent plea not found in Statement of Claim should have been allowed</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1154\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contract</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1184\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contractual terms</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Condition precedent</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether signing and forwarding of Deed condition precedent to obligation to pay under Deed</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1154\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contract</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1184\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contractual terms</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1190\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Implied terms</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Deed signed in counterparts</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether necessary to imply term requiring forwarding of signed Deed to other party</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"/>\n\n<div>\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0September 2004</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against the decision of the judge awarding judgment to Merriwa Nominees Pty Ltd (\u201cthe respondent\u201d) on 8\u00a0January 2004 and ordering Romar Positioning Equipment Pte Ltd (\u201cthe appellant\u201d) to render an account, <i>inter alia</i>, of moneys owed to the respondent. We heard the appeal and allowed it on 26\u00a0August 2004. We now give our reasons.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The facts</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant is a Singapore company. It is in the business of manufacturing, supplying and acting as consultants in automated welding equipment and metal work machinery. The respondent is a company incorporated in Western Australia with a place of business at Perth. It is in the business of providing specialised drilling technology and services.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In early 2000, the appellant approached the respondent to inquire whether the latter was interested to enter into a joint venture to provide specialised drilling services to an Indian company, Reliance Engineering Associates Private Limited (\u201cReliance\u201d), with whom the appellant had established contact. After several discussions between the appellant\u2019s managing director, Jonathan Lim (\u201cLim\u201d), and the respondent\u2019s managing director, James Johnson (\u201cJohnson\u201d), it was agreed that the two parties would jointly undertake the venture.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On or about 13\u00a0November 2000, the appellant entered into an agreement with Reliance (\u201cthe Reliance Agreement\u201d) to provide technical assistance, direction and supervision for the installation of a network of optic fibre cables throughout India (\u201cthe project\u201d). Although the appellant alone contracted with Reliance, it was agreed that the contracted works would be provided by both parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 1\u00a0December 2000, the appellant and the respondent entered into two written agreements, one being a Service Agreement and the other a Partnership Agreement. Under the Service Agreement, the respondent was to train and provide sufficient personnel to be employed by the appellant to enable the company to fulfil its obligations under the Reliance Agreement. In consideration of this, the appellant would, within three business days after it had received payment from Reliance for the services rendered, provide to the respondent the details of the payment received and all reasonable expenses incurred under the Reliance Agreement, as well as a cheque for an amount equal to half of the payment received by the appellant (less reasonable expenses incurred).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the period between December 2000 and September 2001, the respondent recruited and trained personnel for the appellant. By September 2001, the appellant had paid the respondent US$165,000 for the latter\u2019s share of the services provided to Reliance. This sum was in addition to amounts paid to Johnson for his work as one of the specialists employed in the project.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reliance\u2019s delay in paying invoices issued by the appellant caused unhappiness to the respondent. The respondent accused the appellant of withholding payments from and of not accounting fully to it. The respondent would not accept the appellant\u2019s explanation that Reliance was responsible for the delay.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 After an exchange of telephone calls and e-mails between Lim and Johnson on the accounts issue, a meeting took place on 7\u00a0February 2002 in Australia, at the office of the respondent\u2019s Perth solicitors, attended by the respondent\u2019s solicitor Chris Stokes (\u201cStokes\u201d). The parties reached an agreement at the meeting to settle their differences. It was agreed that the appellant would pay the respondent a sum of US$325,000 (\u201cthe settlement sum\u201d) in full and final settlement of all claims between them in connection with the Service Agreement. The settlement sum would be paid in three instalments, <i>viz</i> US$250,000 upon the signing of the settlement agreement, US$50,000 on or before 31\u00a0May 2002 and US$25,000 on or before 31\u00a0July 2002.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As Lim had to return to Singapore on the same day, it was agreed that Stokes would draw up the settlement agreement and fax a copy to Lim\u2019s Singapore office for his signature. A deed of settlement and release (\u201cthe Deed\u201d) was subsequently prepared by Stokes. Clause\u00a01 of the Deed reflected the agreement to pay the settlement sum by three fixed instalments in accordance with the time frame stated above. Clause\u00a07 provided that the Deed would not be effective until the full settlement sum had been received by the respondent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Also on the same day (7\u00a0February 2002), Stokes faxed a copy of the Deed to Lim for his signature, under cover of a letter. Lim duly executed the Deed and forwarded it to Stokes\u2019 office.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 8\u00a0February 2002, the appellant\u2019s solicitors received a letter from the respondent\u2019s Singapore solicitors confirming the settlement agreement and stating that a copy of the Deed was signed by the appellant and another copy was signed by the respondent. The letter also gave details of the bank account into which the settlement sum was to be paid. However, no copy of the signed Deed was attached to the letter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the same day, the appellant\u2019s solicitors hand-delivered a draft of US$250,000 to the respondent\u2019s Singapore solicitors together with a request for a copy of the signed Deed. There being no response, the appellant\u2019s solicitors wrote again on 16\u00a0May 2002 to the respondent\u2019s Singapore solicitors for a copy of the Deed; this was before the second payment was due.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 31\u00a0May 2002, the appellant\u2019s solicitors forwarded to the respondent\u2019s Singapore solicitors the second instalment of US$50,000 due that day, even though they had still not received a copy of the signed Deed. The appellant\u2019s solicitors made a third request for a copy of the Deed by their letter dated 28\u00a0June 2002, giving notice therein that the final payment (when due) would only be set aside, unless a copy of the Deed duly executed by the respondent was received by them.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 By a letter dated 29\u00a0July 2002 from Stokes\u2019 law firm to the appellant, the respondent gave notice that it no longer considered itself bound by the Deed because of alleged misrepresentations on the part of Lim. (The appellant said it only received the letter on 2\u00a0August 2002). Two days earlier, the appellant had obtained a draft for US$25,000 in payment of the final instalment due that day. However, the draft was never tendered to the respondent. Instead, on 1\u00a0August 2002, the appellant\u2019s solicitors wrote to the respondent\u2019s solicitors giving notice that a draft for US$25,000 had been issued and would only be released in exchange for the Deed. The solicitors followed up with another letter dated 26\u00a0August 2002 to the respondent\u2019s solicitors, rejecting the respondent\u2019s allegations of misrepresentations and electing to treat the Deed as valid and subsisting.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The proceedings below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 2\u00a0April 2003, the respondent commenced action against the appellant for breach of contract in failing to render accounts and to make payment in accordance with cl\u00a02.3 of the Service Agreement. The statement of claim also pleaded that the Deed was vitiated because the respondent (Johnson) had been induced to enter into the Deed by alleged misrepresentations on the part of the appellant (Lim). The appellant\u2019s defence was that there had been satisfaction and discharge of the respondent\u2019s cause of action by reason of the Deed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the first day of trial, the respondent sought and obtained leave from the court to amend its reply to include a new basis for vitiating the Deed in addition to the plea of misrepresentation. The respondent pleaded in para\u00a04 of the Amended Reply that cl\u00a07 of the Deed stated that the Deed was not effective until the respondent had received all three instalments. Since the last instalment of US$25,000 was not received by it, the respondent averred that the Deed was not effective.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The trial judge ruled in favour of the respondent on the ground that the appellant\u2019s defence of accord and satisfaction was not made out. There was no finding that any misrepresentation vitiated the Deed. Instead, the respondent\u2019s new plea in the Amended Reply was accepted and the Deed was held to be ineffective because the third payment was not made on time. The trial judge took the view that the appellant\u2019s act of purchasing the bank draft of US$25,000 did not suffice as the payment was not actually tendered. He rejected the appellant\u2019s argument that the final payment was not tendered because it was conditional upon receipt from the respondent of a copy of the executed Deed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The issues</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Two issues arose for determination in this appeal:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Could the appellant rely on the Deed as a valid defence to the respondent\u2019s claim notwithstanding that the third and final instalment of US$25,000 was not paid on the due date of 31\u00a0July 2002?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Should the last-minute amendment to the Reply have been allowed?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Did the Deed constitute a valid defence notwithstanding the non-payment of the final instalment?</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As stated earlier at [17], the trial judge made no finding on the respondent\u2019s allegation of misrepresentation which purportedly induced it to enter into the Deed. Consequently, the only issue to be determined on appeal was whether non-payment of the final instalment rendered the Deed unenforceable.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The crux of the appellant\u2019s case was that payment of the instalments was conditional upon its receipt of a copy of the executed Deed. Therefore, it was entitled to withhold payment of the last instalment of US$25,000 until it received a copy of the Deed, which never came. The trial judge had rejected this argument of counsel for the appellant on the basis that it was not a pleaded defence (see <nobr>[2004] SGHC 78</nobr> at [14]). His finding overlooked the fact that it was the respondent who first raised this issue by its eleventh hour amendment of para\u00a04 of the Reply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was our view that the appellant had succeeded on the first limb of its appeal. We accepted its counsel\u2019s submission that it was a condition precedent to the appellant\u2019s obligation to pay under the Deed, that the respondent would firstly sign and secondly forward a copy of the signed Deed to the appellant in exchange for payment of the first instalment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the context of contracts, the words \u201ccondition precedent\u201d have two meanings. According to Kim Lewison\u2019s <i>The Interpretation of Contracts</i> (3rd\u00a0Ed, 2004) at para\u00a015.02:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A condition precedent is a condition which must be fulfilled before any binding contract is concluded at all. The expression is also used to describe a condition which does not prevent the existence of a binding contract, but which suspends performance of it until fulfilment of the condition.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Clause\u00a01(a) of the Deed provided that the first instalment of US$250,000 would be paid \u201cupon the signing of this agreement\u201d. This meant that signing of the agreement was a condition precedent to the appellant\u2019s obligation to pay the first instalment, under the second meaning referred to in [22] above.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As the respondent failed to fulfil the condition precedent by furnishing a copy of the signed Deed to the appellant, the latter\u2019s obligation to pay the settlement sum did not arise. The non-production of the Deed was a valid defence as the appellant did not waive its right to be given a copy, judging by its repeated requests to the respondent\u2019s solicitors for the document, notwithstanding its payment of the first and second instalments. It was perfectly entitled to withhold payment of the third and final payment of US$25,000. Indeed, we had grave doubts that the respondent signed the Deed at all. It was admitted by counsel for the respondent that the Deed was not in the respondent\u2019s list of documents filed for the trial and he could not offer any explanation for the omission. As a half-hearted justification, he pointed out that the appellant did not in any event ask for discovery of the document in the court below. We noted that the Deed was also not produced before us.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Yim for the appellant had also referred the court to an undated internal note of Johnson which his clients had obtained in the process of discovery from the respondent. The following are extracts from that note:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Suggested plan of attack</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">After the next $50,000 has been transferred start new action threatening to take legal action in Singapore</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Fly to India and speak to Reliance directly</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Contact all trade centers and blacklist him</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">He thinks my Achilles heel is the taxation but I don't think so</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Possible renege on excepting [<i>sic</i>] final payment from Lim</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Target getting another $250,000 of him.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The note clearly revealed the respondent\u2019s intentions to renege on the Deed. Counsel also referred to extracts from the cross-examination at the trial of Johnson on the above note.</span><a id=\"_ftnref1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn1\" name=\"_ftnref1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[1]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">He submitted that it showed that Johnson was evasive. The appellant surmised that the respondent withheld a copy of the signed Deed (if indeed it was signed by the respondent) as part of the latter\u2019s strategy to frustrate the appellant\u2019s payment of the final instalment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would also be appropriate at this juncture to address the following submission in the Appellant\u2019s Case (at p\u00a050):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It was an express and/or implied term of the Deed, alternatively, the [respondent] had made a collateral warranty, that the signed Deed would be given to the [appellant] upon payment by the [appellant] of the first US$250,000.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At law, a term may be implied into a contract to give effect to the presumed intention of the contracting parties. That intention may be gathered from the express words of the contract and the facts and circumstances surrounding it. <i>Chitty on Contracts</i> (29th\u00a0Ed, 2004) vol\u00a01 at para\u00a013-004 states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 The court will be prepared to imply a term if there arises from the language of the contract itself, and the circumstances under which it is entered into, an inference that the parties must have intended the stipulation in question. An implication of this nature may be made in two situations: first, where it is necessary to give business efficacy to the contract, and secondly, where the term implied represents the obvious, but unexpressed, intention of the parties. \u2026 Both, however, depend on the presumed intention of the parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The tests were reaffirmed by our courts recently in <i>Hiap Hong &amp; Co Pte Ltd v Hong Huat Development Co (Pte) Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] 2 SLR 458</nobr> and <i>Tan Chin Seng v Raffles Town Club Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2003] 3 SLR 307</nobr>. The first or \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d test was laid down by Bowen\u00a0LJ in <i>The Moorcock</i> (1889) 14\u00a0PD 64 at 68 whilst the second or \u201cofficious bystander\u201d test was propounded by MacKinnon\u00a0LJ in <i>Shirlaw v Southern Foundries (1926), Limited</i> <nobr>[1939] 2 KB 206</nobr>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Chitty on Contracts</i> went on to add (at para 13-009):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A term ought not to be implied unless it is in all the circumstances equitable and reasonable. But this does not mean that a term will be implied merely because in all the circumstances it would be reasonable to do so or because it would improve the contract or make its carrying out more convenient. \u201cThe touchstone is always <i>necessity</i> and not merely <i>reasonableness.</i>\u201d\u2026 A term will not be implied if it would be inconsistent with the express wording of the contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the facts of this case again, we noted that the parties arrived at a binding agreement during a meeting at the Perth office of the respondent\u2019s solicitors. The parties also agreed that a formal deed of settlement would be drafted to reflect the agreement. One may well ask, why was there a need for a document if a verbal agreement had already been reached? Presumably (and logically), it was to have written proof of such a settlement. Hence, it was further agreed that the parties would sign the Deed in counterparts, for one party to ensure that the other party had signed. It was therefore reasonable and necessary to imply a term (be it under the \u201cbusiness efficacy\u201d test or the \u201cofficious bystander\u201d test) that the Deed, signed by the respondent, would be forwarded to the appellant before the appellant was required to make any payment under the Deed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Our view was reinforced by Stokes\u2019 fax to Lim of 7\u00a0February 2002 of which para\u00a03 stated:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In accordance with your telephone discussion with James Johnson and myself of this afternoon, <i>it is agreed that a signed copy of the Deed of Release will be provided to you by our Singapore Agents in exchange for your bank cheque in the sum of US$250,000</i> made payable to the Mohan Singh trust account. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although not specifically phrased, the appellant raised accord and satisfaction in the following paragraphs of its Defence:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In pursuance of the Deed of Settlement and Release, the Defendants made payments of US$250,000 on 8<sup>th</sup> February 2002 and US$50,000 on 31<sup>st</sup> May 2002;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 31<sup>st</sup> July 2002, the Defendants purchased a bank draft for US$25,000 being the final payment to the Defendants under the Deed of Settlement and Release. However, the Plaintiffs had refused to accept payment and attempted to repudiate the said Deed</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the premises, by reason of the Deed of Settlement and Release, there has been satisfaction and discharge of the Plaintiffs\u2019 alleged cause/s of actions.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent relied on the definition of accord and satisfaction from <i>Chitty on Contracts</i> (28th\u00a0Ed, 1999) at para\u00a023-012, for its submission that the appellant could not rely on that plea as a defence, since the appellant had failed to pay the last instalment:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Accord and satisfaction is the purchase of a release from an obligation whether arising under contract or tort by means of any valuable consideration, not being the actual performance of the obligation itself.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, when Johnson was cross-examined in the court below</span><a id=\"_ftnref2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftn2\" name=\"_ftnref2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[2]</span></span></span></span></a> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">he admitted that the respondent had decided, on or about 26\u00a0June 2002, not to be bound by the Deed. It did not therefore lie in the respondent\u2019s mouth to say there was no accord and satisfaction due to non-payment of the final instalment, when it itself had decided to renege on the Deed before the final instalment was due on 31\u00a0July 2002</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Should the amendment to the Reply have been allowed?</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although we decided in the appellant\u2019s favour on the first issue, we will, for completeness, address the second limb of its appeal. Had it been necessary to do so to determine the outcome of the appeal, we would have reversed the order made below for the respondent to amend its Reply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant mounted two arguments in relation to its objection to the amended Reply. First, the application was made at a late stage of the proceedings. Second, the amendment raised a new ground of claim which was inconsistent with that pleaded in the Statement of Claim and which would not be allowed under O\u00a018 r\u00a010(1) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05) (\u201cthe Rules\u201d). Order\u00a018 r\u00a010(1) reads:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A party shall not in any pleading make an allegation of fact, or raise any new ground or claim, inconsistent with a previous pleading of his.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The appellant cited various English authorities to support its first objection (<i>Williamson v London and North Western Railway Company</i> (1879) 12\u00a0Ch\u00a0D 787; <i>Kingston v Corker</i> (1892) 29\u00a0LR\u00a0Ir 364; <i>Herbert v Vaughan</i> [1972] 3\u00a0All\u00a0ER 122).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is not in dispute that under O\u00a020 r\u00a05 of the Rules, a court has the discretion to grant leave to amend a pleading at any stage of the proceedings. This could be before or during the trial, or even after judgment or on appeal. Delay <i>per se</i> therefore does not automatically prevent the application from succeeding, unless it will result in an injustice to the other party, which cannot be compensated by an appropriate order for costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this case, however, the respondent applied to amend its Reply on 5\u00a0January 2004, almost eight months after the original Reply was filed on 9\u00a0May 2003. The amended para\u00a04 of the Reply states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The plaintiffs deny that there had been satisfaction and discharge by reason of the Deed of Settlement and Release <i>in view of the matters pleaded in paragraphs\u00a016 to 21 of the statement of claim and in particular for the reason that the said Deed is ineffective, clause\u00a07 of the Deed providing that the agreement is not effective until all funds have been received into the plaintiffs' solicitors' bank account and confirmation of that receipt has been provided by the plaintiffs\u2019 solicitors. All funds payable under the Deed has not been received into the plaintiffs\u2019 solicitors\u2019 bank account.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(The italicised words reflect the amendment.)</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It was difficult to find any reason that could justify the delay in the respondent\u2019s application. The amendment did not arise out of any new facts or circumstances which came to the attention of the respondent only at a late stage of the proceedings. The consequence of the amendment was that the appellant became aware of the respondent\u2019s new stand, that the Deed was unenforceable due to non-payment of the final instalment, only on the first day of trial. Arguably, this prejudiced the appellant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It bears remembering that the function of a reply is to allow the plaintiff to raise facts in answer to the defendant\u2019s case. In particular, it will be necessary to file a reply if the defendant raises a new issue for the first time in the defence. As the function of a reply is limited to answering matters raised in the defence, it follows that the reply should not be used as an avenue to introduce new causes of action which are not raised in the statement of claim. If a plaintiff wishes to raise an additional and inconsistent claim in the alternative after the statement of claim has been filed, the proper approach should be to apply to amend the statement of claim, rather than slip it in by way of the reply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the original Statement of Claim, the respondent pleaded that the Deed was unenforceable as it was vitiated by the appellant\u2019s misrepresentations. The appellant came to court prepared to meet that case (in para\u00a021 of the Statement of Claim). In the Amended Reply, however, the respondent pleaded that the Deed was ineffective because the appellant failed to pay the final instalment, a position which was diametrically opposite to its original stand. It was an inconsistent plea which should have been made in the alternative in the Statement of Claim. As was said by G\u00a0P\u00a0Selvam\u00a0J in <i>Nirumalan K Pillay v A Balakrishnan</i> <nobr>[1997] 1 SLR 322</nobr> at [10], a case cited by the appellant:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The reply serves the function of answering points raised in the defence so that the defendant is given notice of matters which are intended to defeat a defence or explain a matter raised in the defence in a way favourable to the plaintiffs. \u2026 Further, because the function of a reply is to answer matters raised in the defence, its contents must relate to matters raised in the defence. What is the same thing, the plaintiffs may not supplement [their] statement of claim by including in [their] reply matters which ought to have been included in the statement of claim. In this respect, a reply is analogous to re-examination of a witness which should be confined to matters touched on in cross-examination. Fresh evidence adding to or re-affirming evidence-in-chief is not permitted in re-examination.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 An appellate court will normally not interfere with a lower court\u2019s discretion to grant or refuse an amendment unless that court has exercised that discretion wrongly (see <i>Wright Norman v Overseas-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd</i> <nobr>[1994] 1 SLR 513</nobr>). However, the respondent in this case succeeded on its claim below based purely on its Amended Reply, there being no finding on the allegation of misrepresentation. The amendment was made without any explanation for the lateness and it prejudiced the appellant. It should not have been allowed. Consequently, the appellant would also have succeeded on the second limb of its appeal, had it been necessary for us to make that ruling.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Appeal allowed.</span></p>\n\n<div><br clear=\"all\"/>\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<div id=\"ftn1\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn1\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref1\" name=\"_ftn1\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[1]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Verbatim notes pp\u00a064\u201367</span></p>\n</div>\n\n<div id=\"ftn2\">\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"_ftn2\" title=\"\" href=\"#_ftnref2\" name=\"_ftn2\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><span class=\"MsoFootnoteReference\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[2]</span></span></span></span></a><span lang=\"EN-GB\">See verbatim notes p\u00a047</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n"]
